HEADLINE: Colleges to Offer Their Ideas In Battle to Overhaul CUNY

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
In the next two weeks, the presidents of the City University's 17 undergraduate colleges are to deliver to Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds their plans for eliminating or consolidating some programs and expanding others. The goal, the Chancellor says, is to save millions of dollars and insure CUNY's survival as the nation's largest urban university in a time of economic hardship.
But accomplishing those changes depends in part on the fragile relationship between Ms. Reynolds and the faculty of these institutions. Since she announced her proposal to streamline the system last December, she has faced a barrage of criticism from restive faculty members who view her as high-handed and abusive. She, in turn, appears to regard the faculty as jealously territorial and stubborn. 
 Her recommendation to dismiss the president of the College of Staten Island, which the system's 17-member Board of Trustees supported on Monday, brought those tensions to the forefront. The dismissed college president, Edmond L. Volpe, has been a vocal opponent of the Chancellor's plans. On Friday, Karen Kaplowitz, chairman of the Faculty Senate of John Jay College of Criminal Justice, spoke of the possibility of "civil war at the university."
Since the fall term began, faculty groups at CUNY's various campuses have churned out a blizzard of resolutions alternately challenging, condemning and sometimes grudgingly accepting the Chancellor's efforts to streamline the curriculum.
She has responded by meeting with the faculty and giving the administrations of the colleges responsibility for recommending changes.
"Maybe there wasn't enough consultation initially," said James P. Murphy, chairman of CUNY's board of trustees, "but Ann Reynolds is doing a courageous job and has the full support of the trustees."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who appoints a majority of the trustees, also remains a supporter, arguing that change will be difficult but necessary. In the last four years the State Legislature and City Council have eliminated more than $200 million, or 20 percent, from CUNY's $1.1 billion annual budget. Ms. Reynolds is asking for $19 million back this year.
Furthermore, she points out, while revenues decline, the student body continues to grow and change, from 208,000 today to a projected quarter million by the year 2000. Once the system mainly enrolled white students of European ancestry; today, the university reflects the changing city -- about 40 percent of the current entering students are black or Hispanic and trace their ancestry to the Caribbean. Two-thirds of the students are from minority groups, with blacks making up 30.5 percent of the student body, Hispanic students 21 percent, and Asians 11.4 percent.
 
Shifting Money
 A principal objective of Ms. Reynolds's proposals has been to shift money from academic programs with low enrollment -- like physics and French -- to those overflowing with students, particularly in the seven community colleges.
"We have 8,700 applicants in the field of nursing and fewer than 2,000 openings for them," Ms. Reynolds said. "We also have students backlogged in psychology, biology and chemistry, and we have to do something about that."
Although the colleges have not yet submitted their plans, these are among the specific proposals under discussion:
*Students in international business at Baruch College could study modern languages at Hunter College, perhaps through video and telephone hookups.
*Theater majors at Brooklyn College could take courses in lighting and stage design at the New York City Technical College in Brooklyn, and students at the latter could study theater at Brooklyn College.
*The French major at City College would be dropped, and language instruction would be available from faculty at Lehman College and perhaps Hunter College.
Chancellor Reynolds said that while these changes might seem minor, their cumulative effect on the university would be great. "We are phasing out 23 programs at Baruch College alone," she said.
"The total may come to 46 phaseouts," she said. "And there will be 45 programs under similar review, 22 programs for further review and 61 programs under consideration for strengthening."
Once the Chancellor approves the plans, CUNY presidents will have until next May to work out ways to put them in place. After those plans are accepted by the Chancellor, they must be approved by the university's board of trustees.
Next month, Ms. Reynolds will make an appeal in Albany for more money for the system. She has an opponent in State Senator John J. Marchi of Staten Island, a longtime leader of the Republican majority, who supports Mr. Volpe. He said on Friday that continued strife at the university could permit the Legislature "to seize on this as an opportunity to reexamine the budget."
The dispute over the reorganization plans began last December when Dr. Reynolds, a veteran of academic wars at the California State University system, who took office in 1990, announced a proposal that would have eliminated about 200 baccalaureate- and associate-degree programs at individual colleges, saying they were duplicative or had small enrollments.
Opposition throughout the CUNY system led the Chancellor to offer a scaled-back plan to the trustees in June in which she called for a periodic review of academic programs. But this scaled-back plan, though approved by the trustees, drew vigorous opposition when an internal memo came to light in July revealing Dr. Reynolds' intention to divide up $15 million in discretionary funds among only those campuses that had pursued her original plan. The faculty voted to condemn this "pattern of duplicity."
"This is a case of rewarding your friends and punishing your enemies," Kenneth Sherrill, a political science professor from Hunter, said at the time.
 
Faculty Dissent
 The faculties of five of the nine senior colleges began the fall term with votes expressing displeasure with Dr. Reynolds's leadership. Their message was clear: changes in curriculum should be initiated by the faculty, not dictated from above, as in the business world.
The Chancellor held a series of meetings to quell the dissent, culminating with a session on Sept. 24 with the faculty governance committee, which represents the faculty leaders from all the colleges. Professor Robert Picken, the chairman of the group, reported to Ms. Reynolds that she had taken "one necessary step towards restoration of our confidence in the academic administration of the University."
Today, Ms. Reynolds insists that she never intended to use the $15 million discretionary fund to reward colleges that went along with her plans, but rather "to recognize people who had worked their hearts out."
"City College had attacked me more than anyone," she continued, "but they came up with a dazzling set of academic ideas and therefore were in line for funding some programs that would be part of their budget request for 1994-95."
One longtime CUNY observer summed up Ms. Reynolds predicament this way: "She's brilliant. She's forceful. But when you set out to change things, as she has, you must make sure that the people who are involved understand your intentions. If you don't, they'll mount the barricades."

HEADLINE: Deficit Falls for Year

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
The Government announced last week that its budget deficit tumbled to $254.9 billion in the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30. The budget gap was $26.1 billion less than the Administration had estimated in August and $67 billion less than the estimate in the April budget. In the 1992 fiscal year, the budget deficit was a record $290 billion. The narrower gap in the latest year mainly reflected falling interest rates and the failure of Congress to pass legislation that would have allowed the Resolution Trust Corporation to close its allotment of failed savings institutions.

HEADLINE: THE 1993 CAMPAIGN: THE RACE FOR MAYOR;
The Candidates on the Issues: In Their Own Words

 BODY:
In the months in which Mayor David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani have crisscrossed the city seeking support for their electoral bids, countless words have been uttered on issues ranging from the safety of the city to the temperament of each other's opponent. Here are some of the more memorable comments.
 
DINKINS
 
Crime
We've hired 9,000 cops since I've been Mayor, for a net of 5,700, pretty close to 6,000 and more coming. And crime is down in the seven major F.B.I. index categories for the first time in 36 years, and for more than two consecutive years. Down in the major areas. Giuliani says, well, crime is not really down, they're just not arresting as many people. Well, you know, you've got less crime, there are fewer things for which people ought to be arrested, that makes sense. nd moreover, among the categories is homicide. Where do you think they are hiding the bodies? He says they are not down, so they are hiding the bodies somewhere, I guess. Nonsense, crime is down.
 Speech, Bethel A.M.E. Church, Harlem, Oct. 10
 
Race
Whether we like it or not, race is the silent visitor. Race should never be a subject of political debate. But race relations, if our city is to reign pre-eminent, must be spoken about -- without fear, and without rancor. Let me say, as clearly as I can, that I believe race relations can be an appropriate issue for a political campaign. To pretend that people in our city don't discuss it is silly. But our politicians must discuss it as sensibly as most of our people do -- in their daily lives, and in their daily dealings, in the most diverse city in the world. If you want to play the race card, then you should deal the whole deck. Lay out your plan on how to improve race relations in our city.
Race relations can be an appropriate issue ... but only if you want to craft solutions, and not catalogue complaints. If we use the issue appropriately, we can transform it from the cancer of our society into the cure.
 Speech at fund-raising event, Oct. 14
 
Police
Rudolph Giuliani ... opposes laws that would require New York City police officers to live in our city. But [suburban] legislators, you see, they like the fact that they and their constituencies are safer, because our cops live around the corner from them with money we pay for, with salaries we pay. Rudolph Giuliani thinks that's OK.
 Bethel A.M.E. Church, Harlem, Oct. 10
 
Jobs
We have not only the vision, but the plan for new jobs in our city. And let me tell you: those who say we should give up, or give in, or turn back are talking about one job -- in City Hall... I'm talking about creating 110,000 jobs all across the city... It's time for people to decide who has the experience, the vision, and the values to make this $32 billion corporation work for all New Yorkers.
 Policy speech, Sept. 21
 
Schools
The Board of Education is responsible to no one. Not to the Mayor and certainly not to you... I envision a system in which decisions are made not by a central board which couldn't recognize and asbestos cloud literally hanging over its head, but by parents and teachers and principals in a new set of school councils.
 Policy speech, Sept. 13
 
Neighborhoods
Those who bemoan the death of the old neighborhood ... reject the economics of upward mobility for all New Yorkers. They fail to understand, or refuse to understand, that the old neighborhood is alive and well in our city, that little has changed in our New York neighborhoods except the faces, the names, and the languages spoken. The same decent values of hard work and accomplishment and service to city and nation still exist... A Republican candidate who doesn't understand what our neighborhoods were about yesterday or what they are about today has little chance of understanding what they will be about tomorrow.
 Policy Speech, Sept. 13
 
Social Services
My friends, this election is much more than a choice among candidates. It's a test of our values... He wants to evict the homeless on the 91st day. We believe that there is no deadline on a city's decency. He wants to sell off public hospitals to the highest bidder, even if millions of working people have to go without health care. We believe that no one should go without health care, and that principle is not for sale.
 Speech to Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Oct. 28
 
About the Other Guy
I think it's necessary for you and the rest of the media to realize that Rudolph Giuliani has been under the candidate protection program. For the past four years, he's done nothing, absolutely nothing! Rudolph Giuliani says I want to be dictator. But when you, sir, and others challenge him on questions like that, and his ridiculous responses are put forth, then run your poll and see what the people think!
 Speech to Crains New York Business/New York Chamber of Commerce Forum, July 15
 
GIULIANI
 
CRIME
 "Has Mayor Dinkins worried about your concerns? And has he worried about the damage that he is doing by failing to arrest street-level drug dealers? He looks at statistics and he thinks that the city is safe. Well, get out of your limousine and walk the streets of this city!
We are not going to stand by while we watch the drug dealers take over our communities more and more each year. We don't have miracles. We don't have a magic wand that we can wave and all of a sudden the drug problem is gone. But we aren't going to surrender to the drug dealers the way this administration has by failing to arrest the drug dealers.
 Town Hall meeting in Jackson Heights, Oct. 11
 
RACE
"The question is that I'm guilty, that I'm guilty of raising the race issue by putting on two commercials that point out the way in which David Dinkins is stirring the issue... And Dinkins didn't do it because Dinkins didn't call me a fascist. Instead he stood there with three or four ministers who had just endorsed him for mayor, who had sat inside City Hall with him... planning the endorsement... They said that my supporters were fascist. They then went on to elaborate that I was surrounded with people like Hitler, Mussolini and Franco... I don't regard associations of my people that support me as fascists as a light matter... So excuse me if I have the sense that because they can't do the Mafia thing on me because it would be ludicrous, because I put two to three hundred of them in prison, they do the fascist thing on me.
 Breakfast meeting with Upper West Side Groups, Oct. 7
 
Police
We will begin the process that I will begin to unfold in the three or four years that I will be Mayor of giving the police a clear understanding of why they are there. They are there to prevent crime. When they take reasonable steps, the Mayor of New York will support them and that will create a less brutal, more honest and less corrupt police department. Because the thing that creates corruption more than anything else is the devastated morale in an organization. Corruption is the tone you set at the top.
 Policy Speech, Sept. 9
 
JOBS
Once, New York City was the undisputed business capital of the nation and the world. The sound of our commerce circled the globe. But if you listen closely today, what you hear is an ominous silence. In the last four years, the city has lost nearly 400,000 jobs... I'm not listening to anybody who tells me that we have no control over the national economy, and, therefore, no control of the nation economy's impact on the city... It really comes down to one word, and a powerful word at that. The word is management.
 Policy speech, Aug. 10
 
SCHOOLS
I can't imagine that any parents in the city are resting any easier today knowing that Norman Steisel, the same person who seemed not to know what he was doing in handling Lockheed, is now in charge of asbestos removal in the schools. And with this cloud hanging over Norman Steisel's head I would imagine the Mayor is going to have to remove him for a time during the asbestos removal and put someone else there until these questions are cleared up.
 Curtis and Lisa Sliwa Show, WABC-Radio, Aug. 19
 
NEIGHBORHOODS
New York City is becoming or already is the dirtiest city in America. I hear it over and over and over again... How can your city be so dirty. I don't pretend it isn't true, though the current administration pretends it isn't true. I say, lets clean up New York City instead of making stupid political excuses. Let's clean our city up!
 Policy speech, Sept. 9
 
Social Services
New York City stands alone in the expansiveness of its homeless policies. Were these policies effective the city's efforts could be applauded, but essentially they have proved to be useless and self defeating. In short the policies are bankrupt and are in need of major rethinking and overhaul.
 Position paper, Sept. 17
 
Obout the Other Guy
Nobody is suggesting that he is responsible for the asbestos in the schools. Would we suggest that David Dinkins is responsible for anything? Nobody is suggesting that he is responsible for it. Yes, it started under Ed Koch. But, hey, you've been Mayor for three and a half years, David! Do you think you could have found out about it? In less than three and a half years do you think you could have appointed somebody to the School Construction Authority? Do you think could have found out about the Korean boycott in less than six months? Or how come you were the only person in this city that didn't know that a riot was going on for four days? Give us a break!
 Town Hall meeting in Washington Heights, Oct. 27

HEADLINE: U.S. Authorizes Wisconsin Curb On Aid to Poor

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today gave Wisconsin permission to impose a two-year limit on welfare benefits for indigent families with children, inaugurating what could become the most radical experiment in the welfare program's history.
Advocates for welfare recipients have denounced the plan, to be tried in two counties, as a Draconian measure, and its constitutionality is certain to be challenged in Federal court. 
 Even if a court upholds the plan in theory, many provisions, outlined in 20 pages of Federal fine print, remain subject to conflicting interpretations, and it is unclear how strictly the provisions would be applied.
 
Violation of Normal Policy
 Since the Wisconsin plan violates normal Federal policy, the state had to seek waivers from two Federal departments, Health and Human Services, which oversees the welfare program, and Agriculture, which oversees food stamps.
The decision to let the experiment proceed was a politically delicate one that comes as the Administration is laying its own plans to revamp the welfare system nationwide.
President Clinton has done much to promote the idea of limiting the time a person can receive welfare payments, making it an important part of his campaign last year. "I want to erase the stigma of welfare for good by restoring a simple, dignified principle," Mr. Clinton declared. "No one who can work can stay on welfare forever." But his aides have envisioned a plan much richer in social services and protections than the one put forward in Wisconsin.
The concept of time limits seems to have gained a momentum of its own, and if the President had barred the Wisconsin plan he risked being accused of backsliding.
Instead, Administration officials softened some of the original Wisconsin provisions, refusing, for example, to let the state withdraw medical assistance after the time limit ends.
In celebrating the decision to proceed with a modified plan, Gov. Tommy Thompson, a Republican, contended that the change was in keeping with his state's long history of innovation in social policy.
But Mr. Thompson also acknowledged that "ours is different" from the approach the Administration seems to favor. "They gave us a waiver to try something revolutionary," he said, "and I want to compliment them."
 
Differing Methods
 The time-limit plans that most Administration officials seem to favor would offer some sort of community service option for people who had not found jobs within two years, allowing families to continue to receive benefits. The Wisconsin plan simply ends cash assistance after two years.
"They were looking for a little more protection," Governor Thompson said. "We said, 'No, we want this to be a mirror example of what you do in the marketplace,' " where there are no guarantees of jobs.
Advocates for the poor predicted an increase in homelessness and other hardships. "Children will be hurt by the Wisconsin waiver," said Cliff Johnson, director of programs and policy for the Children's Defense Fund. "It violates the most basic standards of fairness and decency. Parents who can work, should work but children shouldn't be punished when parents can't find jobs."
 
Starting in 1995
 The Wisconsin plan passed both the state's Democratic-controlled Assembly and its Republican-controlled Senate with strong support.
Wisconsin has a history of being on the cutting edge of social program expansion. But in recent years Governor Thompson has been leading something of a counterrevolution, trying to constrict aid and impose new conditions on those who get it.
Under the plan, which is scheduled to begin in January 1995, welfare parents will be allowed to collect cash benefits for two years. After that, they will be allowed to receive food stamps, medical assistance and, in some cases, vouchers to defray some housing costs. The vouchers would be worth less than the welfare grant.
During the first two years, welfare and food stamp payments would in cash, and families would be required to work them off at the minimum wage.
A mother with two children, for instance, could receive up to $729 a month, $517 in welfare payments and $212 from the food stamp program. In return, she would be required to work 172 hours a month, or about 40 hours a week, in a community work program.
During the first year, a mother could satisfy the work requirements by spending the same amount of time in a training program.
But even with the Federal permission granted, it remains unclear how the program will work in practice. One uncertainty is how lenient the state will be in exempting mothers with physical and emotional disabilities; another is exemptions for families who have made good-faith efforts to find jobs but have not succeeded.
Gerald Whitburn, Wisconsin's Secretary of Health and Human Services, said such exemptions would be considered only if a county's entire economy had soured. "As long as there's health in the economy, then the benefits would end," he said.
Melissa Skolfield, a Deputy Assistant Secretary at the Federal Department of Health and Human Services, sharply disagreed, saying: "I don't think that's right. What we're talking about is an individual exemption. It is not tied in any way to the county's economic conditions."
It is also unclear what the waiver might portend for the Administration's welfare plans. The President has said he will approve experiments, even if he disagrees with them, and the Wisconsin approval may just be an example. Or it could indicate the beginnings of a shift in the political debate, which might lead to a broader application of similar plans.
 
Reaction in Congress
 Representative Harold E. Ford, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Ways and Means subcommittee that will take up the Administration's welfare proposals when they are announced, said that he believed the plan had enough protections for the poor to proceed as a small experiment but that he would take a dim view of efforts to do the same thing nationwide.
"Working off your welfare grant in make-work jobs, that's not something I look favorably upon," he said.

HEADLINE: No Longer a Pariah, Peru Is Being Recast As Business Magnet

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
Once crippled by guerrilla violence that left more than 25,000 dead and $23 billion in losses and considered by many to be ungovernable, Peru these days is drawing a rash of investors ranging from the United States to South Korea who are looking for big returns.
Foreign executives -- many of whom admit they are taking high risks -- are doing what as recently as mid-1992 was considered unthinkable for the profit-minded -- pouring hundreds of millions of dollars into one of the poorest and most chaotic countries in the third world, buying mines and television stations, fishing companies and airlines.
 
Business as the Vanguard
 Though the investments are still small by world standards, they are enormous by Peruvian standards. They are also the strongest sign yet that Peru may be on its way back from what many experts had predicted 18 months ago would be virtual collapse from rampant guerrilla violence. 
 Business investment is ahead of the diplomats, as it has often been in developing economies, in recognizing Peru's progress. In Washington now, there are the beginnings of a consensus in the Clinton Administration that once it has assurances on human rights, it should renew the aid to Peru that was halted after President Alberto K. Fujimori seized dictatorial powers last year.
"I think that business is out in front of the issue" in recognizing what has happened in Peru, "as it certainly was in Chile, Argentina and Mexico," years ago, said Brian D. O'Neill, a senior vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank and one of its top executives in charge of Latin American operations.
In the last two years, businesses have either invested or announced plans to invest more than $2 billion. By contrast, from 1985 to 1990, the era of President Alan Garcia, there was effectively no foreign investment, a result of laws forbidding companies to take profits out of the country and of nationalization policies.
The change largely results from the economic policies of Mr. Fujimori -- policies that have made him highly popular, as was underscored Sunday, when Peruvians widely voted to support the President's new Constitution.
Business executives have applauded Mr. Fujimori's opening of the economy, his elimination of almost all regulations, control of inflation, plans to sell state companies -- and the capture of the country's most violent guerrilla leader.
Foreign executives here say Mr. Fujimori's seizure of powers -- suspending the old Constitution and dissolving Congress and the courts -- also fundamentally changed Peru's business climate for the better.
While the President is hailed by investors for turning around Peru, political opponents and many leaders in other Latin American countries remain concerned over the authoritarian rule he has set up. Under Mr. Fujimori's regimen, Congress often rubber-stamps his policies and the courts remain effectively under his control. Yet, business often prefers a stable authoritarian climate to an unstable struggling democracy, and Peru has proved no exception.
When Mr. Fujimori assumed powers outside the Constitution, he argued that he needed the authority to combat corruption, cocaine trafficking and a rebellion by the Maoist Shining Path rebel movement, which controlled large parts of the countryside and the Lima shantytowns.
Within months, the armed authorities acted to reinforce his point. In September 1992, Shining Path's founder and leader, Abimael Guzman Reynoso, was captured, and businesses around the world that had been intimidated from investing in Peru because of the guerrilla activities took notice. Some lined up to invest.
"A year ago we felt there was no future in Peru," said Carlos Bolona Behr, former Economy Minister and architect of many of the Fujimori economic changes. "We were losing the war against the Shining Path and Peruvians were sending their money and children outside just waiting for the Government to fall. Now, people are talking about Peru seriously for the first time in decades."
 
Companies Respond
 And Leonard Harris, general manager of the Newmont Mining Corporation's new Andean gold mine, added: "We're moving into boom times here in Peru. The day Guzman was caught, the country was different."
Occidental Petroleum is spending more than $60 million for drilling. Nabisco has bought a Peruvian cookie and cracker maker, Field, for $10 million. Owens-Illinois purchased a Peruvian bottle maker, Vinsa, for $7 million. And the Southern Peru Copper Company, a joint venture of Asarco and Phelps Dodge, has announced plans to invest $300 million over the next five years in mining development. The Mexican network Televisa bought a controlling interest in Channel 4 of Lima. Peru is also becoming attractive to auto makers.
Big names have been attracted to the privatization program. Aeromexico paid $35 million for Aeroperu. Concerns including Phelps Dodge, Mitsubishi, Mitsui and Daewoo have lined up to bid on the privatization of the two other state mining enterprises. A.T.& T, GTE and Southwestern Bell say they will bid for Peru's two phone companies, to be sold early next year.
Newmont Mining, together with its French and Peruvian partners, opened the Yanacocha gold mine in August. It is now producing $1 million in gold bullion a week, and in six months, the expect to recoup their entire $37 million investment. The rest will be pure profit.
But the wave of investment, and the euphoria, raise difficult issues for Peru: Is this just another case of industrialists plundering the riches of a poor country? Is foreign investment the engine that will lift Peru out of years of recession and industrial decline? And most important, will it create jobs and an economic prosperity that trickles down to millions living in devastating poverty?
Economists say Peru is so depressed that there is no way foreign investment, at current levels, can quickly turn it around. The modernizing of industry and a narrowing of the gap between rich and poor would take decades, as it has taken Peru decades to reach its current state. But there seem few options for a country that is poor and deeply in debt.
As for lifting millions out of poverty, no one is expecting that quickly, either. Throughout Latin America, where governments have moved to open economies to lure foreign investors, officials are learning that benefits do not quickly trickle down. They find themselves under pressure to persuade the poorest to be patient.
In fact, many politicians seem relieved that with Communism gone as a contending economic philosophy, there has not so far emerged a credible alternative in Latin America to a policy of open markets.
In Peru, as elsewhere, foreign investment, when coupled with the sale of state-owned companies, removes the Government from excessive control over the economy, making it less susceptible to political manipulation that could kindle runaway inflation.
Foreign money also reinforces the confidence of local investors, leading, officials hope, to the return of billions that left the country in the 1980's. And profitable foreign companies pay taxes, providing revenue that can be used for salaries or social programs.
For Peru, the investment influx will not mean a windfall in new jobs, mainly because these companies tend to employ modern manufacturing and management tactics that require far fewer workers than before.
Yet, there is an unmistakable boost to local economies, particularly in generating secondary jobs that service the new companies. For example, Newmont Mining employed several hundred local workers to build the road to the Yanacocha mine, though the work near Cajamarca, a regional center, was only for a few months.
The wave of investment has spilled over to the tiny Lima Stock Exchange, which has risen more than 200 percent over the last two years. Most of that money is coming from foreigners.
Last year, the return on capital was 138 percent. In 1993 so far, the return is up 80 percent. "Our stocks used to be worth less than the paper they were printed on," said Jose Carlos Luque Otero, president of the exchange. "The change is a symptom of reactivation in the country, that things are getting better."
The notion of Peru as an emerging market follows the experience of other Latin American countries as "hot markets." Among these, Argentina, Chile, Mexico and Brazil have at various times seen big run-ups in the values of their companies. Some of those markets, at this point, are not considered bargains.
 
Changes in Inflation and Debt
 Mr. Fujimori, on taking office in 1990, inherited from the Garcia Government a geometrically increasing inflation rate, bank reserves of $100 million, and pariah status among international lenders for nationalizing or trying to nationalize foreign businesses and stopping debt payments.
The new President eliminated subsidies, froze wages, began making debt payments and opened negotiations with foreign investors to settle disputes. Today, Peru has inflation of about 3 percent a month and bank reserves of $2.6 billion. Some businessmen say its economy is the most liberalized in Latin America.
"We can now take oil out of the ground and do with it what we want instead of having to sell it to the Government oil company and below market prices," said Roger C. Alderson, general manager of the Peruvian subsidiary of Great Western Resources, an independent oil company in Houston. "Peru is one of the great unexplored areas on earth for oil, both onshore and offshore."
But not every business story is like that, or like Newmont Mining's success. Certainly, there are high risks in coming to a troubled country.
Ask Leslie Hong, president of Corsair Inc. of Bellevue, Wash., which leased five Boeing 727-100's to a start-up airline, Americana, that earlier this year went bankrupt. For more than nine months, a Peruvian court has frozen the assets, and four of the planes sit at Jorge Chavez Airport near Lima. Meanwhile, the airline continues to fly the fifth, and, according to Mr. Hong, cannibalizes parts from the four other 727's.
Mr. Hong says his company has lost $10 million in Peru, and is getting nowhere in the court. He wishes he had never come here.

HEADLINE: IN SHIFT, U.S. PLANS TO LIMIT PENALTIES TO RULERS IN HAITI

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Ranking Administration officials said today that because a strengthened United Nations embargo on Haiti might do more harm than good, they were framing a narrower plan to impose new penalties on those who have opposed democratic rule there, rather than on Haitians in general.
At some later date, one official said, the United States might well be willing to support the sweeping sanctions urged by France and by the exiled Haitian President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. But first, the official said, "we would like to try a somewhat less blunt instrument." 
 So calls went out over the weekend to a number of countries -- France, Switzerland, the Dominican Republic, Britain and some others -- urging them to follow the American lead in freezing the assets and revoking the visas of the 40 or so principal figures in the resistance to Father Aristide's return to power. At the top of the list are Gen. Raoul Cedras, the army commander, and Col. Joseph Michel Francois, the chief of police in Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital.
 
U.N. Plans Similar Approach
 A resolution to the same effect is being drafted at the United Nations. It is not clear yet how much support it will command, nor has the Administration received answers to its appeals to individual countries. A potential weakness in the American plan is the traditional reluctance of Switzerland to freeze assets in its banks.
A State Department planner said: "We want the people running the show to suffer, not those who live at the bottom of the heap already. They have bank accounts all over, and houses, too, and they like to fly off for elaborate vacations. Maybe this will give them second thoughts without punishing the average Haitian."
Since it became clear last week that the Saturday deadline set in a United Nations-sponsored agreement for Father Aristide's return would not be met, a number of academic and diplomatic experts have suggested that the United States has only two choices: sending in the Marines or leaving the problem to the Haitians to resolve on their own.
 
Delay and Embarrassment
 But the Administration, top officials insist, sees no real appeal in either alternative. President Clinton's intention, they say, is to keep pushing, through sanctions and other pressure tactics, for adherence to the agreement that was signed on Governors Island in New York harbor in July.
Inevitably, that means delay and embarrassment for Mr. Clinton. Having lined up firmly behind Father Aristide, the President must watch while anti-Aristide forces dance in the streets of Port-au-Prince, celebrating what they call their victory over Washington and calling for fresh elections. Father Aristide remains in Washington.
The Administration is also loath to expand sanctions already voted by the United Nations, which affect weapons, munitions and fuel.
In practical terms, total sanctions against Haiti would be simple. Some products could flow across the border with the Dominican Republic, but because the two countries occupy the island of Hispanola, shutting off ports and airports would shut off almost all shipments. In addition, there is near-universal condemnation of the Haitian military's actions among other nations.
 
The Lesson of Rhodesia
 When sanctions were imposed in the 1970's against Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe, they were weakened by the willingness of a number of countries to permit their violation, either implicitly or explicitly, and by the difficulty of closing the nation's borders.
Many American specialists say widespread broad-based sanctions against Haiti will inevitably worsen the lot of the Haitian masses, many of whom already live in wretched circumstances. That, in turn, might restart the mass emigration in leaky boats that caused so much trouble in the past and prompted, to a considerable degree, the negotiations at Governors Island.
In addition, as one State Department official said, "The last thing we need this winter is pictures of hungry Haitian kids to go with pictures of shivering Bosnian kids."
The embargo on fuel could by itself create serious problems for the innocent, like disrupting the distribution of food and curtailing the production of electricity for basic public services.
Reluctant to move further down that road, the Administration seems to be engaged in a balancing act, resisting the French drive for broader sanctions, which are backed by Father Aristide and his supporters, but at the same time holding open the possibility of supporting them lest General Cedras and Colonel Francois conclude that they have won.
"The bad guys have to be convinced that we are dead serious, or they won't yield an inch in the negotiations that have got to start eventually," a White House aide said tonight.
Dante Caputo, the United Nations envoy in Port-au-Prince, is trying to restart a diplomatic effort on Wednesday, but American officials hold out relatively little hope for success until sanctions of one kind or another have begun to bite more deeply.
There are still no signs, the officials said, that General Cedras and Colonel Francois are prepared to step aside, as mandated in the Governors Island accord. Indeed, small right-wing groups argued over the weekend that because Father Aristide had not returned by the deadline, the agreement was null and void, and new elections would be needed.
As difficult as Father Aristide has sometimes been, Washington has no intention of abandoning him now, if only because that would constitute a humiliation for Mr. Clinton, who pledged during the 1992 campaign to do better in solving the Haitian problem than President Bush did.

HEADLINE: Foreigners Find New Ally in U.S. Industry

SERIES: Powerful Persuaders: A Look at Lobbying Tactics -- Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG with MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Grant Bennett leads one of the last American companies that make a tiny but essential ceramic part for computers and advanced weapons systems, and he reluctantly concluded late last year that he needed Government help to survive in the face of Japanese competition.
So Mr. Bennett and another American company asked the Commerce Department for a bit of trade protection, arguing that America's national security would suffer if the troubled industry were allowed to collapse. 
 He knew that Kyocera Inc., the Japanese company that dominates the industry, would mount a determined fight, and he fully expected to confront a covey of Washington lobbyists representing the Japanese.
But Mr. Bennett was astonished to find that it was not those lobbyists who tipped the balance in Kyocera's favor. Instead, it was a chorus of American voices. One by one, many giants of American industry lined up in support of Kyocera, including the American Semiconductor Industry Association, I.B.M. and the Aerospace Industries Association.
 
The Power of Business
 All of them had important economic ties with Japan that they wanted to protect. As a result, "we got overpowered," Mr. Bennett said ruefully. And with the Commerce Department's decision in favor of the Japanese a few weeks ago, Mr. Bennett's case stands as a stark illustration of a quiet revolution that is sweeping the world of foreign lobbying.
For generations, foreign governments and companies from South America to East Asia have hired high-powered Washington lobbyists to press their views on their friends in government. In many cases, that is still true.
But even before Ross Perot and others began turning this sort of insider lobbying into a political issue last year, foreign interests began adopting a new strategy. Just as domestic lobbyists have turned to "grass roots" campaigns that use ordinary citizens to carry a corporation's arguments to Washington, foreign governments are now busily recruiting American businesses to make their cases.
"Foreigners don't vote, so foreigners need allies," said Joseph Massey, a former United States Assistant Trade Representative for Japan and China. When lobbyists come to Washington to speak for their foreign clients, "they get a polite reception because Americans are polite," he said. But if A.T.&T. or Motorola comes, he said, "they get listened to."
Japanese companies have come to the same conclusion.
As they built factories in this country over the last decade and opened their markets a bit to some American companies, an interdependency developed. In many ways, the relationship benefits this country. Thousands of Americans now work in Japanese automobile assembly plants; American companies make more money selling products and services in Japan.
But a byproduct is that governors and members of Congress, particularly those from states with Japanese plants, flock to Tokyo's side on certain important issues. So do American businesses that have a stake in averting trade conflict. Meanwhile, the Washington lobbyists who used to twist arms on behalf of their foreign clients now quietly glean information from low-level officials and plot strategy to marshal Japan's new American allies.
Other foreign companies and governments are following suit.
The Boeing Company, for example, has become one of China's most reliable allies whenever Beijing finds itself fighting to keep its most-favored-nation trading status. Chinese airlines regularly place orders with Boeing for new aircraft worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
"You have to find American allies," said Lance Morgan, an executive at a large Washington public relations and lobbying company. Ten or 12 years ago, he said, lobbyists working for foreign interests could make a few phone calls to well-placed officials and sway an issue. But now, he said: "No back-room deals. It has become wholesale politics, not retail relationships."
 
Establishing the Ties
Industry Replaces 'Superlobbyists'
 Of all foreign nations, Japan has the largest and most influential lobbying presence in Washington. From 1988 to 1992 Japanese interests hired more than 125 law firms, economic consultants and public relations companies, according to records the Justice Department keeps on lobbyists. That is not surprising; the United States is Japan's biggest export market. As a result, Japan has more to gain, or lose, from decisions made in Washington.
Japan's lobbyists spend much of their time compiling reams of intelligence: Where are the rifts between agencies? Who are Japan's natural allies within the bureaucracy? Who on Capitol Hill is most likely to push protectionist legislation?
During President Ronald Reagan's Administration, Tokyo relied on "superlobbyists" to exploit this information. Stanton Anderson, a former State Department official; John Sears, a one-time Reagan campaign manager, and Richard J. Whalen, an aide to Mr. Reagan from 1978 to 1980, were among the well-connected former officials hired by Japanese companies.
But the character of Japan's efforts began to change in the mid-1980's, as the United States trade deficit with Japan climbed toward its record high of $56.3 billion in 1987. Many officials believe the turning point came that same year, when a furious Congress came close to imposing huge sanctions on the Toshiba Machine Corporation for selling sophisticated machine tools to the Soviet Union.
The battle seemed lost until Toshiba and its Washington representatives mobilized a group of American companies with close ties to Japan to lobby on behalf of the Japanese company. Together they blocked the penalties.
"That was a watershed," said Mr. Massey, the former trade official. The Japanese quickly learned that "their most effective source of pressure was not from their lobbyists, but from I.B.M. and the others who depended on the Toshiba components."
"They learned that when they did it themselves, first of all they were unsuccessful," he said. "Second, they embarrassed themselves and made Americans angry and scared off potential domestic allies."
 
Dropping the Big Names
 Yoshihisa Komori, Washington bureau chief of The Sankei Shimbun, a major Japanese newspaper, and author of a book on Japanese lobbying, said Japanese corporate chiefs were particularly sensitive to unflattering American news reports in the 1980's about the high-priced former officials who were working for them.
"The Japanese proclivity to resort to big names, it's over," he said. "They really got bashed for that." What is more, he added, Japanese executives have all but given up on the idea of directly influencing American government decisions. What they look for instead, he said, "are the chances to ally themselves with American political entities that have clout."
As a result, members of Congress say they rarely see lobbyists representing Japan or most other foreign countries any longer.
"I got a little lobbying from Mexico," said one Senator, Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois. "But that's it."
The ties to American allies have worked to the advantage of Japanese companies in several recent disputes. Plans by the Bush Administration from 1989 to 1991 to impose tariffs on displays for laptop computers were dropped after complaints from Apple Computer and other American customers that relied on the Japanese parts for its products.
 
Strengthening the Ties
Chilling Effects Of Japan's Power
 As part of their lobbying strategy, Japanese corporations and Government agencies hire dozens of American law firms and consulting agencies to represent them here, and American analysts endlessly debate what is really behind the practice. Some analysts say the Japanese hire so many firms because they want to tie up the country's most talented trade lawyers; others say Japan is wasting its money.
But Jiro Murase, a New York lawyer whose firm represents several hundred Japanese companies, has his own view. Born in New York City, he grew up in Japan during World War II and returned here to attend college and build a legal practice.
Mr. Murase said the Japanese take a long view of their relationship with Washington and are well aware that today's lawyer may be tomorrow's senior official. He listed several Clinton Administration officials from law firms with significant Japanese contracts, including Samuel R. Berger, the Deputy National Security Adviser, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher. Other prominent Administration officials from firms with Japanese lobbying contracts include Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and Howard Paster, the White House's chief Congressional lobbyist.
"When you represent the Japanese, and your source of income is Japanese, your perceptions change," Mr. Murase said, adding: "With so many companies now doing business with the Japanese, making profits with the Japanese, I always say we're like one Siamese twin. If you hit too hard on one, pain will come to the other side."
 
U.S. Suppliers Back Clients
 Some Washington law firms now rely on Japanese clients, and that can have a chilling effect on former officials looking for jobs. William von Raab, a critic of Japanese trade policies while he served as Customs Commissioner in the Reagan and Bush Administrations, said several lobbying firms told him that "if we hire you, they'd pull their business."
The hundreds of American companies that supply parts to Japanese auto plants are another source of leverage. For a lobbying battle earlier this year, Toyota Motor Corporation urged 119 of its American suppliers to register their opposition to import quotas or higher tariffs on minivans.
Koichiro Noguchi, an official at the Japanese headquarters, helpfully enclosed a fill-in-the-blank form letter. It began this way:
"Dear President Clinton:
"(Company name) has invested some [ ) and employs ( ) at plants located in ( ). Currently we supply (part type) to (company name). We are very concerned to hear that your Administration is planning to make changes in this country's long-standing trade policy towards Japanese automakers."
So far, none of the proposed quotas, production limits or minivan tariffs have been adopted.
 
Cementing the Ties
Fear of Retaliation Shapes a Ruling
 Mr. Bennett's experience with Kyocera brought out the multilayered nature of Japanese lobbying. Wherever Mr. Bennett turned, it seemed, he encountered people with professional, personal or institutional relationships with Japan.
Mr. Bennett's company is among the few remaining domestic makers of ceramic housings that hold computer chips and transmit their signals. Roughly 90 percent of this country's high-tech weapons -- from tanks to fighter aircraft to the Patriot missile -- are made with imported supplies of this part, the majority from Kyocera. Most of the chips in the newest personal computers are also connected to these ceramics.
Last November, days after Mr. Clinton won the election, Mr. Bennett's company, Ceramic Process Systems Corporation of Massachusetts, joined with a Tennessee business, Coors Electronic Package Company, to file the Commerce Department complaint. They argued that it was essential for national security to maintain a domestic industry and asked the Government to invoke a cold-war-era trade law that authorizes the President to restrict imports or take other tough steps.
Mr. Bennett said he merely wanted the Clinton Administration to set aside an unspecified percentage of Pentagon business for American contractors. The idea has precedents: the Government requires its agencies to buy American cars and to book flights on American carriers.
A Japanese counterattack began almost immediately. On the front line stood Global U.S.A., a Washington lobbying group that had represented Kyocera since 1984. Justice Department records show that Global, which represents eight Japanese clients, over the years regularly met with the mid-level officials who would make the decision on Mr. Bennett's request.
 
Cultivating Officials
 In addition, several Clinton Administration officials involved in deciding Mr. Bennett's case -- including Mr. Brown, the Commerce Secretary -- had worked as lobbyists or consultants to Japanese industry before they joined the Government.
Even with all that, Mr. Bennett says that the decisive assistance came from American companies that have come to be dependent on Kyocera or other Japanese customers. The Aerospace Industries Association, for example, feared that its members would be vulnerable to retaliation if Washington imposed sanctions. American aerospace manufacturers enjoy an 8-to-1 trade surplus with Japan, and as Joel Johnson, the association's vice president, explained, "We're a nice big juicy target" for retaliation.
John Deutch, the Pentagon's senior procurement official, echoed that theme in a meeting with Mr. Bennett. Mr. Deutch said trade sanctions against Japanese companies would be imprudent when the Clinton Administration was pushing the Japanese to permit American companies to bid on work for Nippon Telegraph and Telephone.
For their part, Mr. Bennett and his lawyers argued that the Japanese supply of ceramics could be cut off at any time, either deliberately or because of an accident or terrorist incident. He noted that Japanese companies' sales of parts to American military contractors already skirt a Japanese law that forbids exports to military manufacturers.
 
U.S. Heavyweight Enters
 Initially the Commerce Department accepted that argument and drafted a ruling in Mr. Bennett's favor. Without protection, the Department concluded, the remaining American companies making ceramic housings would disappear within a few years.
But then I.B.M. entered the debate. The company makes ceramic housings for its own computer chips and recently began selling them as well from its factory in East Fishkill, N.Y. And at first, I.B.M. was sympathetic to the petition. The company told the Commerce Department that while it did not favor import restrictions, America's dependence on imported ceramics posed the threat of a "critical, extended supply interruption."
Just two weeks later, however, the company reversed itself and expressed implacable opposition, a view reasserted in two later letters.
I.B.M.'s stance was crucial, Government officials say. With it, Pentagon officials argued that the national security threat was illusory, that the nation's needs for ceramic parts would always be met by the computer giant.
Mark Holcomb, a Washington spokesman for I.B.M., said the company's conflicting letters reflected "an internal debate" and that company officials eventually decided to oppose any trade remedies that might invite "reciprocal behavior."
 
Protecting Ventures in Japan
 Soon after, the Commerce Department's preliminary finding in favor of Mr. Bennett was redrafted.
Bob Denysyk, Kyocera's chief lobbyist, asserted that I.B.M. and other American companies who supported Kyocera because of "business realities," not any campaign orchestrated by Japanese company. Still, one American industry official said a Kyocera lobbyist had asked him to join the case.
While the Government ruled against Mr. Bennett, Secretary Brown did order a plan to shore up the industry. It includes Government help for research and development, and Mr. Brown promised to have another look at the issue within a year.
But the story did not end there for another American company that had written a letter opposing Kyocera.
International Micro Industries Inc., of Mount Laurel, N.J., makes computer chips, but said it has since been unable to obtain ceramic parts from its Japanese suppliers. Thomas Angelucci, the company's president, said three Japanese companies that that had been soliciting his business just a few months earlier suddenly told him that they could no longer fill his orders.

HEADLINE: Salinas Defends His Government and Pledges Civility in Vote in '94

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Defending his Government against rising criticism, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari today pledged civility and fairness in national elections next year and promised his opponents "full freedom" to present their cases to the people.
In his annual state-of-the-nation address Mr. Salinas said he would not go beyond the changes to political statutes that his Institutional Revolutionary Party pushed through the legislature in September. Those changes have been criticized as grossly inadequate by many critics, although they were eventually endorsed by the conservative opposition in Congress. 
But Mr. Salinas went further than he has before in answering opposition leaders who have warned that after 64 years in power the governing party is gearing up for a no-holds-barred effort to retain the presidency for an additional six-year term.
"I offer the diverse political forces and the contenders who will take part in the electoral contest full respect, abidance to the terms of the law and proper conditions for them to present their options to the Mexicans in full freedom," Mr. Salinas said.
 
Issue in U.S. Congress
 The political conduct of the Government and its party have come under harsh attack after a series of incidents in which they have been accused of trying to censor critics and discredit a leftist leader, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, who is expected to be the sole strong opposition candidate in the presidential vote in August.
The shortcomings of the political system have also flowered as an issue in the United States Congressional debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement. With the accord expected to go to a vote in the House of Representatives as early as Nov. 17, some American legislators are arguing that Mexico should have fair elections if it is to be in a free-trade zone with the United States and Canada.
Responding to pressure to allow foreign observers in the vote Mr. Salinas said "only the Mexicans" should be "the definitive watchmen."
Reflecting his Government's deep concern that the trade agreement might be voted down in Washington, Mr. Salinas sought again to play down the importance of the pact, stressing the availability of trade and investment partners in Europe and Asia. "It should be noted once again that its benefits will not be forthcoming in the short term," Mr. Salinas said of the proposed treaty. "Nor will they produce spectacular results."
Obliging tradition, Mr. Salinas said nothing of the secretive process by which he will soon announce his choice of the governing party's presidential candidate. In the past, the incumbent's nomination has been tantamount to election, and any of the senior officials considered to be strong contenders would probably be favored over Mr. Cardenas. But Mr. Salinas's three-hour address will nonetheless be sifted for apparent clues about his choice.
 
Some Prominent Contenders
 Some political commentators thought that Mayor Manuel Camacho Solis of Mexico City received a particularly strong pat on the back through mentions of the soundness of municipal finances, a new children's museum and other projects. But other commentators saw tacit endorsements of Finance Secretary Pedro Aspe or Education Secretary Ernesto Zedillo. And none of the commentators seemed ready to downgrade Luis Donaldo Colosio, the Secretary of Social Development.
Defending his Administration against criticism of its economic policies, Mr. Salinas cited statistics showing that poverty had declined, an assertion that some economists dispute. He said inflation had been the most insidious force in concentrating wealth. Inflation fell to an annualized rate of 8 percent from 51.7 percent in the year that he took office, Mr. Salinas said. -- He argued that the emergence of big conglomerates and a new elite from his privatization of state companies did not mean further poverty for the poor.
The heart of the message, though, was a promise of civility in the contest ahead and a call to his supporters and opponents "to unite in a committed effort to hold clear, transparent and exemplary elections, to join in a political pact of civility within the framework of the law."
Some opposition leaders, particularly those on the left, dismissed the pledge, noting that the governing party would still be able to influence election boards, dominate television advertising and shape the first limits on campaign spending. Where the governing party has traditionally depended on back-channel financing from the state, it can also now collect individual contributions of more than $650,000 a year from executives and others who depend on Government support.
"He didn't talk about free elections," the president of Mr. Cardenas's Democratic Revolutionary Party, Senator Porfirio Munoz Ledo, said. "He talked about civility, about kissing our grandmothers on the cheek. The question is whether his Government will agree to accept an opposition victory and minimal conditions of equity in the campaign."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico yesterday in Mexico City after his annual state-of-the-nation address. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Announcement of New Film Sends Silver Prices Down

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Silver prices plunged yesterday after the Xerox Corporation announced that it had developed a new type of silver-free film.
Silver for December delivery fell 14.2 cents, to $4.225 an ounce, the lowest level in four weeks, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Gold prices also dropped, with the December futures contract falling $7.50 on the Comex, to $362.10 an ounce. 
 Silver prices had recovered this summer to a level of $5.40 an ounce -- from a two-year low in March of about $3.50 -- on inflation fears and a belief that industrial demand would pick up along with the global economy.
But prices have receded since August, and news of the new silver-free film sent the market reeling.
Xerox said its new Verdefilm, for use in graphic arts, not only does not have silver content, but it also does not require chemicals to develop.
Alternatives to existing silver-halide technology are already in use by some film manufacturers. But if, as Xerox asserts, the quality has been improved, "this could be extremely threatening for silver," said Tony Warwick-Ching, a metals analyst at Commodity Research International.
The Silver Institute, a industry group, estimated that worldwide, photography consumes nearly 186 million ounces of silver a year, with 41 million going for graphic arts applications. Total global silver consumption is 590 million ounces, the institute said.
An analyst at Merrill Lynch, William O'Neill, stressed that Xerox's news simply added to the already bearish fundamental outlook for silver, based on thousands of tons of excess supply.
The Xerox announcement "just adds more and more silver, and makes silver less and less attractive as an industrial metal," Mr. O'Neill said.
Among other commodities, oil and natural gas prices rose sharply, partly in response to a cold snap in much of the nation. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for December delivery jumped 51 cents, to $17.43 a barrel, rebounding from a fall last week to a six-week low of $16.92. December heating oil soared 1.56 cents, to 53.12 cents a gallon, and December natural gas gained 6.6 cents, to $2.434 for 1,000 cubic feet. December unleaded gasoline added 0.79 cent, to 48.50 cents a gallon.
 The Northeast was bracing yesterday for winter temperatures, which would raise demand for heating oil and natural gas from homeowners and utilities.

HEADLINE: After 4-Week Crescendo, Blast Suspect Is Mentioned

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
It was a first, and it took four full weeks of testimony and 60 witnesses before it happened, but yesterday, finally, the name of a defendant was mentioned in testimony in the World Trade Center bombing trial.
Late in the afternoon, an executive of the Ryder Rental Agency, Clark Anderson, was led through his testimony by a prosecutor, Henry DePippo. Mr. Clark looked through several folders that contained the history of one of the many thousands of vehicles in the Ryder fleet -- a vehicle that, Mr. Anderson said, bore Ryder identification number 115141, which corresponded to a Ford Econoline van stamped with a manufacturer's identification number of LHA75633. 
 The number LHA75633 has come up numerous times in the last few days of the trial as the prosecution painstakingly resurrected in court a Ryder rental van found in many small, crumpled pieces in the wreckage of the World Trade Center. The prosecution's case hinges on showing that this van contained the explosive that blew a huge hole in the underground parking garage of the trade center complex on Feb. 26.
Having, it seems, finished with the evidence regarding the identity of the van, Mr. DePippo moved on to the logical next step.
"Can you tell us, sir, who was the last customer who rented that van?" he asked the witness.
Mr. Anderson looked at the rental history of the van, which had been put into evidence moments before.
"Mohammed Salameh," he said.
In fact, the mention of Mr. Salameh's name did not have enormous significance for the prosecution's case, since Mr. Salameh, as his lawyer indicated in his opening statement a month ago, does not dispute renting a van from a Ryder agency in New Jersey on Feb. 23, three days before the World Trade Center blast. The lawyer, Robert E. Precht, said that Mr. Salameh reported the van stolen on Feb. 25, the day before the bombing, the suggestion being that the mere fact that he rented the van does not prove at all that he used it for any illegal purpose.
 
Case Built From Bottom Up
 Still, the long anticipated mention of Mr. Salameh's name came as a kind of dramatic high point in a trial that has focused, for the past three weeks now, on such dry matters as the identification of vehicle parts and the reconstruction of tire fragments without any direct reference to the four men actually on trial.
There are no eyewitnesses in the case who actually saw any of the defendants planting a bomb or even in the vicinity of the World Trade Center. Therefore, the prosecution's strategy has been to build a case, based almost entirely on circumstantial evidence, from the bottom up, beginning with the fragments of evidence found during a one-month search of the trade center wreckage by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.
After the investigators presented the shards of metal and the shreds of rubber tire, experts were called in to show that they all belonged to a Ford Econoline van belonging to the Ryder Rental Company.
 
Pointing to One Moment
 Two witnesses, tire experts for the Michelin Tire Company and Bridge stone-Firestone Inc., told the jury last week that the 19 tire fragments found in the wreckage indicated that there were four tires present: a Michelin, a Michelin retread, a Bridgestone and a Firestone.
The last witness in this long series of witnesses was William F. Peffer, an engineer for the Ford Motor Company who finished his testimony yesterday with what might turn out to be a crucial element in the case.
Looking at the two rear wheels recovered in the debris, Mr. Peffer said that it looked as though they had both been torn from their bolts from the inside out. At some point the prosecution will have to show that the van was not only blown apart by the blast but that it contained the explosive device. If the wheels were blown outward, as Mr. Peffer contended, that would indicate that the explosive had been placed between them.
All the testimony, in short, pointed to the moment when somebody from Ryder would take the stand, finally, to make the formal connection between the fragments of metal and tire and the defendants in the case.
Enter Mr. Anderson.
 
Tire-Replacement Record
 Before he named Mr. Salameh, he was led by Mr. DePippo through a couple of other key points. He reaffirmed certain unusual characteristics of Ryder vans that had already been shown, without their meaning being made clear, to the jurors. He testified, for example, that Ryder vans are all painted a characteristic yellow, called "Ryder yellow" by Mr. Anderson. The wheels are painted white, he said, as were the wheels recovered in the rubble.
Mr. Anderson also read out the record of tire replacement for van number 114151. The record indicated that the rear wheels were equipped with one Michelin tire, one Michelin retread and two Bridgestone tires.
Mr. DePippo asked whether the tire records are always complete, making an effort to account for the fact that the record did not indicate the Firestone tire that had been identified by the tire experts last week.
"No," Mr. Anderson said. "Sometimes if a customer damages a tire, he might replace it on his own, and then we wouldn't know about it, or it wouldn't show up on the computer records."
Then the crucial, and final question: Who was the renter of the van?
Mr. Anderson answered as if the name had no particular meaning to him. Mr. Salameh sat at the witness table, his arm draped over the back of his lawyer's chair, showing no expression on his face as his name was uttered by a witness in the trial for the first time.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Indications Of Stronger U.S. Economy

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most leading currencies yesterday, as upbeat economic news in the United States drew investors into American financial assets.
The dollar rose after the National Association of Purchasing Managers monthly index of manufacturing activity rose to 53.8 percent in October from 49.7 percent in September, pointing to a rise in growth. Construction spending, which rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in September, also lent support to the dollar. 
 With a bullish climate, a factor that held back the dollar was talk that European central banks sold dollars through the Bundesbank, the German central bank, dealers said.
"The presence of central banks kept a lid on the market," Frank Pusateri, vice president of the Bank of Boston, said.
Many of Europe's markets were closed yesterday for All Saints Day.
"There's certainly been a lot of central-bank activity in the last few weeks," Bruce English, head of institutional sales at ABN/AMRO N.V., said. "Now that marks are cheaper, banks might be selling dollars and buying marks to replenish reserves."
 
 
Yen Rises Against Dollar
 The yen, however, rose against the dollar, mostly because traders bought the Japanese currency and sold off other weaker European currencies.
"Right now, the tendency is to buy yen and sell marks," Mr. English said.
The dollar rose to 1.6940 marks in late New York trading, from 1.6858 marks on Friday. But it slipped to 108.20 yen from 108.65 yen.
While the dollar's gains were stalled by profit taking and rumored bank sales, technical factors and promising economic data continued to cast a bullish light on the buck.
Others cautiously noted, however, that this perception could change should Friday's key payrolls report for October fall short of expectations.
The British pound closed in New York at $1.4815, unchanged from late Friday. Other late dollar rates, compared with Friday's quotes, included: 1.5020 Swiss francs, up from 1.4915; 5.9297 French francs, up from 5.8980; 1,651 Italian lire, up from 1,645, and $1.3101 Canadian, down from $1.3208.

HEADLINE: The 1993 CAMPAIGN;
The Region: Tough Races for L.I. District Attorneys and Connecticut Mayors

 BODY:

Nassau District Attorney
Denis Dillon, Nassau County District Attorney, is seeking an unprecedented sixth term, running against a former member of his own staff, Timothy Calonita, who served as an assistant district attorney until his resignation in May in a dispute with the county over budget cuts.
Mr. Dillon is a former Democrat who, because of his support of the anti-abortion movement in the mid-1980's, switched to the Republican Party. He also is running on the Conservative and Right-to-Life lines. 
 Mr. Calonita, a Republican running on the Democratic line, contends that Mr. Dillon has become sidetracked by issues, such as abortion, and has lost his mandate as the county's chief law-enforcement official.
Mr. Dillon contends that Mr. Calonita, who was a member of his staff for 5 1/2 years, lacks experience. He is also critical of Mr. Calonita's academic record, noting that he graduated from law school near the bottom of his class and failed his first attempt to pass the bar exam.
Both candidates have suffered bouts with cancer, and both say they have recovered and that their health should not be an issue in the campaign.
A third candidate, Mark J. Morgenstern, is an independent running on the Liberal party line.
 
Suffolk District Attorney
 In Suffolk County, District Attorney James M. Catterson Jr., a Republican seeking a second four-year term, is accused by the Democratic candidate, Patrick Kevin Brosnahan, of arrogant behavior and of failing to root out political corruption.
Mr. Brosnahan, 44, whose legal specialty is election law, has faulted Mr. Catterson for driving a BMW seized from a drug dealer under Federal forfeiture laws. He has also asserted that Mr. Catterson turned a blind eye to allegations of corruption among Republican officials in the Town of Brookhaven, where Mr. Catterson lives.
Mr. Catterson, 63, said his staff of 142 lawyers has the highest rate of convictions, after trials, in the state. He said his 30 years of legal experience, emphasis on staff training and initiatives in environmental and spousal abuse cases made him a better choice than Mr. Brosnahan, whom he called a "Democratic attack dog" given to delusional charges and lacking in criminal law experience.
 
Connecticut Races

In Connecticut, Hartford's three-term Democratic Mayor, Carrie Saxon Perry, is facing a hard-fought challenge from a fellow Democrat, Michael P. Peters, who is running as an independent. Ms. Perry has campaigned on the theme that Hartford, having been battered by the recession, is on its way back with visionary projects like the recent attempt to attract a professional football franchise. Mr. Peters, a city firefighter, says the Mayor presumes too much and that Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has been the real mover behind Hartford's elevated spirits. Democrats outnumber Republicans in Hartford by about 8 to 1.
In Waterbury, a city racked in recent years by corruption scandals, both the incumbent Democrat, Edward D. Bergin Jr., and the Republican challenger, State Senator Stephen R. Somma -- in a mud-slinging contest -- have tried to link each other with elements of the city's less savory past.
In New Haven, John DeStefano Jr., a Democrat, and Kevin A. Skiest, a Republican are vying to replace Mayor John C. Daniels, the city's first black mayor, who declined to run for a third term. Democrats there outnumber Republicans 10 to 1.
 
New Jersey Legislature

New Jersey voters will decide contests for all 120 seats in the Legislature.
Two years ago, Republicans capitalized on voter anger over Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax program to take control of both the Senate and Assembly from the Democrats. Republicans picked up 10 seats in the Senate for a total of 27 out of the 40 seats, and increased their membership in the Assembly by 21 seats to hold a 58 to 22 majority.
With Governor Florio running ahead of his Republican opponent, Christine Todd Whitman, Democratic leaders hope to win back seats in nominally Democratic districts in Mercer, Middlesex and Bergen that they lost in 1991, but the election is not expected to return control to the Democrats.
New Jersey voters will also have an opportunity to give themselves the power to recall elected officials. A ballot question will ask whether the State Constitution should be amended to make it possible to remove officials from the municipal level to Congress after they have served a year in office.
 
Bergen County Blue Laws
 The 34-year-old ban on Sunday shopping in Bergen County, N.J., one of the country's richest shopping hubs, will be put to a vote for the first time since 1980, when residents voted 192,394 to 157,648 to maintain restrictions that bar the sale of clothing, furniture, appliances and building supplies.
Proponents of repeal say two-income families and the complexities of modern life require the flexibility of a full, seven-day shopping week.
Supporters of the status quo say those who would overturn the blue laws are motivated by greed. Sunday shopping, they say, would also worsen the suburban quality of life by adding a seventh day of unbearable highway and local traffic.
Ten of the state's 21 counties enacted Sunday shopping bans in 1959, but Bergen is the only one to retain them. If the blue laws are repealed, unrestricted shopping could start on Sunday. But not in Paramus, which is home to the Garden State Plaza and other large shopping centers along Routes 4 and 17. Paramus and two other towns, Ridgewood and Wyckoff, maintain their own Sunday restrictions.
