HEADLINE: Clinton Steps Up Campaign for Trade Accord

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
With a little more than two weeks to go before Congress votes on the free trade agreement with Mexico and Canada, President Clinton today stepped up his campaign for it and told business leaders that if it was rejected, Japan and Europe would swarm over the Mexican market like "flies on a June bug."
Speaking here to a conference sponsored by the United States Chamber of Commerce and beamed on television by satellite to forums organized by business leaders at some 1,000 locations around the country, the President reached for every argument he knew in favor of the North American Free Trade Agreement: 
 *He sounded alarms: If the United States turns down the agreement Japan and Europe will swoop in.
*He pressed the immigration button: The accord would encourage Mexico to export goods instead of people.
*He painted grand visions: It would pave the way to a free trade zone of a billion people from the northern tip of Canada to the southern tip of Chile.
*And he waved the flag, declaring that only someone who was "nuts" would say that America could not win in head-to-head economic competition with Mexico.
The House of Representatives is scheduled to vote Nov. 17 on the agreement, which over the next 10 years would abolish all tariffs and other trade barriers among the United States, Mexico and Canada. If the accord is approved then, quick passage is likely in the Senate, where it has more support. But in the House most Democrats remain opposed, and so the President and his Cabinet are going into high gear to muster votes.
 
Deals Behind the Scenes
 The White House is making deals behind the scenes with fence-sitters in Congress, and Mr. Clinton has scheduled events almost every day this week to sell the accord. On Tuesday, all the living former Secretaries of State are coming to the White House to show support for the pact. Secretary of State Warren Christopher will then fly to Los Angeles to deliver a speech, and Vice President Al Gore has scheduled a series of arm-twisting dinners with members of Congress.
These next few days are crucial, White House officials say, because if the fence-sitters are to be won over, they must be convinced that sentiment has turned in favor of the agreement.
White House officials say the accord will either pass by a slim margin or be defeated by a large one, depending on which way the tide of undecided lawmakers starts flowing in the coming days. Organized labor and Ross Perot are insisting that the pact would lead to fewer jobs and lower wages in this country, and Mr. Perot is threatening to bring his campaign against the agreement to Washington and lead a protest march down Pennsylvania Avenue.
But at this stage a reliable vote count in the House is hard to come by. The Democratic whip, Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, who is leading the opposition forces, has said he is 10 votes shy of enough to insure that the accord will be rejected. But Administration officials and lawmakers favoring the pact say they are increasingly confident of victory.
Time and again today, the President used as his most emotive weapon the specter of a Mexican market stolen by Japan and Europe, not that any such weapon was needed to drum up support from his Chamber of Commerce audience, which was stacked in favor of the White House. Acknowledging that he was speaking to the converted, Mr. Clinton said:
"You all have to be missionaries. We only have 17 days. We need you to go out and make sure that your members of Congress, every man and woman in the Congress that you can reach, is contacted by real people who say, 'My life will be better.' "
"We're trying to give the secret supporters of this agreement in Congress, and there are lots of them, the political cover they need to vote yes," said a senior Clinton aide.
The President said that in the event Congress rejected the agreement, "if I were Prime Minister of Japan and I had a low growth rate and I had my companies going crazy, I would jump on this like flies on a June bug."
"If Congress votes this down on the 17th of November," he continued, "I would, if I were the Prime Minister of Japan, have the Finance Minister of my country in to see the President of Mexico on the 18th of November. That's what I would do. I'd say, 'We've got more money than they do anyway; make the deal with us.' "
Mr. Clinton also tried to puncture the main economic argument used by opponents of the accord: that jobs would flow to Mexico because of lower wages there.
"If that were true," he said, "what you would be reading this morning about Haiti is that Haiti had all the manufacturing jobs in America, right? I mean, if this were a case of low wages, the headlines on Haiti today would be, 'General Motors Shuts Down in Michigan,' 'Caterpillar Leaves Illinois, Goes to Port-au-Prince.' "

He spoke to a conference sponsored by the United States Chamber of Commerce that was beamed by satellite to forums organized by business leaders at 1,000 locations across the country. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The 1993 CAMPAIGN;
The City: Much at Stake in Contests for Council, Comptroller and Advocate

 BODY:

 Public Advocate
Susan D. Alter, the Republican-Liberal candidate for Public Advocate, spent the last day of the campaign stumping with the top of her ticket, Rudolph W. Giuliani, at centers for the elderly across New York City while her Democratic opponent, Mark J. Green, met with union supporters, attended to fund-raising duties and campaigned among liberal voters in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
With Mr. Green well ahead in the polls, interest in the race has focused largely on its impact on the mayoral campaign. Ms. Alter, a Democratic Councilwoman, Orthodox Jew and the only woman seeking citywide office, could draw women, Jewish and conservative Democratic voters to Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Green is popular among liberal and Jewish voters, both important swing constituencies that Mr. Dinkins needs to win. 
 After running a low-profile media campaign for much of the race, Mr. Green has released television commercials in recent days that highlight his accomplishments as the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs. Ms. Alter, who has been running commercials for several weeks focusing on her record as a City Councilwoman, has turned to attacking Mr. Green in her most recent spots.
While Ms. Alter has little field operation of her own and will depend heavily on the drawing power of Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Green's aides say they have assembled a citywide corps of 1,000 volunteers who will distribute literature and get out the vote today. They will focus their efforts in areas where Mr. Green can help Mr. Dinkins, particularly in Queens, Mr. Green's aides said.
 
Secession From Both Sides
 Advocates and opponents of a referendum to allow Staten Island to secede from New York City waged their battle across the island yesterday, appearing on television programs, distributing literature on the Staten Island Ferry and appealing to voters in newspaper advertisements -- even though the results of today's vote are considered a foregone conclusion.
Both sides say the referendum will pass easily, but anti-secessionists are hoping to keep the yes vote below 60 percent while pro-secessionists are seeking to push it above 66 percent -- each figure considered an important psychological benchmark.
If the measure passes, it would have to be approved by the Republican-controlled state Senate, the Democratic-controlled state Assembly and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo before Staten Island could become the state's second-largest city.
Opponents, who include unions representing teachers, transit workers and white-collar municipal employees, argue that Staten Island lacks the economic base to survive independently and that secession will lead to tax increases and service cuts. They also contend that zoning laws will be revamped to allow more concentrated development along the island's shores.
But proponents, who include Borough President Guy V. Molinari, most of the local elected officials and the Chamber of Commerce, say government costs can be pared to avoid tax increases. And though there may be protracted litigation with the city over municipal land and buildings, the end result will be a new pride on Staten Island, they say.
"Isn't it worth the price of an ugly divorce to have happiness and freedom?" said Mr. Molinari on WNBC-TV on Sunday.
 
City Council
 Although the Democratic majority in the 51-member Council led by Speaker Peter F. Vallone is in no danger of collapsing, Republican challengers are threatening to take seats away from Democratic incumbents in four races in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.
The Council is also virtually assured of picking up three new Democratic members who will replace two members who retired in Brooklyn and one Bronx lawmaker who has been indicted on fraud charges.
The most contested race is on Manhattan's East Side, where the Republican Andrew S. Eristoff, the 30-year-old scion of the Phipps family fortune, is trying to hold onto the seat he won last spring in a special election, spending more than $329,000, much of it his own money, on this race. His challenger, Jane R. Crotty, a school teacher and community board member, came in second in the special election and has strong support from the Democratic Party and unions.
In Brooklyn, Sal F. Albanese, a veteran Democratic lawmaker, is fighting off a stout challenge in a conservative district from Republican Joseph F. DeFina, and on Staten Island, another veteran Democrat, Jerome X. O'Donovan, is up against a strong Republican bid from Lee Covino, an aide to Borough President Guy V. Molinari.
In Queens, the longest serving Democrat in the Council, Walter Ward, who is 82 years old, has a tough contest on his hands from Alphonso C. Stabile, a real-estate investor who has spent more than $100,000 to force Mr. Ward out. And Walter L. McCaffrey, a powerful Democrat from Maspeth, may be in trouble. He faces a tough challenge from James J. Dillon, a former Democrat and community board member.
 
Term Limits
 The supporters and opponents of a referendum that would limit New York City's elected officials to two consecutive terms, or eight years, in office concluded their brief, mostly unpublicized campaigns yesterday with appeals on the air waves and on the streets.
Both sides agree that the referendum, Proposal 4, would bring one of the most radical changes to government in the city's history.
Supporters of the referendum, which reached the ballot largely because of the efforts of Ronald S. Lauder, the cosmetics family heir who ran unsuccessfully for mayor in 1989, expressed confidence that voters frustrated with entrenched incumbency would pass the measure overwhelmingly.
Opponents, including most elected city officials, acknowledge that the referendum has popular support but say limits would deprive voters of their right to choose and force out effective lawmakers with the deadwood.
Former Gov. Hugh L. Carey urged New Yorkers to vote against the referendum. "Don't sell your franchise to some millionaire who wants to run this city with his bankroll," Mr. Carey said.
Lacking the resources of Mr. Lauder, who has spent more than $1 million, the opponents have relied on a grass-roots effort. "As I'm stumping for myself, I'm stumping against term limits as well," said Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey, a Queens Democrat.
The referendum, which the State Court of Appeals ordered on the ballot only two weeks ago, would limit the terms of the mayor, comptroller, public advocate, borough presidents and City Council members.
A New York Post/WNYW-TV poll released yesterday showed 50 percent of voters in favor of the measure and 35 percent opposed, compared with 55 and 29 percent a week ago. The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 1/2 percentage points.
 
City Comptroller
 The candidates for New York City comptroller spent the final day of campaigning seeking votes from subway commuters and the elderly, revving up supporters at rallies and putting in joint appearances with the two mayoral candidates whose fate may help determine the outcome of their race.
Alan G. Hevesi, 53, the Democratic Assemblyman from Queens who is leading in polls, raised money in the morning and then appealed to voters at a center for the elderly in Queens and a subway stop in lower Manhattan. He appeared with Mayor David N. Dinkins at an afternoon get-out-the-vote youth rally for the Democratic ticket at a downtown hotel and at a dinner in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. In between events he dropped in on Local 1199 of the hospital workers union, which had endorsed him, to thank campaign volunteers.
Herman Badillo, 64, the former Congressman from the Bronx running on the Republican-Liberal line, crisscrossed the city with Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal mayoral candidate, on a hectic schedule that included visits to seven senior centers in Brooklyn and Queens and rallies in all five boroughs.
Mr. Badillo, staging a political comeback since he last held elective office 15 years ago, has made a contest of the race, despite the Democrats' advantage in voter registration, because of his high name recognition and his alliance with a strong mayoral candidate. Mr. Hevesi, however, is shown in polls to be ahead by up to 15 percentage points.

HEADLINE: U.S. Investigating Clinton's Links to Arkansas S.& L.

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH with STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Federal investigators are raising questions about ties between President Clinton and an Arkansas businessman, a political patron of Mr. Clinton in the 1980's whose failed savings and loan is now under investigation.
Government officials and lawyers familiar with the case said the President was neither the subject nor a target of the investigation, which is still in its early stages. 
 But the inquiry focuses on questionable financial dealings involving the savings and loan, Madison Guaranty, from which Mr. Clinton benefited both personally and politically. The savings and loan's owner, James McDougal, was one of Mr. Clinton's closest associates in Arkansas and was, at various times, his business partner, political fund-raiser, family banker and senior aide when Mr. Clinton was Governor of Arkansas.
 
Advantageous Relationship
 Mr. Clinton's banking commissioner advised him in 1983 that Mr. McDougal was engaged in questionable banking practices. But the two men nevertheless maintained a business and political relationship throughout the 1980's that helped both men. When Mr. Clinton needed someone to raise $35,000 to retire debts from his 1984 re-election campaign, he turned to Mr. McDougal.
Mr. McDougal denies any wrongdoing. His lawyer, Sam Heuer, said his client was under investigation by the United States Attorney in Little Rock, Ark. Last month the Federal agency that disposes of failed savings and loans, the Resolution Trust Corporation, asked the United States Attorney in Little Rock to examine several possible violations of law in the operations of the savings and loan, including transactions that may have helped Mr. Clinton pay his campaign debts.
According to Federal officials, court documents and lawyers familiar with the case, the two Federal agencies have been trying to find out whether more than $250,000 in business loans was improperly diverted from Madison in April 1985 to several sources, including Governor Clinton's re-election campaign.
The officials said the campaign received $12,000 in cashier's checks from Madison, some of which appeared to have been paid for by the business loans. The former Clinton aide who deposited the money said neither she nor Mr. Clinton was aware of any irregularities about its source.
Investigators have asked prosecutors to see whether the campaign contributions were linked to efforts by Madison to win state approval for an unusual plan to raise new capital by issuing stock, the officials said.
Finally, prosecutors are studying a $300,000 loan from a federally sponsored lending company to Mr. McDougal's wife, Susan. The man who made the loan, David Hale, was indicted in September on unrelated charges.
In an effort to win leniency from prosecutors on the eve of his indictment, Mr. Hale offered prosecutors information about Mr. Clinton and other Arkansas politicians, but was unable to reach a plea agreement. Mr. Hale asserted in interviews with reporters that Mr. Clinton had personally pressed him to make the $300,000 loan.
A White House spokesman said Mr. Clinton had no recollection of any such conversation. Mr. Hale said Mr. McDougal told him the money would help conceal earlier favors for the Governor.
 
New Prosecutor
 The criminal investigations of Madison and Mr. Hale's lending activities are being directed by the new United States Attorney in Little Rock, Paula J. Casey. On Sunday, The Washington Post disclosed the Resolution Trust Corporation's request to Ms. Casey, and The Wall Street Journal reported on the inquiry today.
Mr. Hale's lawyer has questioned Ms. Casey's independence. She was a volunteer in Mr. Clinton's campaigns for governor and was his student at the University of Arkansas law school. Ms. Casey would not discuss the case but told Mr. Hale's lawyer that she was not afraid to prosecute anyone.
Mr. McDougal, who is at the heart of the inquiry into the savings and loan's affairs, continues to blame regulators and prosecutors for his downfall, calling them overzealous. He was acquitted of Federal bank fraud charges involving Madison in 1980.
Mr. McDougal met Mr. Clinton in the late 1960's, when both men worked on the staff of Senator J. William Fulbright, the Arkansas Democrat and longtime chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
 
Ozarks Real Estate Deal
 In 1978, the McDougals brought Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, into a real estate deal, buying 200 acres of the Ozarks in northern Arksansas. Later, the property was transferred to their company, Whitewater Development, with both couples sharing the liabilities and potential profits.
When Mr. Clinton first took office as Governor in 1979, Mr. McDougal joined him as an economic development aide. But he soon returned to business, buying a bank in northern Arkansas and a savings and loan in a small town about 75 miles from Little Rock.
By 1983, Mr. McDougal's bank was in trouble with Arkansas regulators. The state's banking commissioner, Marlin S. Jackson, ordered the bank to stop making imprudent loans. Mr. Jackson, a Clinton appointee, said in an interview last year that he told Mr. Clinton at the time of Mr. McDougal's questionable practices.
Meanwhile, the savings and loan continued to grow, from $6 million in assets to more than $100 million by 1985. It opened a branch in Little Rock near the Statehouse and began making loans to prominent Democrats, including Mr. Fulbright and Jim Guy Tucker, a Little Rock lawyer who is now Governor of Arkansas.
Records also indicate that Madison was helping Whitewater, the real estate business owned by the Clintons and McDougals. In 1984 and 1985, as the company continued to post losses, check ledgers show that the company had frequent, sizable overdrafts on its account at Madison.
Also in 1985, Madison Marketing, a McDougal family business that derived all of its revenue from the savings and loan, provided the funds for Whitewater to make a $7,322 payment on a loan taken out by Mr. Clinton from another bank, according to bank records.
The Clinton Presidential campaign said last year that the McDougals had contributed a disproportionate share of Whitewater's money, $92,000 against $68,000 by the Clintons.
In interviews last year, Mr. McDougal seemed to view his relationship with Mr. Clinton as unbalanced. On the one hand, he said, "Bill never turned me down on something I asked for, and I only asked for it occasionally."
But on the other hand, Mr. McDougal said, he helped the Clintons in numerous ways, from agreeing to hire Mrs. Clinton to do additional legal work at Madison, to paying on Mr. Clinton's behalf part of the loans on the Ozark property.
 
Favors on Both Sides
 Mr. McDougal said in the same interviews that 1985 was a year of favors on both sides. In early 1985, he said, Mr. Clinton asked him to raise enough money to retire about $35,000 in debts left from his 1984 campaign.
Betsey Wright, who ran the 1984 campaign, confirmed that Mr. Clinton had made the request and said it led Mr. McDougal to be the host for a small fund-raising event in 1985 at the savings and loan. Mr. Clinton attended that event.
As for the source of the donations, Ms. Wright said: "I'm sure we would have no idea. Any hint of a problem and we would not have accepted."
At least $12,000 worth of cashier's checks issued by Madison wound up in the campaign's coffers in April 1985, Federal officials said. Some came from a business loan that Madison made to a McDougal associate and was never repaid. The rest was from Mr. McDougal's personal and corporate accounts, the officials said.
Days before Mr. McDougal held his fund-raising event for Mr. Clinton, Madison learned that it faced a serious problem. Federal regulators were concerned by the savings and loan's rapid growth and the failure to have on hand enough capital to meet Federal requirements.
 
State Approval Needed
 Madison's proposal was to raise money to meet the capital requirement by selling a form of stock never issued before in Arkansas by a savings and loan. Because it was a state-chartered institution, Madison needed the approval of Arkansas regulators.
The savings and loan did not rely on its usual outside counsel for this issue, turning instead to the Rose law firm of Little Rock, where Mrs. Clinton was a senior partner. In written answers to questions last year, she said she met with Mr. McDougal once in April 1985 to discuss working for Madison. She declined to elaborate.
In the documents forwarded to prosecutors, investigators for the Resolution Trust Corporation have questioned whether the campaign contributions were connected to Madison's effort to get state regulators to approve its stock plan, Federal officials say. By May, Arkansas regulators had concurred that the stock plan was legal, but it was never carried out.
James M. Lyons, a Denver lawyer who reviewed Mr. Clinton's dealings with Mr. McDougal for the Clinton Presidential campaign last year, said today that there was no connection between the contributions and the effort before the state regulators.
Mr. McDougal, in interviews, denied any impropriety in connection with the campaign contributions or the attempt to win approval for the stock plan.
At the end of 1985, Mr. McDougal said last year, Mr. Clinton did do him another favor, helping set up a state revenue office in a Little Rock building owned by a subsidiary of Madison.
By the fall of 1985, Mr. McDougal faced mounting pressure, some of which came from the prospect of a Federal audit scheduled for early 1986.
David Hale, a Democratic municipal judge in Little Rock who operated a federally sponsored lending company, said he was approached by Mr. McDougal in late 1985 to make loans that would help the "political family" of Arkansas Democrats.
Mr. Hale's company was part of a Small Business Administration program intended to provide capital for businesses owned by "socially or economically disadvantaged" people. Mr. Hale was recently indicted on charges of misleading the Government about the condition of his lending company. He has since resigned as a judge and is contesting the charges.
In interviews before his indictment, Mr. Hale said Madison financed a land deal in February 1986 in which he was paid hundreds of thousands of dollars more than the property was worth. Court records show that this loan was never repaid, resulting in a loss of $672,000 to taxpayers.
 
Questionable Transactions
 With profits from that deal in hand, Mr. Hale said he had been able to fulfill Mr. McDougal's request for a $300,000 loan to his wife.
Mr. Hale said in an interview that Mr. McDougal told him the $300,000 would not be used by the designated borrower. Instead, he said, it would conceal questionable transactions by Madison, including indirect help for the Clintons.
Mr. Hale asserts that Mr. Clinton twice pressed him to make this loan. Mark D. Gearan, the White House communications director, said the President had "no recollection" of any such conversation and did not believe it took place.
Mr. McDougal denied any wrongdoing in his dealings with Mr. Hale, saying he thinks the $300,000 wound up in his real estate ventures.
Federal officials are now trying to trace where the $300,000 lent by Mr. Hale ultimately went.

HEADLINE: The 1993 CAMPAIGN: Final Flurry of Activity as Campaigns Reach End of the Trail -- New Jersey;
Florio and Whitman Wind Up Their Contest Of Unexpected Tactics

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The last day of campaigning in the race for governor took Jim Florio to Camden, where his political career began, while Christine Todd Whitman, his Republican rival, spread her message to tax-sensitive older voters across the state.
After spending much of the day in the Camden County area he represented as a Congressman, Mr. Florio stopped at North Brunswick High School, attended labor rallies in Newark and Bordentown then ended the day in Cherry Hill. Mrs. Whitman visited housing and nutrition centers for the elderly in Ocean County then attended rallies in Toms River and Hamilton Township. 
 What was surprising about Election Eve 1993 was not where the two candidates found themselves geographically, but where they were politically. The Governor, once considered a hopeless case for a second term, led in an assortment of polls, albeit by a narrower margin than a month ago. Mrs. Whitman, who made her name by nearly toppling Senator Bill Bradley, far more popular than Jim Florio, was struggling to bring off the stunning upset she just missed three years ago.
 
Behind a Difficult Choice
 For their part, New Jersey voters will choose between two candidates who have failed to ignite an enthusiastic following. In successive surveys, nearly half of the New Jerseyans polled said they would be voting against one of the candidates when they entered the voting booth, rather than for his or her opponent. As late as mid-October, only 35 percent said they had a favorable view of Mr. Florio -- but that was twice the 17 percent who thought favorably of Mrs. Whitman. One frequent interpreter of New Jersey folkways, Dr. Clifford Zukin, a professor of political science at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, said that New Jersey voters had left themselves with a choice between the devil they know and the devil they don't.
"You have to understand there are only two questions: Do I like the incumbent for four more years?" the professor said. "If the answer is yes, as with Ronald Reagan, then the election is over.
"If it is no, as in the case of George Bush, then you must answer the second question: Is the alternative acceptable?"
And for many voters, he said, the answer to both questions this year is no, and that is why choosing a candidate is so difficult.
 
An Unfulfilled Scenario
 The seeds for this race between Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Florio were planted three years ago when the Governor pushed his $2.8 billion tax program through the Legislature, and Mrs. Whitman rode the ensuing voter anger to a near upset of Senator Bradley. She successfully focused the backlash on the only surrogate Democrat at hand, and her performance immediately marked her as the candidate to take on Mr. Florio this year.
By many measures, Mrs. Whitman gained in the campaign's final week, and many voters indicated that they remained undecided even as they headed to the polls. But political analysts and former party officials say that the expected scenario for campaign 1993 -- the election as a referendum on Mr. Florio that Mrs. Whitman, an attractive newcomer, would press home relentlessly -- never materialized.
Mr. Florio appeared to have some success in defining his own first four years and won grudging admissions from many voters that in retrospect his tax increase was the right medicine for the state. Mrs. Whitman was not successful in casting the increase as folly in the face of a looming recession, or in rekindling the anger that had been directed at the Governor. And her own plan for economic recovery, a 30 percent cut in state income taxes over three years, laid an egg.
According to Neil Upmeyer, president of the Center for the Analysis of Public Issues in Princeton, a nonpartisan organization, Mrs. Whitman's tax cut plan was the greatest surprise of the campaign. "She built up expectations and said the campaign wouldn't really start until she released her plan," he said. "Well, the campaign never started because when the plan came out, it was such a slapdash effort, it was all over."
 
Florio Takes the Offensive
 A poll taken right after the plan was released showed that 70 percent of the voters did not believe it was possible.
Professor Zukin of Rutgers also noted that Mr. Florio managed in some cases to define the debate in terms of issues he wanted to emphasize, like his opposition to assault guns. "Crime, which is always an important issue in an election, became assault weapons, and urban issues became deadbeat dads," he said. "When Mrs. Whitman came back from her summer vacation, she responded to his issues and played on his playing field."
While the Whitman campaign was hoarding its powder for a fall campaign, Mr. Florio's campaign was busy defining Mrs. Whitman as a gentrified neophyte who lacked the qualifications for the job she sought and depicting the Governor as a strong leader who had made difficult, if unpopular, choices.
In another surprise, Mr. Florio managed to move to the right of his Republican opponent on issues of crime (by supporting mandatory prison sentences) and welfare reform. "Instead of being depicted simply as a 'tax and spend liberal,' Florio outflanked her on some issues that appeal to conservatives and I think it has helped him," said Thomas V. O'Neil, a former executive director of the Democratic State Committee and former aide to Governor Brendan T. Byrne.
Mr. Upmeyer agreed that Mr. Florio had adopted much more conservative positions on some issues, but said that change had happened over the last two years. "I think it's designed to bring back the so-called Reagan Democrats and woo the Perot voters as well," he said.
To the political professionals, it was also puzzling that Mrs. Whitman chose to go on vacation soon after the Republican primary in June and then campaign sparingly until Labor Day. "She had been campaigning for the governorship flat out since 1990, and then she takes a summer vacation this year on the theory that all you need to do is to work hard the last few weeks," Mr. O'Neil marveled.
But perhaps the biggest surprise was that the campaign was largely devoid of any discussion of programs or proposals for the next four years. Beyond broad statements about working "to attract jobs" and "improve education" the candidates spend much of their time and advertising budgets either launching personal attacks or defending themselves against them. Mrs. Whitman's ill-received tax-cut plan was the exception that proved the rule.
"If Florio wins," said Alan Marcus, a lobbyist and former Republican campaign consultant, "he could take the next four years off, because he was never forced to say what he envisions for his second term."
 There will be elections today, Nov. 2, in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut.
 
Information on Voting
 There will be elections today, Nov. 2, in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut.
 Polls will be open in New York State from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M., in New Jersey from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. and in Connecticut from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M.
For information on polling places in New York City, voters can call the New York City Board of Elections Voter Information Hot Line -- (212) VOTE-NYC, or (212) 868-3692 -- or the New York Public Interest Research Group at (212) 349-6986.
For polling places in Westchester County call the County Board of Elections: (914) 285-5700. The Nassau County Board of Election is (516) 571-2411 and in Suffolk County the County Board of Elections is (516) 852-4500.
For information on polling places in New Jersey and in Connecticut voters can call county or municipal election boards.
For the first time, Connecticut residents will be required to produce valid identification, like drivers' licenses, credit cards or utility bills, to vote. The new requirement, meant to cut down on voter fraud, was passed by the Legislature earlier this year.

HEADLINE: The 1993 CAMPAIGN: Nassau;
Rivals Portray Two Counties: One Content, One Aggrieved

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 1

 BODY:
As an accordionist played "Hail, Hail, the Gang's All Here," Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County Executive, strode confidently into a senior center in his hometown of North Merrick this afternoon, where he hugged elderly residents and called this suburban county a "warm and caring" place.
It was an appeal to his most loyal voters, the people who voted a generation ago for Mr. Gulotta's father, a prominent Republican who served as District Attorney, and who have remained devoted to Mr. Gulotta over his 18-year political career. 
 At roughly the same time, a few miles away, Benjamin L. Zwirn, the Democratic candidate, stood outside in the cold, in front of a house with three large Zwirn campaign signs, and complained about the county's high taxes. Because of the signs, Mr. Zwirn charged, Republicans acting like "street hoodlums" had harassed the family living there.
Standing with Mr. Zwirn was the homeowner, Annette Saccoccio, 33, who said she had voted for Mr. Gulotta in the last election but is now furious with the Republicans. "This is not how American politics is supposed to work," she said.
 
Reaching the Bitter End
 On the final day of the campaign, the candidates continued to present divergent views of life in the county, from its economy to the state of the campaign. While each criticized the other's political tactics as dirty, neither wandered far from the basic messages they have delivered for months.
At the senior center and in other appearances over the last few days, Mr. Gulotta was upbeat about the county, saying its unemployment and crime rates were low. In contrast, Mr. Zwirn insisted that voters were angry over high taxes and that the election would reveal their readiness for substantial change.
Many Democrats say that Mr. Zwirn, the Supervisor of the Town of North Hempstead, has the best chance in a generation to win the county executive's job, a position held by Republicans since 1970. The Nassau Republican organization was considered vulnerable this year because of the faltering economy and because the party had lost a number of elections in recent years.
A Newsday poll released on Sunday found that 52 percent of likely voters planned to vote for Mr. Gulotta, to Mr. Zwirn's 39 percent, with 7 percent undecided. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
Mr. Zwirn this afternoon dismissed the poll as "horsefeathers," predicting a "tremendous upset" on Tuesday. "Many people are afraid to tell pollsters how they really feel," he said, because the Republicans control an elaborate patronage system and threaten those who do not toe the line.
Mr. Zwirn added that the Republicans would do almost anything to maintain their "one-party rule," and cited Mr. Gulotta's advertising campaign, the most expensive in county history, as an example of how the Republicans had tried to smear him as an ultra-liberal when he insists he is a fiscal conservative.
"It is the big lie," he said. "From the pictures they use to the distortions of my record, that has been their whole campaign."
Mr. Gulotta, however, said that the accusation showed that Mr. Zwirn's campaign was coming apart.

HEADLINE: Doris Duke Leaves $1 Billion to a New Charitable Foundation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Doris Duke, the tobacco heiress and philanthropist who was one of the world's richest women, left the bulk of her $1.2 billion estate to charity but nothing to a disowned adopted daughter with whom she had been feuding, according to a will filed for probate in a Manhattan court yesterday.
Miss Duke, who died last Thursday at the age of 80 after a life of luxury and generosity that attracted cranks and drove her into partial seclusion in her later years, left most of her estate -- more than $1 billion -- to a new Doris Duke Charitable Foundation that will become one of the nation's best-endowed philanthropies. 
 It will not rival the richest foundations -- Ford and Kellogg each have assets of more than $6 billion and a half-dozen others have more than $3 billion -- but it would rank among the top 12 and would provide funds for performing arts, environmental and ecological causes, education, the prevention of cruelty to children and animals, and medical research, all causes Miss Duke supported in her lifetime.
"The foundation will be dedicated to the improvement of humanity," Miss Duke, who dabbled in jazz piano and dance and was an ardent opponent of medical experiments on living animals, declared in the will, signed last April and filed yesterday in New York County Surrogate's Court.
 
Annuity for Executor
 Miss Duke's closest friend and adviser, Bernard Lafferty, 48, who was hired six years ago as a butler with administrative duties and since became her most trusted confidant, was named executor of the will and a trustee of the foundation that will control most of her fortune. The will also named a friend, Marian Oates Charles, as a trustee, but gave Mr. Lafferty authority to appoint the other three members of the board.
Mr. Lafferty, who has appointed the United States Trust Company of New York to serve as co-executor of the will, also was left a lifetime annuity of $500,000 a year.
Miss Duke's will also sets up or enlarges other foundations to benefit endangered wildlife, ecological causes and Southeast Asian art and culture, and makes specific bequests of $10 million each to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and Duke University in Durham, N.C., which was named for the family, and $1 million to the New York Zoological Society.
Miss Duke was the only child of James Buchanan Duke, who made fortunes as president of the American Tobacco Company and other interests and died in 1925, when she was 13. Her share of his $100 million estate was appraised in 1927 at $50 million, and she acquired more on her 25th and 30th birthdays. Her estate grew over the decades, mainly through investments and inflation.
Her palatial estates -- a New Jersey farm and a mansion in Newport, R.I., a Park Avenue penthouse in Manhattan, a Beverly Hills home and a Hawaiian retreat called Shangri-La -- also will be used to benefit charities, with some sold and others turned into museums.
Miss Duke's main residence, Duke Farms, a 2,700-acre ducal estate in Somerville, N.J., with a 30-room stone manor house, a private theater for her beloved movies, and with parks, farmlands and 42 miles of private roads, will be turned over to the various newly created Doris Duke foundations.
 
Homes Into Museums
 Her Newport, R.I., home, known as Rough Point, and Shangri-La, her vacation home on the coast of Oahu, are to be left to charitable foundations and turned into museums. The Beverly Hills home, formerly owned by Rudolph Valentino, and her Park Avenue penthouse will probably be sold and the proceeds given to the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation, lawyers familiar with the will said.
Miss Duke's closest surviving relative, Walker P. Inman Jr., a nephew, was left a $350,000-a-year annuity, but six cousins with whom she was not close, including Angier Biddle Duke, a former United States ambassador to Spain, Denmark and Morocco, were not named in the will.
Miss Duke also left sums ranging from $500,000 to $3 million to friends and bequests and annuities to scores of employees and confidantes. The largest cash bequest was $3 million to a friend, Eleanor Lawson, but Miss Duke also left $1 million each to four other friends, and 150 employees at her various estates received bequests based on their salaries and years of service.
Besides specific bequests, Miss Duke also forgave several unpaid loans that she had made to friends and acquaintances over the years.
But she directed her executor to collect $5 million that her friend Imelda Marcos, the wife of former Philippine president Ferdinand Marcos, had borrowed in 1988 to post bail after being indicted on Federal racketeering charges in New York. But the will said Mrs. Marcos need not repay the loan until she and the Philippine Government settle their longstanding financial dispute.
Miss Duke left some harsh words but no money in her will for her adopted daughter, Charlene Gail Heffner, who earlier this year filed a lawsuit in New Jersey seeking to be named the beneficiary of Miss Duke's estate. Ms. Heffner, known as Chandi, was adopted by Miss Duke in 1988, when she was 35 and Miss Duke was 75, but by 1991 their relationship had collapsed.
Ms. Heffner, a former adherent of the Hare Krisna religious group, contended in her lawsuit that Miss Duke had promised to make her the heir of her estate and to take care of her for the rest of her life in the style to which she had become accustomed during their few years together.
Miss Duke denied these contentions in court and sought to have the lawsuit dismissed, but a judge upheld Ms. Heffner's right to sue and the matter is still pending. Legal observers said the case would be closely watched because of its enormous potential consequences for the many charities that stand to benefit under Miss Duke's will.
And Miss Duke left no doubt about her feelings on the matter in her will, which stated that Ms. Heffner "not be deemed to be my child for purposes of disposing of my property under this [will]."
Miss Duke's will went on: "I am extremely troubled by the realization that Chandi Heffner may use my 1988 adoption of her (when she was 35 years old) to attempt to benefit financially under the terms of trusts created by my father. After giving the matter prolonged and serious consideration, I am convinced that I should not have adopted Chandi Heffner.
"I have come to the realization that her primary motive was financial gain. I believe that, like me, my father would not have wanted her to have benefitted under the trusts which he created, and similarly, I do not wish her to benefit from my estate."
Benjamin P. Michel, a Morristown, N.J., lawyer who represents Ms. Heffner, said yesterday that the lawsuit to gain control of the estate would continue. He declined to comment on the will, saying he had not yet seen a copy. But he said Miss Duke's comments on Ms. Heffner in the will "make no sense at all, given the nature of the relationship." He added: "It is very peculiar that such things could be said, even in the context of the lawsuit having been brought."
He said the lawsuit contended that Miss Duke had left Ms. Heffner in Hawaii "without a word as to anything having happened between the two of them," and that "thereafter they only spoke twice, and there was no word as to the why or wherefore of her abrupt departure. She just left with Bernard, the butler."
Mr. Michel identified Mr. Lafferty as a "personal traveling butler," who generally was with Miss Duke at her various homes and on her many journeys around the world. "As far as I know, he's the butler," Mr. Michel said.
Others familiar with Miss Duke's affairs said that Mr. Lafferty had been hired by Miss Duke six years ago as a butler, but that he had quickly become a confidant and adviser. Calling him the butler, they said, appeared to be an attempt to denigrate the closeness of his relationship to Miss Duke.
"She was the most important person in his life and he the most important person in her life," said Lloyd Kaplan of Howard J. Rubenstein Associates, a public relations firm representing Miss Duke. "They discussed every important decision and had a community of interests in art and culture. She had enormous respect and regard for him."
Emily Rafferty, vice president for development and membership of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said of the $10 million bequest: "It's obviously enormously generous. To my knowledge, we did not expect it. She was generous to this museum over the years, since the early 1980's." She said museum officials had not yet determined how the bequest would be used.
At Duke University, where chapel bells tolled 80 times and flags were at half-staff for Miss Duke last week, there were expressions of gratitude. "Miss Duke's bequest continues the remarkable philanthropic tradition of the Duke family to the university," Nannerl O. Keohane, the president, said. She recalled that Miss Duke's father had provided a founding endowment of $40 million in 1924, and that Miss Duke had given the university $2 million last year for AIDS research.
William M. Doyle Jr., a lawyer representing the estate's executors, said Miss Duke had envisioned that the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation, which will receive the bulk of her estate, would eventually become one of the nation's top philanthropic organizations, aiding causes for generations like the Ford, Rockefeller, MacArthur and other foundations.
In addition to the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation, the will establishes the Doris Duke Foundation for the Preservation of Endangered Wildlife and the Doris Duke Foundation for the Preservation of New Jersey Farmland and Farm Animals. Other organizations established by Miss Duke during her lifetime will also benefit, including the Newport Restoration Foundation, the Duke Gardens Foundation and the Foundation for Southeast Asian Art and Culture.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 12.02 Points to Another Record

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Another batch of encouraging economic news pushed blue-chip stocks to a new record yesterday but failed to ignite a broader rally. Investors seemed to be waiting for more information on the pace of the recovery before deciding whether to blanket the market with buy orders.
The Dow Jones industrial average hit its third record in about a week, rising 12.02 points, to 3,692.61. The Dow Jones transportation average, which has churned relentlessly through records in recent days, again reached another high, jumping 15.17 points, to 1,742.24. 
 But most of the rise in industrials came from International Paper, up 2 1/4 to 61 3/4, and I.B.M., up 1 3/4, to 47 3/4. Of the 30 stocks in the index, 14 were up, 14 were down and 2 were unchanged. Over all, about 10 stocks advanced on the New York Stock Exchange for every 9 that declined, indicating there was little depth to yesterday's gains.
The enthusiasm appeared to be limited mostly to the cyclicals -- stocks whose earnings tend to be linked to the economy -- and technology issues on both the Big Board and the secondary markets.
Traders said the cyclicals increased because investors were responding to the National Association of Purchasing Management's report that the domestic manufacturing sector expanded in October, while the Commerce Department reported that construction spending rose eight-tenths of 1 percent.
"People are betting that the economy is perking up," said William Raftery, vice president for technical research at Smith Barney Shearson.
He added that investors were also awaiting the Government's report about the October job market, to be released on Friday.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 256 million shares. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 1.27 points, to 469.10. The American Stock Exchange composite index increased 1.13 points, to 482.57. And the Nasdaq composite index shot up 4.51 points, to 783.77.
Among the cyclicals that rose yesterday were Allied Signal, up 1 to 72 5/8; CSX, up 1 1/2, to 82 1/2, and PPG Industries, up 1 1/2, to 71 1/4.
Paper stocks, which fell on Friday ahead of new industry regulations for air and water pollutants issued yesterday by the Environmental Protection Agency, rebounded. Besides International Paper, Georgia-Pacific jumped 2 3/8, to 66 5/8; Louisiana Pacific rose 2 1/8, to 38 3/8, and Weyerhaeuser rose 1, to 40 5/8.
Despite the gains in the cyclicals, some analysts stressed that the market remained choppy. Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist for Kemper Securities in Chicago, pointed out that the Dow Jones utility index rose only 0.40 point yesterday, to 241.17, and has slumped recently.
He said the drop reflected a simmering fear that after months of declines, interest rates would again rise. Utility companies are capital-intensive, so their stocks are sensitive to swings in interest rates.
The yield on the Treasury's main 30-year bond rose to 6.02 percent yesterday from 5.96 percent on Friday. Stocks often suffer when bond yields rise because investors switch to fixed-rate securities and corporate borrowing becomes more costly.
"The thing that has moved the market forward is that interest rates were going down," Mr. Chalasani said. "That may not be happening anymore.
"What you really have here is a rotation move still going on in the market where the technology stocks and some of the laggards -- like I.B.M. and Philip Morris -- are doing well. But you don't really have much participation."

HEADLINE: The 1993 CAMPAIGN: The Long Shots;
Candidates Who March To Different Drummers

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
There is another choice.
Contrary to what many disgruntled voters believe, the contest in the governor's race Tuesday is not simply between Christine Todd Whitman and Gov. Jim Florio. Seventeen independent candidates are also vying for the governorship, making this year's ballot the most crowded in history. 
 The independent candidates range from the experienced to the eccentric. They include a populist and a poet, a Libertarian and a candidate who wants to ship all criminals to the former Soviet Union.
Most have little money to get their message out. Many had no statewide exposure until last week, when New Jersey Network broadcast two half-hour programs showing 13 of the candidates reading prepared statements. Four candidates declined the network's invitation.
Here are the 17 candidates, their party affiliations, and brief descriptions of their positions:
Alene S. Ammond, For the People. Ms. Ammond, of Cherry Hill, is a former Democratic state senator, an advertising agency president and the director of an outfit called Public Policy Research Project. Ms. Ammond criticizes both major parties for links to special interests. She said she is the only independent candidate who can unseat Mr. Florio: "Only a new way of thinking and managing will reign in a government that is out of control."
Marilyn Arons, Maximum Citizen Involvement. Ms. Arons, of Teaneck, founder of a parents' rights group, says education is the central issue. She supports abortion rights, opposes capital punishment and proposes merging the education and human services operations of the state.
Tom Blomquist, New Jersey Conservative Party. Mr. Blomquist, of Brick Township, is making his second independent run for governor. He calls for term limits, an annual limit on property tax increases, and favors giving voters the right to abolish county governments.
Pat Daly, Abortion Is Murder. Ms. Daly, of Red Bank, is running as an anti-abortion candidate. Her ballot statement includes a call for teaching the Bible in public schools.
Pete Di Lauro, Common Sense Government. Mr. Di Lauro, of Leonardo, is a retired New York City police officer and a member of the state chapter of United We Stand, the Ross Perot group. "After choosing the less of two evils from both major political parties, we must come to the realization that this rationale just doesn't work," he said in his ballot statement.
Timothy S. Feeney, The Independent Choice. Mr. Feeney, a dentist from Little Falls, wants to cut government spending and increase mass transportation.
Tom Fuscaldo, Zero Sales Tax. Mr. Fuscaldo wants to end the sales tax and repeal the state semiautomatic weapons ban. "God bless friends in taxpayer associations, Right to Life, N.R.A., beekeeper associations and bottle collectors," said his ballot statement.
Jerry T. Grant, You and I. Mr. Grant, a car salesman of New Egypt, says he is a conservative. His ballot statements say he has a "very definite set of plans to return the government to the people," but does not say what they are. "Voting for Jerry T. Grant is like voting for yourself and voting for both you and I would be nice for a change," he said on his ballot statement.
Kenneth Kaplan, Libertarian Party. Mr. Kaplan, of Livingston, calls for privatizing the public school system and ending the war on drugs.
John L. Kucek, Populist Party. Mr. Kucek, a certified public accountant from North Plainfield, opposes gun control, calls for a ceiling on property taxes and proposes exporting criminals to the "now vacant Soviet gulags."
Andrea Lippi, People Purpose Progress. Mr. Lippi, formerly of Philadelphia and now of Goshen, is a real-estate investor who submitted "An Ode to New Jersey" as his ballot statement. It read, in part:
Along the Delaware and the Hudson
From ocean beaches to mountain high,
In a mecca of earthly beauty
Does the State of New Jersey lie.
Richard J. Lynch, Independents 4 Change. Mr. Lynch, a businessman of Moorestown, said he would bring a businessman's sensibility to the governorship. He said he would reduce the budget by $4 million a year for two years and train state managers to prepare zero-based budgets.
Joseph Marion, Independent Party. Mr. Marion, of Ho-Ho-Kus, is a businessman who promises to cut government bureaucracy and create jobs by focusing on the needs of small business.
Mark J. Rahn, Socialist Workers Party. Mr. Rahn said he would fight to build an international workers' movement to demand, among other things, a 30-hour workweek and an emergency public-works program for cities.
Michael R. Scully, Fresh Start. Mr. Scully, a lawyer from Hawthorne, said he would repeal the entire tax package passed by the legislature in 1990. He said both major party candidates have ignored education, crime, health care and race relations.
Andrew Zemel, Integrity-Common Sense. Mr. Zemel, of South Orange, has a five-point "E plan" that includes unspecified measures on education, employment, economy, environment and equal opportunity.
Michael Ziruolo, Better Affordable Government. Mr. Ziruolo is a Jersey City tenants' rights advocate who ran for governor in 1989.

HEADLINE: Key Corporate Tax Case to Be Heard

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Accepting a state tax case with important implications for international tax policy, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Constitution limits the ability of states to tax multinational corporations on a portion of their earnings beyond the state's borders.
The Court's action surprised nearly everyone who has followed the case, and handed the Clinton Administration a political predicament as unwelcome as it was unexpected. 
 At issue is a method that California applied until last month to tax the income of both foreign and domestic multinational corporations.
 
The 'Unitary' Approach

 
 The method, known as worldwide combined reporting, made no distinction between subsidiaries doing business in California and those operating elsewhere. The entire business was instead treated as "unitary" and subject to California tax on a portion of its worldwide income reflecting California's share of its overall property, payroll and sales.
The California approach has long angered the United States' trading partners. The Federal Government, as well as most states and foreign countries, uses an arm's-length accounting method under which each affiliated corporation is treated as a separate entity, subject to tax only in the jurisdiction in which it operates and for the income it realizes on its own books.
The California law was challenged by the London-based Barclays Bank in a tax-refund suit that had the support not only of the British Government, but also of the Bush Administration when the case first reached the Court in early 1992. At that time, the Court declined for procedural reasons to hear the case.
 
Candidate Clinton's Stance
 Campaigning then in California as a Presidential candidate, Bill Clinton promised California tax officials that in contrast to the Bush White House, "a Clinton Administration will be pro-California in this litigation."
Barclays, which lost its case before the California Court of Appeal, appealed again to the Supreme Court earlier this year, and the Justices asked the Clinton Administration for its views.
Faced with balancing longstanding Federal tax policy against the President's campaign promise, the Administration held off until last month, acting a day after the California Legislature repealed the disputed tax policy amid increasing pressure from the state's corporate taxpayers. Skirting the legal merits of the case, the Administration's brief said there was now no need to consider Barclays's appeal.
The Court today, however, granted review not only in Barclays case, Barclays v. Franchise Tax Board, No. 92-1384, but also agreed to hear another challenge to the California law brought by the Colgate-Palmolive Company. Like Barclays, Colgate is a multinational, but unlike Barclays, it is based in the United States.
Ten years ago, in a landmark tax case, Container Corporation v. Franchise Tax Board, the Supreme Court upheld the application of California's unitary tax to a domestic multinational, so the Court's action today was especially surprising. By granting review in Colgate-Palmolive v. Franchise Tax Board, No. 92-1839, the Court is at least implying that this entire approach to taxation is under review and that the Container case could be overruled.
In the 1983 Container decision, the Court did not address the application of the California tax to foreign multinationals, saying only that the outcome would be governed by the Constitution's foreign commerce clause, which gives Congress the power "to regulate commerce with foreign nations."
In light of today's action, the question now seems to be whether the foreign commerce clause really makes a difference in the Court's analysis, or whether the two situations should be treated similarly.
Several other states have laws like California's former law, but none of those states come close to having an economy the size of California's. California says it faces a potential refund liability of $4 billion if its former tax is found to be unconstitutional. "I'd be concerned if I were California," Mark L. Evans, a tax lawyer here who has followed the cases, said today.
 
Cigarette Tax Case From New York
 In another tax-related case, the Court accepted an appeal from the New York State Department of Taxation and agreed to decide whether the state can regulate the sale of cigarettes on Indian reservations.
Sales made on reservations to Indian purchasers cannot be taxed, under a doctrine known as tribal sovereign immunity. Sales made on reservations to non-Indians are subject to tax, but states have typically had difficulty enforcing the law because many non-Indians visit reservations to buy untaxed merchandise.
The New York Court of Appeals ruled in the summer, in a suit brought by a non-Indian wholesaler, that New York's latest effort, a coupon system intended to limit a tribe's acquisition of untaxed cigarettes to the amount that tribal members will actually consume, was pre-empted by Federal law. The state's appeal is New York v. Milhelm Attea Bros., No. 93-377.

HEADLINE: Data Show Factories Picking Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The economy's manufacturing sector expanded in October for the first time in five months, with 15 of 20 industries surpassing their September performance, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported today.
The sharp increase in the association's monthly index of manufacturing activity, to 53.8 percent from 49.7 percent, was bigger than expected and confirmed the views of various analysts that the economy's general acceleration was spreading to factories. 
 The association's report is based on data collected from purchasing executives in more than 300 companies. The index measures the percentage of positive responses plus half of those calling conditions unchanged. A reading above 50 percent means the factory sector is expanding; sustained readings above 44.5 percent mean the overall economy is expanding.
 
'All 8 Cylinders'
 "We're probably at a point where we may have an economy hitting on all eight cylinders," contended Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist for ASB Capital Management, a Washington investment manager.
In a second encouraging report today, construction spending -- from homes to highways -- climbed eight-tenths of 1 percent in September, according to the Commerce Department. While the gain appeared no larger than anticipated, it came on top of sizable upward revisions for both July and August.
The survey of purchasing managers, the first important indicator published each month, reflected the fastest manufacturing pace since February of the economy at large.
 
Backlog Termed Improved
 "A surge in new orders provided the fuel for significant improvement in the over-all economy and a sharp reversal in the manufacturing sector toward healthy growth," said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the trade group's survey committee. "Moreover, the significant improvement in the backlog of orders suggests continued growth in this final quarter of 1993."
Despite these advances, analysts said that new factory jobs were likely to remain scarce.
"There's ample inventory on hand to meet the first wave of further increases in demand," said David H. Resler, chief economist for Nomura Securities International in New York. "So it's not likely to translate very quickly into more hiring."
Factory jobs declined again in October, though at a slower pace, with the result that the association's employment index moved up a point, to 45.5 percent, the highest since March.
A common expectation is that the Labor Department's monthly labor market report, to be published Friday, will show factory jobs stopped declining in October.
Another cautionary voice today was that of Gordon Richards, economist for the National Association of Manufacturers. He said that the size of the jump in the purchasing managers' index should be considered a "statistical anomaly" since the index has for several months risen much more slowly than the Federal Reserve index of industrial production.
 
Autos' Fast Pace
 In addition to this "catching up," Mr. Richards said, the October advance reflected an unsustainably high pace of auto assemblies that would reverse later this quarter.
The industries posting the biggest improvement last month, the report showed, were plastics and rubber; furniture; fabricated metals; leather; electronic components and equipment; transportation equipment; petroleum; food; primary metals, and chemicals.
The least improvement was in textiles; tobacco; printing, and glass, stone and aggregate.
Production and new orders climbed to their highest rates since March and January, respectively, while backlogs of orders grew substantially after falling in September, the report also showed. New export orders rose for the third straight month while imports declined slightly for the fourth straight month.
The construction report showed spending on public projects jumped 1.7 percent while the private-sector gain, concentrated in residential work, was held to three-tenths of 1 percent, the department found.
