HEADLINE: A Voyage Into the Abyss: Gloom, Gold and Godzilla

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

DATELINE: ABOARD ATLANTIS 2

 BODY:
FLASHES of light from luminescent creatures swirled in the darkness past our windows as we descended a mile and a half to a fiery gash on the ocean floor, to what scientists increasingly see as a colossal, hidden engine of creation.
After falling for more than an hour, we switched on the lights of our tiny, three-person submarine. There, barely illuminated in the gloom, some 250 miles off the Oregon coast, lay endless fields of gnarled lava, frozen in the midst of an eruptive frenzy by the icy sea water. 
 A string of scientific discoveries have revealed that over the eons such rocks have played a major role in shaping the planet. Volcanic fissures in the ocean floor gird the earth like seams on a baseball. All told, they measure some 40,000 miles. Though hidden from sight, zigging this way and that through the deep, often veiled by undersea mountains, they make up one of the planet's dominant and most dynamic features.
Spewing molten lava and blistering hot water, these rifts of fire are the place where planetary crust is formed, where oceans and continents are created, where the sea gets much of its chemical identity, where precious metals like gold are concentrated and where bizarre creatures that never see sunlight feast on chemicals made by the earth's inner heat. Perhaps most important, they are the place where life itself may have begun billions of years ago.
Our tiny submarine, Alvin, was just ending a 16-day voyage of discovery to one corner of this alien world, the Juan de Fuca ridge off the West Coast of the United States.
The effort was prompted by a recent undersea eruption here, which, in an oceanographic first, was monitored by scientists as the sea floor shook and then studied by six expeditions from the United States and Canada. The last and largest of these featured Alvin, whose mission was to probe deeper than ever before into the heart of undersea creation.
Among other things, we found the sea floor alive with fresh flows of lava and blizzards of white bacteria surging upward on hot-water plumes. After days of frustration caused by bad weather and enigmatic clues of deep activity in one area, we discovered a field of towering chimneys spewing super-hot water and surrounded by strange forms of life, some apparently never before seen.
There were thickets of tiny tube worms, odd growths of beard-like bacteria, legions of tiny white crab-like creatures and, on rocks facing some mineral towers, delicate networks of colonial organisms whose tentacles reached out toward the monoliths like worshipers at a temple. Scientists said these creatures appeared to be corals, which if true would be a first.
"It's exciting as hell!" said Dr. John R. Delaney, a geologist from the University of Washington who led the expedition. "I'm blown away that they pay me to do this stuff."
 
The History
 From Dead Abyss To Cradle of Life
 The ocean abysses used to be thought of as geologically dead and having only a thin population of bizarre fish, mainly scavengers living off a drizzle of detritus from above. It was considered a graveyard, basically inert and irrelevant.
Discoveries over the last 40 years have shown the truth to be the opposite. The abysses are the birthplace of the fissures where the ocean plates are moving apart, so that the line of fissures along the mid-Atlantic, say, mirrors the coastlines of the once united continents between which the Atlantic emerged.
The abysses also teem with special forms of life that cluster around vents of very hot water and are adapted to the heat and chemistry of the volcanic eruptions. The first community of strange animals was discovered in 1977 off the Galapagos Islands. These animals thrived on substances that to all others were toxic.
As similar communities were found on other midocean ridges, scientists theorized that life on Earth may have begun at undersea geysers, nurtured by a steady diet of warm chemicals and protected from hurtling rocks and blasts of radiation from outer space that pounded the planet's surface in its early days.
 
A Chimney Named Godzilla
 Among the strangest discoveries at the hot vents were giant towers of rock, dubbed chimneys and smokers, that discharged very hot water, often gray or jet black. The towers built as suspended minerals in the super-hot fluid were precipitated by icy sea water. One such structure recently discovered on the Juan de Fuca ridge is more than 15 stories high. It is nicknamed Godzilla. Nearby vents gush water as hot as 750 degrees, which is kept from boiling by the crushing pressures of the abyss. Mineral-rich plumes from such vents have been found to spread across thousands of miles of ocean.
By some estimates, up to 70 percent of the earth's internal heat flows through such zones, which every eight million years filter a volume of water equal to all the world's oceans. Such processes play major roles in determining the planet's heat and chemical balances.
Gold was found in some vents during the 1980's, igniting a rush of precious-metal analysis. Many billions of dollars' worth of rich ores, including zinc, silver, gold and copper, were soon estimated to lie hidden among the midocean rifts. In March 1983, President Ronald Reagan nearly doubled the size of the United States by declaring sovereignty over nearby ocean floors, inspired in part by the allure of sea-bed riches.
To date, private companies have found mining the deep ocean too expensive. But they have raced to exploit the new findings for clues to mineral wealth on land, hunting for slices of ancient sea floor.
"The work on the ridges is really in its infancy," said Dr. Randolph A. Koski, an economic geologist on the voyage from the United States Geological Survey. Among other things, his agency is assessing the likelihood of an undersea gold rush sometime in the future. To date, Dr. Koski said, less than 1 percent of the volcanic ridges have been studied close up.
 
The Breakthrough
 Researchers Rush To Site of Eruption
 The mysteries of this world are many. For instance, no one knows for sure how water flows through the midocean ridges, whether from the sides or along the axes. In general, deep hot rock is thought to cause the sea floor to crack. Water then trickles down, encounters magma and is heated. The hot fluid leaches minerals out of the ocean crust as it flows upward to the surface. But this is just an educated guess, scientists stress.
"The dynamics are basically unknown," said Dr. H. Paul Johnson, a physicist at the University of Washington who was on the voyage to study geomagnetism as a clue to vent action.
No detailed studies have been done of active volcanism at sea, especially the subtleties of how and when hot springs form. Opportunities for observation are few. Expeditions to sites of interest usually last only days and are often cut short by bad weather. Scientists have at times stumbled on volcanic outbursts, but have never witnessed the birth of hot-water vents and their associated colonies.
All that began to change on June 22 when a small laboratory of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in Newport, Ore., was electronically linked to a formerly secret Navy network for listening to ocean noises and enemy submarines. Only four days later, the lab recorded a sea-floor eruption along the Juan de Fuca ridge. For two days, moving south to north, swarms of sea quakes shook an area some 25 miles in length, implying that lava was surging out of the earth to form new sea floor.
In response, an ad hoc alliance of universities, Federal agencies and the Canadian Government launched six forays (most rerouted from already planned voyages) to examine the site with undersea sensors, robots and a mini-submarine. The Alvin expedition was financed by the National Science Foundation and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, both of which have formal programs to study undersea ridges and vents.
 
The Expedition
 Probing for Clues In Inky Darkness
 Alvin is a white, 25-foot-long research submersible that can carry three people to a depth of 2.5 miles. Inside the sub is a seven-foot titanium sphere that carries not only the pilot and two observers but all the vessel's electronics and life-support gear. Alvin and its support ship, Atlantis 2, which is 210 feet long, were built more than a quarter century ago but are still on the cutting edge of deep-sea exploration. They are operated by the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution on Cape Cod.
The sub has two mechanical arms, and its exterior racks can hold cameras, sonars, temperature probes, animal traps, water-sample bottles and magnetometers. Its variable buoyancy allows it to carry scientific payloads of vastly different weights. The sub dives only in daylight, when launch and recovery are safest.
The Atlantis 2 left Astoria, Ore., on Oct. 9 with 52 people on board. A day later, it reached the quake zone and lowered a network of electronic buoys to the sea floor. During dives, Alvin would chirp and the distant buoys would beep in response, letting the sub continuously fix its position even in the inky darkness.
Dr. Delaney, the expedition's chief scientist, told his team they had a "historic opportunity" to discover how the vents formed and evolved. The plan was for the submarine to work its way southward during the day, while at night unmanned sensors and cameras were towed on long cables from the ship in wide searches for likely observational targets.
The sky was gray and the sea was relatively calm during Alvin's first dive. One of two scientists who went down was Dr. Marvin D. Lilley of the University of Washington, a chemist. "Save the Tube Worms," read the logo on his T-shirt.
The scientists that day explored part of a 1.5-mile stretch of freshly erupted and still-glassy lava in the northern quake region. One volcanic vent spewed shimmering water whose temperature was measured at 97 degrees, up from the near-freezing 35 degrees in the surrounding waters. But there were no signs of new life or mineral chimneys.
 
Colonies of Bacteria
 After three days, the team moved some 10 miles south to an area known from earlier work to have many particles in the water, mainly matted bacteria. Temperatures were measured at up to 65 degrees. Clumps of waving bacteria would occasionally break loose from the fissures, joining a swirl of biologic snow.
The scientists believed the bacterial storms were related to the recent outburst, though lava there was clearly old. Their thesis was that fresh magma lay just beneath the sea floor, heating the water and creating an ideal environment for bacterial growth.
At night, scientists from the Seattle-based Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration would tow a sensor up and down through the water column as the ship moved forward. Over several nights, they found at the southern end of the quake region a strong signal indicating high heat, chemicals and particulate matter -- signs of a large vent field.
That area was nicknamed the Source site, since it was where the sea quakes had begun as magma deep in the earth surged upward.
But Alvin's initial dives there were disappointing, and the expedition quickly moved back to the bacterial site. On one dive, a time-lapse video camera and a temperature probe, both battery powered, were left near an energetic vent to track its evolution for up to a year.
 
The Source
 A Tangle of Life About a Monolith
 As the second week began, the scientists renewed their search for the Source. But dive after dive found little of interest, and even the unmanned instruments lost evidence of strong activity. The sky turned dark, the seas high. On the night of Oct. 22, just before all operations were shut down by bad weather, a towed sensor suddenly reported a series of exceptionally strong signals, helping pinpoint a likely target.
As Atlantis 2 rode out the rough weather, Alvin could do no work during the last two scheduled dive days. With a discovery so close, Dr. Delaney asked Woods Hole if the expedition could be extended a day, gambling that the weather would break. Woods Hole said yes.
On Oct. 24, scattered clouds were shot with gold from the rising sun as Dr. Delaney and this reporter climbed into Alvin to descend more than a thousand fathoms into the darkness in search of the Source. "May the force be with you," a dive controller aboard the ship said over the hydrophone as we began our descent.
The cramped sphere was surprisingly comfortable, lined with soft cushions, feeling like a college dorm packed with stereos and high-tech gear. Outside my observation port there flashed the lights of an endless procession of gelatinous organisms, some seemingly a foot or two in length. Ripples of light would pass along their bodies as we swept past them.
We reached bottom around 9:30 A.M. and proceeded to fly over endless fields of pillow-shaped lava. After an hour of fruitless searching, we came upon a Reebok shoe that had sunk into the abyss, a jarring discovery given the gravity of our pursuit.
Slowly our tiny sphere grew colder. Water vapor began to condense on exposed metal parts of the titanium hull, forming a glistening sheen. I put on a sweater.
Then, at 11:30 A.M., after what seemed like many hours of viewing interminable mounds of lava, we came upon a giant chimney looming up out of the dark, spewing water that shimmered with motion.
"It's hot," reported our pilot, Robert J. Grieve. "It's got tube worms all over it."
A riot of life flourished on and around the unworldly monolith, which loomed three or four stories high. The tube worms were four or five inches long, their red tips emerging from brown outer cases. The chimney's surface was spread with mats of white bacteria and iridescent, dark red palm worms about an inch long. Smaller still were orange worms covered with tiny bristles. The chimney's surface also crawled with swarms of miniature lobsters known as galatheids.
Remarkably, this tangle of life included at least two types of small corals that were heavy with spines, polyps and tentacles. "We've never seen corals among tube worms before," Dr. Cindy Van Dover, a biologist on the voyage from Woods Hole, said later. "It's going to be neat to figure out how the corals make a living."
 
Warm Bed of Creatures
 Surrounding the tower, often lurking behind rocks, were other creatures. There were large sea anemones topped with explosions of tentacles, orangeish-brown spider crabs the size of dinner plates, and more corals, reaching with tentacles toward the chimney like religious devotees.
That day we had time to examine five large chimneys in all. Some small ones in the area were actively venting but naked of life and quickly crumbled in a cloud of debris when Alvin's mechanical arm tried to grab them. The hottest water we measured coming out of vents that day was 543 degrees. At the base of one chimney we left a battery-powered temperature sensor, to be retrieved next year.
Suddenly, our pilot noticed that the temperature of the submarine's skin was starting to rise. By accident, we had positioned ourselves over a vent, a potentially dangerous thing to do since the sub's plastic windows can melt. We quickly began our ascent, exhausted and happy.
Later, back on the ship, Dr. Delaney said the field appeared to be a pre-existing one that had been reactivated by the June eruption. The chimneys were generally big, he noted. But there were also small, fresh ones easily broken apart, as well as creatures that were unusually small, like the tiny lobsters, which were mostly youngsters.
Dr. Delaney held out the possibility that the field might be new, stressing how little was known about chimney growth rates. Ultimately, the field's age will be determined by future studies of the expedition's data and samples.
Over all, he said, the voyage would aid the worldwide effort to better comprehend deep volcanism.
"Catching an event at the beginning and watching its evolution is an essential part of the understanding process," Dr. Delaney said.

HEADLINE: France Hasn't Slipped Off Charts

 BODY:

To the Editor:
As a student of international relations, I have spent considerable time studying France and the European Community. I am greatly impressed by "Has France Gone Bonkers?" (Op-Ed, Oct. 18) by Flora Lewis. I take issue, however, with how she points to the supposed end of France as a "great power" by making vague reference to the strength of a reunified Germany. 
 I fail to understand the habit of many United States journalists of judging the "great power" status of France and of other European countries by making selective comparisons to Germany.
It is true that with German reunification, France's relative population, size and industrial infrastructure are smaller. However, this says less about a decline in France's power than about a rise in Germany's.
How, then, do we measure "power status"? I do not maintain that comparison is an inappropriate tool, but it must be used more broadly. Judging France's power by holding it up to any one other country, even to its largest trading partner, is imprecise.
In measuring the power of a country, it is more accurate to compare the country with a wide array of others if not with the entire world. By these criteria, "great powers" are the few countries that lead the world in a variety of economic, political and military areas.
In any statistical appraisal of relative national power, France is almost always among the top four or five countries in the world. France is the world's second largest exporter of services and of agriculture. It is the fourth industrial exporter and has, depending on how you count, the third or fourth largest nuclear arsenal in the world.
France also remains a leader in many other "great power" pursuits like arms production, telecommunications, aerospace, finance and overseas military intervention. While France may never rival the "superpowers" of the cold war era in terms of its influence and power, it certainly is a "great power" by any objective, global measure.
To say that Germany has become stronger, then, does not imply France is weaker. If anything, France benefits when its largest trading partner and ally experiences growth in economic and political potential.
This makes France's foot-dragging over the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade all the more regrettable. If France were a marginal country with declining power, nobody would be worried about its efforts to scuttle the Uruguay Round.
On the other hand, if the French perceived their own position more accurately, maybe they would not be trying so hard.
 
MARK LIBBY
Somerville, Mass., Oct. 25, 1993

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Jams Already on Data Highway

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Call it a cautionary tale for the information age: The nation's increasingly popular data highway is beginning to groan under the load of rush-hour traffic.
The problem, computer and telecommunications experts say, is that the computer network called the Internet, once a cozy community of a few thousand computer scientists, engineers and programmers who quietly and freely shared their on-line data, has suddenly been besieged by millions of newcomers. Anyone with a personal computer and a modem can easily and cheaply gain access to the Internet, a global web of thousands of computer networks. 
 The Internet has been widely hailed as a here-and-now precursor to the interactive 500-channel cable television systems of the future. But the information highway metaphor is proving all too literal, as traffic jams become increasingly common.
 Although service providers charge usage fees for the telephone lines that connect individuals to the Internet, most of the on-line information is free for the taking. As a result, highly prized digital information that has been freely available to any and all -- like free software, National Weather Service satellite photos and on-line searches of the Library of Congress catalogue -- is now sometimes inaccessible to almost everyone as a clamoring horde overwhelms the computer data bases.
 
 
A Waiting Game
 "It's just like when everybody flocks to a beach on a Sunday," said David Farber, a University of Pennsylvania computer scientist who is one of the nation's computer network pioneers. "Guess what happens. You sit in the car and wait and wait and wait."
Everywhere on the global Internet, which is now roamed by an estimated 15 million computer users, the growth rates are staggering.
At the National Center for Supercomputer Applications in Champaign, Ill., a new service that answers requests to an electronic library called the World Wide Web, has seen the number of daily queries explode from almost 100,000 requests in June to almost 400,000 in October. Officials at the center say the only solution may be to take a $15 million supercomputer away from its normal scientific number-crunching duties and employ it full time as an electronic librarian.
This year, information retrieved using a popular searching program called Gopher increased more than 400 percent, to almost 200 billion bytes a month -- about seven million newspaper pages.
In Ann Arbor, Mich., where an on-line provider, MSEN Inc., has made a career-counseling data base available free through the Internet, usage shot up from 1,000 queries a day when the doors opened in June to 12,000 a day on Monday of this week. Until MSEN is able to afford a bigger computer, it will have to turn away any additional queries each day.
And consider the plight of the operators of the Panix Public Access Network, a small outfit based in New York that for more than four years has quietly provided its 1,500 customers with a convenient electronic on-ramp to the data highway. Late last month, after word leaked out that the company's computers had been broken into by a computer intruder intent on stealing passwords, thousands of curiosity seekers decided to take a look at the Panix network -- the digital equivalent of driving by the scene of the accident.
They were able to do so by each remotely activating a tiny program on the Panix system that in computer parlance is called a finger demon. Such programs are a convenient way of determining everyone who is currently connected to a computer on a network, and modern systems can comfortably run hundreds of these programs at once.
But not thousands. So when thousands of passers-by decided to gawk simultaneously, Panix suddenly came grinding to a halt.
"It was a traffic jam caused by rubberneckers on the nation's data highway," said Marc Rotenberg, an executive at the Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility, a public interest group based in Washington.
With the number of Internet users doubling each year, these kinds of glitches seem bound to continue, many experts say, unless technical and economic changes are made in what has until now been a disorganized and largely voluntary system.
 
Electronic Word of Mouth
 "Free services like those on the Internet can't continue indefinitely," said Alexis Rosen, the president and founder of the Panix service. Because informal news about events on the network flows so quickly through electronic word of mouth, what Mr. Rosen called "flash crowds" are beginning to appear with increasing frequency to instantly clog computer systems.
Recently, for example, a Panix subscriber, Adam Curry, who is a host on the MTV music-video network, began posting an electronic gossip sheet on Panix with spicy tidbits on Madonna's private life. Available free over the Internet, Mr. Curry's gossip sheet soon drew a crowd that began to jam the Panix system, threatening to slow service for other users. The company told Mr. Curry that he had to change the way he distributed his gossip sheet.
So Mr. Curry has set up his own host computer with his own Internet address: called mtv.com. There, his computer correspondents can call up his Cyber Sleaze Report and other documents. He plans to finance his electronic gossip mill through $10 contributions.
"If there is a lesson to be learned it is that you must create technical fixes for these problems because you can't create social fixes," Mr. Rosen said.
An obvious solution to Internet gridlock might seem to be simply adding "bandwidth" -- the digital equivalent of adding more data lanes to the information highway. That, in fact, is the master plan being pursued through the multibillion-dollar installations of fiber-optic cable by the nation's cable television and phone companies. But for their 500-channel networks of the future, the cable and phone companies are still trying to fathom what types of vast computer data bases will be necessary for serving tens of thousands of simultaneous requests for information.
 
Waiting in Line
 For current Internet service providers, higher-capacity data networks would only further overwhelm the abilities of many of the data base computers on the network.
"After you get off the ramp from the data highway you have to wait in line at the gas station," said Allan Weis, the president of Advanced Networks and Services Inc., a joint venture of the International Business Machines Corporation and the MCI Communications Corporation. Advanced Networks and Services maintains one of the Internet's high-speed "backbone" networks on behalf of the National Science Foundation.
Mr. Weis has found that the traffic jams are not limited to the small data bases on desktop work stations that are springing up all over the Internet. Hooking up his company's high- speed network to high-volume information providers has forced them to increase the capacity of their systems as well, he said.
"We have 25 information providers on the networks, and more and more of them are experiencing scaling problems," Mr. Weis said, referring to the scramble to increase data-base access. "They have to take information and deal with it more quickly."
The problem of data congestion is not a new one to the Internet, which came close to collapse in 1987 before its underlying technology was substantially upgraded.
Economists who have studied the Internet say that one potential way to ease the approaching gridlock will be to charge for services, thereby generating the capital to meet the required performance upgrades.
"There are people who say, 'This is terrible; it would crowd out deserving users,' " said Hal Varian, an economist at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. "But the costs will be very low because the technology is so efficient."
 
Rethinking Free Information
 Barry Shein of Brookline, Mass., is a battle-scarred Internet veteran who is rethinking the idea of free information. Mr. Shein is president of the World, a commercial service that provides Internet access to almost 6,000 users for a small monthly fee.
Last November, on Election Day, the World teamed up with a local newspaper to offer updates every half-hour on the Presidential and local elections. The small company was not prepared for the deluge -- tens of thousands of electronic queries from Internet users in more than 40 countries. The average system load, normally between six and eight at any one time, jumped as high as 300. Only by quickly rewriting parts of his computer's software was Mr. Shein able to patch together a system that could temporarily handle the load without crashing.
A Silicon Valley entrepreneur who sees vast market opportunities in the Internet is Steve Kirsch, an engineer in San Jose, Calif. His new company, Infoseek, plans to begin offering a commercial version of the information retrieval systems that are now free in the Internet early next year.
Acting as a clearinghouse for newspapers and other electronic publishers, Infoseek would bill customers based on their use of the network. Mr. Kirsch believes that his pay-as-you-go services will be immune from any gridlock
"The more customers we have using information," he said, "the more money we have to spend to handle the load."

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Long Island;
Gulotta Slips Past Opponent To Remain Nassau Chief

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Wednesday, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Thomas S. Gulotta, the incumbent Nassau County Executive who ran on a platform calling for change, squeaked by his Democratic challenger, Benjamin L. Zwirn, Tuesday night in a contest that was widely seen as a referendum on decades of Republican rule.
With about half the vote counted, Mr. Gulotta had 51.9 percent of the vote to 48.1 percent for Mr. Zwirn, the Supervisor of North Hempstead. 
 Mr. Gulotta declared victory about 12:30 A.M., saying, "This was the sweetest victory of all."
"We had to run this year not only against a Democratic candidate," he said. "We had to run against an anti-incumbent sentiment."
"But worst of all," he added, "we had to run against a newspaper," referring to Newsday and its heavy coverage of the race that Mr. Gulotta charged was biased against him.
This victory proves, he continued, that "the Republican Party in this county is alive and well."
 
Talk of Impounding Machines
 Mr. Zwirn refused to concede and talked about impounding the voting machines. "Our numbers show us ahead," he added.
Mr. Gulotta's narrow victory was seen by some as an affirmation of the loyalty that Mr. Gulotta has cultivated among voters over his 18-year political career. And it showed that the county's vaunted Republican organization, despite recent setbacks, could still command thousands of votes, even in the face of a charismatic opponent with a powerful message.
In other races on Long Island, the incumbent Republican District Attorneys, James M. Catterson Jr. of Suffolk and Denis E. Dillon of Nassau, handily defeated their Democratic opponents, respectively Patrick Kevin Brosnahan and Timothy Calonita. With more than half the vote counted, at about 11:15 P.M., Mr. Catterson declared victory with 56 percent of the vote to Mr. Brosnahan's 40 percent. At about the same time, Mr. Dillon had amassed about 60 percent with a little more than one-third of the vote counted.
 
Incumbent Supervisors Win
 In Nassau County there were decisive victories for all the incumbent members of the Board of Supervisors: Lewis J. Yevoli of Oyster Bay, a Democrat; Bruce Nyman of Long Beach, a Democrat, and Gregory P. Peterson and Richard V. Guardino, both Republicans of Hempstead.
And as expected, Frederick E. Parola Jr., the Republican candidate for Comptroller, decisively defeated his Democratic opponent, Edward J. Shapiro, with about 58 percent with more than half of the vote counted.
In the race for Suffolk County Legislature, with about 75 percent of the vote counted at about midnight, it appeared that the balance of power remained unchanged. Democrats held onto their seven seats, and the Republican-Conservative caucus had 11 members on the 18-seat Legislature.
But it was the Nassau County executive race that had drawn most of the attention on Long Island in recent months, and Mr. Gulotta's victory proved that despite a recession that ravaged the county's finances, he and the Republicans had not lost their iron grip on the county government.
 
A Test of Party Strength
 The election was seen as test of the Nassau Republican Party, an organization often considered to be the most powerful political machine in the country. For decades this party, which has served as the base for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and other national Republican figures, has dominated the politics of this suburban county of about 1.3 million.
But in recent years, the party has lost several important local elections and had close calls in others. And with Nassau now having some of the highest taxes in the nation and the county government borrowing millions of dollars just to balance its budget, many political analysts believed that the race for county executive, Nassau's top political position, would be close.
Officials in both parties agreed that this race was the toughest that Mr. Gulotta had faced in his 18-year political career.
Many Democrats attributed the loss largely to the large war chest Mr. Gulotta had amassed, and they cited the closeness as proof of voters' disapproval of the Republican incumbent. The race was the most expensive County Executive race in Nassau history, with Mr. Gulotta spending more than $2 million to roughly $700,000 for Mr. Zwirn.
 
A Sign of Confidence
 But Republicans claimed the win as a sign of confidence in their candidate. They said that voters had a special place in their hearts for the Gulotta name, a familiarity that Mr. Gulotta had developed over the years by diligently attending thousands of ceremonial events from bar mitzvahs to senior lunches to Kiwanis meetings, and by seeing that government provided basic services to his constituents.
Mr. Gulotta's popularity was also aided by his family's fame in Nassau: his father was a prominent Nassau politician, a District Attorney and then a Supreme Court Judge, and many older voters still feel a special loyalty to him.
As a result, Mr. Gulotta has long been one of the party's most prolific vote-getters. And today's election was his 10th straight victory.
But this year Mr. Gulotta was facing an opponent, Mr. Zwirn, who had made a name for himself by becoming the first Democrat elected Supervisor of North Hempstead in 73 years. Mr. Zwirn had a record of being able to draw the support of Republicans because of his fiscal conservatism. In an appeal to Republicans and independents, Mr. Zwirn ran an anti-incumbency campaign that promised to cut government spending, reduce taxes and end Republican patronage.
 
A Promise of Reform
 As a response, in a shift from his past campaigns, Mr. Gulotta ran on the promise that he would reform the old order and the contention that he was the most experienced candidate to change Nassau. His campaign also emphasized that he was a man that voters knew and could trust. And while he rarely detailed his achievements in office or his plans for the future, his campaign portrayed him as a steady hand, who had made tough decisions in tough economic times and had brought the county through the recession.
In the most expensive political advertising campaign in county history, Mr. Gulotta portrayed himself as an agent of change and coined the slogan: "Tom Gulotta, For a New Nassau." The ads featured a number of proposed changes in county government (which Mr. Zwirn also supported).
And Mr. Gulotta's campaign also broadcast a series of commercials that redefined Mr. Zwirn, casting him as a "Liberal, Through and Through." They also raised other criticisms, such as Mr. Zwirn's failure to vote for six years, that were intended to raise doubts about his character.
"Gulotta had to do something to dissuade voters that he was not the old-style machine Republican," said Stanley B. Klein, a political science professor at the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University. "They defined a different Gulotta, who was young, who was aggressive, who was the man for change, who they never mentioned had come up through the ranks of the Republican Party, and at the same time they were drilling in publicity that the Democrats were tax and spend people and that Ben Zwirn was a liberal tax-and-spend Democrat."
"They described Zwirn to the voter, and that's who the voter saw," he said.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Jump By 20.8%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Inspired by mortgage rates under 7 percent, buyers snapped up new homes in September at the fastest pace since 1986, a performance that far surpassed expectations, Government figures showed today. All regions boomed except the Northeast, where sales eased slightly.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department index designed to forecast the economy climbed five-tenths of 1 percent for September, the first time this year there have been sizable back-to-back gains. 
 Today's figures added to the mounting evidence of economic acceleration and once again prompted a selloff in the credit markets, driving interest rates higher on fears of revived inflation. [Page D20.] The Dow Jones industrial average finished the day up 5.03 points at a new record. [Page D10.]
 
 
'Very Impressive'
 Sales of new single-family homes jumped 20.8 percent for the month, the biggest gain since September 1986, the Commerce Department and the Department of Housing and Urban Development jointly reported. The annual sales pace, 762,000 adjusted for recurrent seasonal swings, was the fastest since December 1986.
"The home sales number looked very impressive," said Robert H. Chandross, the chief economist at the Republic National Bank of New York, noting that the sale of a new homes generates business activity far beyond the purchase of such big-ticket items of appliances and carpets. But he and others cautioned that home sales swing widely from month to month and that statistical adjustments sometimes distort instead of correct.
Actual sales in September -- without annualization or seasonal adjustment -- were 58,000, up only modestly from August's 57,000 and down modestly from June, today's report showed.
 
 
Low Mortgage Rates
 Still, analysts said it was pretty clear that home buyers, many of whom had deferred purchases, decided in September to seize the lowest mortgage rates since the late 1960's. They also noted that prices of new homes moved higher for the second consecutive month, reflecting less discounting by builders and perhaps spending on extra amenities.
Yet the September sales leap was so big that officials at the National Association of Home Builders and the Mortgage Bankers Association said home sales would probably decline in October.
"I don't think it's sustainable," said Warren Lasko, executive vice president of the mortgage group, suggesting that sales this month could run at a pace of 650,000 or so. He said applications for mortgages, refinancings excluded, were "essentially flat" from the last week of July to the third week of October.
The South accounted for nearly half of all sales of new homes in September, today's report showed, soaring 27.9 percent to a pace of 367,000. Sales in the Midwest jumped 24.3 percent, to 138,000, while those in the West advanced 15.3 percent, to 204,000.
The decline in the Northeast was 7.1 percent, as sales slipped to an annual rate of 52,000, from 56,000. "The economy in the Northeast is still limping along," Mr. Lasko said, with sales running 42 percent lower for the month than in September 1992.
At the September sales pace, the nation's inventory of 288,000 unsold new homes would last 4.9 months, the lowest supply since April.
The median sales price for a new home in September was $129,000, up from $127,400 in August, the report also showed. The mean price climbed $400, to $149,600.
The five-tenths of 1 percent advance in the Government index designed to predict economic turns provided little surprise since most of its components have been published previously.
 
 
Consecutive Gains
 Yet analysts were generally pleased that the index had posted two consecutive gains averaging seven-tenths of 1 percent, following a sawtooth pattern of ups and downs during the first half of the year. Revisions announced today lowered the gain in August by one-tenth of a point, for an increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent, and erased the minimal gain that had prevailed for July.
Six of the 11 index components contributed to the September rise, the biggest being an increase in the money supply. The others were higher totals for new factory orders for consumer goods and materials, building permits, stock prices, consumer expectations and backlogs of orders for manufactured durable goods.
Holding the index down were companies getting faster deliveries from vendors, lower contracts and orders for plant and equipment, higher first-time claims for unemployment benefits and lower prices for materials particularly sensitive to the business cycle.
The 11th component, the length of the average workweek, was unchanged.
Two companion indexes, those made up of coincident and lagging indicators, each rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September, the report also showed.
In New York, the Center for International Business Cycle Research at Columbia University reported that its leading index of activity in the service sector eased to 191.9 in September from 193.0 in August. Despite the decline, the center said the index remained in an upward trend and that it expected service-sector growth to persist into 1994.

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Woman in the News;
An Outsider Wins Office: Christine Todd Whitman

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PLAINSBORO, N.J., Wednesday, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Today Christine Todd Whitman both fulfilled the political promise she showed three years ago and realized the obligation of public service that was virtually her familial inheritance.
In becoming the first woman to be elected governor of New Jersey, Mrs. Whitman traveled from little-known but well-connected outsider to the candidate who upset a surprisingly resilient Jim Florio. 
 In accepting victory early this morning, Mrs. Whitman mounted the stage at her election headquarters here and gave two thumbs up and a radiant, relieved grin.
"We did it," she told a roaring crowd of supporters.
Mrs. Whitman, 47, is a member of one of the state's wealthiest and most politically involved families. Her father, the late Webster B. Todd, was a major figure in the state and national Republican parties and a building contractor whose projects included Rockefeller Center and Radio City Music Hall. Her mother, the late Eleanor Schley Todd, was a Republican national committeewoman.
Mrs. Whitman rose to political viability in 1990 by nearly upsetting United States Senator Bill Bradley. Although she had held only one other elected office in her life, that of Somerset County Freeholder, Mrs. Whitman easily won the Republican nomination for that race, because better-known politicians thought it foolhardy to challenge Mr. Bradley, who seemed unbeatable.
Mrs. Whitman focused her campaign on Mr. Bradley's refusal to comment on the $2.8 billion tax increase pushed through the state Legislature by his fellow Democrat, Mr. Florio, and came within two percentage points of beating the incumbent.
Lifted by the near-win, Mrs. Whitman began her unofficial campaign for governor almost immediately and never really stopped. She formed the Committee for an Affordable New Jersey, a political action committee, and raised money for Republican candidates. She wrote a newspaper column, became host of a radio talk show and crisscrossed the state, locking up endorsements from county leaders before her opponents got on the road. By the time the 1993 Republican primary arrived, Mrs. Whitman was the acknowledged favorite.
 
Embarrassing Blunders
 But it was a rocky primary for the front-runner.
First both she and her main opponent, former state Attorney General Cary Edwards, admitted they had hired illegal aliens and failed to pay taxes on the workers' salaries. Then a third candidate, James L. Wallwork, joined the fray.
Mrs. Whitman committed embarrassing blunders such as failing to vote in her local school board election (the election ended in a tie and the school budget was defeated). She handed her opponents ammunition in their battle to portray her as inexperienced and out of touch because of her great wealth, saying, for example, while talking about the property tax rebate program, that "as funny as it seems, $500 is a lot" of money to some people.
Still, Mrs. Whitman emerged from the primary successful, if slightly bruised. She warned her supporters that campaigning against Mr. Florio would not be easy, even if he was one of the most unpopular governors in New Jersey history.
 
Forced on the Defense
 "He's a very good campaigner and people who think a race against him will be easy are wrong," she said in 1991. "You can't just depend on negatives to win an election."
But Mrs. Whitman did not immediately move to capitalize on momentum from her victory in the primary. During the summer, while Mr. Florio drew on the perks of incumbency to maintain visibility, moving about the state signing bills and releasing reports, Mrs. Whitman kept a low profile. She attended mostly small partisan events and civic functions, largely away from the eye of the press. In the middle of the summer she left for a vacation with her family in Idaho.
As the campaign progressed, Mr. Florio attacked first and often. He released a string of television commercials and a flurry of news releases that depicted Mrs. Whitman as a gun-loving, tax-evading, out-of-touch heiress who wanted to put drunken drivers back on the street and opposed putting carjackers in jail.
 
A Change in Command
 Mrs. Whitman found herself trying to explain her positions on issues that Mr. Florio had already defined for her. For example, Mrs. Whitman questioned the effectiveness of mandatory sentences, saying they may lead to prison overcrowding and the premature release of dangerous criminals, a view also held by United States Attorney General Janet Reno. But Mr. Florio suggested to voters that Mrs. Whitman opposed the state's mandatory sentencing law for carjackers because she wanted them back on the street.
Mrs. Whitman sought to run her campaign as a referendum on Mr. Florio and the tax increase he pushed through the Legislature. Seeking to rekindle voter anger over the tax increases, she pounded Mr. Florio on the state's economic situation and told voters he was responsible for high unemployment and for businesses leaving the state.
But she took a pounding herself after putting out an economic plan including a proposal to cut incomes taxes by 30 percent over three years.
After early polls showed her trailing the Governor badly, Republican leaders urged Mrs. Whitman to take steps to steady her campaign.
Ed Rollins, the Republican consultant, took charge of daily operations from Mrs. Whitman's brother, Webster B. Todd Jr., and made it clear that he was willing to engage in negative campaigning despite Mrs. Whitman's insistence that it was against her nature. She released her 1990 tax returns returns after months of stalling that allowed Mr. Florio to suggest she was hiding something, then left the Florio campaign scrambling to justify its innuendo.
She turned in a solid performance debating the Governor, appearing confident, relaxed, and, at times, aggressive.
Then Mrs. Whitman went on the road, stumping for votes one on one, shaking hands and taking the time to answer questions, even when they had little to do with state business. She released a series of commercials around the theme "A Change for the Better" and called on her friend, former Gov. Thomas H. Kean to lend his popularity to her campaign. She appeared on everything from CNN to the Howard Stern radio show, trying to talk directly to voters.
At a shopping center in Menlo Park on Sunday, she summed up what a vote for her would mean.
"If New Jersey elects me, the message is going to be that taxpayers have had enough," she said.

HEADLINE: O'Rourke Squeezes Ahead of Brodsky for County Executive Spot

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Wednesday, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Leading a Republican sweep of Westchester County's top elected offices, Andrew P. O'Rourke staved off a fierce challenge by a six-term Assemblyman, Richard L. Brodsky, and declared victory Tuesday night in his bid to gain four more years as County Executive.
The 60-year-old Mr. O'Rourke, a silver-haired pragmatist who projects an unshakable affability, narrowly proved that voters have grown comfortable with his leadership after 11 years and are wary of any change in what they regard as a congenial county. Although Mr. Brodsky repeatedly questioned Mr. O'Rourke's ethical judgment, many voters seemed to be more anxious about the possibility that Mr. Brodsky might initiate expensive programs and raise taxes. With 96.5 percent of the votes counted, these were the results:
O'Rourke 104,970 49.3%
Brodsky 101,608 47.7% 
 At the same time, Jeanine Pirro, a former judge, decisively defeated a prosecutorial star from Manhattan, Michael G. Cherkasky, for district attorney, a job held for the last 25 years by Carl A. Vergari, who is retiring. [Page B9.]
Had the 47-year-old Mr. Brodsky won, he would have been only the second Democrat in this century elected to either of the top two county positions. Still, Mr. Brodsky came far closer to victory this time than he did in his challenge of Mr. O'Rourke four years ago.
 
Call for Recount
 Shortly after 11 P.M. Tuesday, Mr. O'Rourke appeared before animated supporters at the White Plains Hotel and declared victory.
"We won because this has been the greatest county government in America and because people didn't believe the lies and distortions," he told them. "The people knew about us," he added. "They knew we kept the taxes down, and they didn't believe that other stuff."
Mr. Brodsky, however, refused to concede and instead called for a recount, signing papers that would impound voting machines.
"Don't bet the ranch on either candidate tonight," he said.
Despite their showing, the Democrats proved that changing demographics and the faltering economy of a county that was once a magnet for Fortune 500 companies have given them the power to give the Republicans a scare.
Interviews with voters entering polling places suggested that while some thought Mr. O'Rourke was getting stale, many others believed Mr. Brodsky, as a Democrat, posed more of a threat to raise taxes. That confessed anxiety suggested that Mr. O'Rourke's flood of television advertisements over the weekend were effective in painting Mr. Brodsky as a tax-and-spend liberal.
"O'Rourke has been doing a good job," said Martin Kennedy, a real-estate developer, as he voted in Rye. "He'll keep taxes low, which will give companies incentives to open headquarters in Westchester."
In the county clerk's race, Leonard N. Spano, a Republican County Legislator, handily defeated James P. Doody, the Democratic Supervisor of the Town of Eastchester. The job had been held by Andrew J. Spano, no relation to Leonard Spano, who lost a bid for the Democratic nomination for county executive.
In the county's most closely watched mayoral contest, Sy J. Schulman, a Democrat, captured the White Plains mayoralty by taking advantage of a split among two Republicans, Michael A. Coffey, and Alfred Del Vecchio, who ran as a Conservative.
The Westchester county executive contest was a rematch of the 1989 race, which Mr. O'Rourke won, 125,825 votes to 109,421 for Mr. Brodsky, or 52 to 45 percent. This time, however, the issues over which they fought were strikingly different.
Mr. Brodsky was able to capitalize on a flagging economy and fault Mr. O'Rourke for letting 40,000 jobs slip away. He portrayed Mr. O'Rourke as a burned-out politician whose yearned-for appointment to the Federal bench evaporated with the election of President Clinton. He also exploited disclosures that Mr. O'Rourke recommended his live-in companion for a job with the county medical insurer and sought other county-influenced jobs for family members.
Mr. O'Rourke's strongest assets were a general feeling of well-being among county residents, a AAA rating for county bonds, a 5.7 percent unemployment rate and Mr. Brodsky's reputation for abrasiveness. He also enjoyed the powerful advantage of incumbency in a place where television's preoccupation with New York City politics makes it difficult for challengers to gain attention.
Both campaigns spent far more money this time than last, with Mr. O'Rourke approaching $1 million and Mr. Brodsky nearing $700,000. In the last few days, much of that was spent on telephone drives to urge their historic constituencies to vote in an off-year election, which lacks Presidential or senatorial candidates and issues of global stature.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: Stocks Sluggish Despite Economic Reports

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Investors yanked stocks through a bumpy session yesterday that illustrated how, these days, good economic news is not always good for the market.
The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 5.03 points, to 3,697.64, the fourth record in a little more than a week. The Dow briefly crossed the psychological barrier of 3,700 shortly before the close of trading before falling back. 
 But the gain was tied entirely to a sharp jump in I.B.M., which rose 3 1/8, to 50 7/8, on heavy volume after a formerly critical analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette raised his assessment to "very attractive," from "neutral."
Declining stocks outnumbered advancers, 11 to 9, and the secondary markets rose only slightly.
The tepid performance came despite the Government's announcement that home sales had shot up to their highest levels in nearly seven years and the Commerce Department's forecasting index had climbed five-tenths of 1 percent for September. So, why did so many stocks sag?
 
Investor Nervousness
 Analysts said investors had become increasingly nervous that economic growth would push up interest rates, prompting investors to switch from equities to fixed-rate securities like bonds. The stock market has thrived in the last year on an influx of money from people fleeing low interest rates.
Yesterday's news touched off a drop in bond prices -- and a resulting rise in yields -- because the bond market tends to dislike economic growth, fearing a rise in inflation. That drop in turn dragged down the Dow more than 20 points by late morning.
The rise in interest rates is "really ominous for the stock market," said Michael Metz, the chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. "You are going to have a stock market that suffers from malnutrition. The question in a nutshell is this: Will earnings accelerate fast enough to overcome the negative impact from higher interest rates?"
Volume on the Big Board was heavy at 304.8 million shares. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks declined 0.66 point, to 468.44. The American Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.71 points, to 484.28. And the Nasdaq composite index inched up 1.89 points, to 785.66.
 
Transportation Index Drops
 The Dow Jones transportation index, which has set several records in recent weeks, dropped 3.84 points, to 1,738.40, pulled down by UAL, which fell 3 1/4, to 150 3/4.
The anxiety over interest rates carved into bank, brokerage and utility stocks, while the news of economic growth helped the cyclicals -- companies with earnings that are sensitive to the pace of the recovery.
Chemical Bank declined 3/4, to 40 5/8; First Chicago was off 7/8, to 44 1/4, and J. P. Morgan dropped 3/4, to 70 3/4. Merrill Lynch fell 2 3/4, to 93 1/4; Primerica was off 1 1/8, to 42 3/8, and American General dropped 7/8, to 28 1/8.
Among the cyclicals that rose were Eaton, up 1 3/4, to 54 3/4; Georgia Pacific, up 1 3/8, to 68; Parker-Hannifin, up 1 3/4, to 36; Tenneco, up 1 3/8, to 51 3/4, and United Technologies, up 1 3/8, to 63 1/8.
Other issues showing big gains were Masco, which jumped 1 1/8, to 33 1/4, after reporting higher earnings, and Litton Industries, which increased 2 3/4, to 69 3/8, on news that it had formed an alliance with Orbital Sciences.
On the Nasdaq, Geotek rose 2 3/4, to 13 1/2, after it said it would receive an investment of $40 million from a partnership that included the financier George Soros. And Edgemark Financial jumped 13, to 36 3/4, after Old Kent Financial said it would buy the company.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
DuPont Merck Repackaging Costly

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Members of Congress and Congressional aides said yesterday that a change in packaging of four drugs that will result in sharply higher prices showed the need for the mandatory drug price restraints in President Clinton's health care program.
The Du Pont Merck Pharmaceutical Company, which is based in Wilmington, Del., notified hospital pharmacies on Oct. 25 that four drugs will be sold in bottles starting on Jan. 1. That will effectively raise the prices to a range of $40 to $50 for 100 pills, from $2.50 to $5 for 100 now. 
 In a letter to the pharmacies, Du Pont Merck said it would stop making and selling individually wrapped "unit dose blister packages" of Coumadin, an anti-clotting drug; Percodan and Percocet, which reduce pain, and Symmetrel, an anti-viral drug.
Du Pont Merck Pharmaceutical is a joint venture of Merck & Company, the world's largest drug maker, and E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the giant chemical concern.
Jeffrey Bourret, pharmacy director of the University of Pennsylvania Medical Center in Philadelphia, said hospitals would be forced to consider alternative products or assume the added costs. Hospitals use the individual packages to avert the kind of mistakes in which patients could get the wrong medicine.
Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, accused the company of "price gouging." Mr. Stark heads the health subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee, which has an important role in drafting health care legislation.
Mr. Stark said in a telephone interview that Du Pont Merck had provided "an indication of one reason why you can't have voluntary price controls." He added, "Any bill will have to have some kind of cost controls for pharmaceuticals."
Comparing the change in packaging to the tactics of candy makers who reduce the size of candy bars to mask price increases, he said, "You would have to be checking all the packages."
Du Pont Merck Pharmaceutical is one of 18 companies that have promised to help restrain health costs by keeping average price increases on drugs within the annual inflation rate. The companies strongly oppose Government restraints.
Robert Perkins, a spokesman for Du Pont Merck, said the action was consistent with that promise. "This is a product discontinuance, not a price increase, unrelated to our commitment to keep drug prices within inflation," he said.
The company said its profit margins were too low on the blister packages, which, it added, had only 7 percent of the market for the four drugs. Mr. Perkins declined to disclose the size of the market and the profits on these products.
However, John M. Coster, an aide to Senator David A. Pryor of Arkansas, asked, "If it is such a small part of the market, why would they risk the political fallout of making a move like this at this time?" Senator Pryor, a Democrat, heads the Committee on Aging.
Representative Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat who is a member of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on health, said that discontinuing the individual packages could "produce a situation that is less safe for patients."
A spokesman for Merck & Company, one of the parents, which initiated voluntary restraints on drug prices several years ago, referred a request for comment to Mr. Perkins.
Analysts said this was not the first time that the joint venture, which is headed by former Du Pont executives, had been slow to follow Merck on industry-policy questions. Members of Congress criticized Du Pont Merck Pharmaceutical in 1991, citing its sharp price increases to hospitals, which blunted the effect of a law requiring drug makers to offer their lowest prices to the poor through state Medicaid programs.

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Voters;
In New Jersey, Concern Over Taxes and Trust

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
It was the voters' turn to be heard in New Jersey's governor's race yesterday, and as they left their polling booths in elementary schools and fire houses, in centers for the elderly and libraries, they described their anger about higher taxes and their worries about a poor economy. Above all, they talked of the question that came to dominate the race: whether Gov. Jim Florio deserved another term.
A survey of people leaving the polls and conversations with voters on a cool but sunny election day made it clear that the tax issue remained Topic A with a large number of voters. It was clearly the strongest appeal of the Republican challenger, Christine Todd Whitman, followed closely by concerns about the condition of the state's economy, honesty in government and the candidates' understanding of the public's concerns. 
 Although Mrs. Whitman won the support of some women's groups and had courted women's votes, more than half of female voters went for Mr. Florio, while Mrs. Whitman ran stronger among men, the survey showed.
By a ratio of three to one, voters who called taxes their most important issue voted for the Republican, the poll indicated. Six voters out of 10 who put the condition of the state economy at the top of their list of worries also favored Mrs. Whitman.
 
One in Four Switch
 Throughout the campaign, polls had suggested that Mrs. Whitman was indistinct and out of focus in the voters' minds. But she emerged as the candidate with the strongest appeal to people concerned with the hard issues on which the campaign was fought: jobs, taxes and the economy.
Mr. Florio, in contrast, spent more time on the campaign trail attacking Mrs. Whitman than defending his own record. Perhaps as a result, the survey showed him to be choice of voters who valued attributes in which an incumbent could be expected to show strength, such as leadership, experience and the ability to make decisions.
Those were the elements of Mr. Florio's record that won him John Canella, a Ridgewood marketing and sales manager. "I'd like to give Mr. Florio one more election term to make good," Mr. Canella said. "He's made some tough decision that in the long run will get the state back on track."
According to the survey, conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, Governor Florio lost about a quarter of the people who voted for him four years ago.
 
The Honesty Issue
 One of these was Joy Purdy, a state employee who lives in Lawrenceville. She said a pointed concern about higher taxes and a more general wish to see a new face in the statehouse motivated her to change her allegiance and vote for Mrs. Whitman.
"I would say, taxes and auto insurance were the main things on my mind," Ms. Purdy said. "I know it's nothing I can blame Florio for alone, but I just thought, after all we've been through, that it was time for a change."
The survey of about 1,800 people leaving polling places around the state also showed that Mr. Florio had clearly lost ground among the voters on key aspects of his candidacy.
Yesterday's survey revealed that more than half of the voters believed the Governor's $2.8 billion tax increase was wrong; of that group, eight out of ten voted for Mrs. Whitman.
Mrs. Whitman also had sought to damage the Governor on the issues of honesty and trustworthiness, noting that he raised taxes after a campaign in which he said he saw no need for higher levies and that his chief of staff had resigned amid charges, which he denied, of conflict of interest.
Apparently, she succeeded. Honesty and trustworthiness were among the qualities that many voters, about a quarter of the total polled, said were most important in a governor, and Mrs. Whitman won better than seven out of ten of those votes.
 
Support for Gun Control
 Mr. Florio seemed to be less successful in his effort to portray his opponent as rich and unfeeling toward the problems of ordinary families. A fifth of the voters said it was important to have someone "in touch with the needs of the voters."
Almost seven out of ten voters who put that quality first in their choice of governor said they voted for Mrs. Whitman, who was credited with doing much to portray herself as a warm and relaxed person, in contrast to Mr. Florio's characteristic intensity, in the three candidates' debates last month.
But Mr. Florio held his own on gun control and the related issue of crime, the two most frequently mentioned topics of concern to voters after questions of taxes and the economy. Mr. Florio won better than two out of three voters who gave those issues as their prime concerns.
Mr. Florio also carried voters concerned about school financing, a state role the Governor has championed.
After voting at the West Windsor Senior Ciizens Center, Lynn Thornton, who is active in the West Windsor-Plainsboro Regional School System, said Mrs. Whitman's proposal to cut income taxes for most voters by 30 percent over three years, and her stand in favor of school vouchers, allowing parents to spend school tax appropriations at the school of their choice, were unacceptable.
"We are a very highly taxed area, and I understand the feeling people have about paying higher taxes," Ms. Thornton said. "And I don't think Florio has been a perfect governor. But to me, Mrs. Whitman just doesn't have a credible program."
As a token of how tax-shy New Jersey's voters have become, two out of three voters said yesterday that they would rather have lower taxes and fewer state services than the other way around. Mrs. Whitman won this low-taxes, low-services vote by nearly two to one.
The survey also clearly showed what campaign-scarred candidates have known for weeks, that many New Jerseyans voted their doubts and dislikes yesterday. Only a little more than one out of three voters strongly liked their choice, while the other two thirds either expressed doubts about their choice, or chose one because they disliked the other.
"I had a very clear choice," said Joseph J. Patrizze, a Hackensack police officer who was clearly among the latter group. "Florio lied to us. He promised us that he wouldn't raise taxes and he did. I don't forgive so easily, and I feel it's time to give someone else a chance to do the job."
 
How the Polls Were Conducted
 The Election Day polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting stations yesterday throughout New York City and New Jersey.
The polls were conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, an organization created in 1990 by ABC News, CBS News, CNN and NBC News.
The New York City results are based on 1,746 voters located in 40 randomly selected precincts throughout all five boroughs of the city. The New Jersey results are based on 1,812 voters in 40 randomly selected precincts throughout all parts of that state.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results from such polls should differ by only a few percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all voters who turned out in New York City or New Jersey yesterday. The potential sampling error was plus or minus 3 percentage points for New York City and 3 percentage points for New Jersey.
Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day, like the reluctance of some voters to take the time to fill out questionnaires, may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Prosecutors Pick Up Pace In Trial of Blast Suspects

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
Two more defendants were linked for the first time yesterday to evidence in the World Trade Center bombing trial, as the Government sought to tie one man to chemicals used in the blast and another to a motive of anger over American aid to Israel.
Coming as prosecutors ended a four-week-long windup on the devastation of the Feb. 26 explosion and the investigative trail leading to a yellow Ryder rental van that has been implicated as the bomb-delivery vehicle, the testimony signaled a speedup in the pace, something long sought by Judge Kevin T. Duffy. 
 In the first attempt to establish a motive for the attack, prosecutors read from an immigration statement of a defendant, Ahmad M. Ajaj, a 27-year-old Palestinian who claimed he had been tortured by Israeli forces with electric shocks and cigarette burns.
Then in an unusual twist, his lawyer, Austin V. Campriello, expanded on the often lurid account with reports from Amnesty International on the use of torture by Israeli authorities. Defense lawyers said his aim was to show that Mr. Ajaj's application for amnesty in the United States was legitimate, and, not incidentally, to draw some sympathy from the jurors on his plight.
The second defendant named yesterday, Nidal A. Ayyad, a 26-year-old naturalized United States citizen with Palestinian roots, was identified as a chemical engineer for Allied-Signal, the chemical manufacturer in Morristown, N.J.
In what appeared to be an attempt to show that Mr. Ayyad had no professional reason to use chemicals linked to the half-ton trade center bomb, a prosecutor asked two of Mr. Ayyad's bosses if he worked with any of a list of chemicals, including highly explosive hydrogen gas. In each case the answer was no.
The naming of Mr. Ajaj and Mr. Ayyad followed Monday's identification in court of another defendant, Mohammed A. Salameh, a 26-year-old Palestinian who an executive of the Ryder Rental Agency testified had rented a yellow Ford Econoline van from a Jersey City dealership on Feb. 23. Experts from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the insurance industry testified earlier that blown-apart vehicle parts retrieved from the blast rubble came from a Ford van traced to Ryder.
This leaves only the fourth defendant -- Mahmud Abouhalima, a 33-year-old Egyptian-born cabdriver -- to be linked to the bombing by prosecution evidence.
After more than four weeks spent on the blast scene and the van, the shift of the prosecutorial spotlight to Mr. Ajaj seemed to move the proceedings into a new realm.
As Mr. Campriello has sought to impress on the jury of eight women and four men, Mr. Ajaj, who was detained with manuals on bombing as he stepped off a plane on Sept. 1, 1992, was in jail from almost half a year before the bombing until after it.
The Government contends that Mr. Ajaj, using a false passport, flew to the United States from Pakistan with a missing defendant, Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, to aid the bombing plot.
Prosecutors have also sought to link the attack in part to anger over American aid for Israel.
In what appeared to be an effort to buttress this motive, an assistant United States attorney, Henry J. DePippo yesterday sought to show that Mr. Ajaj held animosity toward Israel since he was a child, including a beating he said he was given by an Israeli soldier when he was a third grader.
Mr. Campriello sought to introduce photographs of Mr. Ajaj's wounds that he said had been administered by the Israelis, but Judge Duffy ruled they were not admissible under the Government's exhibit of the first application.

HEADLINE: Chief Resigning From Convention Bureau

 BODY:
Marshall E. Murdaugh, president and chief executive of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau for the last five years, resigned unexpectedly yesterday, effective Jan. 1. The 52-year-old Mr. Murdaugh has a year remaining on his contract.
The search for a successor to run the highly visible $7.8 million office will begin soon, said the bureau chairman, Arthur A. Surin, who is a senior vice president of the Hilton Hotels Corporation. 
 The 70-person bureau is the official promoter and marketer of New York City's image and attractions, although hotels, airlines, restaurants and the Broadway theater spend millions more advertising the wares of the city.
Last year 24.8 million visitors came to New York, including 5.5 million foreign tourists, but that was only slightly more than the 24.7 million visitors in 1989, including 4.9 million foreigners. That relatively lackluster performance is generally attributed to the weak economy of the last few years, especially in the Northeast, but industry officials also blame taxes totaling 21.25 percent on hotel rooms costing more than $100 a night.
Mr. Murdaugh did not return a telephone call yesterday seeking comment.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Raising some red flags over those stalwart utility stocks.

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas

 BODY:
AS interest rates have fallen, increasing numbers of small investors have shifted their money into utility stocks or mutual funds heavily invested in utilities.
"A retired person used to getting 8 percent on his or her $100,000 who has watched that go down to 4 percent in their C.D. account now puts the money in a utility mutual fund," said Tracey L. Tuttle, a utility analyst at Prudential Securities, which runs one of the oldest and largest utility mutual funds. "They are happy to get 5 percent." 
 It is a truism that utilities are safer than more volatile industries. Even though their stocks grew slowly in the last 20 years as utilities expanded with the economy, there were few surprises because they were often a monopoly. And they paid steady, often increasing dividends.
Such traditional thinking has helped push utility stocks up about 16 percent this year. But new reports from Wall Street analysts could prove troubling to the risk-averse investors seeking steady returns in utilities.
Analysts at Prudential Securities and Standard & Poor's recently revised their outlooks for utility stocks to take into account the riskier times ahead for the industry. Moody's Investors Service also said this week that it expected the ratings on the average senior secured bonds for the 50 largest domestic utilities to fall in the next three years.
Among the utilities S.& P. put on creditwatch were: Northeast Utilities of Hartford, Central Maine Power of Augusta, Centerior Energy of Cleveland, the Public Service Company of New Mexico in Albuquerque and TNP Enterprises of Fort Worth.
The reason for the analysts' concern is what the industry calls "retail wheeling." Under the concept, which is being considered by many states, big industrial customers could bypass the local utility to buy lower-cost power from utilities in other areas or states. If states decide to allow it, most utilities will for the first time face competition for their large industrial customers.
Barry Abramson, a vice president at Prudential who follows the industry, said this would put pressure on local utilities to offer industrial customers lower rates, lest they buy power elsewhere.
Even the stronger utilities are expected to feel the pressure.
Consequently, Mr. Abramson said, his firm developed a new index to measure a utility's dependence on big industrial users.
Under the index, which measures risk on a scale of 1 to 5, seven utilities had scores above 4, making them most susceptible to pressure from increased competition: Centerior Energy, 4.57; Detroit Edison, 4.43; Carolina Light and Power of Raleigh, N.C., 4.14; Ohio Edison of Akron, 4.14; Nipsco of Hammond, Ind., 4.14; Baltimore Gas and Electric, 4.14, and Commonwealth Edison of Chicago, 4.00.
The least susceptible utilities, those with scores of 2.00 or below were: Florida Progress of St. Petersburg, 1.71; Kentucky Utilities of Lexington, 1.86; Texas Utilities of Dallas, 1.86; PSI Resources of Plainfield, Ind., 2.00; the Southern Company of Atlanta, 2.00, and Dominion Resources of Richmond, 2.00.
S.& P. in a re-evaluation of the industry announced last week gave about 40 utilities more pessimistic ratings for the future. S.& P. said that its action was to take into account the tougher times that many utilities would face.
Mr. Abramson said that utilities that lost revenue from industrial customers would have a difficult time recouping it by raising rates for residential customers. Such moves are generally subject to approval by local rate commissions and often face fierce opposition from the smaller customers.
Lower revenues would cut profits, which would put pressure on the utilities' managements to cut dividends -- the big reason that investors put their nest eggs into the stocks in the first place.
Mr. Abramson is worried that there may be some painful surprises for smaller investors who still view the industry as a haven in which managements are committed to paying steady dividends. His advice is to pay closer attention to earning reports and to the new ratings, which seek to bring some means to measure the effects of the new competitive environment that is expected.
