HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Mayor;
GIULIANI OUSTS DINKINS BY A THIN MARGIN; WHITMAN IS AN UPSET WINNER OVER FLORIO

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Rudolph William Giuliani, a tavern owner's son who challenged Wall Street, political corruption and the mob as one of the nation's fiercest prosecutors, edged out David N. Dinkins last night for the right to take on municipal government and become the 107th Mayor of New York City -- the first Republican to lead it in a generation.
 
In a near-mirror image of his 2 percentage-point loss to Mr. Dinkins four years ago, Mr. Giuliani won in unofficial returns by sweeping the white ethnic neighborhoods in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island that have been his political base, solidifying his hold on Republicans and drawing wisps of new support from crossover Democrats. But he fell short of creating the broad new moderate coalition he had hoped for.
 
A Fragile Alliance
 Mr. Dinkins, the old-line liberal Democrat who pieced together a fragile interracial alliance to become New York City's first black mayor, ran a feisty campaign and held onto most of it, but not enough to avoid becoming the first black mayor of a major American city to be defeated in his first re-election bid.
With 100 percent of election districts reporting in unofficial returns, the vote was:
Giuliani . . . . . . 903,114 (50.7%)
Dinkins . . . . . . 858,868 (48.3%)
 George J. Marlin, the nominee of the Conservative and Right to Life Parties, had 10,287 votes, or 1 percent. A bit more than half of the city's nearly 3.3 million registered voters turned out, below the 60 percent level of 1989.
"You gave me your vote and I accept the responsibility that goes with it," Mr. Giuliani told his cheering supporters at the New York Hilton shortly before 2 A.M. "My administration will be universal in its concern, sensitive to our diversity and evenhanded in every way possible. You know, nobody, no ethnic, religious or racial group will escape my care, my concern and my attention."
 
Praise for Dinkins
 He praised Mr. Dinkins's service to New York, as the crowd applauded, and vowed to "reach out to every community in New York City." He said he would be "an activist mayor" who "won't even begin to think about pausing for breath until our city is being managed and on the road to social and economic recovery."
About 20 minutes earlier, the Mayor took the stage in his headquarters at the Sheraton New York, having called Mr. Giuliani to concede. Chants of "recount" filled the room, but Mr. Dinkins, his voice hoarse, said: "The people have spoken They have. They have. And I respect their judgment and I respect their decision and we all must respect their judgment and their decision."
He added: "We must all reach out to Mayor-elect Giuliani," as chants of "no, no" rose up. "We must, we must help him to be as good a mayor as he can be," he said, asking the crowd to pray for Mr. Giuliani and the city.
Aides to Mr. Dinkins said he had insisted on conceding, despite the close result, because he knew how high passions had run in the city and did not wish to do anything to make them worse, saying that he hoped his entire mayoralty had stood for bringing the city together.
As it was, at the Mayor's uptown headquarters in Harlem, Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President and one of Mr. Dinkins's oldest friends, expressed sadness and some anger. "If they could have done for us in our communities what we did for them, then we would be winners tonight," Mr. Sutton said, referring to the Democrats who defected to Mr. Giuliani. "We are an extremely hurt people on this night, African-Americans."
Board of Elections officials said 28,500 absentee ballots were in hand, waiting to be opened on Nov. 12, along with an additional 20,000 still outstanding, and an undetermined number of paper ballots cast yesterday due to missing registrations or other disputes at polling sites. Historically, results from absentee and paper ballots are cast in comparable proportion to machine tallies from polling places.
In all but its outcome, the election was a striking replay of the 1989 contest, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls by Voter Research and Surveys, a consortium of four television networks. In virtually all broad demographic and political categories, Mr. Dinkins did about as well as he did four years ago. He won more than 90 percent of the black vote, about one-quarter of the white vote, nearly two-thirds of the Hispanic vote, and nearly 4 in 10 Jewish votes -- all comparable to his 1989 tallies. The Mayor held onto 7 in 10 Democrats, and white liberal voters remained evenly split.
 
Where Giuliani Gained
 Only among Republicans and voters with high school diplomas did Mr. Giuliani do appreciably better than last time, holding on to 9 in 10 Republican votes, compared with 8 in 10 last time, and winning the support of nearly 6 in 10 high school graduates, compared with 4 in 10 four years ago. Mr. Dinkins did notably better only among voters with incomes greater than $100,000 a year, taking nearly 4 in 10 of their votes, compared with 2 in 10 last time.
The relative composition of the electorate was exactly the same as four years ago, with whites constituting about 6 in 10 voters, blacks nearly 3 in 10 and Hispanic voters just over 1 in 10 percent, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls conducted by Voter Research and Surveys. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 3 percentage points. Besides sampling error, the Election Day polls can contain additional errors because of respondents who refuse to fill out questionnaires.
By almost every measure, the electorate was narrowly divided, though starkly polarized along racial lines. Nearly 4 in 10 of the voters selected crime as one of the two issues that mattered most in their decision, and two-thirds of them voted for Mr. Giuliani. One-fifth picked race relations, and two-thirds of them voted for Mr. Dinkins. A quarter selected quality of life, and they were split between the two candidates.
Four in 10 voters said they thought race relations had stayed the same or improved in the last few years, and more than 7 in 10 voted for Mr. Dinkins. Just over half said race relations were worse, and almost 7 in 10 of them chose Mr. Giuliani. One-fifth of the voters said ability to "bring the city togther" was one of the most important factors in their choice, and these voters were split between the candidates.
Similiarly, about 4 in 10 voters said they thought New York was as safe or safer than four years ago, and more than three-quarters of these people voted for Mr. Dinkins. More than half said it was less safe, and three-quarters of them voted for Mr. Giuliani.
Running on the Republican and Liberal Party lines and invoking the fusion legacy of Fiorello H. LaGuardia, Mr. Giuliani campaigned on a platform of back-to-basics municipal services, pledging to crack down on crime, improve the quality of life, reshape the bureaucracy and challenge the hegemony of municipal unions and entrenched Democratic politics.
A 49-year-old native of Brooklyn, a product of parochial schools there and on Long Island, where he moved at age 7, Mr. Giuliani often noted that he has lived or gone to school in every one of the city's five boroughs but Staten Island. He promised to to lead the city toward a 21st century of common interests rooted in its melting-pot past.
Mr. Dinkins, a 66-year-old regular Democrat who climbed cautiously through the remnants of the city's Tammany Hall machine, won office on a pledge of racial healing, and he likened the city to a gorgeous mosaic of racial and ethnic diversity. During his tenure, however, he was hard-pressed by overwhelming budget shortfalls to deliver on his expansive agenda of social programs for the poor, and often seemed equally hard-pressed to fulfill his vision of harmony, as he struggled to confront anti-Jewish violence on the streets of Crown Heights two years ago.
The candidates' verbal jousting continued through Election Day itself, after each voted on the Upper East Side, Mr. Dinkins near Gracie Mansion, and Mr. Giuliani near his apartment on 86th Street.
The Mayor called a noon news conference at City Hall to accuse the Giuliani camp of waging "an outrageous campaign of voter intimidation and dirty tricks." Mr. Dinkins based his accusation on three unproved allegations from his poll watchers and campaign workers, including a charge that hundreds of small posters urging a Dinkins vote in English and Spanish had been put up in Washington Heights and the Bronx. The posters suggested that illegal immigrants would be arrested at the polls and deported if they tried to vote.
Mr. Giuliani said, "I can assure you this has nothing to do with my campaign and it is precisely what we expected from them."
The Dinkins-Giuliani rematch, which all but began the moment the Mayor was elected four years ago next week, was in some ways more tense and bitter than their first contest. Over the last two years, supporters of both camps feinted and sparred, with Mr. Giuliani complaining that the Mayor was too willing to retreat "into black victimization" in the face of his problems in office, and Mr. Dinkins's campaign manager, Bill Lynch, likening Mr. Giuliani to David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader and legislator, for his speech to a rowdy rally of off-duty police officers last year.
The Mayor wound up his campaign by importing a parade of prominent national Democrats and broadcasting a ferocious ad using footage of Mr. Giuliani's speech to the police rally, while Mr. Giuliani emphasized his endorsements by leading Democrats like Mr. Koch and former Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr.

HEADLINE: High Court Says Surcharges For Hospitals Are Acceptable

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEWARK, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The United States Supreme Court has decided not to hear an appeal over hospital bills that led to major changes in New Jersey's health-care payment laws last year.
The decision, announced Monday, will allow hospitals to pursue an estimated $130 million in disputed billings, a lawyer for the New Jersey Hospital Association said. 
 The Court let stand a ruling by the Federal Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, that said states may legally require people who have insurance to help pay the hospital costs of people who do not.
The appeals court had overturned a May 1992 decision in which Federal District Judge Alfred M. Wolin said such cost shifting was illegal. Judge Wolin struck down New Jersey's system of putting surcharges on all hospital bills to balance the costs of charity care and bad debt between rich and poor communities.
 
Elected Officials Took Action
 Though New Jersey appealed the decision and eventually won, Judge Wolin's ruling led Gov. Jim Florio and the Republican-led Legislature to overhaul the state's health-care payment system.
New laws enacted last November deregulated most hospital rates and replaced the surcharges with a subsidy fund for the neediest hospitals, which was financed by a payroll tax on employers and employees.
To prevent a voter outcry over the new tax, unemployment taxes were lowered simultaneously by the same amount. But the law includes a "trigger" that will automatically raise taxes if the unemployment fund dips too low to cover claims after next July.
A group of labor unions had sued to overturn the original payment system, saying the hospital surcharges, which forced those with insurance to finance the care of those without it, made union labor uncompetitive because unions require employers to pay health benefits.
While the case was being argued in court, a number of unions withheld the surcharge from the hospitals. The hospital association now plans to seek a state court order to get the money from the unions.

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: GIULIANI OUSTS DINKINS BY A THIN MARGIN; WHITMAN IS AN UPSET WINNER OVER FLORIO;
New Jersey Anger Over Taxes Propels Challenger

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman harnessed lingering anger over taxes and scored an upset victory over Gov. Jim Florio last night to become the first woman to be Governor of New Jersey.
"The people of New Jersey have spoken more eloquently than I can," Mrs. Whitman told a cheering crowd at her campaign headquarters near Princeton about 12:25 this morning, only moments after she received a telephone call from Mr. Florio in which he conceded defeat. 
 About the same time that Mrs. Whitman was talking to her gleeful supporters, a grim-faced Mr. Florio was standing before a near-silent gathering at a hotel in East Brunswick.
"It appears we have come up a little short," said Mr. Florio, the first sitting Governor in New Jersey's history to lose in a general election.
He did not offer congratulations to Mrs. Whitman, but promised to work with her to make the transition smooth.
Mrs. Whitman will govern with a Republican-controlled Legislature as she tries to make good on her campaign promises, including a pledge to cut income taxes by a total of 30 percent over 3 years. [Page B8.]
Mr. Florio, once considered irreparably damaged by voter anger over taxes, made surprisingly strong showings in late polls, which showed him well ahead during the last month of the campaign. Last night Mrs. Whitman proved the resiliency of her message as well as the unreliability of the polls.
 
Voters Traditionally Volatile
 With 99 percent or 5,938 of the state's 5,997 precincts reporting, Mrs. Whitman was ahead, 50 percent to 48 percent. She had 1,208,289 votes, while Mr. Florio had 1,175,238. The remaining vote was split among 17 independent or third-party candidates for Governor.
Most recent polls had shown a markedly different trend, giving Mr. Florio a comfortable lead. But there also were indications -- most notably an increase in Mr. Florio's negatives in recent weeks -- that Mrs. Whitman's ads were beginning to register among a sizable part of the state's traditionally volatile electorate.
Carl Golden, the spokesman for Mrs. Whitman, said yesterday that the candidate's message against the Florio taxes "broke through the clutter that was out there."
"We decided we'd have a single message and drive it every day," he said. "We drove it everywhere and it broke through."
And Michael Murphy, media strategist for the Whitman campaign, said: "Jim Florio's negative campaign has backfired. I think it worked in September, but people took another look at Christie Whitman in October."
Mr. Florio had spent the last six months trying to paint Mrs. Whitman as unfit for the job because of her inexperience and because of an immense wealth that he said made her unable to relate to the common voter. But despite the real doubts about Mrs. Whitman and the credibility of her tax plan, in the end a majority of voters apparently could not overcome their anger with Mr. Florio over a $2.8 billion tax increase he pushed through three years ago after campaigning on a pledge of no new taxes.
New Jersey's electorate has long been a faithful gauge of national trends among voters. For that reason, politicians nationwide who have either raised taxes or are contemplating it, especially President Clinton, were carefully watching the outcome of the New Jersey race.
The race also attracted national attention because the candidates hired two of the best-known and most successful political strategists in the nation: James Carville in the Florio camp and Edward J. Rollins Jr. in the Whitman campaign.
There was particular interest in the question of whether the magic touch was still with Mr. Carville, who turned to the Florio campaign after helping guide another Governor, Bill Clinton, to the Presidency. Mr. Carville began working on Mr. Florio's re-election campaign more than a year ago, when there was ample evidence to suggest that the Governor would serve only one term in one of the most powerful governorships in the nation.
 
'We Just Didn't Do It'
 This morning Mr. Carville appeared dumbfounded by Mr. Florio's defeat, accepting personal responsibility for it.
"I'm disappointed in myself," he told a cluster of reporters. "I feel like I let the Governor down. We just didn't do it; in the end, we didn't make it."
The issues that mattered most to New Jersey voters yesterday in the gubernatorial race coincided with the themes that each major-party candidate pushed on the stump.
Those who participated in a poll of voters who had just cast their ballots and who said they were supporters of Mr. Florio listed gun control, jobs and the economy and crime as the most important issues for them. For Whitman voters, taxes, jobs and the economy and corruption were the issues that weighed most heavily on their choice of candidates.
When not attacking Mrs. Whitman, Mr. Florio was talking about the state's ban on semiautomatic weapons, which polls had shown was his strongest issue. In his campaign speeches and advertisements, he also linked the gun law to crime.
Mrs. Whitman, in turn, tried constantly to remind voters of the Florio tax increase. And in the debates against the Governor, in her campaign literature and in her broadcast commercials, Mrs. Whitman attacked her opponent over ethical standards and labeled as corrupt some of his his closest political allies.
Mrs. Whitman, who had never held an elected job above the county level, will be the first woman in a line of Governors that stretches back to 1624. "I do understand what it means to be the first woman governor," she told her cheering supporters this morning. It was her second try for statewide elected office.
 
Powerful Political Family
 It was a 1990 challenge against United States Senator Bill Bradley, in which she fell about 60,000 votes short of winning, that first brought wide public attention to Mrs. Whitman, a member of one of the most politically powerful and wealthiest families in the state.
The tax increase that Mr. Florio pushed through the Legislature in 1990 made him one of the most unpopular politicians in New Jersey's history. Then his ban on semiautomatic weapons and strenuous defense of that tough law made an enemy of one of the wealthiest, best-organized and most politically feared lobbying groups in the nation: the National Rifle Association.
As late as January 1992, Mr. Florio's approval ratings stood at a near-record low for a New Jersey Governor in modern times. Only 2 percent felt he had done an excellent job, 14 percent rated him good and 40 percent said he was only fair. The largest bloc of respondents rated his job performance as poor.
Mrs. Whitman had expected to capitalize on that ill will against Mr. Florio, but stumbles by her own campaign, Mr. Carville's political mischief-making and Mr. Florio's political craftiness kept her off-stride and on the defensive for most of the race.
 
Weeklong Vacation a Misstep
 In the first days after the June 8 primary, when the Florio camp had already begun the combative style of campaigning that became a hallmark of the race, Mrs. Whitman left for a weeklong vacation with her family in Idaho. It was the first of a string of decisions that even without the benefit of hindsight, manifestly hurt Mrs. Whitman's campaign.
Mrs. Whitman's strategy had been to force Mr. Florio to run on his record, including the tax increase. Instead, she spent all summer and into the fall defending herself against issues raised by the Florio campaign that were far afield from what the public expected to hear. Most of the questions dealt with Mrs. Whitman's wealth: two tax-sheltered farms, her failure to disclose her total worth and refusal, at first, to release her income-tax returns.
Mrs. Whitman ran into trouble from her own initiatives, too -- most notably when she released her ambitious economic plan, which promised to cut taxes -- including a 30 percent reduction in income taxes for some -- and to create 450,000 jobs.
Mr. Florio sarcastically derided the two-page plan as "voodoo redo" and editorial-page writers savaged her ideas.
 
A Changed Candidate
 When a New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll a week later showed her trailing Mr. Florio by 21 percentage points and the public highly skeptical of her economic plan, a startled Mrs. Whitman demoted her campaign manager, her older brother, Webster B. Todd Jr., and turned over the day-to-day running of her campaign and her political fortunes to Mr. Rollins.
Under Mr. Rollins's guidance, Mrs. Whitman became a changed candidate, putting aside her aversion to negative politicking to attack Mr. Florio and paying less attention to the daily nettling from her opponent.
In three live televised debates with Mr. Florio, she did not deliver the knockout blow that even Mr. Rollins said she needed, but she held her composure and ground.
For the second time in his political career, Mr. Florio found himself involved in an agonizingly tight race for governor.
In 1981, he lost to Thomas H. Kean, a Republican, by 1,797 votes after a recount of the nearly three million ballots cast. It took a month to recount the ballots from the Kean-Florio race, in what officials described as the most scrupulously counted election of its size in all of American history.

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Mayoral Races;
New Faces Moving Into City Halls Around Nation

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
This most Irish of American cities today elected Thomas M. Menino, the grandson of Italian immigrants, its first non-Irish mayor in 63 years, a sign that the pitch of ethnic politics has been muted.
Mr. Menino, who rose from City Council President to Acting Mayor in July when Raymond L. Flynn resigned to become Ambassador to the Vatican, won overwhelmingly against James T. Brett, a veteran state representative who was the Irish-American candidate. 
 With all votes counted, Mr. Menino had 64 percent of the vote, while Mr. Brett received 36 percent. Mr. Menino and Mr. Brett are both Democrats.
The race here was one in a group that will usher in the biggest turnover of big-city mayors in more than three decades. In addition to Boston, veteran mayors were leaving office in Atlanta, Detroit, Miami and Minneapolis, as well as neighboring St. Paul, opening the door to newcomers.
 
Runoff in Miami
 But in Miami, the decision on who will occupy City Hall will have to await the results of a runoff next Tuesday between Steve Clark, a former Mayor, and Miriam Alonso, a former City Commissioner.
A runoff also seemed likely in Atlanta, where a city council member, Bill Campbell, had 49 percent of the vote with 90 percent of it counted. Michael Lomax, the former chairman of the Fulton County Commission, was in second place with 23 percent. The winner must win a majority or face a runoff, which would be held on Nov. 23.
Voters in Minneapolis rejected a campaign that concentrated on a strong anticrime message by electing Sharon Sayles Belton as Mayor. Ms. Sayles Belton will be the first woman and the first black elected to hold the office. She defeated a fellow Democrat who is a member of the Hennepin County Commissioner, John Derus, in the race to replace Don Fraser, who did not seek re-election after 14 years in office.
Mr. Derus had centered his campaign on a call for more police officers to contend with criminals and gang members. He was backed by the police union, and polls showed that crime was indeed the top issue for voters. But Ms. Sayles Belton, the endorsed Democrat, rallied a liberal coalition that included abortion rights supporters to win a substantial victory.
In St. Paul, Norm Coleman, a Democrat who is an assistant State Attorney General, handily defeated the endorsed Democratic candidate, Andy Dawkins, with a campaign that focused almost exclusively on the crime issue. Violent crime has increased little in the city in the last five years, but Mr. Coleman insisted that many residents were on the verge of fleeing. Aside from hiring 30 new police officers, Mr. Coleman did not detail how he would curtail crime.
Mr. Dawkins campaign was hampered by his admission during the campaign that he had smoked marijuana since entering the State Legislature in 1987.
 
Ex-Justice Wins in Detroit
 In a campaign to succeed Coleman A. Young, Detroit's Mayor for the last 20 years, a former State Supreme Court Justice, Dennis Archer, won after a bitter campaign.
Mr. Archer defeated the Wayne County Prosecutor, Sharon McPhail, who had been endorsed by Mr. Young. Mr. Archer was once Mr. Young's campaign manager.
Afterward, both candidates moved to make peace, with Mr. Archer saying he was "ready to work with anyone within our city and beyond our borders in an effort to redeem our city and to build a better future."
Voters in Pittsburgh elected a Democratic state legislator, Tom Murphy, as mayor over Kathy Matta, a Republican, and Duane Darkins, an independent. Mr. Murphy gained about 67 percent of the vote, The Associated Press reported, while Mr. Darkins had about 15 percent and Ms. Matta 14 percent. Mayor Sophie Masloff, the first woman to hold the post, did not seek re-election.
In Houston, the incumbent, Bob Lanier, was elected to a second term over three opponents in a nonpartisan race. The incumbent Mayor of Cleveland, Michael R. White, a Democrat, was also easily re-elected.
After his victory in Boston, Mr. Menino said: "I never set out to be the Mayor of Boston. I'm pleased. I'm excited. I just want to make a difference in people's lives."
He said he would make education a priority and planned to visit a Boston school on Wednesday.
 
Rancor Is Absent
 "I'm very proud about being the first Italian mayor," Mr. Menino said, addding, "I'll represent the whole city."
David Nyhan, a political columnist for The Boston Globe, summed up the situation, "The land of the bean and cod and Irish mayors is no longer the latter."
Many people here viewed the nonpartisan race as boring, while others, perhaps fewer in number, called it a model civics lesson because it was without name calling, stories of scandal or negative campaigning. In a city where in the first half of the 20th century James Michael Curley gained power largely by stoking Irish resentment against the Brahmins, neither candidate made much of an issue of their ethnic backgrounds. Mr. Brett, in fact, said he did not want to be stereotyped as the conservative Irish candidate.
Here, both candidates called for better schools, more police officers, a citywide ban on new handguns and a stronger economy. They divided on abortion, with Mr. Menino supporting abortion rights and Mr. Brett opposing abortion, but the issue was hardly mentioned.

GRAPHIC: Photo: After winning the mayoral race in Minneapolis last night, Sharon Sayles Belton, the first black and the first woman to hold the seat in the city, hugged her 92-year old grandmother, Hattie Wilson; Thomas M. Menino was joined by his wife, Angela, to celebrate with supporters last night after Mr. Menino defeated Representative James T. Brett to become Boston's first non-Irish-American mayor in 63 years. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1085 words

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Virginia;
Conservative Republican Wins Easily

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Nov. 2

 BODY:
George F. Allen, a conservative former Republican Representative who once was down in the polls by 29 points, won the Virginia Governor's race today, besting former Attorney General Mary Sue Terry, a moderate Democrat.
With 75 percent of the 2,136 precincts counted, Mr. Allen had 752,527 votes, or 58 percent, while Ms. Terry had 532,341, or 41 percent. His margin of victory was one of the largest in Virginia in recent years. 
 Mr. Allen's solid victory ended a 12-year Democratic lock on the Virginia governorship. It was attributed in good measure to mounting voter dissatisfaction in the Old Dominion with Democratic office holders, both state and national.
The incumbent, L. Douglas Wilder, the first black ever elected governor of any state, could not run for a second consecutive term under Virginia law.
Besides Democratic control of the state, other important issues were debated in the campaign, some also with national implications. Among them were crime and guns, a woman's place in the American family and the political influence of the religious right within the Republican Party.
Ms. Terry conceded about 9:30 P.M. "Somewhere in Virginia tonight the first woman governor of Virginia is watching," she said. "This is a fight worth fighting. This is a fight for the right. And someday we will win."
Mr. Allen, who described the campaign as "an insurgency against overwhelming odds," said, "Principles and issues still matter to the people of Virginia."
 
Views Are Similar
 Mr. Allen's conservative Republican thinking does not differ all that much from Ms. Terry's moderate Democratic thinking. But he turned out to be better than his opponent at selling it to Virginia voters, who are mostly moderate to conservative and increasingly declaring themselves to be independents.
Mr. Allen, 41 years old and the son of George Allen, the late professional football coach, is a folksy, back-slapping politician with a sunny, made-for-TV smile. Cowboy boots poke out from under his dark suit, and when the public isn't looking, and sometimes when it is, he chews on tobacco.
But in the 1993 election, the smile and his never-too-serious banter masked a sharp sense of political timing, an adeptness at taking advantage of lucky breaks and a knack for hiring good campaign operatives and ad teams.
By contrast, Ms. Terry, 46, seemed stiff and ill-at-ease out on the hustings. While she handily beat opponents by 2-1 ratios in two runs for Attorney General in the past, her political touch and her political advisers failed her in the fall of 1993, and she found herself constantly reacting to Mr. Allen rather than taking the fight to him.
 
Tumble in Polls
 Her tumble in the polls, from 29 points ahead in May to 19 points behind in the final survey over the weekend, did more than end her hope of becoming Virginia's first female Governor and one of the few women ever elected Governor in the country. It also earned her a stinging political sobriquet -- Mary Souffle.
It was an appellation not fully merited, pollsters and political analysts said, because there was little she could do about the growing unpopularity of Democrats with Virginia voters and the drag that unpopularity was having on her campaign.
During the campaign, only one in four voters polled gave a positive job rating to the state's leading Democratic office holders, Governor Wilder and Senator Charles S. Robb, who have spent much of the past five years feuding with each other while the state, once a national growth leader, has fallen on hard economic times.
Making matters worse for Ms. Terry, only one of three Virginia voters gave a positive rating to the top Democrat of all, President Clinton, who failed to carry the state in 1992.
 
Steering Clear of Clinton
 Ms. Terry almost never campaigned with Mr. Robb or Mr. Wilder and steered well clear of asking Mr. Clinton to campaign for her.
Mr. Allen called in as many leading Republicans as he could get.
In another contest, Lt. Gov. Donald S. Beyer Jr., a Democrat and the lone incumbent in Virginia's three statewide races this year, defeated Republican challenger Michael P. Farris.
And James S. Gilmore 3d, a Republican prosecutor, easily defeated William D. Dolan 3d, a Democratic lawyer, in the race for attorney general.
The Republicans, who have not had the governor's office in Virginia since John N. Dalton's term ended in 1981, also picked up six or seven seats in state House of Representatives, bringing them almost equal to the Democrats.
As in many states, crime and gun control were important issues in the Allen-Terry campaign.
Ms. Terry called for a waiting period for gun purchases, which polls indicate most Virginians favor. But Mr. Allen, who had the support of the National Rifle Association, chose mostly to ignore the purchase issue and concentrated instead on calling for more police and stronger crime laws, including denying parole to serious offenders.
Pollsters found his approach the most effective.
The influence of the religious right in politics is increasingly important in many states, but in Virginia, where many Christian right groups are based or have strong chapters, it is especially important.
Mr. Allen won the support of most of those groups, including considerable monetary help. He responded by supporting their call for the state to help pay the tuition of students who choose to go to private or church schools.
 
Family Issues
 As for the play of family issues in the campaign, it revolved mainly around the abortion debate.
Like a majority of Virginians, Ms. Terry supports a woman's right to abortion and contended that Mr. Allen would seek to limit abortion rights as Governor. Mr. Allen countered, apparently effectively, that he was not totally against abortions but believed they needed to be strictly regulated.
Complicating the family issue, some of Mr. Allen's supporters, among them Oliver L. North, made a series of speeches around the state in which they aargued that Ms. Terry, who has never married, was not as qualified as Mr. Allen, a family man, to pass judgment on such issues as abortion and schooling.
She called the assertions absurd and mean-spirited.
Poll takers said it was difficult to determine whether the marriage issue had any effect on the outcome of today's voting. Voter surveys indicated that Mr. Allen had won the votes of at least 60 percent of the men and had done at least as well as Ms. Terry among women, possibly better.

GRAPHIC: Photo: George F. Allen, right, a Republican and former Representative, was elected Governor of Virginia yesterday. He waited for election returns with his wife, Susan, and his brother Bruce in Richmond. (Associated Press)

LENGTH: 544 words

HEADLINE: U.S. PRESSES JAPAN ON MISSILE PROJECT

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 3

 BODY:
On the first stop of an Asia trip intended to address the North Korean nuclear threat, Secretary of Defense Les Aspin urged Japanese officials on Tuesday to take part in a new, American-led missile defense program. But he said the Japanese would not necessarily have to offer commercial technology in return.
Mr. Aspin discussed the program, called a "theater missile defense," as he sought to build support for the Clinton Administration's strategy for dealing with North Korea's continued refusal to allow full inspection of its nuclear sites. That strategy, as described by Defense Department officials traveling with Mr. Aspin, calls for yet more talks, again delaying any move to seek economic sanctions against the Communist Government in Pyongyang. 
 "Both Japan and South Korea are concerned about allowing this to go on in a chronic, gnawing way, but no one really wants to move to sanctions yet," a senior defense official said Tuesday night, briefing reporters about Mr. Aspin's talks with Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa and other Japanese leaders.
At a news conference this morning before leaving for Seoul, Mr. Aspin refused to say how much longer the United States would negotiate with North Korea, but made it clear that he was not eager to move toward sanctions except as a last resort. "Our strategy is to try through diplomatic means to solve the issue of North Korean nuclear weapons," he said. "This problem has been caused by North Korean action, and it can be solved with North Korean action."
 
 
Some Time Left
 Earlier, Government officials in Seoul and in Washington had suggested that more delays in resolving the nuclear standoff would not be acceptable because Pyongyang could use the time to complete its first weapons. But Tuesday Mr. Aspin's aides suggested there was still some time left.
In his meetings here Tuesday, Mr. Aspin described an American plan to build a missile defense system that could be deployed on Japanese soil. The idea was first broached last month, but immediately raised concerns in Japan because it was the first time Washington had proposed trading advanced military technology for Japanese commercial technology.
The theater missile defense is part of the Pentagon's new defense strategy and is aimed chiefly at regional threats and short-range missiles. The plan replaces the now-defunct Strategic Defense Initiative.
The United States is eager for Japan to have it because Japan is considered to be one of the American allies most vulnerable to missile attack.
Eager not to breed opposition to the plan, Mr. Aspin told his hosts Tuesday that the Pentagon was also willing to sell Japan off-the-shelf systems rather than to receive technological trade secrets in return. While the Clinton Administration would prefer a "technology sharing agreement," a senior defense official traveling with Mr. Aspin said, "We do not want to hold security hostage for commercial technology."
Japanese officials concede that they have little effective defense against a new version of the Rodong missile that North Korea test-fired over the sea of Japan in June. The missile is believed to have a range of more than 600 miles, enough to reach Osaka and other major Japanese population centers.

HEADLINE: HAITI IS SUFFERING UNDER OIL EMBARGO

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 2 -

 BODY:
Two weeks after an oil embargo was imposed on Haiti, the streets of the capital are increasingly piled with garbage, factories are shut down, power blackouts are occurring more freqently and armed gangs are operating more freely as they rob stores and extort money.
Olivier Nadal, a co-owner of his family's import and export business, one of the largest in Haiti, said his volume had decreased so much that unless gasoline was available soon, he would have to close his doors, throwing more than 600 employes out of work. As a result of the embargo, foreign pharmaceutical companies have refused to sell him goods for fear that they may not be able to get paid. Furthermore, Mr. Nadal said, his agricultural products are rotting in the countryside because of a lack of gasoline to transport them to Port-au-Prince, the capital.
 
'Heading Toward Anarchy'
 "We've been taken hostage between the extreme left and extreme right," he said. "If the situation continues as it is now, we're heading toward anarchy." 
 Haitians, from wealthy entrepreneurs like Mr. Nadal to the average person, are suffering under the effect of the embargo and two years of political turmoil following the September 1991 coup that ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
The United Nations imposed oil and arms sanctions to force the military leaders to comply with an accord restoring Father Aristide to power signed by the ousted President and the Army leader, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, last July on Governors Island in New York.
The United States also froze the assests and revoked the visas of 41 Haitian businessmen and military officials believed to be the architects of the coup.
Father Aristide has called for even tougher sanctions on Haiti, although many here doubt that they would be enough to remove the military from power. At the same time, Clinton Administration officials say they are opposed to broad new sanctions on Haiti right now because their effects would be felt primarily by those who can least absorb them.
So far, sanctions against Haitian military leaders have not worked. In addition, some people here say that Haitian rulers have gotten rich as a result of contraband and smuggling.
When the sanctions were voted two weeks ago, some experts estimated that Haiti had three months of oil supply left. The Prime Minister, Robert Malval, then got a court order forbidding the companies to sell their reserves, and the estimate was revised to 12 days of gasoline and 24 days of diesel fuel.
 
Support for Sanctions
 But some people hurt by the embargo still favor tighter sanctions.
Marc Celestin, 40, lives in Carrefour, a working-class suburb, in a three-room apartment with his wife and three children. He lost his job at an electronics firm when it closed two years ago and has not worked since. Though feeling victimized by the embargo, he said he would support tougher sanctions if they meant the return of Father Aristide.
"With Aristide things were going to get better," said Mr. Celestin, who ekes out a living with $100 he receives monthly from a brother living in South Florida. "The army does not want to give up power. If the United States wants them out, they have to come and get them by force. That's the only thing they understand."
For about a week the streets in the capital, and roads leading in and out, have been calm. The city's Shell filling stations are empty. The Texaco stations are deserted, and workers sit and pass the time. A gallon of gasoline, which cost $3.75 two weeks ago, can now be bought on the black market for $14. As the supply dwindles, the price could go to $20.
 
Garbage, Potholes Everywhere
 In the streets of the capital, garbage is piling up in almost every corner, creating a potential health hazard. There are potholes everywhere in a city that was once a favorite of European royal families.
Power outages, always a chronic problem, have become more frequent, with many neighborhoods receiving only about 10 hours of electricity a day. Last week, the electric company warned that if the oil shortage continues, only hospitals and communication centers will get electricity. The staff of the government daily newspaper has not been paid for seven months.
Complicating the average Haitian's existence is wanton violence. The streets are patrolled by soldiers and heavily armed civilians, known here as attaches, who are controlled by the chief of police. Every morning at least five dead bodies are discovered in various neighborhoods.
While the full impact of the embargo is difficult to estimate, about 100,000 jobs have been lost since the coup and the country's gross national product has declined 15 percent, said Stanley Schrager, director of the United States Information Services.

HEADLINE: U.S. and China Agree to Expand Defense Links

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The first high-level military-to-military contact in more than four years has ended here after two days of talks between a Pentagon official and China's top military leaders.
They agreed to a "modest" agenda of future dialogue and professional exchanges on topics like international peacekeeping operations and on the problems of converting defense industries to civilian use. 
 The talks are part of a Clinton Administration effort to broaden American-Chinese relations as a means of heading off a confrontation over continuing human rights abuses in China. China's poor human rights record could force the President to curtail trade between the countries next June.
Chas. W. Freeman Jr., Assistant Secretary of Defense for Regional Security Affairs, said at a news conference that the agreed-to exchanges do not mean that the Clinton Administration is removing the sanctions it placed on China after the military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators at Tiananmen Square in June 1989.
There was no discussion of weapons sales to China, he said, and sharp differences remain over Chinese missile sales to Pakistan and American weapon sales to Taiwan.
At a news conference this afternoon, Mr. Freeman said the long isolation of China after the Tiananmen Square massacre, in which hundreds of civilians were killed by People's Liberation Army troops, "has taken its toll in terms of mutual understanding."
"If you don't have contact and dialogue, it is easy to be unaware of the other side's viewpoint and to misinterpret that viewpoint on occasion," he said. "In other words, ignorance can breed suspicion."
The tone of Mr. Freeman's remarks, which were full of praise for China's peacekeeping record in Cambodia and its diversification of its military industries into civilian areas, underscored recent efforts by the Clinton Administration to broaden and upgrade its relationship with China after a marked deterioration during the summer.
Chinese television news tonight featured Mr. Freeman's meeting with Liu Huaqing, the vice chairman of the Central Military Commission and a close ally of Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader. In remarks carried on the official New China News Agency, Mr. Liu said the meetings represented "a good beginning." He added that China appreciated the efforts by the Clinton Administration "for improving relations between the two military forces."
Mr. Freeman, who served as the No. 2 diplomat in the United States Embassy in Beijing from 1981-84, said that with the end of the cold war, it was not likely that the military relationship would ever return to the closeness of the days when Washington pursued strategic cooperation with Beijing to put pressure on Moscow.
Underlying this talk of a new partnership is also a deep concern by Administration officials that the President may be forced next spring to cancel China's most-favored-nation trade status with the United States because of a continuing poor record on human rights in China.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Warning of Trade Retaliation
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- A senior American official warned today that Washington would take retaliatory trade action if China failed to open up its markets substantially to foreign imports by a Dec. 31 deadline.
 "Dec. 31 is not a flexible deadline," said Charlene Barshefsky, deputy United States trade representative. "Absent significant liberalization, the United States will take action."
 China agreed to do away with controls on imports significantly by Dec. 31 in a memorandum of understanding with the United States signed in 1992.
 "Thus far, the offers are not adequate," Ms. Barshefsky told a news conference.
Ms. Barshefsky said Washington could take a variety of retaliatory actions, including putting duties on imports under the Trade Act. She said that negotiators from the United States and China will meet on Nov. 29-30 to discuss the issue.

HEADLINE: Ho Chi Minh City Journal;
The Boat People Fly Back, With Riches to Invest

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam

 BODY:
After fleeing Vietnam seven years ago with nothing but the desperate hope to make a better life anywhere else, Minh Le returned this fall with a bottle of perfume, a bottle of champagne and $2,000 in cash.
They were gifts for his aging parents, who remained behind when Mr. Le, now 30, slipped across the border into Cambodia in 1986 and found a rickety boat to take him to Thailand. He eventually made contact with relatives in the United States, and today he is a budding computer entrepreneur in Falls Church, Va. 
 "When I left, there was nothing in Vietnam," said Mr. Le, whose pastel Hawaiian-style shirt gave him away in the streets of this city as a Viet kieu, a Vietnamese expatriate. "Now people have money. Everywhere, I see Vietnamese-Americans who are coming back to Vietnam to do business. They buy land, they buy houses, businesses. Someday I want to come back and do business here, too."
Ho Chi Minh City, the southern Vietnamese city that most inhabitants never stopped calling Saigon, is being revived to a large, and still secretive, degree by the same people who were once desperate to leave.
Nearly 20 years after the first of them risked their lives to escape Communism and poverty, many of the so-called boat people are returning, lured by a wish to help the family members they left behind and to invest in one of the most promising economies in Southeast Asia.
 
Visitors Now Welcome
 Although the Vietnamese Government initially treated the returning Vietnamese with suspicion and even scorn, it now welcomes most Vietnamese-American visitors -- and their dollars. American dollars are used in virtually all major business transactions here.
"It would be difficult for us to be rude to these Viet kieu because so many of them are our relatives," said a Vietnamese diplomat who has a cousin living in Washington and another in California. "We are a very pragmatic people. We need investment from everywhere to rebuild our country."
For several years the United States has allowed Americans to travel to Vietnam as tourists, although there are still restrictions on the amount of money they can spend here.
At Tan Son Nhut International Airport in Ho Chi Minh City -- once the central American air base in what was then the South Vietnam capital -- dozens of Vietnamese-Americans arrive every day to tearful reunions with parents and brothers and sisters.
"I am an American now," said a prosperous looking Vietnamese-American businessman from Orange County, Calif., waiting in the immigration line at the airport and holding tight to his blue American passport. He said he owned a convenience store "and I am proud because it is very successful."
 
Stacks of $100 Bills
 "Now I come back to help my family," he said. "Maybe I help myself, too." He allowed a passenger arriving on the same flight a peek inside his black calfskin attache case, which contained stacks of $100 bills. "Everybody does it," he said.
Vietnamese Government economists estimate that Vietnamese-Americans have invested hundreds of millions of dollars in their homeland in the last several years, taking advantage of free-market reforms begun in the late 1980's. But for one very good reason no one is sure exactly how many Vietnamese-American investors are here, and exactly how much money they have brought: most of the investment is illegal, a violation of the 18-year-old United States trade embargo on Vietnam.
Under Federal law, Vietnamese-Americans can provide "humanitarian assistance" for their families in Vietnam, but much of the investment clearly goes beyond that, and almost no one interviewed for this article would allow their names or their photographs to be used.
"For Vietnamese-Americans, the boom business at the beginning was Vietnamese real estate," said Yen Do, editor and publisher of the Nguoi Viet, or Vietnamese People, newspaper in Orange County, Calif., one of the largest Vietnamese dailies in the United States. "Then some began providing money-changing services. The latest boom is selling used cars brought from southern China."
Until recently, he said, it was dangerous for Vietnamese-Americans to acknowledge that they had traveled to Vietnam, let alone that they invested in the country, because of the aggressive anti-Communism of their Vietnamese-American neighbors.
"Now, everybody is going in and out of Vietnam," he said. "You can't hide it anymore because you see your neighbors from Orange County in the streets of Saigon."
Going by the rumors heard around Ho Chi Minh City -- and getting beyond those rumors can be very difficult -- whole blocks of the city are now owned by Vietnamese-Americans who have used family members living here as fronts. The relatives sign the deeds.
Two of the city's leading private hotels are said to be secretly owned by Vietnamese-Americans, as are several restaurants, travel agencies and electronics stores. While most of the Vietnamese-American investment is going to the long-capitalist southern half of the country, there is also evidence of their money in Hanoi, the capital, and elsewhere in the North.
"We are owned by Vietnamese, not by Americans, but we have many Viet kieu from America who come here to enjoy our food," said a manager of the popular Thanh Tra restaurant, where many Vietnamese-Americans play host at extravagant feasts for their families -- and for their new Vietnamese businesss partners.
 
Embargo Helps Business
 Decorated with neon lights and rows of video screens, the restaurant looks much like a disco, with loud music drowning out business conversations that a number of the restaurant's Vietnamese-American guests might not want overheard.
Beneath one of the video screens sat a Vietnamese-American businessman from San Jose, Calif., who said he had been doing business in Vietnam for nearly two years, importing American computer equipment by shipping it through other countries in Southeast Asia.
"For me, the embargo is a good thing," he said, laughing as he downed another glass of the expensive imported whisky that is often used here to toast new business deals. "It keeps out the competition."

HEADLINE: TURNING UP HEAT IN TRADE CAMPAIGN

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
President Clinton placed the reputation of his 10-month-old Administration on the line today, declaring that rejection of the North American Free Trade Agreement would be a "profound setback" to United States foreign policy.
Emphasizing the bipartisan support for the trade agreement, Mr. Clinton brought to the White House several former secretaries of state and the Treasury and a group of Nobel prize laureates who have endorsed the pact. 
 It was an unusual tableau. Mr. Clinton sat beside President Jimmy Carter as well as former Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who ran President George Bush's unsuccessful re-election campaign last year. And Henry A. Kissinger, who was Secretary of State for President Richard M. Nixon, joined them in describing the possibility of the agreement's defeat in near-apocalyptic terms.
In mid-September, Mr. Clinton began his full-scale campaign for the trade agreement with a similar White House ceremony that included Mr. Carter, Mr. Bush and former President Gerald R. Ford. At that time, Mr. Clinton emphasized "the important stakes for our nation in this issue."
He returned to a similar theme today, saying, "This is a decision which will demonstrate whether in this difficult moment, we still have confidence in ourselves and our potential."
 
Some See 'Litmus Test'
 Mr. Carter said that rejection of the trade agreement would be "a devastating blow to our relationship with all other countries in this hemisphere" and a "litmus test" of the United States' commitment to democracy in Latin America.
Many of the President's fiercest opponents on the trade agreement are members of his own party, and the fight over the pact has been cast in anything but partisan terms.
All of those at the White House today, including Andrew Young, the former ambassador to the United Nations, Carla A. Hills, who was United States trade representative under Mr. Bush, and Paul Samuelson, the Nobel prize-winning economist, criticized the measure's opponents.
Mr. Baker, who noted wryly that he hardly expected to be standing in the East Room of the White House aiding a Democratic President on an Election Day in November, said, "All questions of party should stop at the water's edge."
After saying in recent days that he felt Congressional opposition to the trade agreement was fading, Mr. Clinton hardly seemed to mind apparently going out on a limb by by predicting worldwide turmoil if the agreement is defeated. An aide said that Mr. Clinton was making sure "that everyone who votes on this understands the stakes."
Mr. Kissinger said: "If Nafta fails, the relationship with Mexico will be damaged for the foreseeable future. He added that the decision on the agreement, scheduled for a vote in the House on Nov. 17, was the most important foreign policy vote lawmakers would cast this decade.
The trade pact would create a common trading bloc with Mexico and Canada. Its supporters have said it will significantly spur global growth, but opponents in Congress and elsewhere have said it will cost American jobs.
A reliable vote count in the House is hard to come by. The Democratic whip, Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, is leading the opposition and has said he needs only 10 votes to insure the pact's defeat.

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Connecticut;
Mayor Perry of Hartford Loses to an Independent

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Mayor Carrie Saxon Perry was overwhelmingly defeated today in her campaign for a fourth term by Michael P. Peters, a firefighter and Democrat turned independent.
With 26 of 27 precincts reporting, Mr. Peters had 64 percent, or 11,662 votes, to Mayor Perry's 35 percent, or 6,335 votes, according to unofficial results. Two other independents in the race trailed far behind. 
 "We ran on the issues, we took the high road and the people responded," Mr. Peters told cheering supporters. "This was truly a mandate from all parties, from all ethnic groups."
Ms. Perry, 62 years old, took only 35 percent of the vote in a four-way Democratic primary in which Mr. Peters finished second. His strong showing prompted him to abandon the Democratic Party and run as an independent in the general election.
 
Crime and the Economy
 Mr. Peters told 300 supporters at the Polish Home in Hartford that he would work to rebuild the city's ravaged economy and combat street crime.
"During this election, lots of people told me that the city was down and out," he said. "No sir. It was just down, but it was not out. We're coming back, we're coming back strong."
As voters went to the polls, many said crime and the need to revive Hartford's economy were the top issues in the race.
 
Concerns About Gang Warfare
 "Gang warfare is going to be one of the factors," former State Representative Juan Figueroa said as he voted in Frog Hollow, a heavily Puerto Rican neighborhood, where a war between rival street gangs over the summer left at least four people dead. "People are shaky about their physical safety and financial safety," he said.
In Hartford's predominantly white South End, several voters said they supported Mr. Peters because they believed Hartford needed a new leader.
"The financial situation of the city has been deteriorating over the past several years," said Patrick Greiten, 36, a lawyer. "It used to be a nice place to live. Now it's being overridden with crime."
State Democratic Party officials had thought Ms. Perry's campaign was in trouble as Election Day approached and called in reinforcements.
The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and United States Senator Carol Moseley Braun, Democrat of Illinois, both made campaign stops in Hartford for Ms. Perry. The State Democratic Party chairman, Edward L. Marcus, also brought a group of prominent state Democrats to Hartford to give Mayor Perry a boost last week.
Ms. Perry, a former state legislator and social worker, characterized herself as a healer who could lead Hartford's diverse 130,000 residents into the future.
Although the city has struggled through the recession, which has hit the once-dominant insurance industry especially hard, she insisted her stewardship was building momentum for a turnaround.
Mr. Peters, 44, campaigned on the theme that the mayor had proven to be a poor leader during tough times and had left the city divided. Ms. Perry and her handpicked City Council slate from two years ago feuded during her third term, and the Democratic Party failed to endorse a candidate this year.
Mr. Peters also contended the accomplishments she cited -- the city's effort to lure the New England Patriots from Massachusetts, and to help developers build a concert amphitheater in the North End -- were more a credit to the leadership of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who has played a major role in both projects.
 
Waterbury Mayor Re-elected
 In Waterbury, the Democratic incumbent, Mayor Edward D. Bergin, was re-elected by a slim margin, taking 51 percent of the vote, or 15,184 votes, to 48 percent, or 14,395, for the Republican, State Senator Stephen Somma.
The Waterbury race turned into a contest to see which candidate was the most removed from imprisoned former Mayor Joseph Santopietro, a Republican who was convicted on corruption charges and is now in prison. Mr. Bergin nicknamed Mr. Somma "Sommapietro" because he served as zoning board chairman under Mayor Santopietro.
Mr. Bergin defeated Mr. Santopietro in 1991 after being out of office for six years, and after being acquitted of a charge that he took a bribe during his first tenure as Mayor from 1976 to 1985.
Francis Sullivan, Mr. Bergin's chief administrative aide, also has been linked to the corruption that was rampant in Waterbury in the late 1980's. A witness at Mr. Santopietro's trial last year said he had funneled payoffs to Mr. Sullivan. But he has not been charged with any crime, and has denied any wrongdoing.
Mr. Somma, a three-term senator, said he had never been linked to corruption in the Santopietro administration.
Voters in 158 towns and cities in Connecticut elected mayors, first selectmen and other municipal officers.
In Bridgeport, Democratic Mayor Joseph Ganim appeared to be coasting to a second term.
With 10 of 32 precincts reporting, Mr. Ganim had 79 percent, or 16,981 votes, to Republican Anthony G. Minutolo's 19 percent, or 3,960.
In New Haven, Democrat John DeStefano, a former city administrator, was elected mayor in his second run for office, winning in all wards, according to early returns from De Stefano headquarters.
With 31 of 51 precincts reporting, Mr. DeStefano had 80 percent, or 14,388 votes, to Republican Kevin Skiest's 20 percent, or 3,686 votes, according to unofficial results. Two-term Mayor John Daniels did not seek re-election.
In Stamford, Mayor Stanley Esposito, a Republican, won a second term with 51 percent of the vote. The Democrat,Frank W. Livolsi, had 38 percent, and Bill Cahill, of A Connecticut Party, had 11 percent.

HEADLINE: Mantra for the Mayor: Deficit, Deficit, Deficit, Deficit

BYLINE: By Richard Ravitch; Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, was a candidate in the Democratic mayoral primary in 1989.

 BODY:
Congratulations, Mr. Mayor-elect! But now it's time to unseal that envelope labeled "Do Not Open Until After Election Day." In it is this year's revised budget, with a deficit of about half a billion dollars. In other words, you're already in deep fiscal trouble.
It is not unusual for the victor to be rewarded with immediate fiscal woes. In 1974, Abe Beame found that John Lindsay had left him a sizable deficit. In 1978, Ed Koch inherited a billion-dollar deficit and a four-year plan designed largely by others to eliminate it. In 1990, he left City Hall with a $300 million hole to fill. 
 The 1990 budget-balancing approach relied heavily on fiscal legerdemain. It was dominated by financing schemes that led to bigger deficits in the future. Relying on similar schemes this year, like the proposed sale of $215 million in delinquent property-tax notes, will only increase future gaps -- now projected at $1.3 billion in the 1995 fiscal year, $1.8 billion in 1996 and $2 billion in 1997.
Instead of borrowing from future New Yorkers, your administration should attack the current deficit in ways that help make New York fiscally sound and economically competitive. The elements of this overall strategy have been recommended by the Citizens Budget Commission and a growing number of public officials and advocacy groups; of course, not all of them can be accomplished immediately, or solely by the city.
First and most important, the state should assume the current share of welfare and Medicaid financing with broad-based statewide taxes. State mandates now require New York City taxpayers to pay half the non-Federal cost of these programs -- about $3 billion this fiscal year.
An increase in the state personal income tax is the best option. Not only is it a progressive tax, but it is also deductible from Federal taxes, which means that much of the welfare and Medicaid burden would be shifted to Washington, where it belongs.
Second, local property-tax burdens should be redistributed to stimulate job growth and reduce inequities. Right now the effective tax rate for commercial properties is six times the rate for homeowners, and the effective tax rate for apartment buildings is five times the rate for smaller homes -- two huge subsidies for homeowners.
Third, there is enormous potential for improving the productivity of the municipal work force. The Citizens Budget Commission has proposed initiatives in the police, fire, santitation and correction services that would save $450 million a year without cutting service levels. Examples include reducing the number of paid sick days taken by corrections officers, eliminating pay to police and corrections officers for time spent changing clothes, and contracting for garbage collection and recycling.
These three major steps cannot be taken in time to save much money in the 1994 fiscal year, which ends next June 30. But with help from the City Council, you can do some things as soon as you take office.
You can start by eliminating agencies or units of agencies that are not essential, either because they duplicate state (or other city) agencies or because they provide relatively unimportant services. Examples include the Board of Correction, Civil Service Commission, Department of Cultural Affairs, Department of Mental Health, the Off-Track Betting Corporation and WNYC. You might decide that some of these agencies provide essential services, but a comprehensive review would probably identify others that do not.
The number of employees in many other agencies can be reduced without endangering the public. The mayor's office, for instance, does not need 1,400 individuals, or the borough presidents' offices 510.
The Police Department holds large opportunities for savings. Through the Safe Streets, Safe City program, Albany is already paying to improve police protection here, but the city needn't use that money to hire more officers. By putting more civilians in clerical jobs and redeploying officers from low-priority to high-priority posts, the city could put even more cops on the street than the program contemplates, and it could use the money from Albany to help close the budget gap. It would need Albany's permission to do that, but its case would be convincing.
In the Department of Correction, the recent decline in the number of inmates means that fewer officers are needed; when they leave, they should not be replaced.
The work forces of many other agencies could shrink gradually, by replacing only some of the employees who leave. With more than 211,000 employees paid out of city funds and an annual turnover of 8 percent, a careful attrition strategy can mean big savings even in this fiscal year.
Measures beyond these will be required to eliminate the current year's deficit. But the basic points are to avoid gimmicks like those used in early 1990, to take actions that will enable the city to begin the next fiscal year with a smaller built-in deficit and to make the case in Albany that the city is at last putting its own house in order so it can get the help it needs from the state.

HEADLINE: New York and Fashion Industry Fit Each Other

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You say New York City's new industrial proposals "promise too much" by channeling public investment into industries "that often seem to have no more claim on taxpayer dollars than the fact that they hire lots of voters" ("Fixing New York's Sick Economy," editorial, Oct. 18). You ask, "Why does a mature industry like fashion need incubation?" 
 The fashion industry may be mature -- it was mature when I started work on Seventh Avenue nearly 50 years ago -- but it is also constantly changing and would die without new companies, new workers, new ideas, new techniques. These thousands of small companies need just the assistance the city proposes: targeted support funneled through public-private partnerships, such as the Garment Industry Development Corporation.
In the apparel industry, the development corporation has a 10-year record of giving small companies access to training, marketing, technology and export assistance. New York City gets a tangible return for its modest investment of $400,000 a year, doubled from the previous administration. The city's proposal to extend the concept to the jewelry industry shows the program's success.
The Fashion Institute of Technology's proposed business incubator and technology center recognizes the need to support struggling new design organizations, essential for New York to remain the fashion capital of the country, and to integrate the talents of new student designers with the real world of the fashion business. The city's contribution of $4.8 million toward a $70 million project for this State University of New York college attended by 12,000 students is an investment in the future.
Yes, we do employ a lot of voters, as well as many new immigrants, who are more likely to pay taxes than to vote. Nearly 100,000 production workers and 80,000 workers in design and wholesale depend on this industry. It's about time the city recognized the contribution of its oldest and newest industry.
 
ELI ELIAS
President, New York Skirt
and Sportswear Association
New York, Oct. 25, 1993

HEADLINE: Japanese Offer Highest Rate of Low-Skill U.S. Jobs

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
A new Government study of foreign-owned manufacturing companies in the United States has found that they generally provide the same quality jobs as American companies, with one exception: the Japanese employ a higher percentage of low-skilled workers than other companies do.
The study released last week by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics found that among the 233,000 people who work for Japanese-owned manufacturing companies in this country, nearly 74 percent hold relatively low-skilled production jobs. That compares with 64 percent of the 1.7 million workers at all foreign-owned manufacturing concerns and 65 percent for manufacturing companies over all. 
 "The conventional wisdom is that there is no difference between domestic and foreign multinationals," said Prof. Douglas P. Woodward, an economist at the University of South Carolina who specializes in foreign investment in the United States. "This study shows that there are differences between nationalities in terms of investment behavior in the United States. This is the first time we've had solid evidence that Japanese multinationals do operate differently than other multinationals."
 
'Screwdriver Plants'
 Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, said, "If Japanese firms send only lower-skilled, assembly jobs to the United States and keep the higher-skilled and professional positions back in Japan, America is in danger of getting only 'screwdriver plants' that bolt the parts together."
Mr. Obey, who requested the study, said it indicated that "America is not receiving the full labor market benefits that should come with foreign investment" and suggested that the Japanese plants could easily be moved to other countries "because most of their positions require only low skill levels."
The study, based on 1989 data, found that foreign-owned manufacturing companies employed nearly 14 percent of their work forces in professional, paraprofessional and technical jobs, like engineering or accounting, compared with slightly more than 12 percent for all manufacturing companies. But among Japanese companies, only slightly more than 9 percent of workers held such positions.
The study cited Japanese automobile companies as the least likely to provide quality jobs in the United States. It found that nearly 86 percent of their work forces were in low-skilled jobs, compared with about 61 percent for all automobile manufacturers in the United States. Similarly, the share of professional workers in Japanese-owned automobile manufacturing plants was more than 6 percent, compared with 11 percent in foreign-owned companies and 22 percent in all automobile manufacturing plants in America.
According to the latest figures compiled last December by the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis, foreign investment in the United States totaled $2.5 trillion, with $492 billion in direct investment and the rest in stocks, bonds and government securities. Foreign companies now employ 4.4 million people, about half in manufacturing jobs.
 
Seen as Unfair
 Mindy Geller, a spokeswoman for Toyota Motor Manufacturing U.S.A. noted that the Japanese auto maker's complex in Georgetown, Ky., was opened in 1988, only a year before the Labor Department's data were gathered. Thus it was unfair to compare the Toyota operations with those of the Big Three American companies, she said.
"They have more layers of management," Ms. Geller said. "They've been operating much longer," She added that the Georgetown plant employs 4,700 people and is expected to expand to 6,000 in 1995.
Kermit E. Whitfield, a spokesman for the Honda of America Manufacturing Company said that "the low-skilled jobs make up the bulk of our jobs." But he added that the company's 10,200 employees, called "associates," had "a great deal more training than workers in the past."
Although low skilled, they have great responsibility, he said. "It used to be you tightened a bolt 12 hours a day every day, and then you went home," Mr. Whitfield said. "But now, companies like Honda are asking associates for their input, for their thoughts."
Tony Wells, a spokesman for Nissan North America, said the Labor Department study was outdated. "It may have been true four years ago, but it's not a good indication of the overall trend," he said.
He added that of 5,800 workers in the company's manufacturing plant in Smyrna, Tenn., "about 21 percent are professional, paraprofessional and technical," and "about 79 percent are in production," the haven of low-skilled jobs.
Mr. Wells said that the company built a research and development complex in Farmington Hills, Mich., two years ago; another such operation in Stanfield, Ari., in 1988, and a design center in San Diego in 1979. Over all, 500 employees worked on research, development and design, he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond's Yield Rises in Selloff

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond jumped to 6.05 percent yesterday from 6.02 percent on Monday on selling in response to more news that the economy is looking stronger than it did in the first half of the year.
The catalyst for the selloff was the Commerce Department's report that sales of new single-family homes surged 20.8 percent in September. The reported indicated that the drop in long-term mortgage rates may be beginning to have a noticeable impact on the economy. In a separate report, the Government's chief economic forecasting gauge rose five-tenths of 1 percent in September. 
 The heavy selling in the credit market was seen as a sign that the market's long rally, which has sent long-term yields to 25-year lows as recently as Oct. 15, was over. If that is the case, the question now is how high interest rates will go. The range of predictions appears to be in the range of 6.25 to 7 percent.
But there are others who argue that there is a chance for long-term interest rates to move lower.
They acknowledge that the economy is picking up pace. They contend, however, that the pace will slacken at the beginning of next year as the tax increases in President Clinton's deficit-reduction program take hold. And they say that inflation, which is running at an annual rate of 2.7 percent, is still low and that even faster growth at the end of the year is not enough to create dangerous inflationary pressures.
 It is not likely that these arguments will have much of an effect on the bond market at the moment. With yields still at low levels, traders and investors are nervous. They are worried about securing profits for the year, and uncertain about the direction of interest rates. As a result, any news that suggests yields may be moving higher can get them to sell quickly.
In addition, some coming economic reports are not likely to bode well for the market. The Consumer Price Index for October, according to analysts, may rise as much as four-tenths of 1 percent, after no change in September. And retail sales for October may be up more than 1 percent.
"We are at a period where growth is picking up but will not be long lasting," said Richard Berner, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "But the growth is real, and the markets will have to live through that."
 
 
All Eyes on Jobs Report
 These factors will increase the focus on the October employment report to be released on Friday. If the jobs report indicates that there was more strength last month than expected, the selloff could gather momentum, with yields moving even higher. According to Bloomberg Business News, the consensus forecast for the increase in nonfarm payroll jobs is around 154,000.
The composition of the employment numbers will also be closely watched by the market. For example, if the data show that manufacturing employment is rising, that will signal that economic strength is also broadening. In the last year, the number of manufacturing jobs has dropped by 255,000.
The pattern of trading yesterday seemed to reflect these uncertain currents. The yield on the 30-year bond, for example, was up to 6.06 percent early in trading before the release of the home sales report. After the report, the yield jumped to as high as 6.13 percent, with the price down more than a full point. But prices came back before lunch, wiping out most of the losses prompted by the home sales data.
In late trading, the price of the 6.25 percent 30-year bond was down 13/32 as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.05 percent, from 6.02 percent Monday. The yield on the 10-year note was up to 5.60 percent from 5.55 percent.
 
 
Impact on Short-Term Rates
 In addition to its impact on long- term interest rates, the concern about stronger economic growth is pushing short-term interest rates higher. This is because stronger growth makes traders and investors ask when the Federal Reserve is likely to push its target for short-term interest rates higher to insure that growth does not produce new inflationary pressures.
There is much debate about when the Fed will raise its short-term target, which has been unchanged, at 3 percent, for more than a year. Some analysts are arguing that the Fed will have to move rates higher by early next year, while others contend that the 3 percent target could hold until next fall.
The yield on the two-year Treasury note also seesawed through the day. It hit a high of 4.19 percent early in the day but ended at 4.14 percent, up from 4.11 percent the day before.
Also weighing on the market is the usual nervousness ahead of the quarterly Treasury auction, which is scheduled for next week. This is the first auction since the Government announced a new borrowing policy in May. No 30-year bonds will be sold; only 3- and 10-year notes will be sold. The Treasury will announce the sizes of the auction today.
The Treasury said yesterday that it was considering auctioning more of the current 5.75 percent 10-year note due in August 2003 rather than selling a new 10-year note.
