HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices for Lumber Advance After Housing Sales Report

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Lumber prices jumped to seven-and-a-half-month highs yesterday after the Commerce Department reported housing sales in September climbed 21 percent, the biggest monthly increase since 1986.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, lumber for November delivery soared $12.70, to $379.70 for a thousand board feet, the highest prices since mid-March, when prices peaked at more than $400 because of timber- cutting restrictions and rebuilding needs following Hurricane Andrew. 
 After a drop this spring and early summer, prices for spruce two-by-four boards have marched gradually higher since July.
 Low mortgage rates, along with rebuilding needs caused by this year's disastrous Midwest flooding and California brush fires, are expected to keep demand strong for lumber.
 
 
'Starting to Kick In'
 "The housing market is really starting to kick in," Linda Lieberman, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company, said. "We are truly seeing some better housing numbers."
The Commerce Department said new-home sales in September were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 762,000 units, the biggest monthly increase since 1986, which far surpassed Wall Street economists' forecasts.
On other commodity markets, crude oil flirted below the psychologically significant $17-a-barrel level, but managed to close above it. December crude oil declined 31 cents, to $17.12 a barrel, at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
And silver prices added to Monday's sharp declines after the Xerox Corporation said that it had developed a silver-free film. December silver settled 3.5 cents lower at $4.19 an ounce at the Commodity Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Climbs Against Mark On Stance by Bundesbank

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar hit an 11-week high against the German mark yesterday after the president of Germany's central bank said he was not troubled by the dollar's growing strength.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.7035 marks, from 1.6938 marks on Monday. But the dollar was mixed against other currencies, slipping to 107.78 Japanese yen from 108.20 yen. 
 Meanwhile, gold prices rose in the United States after falling overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery gained $1.50, to $363.60 an ounce.
The dollar jumped after Hans Tietmeyer, the president of the Bundesbank, said he was not concerned about the dollar's advance against the mark. He also said Germany had not been selling dollars and buying marks to maintain the exchange rate as some investors had suspected.
"Once that statement came out, the dollar went straight up," said John Nelson, director of foreign exchange at Barclays Bank P.L.C. in New York.
Earlier, the dollar got a lift from two positive numbers on the American economy: a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in the Government's chief economic forecasting gauge for September and a 20.8 percent jump in sales of new homes for that month. But the dollar fell back before Mr. Tietmeyer's comments.
"Just when the market started losing ground, something came out to sustain the rally," said Angelo Evangelista, a vice president at Bank of Boston.
The dollar has been strengthening on the growing perception that the interest rate gap between the United States and Europe is narrowing, traders said. While long-term United States bond rates have been climbing, promising better returns for dollar-denominated investments, European rates are expected to stay low as countries work their way out of recessions.
In addition, Mr. Nelson said, demand for dollars is strong because of investors' desire to benefit from the booming stock market in the United States.
"The combination of those two has led people to think they'll see a high dollar environment through the end of the year," he said.
The British pound, meanwhile, slipped in New York trading to $1.4735 from $1.4825.

HEADLINE: Chinese Issuing What May Be Deng's Final Book

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 3

 BODY:
China's top Communist Party officials appeared to be preparing for the death of their paramount leader this week by issuing what is likely to be the final volume of Deng Xiaoping's private speeches. The book includes blunt comments about his role in ordering the Tiananmen Square crackdown and his fear that democracy in China could ignite civil war.
The appearance of these valedictory writings at a time when the 89-year-old Mr. Deng's health is reported to be failing, together with the saturation coverage they are receiving in official news media, reflects what Western diplomats here say is the insecurity of Mr. Deng's successors over China's political stability after his death. 
 "It's like the Chinese leadership is trying to get imbued with the mantle of Deng Xiaoping," one Western diplomat said, adding that by wrapping themselves in Mr. Deng's words they are seeking to confer greater legitimacy on the next generation of leaders.
Mr. Deng's death will cut the Chinese Communist Party loose from the political anchor he represents as senior leader. A number of Western analysts say they believe that Mr. Deng's death could embolden internal political and economic forces, who are seeking to influence China's future course, to revolt against Communist Party control.
 
Authoritative Rendering
 The issuance of the 119 selections of speeches and recorded talks, most of which have not been previously published, is the most authoritative rendering to date of Mr. Deng's conversations with American presidents, other world leaders and Communist cadres from September 1982 to February 1992, which are the peak years of his power and influence.
In the run-up to the Tiananmen crisis of 1989, the book has Mr. Deng explaining to President Bush during a visit on Feb. 26, 1989, "stability takes precedence over all China's problems."
"If all one billion of us undertake multiparty elections," he said, "we will certainly run into a full scale civil war in the style of the cultural revolution," the decade of political purges and self-examination that only formally ended with the death of Mao Zedong in 1976.
"Civil war doesn't necessarily require guns and artillery," Mr. Deng told Mr. Bush. "Fists and wood bats can also be wielded ferociously."
 
Visit From U.S. Professor
 One of the first Americans to visit Mr. Deng three months after the military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square was a Columbia University physics professor, T.D. Lee, described as an old aquaintance of the Chinese leader. In a 70-minute conversation, Mr. Deng told Professor Lee that Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang had been "exposed" for "splitting" the Chinese leadership over how to deal with thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators who occupied the center of the capital that spring.
"Fortunately," he said, "I was still there to deal with it and it was not difficult." Referring to the decision to dismiss Mr. Zhao and order the military crackdown in which hundreds if not thousands of students were killed, Mr. Deng added, "of course, I was not the only one who played a role."
"If those people who caused the turmoil won, there would be a civil war," he said. "Of course our side would win the victory if a civil war broke out, but who knows how many people would die. That would really damage the tendon and the bones."
The last and most recent selection includes Mr. Deng's so-called "southern campaign" in early 1992 to fight back opposition to the pace of China's economic expansion by hard-line conservatives.
"Whoever wants to change this will be overthrown," Mr. Deng said of his economic program, adding that the only way to keep the Chinese people from rebelling over their plight was prosperity. "We must snatch the opportunity" to grow fast, he said, even if such growth was chaotic and unstable.
"For such a big country like ours," he said, "it's impossible to be stable all the time if we want to develop faster."
The New China News Agency said Mr. Deng personally guided the selections in the new volume. "All essays were examined and approved by him," the agency said. Like the biography of Mr. Deng published by his daughter, Deng Rong, last summer, this new book is drawing broad reader interest from thousands of Chinese intellectuals still trying to sort out Mr. Deng's strengths and weaknesses as a Chinese leader.
The current Communist Party leadership understands all too well that Mr. Deng's attempt to control his own succession may not survive long after his death. Shortly before his death in 1976, Mao Zedong picked Hua Guofeng as his successor. Mr. Hua, a cautious bureaucrat who now lives in seclusion in Beijing, was not able to withstand the strong political comeback by Mr. Deng, who was purged twice during the Cultural Revolution but survived to lead the bold economic reforms in China.
 
arefully Orchestrated
 The release of the 418-page volume was carefully orchestrated with nationally televised mass meetings of the Communisty Party leadership. There was no mention of the state of Mr. Deng's health, but Western officials say they believe his deterioration has accelerated due to the "synergy" of degenerative illnesses, like Parkinson's disease, diabetes and perhaps a prostate problem.
"It will be a miracle if he lasts beyond the end of the year," a Western official said recently. The most recent photographs of Mr. Deng, taken during his 89th birthday celebration in August, and published by a pro-Beijing newspaper in Hong Kong, show a markedly thinner and more frail Mr. Deng than pictures taken a year ago.
On Tuesday, President Jiang Zemin called a special meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee at the Great Hall of the People and swore that "Deng Xiaoping thought" would guide every aspect of future leadership from foreign policy to managing the economy.
Among those attending the meeting was former President Yang Shangkun, a onetime rival of Mr. Jiang whose removal from key posts this year was seen as Mr. Deng's final step in securing the transition of power. Mr. Yang's presence was an unusual return to the limelight.
 
Li Peng Present
 Prime Minister Li Peng was also present. But among the senior leaders, only National People's Congress Chairman Qiao Shi was afforded television time today to lead a praiseworthy discussion of Mr. Deng's work.
In his final years, Mr. Deng has been obssessed with creating a stable succession that will allow China's rapid economic expansion to continue undisturbed.
In May 1989, Mr. Deng lamented to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, that "the only thing that can't be brought to pass is the abolition from the system of lifelong positions for leaders.
"This is one of the system's biggest problems," he said.
On June 16 of the same year, according to the new book, Mr. Deng annointed Mr. Jiang, the former Mayor of Shanghai, as his successor. In a "coversation with a few central comrades," Mr. Deng privately set forth his succession rationale.
Just as Mao was the "core" of the first generation leadership in China and Mr. Deng was the core of the second, "entering into the third generation we must have a leadership core," the book quotes Mr. Deng as saying.
 
An Uncharismatic Successor
 "He that will ideologically maintain and protect this core is one whom we now all have agreed to: Jiang Zemin," Mr. Deng said.
Mr. Jiang, whose uncharismatic style has prompted political observers to suggest that he, like Mr. Hua, could easily be eclipsed by a more dynamic personality, simultaneously holds the titles of president, Communist Party secretary and chairman of the Central Military Commission, which controls the People's Liberation Army.
Another prominent American visitor to Mr. Deng upon his retirement was Richard M. Nixon, who as President began the opening to China that eventually resulted in formal American relations with Beijing.
In their Oct. 31 meeting, Mr. Deng attacked the Voice of America for conveying in its shortwave broadcasts a "rivers-of-blood" image of the Tiananmen crackdown. He told Mr. Nixon that students who demonstrated and signed petitions would be forgiven. But from the text released this week, Mr. Deng gave no hint that China would later arrest and put on trial dozens of pro-democracy students who were branded as ring leaders or "black hands" behind the uprising.
Mr. Deng asked Mr. Nixon to tell President Bush that "America should take the initiative" in lifting sanctions imposed after the crackdown, many of which still apply.
"If you want China to beg, it cannot be arranged," Mr. Deng told Mr. Nixon. "Even if extended 100 years, the Chinese people will not beg for the lifting of sanctions."

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: An Electorate in Revolt;
Voting Nationwide Was Less an Embrace Of G.O.P. Than a Warning to Incumbents

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

 BODY:
The three major Republican victories on Tuesday were less a partisan triumph than a warning that the revolt against established politicians that helped send President Clinton to the White House may imperil incumbents next year and ultimately threaten Mr. Clinton himself.
The President said as much yesterday as he assessed the election of Republicans as Governors in Virginia and New Jersey and as Mayor of New York City. "The American people want change and they want results," he said, echoing his message of the 1992 campaign, when he urged voters to choose him over President George Bush. 
 The Republicans needed little spin after the returns were counted. They crowed that it could not have been mere happenstance that the party's candidates, who ran under the banner of change, won all six high-profile races since Mr. Clinton was elected. Republicans had already this year won United States Senate seats from Georgia and Texas and taken over the mayor's office in Los Angeles.
"It's a big, big defeat for the White House," said Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader.
It would be a stretch to portray the Republican victories in the six contests as a repudiation of Mr. Clinton, even though he and many of his top aides campaigned hard for Mayor David N. Dinkins in New York and Gov. Jim Florio in New Jersey. But the latest defeats cannot help but weaken the President's hand with Congress as he tries to persuade reluctant Democrats to approve the North American Free Trade Agreement later this month and to support his plan to revamp the country's health care system.
"They would have been an easier sell had there been victories in New York and New Jersey," said Stanley Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's pollster.
 
A Florio-Clinton Parallel
 The loss by Mr. Florio was particularly unnerving to White House officials. Confident that the Governor would win re-election despite a big tax increase early in his term, the officials had compared his situation to the President's. They said a Florio victory would prove that a Governor -- or a President -- could raise taxes shortly after taking office and not be punished by the voters.
Instead, the lesson from Tuesday seems to be that a politician had better not raise taxes without showing results. That might be difficult for Mr. Clinton, whose budget plan called for higher taxes, most notably on gasoline. And the likely taxes to pay for his health care proposal would not reap benefits until years after he leaves office. Republicans maintained a united front in opposing Mr. Clinton's budget plan and its tax increases, and so are positioned to contest next year's elections as the party that opposes tax increases of any kind.
"The burden of proof used to be on the challenger; today, it's almost on the incumbent," said Gov. Evan Bayh of Indiana, who as the incoming chairman of the Democratic Governors Association will spend much of his time next year defending incumbents. "You've got to show you can make a difference in tangible terms that people can relate to in their daily lives."
But in these times of economic peril, it is not easy for politicians to deliver. So it was no surprise that Mark Mellman, a Democratic strategist, said that some of his clients who are running for re-election next year were in a panic yesterday.
"An incumbent officeholder called me and said: 'Are we toast? Can we win? What do we do now?' " he said.
Indeed, if voters are frightened these days about losing their jobs and being robbed in their own neighborhoods, politicians are frightened that the electorate is not in a forgiving mood.
In New York, Mayor Dinkins repeatedly mentioned declining crime rates in the city. But the voters never seemed satisfied, and opted for Rudolph W. Giuliani, a former Federal prosecutor who promised to make the city safer.
That New York and Los Angeles elected Republican mayors this year suggests an erosion in the confidence of voters accustomed to choosing Democrats to run their cities.
As much as Mr. Florio sought to shift the attention to crime and welfare, voters seemed unable to forget that he had raised taxes by $2.8 billion and that the state's economy was still sluggish.
"The signal we have from these elections is that we're going to have to be careful about raising taxes of any kind," said Leon E. Panetta, who as Mr. Clinton's budget director is no stranger to raising taxes.
And while no incumbent ran for Governor of Virginia, the losing Democrat, Mary Sue Terry, could also be viewed as a victim of the anti-incumbent furor. Her opponent, George F. Allen, associated her with 12 years of Democratic rule and the bitter rivalry between the state's two leading Democrats, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder and Senator Charles S. Robb.
The Republicans, of course, did their best to promote their victories as part of a trend. But except for Mr. Allen's landslide in Virginia, the margins of victory for Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Giuliani were so narrow that they more aptly demonstrated that the electorate that brought Ross Perot to prominence in last year's Presidential contest was still restive. It was no accident that exit polls indicated that 73 percent of the New Jersey voters who backed Mr. Perot last year voted for Mrs. Whitman.
In perhaps the purest signal of impatience with the status quo, voters in New York City and Maine approved term limits for their elected officials; in New Jersey, voters approved a measure that would give themselves authority to recall elected officials. All three passed overwhelmingly.
"People are not thrilled by incumbents," said David Wilhelm, chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "And they're uncertain of challengers. The major lesson is that voters want change so we need to provide it."
Of course, the Democrats would not be talking about lessons they learned, and the Republicans would not be talking about mandates, had the voting been a bit different on Tuesday. In New Jersey, for example, fewer than 31,000 voters provided the margin of victory for Mrs. Whitman.
"There was a roll of the dice Tuesday," said Mr. Greenberg, the pollster, "that didn't come up well for the President."

HEADLINE: If Trade Pact Fails, Doubt On Japan Role in Mexico

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Contradicting what has become a central argument for the North American Free Trade Agreement, businessmen, diplomats and trade experts say Japan and Europe are unlikely to flood Mexico with new investment and trade if the pact is not approved.
With the prospect for Congressional approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement in doubt, both President Clinton and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari have warned that Japan and other American rivals would seize whatever economic opportunities the United States might pass up in Mexico. 
 Trade experts and businessmen here, however, say Mexico is likely to prove more attractive to many potential Asian and European investors with the trade accord than without it.
Moreover, given Mexico's economic difficulties and its dependence on American capital and commerce, many economists and Government officials also say it simply could not afford to turn away from the United States, even if the trade pact fails.
 
'Afraid of Japan'
 "This has touched a chord in the United States because people are afraid of Japan, but it is not an alternative as such," said a senior Mexican official who supports the accord and spoke on the condition that he not be identified. "Japan will be interested in Mexico. The same goes for Europe. But it would be naive to think that Japan is poised to jump in."
In Tokyo, Japanese officials and business people echoed the view that Mexico is unlikely to loom any larger in their thinking without the North American accord. Total Japanese investment in Mexico last year, they noted, was $60 million, roughly what Japan invested in Bangladesh and barely 3 percent of what the United States invested in Mexico over the same period.
"I don't think that a discussion about a free trade agreement between Japan and Mexico has ever taken place here," said Masakazu Toyoda, the director of the Americas division of Japan's Ministry for International Trade and Industry, known as MITI. "It is an interesting idea, but I don't think it works."
Other Japanese officials expressed irritation or amusement that Mr. Clinton seemed to be invoking Japan to scare Americans. "He's joking, right?" a senior Government politician asked. "Japan and Mexico? Does that sound like a big alliance?"
 
Warning to Congress
 On Monday Mr. Clinton warned that if American legislators vote later this month to reject Nafta, as the accord is known, the Japanese would swarm over Mexico "like flies on a June bug."
Mexican officials have indeed quickened their efforts to find new economic partnerships in Europe, Asia and Latin America in case the agreement is killed. But similar efforts in recent years have been less than successful.
Since taking office in December 1988, Mr. Salinas has courted Asian investment and trade. He has encountered skepticism, however, much of it tied to memories of the huge losses of Japanese banks during Mexico's foreign debt crisis of the 1980's.
In fact, Mexican officials recall that Mr. Salinas turned to the idea of the pact, after initially rejecting it, in part because of difficulties in getting European and Asian investors to come into Mexico.
Some Japanese officials have spoken positively of the trade deal, suggesting that by improving the investment climate in Mexico it would work to the benefit of Japanese investors who might want to use Mexico and Canada as a base for producing products to be exported to the United States.
 
Other Partners Sought
 Throughout its trade talks with Canada and the United States, Mexico has continued to work to diversify the foreign partners for its investment and trade.
Until it became clear this summer that the accord was in serious trouble in the American Congress, however, Mexican officials said they saw little reason to risk antagonizing the United States by wooing America's economic competitors more aggressively.
Last year, for example, Mexican trade with European Community nations was $10.3 billion, accounting for 11.5 percent of Mexico's imports and 7.2 percent of its exports, according to Mexican figures.
Mexico's trade with Japan amounted to $3.2 billion, or less than 5 percent of the national total. But with a drop in the value of Mexico's oil sales, its trade deficit with Japan skyrocketed from $542 million in 1991 to $2.2 billion last year.
By comparison, Mexico's imports from the United States alone were $24.6 billion, or 62.8 percent of the country's purchases from abroad, while the United States accounted for 68 percent of Mexican exports, or $18.7 billion.
 
Lifting of Curbs Seen
 If the deal is rejected, senior Mexican officials say they will probably revise the country's foreign investment law in order to extend to all foreign investors some of the benefits that would go only to Americans and Canadians under the North American accord.
They said restrictions on foreign participation in banking, insurance and other financial services were almost certain to be loosened. Mexico is also contemplating signing investment-protection agreements with European countries in order to guarantee their businessmen special terms, they said.
Mexico's Trade Secretary, Jaime Serra Puche, said in an interview, "It is conceivable that in the absence of Nafta, we would go ahead and negotiate trade agreements with the European Community and Japan."
Mexican officials acknowledged that a tariff-reduction agreement with European Community nations would be difficult to reach because it would have to be negotiated with the community as a whole. They predicted that such a deal might be more possible with Japan, but a parade of Japanese officials contradicted them.
 
Criticism From Abroad
 Like some Caribbean and Central American nations, smaller Asian countries have opposed the North American agreement out of concern that it might divert investment away from them. The central criticism that European and Japanese officials have made of the pact, however, is that it would discriminate against businesses outside North America by setting high "rules of origin."
As tariff barriers are gradually eliminated among the United States, Canada and Mexico, most goods would only be able to move freely through the zone if they were made mostly from North American materials. In two areas where Asian manufacturers might be especially anxious to invest, the automotive and textile industries, this so-called content requirement is even stiffer.
In a speech to Mexican businessmen late last month, a former Japanese Goverment trade official for North America, Yasuo Tanabe, complained that the trade accord showed evidence of "sneaking protectionism." But in a later interview with the Mexican newspaper El Financiero, Mr. Tanabe added that independently of the pact, "There's no Mexican boom among Japanese business society."
Trade experts and businessmen in Mexico gave a similar view: the fact that some non-American companies might be dissuaded from investing in Mexico with the accord in place does not mean those companies will invest without it.
For many larger Japanese and European firms, cheap labor would not now compensate for the other costs of moving manufacturing operations to Mexico. But several businessmen said the trade accord might improve that equation considerably for many of those companies, particularly big multinationals that have established North American regional operations. With the pact, they said Mexico could offer duty-free entrance into Canada and the United States, greater economic stability, and expected improvements in areas like transportation and communications.
"If the Japanese trading companies had identified any opportunities in Mexico, they would be pursuing them now," said Gabriel Szekely, a professor of international relations at the University of California at San Diego who is a leading expert on Mexico's economic relations with Asia.
"Mexico will become truly important to the Japanese and the Asians to the extent that it finally joins the North American economy," Dr. Szekely added. "Without Nafta, that won't happen."

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Propositions;
Ballot Measures on Term Limits and Crime Draw Wide Support

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Voters across the country continued to show strong support for term limits, a tougher than ever stand on crime and opposition to gay rights, while indicating they would pay higher taxes if the revenue was used for health care or education.
Only a handful of significant ballot measures were on state electoral plates in Tuesday's matchups, but the results showed an electorate that was generally unwilling to experiment with new ideas. 
 The exception is crime. Here in Washington state, 76 percent of the voters approved a referendum called "Three Strikes, You're Out," which would mandate life sentences without chance of parole for people convicted of three consecutive felony offenses. It would not apply to juveniles.
The measure, which had strong support across party lines and in rural as well as urban areas, is likely to show up on the ballots of other states.
 
'Blueprint for Other States'
 "This crime initiative is the first of its kind, and it will serve as a blueprint for other states," said Peter Wehner, policy director of Empower America, a conservative advocacy group based in Washington, D.C.
School vouchers, another major initiative supported by conservatives, failed by a huge margin in California. Proposition 174, which would have provided $2,600 in vouchers for each of the state's 5.8 million schoolchildren, was rejected by 70 percent of California's voters. School voucher plans have now been voted down in all three states where they have been tried. The others are Colarado and Oregon.
California's political establishment, including Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, joined teachers' unions and President Clinton in opposing school vouchers. Proponents said the measure suffered from a lack of campaign money and was too broadly written.
Here's a look at how the other issues fared on Tuesday:
 
Taxes
 The tax revolt, which started nearly 15 years ago in California, seemed to run out of steam on Tuesday. Voters in California, suffering from the state's worst economic slump in a generation, nonetheless approved by 58 percent to 42 percent a half-cent rise in the sales tax. The increase, passed this year by the Legislature but needing voter approval to become permanent, would be used for increased police protection.
In Washington state, an attempt to roll back nearly a $1 billion in new taxes was defeated by a margin of about 12 percent. The measure, Initiative 602, holds some lessons for Mr. Clinton, as he has said he will seek higher taxes on tobacco products to pay for health care.
Washington passed a universal health care plan this year that is very similar to the one proposed by the President. It raises taxes on tobacco and alcohol to help pay for the program. In this case, voters chose the higher taxes.
But a companion measure, Initiative 601, which limits the growth of state government to the rate of inflation and population increase, was winning approval by a margin of less than 1 percent. The measure would require voter approval for any new state taxes in the next 18 months; beyond that, new taxes would have to be approved by a two-thirds majority in the Legislature.
"The latest trend in tax revolt, voter approval for new taxes, apparently has continued," said David Keating, executive vice president for the National Taxpayers Union in Washington, D.C.
 
Gay Rights
 For those seeking legal protection from discrimination against homosexuals, Tuesday was the latest in a series of defeats, as voters in Cincinnati, Lewiston, Me., and Portsmouth, N.H., rejected gay rights.
By 62 percent to 38 percent, Cincinnati voters repealed a 1992 ordinance protecting homosexuals from discrimination. A similar law was repealed by a margin of more than 2 to 1 in Lewiston, and a nonbinding vote on gay rights in Portsmouth failed by a 3-to-2 margin.
The defeats come as a dozen states are considering ballot measures for next year that would bar legal protection for homosexuals. The measures are modeled after an initiative approved by Colorado voters last year, and is now tied up in a court challenge. On Monday, the Supreme Court declined to hear an appeal by the State of Colorado from a ruling requiring it to prove that the gay rights measure serves a "compelling state interest."
Gay rights supporters are taking a new look at their strategy.
"The initiatives show that we've got a lot of work to do," said Gregory King, a spokesman for the Human Rights Campaign Fund, based in Washington, D.C. "It's clear that our message is not moving the public."
 
Term Limits
 The national campaign to limit the terms of elected officials continues to roll, and is gaining momentum. Already, 16 states have approved term limits. The one state where it had lost -- Washington -- voted in favor of term limits last year when a less severe measure was presented to voters.
On Tuesday, voters in New York City and Maine joined the bandwagon. The Maine proposal, limiting the terms of state officeholders, passed by a 2-to-1 margin. Voters in New York City approved, by a roughly 3-to-2 margin, a referendum to limit the terms of the mayor, comptroller, public advocate, borough presidents and City Council members.
Term limits for members of Congress are clouded by a legal challenge. Opponents, led by the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, have filed suit here to overturn last year's voter mandate. The suit contends that limiting the terms of Federal officeholders is unconstitutional. A trial is expected next year.
In another referendum, voters in Houston defeated a proposal to bring zoning to that city.

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Mayoral Elections;
Results Hint at Secondary Role for Race

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Six weeks after President Clinton, campaigning in New York, described some opponents of Mayor David N. Dinkins as unwilling to vote for "people who are different than we are," a notable feature of mayoral elections around the country was how secondary a role race and ethnicity played.
In Minneapolis, which is 78 percent white, Sharon Sayles Belton became the city's first black mayor by outpolling a white man, Jon Derus, who ran a law-and-order campaign. In Seattle, Norman Rice, who four years ago became the first black mayor in a city that is 75 percent white, easily defeated a white opponent who focused on crime. 
 In Boston, which has twice as many Irish-Americans as Italian-Americans, Thomas M. Menino became the city's first Italian-American mayor, defeating James T. Brett, whose election would have continued 63 years of Irish-American mayors. In Miami, where Hispanic voters far outnumber non-Hispanic ones, former Mayor Steve Clark led Miriam Alonso, a city commissioner. The two will meet in a Nov. 9 runoff.
In a race between two black candidates in Detroit, which is at least 75 percent black, Dennis Archer defeated Sharon McPhail despite Ms. McPhail's efforts to paint herself as the champion of Detroit's blacks and Mr. Archer as a tool of white suburbanites.
 
Change, Not Race
 No one is suggesting that race is no longer a major factor in American politics. In the bitter election in New York, voters cast ballots along racial lines, as Rudolph W. Giuliani narrowly defeated Mr. Dinkins. But the elections Tuesday may have been a signal that many urban voters want change and progress more than they want a candidate who looks like they do.
"I think the new pragmatism astride cities has made voters much more focused on the bottom line and much less on issues of race or other groupings," said David Axelrod, a Chicago political consultant who worked for Mr. Archer in Detroit. "I think people desperately want leaders who will make cities work, and they will take them in whatever shapes, sizes and colors they come in."
The Tuesday elections also brought a new generation to power, with longtime mayors like Maynard Jackson of Atlanta, Coleman A. Young of Detroit, Xavier Suarez of Miami, Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, Sophie Masloff of Pittsburgh and Donald Fraser of Minneapolis stepping down this year.
Two incumbents, Michael R. White of Cleveland and Bob Lanier of Houston, faced only token opposition and were overwhelmingly returned to office.
In Atlanta, Councilman Bill Campbell, who gained 49 percent of the vote Tuesday, faces Michael Lomax, former chairman of the Fulton County Commission, in a Nov. 23 runoff.
 
Winning Moderates
 Tuesday's winners, both newcomers and incumbents, tended to be political moderates with strong multiracial support.
One of the contests where race figured to play a role was in Minneapolis, where Ms. Sayles Belton, president of the Minneapolis City Council, was put on the defensive by Mr. Derus's aggressive campaign centered on crime. But she put together a mostly liberal coalition to win in a city with a long history of generally liberal politics, though a relatively small black political presence.
"A lot of people said it couldn't be done," Ms. Sayles Belton said after her victory Tuesday night. "A lot of people said Minneapolis wasn't ready."
The victor most likely to gain national attention may be Mr. Archer of Detroit, a former Michigan Supreme Court Justice, who was elected Tuesday to head the nation's seventh largest city and the center of the sixth largest metropolitan area.
His predecessor, Mr. Young, who became the city's first black mayor 20 years ago, symbolized a first generation of black politicians whose tactics echoed those of the civil rights era. He endorsed Ms. McPhail, who adopted his practice of trying to pit black voters against white suburbanites and business interests.
But Bob Kahle, polling director at the Center for Urban Studies at Wayne State University, said the economic and social decline in Detroit made Mr. Young's mantle a dubious inheritance in this year's election.
"The level of racial animosity between the suburbs and the city has grown tiresome for many people," he said. "People want a focus on economic issues, not the racial divide. Archer showed the divide-and-conquer strategy isn't going to work. You have to have a big-tent strategy. For us in Detroit, that's news."
Mr. Archer, who spent his first morning after being elected, meeting with Gov. John Engler, a Republican, called today for cooperation with the city's suburbs and business interests.
"What used to be used as a race card in an effort to perpetuate business as usual has received a long-term burial," he said.
Crime was a prime issue in almost all the elections. But, for the most part, the candidates who made the biggest claims for urban wars on crime were unsuccessful.
In Seattle, where Mr. Rice won by a 2-to-1 margin, his opponent, David Stern, hit hard and often on crime, promising curfews to keep criminals off the streets and the hiring of 200 additional police officers. Mr. Rice talked about crime too, but he said the public is wary of grandiose claims for quick fixes.
"I think people understand that there aren't simplistic answers to these questions," he said.
Mr. Dinkins was not the only black candidate to lose to a white one. In Hartford, a white firefighter, Michael Peters, defeated Mayor Carrie Saxon Perry, denying a fourth term to the first black woman to be elected mayor of a large American city.
 
Where Race Mattered
 It is only necessary to look at the New York mayoral contest, where exit polls showed that Mr. Giuliani got 77 percent of the white vote and Mr. Dinkins got 95 of the black vote, to realize how much of a factor race can be.
No one expects such tendencies to disappear anytime soon. But, particularly in mayoral races, where voters have a gut sense of whether things are going well or not, economic and social concerns often accounted for more than racial ones this year, experts said.
"In municipal elections, voters feel they can make a judgment on whether someone is getting the job done: are the streets paved or not; are there enough police on the street or not," said Alan Secrest, a pollster who worked for Mr. Campbell in Atlanta. "As a result they're able to distinguish between candidates on grounds that go beyond race or gender or candidates who are 'like them.' "
He added: "In some places like Houston and Seattle, voters felt the record showed the incumbent was doing a pretty good job and they won. The same dynamic of voters assessing performance and voting accordingly played out in New York, and Dinkins came up short."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
However the N.F.L. handles expansion, challenges are likely.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
Oct. 22. A jury in Boston decides that the National Football League had violated the antitrust laws by restricting William Sullivan's sale of a minority interest in the New England Patriots.
Oct. 27. N.F.L. owners postpone the award of a new franchise to one of four cities still in the running. 
 TO most people, the two events might seem unrelated. Frederick Furth, counsel to Mr. Sullivan and an antitrust lawyer with a mission, said he thinks otherwise. "The N.F.L. is stalling to see whether the four cities bring up the antitrust question," said Mr. Furth, who makes no secret of his desire to sue the league on behalf of the three suitors who are sure to be spurned.
It is possible that Mr. Furth is making much of little. What is clear, though, is that Congress or the courts might soon be forced to decide how special the special business of sports really is -- and economists will be happy to tell them.
Some, notably Roger Noll of Stanford University, said they think professional teams are much like other private enterprises, and thus their inclination to collude should be tightly policed. Others, notably George Daly, the dean of the New York University Stern School of Business, said they think sports leagues are unique cooperatives that need broad exemption from the antitrust laws to serve the public interest.
Mr. Sullivan, the owner of the New England Patriots, was barred in 1987 by the other N.F.L. owners from selling $40 million of public shares in his team. He eventually sold the whole team on far less favorable terms. And last month, a jury awarded him $114 million for his troubles.
The Sullivan antitrust case has no direct bearing on the league expansion issue. But the willingness of the jury to second-guess the motives of the league suggest that the public is no longer prepared to let the N.F.L. decide what is best for professional football.
The N.F.L. had long planned to add two teams, the first expansion since 1976. With the choice of Charlotte, N.C., last week, four cities (St. Louis, Jacksonville, Fla., Baltimore and Memphis) remain in the wings. And that means three cities, each with a sponsor willing to pay $150 million for a franchise, will end up unhappy.
The deliberate pace of N.F.L. expansion makes Jim Quirk, the co-author of "Paydirt: The Business of Professional Team Sports" (Princeton University Press) unhappy, too. "These are monopoly restrictions," he said flatly -- restrictions intended to maximize profits for the group.
About 60 percent of the N.F.L.'s revenues come from national television rights, with the money ($900 million this year) evenly divided among the 28 clubs. Adding franchises, it is generally acknowledged, would not add much to the pot. Hence it would only serve the current owners' interests to add teams if the franchise fee fully compensated them for lost national television revenue.
Those seeking evidence of pent-up demand for franchises, he argues, need only look to the sky-high price of tickets for N.F.L. games and the sweetheart stadium deals offered by football-mad cities. Hartford, for example, is dangling a $250 million stadium to lure the Patriots.
If 28 -- or 30 -- franchises are too few, how many would be just right? Mr. Noll said he would "let the market decide." The N.F.L might, for example, be allowed to set minimum standards for the size of stadiums, the depth of franchise owners' pockets and their managerial capacity. The league would not, however, be permitted to charge franchise fees that offset the dilution of television revenues.
The catch, said Gerald Scully, an economist at the University of Texas at Dallas and the author of "The Business of Major League Baseball (University of Chicago Press), is quality. "Expansion means weaker clubs," he said, because there would be fewer great players to go around.
Joe Browne, the N.F.L.'s vice president for communications, said: "With 30 teams, football will have more franchises than any other sport." But Mr. Noll said the quality issue is based on a misunderstanding. Competitive balance counts more than average player quality, he said, and there are enough good athletes for more teams.
The idea of micro-managing competition within sports leagues frustrates Mr. Daly of New York University, who offers a very different perspective on the antitrust issue. Sports leagues are dependent on cooperation among teams, he said, "and we just haven't done much thinking about the economics of creating such products."
One could argue that "the N.F.L. is a form of entertainment competing with other television programming," Mr. Daly said. By this logic, he suggests, it makes about as much economic sense to tell the N.F.L. where to play or how often as it does to tell Steve Bochco who should star in the next episode of "L.A. Law."
If you are puzzled, wait; it gets worse.
"The thing a league fears most," Mr. Scully said, "is the rise of another league." Thus while the reluctance of the N.F.L. to expand might be based on a wish to maximize monopoly profits, expansion might prove anticompetitive if it deters the formation of a new league or undermines the viability of a fledging effort.
In fact, Mr. Quirk said the N.F.L. had been sued on this issue. In 1962, the American Football League failed to convince a Federal appellate court judge (the soon-to-be Supreme Court-nominee Clement Haynesworth) that the N.F.L.'s expansion into Dallas and Minnesota constituted predatory behavior under the antitrust laws.
All this suggests that however the National Football League handles the expansion question, it is likely to be challenged in court. And economists, it seems, will be of only modest help in deciding where the public's interest lies.

HEADLINE: Russia Warned Over Libya By U.S., Britain and France

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 3

 BODY:
The United States, Britain and France have warned President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia that relations between their countries will suffer if Moscow continues to block plans for new sanctions against Libya over its refusal to extradite two men accused in the bombing of a Pan American World Airways jet over Scotland five years ago.
President Clinton and Prime Ministers John Major of Britain and Edouard Balladur of France sent separate messages to Mr. Yeltsin this week conveying this warning and saying that public opinion in their countries demands additional measures against Libya over the Pan Am bombing, in which 271 people were killed, diplomats here say. 
 The American message alludes to the possibility that Congressional opinion could turn against the emerging Russian democracy if Mr. Yeltsin blocks the new sanctions, prejudicing his chances of receiving further financial aid and export outlets in the United States.
Originally, the three allies planned to ask the Security Council to vote for the new sanctions if Libya did not hand over the suspects for trial by Oct. 1 and promise to cooperate with a French investigation into the bombing of a French airliner over Niger in 1989.
 
Threat of a Veto
 But the vote at the United Nations was first postponed at the request of Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, who said he wanted more time to try to persuade Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, to hand over the men. Then, after that mediation effort failed, Russia threatened to use its Security Council veto to block the new sanctions unless America and its allies agreed to sequester Libyan overseas assets and use them to pay a $4 billion arms debt Moscow is owed by Libya.
The Council has already cut all commercial air links with Libya. But the Russians were apparently angered that the proposed new embargo, which mainly affects supplies of oil refining and pipeline equipment, had been carefully crafted to protect valuable oil and gas drilling contracts European companies have won in Libya while ignoring the debt Libya owes Moscow.
 
Second Clash Possible
 When the United States and its allies replied that they could not give Russia precedence over Libya's other foreign creditors, Moscow asked the Western allies for a $4 billion interest-free loan instead.
The United States and its allies now plan to wait until the end of this week or early next week before bringing the new sanctions resolution to a vote in the Security Council.
Meanwhile, the Clinton Administration faces another clash with Russia in the Security Council over the embargo against Yugoslavia. The United States is expected to veto a request by Russia on Thursday to relax trade sanctions so it can sell natural gas to the Yugoslavian federation of Serbia and Montenegro for heating schools, homes and hospitals this winter.
In a letter to the committee overseeing the sanctions, Russia echoed the recent warnings of senior United Nations officials about the serious difficulties the embargo is creating in much of Yugoslavia.
Last month Under Secretary-General Jan Eliasson, the United Nations aid coordinator, wrote to Mr. Boutros-Ghali asking him to alert the five permanent Security Council members -- the United States, Britain, France, China and Russia -- to the growing hardship the embargo is causing.
"The application of sanctions, in certain instances, has devastating consequences on innocent civilian populations and particularly on vulnerable groups," Mr. Eliasson wrote. "What is required is appropriate action both within the United Nations system as well as in the Security Council to insure sanctions do not cause deprivation and suffering."
 
Shortage of Medicine
 In August the head of the World Health Organization, Hiroshi Nakajima, also wrote to the Security Council, telling of a severe shortage of medicine in Yugoslavia and asking the Council to take a fresh look at how sanctions are applied.
Administration officials, however, say they will block the proposed Russian gas sale in order to increase pressure on Belgrade to force the Serbs in Bosnia and Herzegovina and in Croatia to make peace.
The White House officials say most of the 132 million cubic meters of gas Russia wants to supply to Serbia by pipeline each month this winter is destined for private homes rather than hospitals or schools.
And they point out that the Bosnian Serbs besieging Sarajevo, the Bosnia capital, have still not agreed to open a pipeline carrying Hungarian natural gas into the city to provide the inhabitants with central heating.
The Serbs have also not helped their case with American officials by blocking United Nations war crimes investigators and Dutch Army engineers from excavating a mass grave near the Serb-controlled Croatian town of Vukovar. The town is believed to contain the remains of some 200 Croatian civilians abducted from Vukovar hospital two years ago and executed by Yugoslav Army and Serbian paramilitary units.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Prudential Securities' lawyers are working aggressively to limit the firm's liability in a fraud, brokerage executives say, despite public statements that it hopes to make amends to investors who lost millions in limited partnerships. [Page D1.]
I.B.M. management's confidence about the company's direction is not shared by all analysts. [D1.] 
 Texaco was sued for $1 billion by Ecuadorean Indians seeking restitution for damage to their forests. [D4.]
Banc One will acquire Liberty National Bancorp of Louisville, Ky., in a stock swap valued at $842 million. [D4.]
Brooks Brothers sales rose 10 percent in the first half of the year, and operating profits rose 18 percent. [D4.]
Northern Telecom joined I.B.M. and MCI in developing technology to improve the performance of the national data highway. [D4.]
Datapoint named a 35-year veteran of the computer industry as its president and chief operating officer. [D4.]
Prudential Insurance will sell its Centermark shopping malls for $1 billion rather than package them into a REIT. [D5.]
Bristol-Myers Squibb agreed to sell the appliance division of its Clairol subsidiary to Remington Products. [D6.]
QVC Network and BellSouth were said to be discussing an investment by BellSouth in QVC's bid for Paramount Communications. [D11.]
 
The Economy
With seven Nobel prizes in economics, the University of Chicago has had an extraordinary run. But many say Chicago's clutch of prizes is a measure of past, not present, influence. [D1.]
Business conditions improved at a "slow to moderate" clip in most areas in September and October, the Fed reported. [D2.]
The auto industry recovery continued, with sales of vehicles built in North America increasing 8.5 percent in October. [D2.]
 
International

HEADLINE: Another Tumble In the Decline Of Main Street

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BROCKTON, Mass., Nov. 3

 BODY:
The heart of another Main Street broke today.
Romm's & Company, jewelers at No. 162, after 93 years here the oldest store in downtown Brockton, a Tiffany's to the working class, a store whose third-generation owner is this year's chairman of the downtown merchants' association, packed up and moved to a shopping strip near a highway interchange. And one more boarded-up cadaver was left on a street where about half the commercial space stands empty. 
 "When I heard they were leaving," said George Thomas, born here 59 years ago and an official of the state employment office just off Main Street, "I looked at it and said, 'There goes the landmark of downtown, the backbone of downtown.' If I wanted to buy my wife a nice piece of jewelry, that's where I would go."
There is nothing especially novel about the travails of the crippled shopping hub of this old industrial city in southeastern Massachusetts, midway between Providence, R.I., and Boston. Here, as along most Main Streets, grand old names like Sears, Woolworth's and W. T. Grant and scores of one-of-a-kind specialty shops are long gone, either dead or flown to shopping centers. Competition from suburban discount chains, scarce parking and one-way streets have been choking downtowns for decades.
But in good times or bad some stores, usually family-owned, had held on and prospered. In many cities now, even those stores are giving up, victims not only of competition with the malls but also of job losses and declining wages among longtime customers.
Brockton (population 95,000), which claims at one time to have put shoes on the feet of 1 in 5 Americans, has just one shoe factory now. In the past, people who earned wages that let them shop at Romm's reclaimed their jobs when recessions ended, so they would return to the store for their engagement rings, their silver, their crystal.
This time, more than two years after the latest recession officially ended, many shoe factory jobs, and manufacturing jobs here in the newer defense and computer industries, have not come back, in large part because of foreign competition and cuts in military spending.
Plenty of other jobs have developed, Mr. Thomas says, but many are in part-time retail work. That kind of job -- and Brockton's typical retail wage of $5 to $9 an hour -- does not support families, much less purchases of silver and crystal.
 
Fearful Customers
 Meanwhile, welfare families and new immigrants, many without jobs or credit, have settled into downtown's cheap housing and share Main Street's sidewalks. With poverty and an unemployment rate of 8 percent have come other changes downtown: break-ins, teen-age prostitution and drug abuse that tear at the city's pride and heighten the fears of middle-class consumers.
As he supervised the installation of his old display cases in the new Romm's, at a one-story shopping center called Michael's Plaza, Alexander Romm Rysman, 51-year-old grandson of the Russian immigrant who founded Romm's, said, "Our customers didn't want to be there" in the downtown store.
"They didn't want to be seen coming out of the place with a gift bag," he said, though declining to say how much his sales had been hurt. "We would wrap it in a package and hide it under their coat The crazy thing was, we never had a customer report a mugging. But it didn't matter. They didn't feel safe down there."
The city is now using police foot and bicycle patrols to assuage downtown shoppers' fears. But the area's new consumers have created problems, too. Mr. Rysman said the annual cost of the fees that his bank charges him for his customers' bad checks had jumped to $500 from $20 eight years ago.
Mr. Rysman has a doctorate in sociology and teaches sociology part time at Northeastern University in Boston. So in explaining downtown Brockton, he likes to look beyond the simple exigencies of managing a business.
"There has to be a way for someone who is not academically gifted to make a living," he said. "What's happened over the last 20 years is the working class has been hammered. It's been forced into the dependency classes. The influx of the dependency classes has hit downtown hard.
"Downtowns should be anarchic, with a wonderful mixture of everybody living cheek by jowl. It should have stores catering to the low end and boutiques catering to the wealthy, not like the malls."
But with mostly the poor left downtown, he said, that dynamic dies. "And until we can get the guns out of the hands of children," he added, "the middle class is going to retreat to narrow enclaves."
 
A 'Dependency Class'
 LeMar's House of Fashion, the last women's specialty store on Main Street, is ready to move, too. Lee Roukous, co-owner with Margaret George, said she was waiting for a place at Michael's Plaza, after 38 years downtown.
Four months ago, Mrs. Roukous installed a door buzzer so she could see whom to let in. Romm's had one, too. So does Thuya's Fashion, a Gap-like casual-wear store where a saleswoman said someone smashed a window 15 days ago and took some clothes.
"We're mostly high fashion that has average-to-better prices," Mrs. Roukous said. "We still have our first customer. Every Thursday she comes in. We have a lot of people like that. Very loyal. The bad thing is, I can't open evenings because of the bad publicity, even though nobody's ever bothered us."
A homeless shelter nearby on Spring Street seems to fan customers' apprehensions. "I think because of their appearance, people think they might be dope addicts," Mrs. Roukous said.
 
Oases of Prosperity
 At 3 o'clock on a Tuesday afternoon, 17 men and 3 women -- former factory workers -- are seated around Sweeney's four-sided bar downtown. Jim Mongeau, co-owner of the Genova Pub and Cafe, comes in for a drink. He knows every one in the place. "There's not a person in here that works," he said. Most, he said, are getting by on unemployment checks, disability checks or Social Security.
Some Main Street businesses are doing all right, Mr. Mongeau said, including his. He opened his pub a little over a year ago, and a sign on the window announces that its closing time has been extended to 11 P.M. from 9:30. John J. Merian, owner of a tuxedo and wedding-gown rental shop, Mr. Rysman's successor as head of the Downtown Brockton Association, says he is also doing fine.
"But there's this meltdown," Mr. Merian said. "There needs to be a focus on rebuilding the community. If you can get that, you can get a resurgence of downtown. We have to work to alleviate that perception of crime."
James Skenas, 74-year-old owner of United Furniture, said, "The only thing we can do is clean up some of the mess." Like Mr. Merian and Mr. Mongeau, Mr. Skenas plans to stick with Main Street, though doing so will mean a different way of doing business.
He said he would not open charge accounts for "the new people" but would take a credit card or let them use the layaway plan. "We're taking our money guaranteed," he said.
"Good luck to him," Mr. Skenas said of Mr. Rysman. "He's a smart boy. He hasn't helped the situation by moving out. But it's in his best interest."

GRAPHIC: Photo: About half the commercial space along Main Street in Brockton, Mass., now stands empty as merchants flee the downtown to head for suburban shopping centers. Alexander Romm Rysman, the owner of Romm's & Company jewelers, watched workers move his business to a mall. (Evan Richman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Domestic Vehicle Sales Grew 8.5% in October

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 3

 BODY:
The recovery among auto makers that began late in the spring continued last month, with sales of cars and light trucks built in North America climbing 10.3 percent in late October.
For the month, the auto companies reported yesterday, sales of all vehicles -- cars and light trucks, assembled in North America and shipped from overseas -- rose 8.5 percent from October 1992 levels, to more than 1.1 million. 
 The results, coming atop robust sales a year ago, were "significant because of the scope of the increases, as well as the size of the increases," said John J. Ferron of J. D. Power & Associates in Agoura Hills, Calif. "You're seeing, in particular, North American-produced vehicles growing in the marketplace."
The strength of the yen is driving buyers away from increasingly expensive Japanese imports, he continued, and toward domestic-built vehicles -- which the industry defines as those assembled in Mexico, the United States and Canada.
Partly because of this value consciousness among shoppers, auto makers like the Toyota Motor Corporation, which have assembly plants here and overseas, saw their sales of imports plummet while their sales of domestic-built cars rose.
Meanwhile, the General Motors Corporation, offering few imports and a wide variety of domestic vehicles, some at relatively low prices, posted its largest monthly increase in sales since September 1989.
G.M. also took back some market share, rising from 32.4 percent in October 1992 to 34.7 percent last month. The greatest strength was in the Chevrolet division, where sales spurted 41.1 percent in the month.
"October was very good, excellent," said Dan Bischof, vice president and general manager of Ed Morse Chevrolet in Lauderhill, Fla. "Customers seem to be more readily available and in buying moods."
But other dealers said consumer wariness about the economy was leading many to postpone buying. "People are just sitting back on the midrange auto -- the blue-collar and lower-level white-collar workers -- until after the 1st of the year, after holidays," said Dominic Giambrone, general sales manager of Al Piemonte Ford in Arlington Heights, Ill.
Analysts said the market was on track to exceed 15 million vehicles for the year. "I thought sales were just fine," said Ron Glantz, auto analyst with Dean Witter in San Francisco. "We're back on trend line."
Late in October, domestic car sales rose 10.4 percent, to 226,424. Domestic light-truck sales -- including pickups, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles -- rose 10.1 percent, to 168,743.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales for the Oct. 21-31 period was 6.9 million, compared with 6.6 million during the corresponding period last year and 7.8 million at mid-month. For the month of October, the selling rate was 7.1 million. For the month, sales of domestic and imported cars rose 7.3 percent, to 722,524. Sales of both groups of light trucks rose 10.5 percent, to 438,063.
For the month, G.M. posted a 14.7 percent increase in sales of its domestic cars, to 250,514, and a 12 percent increase in sales of domestic light trucks, to 145,376.
The Ford Motor Company's sales of domestic cars rose 4.5 percent during October, to 158,984. Its sales of domestically built light trucks rose 19.1 percent, to 142,818.
The Chrysler Corporation's sales of domestic cars rose 15.9 percent, to 64,233. Chrysler domestic truck sales increased 6.7 percent over a strong sales period a year ago, to 94,340.
Toyota's sales of North American-built cars increased 18.8 percent, to 26,581, but its sales of imports declined 24.6 percent, to 24,463. Its sales of North American light trucks increased 2.7 percent, to 8,521.
The Nissan Motor Company's sales of cars made in North America increased 54 percent, to 23,899, while its sales of imports fell 22.3 percent, to 14,789. Its sales of North American light trucks fell 12.4 percent, to 13,232.
Honda's sales of North American-built cars slipped 1.6 percent, to 35,224. But its sales of imported cars rose to 27,328, an increase of 12.2 percent. Mazda posted a 25.2 percent rise in North American-built car sales.

BYLINE: AP; Two Groups Assail Plan to Let Airports Use Private Guards

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Consumer advocates and a police union official say they are outraged by a Government proposal to allow airports to use private security guards instead of police and to continue curbside baggage check-ins during terrorist alerts like those imposed after the Persian Gulf war and the World Trade Center bombing.
Critics said the proposed rules, which the Government drafted to eliminate red tape and excessive costs during terrorist alerts, would jeopardizepublic safety. 
 But the Federal Aviation Administration said the change would save money and simplify procedures without lowering the nation's guard.
The F.A.A. said the rules were not yet in effect, but unlike most Federal rules, they could be implemented without public comment being sought. It is not clear what, if any, further steps are required to implement the new rules or whether the agency will even say when they have gone into effect. The agency does not make its security plans public.
 
Weak Link at Curbside
 Among critics of the plan is Frank McGuire, who edits Security Intelligence Report, a newsletter that deals with airline safety. "At the highest stage of alert, a private guard doesn't have the clout of a police officer," Mr. McGuire said. "I don't think that's the place for a rent-a-cop."
Mr. McGuire said curbside baggage check-in, which under current rules is halted during terrorist alerts, "is considered the weakest link in the security chain."
Geraldine Frankoski of the Aviation Consumer Action Project said: "The industry is expert at negotiating to avoid the more costly and inconvenient countermeasures. There is no justification for excluding a bona fide public representative from developing these standards."
Gus Danese, head of the New York-New Jersey Port Authority Police Benevolent Association, said, "If there's an extra need for security, let them hire more police officers." He said that "$5-an-hour private guards" were not trained to handle law-enforcement emergencies.
In its draft of the new rules, the F.A.A. promises to be more selective in ordering terrorist countermeasures that "would impose relatively high operational and economic burdens on airports and air carriers."

HEADLINE: Fed Reports a Slow to Moderate Improvement in Business

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Business conditions in most of the country improved at a "slow to moderate" clip during September and October, but large pockets on both seaboards remained lackluster, an anecdotal survey of the Federal Reserve Board's 12 districts showed today.
The findings of the central bank, though noting renewed strength in motor vehicles and housing, struck much the same tone as two months ago when it also described national growth as "slow to moderate," and seemed less buoyant than implied by various recent statistics. 
 The Fed's so-called beige book survey, conducted to aid the members of the Federal Open Market Committee when they gather for a policymaking session on Nov. 16, also pointed to a holiday season that is unlikely to match last year's, when shoppers went on a largely unexpected spending spree.
"Retail sales growth is not expected to be as rapid as last year's strong Christmas season," the report said, summarizing the comments of the five districts that expressed a view on holiday sales.
 
Acute Differences Found
 The survey also showed acute differences among geographic areas and industries. The Chicago and Minneapolis districts appeared particularly strong, while the New York and San Francisco districts were singled out as "mixed," meaning they showed negatives as well as positives.
Smaller home builders in the New York district, for example, which includes northern New Jersey, still found it difficult to get construction loans without a signed contract from a buyer, with loans to acquire and develop land "virtually impossible" to get, the Fed report said.
The San Francisco district reported improvement across much of its eight states, but California remained "sluggish," and weak conditions were also found in western Washington and Hawaii, heavily reliant on aerospace and tourism, respectively.
Partly offsetting the drag in California from cutbacks in military-related manufacturing and construction were some improvements in electronics and retail trade. The motion picture industry and agriculture remained strong.
 
A 'Weak' Picture
 But the Fed concluded, "While contacts in California indicate more positive signs than in previous reports, the overall picture remains weak, particularly in the South."
The Clinton Administration has been seeking ways to aid the most populous state in the country, but this effort seems likely to be confined to the lifting of export controls on high-tech goods and transition aid for military industries, Robert Rubin, the head of the President's National Economic Council, indicated this week.
By contrast, respondents to the survey in the Chicago district reported that factory output had "strengthened considerably" in the last two months, bolstering employment, mainly reflecting a surge in the automotive sector.
At the same time, exporters in the area said they had suffered from weak European activity that had cut demand and led to more aggressive pricing by competitors there.
 
Hiring Is Deferred
 The Chicago district also reported on a poll of small employers in Michigan, a substantial majority of which had deferred hiring because of regulatory uncertainty. On the other hand, the Fed reported that a placement firm for engineers said employers were increasingly expecting the overhaul of the country's health care to be such a "prolonged" process that it had become a less serious constraint to hiring than it had been earlier in the year.
The Minneapolis bank reported that even in Sioux Falls, S.D., which had an unemployment rate of just 1.6 percent, there was a shortage of labor. "Businesses report difficulty finding qualified help," the survey said.
The Atlanta district, which includes Florida, said the retailers in the Southeast had found that consumer spending had leveled off in recent months following relatively strong growth in the first half of 1993 and auto sales "have slowed from their torrid midsummer pace."
 
Richmond Market Stronger
 Richmond reported that the real estate market in its district strengthened slightly, with activity particularly strong in northern Virginia. Lower-priced houses in Charleston, S.C., however, suffered from the announced closing of the naval base there.
The real estate market in New England perked up, with the Boston district reporting single-family house sales running 15 percent to 20 percent ahead of the levels a year earlier in Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Maine. House prices in Connecticut, however, were still falling and expected to bottom out before the spring.
Consistent with recent Government figures, the Fed's survey uncovered very little inflation pressure across the country, describing retail prices as flat and competitive. The demand for bank loans was said to be steady to slightly higher.

HEADLINE: Stocks Tumble in Selloff On Fear of Higher Rates

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Apparently spooked by the prospect of rising interest rates, investors pummeled stocks yesterday, dragging down a broad swath of the market in very heavy volume.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which had hit four record highs in the last 10 days, plunged more than 50 points by late afternoon before the New York Stock Exchange activated its restrictions on computer-program trading to prevent the index from falling further. The Dow ended the day down 35.77 points at 3,661.87. 
 The selloff came as yields on Treasury bonds and notes rose for the fourth session. [Page D16.] Disturbing some traders were signs of price increases in the Federal Reserve's so-called beige book, which noted that business conditions improved at a "slow to moderate" pace in September and October. [Page D2.]
Analysts said yesterday's heavy stock trading seemed to reflect a growing fear that a jump in interest rates would damage the stock market because many investors would switch to fixed-rate securities from equities. Stocks have flourished in the last year on an influx of money from people seeking higher returns on their investments.
The Government in recent weeks has released data indicating that the pace of the recovery was accelerating, pushing down the bond market, which dislikes economic growth because it may fuel inflation. The declines in bond prices in the last four sessions -- and the resulting rises in bond yields -- appear to have increasingly chipped away at the confidence of stock investors.
"It was the worst market we've had in quite a while," said George P. Pirrone, a vice president at the Dreyfus Service Corporation. "People are nervous about high interest rates. If we get a sign -- and we haven't had one yet -- that inflation is ready to rear its ugly head, that could promote a large selloff."
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was 342.1 million shares, up from 304.8 million shares on Tuesday. The heavy volume was tied to computer-program trading that kicked in late in the afternoon, apparently triggered by rapidly declining stock prices.
Declining issues on the Big Board outnumbered advancing issues by nearly 3 to 1. Stocks in small- and medium-sized companies were also pounded. The Nasdaq composite index plunged 12.71 points, to 772.95.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped 5.42 points, to 463.02. The American Stock Exchange's composite index declined 2.58 points, to 481.70.
Many investors spent the day fixated on the Dow Jones utilities index, which fell 6.19 points, or 2.6 percent, to 231.68, its lowest level since Feb. 18. Utility stocks tend to be sensitive to interest rates because those companies are capital-intensive. As the index continued to drop through the day, it spread gloom through the market, traders said.
 
Semiconductors Slump
 All 15 stocks in the utilities index declined, including Philadelphia Electric, down 1 1/8, to 29 1/4; Niagara Mohawk, down 1 1/4, to 20 1/8; Consolidated Edison, down 1 1/2, to 32 1/2, and American Electric Power, down 7/8, to 36 7/8.
Life insurance, bank and stock brokerage stocks were also battered because of the anxiety over interest rates. And semiconductor stocks, which have led many recent rallies, slumped after some analysts warned of a weakness in the demand for computer chips.
"With the way the semiconductors were being sold off, the way the electric utilities were being sold off, they all gave a very bad tone to the market," said Dennis E. Jarrett, the chief market analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company. "We didn't have anything that was really positive to offset the long list of negatives."
Also suffering were the cyclicals, whose earnings are sensitive to the performance of the economy. Motorola plunged 3 7/8, to 99 3/8; Caterpillar dropped 1 3/8, to 91; Allied Signal fell 2 1/4, to 71, and Hewlett-Packard declined 1 5/8, to 74 1/2.
 
Impact of Elections
 Among the few bright spots were the pharmaceutical stocks, which appeared to gain because of the elections on Tuesday. Investors were apparently betting that the defeat of Democrats in New York City, New Jersey and Virginia would weaken President Clinton's ability to push through his health care package, which may cut into the profits of pharmaceutical companies.
Merck rose 1 1/8, to 32 7/8; Pfizer increased 1 3/8, to 63 5/8, and Eli Lilly was up 1 1/8, to 55 3/8.
Technology stocks on the Nasdaq, which have powered that market in recent months, were hit hard. Intel was the most active on the exchange, dropping 1 7/8, to 60 7/8. Nextel Communications fell 2 5/8, to 49 7/8; Microsoft declined 1 3/4, to 78 1/2, and Apple Computer was off 1 1/8, to 31 5/8.
But Claudia Mott, the director of small capitalization research for Prudential Securities, said she was not worried by the steep Nasdaq decline. "The small cap market has done very, very well in the last few months, so it was probably time for a pullback," she said.
Still, she added, "it doesn't mean that anything devastating is going on. It's healthy to have a correction when the market is going too fast and furious so things can proceed upward at a more modest pace."
