HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Governor;
Whitman Triumphantly Pledges Income-Tax Cut by 1994 Budget

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman made a triumphant entry into the State House today only hours after claiming a narrow victory over Gov. Jim Florio. Appearing before a crowd of legislative leaders and cheering supporters, she said she would get to work immediately to redeem a major campaign pledge: cutting income taxes for most residents, beginning with the 1994 budget.
"My first priorities for the state of New Jersey are creating jobs and lowering taxes," said Mrs. Whitman, the first woman ever elected governor of New Jersey. "That's where my focus is going to be." 
 But within an hour, legislative leaders held a news conference of their own where they distanced themselves from the tax plan. The Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, said he wasn't sure the income-tax cut proposal was meant to be "anything concrete," describing it as a proposal made during the campaign season to encourage a comparison with "someone who made no proposals at all." [Page B7.]
Mr. Florio spent the day at the Governor's mansion in Princeton, ceding the spotlight at the capital to Mrs. Whitman. By contrast, in New York City, both Mayor David N. Dinkins and Rudolph Giuliani, the next Mayor, appeared together to appeal to voters to work together for a better New York.
Mr. Florio and Mrs. Whitman did talk briefly by phone about the transition, a conversation that the Governor-elect said was "gracious."
Today Mrs. Whitman, who capitalized on voter anger over tax increases to defeat Mr. Florio by more than 30,000 votes, said her election proved that New Jersey voters were able to see through the smokescreens raised by Mr. Florio during the campaign and focus on the important issues of jobs and the economy.
"The voters of New Jersey did a couple of things yesterday, one of which was to prove the pollsters and the political pundits wrong," she said.
"More than that they really said they wanted a change and they were able to see through a lot of things that were thrown up that weren't necessarily relevant to their desires."
And she said that by electing her, voters signaled a red light to President Clinton and Congress about tax increases.
"They want to see the cuts before they see the tax increase if there's ever going to be tax increases," she said. "The voters did say you've got to take a second look. I believe those in Washington who are watching and have watched this race will understand that, and take a second look at their policies and insure those spending cuts are there."
 
Major Point Is Tax Cut
 Mrs. Whitman staked her campaign on a package of economic proposals that included regulatory reform and increased emphasis on support for small business. But the major proposal was a promise to cut the state income tax for most residents by 10 percent a year for three years.
Today Mrs. Whitman promised to adhere to that plan.
"As I said over and over again, what I talked about in economic policy was not a campaign promise, it wasn't a political promise, it was promise for governance," she said. "And that's how we're going to do the business of New Jersey."
Later, in response to a question, Mrs. Whitman said she would spend her first five months concentrating on trimming the state budget. She said the income-tax cut would take affect July 1, 1994. And when asked again if she could trim the budget enough to offset what will eventually be a 30 percent cut in income taxes, Mrs. Whitman turned to Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, who was seated in the spectators' gallery.
"Are we going to do this?" she asked.
Smiling down at her and giving her the thumbs up, Mr. Haytaian said, "You got it."
At the legislative news conference a short time later, however, Mr. Haytaian joined Senator DiFranscesco in cautioning that Mrs. Whitman would still have to put her plans into detail and obtain Legislative approval.
Mrs. Whitman said she would immediately begin screening potential cabinet appointees, saying she hoped to have most slots filled by the time she takes office in January. She appointed two people to head her transition team: John Sheridan, a Morristown lawyer and former state Commissioner of Transportation, and Hazel F. Gluck, the Whitman campaign chairwoman, who held several positions in the Kean administration.
As the only official elected statewide, New Jersey's governor exercises unusual control over most aspects of state government. Mrs. Whitman will be able to appoint 3,500 positions, according to her chief campaign spokesman, Carl Golden. That number includes all cabinet members, judges from the Supreme Court to the local level, county prosecutors and members of dozens of authorities, including those that operate the Garden State Parkway, New Jersey Turnpike and the New Jersey Sports Complex.
Already political analysts are speculating about the most important positions in the cabinet and the kind of people she might seek to fill those jobs. Even though both leaders of her transition team were members of the Kean administration, some Republican analysts said Mrs. Whitman would not simply look to people from the last Republican administration. They said Mrs. Whitman would take her time in seeking candidates, reaching out to successful people outside of government as well as some who are more familiar with the inner workings in Trenton.
"Just look at the campaign," said one analyst. "She marched to the sound of a different drummer. In June, July, August, when people were telling her to step up the campaign, she didn't give in."
 
Slots to Reflect Population
 Mrs. Whitman said that the positions of treasurer and secretary of state were among the most important slots she would fill and said her administration would reflect New Jersey's population in race and sex.
"I also want cabinet officers who are going to be confident enough in themselves and who they are" to be able to reduce the size of their departments, she said.
Mrs. Whitman said she would meet this week with Republican legislative leaders and Mr. Florio to discuss any unfinished business of this administration. Republicans lost the two-thirds control of both houses they held before Tuesday's election, but held majorities of 24 to 16 in the Senate and 53 to 27 in the Assembly, a Democratic gain of three seats in the Senate and five in the Assembly.
At home in Princeton, Mr. Florio took sympathetic calls from President Clinton, United States Senator George Mitchell of Maine and former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne. Audrey Kelly, the Governor's spokeswoman, said the day belonged to Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Florio did not want to detract from it. The Governor is scheduled to meet with reporters at the State House on Thursday.
After leaving the State House, Mrs. Whitman climbed aboard her campaign bus and made several stops to thank voters.
At Fred & Pete's Deli, a popular Hamilton Township meeting place for local politicians of all stripes, a Whitman volunteer, Bill Baroni, covered a sign advertising the daily specials with a newly printed one: "Welcome to Hamilton Governor Whitman."
Mrs. Whitman was greeted by scores of well-wishers chanting "Christie, Christie."
"A lot of folks in here have seen politicians come and go," said Mr. Baroni as Mrs. Whitman accepted congratulations and signed dozens of autographs. "The people here are treating her like a celebrity. And, well, she is a celebrity."
As Mrs. Whitman thanked local campaign workers, others in the crowd beamed approvingly and were already foreseeing bigger and better things for the Governor-elect.
"If she governs the state well, she's Presidential material," said Wanda Pettit-Schielke.

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: The Capital;
Uncertainty Surrounds New Arrival

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Tony Constantini, manager of the snack bar in the State House, was curious about how to address New Jersey's newly elected head of state. "Can you get used to saying Madame Governor?" he asked with a chuckle this morning.
Mr. Constantini was one of the few people chuckling in the hushed hallways at the seat of New Jersey government today following Christine Todd Whitman's narrow victory over Gov. Jim Florio on Tuesday. Until Mrs. Whitman and her top aides breezed into the Assembly chambers for a news conference in early afternoon, the State House atmosphere was subdued, almost funereal. All morning long, the hallways and the main lobby seemed as empty as a theater hours before curtain time. 
 The prevalent mood was one of startled surprise at Governor Florio's loss and jitters about possible cuts in state jobs once Mrs. Whitman takes office in January.
 
'Almost Everyone's Surprised'
 "I thought he was going to win," said John Fratinardo, manager of State House custodians. "I heard a lot of people say they felt he was going to win. Almost everyone's surprised. They really felt that listening to the polls he wasn't going to lose."
Over at the Labor Department Building, Mr. Fratinardo's sentiments were echoed by an operator in the Office for the Disabled Unemployed.
"I thought sure he was going to win," she said. "Most of the other workers thought so too."
Now come weeks of uncertainty for thousands of state workers, said the operator, a state employee for 23 years. She asked to remain anonymous.
"We know what we have, and now we don't know what we're getting," she said. "I thought he was good. Now she's talking about cutting back. But we never know till they get in that chair. They say one thing and turn around and do another."
The only specific job reduction plan Mrs. Whitman discussed today was a 20 percent cut in the Governor's staff of 152. She spoke generally about trimming the size of some departments, without identifying which ones or by how much. There are about 67,000 state employees.
"The First Lady's office will go for sure," Kim Klein, a secretary in the agency that manages the State House, said of the office that Mr. Florio's wife, Lucinda, opened soon after he became governor.
 
Civil Service
 Ms. Klein is a state civil service employee with 11 years experience. She didn't feel her job was jeopardized.
"Once you're in civil service, you're pretty safe," she said. "It's kind of hard to get fired unless you're really bad. If I get bumped, I'll just bump somebody else with less years than me."
Out on the State House lawn, a groundskeeper who identified himself only as Jim was moving fallen oak leaves into a pile with a leaf blower. He shared none of Ms. Klein's sense of a secure job. In the last seven years, he said, his maintenance crew has been cut from 14 to four members.
"We used to cut grass at 23 state buildings," he said. "Now we don't cut any at all, or plant any flowers, or do any carpentry. Everything is contracted out to private companies who hire illegal aliens.
"The way it looks and the way they're talking, there's going to be a layoff in January," Jim said. "With Florio, at least I had a job."
 
Blueberry Muffins
 Mr. Constantini, the snack bar manager, said the change in government will mean losing old friends in the Florio administration, gaining new ones when Mrs. Whitman takes office and taking care to satisfy a new governor's tastes in snacks.
"Governor Florio likes a blueberry muffin each morning," Mr. Constantini said. "And when he's sick, he gets five to six large teas each day and plenty of soup." Aides stop by for them, he said.
At the Labor Department, Walter Burke, a labor market analyst, spent an afternoon break puffing on his pipe, serenely indifferent to anxieties about a new administration and job security.
"Who was it that said, 'The more things change, the more they stay the same'?" Mr. Burke said. "I think the state runs well and will continue on. Governors come and go. I thought Governor Florio did an excellent job in the face of adversity. I also think Mrs. Whitman will do a very good job."

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: NEW JERSEY -THE VOTERS;
'Undecideds' Decided for Whitman

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
New Jersey's voters remained true on Tuesday to their reputation as an independent and volatile electorate by moving in the last weeks away from an incumbent Governor campaigning as a front-runner and handing a come-from-behind victory to Christine Todd Whitman.
An analysis of responses by nearly 2,000 voters leaving the polls from around the state suggests that Gov. Jim Florio may have run the right campaign for an election being held in mid-October. It was not until the last few weeks that Mrs. Whitman, perhaps by softening her campaign style while Mr. Florio stuck to a scorched-earth approach, captured a bloc of undecided voters that was more than large enough to provide her margin of victory. 
 The voter poll, conducted by Voter Research and Surveys at 40 sites around the state, found that 59 percent of the 2.4 million voters who turned out said they had made up their minds by Labor Day, and that Mr. Florio held the lead in this group by 53 percent to 47 percent.
Fully 30 percent of all voters, however, said they had not decided until the final two weeks of the campaign, and Mrs. Whitman won 58 percent of those voters. Put in terms of raw votes, the net advantage from the last-minute deciders who went for her amounted to 5 percent of the turnout, equal to about 120,000 out of the 1.2 million people who voted for Mrs. Whitman, about four times her 30,000-vote margin of victory.
 
Low-Key Scenes at End
 The last few weeks of the campaign coincided with a marked softening of Mrs. Whitman's tactics. Her advertisements, which for months had been largely negative attacks on the Governor, began to feature her and her children, and paired her in low-key scenes with former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who is still hugely popular in the state.
"She clearly decided to go positive in the last few days, and it turned out to be a good calculation," said David Rebovich, a professor of political science at Rider College, in Lawrenceville. "The undecided voters already knew why they should not vote for Florio. The trick was to get them, one, to turn out, and two, to vote for her. Apparently she did it."
So the last lap of Mr. Florio's roller-coaster ride as Governor turned out to be a downhill one. First written off as all but dead when voter hostility to his $2.8 billion tax increase in 1990 gave Republicans veto-proof control of the Legislature, he fought his way back in earlier opinion polls by stressing his leadership and by savaging Mrs. Whitman's lack of experience in state politics.
As late as September, after Mrs. Whitman was found to be particularly vulnerable for her promise to cut income taxes for most voters by 30 percent over three years, Mr. Florio scored high on qualities of leadership, sensitivity to voters' needs and administrative reliability. A slim majority of respondents even seemed willing to accept his huge tax increase.
 
Different View at the Polls
 On Tuesday, however, voters leaving the polls reported different views of both candidates. They showed themselves to be much more worried about high taxes and the state's laggard economy, issues Mrs. Whitman had run on, than they were on Mr. Florio's strengths, in areas of experience, crime and gun control.
A quarter of the voters also put honesty and trustworthiness as primary values they looked for in a candidate, and three quarters of those who said this said they had voted for Mrs. Whitman.
Finally, Tuesday's voters seemed much more willing to give the Governor-elect the benefit of the doubt on her claim that she could make good on her tax-cut pledge without gutting state services: 51 percent said she could not do it, but 47 percent said she could. She won three-quarters of the votes of those who said she could.
These responses from voters suggest that besides capturing a large 'anyone but Florio' bloc, Mrs. Whitman managed to reach many voters with the three themes of her race: that she was a new breed of citizen-politician, that she wanted to revitalize the political culture of New Jersey by connecting with the people during her administration, and that she had a plausible alternative plan for governing.
 
Aided by the Year of Recall
 Being something of an outsider -- her only other elected office was as a Somerset County freeholder -- may also have helped her with an electorate in an anti-politician, anti-incumbent mood, to judge from the 3-to-1 approval of a constitutional amendment authorizing recall elections in the state.
The gap between the sexes that has emerged as a feature of national politics also played a part in New Jersey's vote, with 53 percent of the women favoring the male Democrat and 55 percent of the men supporting the Republican woman.
Meanwhile, Governor Florio lost about a quarter of the people who said they voted for him in his 1989 race against United States Representative James A. Courter, while Mrs. Whitman kept all but 10 percent of the people who said they had supported her in 1990 in her near upset of Senator Bill Bradley, the event that began her statewide career.
In one of the election's more enigmatic developments, Mrs. Whitman also gained strongly among people with at least some college education in her victory over Mr. Florio. By comparison, in her race with Senator Bradley, voters in those educational categories, amounting to half the electorate, said they favored Senator Bradley by a small margin, while in Tuesday's race, they said they had abandoned the Democrat for Mrs. Whitman by about 55 to 45 percent.
 
Economic Insecurity
 It is impossible to guess at a single factor that could account for such a shift in sympathies among such a large and diverse segment of the electorate, but some analysts suggested yesterday that economic insecurity in a recession that has touched white-collar employment to an unusual degree may be partly responsible for it.
It is clear, however, that Mrs. Whitman cut deeply into areas that were once loyally Democratic. In his 1989 race, Mr. Florio carried all but four rural counties, while on Tuesday, Mrs. Whitman won eight counties that Mr. Florio had won four years ago.
These included Mercer County, seat of the State Capital and home of many state employees who blame Mr. Florio for large reductions in the state work force. Mrs. Whitman also carried the central and southern counties of Monmouth and Ocean, which Mr. Florio easily won four years ago. Those two counties are home to dozens of new communities that have sprung up among sod and fruit farms in recent years to house many retirees and first-time home buyers, who are known to be particularly unforgiving of new taxes.

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Ballots Measures;
New Brooms Sweep In Power of Recall and Term Limits as Well as Candidates

 BODY:

New Weapon: The Recall
New Jersey voters gave themselves new leverage over elected officials Tuesday, approving a constitutional amendment that would allow the recall of everyone from borough council members to United States senators.
The measure, the only statewide ballot question, was approved by a margin of 75 percent to 25 percent. 
 Members of the State Assembly and Senate must now develop the legislation that will put the amendment into practice and could ultimately be used against them.
Politicians are subject to recall after serving one year in office. If 25 percent of registered voters sign a recall petition, a question to remove the official would appear on the following November's ballot.
The time frame effectively exempts members of the State Assembly and House of Representatives, who serve two-year terms.
Recalling United States senators also poses unresolved legal questions, as their terms are governed by the Federal Constitution. Three other states have a recall provision applicable to Federal legislators: Arizona, Wisconsin and Michigan. No attempt has ever been made to recall a United States Senator or Representative, according to Dave Kehler of the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey.
 
Still True to the Blue Laws

Residents of Bergen County decided that they wanted to keep the state's only countywide blue laws, which prohibit most shopping on Sunday.
Voters rejected the effort to repeal the laws by 63 percent to 37 percent, with 99 percent of the county's precincts reporting.
The question was largely about convenience and competitiveness, on the one hand, and the maintenance of suburban tranquillity, on the other. The densely populated county is home to some of New Jersey's largest malls, and many of its more than 825,000 residents commute to New York, a combination that produces perpetual weekday traffic jams.
Even if the county laws had been repealed, several major malls would have remained closed because they are in Paramus, a community that enforces its own ordinances against Sunday shopping and has vowed not to lift them. Repeal would have put the Paramus malls at a disadvantage compared with other malls in the county, and commercial and political pressure to join the rest of the county could have become intense.
 
Results on Term Limits

Voters across New York reached different conclusions on the merits of term limits for local politicians.
In the Rochester area, Monroe County voters decided to limit the county executive to three consecutive four-year terms and county legislators to 10 consecutive years in office beginning in 1995.
In the Binghamton area, Broome County voters defeated a three-term limit for their county legislators. The measure would have increased the length of terms from two to four years.
On Long Island, a majority of Suffolk County voters ruled that top elected officials and county legislators, starting next year, should be limited to 12 consecutive years in one job.
In the city of Plattsburgh near the Canadian border, voters decided the mayor and city council members should have term limits of eight consecutive years starting next year.
Voters in Jamestown defeated a proposal that called for limiting the mayor to two four-year terms as of 1996. The mayor can now serve an unlimited number of two-year terms.
 
New Mayors Upstate
 Several cities in upstate New York are getting new mayors.
Rochester voters knew they would be electing their first black mayor and a political outsider because that's what both candidates were. They chose William A. Johnson Jr., a Democrat who has led the local Urban League chapter for 20 years, over his Republican opponent, Mark Dulaney. Neither one had ever held elected office.
Buffalo will be getting its first new mayor in 16 years: State Senator Anthony Masiello, who swept to an easy victory in the heavily Democratic city. He will replace Mayor James Griffin, a provocative leader who once called the city council "a bunch of goofs" and has picked fights with city officials and reporters.
In Syracuse, a Republican will serve as mayor for the first time in 24 years. Roy Bernardi, the city auditor for 20 years, defeated Joe Nicoletti, a Democratic State Assemblyman. Mr. Nicoletti had been endorsed by the current Mayor, Tom Young, who must leave office because of term limits imposed after a scandal in an earlier administration.
 
Sweep in Southold
 On the ballot, it looked like no contest. Scott L. Harris, the incumbent Republican Supervisor of Southold, L.I., a rural town on the North Fork, was running for a third term on the Republican, Democratic and Conservative lines.
Yet, Mr. Harris and other Republicans with similar cross-endorsements were swept from office by an insurgent party, United Southold, composed of dissidents from the three parties who said town government had grown to be a closed shop, too much in the thrall of local party bosses.
Thomas H. Wickham, the supervisor-elect and scion of one of Southold's oldest families, said even he was surprised by the insurgents' lopsided victory. He defeated Mr. Harris 5,737 to 3,628, in unofficial results.
In another Suffolk County race, Nora Bredes, a Democrat from Stony Brook and an environmentalist, turned back her Republican challenger, Jeanne Garant, a Port Jefferson real-estate agent, who had questioned whether environmental issues deserved top billing in a hard economic time.
Suffolk Republicans scored victories in races for district attorney, sheriff and treasurer, but failed to add to their 11 seats in the 18-member County Legislature.

HEADLINE: Fuel Dispute Is Brewing In E.P.A.

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
In a collision between clean air in New York and foreign policy in Latin America, the Environmental Protection Agency in Washington is considering a request to let Venezuela ship gasoline to the Northeast that contains more of a smog-producing chemical than American refiners will be allowed to market.
The request from Venezuela has created an alliance of two perennial enemies, the domestic oil companies and the top environmental officials of the Northeastern states, who have asked the E.P.A. to deny the request. But the Venezuelan Ambassador to the United States, in a stiffly worded letter, has complained that under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, to which both countries are signatories, the United States must allow the imports. And officials in Washington say the State Department has asked the Environmental Protection Agency to interpret the gasoline rules in a way that favors the Venezuelans. 
 Much of the Venezuelan gasoline would be sold by Citgo, which Venezuela owns and which has more than 6,200 outlets on the East Coast, but the issue is of particular importance in the New York metropolitan area because of summer smog problems. Nearly 20 percent of the gasoline used in the Northeast is imported. About 20 percent of gasoline imports come from Venezuela.
 
Turmoil in Venezuela
 The Venezuelan national oil company, known by its initials, PDVSA, wants to sell gas here containing olefins, a category of smog-causing chemicals, at a level of up to 29.8 percent. Under the Clean Air Act amendments of 1990, American refiners will be limited to 9.2 percent olefins, beginning in 1995.
Venezuela has long been considered a force for moderation within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, and during the Persian Gulf war, when oil prices briefly approached $40 a barrel, the Venezuelans obliged a United States request to maximize oil production, rather than profits. In addition, Venezuela, the hemisphere's largest oil exporter, is in the midst of economic and political turmoil, with two coup attempts so far this year, and the United States does not want to add to instability there. Venezuela has invested heavily in the United States and has recently permitted American companies to invest in its oil sector.
"It's a democracy; it's one of the countries that has supported us," said John Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, based in New York. "There is a special relationship there."
At the Northeast States for Coordinated Air Use Management, an organization comprising the air pollution control directors of New Jersey, New York and the six New England states, the executive director, Michael Bradley, said that the environmental imperatives were clear but that "there is some Department of Commerce sentiment to give them exemptions, for issues unrelated to the environment."
 
Harsh Letters Exchanged
 Environmental considerations often clash with foreign policy goals, but usually the environment at stake is in the Third World, not in this country, and the issue is whether to give aid to a country that is involved in environmentally unsound activity within its borders.
The issue, which the E.P.A. is to decide by Dec. 15, has provoked the exchange of some unusually harsh letters. The chairman of the Sun Company Inc., which uses the Sunoco and Atlantic brand names, said in a letter on Oct. 1 to Carol M. Browner, the E.P.A. Administrator, that "at a recent energy gathering in London two weeks ago, the Venezuela Minister of Petroleum, Dr. Alirio Parra, virtually bragged to the attendees that PDVSA has been able to convince the highest levels of the Clinton Administration that they should be granted special treatment."
Two weeks later, the Venezuelan Ambassador to Washington, Simon Alberto Consalvi, wrote to Ms. Browner that Sun's chairman, Robert H. Campbell, had been "disparaging, intemperate and truly offensive."
But in a letter last week, Mr. Campbell said, "If ever there was a line-in-the-sand issue for the U.S. refining industry and the men and women who work there, this one is it."
 
Effect on Jobs
 A spokesman for Sun, Bud Davis, said yesterday: "We shut down the fuels production portion of our Tulsa refinery because it was going to take $150 million to meet environmental standards. Two hundred people are out of work there because of that.
"Why should those people be out of work because it's so expensive to meet environmental standards, when we have Venezuela getting an exception so they can continue to bring dirty gasoline in?"
A spokesman at the Venezuelan Embassy said no one there yesterday could comment.
Under the Clean Air Act, beginning in 1995 refiners may not sell gasoline with more olefins than was present in their gasoline in 1990. The issue is whether Venezuela will have to hold itself to the olefin level that the law says was present in domestic gasoline in 1990, or whether it may use the level that was present in Venezuelan gasoline in 1990. A different set of rules takes hold in 1998.
Olefins contribute to the formation of nitrogen oxides, which in summer can combine with hydrocarbons in air to make smog. But her agency has not yet reached a decision on the Venezuelan request, she said. She added that the State Department had not taken any official position.

HEADLINE: Towns Use Tax Incentives to Lure Companies

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AVON, Conn.

 BODY:
Years ago this affluent suburb of Hartford was able to rely on a low tax rate, good schools and even an unmistakable New England charm to persuade companies to move here.
But when Bauer Aerospace, a manufacturer of aircraft test equipment, approached Avon officials last spring about receiving tax abatements if they moved to Avon, town officials agreed. Bauer saved itself about $32,000 in taxes over seven years, a small amount compared with the $4 million in grants it received from the state, but money Avon might not have had to give up four years ago. 
 Avon is among several suburban towns in Connecticut beginning to offer tax breaks -- long the purview of larger cities like New Haven and Bridgeport -- to attract companies. Economic development experts point to the lagging economy, stagnant property-tax base and reductions in state aid to wealthier towns as among the reasons.
"Anybody interested in economic development has to get into a participation with the utilities, the state and other agencies," said Avon's Town Manager, Philip K. Schenck. "It's definitely a bargaining environment."
 
Grand Lists Barely Up
 A survey by the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities found that municipal grand lists, the value of all taxable property in a community, had increased an average of only six-tenths of one percent this year, compared with 5.1 percent in 1988-89.
"There's no doubt the effect of the recession has been brought to bear on the suburban towns," Kevin Maloney, a spokesman for the conference, said. "The public is saying, 'We can't afford to pay more. We're in the middle of a recession.' So towns haven't been able to get the tax increases they need just to keep pace with inflation."
Connecticut towns are being more aggressive about using tax incentives than towns in nearby states, development officials said.
In New Jersey, small towns cannot offer such tax abatements, since the Legislature has authorized their use only by the state's large cities. Municipalities in New York have been allowed to offer tax abatements to businesses since 1976, but the state's small towns and suburbs have used them largely to induce companies to expand, instead of to attract new ones.
Joseph M. Cohen, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Economic Development, said towns in Connecticut are following the lead of the state, which has been aggressively pursuing companies that want to move to Connecticut. The state, for example, closed a deal in May with Dun & Bradstreet, giving the financial information company a $7.2 million grant to move its executive headquarters from Manhattan to Wilton.
"Municipalities, in a manner similar to the state, are finding it's a much more competitive game and to meet the national and international competition For jobs, they're being pressed to be more aggressive," he said.
 
Competing With Neighbors
 Yet that competition mimics the state in another way as well: Just as Connecticut is luring companies from neighboring states, especially New York, towns often end up luring businesses from neighboring municipalities.
Cheshire, for instance, approved its first tax-abatement program this summer. The G. S. Building Systems Corporation, which has offices in Newtown and Farmington, is seeking a tax break to consolidate its corporate offices in Cheshire. The company, a unit of General Signal in Stamford, manufactures building safety products like emergency lighting and fire systems.
Similarly, East Haven, a town bordering New Haven, negotiated its first tax break last year when Town Fair Tire, a retail tire company, used a vacant mattress factory there to consolidate its warehouses in Bridgeport and West Haven and its Wethersfield corporate headquarters.
Town and state leaders defend the incentives, saying that even when companies leave one town to move to another, the companies are staying in Connecticut, keeping the jobs in the area. G. S. Building Systems, for example, was considering moving to Maine or Florida, Gerald L. Sitko, Cheshire's economic development coordinator, said. Bauer Aerospace, a division of Woodward Governor Company of Rockford, Ill., was also talking about moving out of state, Mr. Cohen said.
 
East Haven's Program
 East Haven, which now has a tax-incentive program ready for any manufacturer, is working with a national company looking to relocate. The company, which town officials declined to identify is also considering moving out of state, said Louis A. Zullo, the town's director of administration and management.
"What we're offering probably pales in comparison to what they can get in the Sun Belt," Mr. Zullo said. "Maybe it's still costlier to be here, but it might bridge the gap just enough."
The competition among towns is particularly difficult for Connecticut's cities, which were already struggling to steady their industrial base when the recession hit. A second company to benefit from Avon's policy was the Reflexite Corporation, which moved a factory from the neighboring Farmington and its corporate headquarters from New Britain.
 
A Bitter Disappointment
 David O. Prendergast, executive director of the Municipal Economic Development Agency, a nonprofit group that handles New Britain's economic development, said Reflexite's decision was a bitter disappointment for the city. Reflexite, which makes reflecting material for clothing, road signs and other products, had been working with the city on plans to renovate a New Britain building when it heard about the Avon property.
"We were hoping to keep a company that had started here and had been doing very well," Mr. Prendergast said. "But these are the realities of economic development, and sometimes we can't compete with the suburbs, especially in this economy, when there are bargain pieces of real estate."
"It's doubly hard when they offer tax breaks," he said. "That was the kind of thing we used to use to bring us closer to an even playing field."
Reflexite was able to buy the Avon property at a good price: $1.8 million for a 55,000-square-foot building and surrounding 15 acres. The same property sold for $3.7 million in 1986.
But Avon's willingness to offer the company a small tax break -- $5,000 over two years -- also contributed to the company's decision, said Cecil Ursprung, the company's chief executive officer. "In the broad scheme of things, local taxes rarely make or break a deal," Mr. Ursprung said. "But it served as an indicator of the town's desire to have Reflexite become a citizen."
Cheshire town officials realized they needed to have something to offer in addition to the strengths -- its professionally managed government, a small-town atmosphere -- that it traditionally emphasized.
"Historically, a company would come into town and say, what could we do to cut taxes? And we would say, 'We don't do any of that.' And the company might walk out and go somewhere else," Mr. Sitko said. "Just having a policy in place has helped."

HEADLINE: Nobels Pile Up for Chicago, but Is the Glory Gone?

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
The University of Chicago, the home of great conservative economists like Milton Friedman and George J. Stigler, has had an extraordinary run. Just how extraordinary was underscored last month when Robert W. Fogel, an economist who revised history's view of slavery, took the university's fourth Nobel Prize in economics in four years.
With seven Nobel Memorial Prizes in Economic Science in all, the bold, brilliant, free-market Chicago school has won as many Nobels as M.I.T., Stanford and Harvard universities combined. Long distinguished by its emphasis on empirical research, strikingly simple ideas and a biting, polemical style, Chicago has been kicking sand in Cambridge's face since its economics department was founded in 1892 by James Laughlin, an archconservative. 
 To many, however, Chicago's clutch of prizes is a measure of past, not present, influence. "It's old glory that's being rewarded here and much of that is glory that's gone," says Arjo Klamer, an economic historian at George Washington University.
"Chicago doesn't loom very large in people's minds right now," added Paul R. Krugman, an M.I.T. economist who won the John Bates Clark Medal for young economists in 1991.
 
Remaining in the Ivory Tower
 It may be tempting to think that Chicago is out because Clintonomics is in or because the academics who now occupy palatial offices in the Treasury Department or the President's Council of Economic Advisers tend to hail from Cambridge, Princeton or Berkeley. But the measure of the past influence of Chicago never was the number of posts its faculty occupied inside the Beltway. There were few even in the Reagan days when some of Chicago's most outspoken free marketeers chose to stay in the ivory tower, where they could continue to criticize.
"I don't think our department's ever been influential in the sense of phone calls to Washington," says Sherwin Rosen, the chairman of the department. "There's no shuttle service here and there."
Instead, economists at Chicago and elsewhere attribute its waning influence to its own success, the unique role of dominant individuals like Milton Friedman, as well as to the technical bent of its younger faculty. And some of the harshest assessments come from Chicago disciples.
Robert J. Barro of Harvard, who was on Chicago's faculty twice and is one of the most prominent conservative economists of his generation, says, "The kind of work going on there is bound to be less influential."
And David Henderson, a research associate at Stanford's right of center Hoover Institution (where Professor Friedman moved after retiring from Chicago in 1977), says, "The new Chicago doesn't have the old Chicago flash, moral tone or importance for public policy."
Chicago's defenders insist that critics have always denied the influence of Chicago, including during what are now seen to be the good old days, and that Chicago's detractors can't possibly know what current research will prove to be of lasting value.
Chicago's grand slam, of course, was breaking up the near-monopoly in American economic thought by that patron saint of government intervention, the British economist John Maynard Keynes. Keynesianism, which focused on market failures and government policies for correcting them, took hold after the Depression and, by the early 1970's, reigned supreme in the White House and Capital Hill as well as in academe.
Much of the doctrine's influence stemmed from its seemingly successful prescription for avoiding booms and busts by running budget deficits during recessions and surpluses during expansions.
Professor Friedman argued that the apparent postwar successes of policy makers in moderating the economy's swings had more to do with growth of the money supply than with deficit spending and predicted trouble, more inflation and less employment, from the Keynesian policies. His star student, Robert E. Lucas Jr., took the Friedman critique a step further by exposing a fundamental theoretical flaw in Keynesianism.
In a theory that came to be known as rational expectations, he showed that if consumers and businesses could learn from experience, monetary and fiscal policy could do little to smooth the economy's growth except to make things worse. Initially rejected as far out, monetarism and rational expectations gained credence in the 1970's when stagflation -- that nasty combination of high inflation and high unemployment -- stymied Washington and its Keynesian advisers, many of them from Cambridge.
 
Reinvigorating Conservatism
 By boldly showing how well the market worked, how often government failed and how relevant the workings of the market were to social issues, pioneers like Professors Friedman and Stigler helped reinvigorate American conservatism by providing a rigorous, intellectually respectable rationale for laissez-faire. At the same time, innovative Chicago economists, including Gary S. Becker, Ronald H. Coase, Merton H. Miller and others, invented entire disciplines by applying basic economic insights like the law of supply and demand to sociology, law and finance.
"You could call all these people missionaries," says John Y. Campbell, an economist at Princeton. "They all learned Chicago price theory and took it to some benighted field and converted the heathens. There was a very hostile reaction at first, but, in the long run, they made a difference."
Interviews with graduate students, assistant professors, stars and superstars, leave little doubt that Chicago is still a force, one that most economists expect to collect more Nobels. The university nurtures brilliant young scholars: from the labor economist James J. Heckman to the mathematical economist Nancy L. Stokey. And it is still churning out leading-edge research. The university's Nobelists, following a Chicago tradition, eschew elder statesmanhood to pursue ambitious research agendas.
Casey Mulligan, who got his B.A. at Harvard and took his doctorate at Chicago, turned down offers from Harvard and Stanford to stay at Chicago, says: "When I come into my office on Sundays, Gary Becker is in his office, too. If I went into Littauer on a weekday, I wouldn't be able to find Larry Summers." Professor Summers, arguably Harvard's biggest star and winner of this year's John Bates Clark Medal, left his research post (and his office in Harvard's Littauer building) to become, first, chief economist at the World Bank and now Under Secretary for International Affairs in the Clinton Treasury.
 
Dedication Is Intense
 The dedication is so intense that it is no exaggeration to say that Chicago resembles a monastery -- and an atmosphere that is not hospitable to young scholars who want to spend time elsewhere. Professor Becker, whose own research program remains ambitious despite the laurels he has won, says that Chicago is downright unpleasant for anyone not totally immersed in research.
"Nobody minds rudeness, exaggeration or simplicity," Robert W. Vishny, a lively young finance professor, says with a grin.
And at Chicago, economics isn't practiced just in the economics department, but in business, history, sociology and law. Lunchtime talk, indeed talk at any time of the day, is more likely to revolve around models and algorithms than who's doing what to whom.
A typical passing remark at Chicago: "You know why that guy isn't going to run us over even though the light's green?" asks Kevin Murphy, a young labor economist. "It'd cost him a lot of money if he did."
Professor Murphy, an intense redhead who looks more like a high school football coach than an academic, in many ways typifies both the old and new Chicago. His research explains why pay inequality surged during the 1980's. Other researchers had hypothesized that the shift from manufacturing to service jobs, and competition from imports were to blame. But the growing spread of pay within professions and within industries, that Professor Murphy had hypothesized, turned out to be far more important than shifts among industries.
Ironically, this path-breaking research underscores why Chicago is not as influential as it used to be. Its methods and message are no longer as unique as they once were.
 
'Not a Revolution Anymore'
 "When a revolution succeeds, it's not a revolution anymore," says Douglas B. Baird, director of Chicago's Law and Economics Program in the law school.
Professor Krugman, the M.I.T. economist, agreed. "When Gary Becker started with the idea of edcuation or changing jobs or having a third child as investment decisions, it was startling. Now everybody does it."
And while Chicago's brand of libertarianism never won much favor in Washington and it was supply-siders who came to Washington under President Reagan, Chicago indeed succeeded in converting the heathen. Communism is dead. Israel's new central banker, a former Chicago professor, is a hard money man. Former Latin American populists and protectionists now embrace privatization and free trade.
Chicago's lingering influence is also evident in Washington, where Chicago ideas helped push policy back toward the center and helped to lower expectations about how much micromanagement of the economy could hope to achieve.
 
Chicago Has Changed
 But Chicago, too, has changed. It has lost some of its moralistic edge, and is no longer the center of the Chicago school. Many of the extreme real free-market types have chosen the University of Minnesota, the University of Rochester or Carnegie Mellon as their outposts.
"In Chicago under Friedman, there was this moral tone," Mr. Henderson says. "Not only is this important, but it's also to help us figure out what's right and wrong."
Like most other economics departments, Chicago has also become far more abstract. One Cambridge economist called it "a long sorry descent into techno-babble." Mr. Henderson says, "The old Chicago approach based on clearly articulated theories subject to straightforward empirical tests has been lost in favor of slightly mindless mathematical games."
But if Chicago's star has waned, it isn't because another center of influence has emerged. Harvard and M.I.T. -- usually referred to as "Cambridge" -- have generated some excitement in trade, the transformation of socialism to capitalism and financial markets. Princeton dominates labor economics. Stanford has become the headquarters for information economics and game theory.
Some Chicagoans acknowledge that others are catching up. Professor Becker, who won the Nobel Prize in economics last year for work on discrimination, demographics and crime, says he doesn't know if Chicago is still as good as it was. "Is Chicago going to produce as many Nobels? No. Will there be several more? Yes. The monopoly is almost impossible to maintain."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Eases as Traders Await Employment Figures

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar eased against most leading currencies yesterday, taking a step back after recent advances as traders awaited tomorrow's employment figures.
"We had a big day yesterday and we're seeing a little consolidation today as the dollar builds a base ahead of Friday," said Paul Farrell, vice president at Chase Manhattan. 
 Traders will get the first official report on the economy in October tomorrow with the release of the employment data. Unemployment is expected to have remained unchanged at 6.7 percent, and payrolls are expected to have grown by 146,000, compared with the prior month's rise of 156,000.
Dealers attributed the dollar's weakness against the Japanese yen yesterday partly to capital flows into Japan and out of the weakening Treasury bond market.
"They're selling U.S. 30-year bonds and dollars along with it, and repatriating the yen," a dealer said.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 107.63 yen, from 107.78 on Tuesday.
But mostly, dealers cited technical selling after the dollar surged to an 11-week high Tuesday against the German mark after the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, said the central bank was not concerned about the dollar's strength.
 
'Having a Hard Time'
 "The dollar market's long and looking to retrace, but we're having a hard time approaching a solid selloff," said Richard Koss, director of foreign exchange sales for CIBC. "There's still sentiment to buy dips, but we're having a hard time pushing higher ahead of Friday's number."
The dollar fell to 1.6943 German marks in late New York trading, from 1.7040 marks on Tuesday.
The Federal Reserve's beige book, a survey of American economic activity, had little impact on the dollar, although it noted an increase in the pace of manufacturing and consumer spending. The Fed also said there were some shortages in automobile inventories. The beige book said retail prices had been mostly flat.
The British pound closed in New York at $1.4820, up from $1.4730 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.5010 Swiss francs, up from 1.4730, 5.9065 French francs, down from 5.9385; 1,637 Italian lire, down from 1,644, and Canadian $1.3087, up from $1.3070.

HEADLINE: AT WORK WITH: Chief Wilma Mankiller;
The Name's the Most and Least of Her

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAHLEQUAH, Okla., Oct. 29

 BODY:
When she was 10 years old, says Wilma Pearl Mankiller, the principal chief of the Cherokee Nation, "I set out on what I call my own little Trail of Tears."
Having spent her childhood in Mankiller Flats, near this Cherokee capital in the hills of eastern Oklahoma, she was uprooted in 1956 when her father, a full-blooded Cherokee, enrolled in a Federal program intended to urbanize rural Indians. She had never been west of Muskogee, and she, her parents and seven brothers and sisters were stepping on a train bound for San Francisco.
"I remember as we drove to the train, I felt so sad," she said. "I wasn't excited at all. I was trying to memorize every tree, and what the school looked like, which flowers were blooming in my grandfather's front yard, all those sorts of things."
But unlike the Cherokees along the notorious Trail of Tears of the 1830's, who were forced to move from their homeland in what is now the Carolinas and Georgia hundreds of miles west, Wilma Mankiller eventually came home again.
Hers is, in fact, a remarkable tale of a life come full circle, chronicled in a new book, "Mankiller: A Chief and Her People" (St. Martin's Press), which she wrote with Michael Wallis, a Tulsa journalist and author. It takes her from a childhood in the heart of Cherokee territory to a life as an unhappy housewife in the San Francisco Bay Area to what she says was an awakening in the protests of the 1960's that led her back to Tahlequah in the late 70's as an agitator for water lines, better schools and health clinics.
In 1985, she became the principal chief of the 94,460-member Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma. The first elected female leader of a major Indian tribe, she won a full four-year term in 1987 and was re-elected in 1991.
Chief Mankiller, whose mother is of Dutch and Irish descent, is a stocky woman whose face radiates a placid authority. But she can quickly inject a humorous edge into the conversation -- for instance, when the subject of her name comes up.
"Mankiller," an old term of respect for Indian warriors who guarded tribal villages, has been in her family for several generations. It's not an unusual name in these parts. There are Fourkillers and Tenkillers and Whitekillers, too. But outside of Oklahoma, she says, it draws comments, questions and even nervous laughs.
"Some people do earn their names in native culture," explains Chief Mankiller, who turns 48 on Nov. 18. "I didn't, but I don't always tell people that. Sometimes I just say that Mankiller is my name, I earned it, and I let 'em wonder."
But not just anyone can joke about the name. As her book makes clear, she was not amused when the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal, noting her presence at President Clinton's economic summit in Little Rock, Ark., said: "Our favorite name on the summit list, we have to admit, is Chief Wilma Mankiller, representing the Cherokee Nation, though we hope not a feminist economic priority." Chief Mankiller calls the remark "a cheap shot" and "a rather unfortunate remark about my surname."
At the modern brick-and-glass Cherokee Nation headquarters, the chief offers a study in eclecticism. For one thing, her wall decorations range from the tribal seal to Georgia O'Keeffe prints, from old legal codes written in the Cherokee syllabic alphabet to framed letters from Ronald Reagan and George Bush.
"It just came and the staff put it up," she says dismissively of the Reagan letter, which congratulates the chief on her leadership. "Ronald Reagan was not good on Indian issues at all. I met with him, along with some other people, and he didn't have the tiniest bit of interest in Indian issues," including increasing Federal funds for Indian health or education. Still, his letter is up there on her wall.
As a tribal chief, she knows plenty of traditional dances. But her favorite dancing song, she says, is Aretha Franklin's "Respect."
Chief Mankiller is at once the guardian of a centuries-old Cherokee heritage, encapsulated in the seal and the legal codes, and the chief executive of a major corporation, Cherokee Nation Industries, whose income from factories, a motel, gift shops, a ranch, a lumber company and other concerns accounts for nearly half the tribe's $76 million annual budget. Call the chief and a recording says: "Thank you for calling the Cherokee Nation. If you're calling from a touch-tone phone and know your party's extension, please dial it now."
While the Cherokee have a much stronger economic base than many other tribes, and tend to mix their economic and social activities more freely with the surrounding non-Indian population, Chief Mankiller says the money the tribe directs back into health-care and job-training programs, Head Start and a local high school has not produced miracles.
"If you look at data over the last 20 years, we've had an impact in infant mortality and the educational attainment level," she says. "We're nowhere near where we need to be on any of those issues, nowhere near, but we're headed in the right direction."
In her book, Chief Mankiller alternates accounts of the Cherokee Nation with her own personal narrative, both uncommon stories of survival. In her case, a head-on automobile collision in 1979 almost killed her; she has battled a degenerative nerve disorder, myasthenia gravis, and a few years ago she would have died from kidney failure had an older brother not given her one of his kidneys.
"To think of myself outside the context of the tribe or my family or my community would be very difficult," she insists in the interview.
One of the most critical episodes in Chief Mankiller's life was the seizure in 1969 of Alcatraz, in San Francisco Bay, by a group of Indians who claimed the island "in the name of Indians of all tribes." They stayed there for 19 months, and Ms. Mankiller visited frequently.
"I had felt there was something wrong with me because I wasn't happy being a traditional housewife," says Ms. Mankiller, who at the time was married to a wealthy Ecuadorean businessman, Hugo Olaya. "I started listening to what these people were saying. What Alcatraz did for me was, it enabled me to see people who felt like I did but could articulate it much better. We can do something about the fact that treaties are no longer recognized, that there needs to be better education and health care.
"This was also the time of the women's movement," she adds, growing more animated. "I saw women standing up and speaking out. All these things were powerful influences on me."
She had returned to Oklahoma a few times to see relatives and in, 1971, to take home the body of her father, Charley Mankiller. By 1977, divorced, she returned for good with her daughters, Gina and Felicia, who still live nearby with their four children.
"I never felt home until I came home," she explains. "When I came back here, then I began to understand, this is where I belong."
"One day I went to the courthouse in Stilwell to check on some land and I'm walking across the courthouse square. And there's a group of Cherokee men, old guys chewing tobacco, just sitting in judgment of everybody and the world. And then someone said, 'Ho, there goes John Mankiller's granddaughter!' That had such an impact on me. It was very sweet to my ears. I knew I was home, because no one in a courthouse in San Francisco would have ever said that."
Another profound event a few years after she moved back was her marriage to Charlie Soap, 48, a full-blooded Cherokee and community activist whom she credits with helping her get involved with Cherokee issues and to win election as chief.
"My ideas were way more liberal than those of the people I was asking to elect me," she says. But Mr. Soap, who had been in the area a long time, helped to assure the elders that she was not too radical and emphasized that, at least before the arrival of the white man, Cherokee women played a major role in tribal government.
Ms. Mankiller attracted considerable attention with her ascension to tribal leadership in the 1980's and her designation as a Woman of the Year by Ms. Magazine in 1987 -- as well as with honorary degrees from several Ivy League colleges and installation in the National Women's Hall of Fame in Seneca Falls, N.Y.
She says that when publishers approached her about writing a book, she insisted that it cover plenty of Cherokee history and the flaws of several figures long revered in American history, from Columbus (she includes a quote from the Indian activist Russell Means that Columbus "makes Hitler look like a juvenile delinquent") to Thomas Jefferson.
What's next? Next year she and her mother are off to Ireland to search for their roots. And what about 1995, when she is up for re-election?
Her husband, ever the supportive political spouse, says: "I'd certainly like to see her continue. If she runs, I'll be there, supporting her, going down roads campaigning for her."
And Chief Mankiller, the successful politician, is judiciously noncommittal. "I've kind of put off thinking about that, because it's two years away," she explains. "Maybe I'll start thinking about it in the spring."

HEADLINE: Relatively Few Taxpayers Are Jolted by the Nanny Scandal

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
THE Zoe Baird nanny scandal was expected to teach American taxpayers, be they rich or middle class, a lesson: you can't get away with employing illegal immigrants or failing to pay Social Security and Medicare taxes for legal domestic workers. Come clean or pay the price.
But it appears that many Americans didn't take to heart the predicament of Ms. Baird, who withdrew as a candidate for Attorney General in January partly because she had not paid the proper taxes for her household help. 
 It also seems that when it came to a choice between cutting into the earnings of a cherished nanny to pay Federal taxes or breaking the law by keeping quiet about employer-employee relationships, many taxpayers adopted the military approach: "Don't ask, don't tell."
Ms. Baird's case and similar situations encountered by a number of other Clinton Administration nominees appear to have jolted some people into action. The Internal Revenue Service reported a 17 percent increase in the number of Americans who paid taxes for domestic help in the first quarter of 1993 over the same period a year earlier.
"We suspect the reason for the difference between the first quarter calendar year of 1993 and the same period last year was that people were catching up for prior years, paying taxes for several quarters," said Donald D. Roberts, a spokesman for the I.R.S.
But the increase in those paying the taxes, to 408,000 from 349,000, is not expected to continue throughout the year, Mr. Roberts said. "We think we will probably see at least a 5 percent annual increase in the total number of quarterly returns of 942's -- the forms filed by employers for household help," he said.
The last available data for a full year are for 1991, from the Census Bureau and the I.R.S. A study based on the data estimated that only 25 percent of two million households employing domestic workers paid the required taxes that year.
Under the 1950 law that provides Social Security coverage for domestic employees, a 15.3 percent tax must be paid for every household employee who earns more than $50 in a calendar quarter, even the teen-ager who occasionally shovels snow or mows the lawn. Half of the 15.3 percent is supposed to be paid by the employer and half withheld from the employee's pay. If the worker is paid more than $1,000 in a quarter, unemployment taxes must also be paid.
It sounds simple, but it's a little more complicated than that.
"It wouldn't be so bad if it were just the 942's," said Albert A. Miller, a partner in Miller Levine & Company, an accounting firm in New York. "What happens is everybody gets into the act. Once you file the 942's, you become subject to state and Federal unemployment insurance taxes. Add to that the W-2 forms; now you're up to three or four pieces of paper.
"If you want to catch up, you're talking penalties and interest ad infinitum, and the I.R.S. changes its interest rates every six months."
Then, there's the little problem of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. A woman who called a radio talk show after the Zoe Baird story was front-page news told of paying her cleaning woman's Social Security, which brought the employee to the attention of the immigration agency. The agency then began questioning her.
Mr. Miller, the accountant, said he had found that most people who have permanent domestic workers were, and still are, complying with the law. Those with temporary help or people who come in once a week, he said, "ignored it, paid in cash and still do."
The issue gained widespread attention when Ms. Baird, President Clinton's first nominee for Attorney General, said she had not paid the required taxes for her nanny and her chauffeur, who were illegal immigrants. The President's next nominee, Judge Kimba M. Wood of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, was forced to withdraw after it was learned that she and her husband had employed an illegal immigrant to care for their son -- although doing so was legal at the time and she had paid the required taxes.
There are others who ran into problems over the issue. They include Ronald H. Brown, the Secretary of Commerce, who admitted having failed to pay taxes for a maid; Judge Stephen G. Breyer, a leading candidate for the Supreme Court, who did not pay taxes for a part-time housekeeper, and Shirley Sears Chater, the new Social Security Commissioner, who failed to pay taxes for a part-time baby sitter in the early 1970's.
Ms. Baird pleaded ignorance of the law. That is no excuse, but she apparently wasn't alone. News reports and Congressional testimony indicated that most Americans had not fully understood the law or known of its existence. And there are those who say they are perfectly happy not knowing whether the people they hire to work in their homes are in the country legally.
"If you use an agency, you get people with proper papers," said a woman who works as a social worker in Chicago and spoke only on condition of anonymity. "I got my housekeeper and nanny based on the recommendations of friends. I didn't bother to ask whether they were in the country legally. Even if they weren't, I wasn't about to turn them in."
Indeed, some taxpayers are finding that obeying the law may mean risking the loss of valued help.
The housekeeper of a woman on the Upper East Side threatened to quit if her employer began withholding a percentage of her salary. The woman, who also insisted on anonymity, said she acquiesced to avoid losing a trusted employee of nearly 10 years.
After years of paying their household help in cash, a well-to-do Hollywood couple with friends in the entertainment business, decided it was time to play it safe, which to them meant not only paying by check, but also withholding taxes.
"My husband and I went to our cook, our gardener, our nanny and our housekeeper and told them what we were going to do," the woman said, adding that she suspected that some of her workers were not legal residents. "They were horrified and begged us not to. The cook and the gardener said they would have to leave because they needed every cent they were earning."
The couple decided to leave well enough alone.
With President Clinton's new tax package expected to bring a tax increase primarily to those who can afford to hire nannies and housekeepers, it's doubtful that many Americans will voluntarily pay a tax they've been getting away with not paying. Besides which, there is nothing to indicate that the I.R.S. plans to crack down on violators, Zoe Baird notwithstanding.
"Our neighbors said we were foolish to even think about paying taxes for our household help," the Hollywood woman said. "It's like that old saying: Why invite trouble?"

HEADLINE: Review/Theater: The Lights;
Crime, Drugs, Trash, the Homeless: Urban Reality at Its Grimmest

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
The bleak urbanscape that brought New York City a new Mayor this week can be found live onstage at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center. Howard Korder's play "The Lights" is set in an unnamed "large city" of "the modern era" that would have been right at home in Rudolph Giuliani's campaign commercials. Crime, drugs and garbage are rampant. The homeless are always underfoot. Civic corruption is ubiquitous. The good old immigrant values that once built the town are in rout.
And Mr. Korder's prescriptions for salvation are vague. "The Lights" is a two-hour, 40-minute wallow in the mess that would rather curse the familiar darkness with Expressionist flourishes than light any candles. It is the second urban nightmare play to arrive Off Broadway this week -- following "The Treatment" at the Public -- and it often seems indistinguishable from recent productions of Jose Rivera's "Marisol" and Sophie Treadwell's "Machinal," not to mention the doomsday Gotham of Tim Burton's "Batman" films. Given Mr. Korder's penchant for David Mametesque dialogue, audiences with longer memories will find echoes of Mr. Mamet's "Edmond" and "Water Engine" as well. 
 Though "The Lights" opens a Festival of New American Plays at the Newhouse, newness is hardly one of its qualities. Mr. Korder, whose earlier plays include "Boys' Life" and "Search and Destroy," can be both a provocative and bleakly funny writer, but in aiming for epic scope in this highly populated piece, he often states the obvious thunderously. The play seems to be speaking down to an unsophisticated audience, and it cautiously sticks to oblique references to racial divisions rather than risk getting anyone mad. Even the script's occasional subtle moments are often hammered in with overbearing electronic music, sound or visual effects that can turn a mild curtain line into a portentous cue for the End of Civilization as We Now Know It.
Here and there you can spot signs of the author's talent. Undisciplined and sprawling as "The Lights" may be, it has a clever trigger: the small act of shoplifting a watch at the play's start sets all its enormous machinery in motion (when it is in motion) and also introduces Mr. Korder's meditative, even hallucinatory preoccupation with time and history. Patient viewers will also discover some eerily poetic set speeches, including one in which the city is viewed from a skyscraper's great height and dissected as an infinity of individual decisions, "piled one on top of another," that may reflect what its citizens really want after all.
More typical of this predictable evening is the major and schematic plot thread that deterministically reduces Fredric (Dan Futterman), a young unemployed man who reviles the panhandling homeless, into the very image of what he despises. Fredric's sometime girlfriend Lilian (Kathleen Dennehy) is just as mechanically dehumanized when she and a fellow shopgirl (Kristen Johnston) allow themselves to be picked up by a pair of piggish businessmen (Jerry Grayson and Christopher McCann) who don't think twice about raping either the city or its female inhabitants.
The British director is Mark Wing-Davey, who does not draw many distinctions between the American city of "The Lights" and Ceausescu's Romania, which he brought to such stunning life in his production of Caryl Churchill's "Mad Forest." One size apocalypse fits all. Similarly, the gifted designer Marina Draghici has provided a striking two-level set -- part Constructivist, part Fritz Lang -- that will be most impressive to audiences who didn't see her similar design for the New York Shakespeare Festival's "Woyzeck" last season.
At their best, Mr. Korder, Mr. Wing-Davey and Ms. Draghici collaborate with the superb lighting and costume designers, Christopher Akerlind and Laura Cunningham, to create sepia-tinged spectacles that recall in words and chiaroscuro the urban jungle fantasized about in 30's Hollywood. A chaotic movie premiere suggests "The Day of the Locust," and the shopgirls' misadventures with moneyed male predators could be a sweaty Wallace Beery subplot from "Grand Hotel."
Other sequences are merely heavy, visually and aurally, and so is much of the acting from the Atlantic Theater Company. Jordan Lage and Steven Goldstein, past specialists in the Korder canon, have their sharp moments in various roles, as do Mr. Grayson, Mr. McCann and Ray Anthony Thomas. The rest are forgettable faces in the crowd, dutifully animating what one line accurately describes as "everyday scenes of violence and degradation" at which "we feel nothing."
 
The Lights
By Howard Korder; directed by Mark Wing-Davey; sets by Marina Draghici; costumes by Laura Cunningham; lighting by Christopher Akerlind; additional music and sound by Mark Bennett; fight director, David Leong; general manager, Steven C. Callahan; production manager, Jeff Hamlin. A Festival of New American Plays, Play No. 1, the Atlantic Theater Company, presented by Lincoln Center Theater, under the direction of Andre Bishop and Bernard Gersten. At the Mitzi E. Newhouse, Lincoln Center, 150 West 65th Street.

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: Suburbs;
Region's Incumbents Are Shaken Winners

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
While incumbents were toppling almost everywhere, the Republican leaders of Nassau and Suffolk Counties managed to survive election night in one piece, but they suffered a fright they will not soon forget.
In Westchester, Andrew P. O'Rourke, County Executive for 11 years, beat Richard L. Brodsky, a six-term Assemblyman by fewer than 4,000 out of 207,000 votes cast, a far smaller margin than the last time Mr. Brodsky challenged him in 1989. In Nassau, Thomas S. Gulotta narrowly held off Benjamin L. Zwirn, the maverick Democratic Supervisor of North Hempstead, by 4 percentage points -- again far closer than his two earlier victories for the County Executive's job. 
 The narrow margin was particularly surprising in Nassau, where Republicans enjoy a 3-to-2 edge in voter registration and have one of the nation's most vaunted political machines.
The tight contests, political analysts said, reflected an anti-incumbent mood throughout the Northeast that is attributed to a faltering economy and that hurt Mayor David N. Dinkins in New York City as well as Gov. Jim Florio in New Jersey.
"There's a restlessness in the land with the way things are," said Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute of Public Opinion.
But the races in Westchester and Nassau, Mr. Miringoff and other analysts said, also reflected a discontent that important problems are not being solved effectively or fairly.
In Nassau, a Republican patronage machine that fills hundreds of county jobs with party favorites has been partly blamed for driving up taxes and chasing away businesses that could provide jobs. Nassau's bonds are rated one notch above junk bonds.
 
Sending a Signal
 Many voters signaled Tuesday that they had had enough. Indeed, the Democratic organization was claiming victory of sorts by its surprisingly strong showing against Mr. Gulotta and its victories in more local races.
In Westchester, Mr. Brodsky ceaselessly reminded voters that Mr. O'Rourke had raised property taxes 124 percent during his 11 years. On a more personal level, Mr. O'Rourke was hurt by disclosures that he sought jobs and favors from county contractors for his live-in companion and family members.
"I'd actually rather have a Republican conservative in office than a Democrat because I think with Brodsky chances are taxes will rise," said Joan R. Katz, a retired teacher as she voted in Scarsdale. "But I don't like it that O'Rourke used his power to help a friend and so I voted for Brodsky."
Paradoxically, complaints about high taxes may have helped salvage the jobs of the two County Executives. Even if they were unhappy with Republican spending, many voters may have feared that the Democrats would spend even more, said Peter W. Delaney, Mr. O'Rourke's campaign manager.
 
Candidate Potshots
 In a blitz of television advertisements on the final weekend, Mr. O'Rourke portrayed Mr. Brodsky as "addicted" to raising taxes in Albany, just as Mr. Gulotta painted Mr. Zwirn as a tax-and-spend liberal.
Ultimately, the outcome may have been decided by such picayune political details as a lower-than-hoped-for turnout in Mr. Brodsky's home base of Greenburgh to offset the advantage Mr. O'Rourke has always had in attracting conservative Democrats in the city of Yonkers.
In plotting to snatch the county's top political job, Richard L. Brodsky faced three mountainous obstacles. He had to become better known, overcome a tough primary opponent, and persuade Westchester residents that their sense of well-being was an illusion.
In some ways, those goals clashed with one another to his disadvantage. The primary fight with County Clerk Andrew J. Spano, he said yesterday, cost him $185,000 that he could have spent against Mr. O'Rourke. In the waning days, he had almost no money to counter Mr. O'Rourke's television advertisements depicting Mr. Brodsky as a spendthrift "Liberal to a Fault."
Yet, Mr. Brodsky came close enough to capturing the executive's prize that he has demanded a recount.
The issues that he hit repeatedly were high taxes, ebbing jobs, and the ethical blindness of Mr. O'Rourke, issues that, in a sour economy, were far more resonant than four years ago. Mr. Brodsky did well in such upscale bastions as Scarsdale and Mamaroneck, which have also suffered from corporate layoffs, and he did better than four years ago in White Plains, Ossining and Eastchester. Mr. O'Rourke never racked up the margin predicted by a Gannett Suburban Newspaper poll of 11 percentage points.
 
'By and Large Satisfied'
 Still, Mr. Brodsky's efforts were not enough to erode Mr. O'Rourke's advantages as the incumbent who still runs a county with a AAA bond rating and a 5.7 percent unemployment rate.
"People are by and large satisfied with the way things are," said Dr. Anthony A. Cupaiuolo, director of the Michaelian Institute of Public Policy and Management at Pace University.
Mr. Delaney, Mr. O'Rourke's campaign manager, said Mr. O'Rourke neutralized Mr. Brodsky's criticisms on taxes by pointing out that Mr. Brodsky was not above suspicion in this area, having voted 48 times for tax increases as a legislator.
"When taxes and spending are the key issue, there's no question that people believe Republicans handle it better," he said.
That observation was echoed by voters in the affluent town of Rye.
"As far as I'm concerned, taxes are the issue, and a Republican will keep them down," said Roger Clark, a retired sales manager.
Time and again, Mr. Brodsky attacked Mr. O'Rourke as tired and corrupt. But, Mr. O'Rourke observed at a news conference yesterday that Mr. Brodsky did not have enough of a countywide identity to make such nasty charges without developing a venomous image that finally cost him.
