HEADLINE: Essay;
7 More in '94

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
To Tip O'Neill's dictum, "all politics is local," let me append Safire's Corollary: all local politics is now national.
Looking from the bottom up: a local election in a television age has a national impact. Looking from the top down: the national fixation on Presidential fortunes has an effect on the decisions of voters in local elections. 
 In the urban base of what became the G.O.P.'s 1993 triple play, Republican Rudy Giuliani was squeaking past Mayor David Dinkins on the crime issue. Then Bill and Hillary Clinton came in and turned it into an open "race race" with his inflammatory "too many of us are still too unwilling to vote for people who are different than we are."
That grated on my ears (he meant to say "people who are different from ourselves") but grated more coarsely on the ears of white New York liberals, fed up with a passive Mayor, who did not appreciate the President lecturing them about how their anti-incumbent votes were motivated by racism. In this way, Clinton nationalized the city's election and magnified Democratic defeat.
In Virginia, a stone's throw from D.C., Republican George Allen ran against the "Clinton-Wilder-Robb" set, the Clinton tax double-cross, and the Clinton government-controlled health plan. Local Democrats, afflicted with voter distaste at their national policies, were reduced to running against fear of the religious right; they succeeded only in knocking off a novice running for Lieutenant Governor. In the State House, Governor Allen will help steer Virginia rightward in national races.
New Jersey was the big one. The defeat of Democratic Gov. Jim Florio was rooted in the most national of issues -- tax increases -- and had the greatest impact. Liberals were saying for weeks that New Jersey was the key battleground this year because they thought a Florio victory would endorse Clinton's tax hikes.
But the winner, Christie Whitman, promised tax cuts for economic growth, and her victory is a blow to Clintonism. Her campaign strategist, Ed Rollins, was a card-carrying Reaganite; Florio's James Carville is Clinton's political guru, who should change his favorite sign to "It's the taxation, stupid."
What do this week's three-for-three G.O.P. victories, added to three-for-three earlier this year, mean for national politics? The impossible is now possible: control of the U.S. Senate is within reach, which would effectively end the creeping centralization of government power. Bob Dole's slogan is "Seven More in '94."
Looking especially vulnerable today are Democrats Robb of Virginia and Lautenberg of New Jersey. Wofford of Pennsylvania is shaky, as are Bingaman of New Mexico and Kohl of Wisconsin. Mathews of Tennessee, appointed to Al Gore's seat, is a G.O.P. target, as is Jim Sasser, who also runs in '94. (Tennessee Republicans are eager to have the Vice President nationalizing their campaigns; they think he can be as useful as Hillary Clinton was to Dinkins and as Janet Reno was in campaigning for Florio.)
Democratic open seats are Riegle's in Michigan, Metzenbaum's in Ohio and DeConcini's in Arizona; Republicans have a good shot at all three. Of open seats now Republican -- Durenberger's in Minnesota, Danforth's in Missouri and Wallop's in Wyoming -- only Minnesota is considered vulnerable.
What can turn a possibility into a reality? Events like Election Day 1993, for starters; as Dole says: "Winning builds confidence. Winning helps us raise money and recruit candidates." Losing works the other way: In D.C. today, it's hard to tell a Democrat from a Redskins fan.
If Republicans, running as candidates of change, upset the status quo in the Senate in 1994, the recent statist drift would be corrected. Clinton would not be finished -- the results of his foreign economic policy might save his political life -- but all eyes would be on the likely Republican challengers.
California Gov. Pete Wilson is on the comeback trail; if re-elected in '94, he and Jack Kemp -- both reach-out conservatives -- will be front-runners in the primaries, putting the party in a win-win position. What about Bob Dole, who might then be majority leader -- would he give up that power to run for President?
Dreamily, Dole says: "That would be a nice worry to have."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: No Boon From Yankees

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has never lost his boyhood love for baseball, but he stands on shaky ground when he uses an economic argument for keeping the Yankees in New York. 
 An eight-year study of 47 United States cities found that those with professional sports teams lag behind those that create a wider set of incentives for all private industry. The Lake Forest College study and others show pitfalls when governments give special breaks to pro sports.
Pro teams produce mainly low-paying seasonal jobs. A small group of owners and players tend to benefit. Players and owners often live elsewhere. Money the public spends watching pro teams would be spent in other local leisure activities.
There are other reasons, including a spiritual one, for keeping the Yankees in the Bronx.
 
FRED BRATMAN
New York, Oct. 29, 1993

HEADLINE: THE 1993 ELECTIONS: News Analysis;
The Tide Turns on Voter Turnout

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
For all the predictions of epochal changes that Rudolph W. Giuliani's election will mean at City Hall, his historic victory resulted much less from an overwhelming change in voters' attitudes and more from tiny shifts in the voting blocs that he and David N. Dinkins assembled in 1989.
Those shifts, coupled with higher turnout in white neighborhoods -- especially on Staten Island -- and the failure in some black neighborhoods to capitalize on registration increases, enabled Mr. Giuliani to amass a 44,000-vote margin. 
 Surveys of voters leaving the polls found that compared to 1989, support for Mr. Dinkins eroded most among whites -- especially college graduates, self-described moderates and Protestants -- and to a lesser degree among Hispanic New Yorkers.
But shifts among other groups were negligible or statistically insignificant. For example, the share of Jewish voters for Mr. Dinkins declined from 35 percent to 32 percent, of white liberals from 51 percent to 50 percent, and of Democrats from 69 percent to 67 percent.
 
Similar Patterns
 In fact, voting patterns were so similar across the city that even though district lines have changed somewhat since 1989, a map showing the candidates' relative strengths on Tuesday is almost an exact copy of the 1989 map. The numbers within the districts are similar, too. In the integrated and liberal Flatbush-Park Slope area Mr. Dinkins received 13,925 votes on Tuesday, as against 14,143 in 1989. On the Upper West Side he received 25,916, compared with 23,287 four years ago.
Still, in every borough, Mr. Dinkins received fewer votes than he had four years ago. And in every borough except the Bronx, Mr. Giuliani collected more than his 1989 totals.
Nearly half of Mr. Giuliani's victory margin could be attributed to his gains on Staten Island, where turnout was bolstered by a referendum to secede from the city whose mayor the island helped elect. More than 20,000 additional voters turned out on Staten Island compared to 1989, and Mr. Giuliani's vote total in the borough increased by nearly the same amount.
"Rudy," said Robert Shrum, Mr. Dinkins's media adviser, "is the mayor of Staten Island."
 
Two Political Milestones
 To become mayor-elect, Mr. Giuliani achieved two political milestones: He is the first Republican in modern times to win what amounted to a two-way race; and, in striking contrast to two other Republicans, Fiorello H. La Guardia and John V. Lindsay, Mr. Giuliani ran to the right ideologically of his Democratic rival.
But it is arguable whether his election signaled either a sudden seismic shift or the precursor of an enduring conservative trend in a city where liberal nostrums have historically been preached if not always practiced. Moreover, a shift of fewer than 25,000 votes, or less than 2 percent of the total, would have produced the opposite result.
In many ways, Mr. Giuliani eked out his victory by reassembling and broadening the traditional coalition that has elected every Democratic mayor of New York for decades -- except for the one he defeated Tuesday, Mr. Dinkins, as well as the last Republican, Mr. Lindsay. For decades New York City politics was defined by competition between candidates identified with Jewish constituencies and others identified with white Catholic voters. But in the 1970's the two constituencies joined. "Both groups were in a long-term relative decline and race was a factor that drove them together," said John H. Mollenkopf, a political science professor at the City University of New York Graduate Center.
 
The Koch Coalition
 In his book "A Phoenix in the Ashes," Mr. Mollenkopf wrote that Mr. Dinkins's campaign four years ago represented an unusual black-led, biracial, multiethnic insurgent coalition. And Mr. Mollenkopf warned presciently that "the Dinkins coalition may founder, as have many of its reform predecessors, on its internal contradictions, opening the way to efforts to restore the Koch coalition in some new form."
On Tuesday, Mr. Mollenkopf said, "the white ethnic and Jewish outer-borough base that you would call the core of the Koch coalition is certainly what provided the bulk of the Giuliani coalition as well."
"Latinos and Jews did not desert Dinkins in big numbers," Mr. Mollenkopf said. "The differential in turnouts accounts for a lot."
Raymond B. Harding, the Liberal Party leader, said, "The difference between the Giuliani coalition last time and this time is that you had an add-on this year that comes as a reaction to the Dinkins record: Bob Wagner, Ed Koch, Ed Costikyan, and the independent wing of the Democratic Party that they represent."
 
The Can-Do Mantra
 In one sense, voters rejected ideology -- liberal ideology, in this case -- for the can-do mantra that also resonated in the recent victories of two other Republicans -- Richard Riordan in Los Angeles and Edward G. Rendell in Philadelphia -- as well as of two of Mr. Giuliani's predecessors in New York, Mr. Lindsay and Edward I. Koch.
Mr. Giuliani campaigned on a platform of competence for a change, much like La Guardia, Mr. Lindsay and Mr. Koch had in challenging the dominant Democratic machine. Mr. Giuliani won by defeating an incumbent who presided during a recession and who was unable to transform the election from a referendum on his record to a referendum on his rival.
Also, while Mr. Dinkins's race was undoubtedly a factor in driving potential challengers from the primary field, the fact that he is black probably cost him votes, too. And in spite of registration gains, black voters in some districts appeared to have turned out in smaller proportions than in 1989.
In Central Harlem, Mr. Dinkins received 29,464 votes compared to 30,560 four years ago; in Bedford-Stuyvesant, his vote declined to 26,714 from 28,384. Mr. Giuliani's vote grew in Forest Hills, Queens, from 25,519 to 29,288 and in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn from 23,343 to 30,320.
 
'Demography Was Destiny'
 While the outcome was markedly different, the major components of Mr. Dinkins's coalition appear to have become frayed rather than unglued.
"Demography was destiny in a way that it almost was four years ago," Mr. Shrum said, and in a way that, given declining numbers of older whites and growing proportions of younger black and Hispanic New Yorkers, suggest Mr. Giuliani's potential vulnerabilities in 1997.
"The coalition that brought David Dinkins into office remains very much intact," Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's spokesman, said early yesterday, acknowledging, though, that it no longer encompassed enough voters to constitute a majority.
"Hopefully," Mr. Jones said wearily, "four years from tonight it will be enough."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 5, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A news analysis article yesterday about shifts in voting patterns in the New York City mayoral election misstated the party affiliation of Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia. He is a Democrat, not a Republican.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Datapoint Names a Returnee Its President

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Nov. 3

 BODY:
The Datapoint Corporation today named Doris D. Bencsik, a 35-year veteran of the computer industry, its president and chief operating officer.
Mrs. Bencsik, 62, rejoined Datapoint, a computer networking company based in San Antonio, in February as executive vice president and chief operating officer after five years as a consultant. She previously held senior management positions at the company and shared the president's post before leaving in 1987. 
 She has also held management positions at the Data General Corporation, Honeywell Inc. and RCA.
Datapoint's previous president, John Harrison, who largely ran the company from offices in Europe, left in October 1992 to pursue other business interests.
Mrs. Bencsik's appointment caps a year of restructuring in an effort to turn around a string of losses and revenue slides at Datapoint, which was known as a technology innovator in the 1960's and 70's.
 
Getting a 'Second Chance'
 In a telephone interview, she said her first objective was to rebuild Datapoint's presence in the United States market, particularly in the growing area of video conferencing and video networks.
"It isn't often that a company gets a second chance," Mrs. Bencsik said.
Asher B. Edelman, a New York investor, took over Datapoint in 1985 and is the company's chairman and chief executive.
Datapoint lost $11.3 million in the 1993 fiscal year, which ended July 31, after revenues fell sharply, to $208.3 million from $255.2 million a year earlier. Most of the decline resulted from a strong dollar and a weak economy in Europe, where Datapoint has major customers.
Datapoint also took $6.2 million in restructuring charges and has been repositioning itself to sell new products, including desktop video communications systems.
Mrs. Bencsik said that one reason she returned was to be part of the company's growing focus on video.
"I rode the computer market for 35 years and it was a wild ride," she recalled. "Now I get a chance to do it again in video."

HEADLINE: Race, Reform and Urban Voters

BYLINE: By Nicholas Lemann; Nicholas Lemann, a national correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly, is author of "The Promised Land."

 BODY:
With startling rapidity, four of Am erica's five biggest cities have replaced black mayors with whites: first, Chicago, four years ago, then Philadelphia, then Los Angeles and this week New York. It's irresistibly tempting to see a big trend here, and indeed pronouncements of the end of an era are filling the air.
The era that has supposedly ended is that of "old" black politics -- stressing civil rights, welfare and other traditional liberal policies. Now, the argument goes, the cities have deteriorated to the point where voters want pragmatic, effective government and are willing to vote for whoever can provide it -- "new" (meaning centrist) black politicians, or, as in our biggest cities, white politicians. David Dinkins lost because, by presenting himself as a race-relations expert rather than as a tough manager, he epitomized the old black politics. 
 Watch out for this theory. It misstates the true nature of black politics and urban politics. And as a guide to future events, it is about as useful as the prediction, widespread when Mr. Dinkins was elected, that New York would never again have a white mayor.
The boom years for African-American politicians were the early 1970's, when the lowest annual increase in the number of black elected officials was 14 percent. Two large historical forces drove the increases: the legal enfranchisement of black voters in the South, thanks to the Voting Rights Act, and the massive black migration from the countryside to the cities, which produced large concentrations of black voters.
Both of these forces have long since played themselves out. There is no vast untapped pool of African-Americans who can't or don't vote. For the last decade, the annual rate of increase in the number of black elected officials has usually been well below 5 percent.
The overwhelming majority of black politicians represent black-majority districts. Outside of a few all-black small towns, the only place where a majority of elected officials are black is the District of Columbia, which is mostly black. Only four states have an officialdom that is more than 10 percent black: Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi and South Carolina -- all part of the old Southern Black Belt. The Congressional Black Caucus has only two members (out of 40) from white-majority districts.
Obviously, white-majority areas should never be thought of as places that will easily elect black representatives. All four of the big cities that used to have black mayors have white majorities. New York never got much above one-quarter black and Los Angeles topped out at about one-sixth.
What generated the feeling that cities like New York and L.A. would ordinarily have black mayors was an idea that all urban "people of color" would stick together politically and look to African-Americans as their natural leaders. This was the premise behind Jesse Jackson's Rainbow Coalition -- but it hasn't proved true.
In Chicago, the Latino population holds the balance of power because the city is about 40 percent black and 40 percent white. Yet it has thrown in its lot with the white mayor, Richard Daley, rather than his black opponents.
Even in black-majority big cities, it's extremely rare to find a fiery "race man" becoming mayor, because the business establishment usually wields power far beyond the small number of votes it can deliver. Marion Barry of Washington, probably the closest approximation, won only because the endorsement of The Washington Post made him respectable. He became confrontational after he was elected.
All of the former black mayors of the four big cities were the kinds of minority politicians white voters found nonthreatening. Of David Dinkins, Tom Bradley of Los Angeles, Harold Washington of Chicago and Wilson Goode of Philadelphia, only Mr. Washington had any reputation among blacks as a race leader. But before his election, he had spent a long career as a loyal member of the Daley machine, as had his father before him. Mr. Bradley was a veteran of the police force, Mr. Goode was a municipal bureaucrat with a degree from the Wharton School and Mr. Dinkins was an accommodationist who spent years rising through the ranks of the New York Democratic apparatus.
David Dinkins had the added advantage of running in what is arguably the only big, non-black-majority American city with a liberal electorate. The general rule is that the whiter the jurisdiction, the more conservative its black representative will have to be. It's no accident that the only Republican member of the Congressional Black Caucus, Gary Franks of Connecticut, is also the caucus member with the fewest black constituents.
For at least a century, one of the consistent voices in municipal politics has come from the "reform" or "good government" element: people from the middle and upper classes who long for a clean, efficient government that will foster business development. Traditionally, the reformers' opponents were the Democratic machines, which represented blue-collar and poor voters, who were intensely ethnicity-conscious in their politics.
The main policy difference between these two groups was that the "goo-goos" (as the machine derisively called them) saw government purely as a purveyor of services -- police, housing, parks -- while the machines saw government as having two missions: performing services and providing jobs and contracts to people who couldn't find economic opportunity in the private sector. It was in the course of doing the latter that the machines committed sins like graft and featherbedding that horrified reformers.
Reformers have historically realized that most urban voters weren't in their camp, so the only way to get city government to focus solely on providing services efficiently would be to depoliticize it. There have been two main ways of doing this. One is replacing patronage hiring with a civil service system. (Nothing better symbolizes the difference in worldviews between the reformers and the machines than the jailing of Boston's future mayor, James Michael Curley, in 1903, for taking the civil service exam under his constituents' names so they could get city jobs.) The other is chartering city governments in which a hired professional manager runs things and the elected mayor is paid so little that no professional politician would take the job.
To believe that Mayor-elect Rudolph Giuliani and Mayors Richard Riordan of Los Angeles and Edward Rendell of Philadelphia sit at the head of a fundamentally reform-oriented urban electorate requires ignoring all the lessons of city political history.
It is true that many municipal school boards, police forces and housing departments need to be cleaned up. It is also true that politics provides enough of a market test that mayors who don't run their cities well (like Mayors Dinkins and Goode) often get turned out of office.
Still, city voters remain poorer and more ethnically unmelted than the national average and therefore more likely to have the dual-role view of government as a source of jobs and power as well as services. Mayors who only provide efficient services are going to find their constituents curiously dissatisfied. Big cities don't have a voting majority of people who can can afford to look to government to pick up garbage and put out fires but not to give them jobs and a sense of ethnic pride.
One reason Richard Daley of Chicago looks like a mayor-for-life is that, as a child of the machine, he instinctively balances efficient governance with ethnic and patronage concerns. Rudy Giuliani, who has spent his career in moral crusades rather than administration, is not going to keep a majority of New York voters happy for very long if all he does is try to clean up the city. Urban politics is never going to get that new.

HEADLINE: Gore and Perot Are Set to Debate Trade Accord

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 4

 BODY:
The White House dared Ross Perot today to debate Vice President Al Gore on the North American Free Trade Agreement before the House votes on it in two weeks, and Mr. Perot quickly accepted.
The challenge was publicly issued by President Clinton as he campaigned here for the accord, which Mr. Perot has long denounced as an ill-conceived deal that would send American jobs flowing to Mexico. 
 "The Vice President has challenged him to a debate on Larry King," Mr. Clinton told reporters here. "Let's see if he takes it."
Mr. Perot, visiting Washington to stump against the agreement, not only accepted but also quickly proposed three debates, as well as their times and locations: one in Tampa, Fla., on Sunday, a second in Detroit next Wednesday, and a third in Seattle on Nov. 15, two days before the House vote.
In response, a spokesman for Mr. Gore said tonight that his office was still working to arrange the dates and locations.
Mr. Perot said the White House challenge was a "desperate move" made because "they've tried everything to sell the deal, and they can't."
The White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, was asked whether Mr. Clinton's challenge was giving Mr. Perot credibility on the trade issue. "He has credibility," she replied, "and he's playing on people's fears."
The quick exchange of challenge and acceptance came on a day when Mr. Clinton urged laborers here to pressure their lawmakers to back the accord, which over the next 10 years would eliminate all tariffs and other trade barriers between the United States, Mexico and Canada.
Speaking to 900 workers from five Kentucky factories that manufacture high-tech products, Mr. Clinton said fear of losing jobs to Mexico was irrational, unfounded and almost unpatriotic.
"American workers are now the most productive in the world," he said. "You've got to believe in yourselves. We can do this. We can compete. We can win if we have access to the markets. That's what this gives us."
The House vote on the pact is only 13 days away. If the accord is approved then, quick passage is likely in the Senate, where it has more support.
But in the House, most members of the President's own party, heeding concerns of a job drain to Mexico, remain opposed. And with the outcome of the vote still very much uncertain, Mr. Clinton today took his case before an audience gathered in a town-hall format and urged pressure on lawmakers.
 
Friendly Reception for Clinton
 This was hardly a typical audience, however. The location was a Lexmark factory that is dependent on exports of its computers and laser printers to Mexico and Canada, and that dependency was reflected in the polite, friendly questions to the President.
One theme sounded by Mr. Clinton was that in a stagnant economy, the only way American workers can maintain their jobs and increase their wages is by selling more products to more places. That is possible, he said, only with free trade.
Referring to Mr. Perot, who campaigned against the agreement during his run for the Presidency last year, Mr. Clinton urged the assembled workers to ignore "that one fellow who talks about the giant sucking sound" of jobs' moving to Mexico.
In Washington, Mr. Perot, appearing with about a dozen House Republicans, stood before a bank of television cameras and hundreds of tourists in the parking lot on the east side of the Capitol and denounced the accord. He promised that his supporters would stand behind lawmakers who vote against it.
That was not the only rear-guard action in Washington that Mr. Clinton had to fight even as he went on the offensive here in Lexington. Another stemmed from sentiment on Capitol Hill that the defeat of Democratic candidates in leading gubernatorial and mayoral elections on Tuesday should prompt already jittery Democratic lawmakers to vote against the accord so as not to further alienate skeptical voters, to say nothing of organized labor.
"That's ludicrous," Mr. Clinton testily told reporters here. "That's just a Washington story. That's ridiculous. Nafta wasn't an issue in any of those races."
The President also placed new emphasis on an argument that other members of his Administration have frequently made in support of the accord: that what is at stake in the House vote is not only freer trade relations with Mexico and Canada but also America's effort to win trade concessions from Japan and Europe.
He said the still-uncompleted world trade accord -- the new round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -- would bring more investment to the United States from Europe and Japan than would flow into the nation from Canada and Mexico as a result of the North American agreement. And more investment, he said, would mean more jobs for Americans.
The worldwide agreement would lower or eliminate tariffs on a wide range of goods and services. But Mr. Clinton said that in order to conclude it, the United States had to win concessions from Europe and Japan. He argued that Nafta would pressure the Europeans and the Japanese to make those concessions, out of a fear that otherwise they would be shut out of the huge North American market that Nafta would create.
If Congress rejects the North American accord, Mr. Clinton argued, the Europeans and the Japanese will have less pressure to make the concessions, unpopular in their own countries, that are needed to complete the world accord.
The President also said Congressional rejection of the North American agreement would stem a trend toward free-market democracy in the Western Hemisphere.
"There are a lot of people who have criticized the Nafta agreement, coming out of the labor movement particularly, on the grounds that there are violations of human rights in Mexico or the Mexican system is not as democratic as ours is," Mr. Clinton said. "It is different from ours and not as open and democratic as ours. But it is becoming more democratic. Again, I think if we shut them off from us, it is likely to become less democratic."

HEADLINE: A Stronger Yen Is Hurting Sales Of Japan's Cars

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The Big Three may still be complaining in Washington and Tokyo that prices of Japanese cars and trucks are suspiciously low. But Japanese prices have risen faster than those of American auto makers, and in the marketplace the Americans have not hesitated to crow about why. 
"It's the exchange rate, you simpleton," declares a television advertisement promoting relatively cheap Oldsmobiles.
Despite their best efforts, Japanese auto makers' combined share of the American car and truck market is slipping. In fact, over the course of the 1993 model year, which ended in September with 13.6 million vehicles sold, the Japanese companies lost almost a full percentage point of the market -- their biggest loss in a decade -- to 23.7 percent. The Big Three gained a point and a half over all, to 73.4 percent.
HB>A $3,300 Disadvantage
 For the Japanese, the timing of the strong yen could not be worse. It comes as a torpid car market and rising labor costs in Japan are slicing into profits, and the Big Three are selling much-improved cars and trucks. In October, several Japanese auto makers saw sales of their imports plunge even as sales of their North American-built vehicles rose, reflecting in part the burden of the higher yen. Vehicles built in Japan and sold in the United States now cost about $3,300 more than comparably equipped counterparts built by the Big Three, according to a study by Ronald A. Glantz, an auto industry analyst for Dean Witter.
 As a result, the Japanese are rushing to increase production in North America. But that is a long-term solution. In the short term, Japanese auto makers are anxiously turning to several strategies -- from shrinking dealer markups to offering fewer versions of their models -- to hold down prices and remain competitive.
"It's a very serious problem for the Japanese," said Susan Jacobs, president of Jacobs & Associates, a consulting firm in Rutherford, N.J. The Honda Motor Company and others made inroads by selling high-quality vehicles at reasonable prices, she pointed out. "Now they risk a kind of sticker shock when owners come through the door of a dealership," she added.
 All of that adds up to Japan's biggest setback yet in the American market. "There is not a short-term, quick answer to the dollar-yen appreciation," said J. Davis Illingworth, the Toyota Motor Corporation's vice president for American sales, who predicted that the price gap would not close "in the foreseeable future." His hope is that consumers will pay a premium because of Toyota's reputation for high-quality vehicles.
 
 
Sales Pattern Changing
 Many analysts, dealers and car buyers are skeptical, and last month's car sales confirm their doubts. The improved quality of American cars and the widening price difference, combined with a sense that buying American supports the domestic economy, is starting to coax Americans out of Japanese cars and into Detroit's products.
"I loved my Honda," said Cheryl Wiener, a saleswoman in Randolph, Mass., who bought her Honda Accord in 1986, after headaches with a Buick Regal. "I swore I would never drive another American car, they were so awful," she said.
So when it came time to replace her beloved Accord this year, Ms. Wiener started hunting in Japanese showrooms. She drove the new Accord, the Toyota Camry, the Nissan Altima and the Mazda 626. "Nothing really turned me on," she said.
Then she drove a Dodge Intrepid -- and bought it, to her own astonishment. "Never, never in a million years would I have thought it," she said. But, she added, "I felt I was getting a lot more for my money with the Intrepid."
While clearly pleased with their sharpening competitive edge, the Big Three still argue that Japanese auto makers' prices do not reflect their costs. "The prices should reflect the strengthening yen, and in large measure they clearly don't," Alexander J. Trotman, the new chairman, president and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, said in a recent interview. "We're going to put pressure on that issue."
The Japanese companies say their seven American assembly plants have given them a hedge against the rising yen, enabling them to limit price increases. But domestic production alone has not solved the problem.
These are some of the steps taken to control price increases:
*Spreading price increases over the model year.
*Lumping the increases onto less-price-sensitive luxury models, while trying to control the prices on bread-and-butter cars, like the Accord.
*Raising wholesale prices paid by dealers faster than sticker prices, leaving less bargaining room for shoppers.
*Cutting costs by reducing the variations within model lines while increasing the proportion of shared parts.
*Making more options standard, so that consumers feel they are getting something extra.
 
 
 
Limited Price Increases
 The Japanese auto makers say such steps have helped to limit price increases on 1994 models despite a 20 percent rise in the yen against the dollar this year. At the Nissan Motor Company, recommended retail prices have risen 5.2 percent on a sales-weighted basis, compared with the final prices for 1993 model-year vehicles. At Honda, the increase is only 2.7 percent, while at Toyota it is a heftier 6.2 percent.
Those increases compare with a 2.2 percent rise at the Ford Motor Company. The Chrysler Corporation and the General Motors Corporation use a different standard for calculating changes, which is not comparable.
While the Big Three may call the price rises paltry, analysts point out that Japanese auto makers have a habit of raising prices two or more times in a model year. "If your intent is to raise your prices 14, 15 percent, you have to spread it out over the year," said Sean P. McAlinden, a research scientist for the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan. Indeed, since announcing higher prices for its 1994 models, the Mazda Motor Corporation has already raised some of them even more.
 Despite the price increases so far, dealers in Japanese-made automobiles and trucks insist that interest in the new models is strong. "It's a little obstacle, but, hey, they always go up, and they always sell," said Bruce G. Ochs, the new-car sales manager for Fred Haas Toyota in Houston.
Japanese auto makers acknowledge that they can ill afford a bigger disparity between their prices and those of the Big Three. But they insist that they are not dumping their vehicles below the cost of making them.
"The way we were able to hold that increase is that the majority of the cars we sell here now are made here," said Thomas G. Elliott, executive vice president of American Honda Motor Company, which markets and distributes Honda cars in the United States. Not counting its Acura line of luxury cars, 69 percent of the Honda vehicles sold in America this year were made here.
At Honda, the increase varies with the origin of the car. Prices for the Acura line, for example, are rising by 4 to 5 percent because, Mr. Elliott said, "those models basically are built in Japan, and the effect of the yen is much more significant." In fact, the company is considering assembling some Acuras in America to offset the currency fluctuation.
 
 
Accord Holds the Line
 At the other extreme of Honda's price strategy is the brand-new Honda Accord, the base price of which is exactly the same as it was last year: $14,330. Most Accords sold in the United States are assembled at a Honda plant in Ohio. Further, 82 percent of the value of the new cars was contributed by American suppliers and workers, Honda says.
Honda has taken another step to reduce the costs of selling its vehicles here: it has cut its dealers' profit margins by 1 percent, to 15 percent.
Nissan also contends that its large amount of American production shields it from the rising yen. Of Nissan cars sold in this country so far this year, 63.6 percent were built in the United States, compared with 50 percent last year.
Unlike Honda, Nissan spread its increases across its product lines, raising prices on all of its vehicles at similar rates -- including its popular Altima sedan.
The base price of the Altima, which Nissan held steady in the 1993 model year, has climbed $740, from $12,999 to $13,739, an increase of 5.7 percent. Softening the blow, however, the new model features a passenger-side air bag as standard equipment.
 
 
6% Rise for Infiniti
 As with Acura, all of the luxury vehicles sold by Nissan's Infiniti division, are imported. Their price increase for 1994 is 6 percent.
Of the cars and trucks Toyota sells in the United States, more than 50 percent are made in this country. Still, Toyota's prices have jumped considerably. The base price of the Celica coupe, which was redesigned this year, rose 12.7 percent to $16,168, a jump of $1,820. But the base price of the 4-Runner, a sport-utility vehicle that was all new in 1990, rose only 3.4 percent, to $19,998.
Toyota's popular Camry sedan has also taken a big increase. The basic 1994 Camry sells for $16,438 -- $1,130, or 7.4 percent, more than in 1993.
In contrast, the base model of the 1994 Ford Taurus sells for $16,140.
The strong yen is also cutting into Toyota's product mix. The company plans to reduce the number of styling and equipment variations for individual models by 20 percent, while increasing the proportion of major parts shared across product lines to 30 percent.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IS SEEN BETWEEN REGIONS IN HEALTH PLAN

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
While President Clinton's sweeping proposals would extend health care equally to all Americans, consumers and businesses in and around older urban areas like New York City are likely to find themselves paying substantially higher premiums for coverage than their counterparts elsewhere, and in many cases even higher than today.
At its core, the Clinton plan would create a web of regional "health alliances" to pool the purchasing power of consumers and negotiate on their behalf for lower prices for health insurance. The Clinton system would not necessarily produce new costs -- indeed it is intended to operate more efficiently than what Americans have now -- but it will almost certainly reshuffle the deck in who has to pay the costs of medical care.
 
Sharing Cities' Burdens
 The states, not Washington, are to create these new purchasing pools and decide their boundaries. What is critical, though, is that the regional alliances that include big cities with costly health care burdens will be forced to charge their residents more than those that do not. 
 Tens of billions of dollars are at stake within the New York area alone. The outcome, economists and health analysts predict, could be a free-for-all over medical costs, pitting cities against suburbs, rich versus poor, region against region. For various reasons, these conflicts may also be acute in Boston, Chicago, Cleveland, Detroit and Philadelphia.
Indeed, just as citizens and officials within states now fight over the allocation of tax funds to schools, the costs that consumers in different areas will pay for health care are likely to become a major statehouse battleground.
 
Boundaries Are Crucial
 "How you draw the boundaries of these alliances will determine the distribution of risk and, in many respects, the distribution of costs," said Lawrence Brown, a professor of public health at Columbia University. "All sorts of hell would break loose once you throw this political football on the field."
No one knows how expensive health care would be under the new system. According to the White House, the average charge for health insurance under its plan would be about $1,900 a year for an individual and $4,300 for a family. But the White House itself acknowledges those charges would be higher in many urban areas, particularly in the Northeast. And, depending on how the plan is carried out, health care protection may vary in cost by 25 percent or more -- even in areas close to each other.
Administration planners point out that health care costs are already higher in most cities than in surrounding suburbs and rural areas. The Clinton plan would allow states, if they chose to, to redistribute those burdens more equitably, but it would also permit even wider disparities.
"These are decisions we are leaving up to the states," said Richard Kronick, a White House official who helped develop the health plan.
 
Community Rating
Spreading Costs Over Large Groups
 To make the alliances effective, the sweeping health care revision proposed by the White House would introduce, in every region of the nation, the insurance system known as community rating. That system is widely applauded by health experts, whatever their position on other reforms.
For most parts of the country, that would be a dramatic departure. As things stand, insurance companies generally charge each individual or family in a given group the same premium. But because groups can be as small as a single business, it may cost a lot more to insure one group than another. Indeed, in a small group one expensive condition like an AIDS case or a premature birth can sharply push up the charges for everyone.
Mr. Clinton would do away with that worry. A community rating system spreads the premiums equally among group members, but it expands the group to a much larger population. In a bigger, more diverse group, the extra costs of care for some people tend to average out.
 
Even Allocations
 The White House health plan takes community rating into a new dimension. A regional alliance could be as small as a single city and its suburbs or as large as an entire state. Within that boundary, the alliance would be required to allocate evenly -- without regard to age, sex, income or medical risk -- most of the costs of providing health coverage to all its non-elderly legal residents.
Each state would choose among three variations: a "single-payer" system, in which the state itself pays the providers directly; one all-embracing alliance; or several different ones that divide the state into separate regions. (The only exception would be large employers with more than 5,000 employees, and even they would have to follow many of the same rules.)
What you pay would no longer depend so much on what you get. Instead, it would be determined even more by where you live and who you are grouped with. A family in Mineola, L.I., for example, would pay one rate if Nassau County were joined at the hip with New York City and another -- almost certainly lower -- rate if it were not.
 
Expensive Problems in Cities
 Many expensive health problems -- AIDS, drug addiction, poverty -- are concentrated in cities. The Clinton program would shift much of the cost that is now borne by Federal taxpayers across the nation to ratepayers within each alliance.
At present, Medicaid pays medical bills for millions of poor people; in New York the state and city pay half those costs, and the Federal Government the rest. Under the Clinton plan, the poor and disabled would become full-fledged members of the health alliances, and their costs would go into the pool that every member shares. (Washington would sharply cut support for institutions now serving the poor, but most urban hospitals say they have little room to absorb the blow.)
 
Paying for the Poor
 To be sure, well-off people are already helping to pay the expense of treating the poor and the uninsured. Hospitals commonly charge paying customers more to make up for giving some people free treatment or for when the government refuses to pay the full cost of care for the indigent. But at present, that practice varies greatly from hospital to hospital, depending on its generosity in opening its doors to everyone.
Though this handicap would likely affect many urban areas, New York and the surrounding areas of New Jersey and Connecticut could be particularly vulnerable. The region tends to have fewer uninsured workers, primarily because unions have won substantial benefits that most employers have become accustomed to matching. As a result, the area will pick up less money from newcomers joining the system.
It also has more generous public health programs, which the Clinton law would prohibit states from cutting back. Moreover, New York and New Jersey include the most crowded and heavily regulated hospitals in the nation, leaving little room for savings from cutting fat.
 
The New York Example
Shifting the Burden To Specific Areas
 Some of these difficulties have already come to light in the new community rating system that New York State adopted last spring in a sweeping overhaul intended to equalize the costs of health insurance for small businesses and individuals.
Among other things, and as expected, it led to sharp increases in rates for many younger workers and more modest reductions at companies with older employees. White House officials acknowledge that the same thing would tend to happen under Mr. Clinton's plan.
But what was not so clear at the time is that the practice also tends to reallocate the burden of higher health care costs to specific locations.
In recent months, health insurers and managed care operators in both the New York City area and around Albany have been socked with unexpectedly stiff extra bills.
Here's how that reallocation works: The state requires that every insured person in a given pool be charged the same premium. But not every insurance company insures the same people, so a company whose clients are relatively healthy (say, mostly younger people) will make money charging the set premium, while another company with a sicker clientele (say, mostly elderly) will fall into the red. Under the New York system, the state requires the profitable company to pay some or most of its excess profits into a pool that it then uses to cover the other company's losses.
 
Payments Increasing
 When the system was introduced on April 1, those periodic payments were modest. Although still a relatively small share of the total cost of health coverage for New Yorkers, they now are starting to soar and are likely to keep climbing. For some they already equal as much as a fivefold increase from their initial contribution.
"Our charge went from $250,000 to $1.25 million literally overnight," said David S. Reynolds, president of Choice Care, a nonprofit managed care company that serves about 120,000 people on Long Island. "Nobody really knows where all the money went, but that is a burden our businesses and their employees will now have to carry."
The money is being used to help bail out Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, which as the insurer of last resort has a very expensive population and was particularly poorly managed. With New York State now carved into seven separate districts, the areas where Empire is active seem most likely to be affected by the higher fees.
 
'Never the Twain Shall Meet'
 While there are differences, the state's new insurance program provides a preview of the much greater upheaval that can be expected both in metropolitan New York and across the country if the far more ambitious Clinton plan becomes the law. Indeed, New York's experience with setting up its community rating system illustrates the political and economic fault lines that would be exposed in establishing the system of regional alliances.
"If we had our druthers there wouldn't have been any territorial distinctions," said Wayne Cotter, a spokesman for the state insurance department. "But that was politically unacceptable. You've got downstate, upstate, and never the twain shall meet."
Instead, the state followed the lines of the seven districts that the Blues had already established. Long Island, New York City and Rockland and Westchester Counties are in a single regional pool.
 
Drawing Boundaries
Plan Would Create Powerful Alliances
 The Clinton health plan, however, would encourage states to draw the alliance borders along the lines of what the Census Bureau defines as a Consolidated Metropolitan Statistical Area. That area covers almost 18 million people in the New York region.
The New York metropolitan area faces particular problems because the Consolidated Metropolitan Statistical Area actually embraces parts of all three states. The White House plan, however, would forbid alliances to cross state lines, complicating the job of businesses that would have to send insurance payments to a much greater variety of health care providers.
Inevitably, a tension is built-in. States would be allowed to build alliances that cover as much as the entire population, but they might prove particularly unwieldy. As an alternative, they could create smaller alliances, but that would produce wider cost disparities among them. The only firm rule would forbid splitting a Primary Metropolitan Statistical Area. In New York, Long Island, with 2.6 million people, is a primary statistical area separate from the rest of the metropolitan area. So is rural Orange County, with its mere 300,000.
 
Enforcing Controls
 Once under way, neighboring alliances could cooperate with each other; the people who belong to them would not be forbidden to go to doctors and hospitals outside their own region. Nonetheless, the Clinton alliances would still be large, powerful organizations with the authority to set rates for traditional fee-for-service care and, by limiting insurance premiums, enforce broad cost-containment controls over all health care providers within their domain.
"Regional health alliances would introduce another costly whole new layer of bureaucracy and regulation," said Dr. David B. Skinner, president of New York Hospital and generally a proponent of the President's plan. As originally proposed, the alliances would have been even more intrusive. But the Administration scaled back some features in response to criticism, and Congress is likely to trim even more. White House officials, however, say such complexity is unavoidable -- and unlikely to be any worse than the present system's rules and red tape.
"You can't rely on the private market alone." said Mr. Kronick, who helped develop the President's plan.
 
Avoiding Big City Costs
 Within the New York region, the Clinton plan calls for one alliance to collect payments from, at a minimum, the 8.5 million people living in New York City along with Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties. Indeed, the alliance could be considerably bigger, but nearby rural areas and Long Island would undoubtedly fight to establish their own alliances to avoid sharing big city costs.
New Jersey could create an alliance covering 5.7 million people from Bergen, Passaic and Sussex Counties in the north as far southeast as Ocean County along the shore. Or it could choose to divide the same area into four regions.
Connecticut, as far as the Clinton health planners are concerned, splits naturally into three regions, with the 830,000 people living around Bridgeport, Danbury, Norwalk and Stamford likely to make up a single alliance. But it, too, could allow smaller alliances.
 
Enlisting the Governors
 White House officials contend that the system of alliances would improve the delivery of health care and help slash costs, such as heavy overhead, that currently hit small businesses and the self-employed particularly hard. They argue that if health care providers offer standardized benefit packages within a region, confusion about coverage will be eliminated and administrative waste will be dramatically reduced, without a loss of flexibility in different localities.
But perhaps one unstated reason, analysts say, that Mr. Clinton chose a state-run approach is that it helps enlist the support of the nation's governors, who would play a big role in the new system.
In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, state officials are beginning to explore how the system of alliances might work. But they all agree that it is likely to become embroiled quickly in traditional political feuds.
"I think there is a strong argument for having just one statewide alliance," said Dr. Bruce Siegel, New Jersey's Commissioner of Health. "But I imagine you would end up with at least three separate alliances, simply because different parts of the state will insist upon it."

Enrolling all eligible residents and serving as collective purchasing agents for employers and consumers at the local level.
 
Soliciting competitive bids from health plans and operating within an overall budget.
 
Establishing a rate schedule for fee-for-service providers.
 
Enforcing, within state guidelines, quality standards, financial solvency, and fair access to services by health plans. (pg. B8)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
Stock market investors' fears of rising interest rates heightened, forcing a sweeping sell-off. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 36.89 points, to 3,624.98, as anticipation rose that money would flee the stock market for higher-yielding bonds. [Page D1.] 
 The bond market's plunge over the last week has been a little like the fires in California: selling has swept through the market while investors watched, unable to stop it. With prices dropping, the 30-year bond's yield is now up to 6.17 percent. [D1.]
Gold prices jumped amid rumors that the financier George Soros was shifting from bonds to precious metals. [D13.] The dollar rose, gaining support from higher American interest rates. [D13.]
 
The Economy
Retailers reported inconsistent October sales figures, leaving merchants with few hints about how they will fare during the critical holiday season. Some said consumers were confused about the mixed signals given off by the economy. [D1.]
More signs emerged of a continuing if mixed recovery, with worker productivity increasing sharply, factory orders rising in September and new jobless claims falling last week. [D2.]
Farmers are divided on Nafta because the trade agreement will probably raise prices for some crops and hold down prices for others. [A1.] Republican gains in Tuesday's elections may make it harder for President Clinton to push Nafta through Congress. [A6.]
 
Companies
Companies are increasingly requiring employees to fly in economy class and stay in less expensive hotels in a drive to cut costs. Aware of the trend, airlines and hotels are basing plans on the assumption that corporate frugality will continue for years. [D1.]
BellSouth is close to investing at least $2 billion in QVC's bid for Paramount. The deal could substantially alter existing telecommunications and entertainment alliances. [D1.]
Vanguard Cellular will invest up to $197 million in Geotek, a radio dispatch company. The move is part of a trend in which companies with radio licenses to link taxi and truck fleets offer a cheap way to compete in the cellular telephone market. [D4.]
Nynex continued shedding information services assets, selling several units of AGS Computers for undisclosed terms. That sale and earlier ones will mean at least a $250 million charge. [D4.]
A former Coca-Cola marketing executive, Peter Sealey, was named president of Interactive Network. Several such executives are entering the fledgling interactive entertainment field. [D4.]
Primerica's top management will not include any executives of Travelers, which it expects to acquire later this year. [D4.]
Merrill Lynch offered investors in a real estate partnership it sold a settlement that would return to them less than 2 cents on every dollar of their original investment. [D4.]
Boeing is studying a new military jet that could serve more than one of the armed services. But analysts say it will be difficult for such a multipurpose craft to gain acceptance. [D6.]
A judge approved G.M.'s plan to give $1,000 coupons to owners of pickups that Federal officials say may pose a fire hazard. [A20.]
 
International
The rising yen is bad timing for Japanese auto makers, raising prices for their products in the U.S. while their home markets are hurting. With their grip on the American market loosening, the Japanese are turning to several strategies to hold down prices and remain competitive as American companies rebound. [A1.]
Canada's new Prime Minister named a moderate Cabinet likely to support the free trade pact with the U.S. and Mexico. [A9.]

HEADLINE: A Pro-Trade Cabinet Takes Office in Canada

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTTAWA, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Jean Chretien formally took office today as Canada's 20th Prime Minister, and he immediately named a moderate, pragmatic Cabinet that is unlikely to walk away from free trade with the United States and Mexico.
The new Ministers of Finance and International Trade, Paul Martin Jr. and Roy MacLaren, both have backgrounds in international business and reputations as staunch free-traders. 
 "It is a problem-solving Cabinet determined to rebuild the economy and boost Canadian exports, objectives that we wholeheartedly share," said Tim Reid, president of the Canadian Chamber of Commerce.
The choice was seen as highly significant because of the deep rift over trade in Mr. Chretien's Liberal Party, which won in a landslide in elections last week. The Liberals fought -- and lost -- 1988 elections on a platform calling for the scrapping of free trade, and a group within the party still backs that position today.
Mr. Chretien told a news conference late today that the United States and Mexico were "aware of our concerns, aware of what our party program is, and that we do intend to sit down with them, even though time is pressing, to obtain satisfaction."
The words and tone were softer than last week when Mr. Chretien warned that he might not implement the pact unless Canadian terms were met. There were no such warnings today.
Mr. Chretien's language and appointments were taken as an indication that his Government will not seek a reopening of the North American Free Trade Agreement, a demand that could affect the vote on the accord by the United States House of Representatives scheduled for Nov. 17.
Instead, Canadian officials are passing the word that Ottawa will accept the pact as it is if the United States and Mexico commit to negotiate next year on specific improvements.
Mr. Clinton formally sent the final Nafta legislation to Capital Hill on Wednesday, and said that while it still lacked sufficient support to guarantee approval, "rapid progress" was being made in attracting new backers.
The Liberal Party has called for renegotiation of Nafta. Its party platform called for a set of rules covering unfair trade to prevent what Canadians consider to be often arbitrary harassment of their exports by American trade enforcement agencies.
American industries may demand retaliation in the form of high import duties if they can show that imports are unfairly priced.
Yet no international rules exist on what's fair or unfair. Canadians say rules would inhibit capricious American actions. They are jittery about the lack of rules because three-quarters of their exports go to the United States, and this accounts for about a fifth of their gross domestic product.
In the United States Congress, opponents of the accord have used Canadian objections to buttress their case that it is flawed. In turn, this has presented President Clinton with new roadblocks in his efforts to win ratification.
 
Distance From the Debate
 In comments today, Mr. MacLaren, the new Trade Minister, sought to distance Canada from the Congressional debate. "The play in Washington is entirely of regional issues in the U.S., of local interest, and not whether Canada has one attitude or another," he said.
Mr. Chretien is expected to meet Mr. Clinton in Seattle on Nov. 19 to discuss the issues at what would be their first official encounter. They will be attending a conference on Pacific trade.
Mr. Chretien, a 59-year-old political leader from Quebec, also acted today on some of his campaign pledges.
At its first meeting, a few hours after the swearing-in ceremonies, the Cabinet canceled the prior Government's purchase of $3.6 billion of military helicopters and began a program to create 120,000 public sector jobs.
But Mr. Chretien still faces major challenges in his efforts to lead Canada into the 21st century: generating an environment for private sector job creation; cutting mushrooming government deficits and debt and uniting protest-minded Canadians who last week also gave new strength to two regional opposition parties.

HEADLINE: As Rates Rise, Signs of a Shakeout Grow;
Plunge in Bonds Threatens to Halt A Yearlong Rally

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The plunge in the bond market over the last week, which pushed the yield on the 30-year bond up to 6.17 percent yesterday, has been a little like the fires in California. Selling has swept the market like wind-driven flames while traders and investors watched, stunned and unable to stop it.
And the selling could push yields even higher today if the October employment data fan the market's concerns about the recent pickup in economic growth. If that happens, more traders and investors will agree that the yearlong rally in the bond market is over. 
 A lot of buyers could have helped contain the bond market conflagration, as long-term yields leaped to their highest level since the end of August. But they chose not to. Instead, many money managers are sitting on their profits or selling to lock them in for the year. And they are keeping their increasing cash to themselves.
"The end of the year looms and we are trying to maintain the value of our shareholders," said Dennis M. Bushe, a managing director at Prudential Investment Advisers. "Cash positions are beginning to get a little higher and people are not putting it to work."
 
Changes in Approach
 Cash positions are rising at the Dreyfus Corporation also. But Barbara Kenworthy, the portfolio manager of taxable fixed-income funds, is also holding back. "If you put it in the context that it is year-end, and we've had a great year, it is easy to understand" why the company is not buying securities as prices fall, she said.
 This is the opposite of what these and many other money managers did earlier in the year. Then they bought and bought as yields fell, adding to momentum as interest rates on long-term securities fell to their lowest level in 25 years.
For some, like Ms. Kenworthy and Mr. Bushe, the recent selloff has not signaled that the rally is over. They both expect inflation to remain low and the economy to slow again at the beginning of next year, which would provide the environment for long-term interest rates to fall again.
But Ms. Kenworthy did note that "more people are seeming to say that we have seen the low yields in the market."
Yesterday, it seemed as if the ill winds picked up in the bond market as the price of the 30-year bond dropped about a point and a half, with most of the fall coming in the afternoon, as the yield surged to 6.22 percent.
Only a rebound after 4 P.M. enabled the bond to end the day with a decline of just 31/32 , with the yield at 6.17 percent, up from 6.10 Wednesday.
Since the selling was touched off last Friday, the yield on the 30-year bond has jumped almost a quarter of a percentage point from 5.95 percent. The yield on the 10-year note is up more than a quarter of a percentage point to 5.67 percent.
But the yields on shorter-term notes were not battered as much, because traders and speculators bought them as they dumped longer-term securities. This is a trade that is done when investors think interest rates are rising. The dollar losses on short-term securities are much less than on long-term ones for the same change in interest-rate levels.
 
 
Fear of Growth
 The first problem for the traders and investors in the last several weeks has been the fear of rising economic growth. Without looking at longer-term trends, traders and investors often instinctively interpret growth as a threat of rising inflation, which erodes the fixed returns in the bond market.
 That fear has increased with reports showing stronger growth in the third quarter and auto sales data indicating more growth in the fourth quarter.
On top of that has come the usual uneasiness ahead of the Treasury's quarterly auction of 3-year and 10-year notes, which is next Tuesday and Wednesday. Dealers often want to sell off some of their inventory ahead of these auctions in an effort to lower the price of the new securities, giving a better opportunity for profit after the auction.
Another factor for uneasiness is that the three most closely watched economic indicators for October are to be issued today, Tuesday and Wednesday.
The employment report is scheduled to come out this morning, the Producer Price Index on Tuesday and the Consumer Price Index on Wednesday. Inflation reports on the days of the Treasury auctions do not make anyone's job easier.
A selloff like yesterday's just before the release of a key economic report is "a sign of how weak the market really is," said Peter McTeague, a fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston.
Another sign of weakness, according to Mr. McTeague and Ms. Kenworthy, is that the selling may continue even if the Labor Department reports that nonfarm payroll jobs are up 130,000 to 150,000 in October, an increase that is just below the consensus forecast.
One reason is that as soon as the employment data are released, traders and investors will be looking ahead to the inflation data scheduled for next week. Initial estimates are that the Consumer Price Index could rise four-tenths of a percent, which could easily spook a market with its current negative tone, even though many analysts contend that the report will not reflect rising inflation but technical adjustments in the way the report is prepared.
Mr. Bushe of Prudential Investment said that because of the inflation reports and the Treasury auctions "it will be a week or two before we know what the real level is in this market."
"There is a lot of smoke in the market right now," he added. "Getting through this auction back to back with some of these numbers is going to be tough."

HEADLINE: For Cuomo, Elections Seeded Many Clouds and Few Linings

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
For Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the victory of Republican mayoral candidates in New York City and two upstate cities on Tuesday have created new political hurdles that will complicate his efforts to win re-election to a fourth term next year.
Political strategists and some of his supporters say the Governor, who has not announced whether he will run, must address the disaffection of black voters who blame the Democratic Party for Mayor David N. Dinkins's defeat. 
 Also, the ouster of Mr. Dinkins and Gov. Jim Florio in New Jersey sends a heartening message to New York State Republican leaders that a wrathful anti-incumbent sentiment still runs strong among voters.
Some blacks have blamed Mr. Cuomo for some of the Mayor's travails because he ordered a report that was highly critical of Mr. Dinkins's handling of the 1991 Crown Heights disturbances.
 
'A Sense of Bitterness'
 "There is a sense of bitterness that more could have been done by the state party and the Governor," said Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., a Brooklyn Democrat who added that he thought Mr. Cuomo had done all he could for Mr. Dinkins. "He has to shore up his commitment to the African-American community."
As Mayor, Mr. Dinkins could also have used the power of his office to energize voters for Mr. Cuomo next year. Mr. Cuomo will lose that type of local field support not only in New York City, but also in Binghamton and Syracuse, where Republicans won mayoral races on Tuesday.
"The political organizations, the political base of the Democratic Party is significantly eroded," said John E. Sweeney, executive director of the New York State Republican Party.
Tuesdays's results are encouraging to Republicans. For years plagued by the inability to find strong statewide candidates, they can now say that running a little-known candidate with no record to attack -- someone like Christine Todd Whitman in New Jersey -- may be a good strategy instead of a perennial weakness.
Indeed, many Republicans leaders seem to be leaning toward supporting George E. Pataki, a first-term State Senator from Peekskill who is well liked by his colleagues but virtually unknown to voters outside his district.
"The up side of running someone without a record is that you cash in on Cuomo's negative rating," said Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute for Public Opinion. "The downside is that you have trouble finding someone who has a grasp of the issues and is capable of putting together a field operation."
In the most recent Marist Poll, released in May, Mr. Cuomo's approval rating was 40 percent, its lowest since he took office in 1982.
To be sure, Mr. Cuomo's allies say that the Governor's record does not have the type of tantalizingly soft weakness that Mr. Dinkins had with Crown Heights and Mr. Florio had with large tax increases.
 
Dark Time for Budgets
 But Mr. Cuomo has presided over a dark time in the state's economy when its budgets have been tight and many companies have laid off workers. For all his efforts to portray New York's hard times as part of a national recession beyond his control, many voters will not see it that way.
"As long as the economy is weak, people are going to blame the incumbent," said Mitchell Moss, an occasional adviser to Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Cuomo.
Mr. Cuomo's friends and supporters also suggest favorable messages in Tuesday's outcomes. They argue that the victories of Democrats Mark Green and Alan G. Hevesi show that the vote was more anti-Dinkins than anti-Democratic Party. And they say that Democrats will be more inclined than ever to help Mr. Cuomo next year because they will not want to see Republicans controlling both the Governor's office and City Hall.
 
'He Ran as a Liberal'
 Mr. Cuomo himself has said that Mr. Giuliani often tried to distance himself from Republican ideas. "He ran as a Liberal, as well as a Republican," Mr. Cuomo said in a radio interview in Albany Wedneday. "He said party doesn't make a difference. I don't know how you convert that into a victory for Republicanism."
Mr. Cuomo will also benefit among black voters by running on the same ticket with State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, the first black to hold statewide office. Mr. Cuomo was instrumental in persuading the State Assembly to appoint Mr. McCall to replace Edward V. Regan, who resigned last spring.
Next year's race could also be affected by how the Republican Mayor deals with the Democratic Governor. Historically, governors and mayors of different parties have got along better than those on the same side.
But some of Mr. Cuomo's aides say they expect Mr. Giuliani to blame the Governor and the Democratic-led Assembly every time he fails to get what he wants from Albany -- a strategy that is likely to be encouraged by a Republican challenger to Mr. Cuomo. Mr. Cuomo's best response, his reporters say, will be to remind Mr. Giuliani that he once accused Mr. Dinkins of blaming others for the city's problems.
But Mr. Cuomo's help will be essential to many of the changes Mr. Giuliani has promised, and it is possible that the new Mayor -- whose inner circle includes Raymond Harding, a Liberal Party leader who is a strong supporter of Mr. Cuomo -- will studiously avoid attacking the Governor.
Either way, Mr. Cuomo could be placed in a difficult bind if Democrats ask him, in effect, to help the city without appearing to help Mr. Giuliani. "It does become tricky," said Mr. Norman. "We will be there for the Mayor because he's serving our constituents. But when he wants certain new initiatives, we may want to study it."
