HEADLINE: As Liberia's Factions Talk, Strife and Fear Drag On

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia

 BODY:
For the last three months, Liberia's political factions have engaged in something rare for this war-battered country: peaceful negotiations to resolve the bitter differences that have led Liberia from dictatorship to anarchy.
Compromise has been elusive, however, and the three main armed factions remain deadlocked on the issue of forming a national government. As a result, politicians, foreign diplomats and relief workers fear that Liberia may be heading back down the path to full-scale civil war. 
 Complicating that prospect are reports that a fourth major armed faction, the Liberian Peace Council, has emerged and is fighting forces of the rebel leader Charles Taylor in eastern coastal Liberia. A relief group said recently that it had halted the first full shipment to the region in nearly a year because of reports of clashes in Sinoe and Grand Bassa counties.
The group, Catholic Relief Services, said that thousands of people were caught behind territory controlled by Mr. Taylor and that an unknown number faced death from malnutrition.
 
U.N. Could Pull Out
 A cease-fire that took effect on Aug. 1 had brought Liberia a fragile respite from three years of fighting and atrocities. But with no political settlement in sight, the United Nations is warning the factions that it could pull out of the peace mission later this year.
If the United Nations withdraws as a mediator, chances are the West African country will be ungovernable for the foreseeable future.
"I'm optimistic in the long run, but in the short run I'm very concerned about a process in which perhaps some people are not acting in good faith," said the United Nations special envoy to Liberia, Trevor Gordon-Somers.
Founded in the 19th century by freed slaves from the United States, Liberia has known long periods of political and economic stability. That image began fading in the late 1970's, when a Government move to increase rice prices set off violent protests by a nascent political opposition.
In 1980, President William Tolbert was assassinated in a coup led by Samuel K. Doe, then an army sergeant. The country's economy deteriorated as President Doe shuffled and reshuffled his Cabinet and cracked down brutally on his critics.
The civil war began in December 1989, when Libyan-backed followers of Mr. Taylor invaded from the neighboring Ivory Coast. Mr. Doe was toppled and killed the following year. As the guerrilla forces expanded and split into rival factions, the conflict grew into a vast tribal war, uprooting about half of Liberia's 2.5 million people. At least 100,000 people are estimated to have been killed in four years.
Since the United Nations brokered the cease-fire and the opening of political negotiations, the fear that had made life nearly intolerable has begun to subside, at least in the capital.
Monrovia is overflowing with 400,000 to 500,000 people, at least twice the number that lived here before the war. Tens of thousands of squatters live inside charred office buildings and houses long since burned, bombed or pillaged.
 
'At Least We're Alive'
 Yet people now stroll easily amid roadside stalls along Waterside, the city's commercial aorta -- a sight that was unimaginable a year ago when Mr. Taylor's rebels were battling unsuccessfully to capture the city. Food is plentiful, though expensive for most.
"Life is not easy here, but at least we're alive," said Moses Matthews, a 27-year-old carpenter from Buchanan who arrived recently with his wife and four children after spending nearly two years in Taylor territory. "I thank God for small mercies."
The picture is less promising for tens of thousands of people who are still behind rebel lines. Accounts of human rights abuses against unarmed civilians in those regions continue to filter into the capital. In recent days witnesses have reported that fighters of the United Liberation Movement in Liberia, known as Ulimo, had burned dozens of villages in Lofa County.
On the highway to nearby Tubmanburg, gun-wielding teen-agers staff Ulimo checkpoints. Slung with rifles, pistols and knives, they almost invariably demand bribes from travelers along the highway.
"They are mean, mean," an elderly woman said as she arrived in town. She said soldiers along the way had taken most of her belongings and all of her money. "They say they're here to protect us, but they just steal, that's all."
The main factions involved in the sporadic peace talks are the United Liberation Movement in Liberia, or Ulimo; the Armed Forces of Liberia and the National Patriotic Front, led by Mr. Taylor.
All three political factions are ethnically based. The United Liberation Movement and the Armed Forces of Liberia were both formed from remnants of the late President's former army, but Ulimo draws most of its members from the Mandingo ethnic group and the Armed Forces of Liberia mostly from Mr. Doe's tribe, the Krahn. The Taylor force is made up mostly of the Gao and Mano groups.
[After weeks of pressure from the United Nations, representatives of the three main factions arrived Thursday in Cotonou, Benin, to resume talks. "This is your last chance," President Nicephore Soglo of Benin told the officials as he welcomed them at a conference center.]
Diplomats say the only hope of breaking the impasse in the political talks would be a cold calculation by the factions that they must reconcile their differences or risk losing the United Nations as a mediator.
 
Disarming Factions Is Difficult
 "Liberia is more divided along tribal lines than it was even before the war began," said a Western relief worker with nearly a decade of experience here. "They seem utterly unable to let go of their old prejudices, and as long as that's true they'll continue fighting."
Even if the factions break their impasse, diplomats and many Liberians agree that the peace effort is almost certain to get bogged down again as the time arrives for the factions to make good on promises to disarm.
Thousands of West African troops, the bulk of them Nigerian, intervened in Liberia as a buffer force in August 1990 when the conflict threatened to spread across the country's borders. The force's role gradually shifted to combat as West African leaders came to view Mr. Taylor as a main obstacle.
In June, when the West African force appeared on the verge of capturing Mr. Taylor's headquarters in Gbarnga, the rebel leader agreed to a new round of negotiations.
 
Deadlock Undercuts U.N.
 In talks in Geneva in July, the three main warring factions agreed to the cease-fire, a timetable for demobilizing and disarming their troops, and perhaps most important, the creation of a new, transitional government of national reconciliation.
The United Nations Security Council voted in September to send about 300 unarmed monitors to supervise disarmament of the factions in cooperation with the 10,000-member West African force, which has returned to its peacekeeping role. Some of the monitors have already arrived, but diplomats say the deadlock in political talks has put their mission in doubt.
Each of the three factions offers a litany of explanations as to why negotiations have repeatedly faltered.
But the real issue is power. None of the camps are certain that it can win outright if elections are held as planned early next year.
"These are really trivia issues dividing them right now," a relief worker said. "But if they can't solve the small issues, how can they expect to deal with the big ones?"

HEADLINE: Business Travel Takes a Pay Cut

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The luxurious business trip has not yet gone the way of the three-martini lunch, and corporations are not requiring executives to pack a bedroll for out-of-town travel. But so intent are companies on holding down costs that they are increasingly requiring employees to fly in economy class and to stay in hotels to match.
Airlines and hotels are basing their plans on the assumption that corporate frugality will continue for years. 
 "We've had a total cultural change that's moved our business travelers out of luxury accommodations into cheaper but adequate hotel rooms," said Pete Dykus, travel director of the Travelers Corporation, which books rooms for more than 100,000 nights annually. "In the last few years we've accomplished a 50 percent drop in room rates."
 
First Fears Dissipate
 Nor is Travelers alone. Motorola's semiconductor division used to send its travelers to Hilton hotels, but now they stay in Comfort or Rodeway Inns. "At first there's a mind-set that 'Oh, God, I'm going down to a cheaper hotel,' " said Mark Heinrich, a systems analyst for the division in Tempe, Ariz. "But the smaller properties are perfectly satisfactory, and it's really not necessary to have more."
Time was when an economy hotel would have conveyed the image of a pinch-penny company with an inferior product. Today it's considered smart management.
"Trading down," as the movement is called, is part of the corporate belt-tightening of the last few years. Last year alone, more than 25 percent of America's top 100 companies cut travel spending, according to a survey by Corporate Travel magazine.
And to hear companies tell it, they have no intention of returning to higher-priced hotels even after the economy rebounds. "No way!" said Don Lepard of Asea Brown BoveriLtd. in Stamford, Conn., the American subsidiary of the Swiss conglomerate. "The name of the game is to select what meets your requirements. If you're just staying a night, you don't have time to use a pool and room service."
A recent study of 500 travel managers by Yankelovich Partners for Mastercard found that 79 percent of corporations already limit spending on hotels and meals, while 43 percent prohibit first-class air travel. Runzheimer International, a management consulting firm, says that air fares average 46 percent of company travel and entertainment budgets, and that 38 percent of corporations limited first-class air travel last year, compared with 23 percent in 1988. Some substitute video conferences for company meetings.
A few, including Travelers and Target Stores in Minneapolis, the Dayton Hudson discount store subsidiary, are even encouraging Saturday-night stays to qualify for lower air fares, which can more than offset the increased hotel expense. Deloitte & Touche tried that but abandoned it as bad for morale. However, the firm, which holds more than 400 meetings a year, often saves by rescheduling them to hotels' open dates.
"We're looking to do the same thing," said George Odom, department head of travel services at Eli Lilly & Company, "because we want to cut our $30 million annual budget for meetings in half."
With business travel showing no signs of bouncing back, Tim Smith, a spokesman for American Airlines, said the carrier's strategy was aimed at "capturing a bigger share of the business travel that's still out there."
American has not only added flights between business cities and fine-tuned schedules to attract business travelers, it has also expanded the first-class cabin to 22 seats from 12 on each of its Boeing 757's. As one travel manager put it, "Tough times or not, senior management isn't about to take vows of poverty."
Mr. Smith added, "Much of the downsizing has fallen on middle management, many of whom were frequent travelers."
Business travelers currently account for 49 percent of American's passengers, and also account for a growing percentage of travelers on Southwest, the low-fare carrier.
"My directive to all my people is to fly Southwest whenever possible," said Jerry L. Lawson, president of the West Coast division of Circuit City, in Walnut, Calif. "We don't need the frills -- just good service, a good fare and to be there on time." The policy of the Unisys Corporation is for everyone, including senior executives, to fly coach on domestic flights.
For some corporate ax-wielders, lodging costs have become a more inviting target than air fares. Air-fare savings are not always easy for corporations to effect, travel managers say. Much business travel is spur of the moment. And some corporate travelers drive rather than fly.
"Our ratio of hotel expense to air fare expense is 75 percent to 25 percent," said Jack O. Reynaert Jr., travel manager for the Ameritech Corporation, the Chicago-based telecommunications company with 70,000 employees. For the last several years, Ameritech has been shifting employees away from higher-priced hotels to Budgetel, Red Roof, Hampton and similar economy hotels.
"Hotel rooms are kind of the last major bastion of controllable expense," said Mark Wells, a marketing executive with the Promus Companies, which runs Hampton Inns, Homewood and Embassy Suites.
Some travel managers said they had not resorted to economy hotels because, with occupancy rates lagging, they had been able to negotiate good deals with midpriced hotels.
Mr. Lepard of Asea Brown Boveri, who manages a $128 million annual travel budget, said, "I have brought my hotel cost down the last two years, to $23 million," by requiring employees to use economy hotels where possible, "and this year we'll save about $3 million more in hotel charges."
 
Rooms for Business Travelers
 While there is no uniform industry definition of hotel classes, Smith Travel Research, an independent research firm, defines budget hotels as the very cheapest, with an average room rate this year of $35.45; economy hotels, which also lack room service, swimming pools, and even restaurants (although many serve a continental breakfast or are near restaurants) average $45 a night, and midprice hotels, which usually have at least one restaurant, average $56. That compares with average rates of $76 for full-service, upscale hotels and $100 for luxury hotels.
Given the new frugality, Choice Hotels International -- which already reports big increases in business travelers in most of its seven economy brands -- is rushing to create 18,000 rooms especially for business travelers in 700 of its Quality Inns.
Indeed, what has made trading down bearable, as one travel manager said, is that economy hotels are the newest in the industry and most are a vast improvement over what many people call budget hotels.
Many hotels now have such business-related amenities as desks, speaker phones with redialing, accessible wall outlets, incoming and outgoing fax machines, computer hookups and in-room video checkout. Although such features increase room rates, Choice said those amenities in its 18,000 business traveler rooms would add "no more than $3 to the rate," now averaging $55 to $70 for corporations.
Some hotel companies cover themselves by offering a wide range of accommodations. Marriott chains, for example, include six luxury JW Marriott hotels ($195 to $215 at its Century City property in Los Angeles) to the bare-bones Fairfield Inns ($29 to $49 a night). In between are its Courtyards ($39 to $89) and Residence Inns ($75 to $105).
The full-service hotels make a better impression for certain business functions, and unlike economy hotels, they can hold large meetings.
"We still use higher-priced hotels for our big meetings or conventions," said Kathryn Spino, the travel supervisor of Office Depot Inc., the office supply company based in Boca Raton, Fla., with more than 300 stores in North America. "Otherwise we have a national account with La Quinta, or we use Budgetel, Hampton Inns, Comfort Inns or Signature Inns."
John Kaegi, senior vice president of marketing for the 215 La Quinta Inns, said: "Not long ago we had less than 100 corporate contracts. But they have increased dramatically, and now the number of corporate contracts is into the thousands."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Merrill Lynch Offers Settlement to Real Estate Investors

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Investors in a real estate partnership widely sold by Merrill Lynch & Company have been offered a settlement that would return to them less than 2 cents on every dollar of their original investment.
Lawyers familiar with the case warned that many investors could collect substantially more, but only if they decide by Dec. 1 not to participate in the settlement. The settlement offer was sent to investors recently by Beigle & Sandler, a Chicago law firm handling the lawsuit in Federal court in Chicago. 
 Herbert Deutsch, a partner at Deutsch & Lipner, a Garden City, L.I., law firm, noted that investors who accept the settlement offered though the class-action lawsuit "are precluded from any other action in the future." For investors able to show that the limited partnership was an inappropriate investment, he said arbitration could result in awards of 50 or 60 cents on each dollar invested.
"I will recommend that investors opt out of the class-action settlement," said Mitchell L. Perlstein, a partner at Parker, Perlstein & Company, a Boca Raton, Fla., firm specializing in arbitration services for investors. He said the Dec. 1 deadline "is an unusually short period."
The Arvida partnerships, called Arvida/JMB L.P. II, were sold to about 15,000 investors, mostly in 1989 and 1990 when they were attracted by the projected interest rate of 12.5 percent. But except for $20 of distributions made on each of the 234,000 units, each worth $1,000, investors never received interest or principal.
The $6 million settlement proposed on the $234 million of limited partnerships sold to investors will be divided evenly between Merrill Lynch and JMB Realty Corporation of Chicago. Lawyers' fees will absorb more than 25 percent of the $6 million. Fred Yager, a spokesman for Merrill Lynch, said he did not know if disgruntled investors were referred by Merrill to the class-action lawsuit.
Despite the well-known names of Arvida, a real estate developer in Boca Raton, and JMB, the partnership was not soundly organized, according to Mr. Perlstein. He noted that the partnership was too risky for the retired people to whom it was sold as a "low-risk" investment and was organized with an excessive concentration -- 47 percent of its assets -- in a single project in Orange County, Calif., that was bought from an affiliate of JMB.
Mr. Perlstein also noted that sales of the Arvida II partnership were helped by the early payouts of 13 percent on Arvida I. Those payouts were a misleading indication of the partnership's success, however, because they came from capital and borrowed money and were far in excess of the Arvida I partnership's earnings.

HEADLINE: Boeing Studies Production Of a Versatile Jet Fighter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The Boeing Company said today that it was studying production of a new military jet that could serve the Air Force, fly from carriers for the Navy and lift off vertically for the Marines.
If the plane is produced, it will be the first time in almost 60 years that Boeing has built a new military fighter aircraft. 
 The plane would also provide unanticipated competition for the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the Lockheed Corporation, which are expected to pummel each other for a shrinking number of military airplane orders.
The Boeing aircraft would be "what we think is the fighter of the future," said Peri Widener, spokeswoman for Boeing's Defense and Space Group. "It would be very small, very lightweight and very low cost."
 
Working on the Concept
 It has been 59 years since Boeing introduced the P-26 so-called Pea-Shooter fighter for what was then the Army Air Corps. More recently, Boeing has built bombers for the Air Force, most notably the B-52, and has converted many of its commercial planes for military transport use.
Boeing said it had been working on the fighter concept for about two years with help from the Advanced Research Projects Agency, the Pentagon's high-tech shop. The cost and size of the plane, which does not yet have a name, were not estimated. The company did not say where the plane would be built.
The all-purpose fighter would depend heavily on composite materials and modular production techniques. Boeing said the modular production would "allow different versions of the airplane to be built on the same factory production line, minimizing assembly costs" and allowing for a variety of configurations for use by different services.
But a plane for all services may not make sense to the military. The services have not been able to cooperate on a joint plane in the past.
"Multiservice airplanes traditionally don't do well at all," said Bill Dane, senior aerospace analyst at Forecast International, a research firm.
 
Different Construction Needs
 For example, the Navy's heavier planes have reinforced landing gear and special equipment to survive the slamming of aircraft-carrier landings. But Air Force planes, designed to land on regular runways, have less durable landing gear and are lighter.
Boeing said that the concept of modular manufacturing was valid, and that it was based on recent advancements in technology and production techniques.
The Boeing concept is similar to that of the Joint Advanced Strike Technology project detailed by Defense Secretary Les Aspin, which is based on common aircraft components fitted to different airframes.

HEADLINE: Ripples in an Election

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The elections on Tuesday were not about President Clinton, and certainly not about the North American Free Trade Agreement. But some in Washington think the results will make it harder for President Clinton to prevail when the North American Free Trade Agreement comes up for a decisive vote in about two weeks.
"Clearly Nafta has long-term advantages," said Representative Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, one of the small band of Democrats still undecided on the issue. "But I have to balance that against the short-term economic pain I would be asking some of the workers in my district to accept. The election showed how high people's anxieties about jobs are, in addition to higher taxes, at least in my state, so it strengthened my reservations about Nafta." 
 The White House argued that there was no connection at all. The whole proposition, Mr. Clinton said, was "ludicrous." He asserted that the real lesson of the election was that "if people think you're for change, you get elected," and in this case, he said, the trade agreement constitutes change. Some of the fence-sitters agreed, like Representative Nita M. Lowey of Westchester.
 
Lowey Says It's Up to Her
 "It's irrelevant," she said. "It's not up to the President to tell me to take the tough vote and he'll protect me, it's up to me to decide."
Clearly, few if any people who cast ballots in the races for governor in New Jersey or Virginia or for mayor in New York City can have had the agreement on their minds. The voting turned largely on local issues like crime and taxes.
But the results -- the defeat of Democrats in the three most publicized contests, after three other major defeats earlier this year -- may still make it harder for Mr. Clinton to gain a Congressional victory for the trade accord on Nov. 17, because they make him look weak when he needs to look strong.
The White House acknowledges that if the vote were taken now, Mr. Clinton would lose. With 217 votes needed to block the agreement in the House, because there is one vacancy, its opponents already have about 200. If he is to prevail, Mr. Clinton must somehow win the backing of a large majority of the 60 to 65 officially undecided Democrats, many of whom fear reprisal from their constituents if they go along with him.
 
Fears Called Overblown
 Stanley Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's pollster, insisted such fears were overblown. Dispatched to Capitol Hill today, he argued that the President would have been strengthened by victories on Tuesday, had they come, but had not been hurt by the losses.
"The public remains tentative, undecided and genuinely conflicted on this issue," Mr. Greenberg said he told worried House Democrats. "Except for a few districts, this is not an issue that has much recrimination in it."
But his presentation was reportedly greeted with some derision, especially from Democratic opponents of the trade accord like Representatives David E. Bonior of Michigan and David R. Obey of Wisconsin, and nose-counters said he made no converts. One skeptic said the President had not been hurt much, but only because his persuasive powers had been damaged by mishaps to his Presidency long before the votes were counted on Tuesday night.
To persuade legislators in a situation like this, a President can appeal to party loyalty, which is weak in general these days and unusually weak on the accord; he can promise things, such as Federal projects or appointments, or threaten to withhold them, and he can provide protection. Vote with me, he can say, and we will win. If they go after you back home, I'll come into your state and help you recover.
But Mr. Clinton helped Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York and Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, and they lost anyway. He showed no clout.
 
Looking After No. 1
 "What do these returns show me?" a Democrat on Capitol Hill asked, after exacting a promise of anonymity."They show me that I had better look after old No. 1. Maybe by next year, Bill Clinton will be strong enough to help me survive, but he isn't right now, and I can't afford to bet on the come.
"I still haven't decided how to vote on Nafta, but I know my people at home don't like it, and I find Florio's loss particularly threatening."
There is a certain irony in that, of course, because Governor Florio is one of the strongest opponents of the trade agreement in either party. But until he lost, he had seemed to professional politicians to be the pre-eminent symbol of the ability of officeholders to take a highly unpopular economic stance (in his case increasing state taxes) and survive.
Mr. Bonior took a somewhat different tack. One of the lessons of the voting, he said, was that "people don't like their leaders much."
"The Administration is trying to sell Nafta with big names -- former Presidents, secretaries of state, Lee Iacocca, people like that," Mr. Bonior said. "I think the public has pretty well had it with that kind of elitism, and tends to think if guys like that are for it, it must be bad for them."
But he and others conceded that it was impossible to say how large the election returns would loom when the final decisions are made or how many votes would be swayed. Two factors make Mr. Clinton's task more difficult: he cannot afford to lose many more Democratic votes in the House, and at least eight of the swing Democrats come from the three states where the Republicans scored big victories on Tuesday.
 
Presidential Weapons at Hand
 The President still has weapons to use. In addition to cutting deals, he can argue that after the the electoral setbacks they have suffered, the Democrats cannot afford to hand a defeat to their President on his major proposal of this autumn. And he can argue that a defeat would cripple him in his meetings with Chinese and other Asian leaders in Seattle in late November, a few days after the vote.
Peter Hart, another leading Democratic pollster, scoffed at suggestions that the election results had doomed the trade accord. But he said they showed how important jobs are to voters. It is therefore all the more important, he said, for the Administration to make the case that the agreement is a job-builder and not a job-destroyer, not even in the short term, for the vast majority.
That argument has not been driven home yet, Mr. Hart said, and George Stephanopoulos, one of the President's closest advisers, agreed with him.
"What we have to do in the time that's left is convince people that standing pat is the most dangerous course," he said. "Look at Tuesday. The most passive candidate, Mary Sue Terry in Virginia, lost the worst."

HEADLINE: Sales Data Offer Few Clues To Stores' Holiday Prospects

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
There was little consistency in the October sales figures reported yesterday by most of the major retail chains, leaving merchants with few hints about how they will fare during the critical holiday sales season.
For every department store operator that had sluggish sales in October, there was one with healthy gains, a pattern that held true for most other types of retailers. 
 Clothing sales lagged last month after showing some signs of strengthening in September, when crisp fall weather drove shoppers into stores in search of sweaters and coats. But sales of appliances, televisions, electric drills and other hard goods continued to advance in October, providing evidence that consumers are still willing to spend.
"It was a mixed bag," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, a retail analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc.
He said the October sales figures reflected conflicting messages on the economy. "You had the University of Michigan survey of consumer confidence showing an improvement, while the Conference Board survey showed a decline," he said. "Manufacturing trends are positive, but employment trends are soft."
 Retailers are playing it safe, analysts and executives said, by keeping inventories and expenses low as they prepare for the holiday season.
Estimates of increases in holiday sales range from 4 percent to as high as 8.5 percent. No one expects a repeat of last year's holiday splurge, when shoppers drove sales up more than 10 percent.
And that strong showing will make it more difficult for retail businesses to show an increase this year.
"They are all up against formidable figures," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Consulting Group. "The figures so far this year are lackluster and a little ominous in terms of what they may mean for Christmas."
The wildfires in California affected merchants unevenly during the last week of October. J. C. Penney, the Dayton Hudson Corporation and Clothestime Inc., which have a high concentration of stores in California, were among the companies reporting that the fires had inhibited sales. But others with a big California presence, like the May Department Stores Company, were not affected.
There were no clear trends to be drawn from the sales numbers released yesterday. Federated Department Stores Inc., which operates seven department store chains including Bloomingdale's and Burdines, said its same-store sales declined 1.5 percent last month. But May Department Stores, which runs Lord & Taylor, Robinsons-May and other regional department store chains, reported that its same-store sales climbed a healthy 5.8 percent.
Same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, are considered a better measure of a retailer's performance because the figure eliminates irregular sales patterns in new stores.
 
 
Effect of California Fires
 Same-store sales at the Kmart Corporation, which operates several specialty-store chains, edged up a meager 1.4 percent. Dayton Hudson, which operates Target discount stores, Mervyn's and three department store chains, reported a same-store sales decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent, in large part because of its heavy presence in California.
But Wal-Mart Stores Inc., which competes with both Dayton Hudson and Kmart, surprised Wall Street with an 8 percent increase in same-store sales. Analysts had expected an increase of 6 to 6.5 percent.
The only retail companies showing similar sales patterns were those that deal primarily in apparel, and their results were almost uniformly disappointing. The Gap Inc. said its comparable store sales slid 2 percent last month, but the retailer added that promotional activity was much lower than during October 1992 so that profits should be better. Clothestime, the retailer based in Anaheim, Calif., that operates specialty stores catering to young shoppers, said its same-store sales dropped 6 percent.
 
 
Fashion Is a Problem
 Analysts said many shoppers were unenthusiastic about recent fashion trends. "I think fashion is a bigger problem for retailers right now than the economy," said Daniel D. Barry, a retail analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. "The consumer just doesn't like the clothes out there, which is why you see the demand for things like autos, electronics and jewelry."
Another factor that might be eating into some stores' business is the reemergence of Sears, Roebuck & Company, said Edward Johnson, director of the Johnson Redbook Service, which tracks retail sales. Sears posted its 10th consecutive monthly gain in October, with a 12.7 percent rise in comparable store sales.
"Sears is a big animal," Mr. Johnson said. "When they get a 12 percent improvement, that takes big hunks of sales out of the market that used to go other retailers."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
So the stock market didn't crash in October, after all. But what was that noise on Madison Avenue?

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
OCTOBER is often a tumultuous month on Wall Street. This time, it was quiet. But on another street -- Madison Avenue -- it was another story altogether.
There is no advertising equivalent of the Dow Jones industrial average or the Standard & Poor's indexes to measure account volatility. However, by one estimate, marketers last month announced reviews, changed agencies or consolidated assignments on accounts with total annual billings of $1.08 billion to $1.18 billion. 
 If it's not a record, it ought to be.
"That's huge," William T. Lynch, president and chief executive at the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, said when told the figure.
The mercurial nature of the advertising business is nothing new. Indeed, clients have been fickle since the days when they were being wooed by Leo Burnett himself. Longtime executives can still recall the day Ted Bates traded Anacin for Bufferin or the time Chrysler left BBDO and Young & Rubicam for Kenyon & Eckhardt.
But the confluence of abrupt account shifts that culminated in October's wild ride might well be unique.
"It does seem to be more extreme now than before," Tony Miller, chairman and chief executive at Lintas New York, said.
"It may be as simple as a coincidence," he added. "But it may be a function of the fact that business for virtually every major industry is tougher than it has been before."
As a result, he continued, "pressure from the board of directors on down to deliver has never been more intense. So those not able to point to the contributions they're making to client business are under increasing pressure."
Mr. Miller knows that all too well. His agency was perhaps the hardest hit amid October's ferment, losing three major clients: Diet Coke; the IBM PC Company, an account it had shared, and Molson Breweries U.S.A. An advertisement the agency ran on Wednesday in The Miami Herald, seeking to become a contender in another of October's surprises, the Burger King Corporation review, began: "Maybe the only thing tougher than being in a tough business is creating advertising for people who are in a tough business."
Mr. Lynch agreed. "Frankly, it is a very difficult world for a lot of marketers out there," he said, ticking off a litany of problems: "Consumer confidence is low. Spending is slow. Unemployment is high. Layoffs are still a concern."
"And as they start looking at 1994," he continued, "the best they can see is more cautious optimism -- the same cautious optimism with which they approached '93 and '92 and '91. So they start saying, 'Gee, I've got to do something about this.' "
That something usually turns out to be a reassessment of their agency relationships.
"There's an upsurge in what I call client moxie," said Donny Deutsch, executive vice president and creative director at Deutsch/Dworin Inc. in New York. "They need to find new solutions, and agencies are fair game."
That had helped to bring about a significant, systemic "refacing of the agency business," he added, "a reconfiguration of the way clients and agencies work together."
The most notable manifestation of the reshaping of Madison Avenue is the wave of smaller boutique, or spinoff, shops formed by huge agencies in hopes of fostering more creativity and less bureaucracy. One of the biggest beneficiaries of October's tumult, Merkley Newman Harty, which was named to share the IBM PC account, is a creatively focused spinoff of Doremus & Company in New York.
While October's frenetic change was, in all likelihood, too hot not to cool down, November has begun with a bang or two. This week, Hardee's Food Systems Inc. named Deutsch/ Dworin the national advertising agency on its estimated $75 million fast-food chain account and Castrol Inc. dismissed Scali, McCabe, Sloves and moved its motor oil brands, with estimated billings of $20 million to $30 million, to Houston, Effler, Hampel & Stefanides in New York.
"The interesting story is a year from now," Mr. Deutsch said. "What will have happened to all these accounts that changed? Does it change anybody's business?"

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Rumors of Buying by Soros Send Gold Prices Surging

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Gold prices jumped again yesterday, amid rumors that the billionaire financier George Soros was starting to buy gold once more.
In lively trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery jumped $4.40 an ounce, to $372.40. Partly because of a late Wednesday rally, gold prices have shot up $8.80 an ounce in two days. 
 Gold's gains lifted other precious metals, as well as the shares of gold-mining companies. Silver for delivery in December rose 7.5 cents an ounce, to $4.382, and January platinum moved up $1.60, to $375.80 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Analysts said the excitement in gold was ignited by talk that Mr. Soros was changing his investment mix, possibly shifting into gold from the weakening bond market as signs of a strengthening economy fanned concern over renewed inflation.
They said that Mr. Soros, who heads the Quantum Fund, had been heavily invested in bonds and that a jump in long-term bond interest rates might have prompted the switch.
The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond jumped to 6.17 percent in late trading after a weeklong rise from less than 6 percent as investors sold bonds. Last month, the 30-year bond traded at a 25-year low of 5.78 percent.
Typically, investors run to gold for shelter in times of rising inflation or economic uncertainty.
Mr. Soros has been a familiar name in gold. In April, gold was hovering at a 10-year low of $326 an ounce when he swept in and bought 10 percent of the Newmont Mining Corporation, a gold giant, from the investor Sir James Goldsmith.
Amid fears of rising inflation, the move unleashed a wave of speculative buying in the bullion market, which sent gold prices racing to a three-year high of $414 an ounce by early August. But the rally fizzled by summer's end on rumors that Mr. Soros was shifting out of gold and into bonds as inflation worries subsided.
A spokesman for Mr. Soros refused to comment, reiterating the financier's policy of not discussing his investment positions or responding to market rumors.
On other commodity markets, the energy market turned relatively quiet yesterday after a sharp jump on Wednesday. Crude oil for December delivery eased 9 cents, to $17.40 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Rising U.S. Interest Rates Help to Push Dollar Higher

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday, gaining support from higher American interest rates and nervousness about the tumbling Tokyo stock market.
"People seem to be interested in buying dollars due to a backup in U.S. interest rates," Bruce English, head of institutional sales at ABN/AMRO N.V., said. 
 Mr. English pointed out that Treasury bond rates have jumped to 6.17 percent, from 6 percent on Monday, making American fixed-income investments more attractive than ones in Europe or Japan, where rates have been falling.
The Tokyo stock market also lost more than 2 percent of its value yesterday, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues dipping below the psychological support level of 19,000 points for the first time since March 31.
"With the Japanese stock market crashing, people feel bearish on the yen," one dealer said.
 
 
Dollar at 108.23 Yen in New York
 The dollar rose to 108.23 yen in late New York trading, from 107.63 on Wednesday. The dollar also rose to 1.6961 German marks from 1.6943 marks.
Dealers said expectations for a strong American employment report today -- the first official economic report for October -- also helped push the dollar higher.
Unemployment is expected to remain unchanged at 6.7 percent, but payrolls are expected to grow by 146,000, following the addition of 156,000 jobs in September. The figures add to many recent signs that the moderate economic recovery in the United States is picking up steam.
Factory orders rose a better-than-expected seven-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported, also buoying the dollar.
The British pound closed in New York at $1.4801, down from $1.4820 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.5020 Swiss francs, up from 1.5010; 5.9070 French francs, up from 5.9065; 1,642 Italian lire, up from 1,637, and $1.3036 (Canadian), down from $1.3087.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Are Up, And So Is Productivity

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
More signs emerged today of a continuing if mixed recovery, with Government reports that worker productivity increased sharply in the third quarter, factory orders rose in September and new claims for jobless benefits fell last week.
"All of the numbers are looking pretty good and moving in the right direction," said Sung Won Sohn of the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. 
 The Labor Department reported that productivity shot up at a 3.9 percent annual rate for July through September, rebounding from declines in the two preceding quarters.
The Commerce Department said September factory orders increased seven-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $255.2 billion, the third advance in four months.
And in a third report, the Labor Department said the number of new claims for unemployment insurance dropped by 10,000 last week, to 338,000, the lowest level in a month.
A bimonthly business confidence index released today by the United States Chamber of Commerce suggested that the economy had begun to pick up. The index rose to 46.4 in October from 45.6 in August, though it was still well below the 62.4 reached in December and again in February.
Today's reports followed an October survey by the Federal Reserve System, released on Wednesday, that also found a moderately growing economy, paced by motor vehicles and residential construction.
On a negative note, major retailers reported today that consumers were spending cautiously in October, which traditionally has been a good barometer of Christmas sales activity. Discount stores and a revitalized Sears, Roebuck & Company posted the strongest results. But some department stores and specialty apparel retailers reported poor sales.
The new data preceded the Labor Department's employment report for October, to be released Friday. Many analysts expect the department to report that 135,000 jobs were created in October, although the unemployment rate was expected to remain at 6.7 percent for the third month.
The Labor Department said the seasonally adjusted increase in nonfarm productivity, or output per hour worked, followed declines of 1.8 percent in the first quarter and four-tenths of 1 percent in the second.
The declines were the first since productivity fell seven-tenths of 1 percent at an annual rate in January-March, 1991. The third-quarter rebound approached the 4.2 percent gain in October-December last year.
Mr. Sohn noted that the advance resulted in a four-tenths of 1 percent decrease in unit labor costs, the first drop since 1987. Unit labor represents two-thirds of the cost of a product.
The Commerce Department said the rise in factory orders included similar seven-tenths of 1 percent gains in durable and nondurable goods. The durable-goods improvement included most major components.
But transportation orders slipped 1.6 percent as a 33.7 percent plunge in aircraft orders offset a 5.4 percent rise in autos.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods -- a barometer of business plans to expand and modernize -- fell 2.6 percent.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Sidewalks: Clinton and Giuliani

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The Dinkins mayoralty campaign in New York City was rich in celebrities, a whole glitter of them -- singers, actors, big-name politicians, rappers, comedians, and of course the two greatest superstars of all, Bill Clinton and Barbra Streisand.
But the Giuliani campaign struck back with its own Hollywood and Broadway contingent. It was called Ron Silver. 
 About 1 A.M. Wednesday, a half-hour after Rudolph Giuliani's family and close friends had allowed themselves victory hugs, they went down to the ballroom for the big celebration.
Sighting the actor leaving Mr. Giuliani's room, somebody cried joyfully: "That's our celebrity!"
Mr. Silver is one of the very best actors in the country. Still, it must be said that for glitz and money, he is no Barbra Streisand. But if you want to talk politics: People like Ron Silver are the reason Rudolph Giuliani won.
Mr. Silver is a Democrat who this year threw himself behind Mr. Giuliani. He senses in that Republican a bone feeling for what so many New Yorkers want most in their daily lives -- safe schools, safe streets, racial peace, civil liberty defined to include civil respect. He longs to see more of that in Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Giuliani defeated Mr. Dinkins and Ron Silver defeated Barbra Streisand.
So where does that leave Mr. Clinton in New York? Not too bad -- if he pays attention to what the mayoralty election means.
He did leave some New Yorkers in extreme grump by implying that those who voted for Mr. Dinkins once but were not happy about his record as Mayor suddenly could not see anything but his color. Yes, there is racism in New York, and Little Rock, plenty.
But, as I told a brilliant good friend, a new New Yorker who announced his support of Mr. Dinkins -- "O.K., but leave your guilt feelings in your carpetbag when you come north, hear? I've got enough troubles of my own."
But that Clinton gaffe will not remain a big case. New York is in a mood to follow Mr. Dinkins's elegant example and try to drown hard feelings.
The difference between Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Clinton is that politically the Mayor-elect walks on city pavements, and the President seems to float just above them. This is getting to be an urban country, in needs, desires and voting power.
So it is not just the sidewalks of New York that Mr. Clinton does not feel through his shoes, but the streets of other big cities. He says the interested things but sometimes with much generality and little passion.
There's one important exception -- universal health insurance, a real town and country item. Whatever his future accomplishments or failures, Mr. Clinton is doing for the U.S. what F.D.R. did with Social Security and unemployment insurance: persuading Americans to take on a great social problem, going for the goal even though it may take years to work out completely.
But many other things that make a difference in quality of life do not seem to seize his emotions or attention fully: crime, drugs, violence, the mentally ill wandering the streets.
All are part of what Americans know is their most critical problem: creating and protecting public safety in a democratic society.
Mr. Clinton is not a city man. But he has been around the U.S. enough to understand. I think he does not concentrate his intellectual and political power hard enough on sidewalk problems because during the Presidential campaign he overgeneralized his objective -- improving the economy.
The economy cannot be separated politically and socially from the sidewalk illnesses that so frazzle Americans. And these problems cannot be left for solution to some other day, until the big economic picture and all the root causes are solved. Americans need relief from crime, drug addiction, hideous street violence -- not by and by but right away.
Mr. Giuliani knew that. He has walked on pavements all his life. He talked of the economy, budgets, deficit, job loss -- but did not say first those, then public safety. He did not run on a slogan of "it's the economy, stupid" but "it's everything, see?"
We will find out what he can do. But walking intellectually on the sidewalks is something for the President to think about -- then do. I voted for Bush, Clinton, Dinkins and Giuliani and for a change I sure would like to vote for the same person twice in a row.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
If Nafta Loses

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
It is as a symbol that the North American Free Trade Agreement really matters. The economic effects of the agreement on this country would be marginal. But if Congress turns Nafta down, the political consequences would be enormous.
No matter how the opponents tried to disguise it, the world would see defeat as a message that America has gone protectionist. That would encourage the protectionism already rising in France and elsewhere in Europe. 
 The effort to complete the Uruguay Round of GATT negotiations would collapse, I am convinced. Why should the French Government, whose fear of farm voters now blocks agreement, show political courage on trade when the United States has abandoned its most important trade venture in years?
From the collapse of the Uruguay Round there could follow a worldwide retreat from free trade. Political leaders might well continue to profess loyalty to the principle, but they would give way to local pressures for barriers here, there, everywhere.
Would such a surge of protectionism matter? It could -- I think it would -- mean the end of nearly 50 years of rising world prosperity. That's all.
Since World War II the world has experienced extraordinary economic growth. The engine for that growth has been international trade: vastly increased trade in an age of more and more rapid transportation and communication.
Successive rounds of tariff reduction have fueled the rise of international trade. The United States has been the leader in efforts to cut not only tariffs but quotas and other non-tariff barriers. And now the leader would be seen to have turned away: turned inward.
The arguments made against Nafta by such significant opponents as the United Auto Workers seem to me to come down to fear of change and fear of foreigners. Change can indeed be painful, certainly so in our accelerating technological world. But the alternative to change is stagnation.
One great American economic asset, historically, has been mobility. The secret of our prosperity has been the mobility of both capital and labor in a huge market, the readiness to seize new opportunities: to move.
The need for mobility is the greater in an age when new technological products can work economic revolutions -- when computer software becomes a vital industry overnight. Yet the opponents of Nafta want us to put our faith in keeping things as they are, resisting change.
The irony is that the jobs they want to protect, many of them, are low-wage jobs. But the future prosperity of the United States depends on moving people and capital into new enterprises, high-paying ones, not in telling us that we need learn nothing new.
I have heard it said that Bill Clinton acted against his own political interest in pressing for approval of Nafta because he alienated the labor unions that are the core of Democratic Party support. I think that gets the politics exactly backward.
Unions in this country, sad to say, are looking more and more like the British unions that have become such a millstone around the neck of the Labor Party: backward, unenlightened. Bill Clinton cannot build a new Democratic Party on that base. The crude threatening tactics used by unions to make Democratic members of the House vote against Nafta underline the point.
The consequences of Nafta's defeat would be particularly bad in Latin America. It would, as Bernard Aronson, former Assistant Secretary of State, said, "strengthen traditional economic cliques, which have grown rich by manipulating and sometimes corrupting their political systems to shut out competition at the expense of ordinary citizens."
Given the growing economic clout of Asia, a rational United States would be doing all it can to increase trade in its own hemisphere. Mexico is already our third-largest export customer -- despite Mexican barriers to U.S. products that would be removed by Nafta. Defeat of the agreement would be a good way to tell Mexico we do not care about that market.
The opponents are really saying: Stop the world, I want to get off. But we cannot do that. All we can do is impoverish ourselves in the attempt.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Art in Review

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:

Oyvind Fahlstrom
 Sidney Janis Gallery
 110 West 57th Street
 Manhattan
 Through Nov. 13
The work of Oyvind Fahlstrom, a Swedish artist who died of cancer in 1976 at the age of 47, occupies a frequently overlooked niche in the history of Pop Art, one that is illuminated by this small, excellent retrospective. It includes 25 works dating from 1963 to 1975: drawings, paintings on paper and a collage whose magnetized motifs can be moved around, as well as three colorful cutout sculptures, reintroducing an artist who was, in essence, a political miniaturist. 
 Born and reared partly in Brazil, Mr. Fahlstrom completed his childhood in Sweden and moved to New York in 1961. Here he became a friend of Robert Rauschenberg and Claes Oldenburg, and an admirer of R. Crumb and Krazy Kat. As the work on view demonstrates, his admiration for popular culture was equaled by a suspicion of nearly all forms of government.
In the 1960's, he evolved a dense, compartmentalized surface that was part map, part squashed-together cartoon, part written commentary and all art. His mature works, mostly paintings on paper from the early 1970's, teem with tiny caricatures of politicians and current events (the Vietnam War, the coup in Chile) and startling statistics about economics and world history, while glowing with rich color-coded hues (red for communism, blue for capitalism, green for the third world). At once grim and hopeful, these works depict the world as an absurdly evil place without seeming to lose their faith in humanity.
Such balance may stem from the fact that Mr. Fahlstrom leavened his art with large doses of humor and held pleasure (both his own and his viewer's) in high regard. His ability to be politically acute and visually entertaining is a lesson that more contemporary artists should absorb. ROBERTA SMITH

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: U.S. Should Match Europe's Shorter Workweek

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Hasn't the time come to consider an American workweek more commensurate with the workweek of our friends in Europe? The latest international data of the Bureau of Labor Statistics are for 1991. They show that in Germany, Norway, France and Denmark the workweek -- including vacations and holidays -- averaged 30 hours. In Sweden it was 28 1/2 hours! Our American workweek, including vacations and holidays, averaged 37 hours. 
 Certainly, there's a strong prospect that with the surge of technology the most serious adverse effect on unemployment is yet to come.
Current 6.8 percent unemployment idles nearly 10 million American workers. It discourages 1 million more from trying to find a job. It forces 3 million who want and need full-time employment to work part time (usually 15 to 20 hours a week).
Here's why this will become far more serious: The door is now slammed shut on the kind of major increase in overall Federal spending that provided jobs in World War II and later in the cold war. The option of a stimulating multibillion-dollar tax cut as in the 1980's is also gone.
This is because an economy-stimulating fiscal policy runs up against a Federal deficit of $300 billion a year and growing and a national debt of more than $4 trillion, which imposes an insufferable annual interest burden of $220 billion, with more to come.
We are going to have to cut Federal spending and seriously consider raising Federal taxes to avoid national bankruptcy. Sure, there's enough waste in our military spending to make spending reductions, but those cuts will cost millions of jobs.
Unfortunately, the country is not ready for the shorter workweek. In coming years, however, as unemployment zooms, and the deficit and debt inhibit an adequate fiscal response, the country will be ready.
Management opposes such a proposal in the belief it will diminish the profit dividend from productivity and laying off employees. And many workers think the shorter workweek will cut their weekly pay.
I propose a kind of standby shorter workweek to go into effect as unemployment worsens. If and when my proposal goes into effect, both profits and wages will share the benefits of productivity with the additional workers and greater leisure.
The first step would only take effect after a year in which national unemployment exceeds 7 percent. Because unemployment will be less than 7 percent in 1993, there would be no shorter workweek until at least 1995.
My proposal would reduce the workweek from the 40 hours in the wage-hour law (without vacations and holidays) to 39 hours. If after three years, unemployment is still about 7 percent, the workweek (without vacations and holidays) would fall to 38 hours. If, after three more years unemployment exceeds 7 percent, it would fall again by one hour.
With productivity rising at 3 percent a year this reduction of one hour every three years would permit a roughly equal sharing of the benefits of productivity between more leisure, higher pay and increased profits.
The proposal responds to the visible reality of high unemployment, not the predictions of economists, which have proved so fallible.
I propose to make the employment effect of the wage-hour law more effective by requiring double time instead of time and a half for overtime. But I would not change the exemption from the overtime requirements for executives and administrators.
 
WILLIAM PROXMIRE
Washington, Oct. 27, 1993
The writer is former United States Senator from Wisconsin.

HEADLINE: U.S. Should Match Europe's Shorter Workweek;
Illusory Recovery

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report Oct. 25 that President Clinton believes the economy has turned the corner, on the path of a steady recovery. To get a better perspective on this view I urge the President to visit Vermont, where in the last year a Digital plant has closed, St. Johnsbury Trucking has closed, Johnson Controls is planning a shutdown, I.B.M. and G.E. have slashed hundreds of well-paying jobs, and workers from several companies are negotiating give-back contracts. 
 I would hope that a President as intelligent as Mr. Clinton does not repeat the absurd economic dogma of Reaganomics. Job growth is not the equivalent of economic recovery. Mr. Clinton should pay attention to this month's Labor Department report, which indicates that we have lost 260,000 manufacturing jobs since last February.
Today, the percentage of our workforce engaged in the better-paying manufacturing sector is 50 percent of what it was in the 1950's, and the standard of living of working people continues to decline. As recent studies report, the vast majority of new jobs created in the private sector last year were temporary, low-wage jobs. This type of economic trend does not constitute recovery.
I was particularly disturbed to read that the President and his advisers have shelved proposals for a new stimulus program. While he may have shelved the concept, many of us in Congress have not.
Work is going on right now to develop a major jobs bill to put millions of Americans back to work at decent-paying jobs, rebuilding our decaying infrastructure and schools, and building the affordable housing we desperately need.
 
BERNARD SANDERS
Member of Congress, Vermont
Washington, Oct. 27, 1993

HEADLINE: As Rates Rise, Signs of a Shakeout Grow;
Stocks in Selloff For Second Day; Dow Loses 36.89

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
With their anxiety over rising interest rates apparently snowballing, investors hacked away at the stock market for a second day yesterday, forcing one of the most sweeping selloffs of the year.
The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 36.89 points, to 3,624.98, after falling 35.77 points on Wednesday. The steep two-day drop came after the index had hit four record highs since late last month. Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange led advancing issues yesterday by more than 3 to 1. 
 Stocks in small- and medium-sized companies were battered again. The Nasdaq composite index plunged 15.69 points, to 757.26, after losing 12.71 points on Wednesday.
"The one thing that has sustained this market rise for two years now is actual and expected lower interest rates," said Harrison Roth, a first vice president at Cowen & Company. "Anybody who was waiting for a signal that interest rates were not going down has now gotten it."
"The market is ruled by a lot of factors, but the two most primitive ones are greed and fear," he added. "The first had ruled the roost until Wednesday morning, and then fear took over."
 
A Recovery Strengthens
 A jump in bond yields yesterday again seemed to feed the fears that investors would flee the stock market for the higher returns of fixed-rate securities. Long-term interest rates climbed yesterday to their highest level since Aug. 25, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond to 6.17 percent from 6.10 percent.
The yield apparently shot up because of new data that indicated the economic recovery was strengthening. The Government said the productivity of workers had improved, factory orders had increased and the number of unemployment benefit applications had declined.
And today, the Government is scheduled to announce the employment figures for October. Good economic news tends to depress bond prices and increase yields because the bond investors dislike inflation.
The spurt in bond yields also pulled down stocks in industries that are sensitive to rising interest rates, like banks, life insurance companies, stock brokerages, utilities and telecommunications companies. And it helped gold stocks, among the few bright spots in the market.
The Dow Jones utilities average plummeted 5.28 points, to 226.40, its lowest level in 10 months. The average fell 6.19 points on Wednesday.
Despite the steep and broad decline in the market, Alfred E. Goldman, the director of market analysis at A. G. Edward & Sons in St. Louis, said he was not worried. He said the market had surged forward for so long that the oft-cited correction was overdue and healthy.
"Everybody lost sleep Wednesday night, came in feeling grumpy and conjured up fears that in my opinion are not rational," Mr. Goldman said.
"I look at this as a normal timeout, not a top-out," he added. "People are forgetting that we had three up weeks in September and four up weeks in October. So we've had seven weeks on the upside. The market has just got itself a little bit overbought and a little bit overenthused."
 
Big Board Volume Drops
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was 323.4 million shares, down from 342.1 million shares on Wednesday, when computer-program trading was heavy. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped 5.53 points, to 457.49. The American Stock Exchange composite index fell 4.17 points.
Among the telecommunications companies, Nynex fell 1 3/8, to 41; BellSouth dropped 7/8, to 60 1/2; Ameritech declined 7/8, to 83 3/8, and GTE was off 5/8, to 38 1/4. In the banking industry, First Interstate declined 2 1/8, to 54 1/8; Wells Fargo dropped 2 1/2, to 105 7/8; Bankers Trust was off 2 3/8, to 74 3/4, and Chemical fell 1 5/8, to 37 7/8.
The selloff on the Nasdaq carved into the technology stocks, which had led many recent rallies. Intel, the most active stock on the Nasdaq, fell 1 7/8, to 59; Cisco dropped 1 1/4, to 49 3/4; Oracle Systems declined 3 3/8, to 55 5/8, and DSC Communications plunged 3 7/8, to 58 3/4.

In New Jersey, the unemployment rate fell to 6.5 percent, from 8.7 percent the month before, according to figures released by the Government. Page 41.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Thousands of formerly discouraged job seekers returned to the employment market last month amid expectations of a recovering economy. Although payrolls expanded by 177,000 jobs, the big jump in the labor force pushed the unemployment rate up a tenth of a point, to 6.8 percent. [Page 41.]
New York State's unemployment rate rose to 7.9 percent from 7.1 percent, pushed higher by New York City, where joblessness rose to 10.8 percent from 8.7 percent. In New Jersey, the rate improved sharply, to 6.5 percent from 7.7 percent. [41.] 
 The White House strategy in challenging Ross Perot to a debate on Nafta is based on a calculation that the measure is in trouble in Congress and can be rescued if the opposition can be identified with Mr. Perot, Presidential advisers say. [1.]
 
Companies
QVC's board met to confirm terms of a $2 billion investment by BellSouth. There were also indications that Liberty Media, QVC's programming company, might retain an investment in QVC rather than sell its entire stake to BellSouth. [41.]
The struggle for Paramount Communications is pitting Hollywood deal makers against one another and putting their many relationships to the test. [41.]
Republic New York made a hostile merger offer for Green Point Savings, a mutual bank planning to convert to stock ownership. Republic's move seeks to block the conversion. [41.]
United Airlines offered its machinists an option to preserve more than 5,000 jobs in exchange for cost cuts. The offer could revive union efforts to buy a majority stake in United. [43.]
Litton Industries is leaving its palatial Beverly Hills headquarters for a no-frills office that more fits austere times. [43.]
I.B.M.'s senior vice president for strategy, M. Bernard Puckett, is leaving after holding the post just four months. [43.]
Nielsen Marketing Research's recently hired chief executive returned to his former employer, Information Resources. [43.]
Drug-dealing investigations at G.M. factories are being widened after 23 workers were arrested at two plants. [8.]
 
 International
European stock markets plummeted in what analysts said was a correction from record levels. Higher U.S. interest rates caused by a recovering economy also drew money out of equities. [41.]
France's Foreign Minister expressed pessimism over world trade talks, citing disagreements with the U.S. [5.]
 
 Markets
Stocks mounted a mild recovery after two sessions of steep declines. Investors appeared to shake off misgivings about rising interest rates, and the Dow gained 18.45 points, to 3,643.43. [42.]
Treasury bond prices sank for a sixth trading day, extending a three-week selloff fed by fears of inflation. [50.]
Gold prices soared to three-month highs amid further rising interest rates. [52.] The dollar was mixed. [52.]
 
Your Money
Picking a health care plan is more complicated than finding the one with the lowest monthly payment. Considerations include a family's particular needs, how an H.M.O. compensates its doctors and whether it covers aggressive new treatments. [39.]
Investors should be wary of sales pitches by brokers. Even big securities firms are capable of engaging in long-term fraud that could result in losses for unsuspecting customers. [39.]
Homeowners waiting for the absolutely lowest rates may be waiting in vain. Mortgage rates appear poised to continue moving higher, and today's levels may soon seem like a bargain. [40.]

HEADLINE: Dow Up 18.45 as Market Shakes Fears on Rates

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
After two sessions of steep declines, the stock market mounted a mild recovery yesterday, as investors appeared to shake off some of their misgivings about rising interest rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average nearly fell through the psychological barrier of 3,600 an hour after the opening bell, but an afternoon rally in tobacco and bank stocks pushed it to a close of 3,643.43, up 18.45 points. 
 Despite that gain, the market showed little breadth: declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advancing issues by about 3 to 2.
Yesterday's trading capped a rocky week. The Dow hit record highs on Monday and Tuesday, briefly crossing 3,700. But then it plunged on Wednesday and Thursday, losing 72.66 points amid investors' fears that rising interest rates on long-term Treasury securities would hurt the stock market.
For the week, the Dow dropped 37.16 points.
The selloff was so intense that the New York Stock Exchange said 1.55 billion shares were traded this week, the second-highest weekly total in history, after the volume during the week of the stock market crash in October 1987. The American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq said they did not set weekly volume records.
 
Foreign Stocks Plummet
 The increases in most of the major market indicators yesterday came even though major foreign stock markets plummeted and bond yields rose because of encouraging jobs data. Investors may have felt that the American markets were ending a temporary dip in a climate that remained bullish, analysts said.
"Considering that the world markets took a hammering and considering the bond market, the stock market gave a good show of itself," said Lawrence R. Rice, an analyst at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. "People are going home feeling a little bit better because the market had every excuse to take it on the chin again and didn't."
Volume on the Big Board was 336.9 million shares, up from 323.4 million shares on Thursday. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 2.08 points, to 459.57. The American Stock Exchange composite index fell 2.20 points, to 475.33. The Nasdaq composite index rose 5.73 points, to 762.99, after dropping 28.40 points on Wednesday and Thursday.
The Dow Jones utilities average, which many analysts consider a key market indicator because its components are sensitive to interest rates, edged up 0.86 point, to 227.26. The utilities average had fallen on Thursday to its lowest mark in 10 months, spreading anxiety among many investors.
The afternoon rally was led by tobacco stocks, which rose amid speculation that the major tobacco companies were ending their price war. Philip Morris jumped 2 7/8, to 55 1/2; American Brands shot up 2 1/8, to 34 3/4; UST increased 7/8, to 26 1/8, and RJR Nabisco was up 5/8, to 6 1/2, in very heavy trading.
 
Bank Stocks Recover
 Bank stocks, which had suffered because of fears of higher interest rates, also recovered. Citicorp was up 1 5/8, to 36 3/8; Chase Manhattan jumped 1, to 32 3/8; J. P. Morgan rose 1 1/8, to 69 7/8; Chemical increased 1, to 38 7/8, and Bankers Trust shot up 1 1/8, to 75 7/8.
Larry M. Wachtel, an analyst at Prudential Securities, said the recent trading might have steadied the market after weeks of hefty increases. He noted that the frenzied buying of stocks like Newbridge Networks and Cisco Systems, two high-technology issues that had propelled the Nasdaq, might have overheated the markets.
"For about a month or two, the Nasdaq volume exceeded the Big Board volume and the initial public offering market was going nuts," he said. "When you have the secondary market volume exceed the Big Board volume, it means that people are more speculative. It's froth, it's excess. When it's happening, everybody is enjoying it, but from time to time you need a reality check."
Mr. Wachtel added that he was not optimistic about the pace of the economic recovery, noting that the new Government data that spooked the bond market this week were not conclusive.
"I question whether the increase in interest rates is going to continue," he said. "And if we could get stability in the rates, then we might get a sense of bottoming in the stock market. As far as I'm concerned, we had a three-day vicious bear market, and given that shakeout, the market is a little bit better for it."

HEADLINE: European Stocks Plummet After Long Climb

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 5

 BODY:
European stock markets plummeted today after a yearlong climb that has taken many exchanges to record levels.
British shares fell more than 2 percent, the French bourse 2.57 percent and the German stock exchange 2.43 percent as shifting outlooks for the United States and European economies prompted many investors to take profits. The falls capped a week-long retreat, with the London exchange down 2.7 percent, Frankfurt 2.7 percent and Paris 5 percent. 
 In the United States, stocks ended a confused week by bouncing back a bit after two days of sharp declines that followed two days of record closes. The Dow Jones industrial average almost fell through the psychological barrier of 3,600 an hour after today's opening bell before an afternoon rally in tobacco and bank stocks pushed it to a close of 3,643.43, up 18.45 points. For the week, the Dow was down 37.16 points. [Page 42.]
Analysts said that some correction in European markets was overdue. Over the year, in local-currency terms, the London stock exchange has risen about 40 percent, the Italian 66 percent, the French 31 percent and the German 35 percent.
These gains have come despite a severe European recession. The rises have been fed mainly by gradually falling interest rates and the expectation of further cuts, which have prompted investors to bet on a European economic recovery in 1994 and to seek higher returns through the stock market.
"The markets were certainly vulnerable to an adjustment," said J. Paul Horne, the chief European economist at Smith Barney. "Nervousness was compounded this week by fears that the European recovery next year will be weak, that world trade talks could collapse and that further interest rate cuts from the German Bundesbank may not come for a while."
The changing outlook for the American economy has also caused unease in Europe. Although reports this week have been positive, they have upset many investors' predictions.
Already, signs that a recovery in America is picking up steam have caused concern that inflation may rise in the United States. This in turn has led to a sharp turnaround in the American bond market, where yields have risen in the last week or so.
Declines in bond yields and low American interest rates over the year have fed the stock rally in America by encouraging many American investors to switch to Wall Street in search of higher returns. Europeans now fear this trend may be exhausted. Any fall in the American stock market, or uncertainty over its direction, is quickly reflected in Europe.
Although the plunge today in Europe was marked, most analysts said there was little likelihood of a huge selloff. The continuing recession has kept pressure on various central banks, particularly the German bank, to lower interest rates and that in turn should help stock markets.
Reports are beginning to emerge from both France and Germany suggesting that the recession may have hit bottom. These could have a positive effect on markets, which have effectively been betting for some time on a recovery that has been repeatedly postponed.
But analysts said the most decisive short-term influence on European stocks would probably come from the United States bond market, whose abrupt turnabout fed today's selloff. "The U.S. Treasury bond market is the absolute key in the short term," Robin Aspinall, an economist at the investment firm Panmure Gordon told Reuters.
Beyond that, the outcome of long-stalled world trade talks, for which a Dec. 15 deadline has been set, will have a significant influence on the European investment climate, analysts said.
