HEADLINE: Job Seekers Outpace Hiring Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Expectations of a recovering economy sent thousands of formerly discouraged job seekers back into the market last month, pushing the unemployment rate higher despite further expansion in the number of jobs.
Payrolls expanded by 177,000 jobs and factory employment ended a seven-month slide, the Labor Department reported today, but the unemployment rate edged up a tenth of a point, to 6.8 percent, because people entered the labor market at a faster rate than jobs were created. 
 The notion that more workers were coming to believe that the economy's slow recovery was real sent jitters through the bond market, where traders expect inflation and higher interest rates to accompany economic growth. Treasury bond prices fell today as investors sold securities and interest rates rose. [Page 50.]
 
 
Overtime and Temporary Help
 Although the rise in payroll jobs last month was the largest in three months, there were two clear indications that employers remained cautious about adding to their payrolls. And economists predicted that hiring would continue to be restrained.
One sign was that nearly 40 percent of payroll expansion last month was at temporary-help agencies, a group that has been posting big gains for nearly two years. Another was that the length of the factory workweek and the amount of factory overtime set or matched postwar records.
With companies having shed thousands of workers during the recession, they remain reluctant to add employees as the economy expands, hoping to increase profits as sales rise by keeping costs low. While orders are picking up, the extra work is being handled by existing workers on overtime or by temporary help.
Only in the South was there much change in the regional labor markets -- the Southern jobless rate rose to 6.5 percent from 6 percent.
New Jersey showed a drop of 1.2 points. But in New York State, the unemployment rate climbed eight-tenths of a point, to 7.9 percent. In contrast to New Jersey, where the labor force was essentially unchanged, New York's grew by 140,000, twice the number of new jobs.
Of the new jobs last month, only 12,000 were at factories. But that ended a streak of monthly declines that has cut employment in manufacturing by more than 250,000 since February. Much of the net improvement was in motor vehicle production and in construction. About 30,000 jobs were added in construction, the most since May.
 And there were sizable gains of 20,000 in finance, insurance and real estate and 29,000 in health services, the Labor Department's survey of payrolls found.
Largely offsetting these gains, however, were declines in military aircraft and instruments and in various industries producing nondurables, particularly apparel.
Traditionally, ever-rising amounts of overtime have been considered good omens for the labor market, and President Clinton's chief economic adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, expressed this hope again today.
"As the recovery continues to pick up pace a bit," she said in an interview, "one would anticipate that employers in manufacturing will go from increasing hours to increasing jobs."
But the length of the factory workweek has been flirting with record levels all year, and many economists remain doubtful that a burst of fresh hiring is imminent. They cite, among other things, fierce competition that continues to spur corporate cost-cutting and risks from various Government policy actions, particularly the overhaul of the health care system.
"We're substituting capital for labor here," said Lincoln F. Anderson, a former Washington economist who is now with Fidelity Management and Research, the Boston-based mutual fund giant.
"The real strength in the economy has been centered in capital-goods spending," with businesses investing in new equipment rather than expanding their payrolls.
Today's labor-market report showed the work force expanding by a huge 739,000 last month. The rise is only slightly less if no adjustment is made for recurring seasonal variation.
Nearly two-thirds of the extra workers found jobs, but about a third did not, and as a result the ranks of the jobless swelled by 269,000, the biggest increase in 16 months. The one-tenth of a point rise in the unemployment rate, however, is considered by the department to be statistically insignificant.
Katharine G. Abraham, the newly installed Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress that the increase in the labor force could not be fully explained. While some people "may have perceived a recent improvement in job opportunities," she said, others may have entered the work force for other reasons, and fewer people than usual may have decided to leave the labor force.
The jobless rate among teen-agers and Hispanic workers climbed by 2 percent and 1.8 percent, respectively, while the rate for blacks eased nine-tenths of a percent, the department's survey of households also showed.
 
 
 
Longer Workweeks
 The number of part-time workers who said they would have preferred to work full time dropped by 323,000 last month, to 6.2 million. This meant that the so-called partly unemployed receded to about the March level after fluctuating around 6.5 million for most of the intervening period.
The average private-sector and factory workweeks edged up six minutes, the survey of payrolls showed. Factory overtime increased by 12 minutes to the highest level since those records began to be kept, in 1956.
A related positive figure in today's report was a rise to 124.7 from 123.8 in the index of aggregate weekly production hours, widely watched as an indicator of industrial output to be reported at midmonth.
Officials reported that preliminary tabulations for the annual benchmark revision will show employment rose 250,000 for the first quarter of 1993, up two-tenths of a percent and within what it called normal tolerances.
For the current quarter, the department said it was assuming 96,000 jobs in new companies not captured by the survey, up from 74,000 in the July-September period.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Rises to 7.9% In New York

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
New York State's unemployment rate rose to 7.9 percent in October from 7.1 percent in September, with the anemic New York City economy dragging down the rest of the state, the Government said yesterday.
In New Jersey, the unemployment rate fell sharply, to 6.5 percent from 7.7 percent. Connecticut is not among the states for which the Government provides monthly figures. 
 In New York City, unemployment rose sharply, to 10.8 percent in October from 8.7 percent in September. Unemployment in the city had not exceeded 10 percent since February.
 The rates, released by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, suggested scattered signs of economic expansion for a region that was among the first in the nation to sink into recession and is now experiencing a more sluggish recovery than most others.
Across the region, the report said, the number of people in the civilian labor force -- those either working or looking for work -- increased in October. In New York City and New York State, part of the increase in the unemployment rate was attributed to large numbers of people who have begun seeking jobs again after having stopped looking for work earlier in the year. The number of these people was greater than the number of new jobs created in the month, pushing the jobless rate higher.
"It is very difficult to conceive of a scenario that gives you a healthy regional economy without New York City," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the New York regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "The city is now the main issue," he said, and a "major drag."
 
 
New Jersey Looks Brighter
 The clearest improvement was in New Jersey, where the number of people working rose 1.5 percent in October, to 3.7 million, while the number of unemployed fell sharply, to 256,000, from 303,000 in September.
Even for New Jersey, however, the improved unemployment rate in October provides no assurance that the recovery will move more swiftly.
One reason is that the jobs improvement followed a series of sharp swings in recent months, and New Jersey's rate of 6.5 percent in October did not represent a drastic change from June and July, when the rate stood at 6.9 percent.
Another reason to temper economic optimism for the state, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, is its close ties to New York City, to which 250,000 people from New Jersey commute to work each day. For New Jersey, "the October numbers tell we are in a clearing, but not that we are heading out of the woods," he said.
The regional spillover of New York City's problems were even clearer in the rest of New York State. Despite pockets of economic distress north of the city, particularly layoffs by the International Business Machines Corporation, Mr. Ehrenhalt said the unemployment rate for the state would have been far lower -- about 6 percent instead of 7.9 percent -- if New York City had not been included.
Despite its prolonged sluggishness, the New York regional economy was not the worst in the nation, the Government said in a report covering 11 leading industrial states.
In California, which has led all of the states in unemployment for most of the year, the rate rose to 9.8 percent in October from 9.4 percent in September. In Illinois, the October rate was 7.8 percent, and in Texas it was 7.5 percent.
The Government said that the unemployment data reflected leaner employment rolls at companies that have cut thousands of workers and have not hired many back now that economic activity is picking up. It said one measure of the trend came in data that showed that the average workweek for factory workers across the nation was 41.6 hours, matching a post-World War II record.The lengthening workweek means that companies have decided to pay their current employees overtime instead of hiring workers.
Mr. Ehrenhalt said the average factory workweek in New Jersey was 41.4 hours in October, slightly less than the national average. In New York State, it was 39.9 hours.

HEADLINE: The Quality of Older Life;
Study Finds Stable Neighborhoods and Local Services Crucial for Aging New Yorkers

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Among the rapidly growing population of older people who call New York City home, what home often means is the neighborhood within 10 blocks of where they live.
Even those who drive, take subways or occasionally travel outside the city tend to focus on their immediate community for most daily activities, like marketing, banking, visiting and worshiping. Many have spent at least 25 years in the same neighborhood, frequently in the same apartment. 
 Just how essential a stable neighborhood is to aging New Yorkers is a central theme that emerges from a new survey, "Growing Older in New York City in the 1990's," which examines the experiences and concerns of 1,570 older residents of New York City.
Dr. Fernando Torres-Gil, United States Assistant Secretary for Aging in Washington, said the study made clear the need for urban planners to look at older residents as taxpayers and as a valuable stabilizing force in arresting the decline of cities.
"After the Los Angeles riots, the single group that fought hardest to restore peace and rally neighbors to get the kids off the streets was the seniors," he said. "It's unfortunate economic developers are ignoring their role in rebuilding cities and renewing neighborhoods."
One service that the study determined that many people could not find close to home was health care -- a finding of particular interest when the Clinton Administration is promoting a health plan emphasizing community-based services, according to Dr. Rose Dobrof, a vice president of Hunter College who helped coordinate the survey.
The study was based on face-to-face interviews in 1990 and 1991 by Louis Harris & Associates. Analysts from Fordham and Columbia Universities used information gathered from the study to offer a portrait of the city's older population: at least 1.3 million people who are over 60, and of these, 953,000 over 65.
The study provided intriguing insights into the backgrounds of older New Yorkers (of those born in the United States, 88 percent of the whites were born in the Northeast and 60 percent of the blacks were born in the South) and into their lives today (only 39 percent said they had a friend or confidant who was not a relative).
Several study participants agreed to interviews after it was released. Seymour Glickman was one of them.
At 73, and married 45 years, he is spending his retirement years in Brooklyn, where he has lived for 45 years.
In good weather, he fishes from the Canarsie pier or "bums the island" in his sports car searching for the ideal eating place. The library is nearby, coffee at his favorite diner is his club. He chooses to stay in New York,
And he has chosen to stay, even as family and friends have moved away, despite some reservations about the city he loves.
 
'A Special Breed'>
 "I used to think New York was the cat's meow -- that's an expression we used when I was young -- but my enthusiasm has eroded some because of the crime in the streets," he said. "Still, New York is very special and New Yorkers are a special breed. They have attitude."
The study found fear of violence increased as people got older and frailer, leading most to stay at home after dark. But less than 4 percent of those in vigorous health said they feared going out alone in daytime.
Marion Britt, who will turn 80 this month was, for much of her life, a hotel housekeeper at the Allerton House for Women, working the night shift and returning home at 2 A.M. without worrying about her safety.
"That was then," she said. "Now the city is different, but I still go where I want -- but not at 2'o clock in the morning."
Mrs. Britt, who has been widowed for 13 years, prides herself on being independent. Hospitalized a year ago after a stroke, she recalled, "I couldn't wait to get away from people doing for me and get home."
She lives in an apartment in East Harlem with the family of one of her six children.
"They live with me; I don't live with them," she says emphatically.
The study also analyzed the income of older residents, exploring how many managed to survive financially. Most said they depended on their monthly Social Security checks. Half of those surveyed reported having difficulties managing on their income, and one in four live in poverty. About a third reported annual incomes of less than $10,000, 29 percent reported incomes of between $10,000 and $25,000, 14 percent between $25,000 and $50,000 and 4 percent above $50,000.
 
Life for Elderly Minorities
 The study did note marked improvement in the last two decades in the financial status of black New Yorkers because of pensions from civil service or unionized jobs -- but the survey also warned that changes in the employment picture could eliminate such pensions for future generations.
Growing numbers of elderly among minority groups present special challenges for the city in the future.
The number of older Hispanic New Yorkers living in poverty was twice the national average. The survey concluded that many aged Hispanic residents are not availing themselves of services to which they are entitled, both financial and medical, probably because of language barriers.
People over 60 already amount to a third of the population of minority groups, said Prema Mathai-Davis, Commissioner of the Department for the Aging. By the end of the decade, it is expected that this over-60 group will swell to almost two-thirds of the population.
Both the stability and the stresses of life in New York are illustrated in the lives of William Adams and his wife, Dorothy -- both 73 and married 53 years -- who are living in retirement in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, where they put down roots 30 years ago.
"This street -- Barnes Avenue -- was an unpaved road when we first moved here," Mr. Adams said. "There were farmlands near us."
But even as he and his wife lamented the fact that drugs are sold openly in what was once a safe haven, they made it clear that they plan to stay.
"When we visit friends, they say to us: 'We read terrible things about New York City. How can you stand it?"' he said. "We resist change. After three days watching the grass grow, we're glad to come home."
 
Many Widows>
 A substantial group of the city's older residents are women and widowed.
Maria Williams lives alone in the same sunlit apartment in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst section where she lived for 40 years and raised her children with her husband, a police officer who is now deceased.
She is 80 years old, with a heart condition that required a triple bypass, but that has barely slowed her activities.
"I still hop a bus and go everywhere," she said. "I go to church socials, flea markets and card parties -- never for high stakes -- and when I'm alone, I listen to radio talk shows into the night, and I swear. Of course I have crabby days but mainly, I keep busy. I make lampshades; I crochet. The first painting I did was a nude. My daughter would like me to move closer to her family, but I keep saying I have everything here. I mind my own business and I tell my neighbors, 'If you need me, just call.' "
Dr. Marjorie H. Cantor of Fordham, who helped analyze data from the study along with Dr. Barry Gurland of Columbia University's Center for Geriatrics, said the older New Yorkers in the study expressed a deep affection for the city.
Dr. Cantor, who worked on a 1970 study of aging New Yorkers, said, "Despite the increase in crime and the deterioration we see in the past two decades, the city is a much better place for the aging because of the services offered, the richness of the environment and the excitement around them, in contrast to rural or suburban living."
In the latest study, 59 percent of those surveyed felt positive about the city, with 13 percent rating it as a "very good" place to live while 46 percent rated it as "fairly good."
And supporting the overall conclusion about the importance of neighborhoods, 80 percent of those surveyed rated their immediate community as a very good or fairly good place to live.
The study was financed by philanthropies led by the New York Community Trust and its New York Center for Policy on Aging. Dr. James R. Dumpson, the center's chairman, directed the undertaking.
"Growing Older in New York City can be purchased from the New York Community Trust, 2 Park Avenue, New York, 10016 for $15 including postage.

Chart: "SNAPSHOT: Older New Yorkers, at a Glance" -- A look at New Yorkers over age 60, based on a survey of 1,570 people by the New York Center for Policy on Aging of the New York Community Trust.
 
Where They Are From
Most United States-born white residents (88 percent) said they were born in the Northeast -- either New York, New Jersey or Pennsylvania. Most black residents (60 percent) were born in the South, with another third born in the Northeast. Almost all Hispanic residents born in the United States said they were born in New York State.
For statistical purposes, information about the Asians included in the sampling were folded into that of white residents.
 
Where They Get Things Done
In most cases, older New Yorkers use services within one to three blocks of home. In the month before the survey, 88 percent said they had gone to a grocery that close to home, 73 percent had used neighborhood banks, 72 percent had gone to nearby pharmacies and 53 percent had attended churches or synagogues.
 
Friends and Neighbors
Although 71 percent of those surveyed said they had someone with whom they felt close and could share a secret, only 39 percent said they had a friend or confidant who was not a relative.
The majority of the older New Yorkers who said they had friends had at least one friend nearby, either in the same building (31 percent) or within walking distance (46 percent).
About two-thirds said they knew at least one neighbor very well.
 
At Work -- Then and Now
Almost four-fifths of those surveyed reported that they had worked outside the home at some point as adults. Almost all (99 percent) of those who had not were women who were homemakers.
Of those who had outside jobs, 85 percent were now retired and 15 percent were still working full or part-time.
Among those still working, 53 percent reported they were working full-time.
 
 Crime
Fifty-four percent said that at some time in their lives they had been victims of crimes like muggings, purse snatchings or apartment burglaries. One-third said they had been a victim of crime in their neighborhoods.
The large majority of older New Yorkers (88 percent) said crime had little effect on going out alone during the day, but 65 percent said fear of crime kept them from going out alone at night. (pg. 29)

HEADLINE: Jose Ramos Lopez, 79, Former Assemblyman

 BODY:
Jose Ramos Lopez, the first Puerto Rican Democrat elected to the New York State Assembly from Manhattan, who went on to serve nearly 20 years as a judge, died on Thursday in a hospital in San Juan, Puerto Rico. He was 79 and lived in Bellerose, Queens, and Puerto Rico.
His family said he died of cancer. 
 Mr. Ramos Lopez, who moved to New York City from Puerto Rico when he was 28, was appointed a Deputy Commissioner of Correction in 1953. He was elected to the State Assembly in 1958 to represent East Harlem. In Albany, he sponsored bills to provide collective bargaining rights, unemployment insurance and workers' compensation for hospital workers. He also sought to ease voting restrictions for Puerto Ricans by omitting a literacy test for any who had voted previously.
In 1967 he was elected a Civil Court judge and in 1978 he was appointed an acting State Supreme Court justice, serving until his retirement in 1985 in the civil division of Supreme Court in Manhattan.
Mr. Ramos Lopez is survived by his wife, Aida; six daughters, Linda Radford, Dolores Saraceno, Marguarite Toro, Denise Grunti, Lissette and Lisa, all of Queens, and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Against Mark But Gains in Yen Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the German mark yesterday in mainly technical trading. But it gained against the yen as Japanese stock prices continued to plunge.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6935 marks, down from 1.6950 marks. Still, it rose to 108.40 yen from 108.23 yen. 
 The dollar lost ground against most European currencies, despite positive October unemployment numbers. The Labor Department said 177,000 jobs were created during the month, although the overall unemployment rate rose to 6.8 percent, from 6.7 percent in September.
The figures, which were in line with expectations, showed the first rise in manufacturing sector employment in three months and confirmed other recent data showing continued moderate economic growth.
"It was generally a good report, a strong report, showing hourly earnings rising," said William Arnold, vice president and chief currency dealer at the Chemical Bank. "That might lead to the question of why the dollar's not higher."
 
Rally Stalls
 After dropping in early trading after the release of the jobs report, the dollar strengthened against the mark. But the rally stalled as institutional investors sold large dollar positions taken during the week on a series of positive American economic reports, dealers said.
"The dollar really was just overbought and that corrected as people started to take profits on their positions," said Victor Polce, foreign exchange manager for Commerzbank in New York.
The dollar advanced for a second consecutive day against the yen in quiet trading. The market largely shrugged off a Japanese Government report that the country's current account trade surplus grew 10 percent in September from a year earlier, focusing instead on this week's decline of more than 9 percent in the Tokyo stock market.
Mr. Arnold noted that in the past, a big increase in Japanese trade surplus would have caused the yen to strengthen. "But the focus has been on the weakness of the Japanese economy and the stock market," he said.
The British pound rose in New York to $1.4840, from $1.4810 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Pushed by Interest Rates, Gold Hits a 3-Month High

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Gold prices soared to three-month highs yesterday, extending their three-day surge to nearly $15 an ounce as rising interest rates continued to jolt the markets.
In very active trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery climbed $5.40, to $377.80 an ounce, its highest level since Aug. 11. At one point, the gold futures contract traded as high as $381.20. 
 "It was just nuts, complete chaos," a Comex broker said. He noted that commodity fund traders were active buyers.
Other precious metals also gained. December silver rose 12.3 cents to close at $4.505 an ounce on the Comex, and January platinum was up $4.20 to end at $380.00 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
 
Pushed by Interest Rates
 Behind the surge in gold and other precious metals is the sharp rise in interest rates, which had fallen to 25-year lows just last month. Yesterday the yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond rose to 6.20 percent; it had gone as low as 5.78 percent. The rising interest rates have also depressed stock prices.
Analysts said the rise in interest rates and the stock market's selloff earlier this week were pushing many investors to look for alternative investments, like gold.
"The move is on the stock and bond market; that's what's fueling this," said James Steel, an analyst at Refco Inc., a commodity trading firm.
Moreover, the prospects of an economic recovery, with the possiblity of rising inflation, have also contributed to gold's rise. Yesterday the Labor Department reported that a steadily expanding economy added 177,000 jobs in October.
Gold is getting an extra lift from rumors that the billionaire financier George Soros is moving out of the bond market and buying gold once more. Mr. Soros, who runs the Quantum Fund, had invested heavily in bonds, but the jump in long-term interest rates may have provoked the switch. He was partly responsible for setting off gold's surge earlier this year from a 10-year low of $326 an ounce to a three-year high of $414 in August.
Still, some analysts have strong doubts about gold's new surge. "It is entirely speculative," said Andy Smith, analyst at the Union Bank of Switzerland.
On other commodity markets, oil prices fell sharply amid reports of ample supplies. Crude oil for December delivery dropped 31 cents, to $17.09 a barrel. December unleaded gasoline posted another new five-year low, dropping 0.92 cent, to 47.05 cents a gallon. And December heating oil sank 0.84 cent, to 51.26 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Consumer Loans Rose 10.5% in September

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
American consumers increased their borrowing at a 10.5 percent annual rate in September, the largest one-month jump in nearly six years, the Federal Reserve said today.
Analysts said the $6.68 billion advance, which brought outstanding credit to a seasonally adjusted $769.2 billion, fit with other recent signs that the economy had shifted to a higher gear. 
 The monthly gain was the largest since January 1988.
"The fact that people do have the confidence to purchase credit-related items is certainly goods news," said Sandra Shaber, an econmist with the WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. "We've waited a long time, but it's finally happening,"
However, she cautioned, the increased borrowing that is fueling the gains in consumer spending is coming at the expense of Americans' rate of saving, which was just 4 percent of after-tax income in September. The low savings rate, she said, means that further employment and income growth are even more critical than usual to sustaining consumer spending.
During the recession and after, consumers reduced their borrowing and sought to pay off old debts. But, encouraged by low interest rates, they have been less hesitant about taking on new debt in the last year.
September marked the 11th increase in 12 months. Borrowing also increased strongly in August and July, both at annual rates of 8 percent.
By category, auto loans increased $2.28 billion, or a 10.2 percent annual rate, to $271.1 billion outstanding.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Consolidating Student Loans
 
Q What is the best way to consolidate my educational loans, which vary in interest rate from 5 percent to 10 percent?
 
MARY ANN T. BANEZ, Baltimore
A Once a Federal student loan is in the repayment period, it can be consolidated with one loan servicer at one interest rate. Information about agencies that consolidate these loans is available at most college financial aid offices. 
By choosing a longer repayment period, the monthly payment can be reduced. But "the cost of the loan can increase significantly," warned Laurie Schaffler, associate director of educational financing of Columbia University. "The longer the repayment period extends, the more interest is charged on the loan."
If you want to pay off a loan ahead of schedule, though, there are no prepayment penalties.
 
Lower Refinancing Costs
Q What does no-cost refinancing mean?
 
IVAN SHORE, New Rochelle, N.Y.
A Some lenders may be willing to waive certain expenses -- like those for the application, appraisal and credit report -- and make a so-called no-cost mortgage loan. But in exchange for waiving these up-front closing costs, which might average $1,500 on a $100,000 mortgage, these lenders usually raise the interest rate on the mortgage by approximately 3/8 of a percentage point. This extra interest can amount to a substantial sum over the life of a 30-year loan.
However, "there are always costs associated with refinancing a mortgage which must be paid by the borrower," said Richard N. Cohen, a real estate lawyer at Shereff, Friedman, Hoffman & Goodman. "Such costs could easily exceed $1,000 for a typical closing."
Among the expenses that banks will not normally waive, he said, are the satisfaction fee in connection with the borrower's existing mortgage, short-term interest owed and tax and hazard-insurance escrow payments.
 
Early Bond Redemptions
 
Q Are there any exceptions to the general rule that an owner must redeem a bond when it is called by the issuer?
 
LUCILLE DOVE, Washington
A No. Whenever a bond is called, the owner must submit it to the bond issuer for redemption. Otherwise the owner will not receive payment for the bond's value or interest payments.
In the current low-rate environment, a large number of municipal and corporate issuers are exercising the call provisions on high-yielding securities. "Many investors are surprised when their bonds are called," said Richard F. Grabish, a vice president of A. G. Edwards & Sons. "It is very important for investors to study offering circulars and confirmation notices, so they will know whether the bonds being purchased contain call provisions."
Some bond owners, however, are confused about the difference between a call and a put. If a bond contains a call feature, the issuer has the right to demand redemption before the scheduled maturity date. On the other hand, a put provision entitles the owner to redeem the bond under predetermined conditions before maturity.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Low Interest Rates Lift the Bond Group

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Most bond fund returns over the last three years have been extraordinary, thanks to a substantial drop in interest rates. Long-term rates have hit 25-year lows and short-term rates 30-year lows.
Investors should not delude themselves into thinking that this market behavior is the norm. "It's not at all in the cards that we'll have a similar decline from today's levels that would provide anywhere near the kind of strength in the bond markets which produced those returns in the last three years," said H. Bradlee Perry, senior partner at David L. Babson & Company, Cambridge, Mass. 
 Even so, he says, bonds are very attractive. Although inflation has returned to its 3 percent long-term average, bond yields have not. Long Treasuries yield 6.2 percent today, compared with their 5 percent historical average.
The most important factor is what will happen to inflation over the next few years. Because of excess capacity worldwide and increased international competition, Mr. Perry said he expected no more than a slight pickup in inflation.

HEADLINE: Warming Up to Global Warming

 BODY:
President Clinton's new plan to control global warming looks a lot more like something George Bush would dream up than like anything straight from the heart of Al Gore, the environmental conscience of the Administration. The plan relies heavily on voluntary actions, goes light on regulatory actions and remains silent on the enormously difficult problem of what to do to head off a big increase in greenhouse gas emissions after the turn of the century.
Even so, the plan is a reasonable response to a distant crisis whose dimensions are uncertain. This is not an issue on which the President should spend much political or economic capital just yet. 
 There is wide agreement that an accumulation in the atmosphere of greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide, will make the world warmer than it would otherwise be. But there's little agreement about the magnitude of the warming and what damage it would cause. And that, in turn, makes it difficult to know how much money and effort to expend now to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
President Bush treated global warming as a secondary issue that required no strong governmental response. He strongly opposed setting any firm targets or timetables for reducing emissions, and almost singlehandedly blocked the setting of mandatory limits in the global climate treaty signed in Rio de Janeiro last year.
The Bush program relied mainly on voluntary actions by industry, most of which were already under way. These efforts, the Bush Administration calculated, would bring the nation within hailing distance of 1990 emission levels by the year 2000, but would not quite reach that goal. Thereafter, the emissions would soar upward again.
President Clinton has now greatly toughened the rhetoric while only moderately toughening the policies. He has called global warming "perhaps the biggest environmental threat to this planet," suggesting that he views the problem more seriously than did Mr. Bush. And he has pledged to bring emission levels in the year 2000 down to 1990 levels, thus imposing a mandate on himself that Mr. Bush declined to impose on the country.
But Mr. Clinton stopped short of proposing the corrective measures recommended by Mr. Gore in his book "Earth in the Balance," namely tougher mileage requirements for all cars and trucks sold in the U.S. and a carbon tax to discourage emissions. He, too, will rely heavily on voluntary actions by industry and individuals. Those would be backed up by new regulatory standards in a few areas, including residential appliances, electric transformers and landfill emissions.
The Clinton program has drawn criticism from disappointed environmental groups. But it is a reasonable response given the uncertain nature of the peril and the strong political opposition to new taxes and tougher mileage standards. Unlike Mr. Bush, Mr. Clinton is putting his own credibility behind the emissions-control effort. He has called for $1.9 billion in government spending, mostly redirected funds, by the year 2000. And his effort to enlist the aid of industry appears far more vigorous than Mr. Bush's.
Administration experts calculate that the program is strong enough to reach the goal for the year 2000. A White House team will monitor progress and ratchet up the effort if necessary. Mr. Clinton still has to tell us how to cope with vehicular emissions and a sharp rise in overall emissions after the turn of the century. But for now he has made a sensible start on an emerging problem that bears close watching.

HEADLINE: Religion Notes

BYLINE: By Ari L. Goldman

 BODY:

Party by Religion
The breakdown of religious affiliations within each major political party is pretty close to the breakdown of the nation as a whole, according to an analysis released after the elections this week.
 The Democratic Party, often seen as the home of Roman Catholics, is only slightly more Catholic in makeup (28 percent) than the Republican Party (24 percent). Twenty-six percent of those calling themselves independents are Catholic. The Republican Party is roughly even with the Democratic Party in the number of people who identify themselves as "born again" Christians (41 percent to 39 percent). 
 Proportionately, there is greater variation when it comes to the party affiliation of Jews. Among Democrats, 3 percent are Jewish. Among Independents, 2 percent are Jewish and among Republicans, 1 percent are Jewish.
The analysis is based on national voter surveys taken by the Gallup Organization throughout the 1992 Presidential election year. It was released by an affiliate of Gallup, the Princeton Religious Research Center, an affiliate of the Gallup organization. Sample sizes were 40,000 or more. The margin of sampling error is plus or minus 1 percentage point.
It was the first time such an analysis was done.
Among the other findings: Republicans are somewhat more likely to be church members than Democrats (79 percent to 71 percent), and members of both parties were about equal in their agreement with the statement that religion is "very important" in their lives (65 to 63 percent).
Republicans and Democrats had roughly the same number of people who profess no religious belief (6 percent to 7 percent), but independents had the largest proportion, with 13 percent.
Based on the analysis, politicians would be wise to stay away from narrow religious appeals, said the author of the study, Robert Bezilla. "They should not charge that they have the moral high ground and that their opponents are irreligious or nonreligious," he said. "The voters are interested in moral issues, such as abortion, but not on whether a candidate is a Methodist or a Catholic or a 'born again.' To most voters, that is irrelevant."
 
Aptly, in the Queen's Hands
 In London this week, Parliament gave its final approval to a measure that will open the priesthood to women in the Church of England. The House of Lords gave its overwhelming approval on Tuesday after a similar vote last week in the House of Commons.
The measure, which was initiated by the church leadership, requires government approval because it involves the state-sanctioned church. The measure now goes to Queen Elizabeth II, whose approval will make it law. Then the church's General Synod will put the change into effect.
The move to ordain women has prompted strong protests from some church conservatives, who see it as a violation of Scripture and as dividing the Church of England from the Catholic Church, which does not ordain women. Some members of the Church of England have left and joined the Catholic Church, including a former Bishop of London, Graham Leonard. Other members say they will leave after the first women are ordained.
Among the supporters of the ordination of women are the Archbishop of Canterbury, George L. Carey, who said in arguing for passage in the House of Lords: "We have well over 1,000 women deacons who are offering their skills and gifts to the service of Christ and many of them see this legislation as offering the fulfillment of their ministry."
The first women are expected to be ordained into the Church of England in April, after the Easter holiday, since ordinations do not take place in the pre-Easter Lenten season.
 
'Message to Women'
 Women have been ordained in the American branch of the Church of England, known as the Episcopal Church, for more than a decade. Three have been made bishops.
On Monday, one of them, Bishop Mary Adelia McLeod, was installed as the head of the 10,000-member Episcopal Diocese of Vermont. She is the first woman to head a diocese; the others assist diocesan bishops in Massachusetts and Washington.
"Our church really does allow for all of us to have a voice," Bishop McLeod said at her ordination in Burlington.
At her side for much of the two-hour service was her son, the Rev. Harrison McLeod, who was ordained in Alabama on June 5, the same day his mother was chosen by her fellow bishops to serve as Vermont's bishop.
"I think it is really a message to women," Bishop McLeod said of her installation. "It is a sign of hope."

International 3-5
 
HAITI MILITARY REJECTS TALKS

HEADLINE: Clinton Opposes Amendment Requiring a Balanced Budget

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
President Clinton informed Congress today that he opposed a proposed constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget, asserting that "it would promote political gridlock and would endanger our economic recovery." 
 In a letter to the Senate Majority Leader, George J. Mitchell, Mr. Clinton said such an amendment would require a combination of increased taxes on working families, massive cuts in Social Security benefits and major cuts in Medicare and Medicaid. He also said the amendment would be bad economics, suggesting that whenever the economy faltered, it would force Congress to increase taxes to close a deficit, thus worsening recessions.

HEADLINE: After the Jobs Went South: A Town Finds Pitfalls in a Retraining Effort

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Mo.

 BODY:
Bill Beeman thought maybe it was not so bad when the Zenith television factory here sent his job to Mexico. The Federal Government, after all, was offering a lifeline to workers hurt by foreign competition -- money to train for a new line of work.
"When I signed up," said Mr. Beeman, who is 42 and had worked at the plant for 23 years, "they said there would be enough funds there to get you through two years of school." 
 That was in May 1992. His books, tuition and a $170 weekly benefit check assured, Mr. Beeman, who tested television sets at Zenith, enrolled in the Ozarks Technical Community College to study electronics and to plan a career in computer operation. He has been rolling along, too, and in nine more months would theoretically be ready for a new job.
 
Lower-Paying Jobs, or None
 But there are a couple of problems with this rosy story. One is that Mr. Beeman's weekly benefit money has run out, for reasons that baffle a lot of program trainees. Another is that the jobs that Mr. Beeman and hundreds of former Zenith workers have been training for often pay much less than their former jobs, or simply do not exist.
The adjustments and headaches that Zenith's cast-offs are facing make Springfield a test case for the nation's ability to retrain workers who lose their jobs when companies relocate to foreign countries.
The Clinton Administration is eager to reassure workers anxious about the possible dislocations of the North American Free Trade Agreement. If the agreement is approved, the Administration would set aside $90 million to assist workers who might lose their jobs because of trade with Mexico. And the Labor Department plans to overhaul Federal unemployment assistance and training services for all Americans who have lost their jobs.
But there is widespread doubt about the utility of retraining programs. Last month, the Labor Department's own inspector general published a report critical of the Trade Adjustment Assistance program, which is intended to help workers like Mr. Beeman. The program succeeds in steering just one in five workers into jobs paying at least 80 percent of what their old jobs paid.
Springfield's experience suggests that retraining often helps displaced workers find better jobs than they might get otherwise, but that the new jobs are often much lower paid and less secure than Zenith's jobs.
Since the 1970's, the Zenith Electronics Corporation has reduced its work force here to 450 from 4,500. Zenith now employs 18,000 workers in Mexico and 6,000 in the United States, a company spokesman said.
Mr. Beeman and other former Zenith workers are luckier than most unemployed Americans. Because they are among the 30,000 people whose jobs are deemed to have been lost to imports, they qualify for the trade adjustment program, which pays them weekly benefits for up to a year and a half and tuition for up to two years of training. By contrast, most unemployed workers receive benefits for 26 weeks, sometimes with extensions.
 
Watching Benefits Dry Up
 Like many former Zenith workers, Mr. Beeman chose to train in a field that the Government had determined would produce good jobs, computers.
But on Oct. 13, the Missouri Division of Employment Security sent Mr. Beeman a letter telling him his weekly benefits had run out -- five months before he thought they would. The Federal Government begins counting workers' eligibility for the allowance from the date of their first layoff, whether temporary or not. Mr. Beeman and most other workers were laid off for a week in January 1992. He was then recalled and not let go permanently until May.
That meant his eligibility had begun running down in January, even though he did not start collecting an allowance until five months later. Mr. Beeman and others who are losing their allowances for the same reason may have to drop out of school.
Proponents of retraining, including Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, urge training programs of up to two years, because they say the longer training leads to better jobs. But here, as in most communities, the Labor Department and state employment services tend to discourage workers from enrolling in longer programs. They think the workers will drop out of the programs when the living allowance is cut off after the maximum 18 months.
So they often encourage workers to take less training, and, as a result, less skilled, lower-paid jobs.
Stanley Seaman, a supervisor at the state employment service here, said he asks the former Zenith workers: " 'How are you going to support yourself while you're in training?' " They have to tell me how they are going to do that, or we can't approve their training. That's why we opt for the least amount of training possible."
Unlike many workers, those let go here can find jobs of some sort. Springfield, with a tourism industry fueled by the booming country music town of Branson, 35 miles away, has an unemployment rate of only 4.6 percent. But many new jobs pay little more than the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour.
Zenith's average wage is $8.02, low by national standards for factory jobs, but company-paid health and other benefits bring it close to $12.
Of the 673 former Zenith workers who registered for training or job-seeking help with a program here run by the Job Council of the Ozarks, 266 reported they had found jobs by mid-October. They reported receiving an average wage of $7.15 to $7.25 an hour -- less than $15,000 a year. Most of them either receive no health benefits or have to share the cost with their employers.
Seventy-two of the 266, including some who received job retraining, earn less than $6 an hour working as nurses' aides, janitors, file clerks, motel maids and cashiers at Wal-Mart.
 
Frustration and Low Wages
 Here is a look at the changes in the lives of some former Zenith workers who received training assistance.
Berny and Debbie Ihrig had both worked at Zenith on the same shift. Mr. Ihrig, 38, had worked there for 20 years; Mrs. Ihrig, 37, for 10 years. Each earned $8.50 an hour, for a total of about $35,000 a year, without overtime. Each has been retrained, but their combined income is now a little more than $20,000.
Two years ago, Zenith laid off Mrs. Ihrig (pronounced EYE-rig), and last year, Mr. Ihrig. Mrs. Ihrig took six weeks of training that led to a nurse's aide job paying $4.98 an hour. And after a nine-month course at Ozark Technical Community College, Mr. Ihrig became a surgical technician for $7.50 an hour.
But both were working nights. "We couldn't afford the day care," Mr. Ihrig said. So his wife quit her job and is now working for $4.35 an hour as an aide at their children's day care center, where she gets a break on the fees. The Ihrigs have to pay $100 a month for health insurance through his employer -- it had been free when he was at Zenith.
The Ihrigs, who have two children, 3 and 4, live on an 80-acre farm with 16 cows and 11 calves 38 miles northwest of Springfield. But the farm and cattle are up for sale.
"I'll sell the cows and the farm and move to town," Mr. Ihrig said.
Margaret Claspill, by contrast, shows how greater training to learn higher skills pays off and why it is beyond the reach of many workers. She is nearing the end of a two-year program at St. John's Hospital to become a registered nurse there, a job that will pay about $12.50 an hour.
Ms. Claspill, 49, who is divorced and has two children in their 20's, lost her job in December 1991 after 23 years as a technician at Zenith, where she was paid $10 an hour.
Knowing she would probably lose her job, she visited a state employment counselor a year beforehand and had been encouraged to continue working toward the nursing degree for which she had started training part time. The counselor warned Mrs. Claspill that she would run out of income before her two-year training program ended.
"She asked me, Was there a way I could foot this bill myself then? So I started working all the overtime I could," Mrs. Claspill said. "I worked double shifts to get the money.
"I think it's wonderful for anyone to try to do what I did. But it's not realistic."
Many older workers say they are stunned to find how little the job market values their experience at Zenith.
Judy Brickner, 51, was laid off in May 1992 after 25 years at Zenith, where she earned $8 an hour. When she left Zenith, her husband, Gerald, was just getting started as a self-employed photographer.
Mrs. Brickner, who has two grown children, took courses in mathematics, English and computers. She dropped out after seven months. "I did it until I got tired," she said.
She has been looking for a full-time job for more than a year. The mortgage on the Brickners' house is paid off, and they have no other debts. But they are now stuck with a $300 monthly bill for their own health insurance that Zenith once covered.
Looking for a job, she said, was a little demeaning. "The kind of work I'm finding is minimum-wage or part-time," she said. "If you look in the paper, you see ads for cooks, waitresses and motel maids."
Mrs. Brickner has just taken a job at Wal-Mart. It pays $4.50 an hour, 25 cents more then the minimum wage.
The Beemans had already retrenched by the time he was laid off. In 1987, after Zenith cut the pay of workers by 8 percent, Mr. Beeman and his wife, Latrisia, 41, a $6.50-an-hour office manager, sold the house they had just bought for what they had paid, about $47,000. The couple and their 13-year-old son are now renting.
One morning before classes, Mr. Beeman, in a gray pin-stripe suit, returned from interviews for part-time jobs at Radio Shack and Service Merchandise. To make up for the benefit check he had lost, he would have to work 40 hours a week at the minimum wage.
"I worked all the way from assembler to technician," he said. "I took all the schooling that Zenith offered. But when I left, their certificates were worth nothing. Now here I am trying to better my education and be a more productive human being. Why can't they just say, 'This person is trying. Let's help him.' "
Days later, he accepted a sales job at Service Merchandise at $5 an hour, just over half his Zenith pay of $9.76. So far the store has needed him only six hours a week, so he is looking for another job.
Mr. Beeman recently wrote a letter of complaint to President Clinton. "It's hard," he wrote, "not to question both your commitment and the Federal Government's commitment to retraining displaced workers."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I took all the schooling that Zenith offered," said Bill Beeman, after the company moved his job to Mexico. "But when I left, their certificates were worth nothing. Now here I am trying to better my education and be a more productive human being." He attends the Ozarks Technical Community College in Springfield, Mo., where he studies electronics and plans a career in computer operation. (Ted Reisinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Serbia Arrests 18 Leaders Of Opposition Party Militia

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 5

 BODY:
The Serbian authorities have arrested 18 leaders of a Serbian militia, charging them with murder, rape, kidnapping and illegal arms possession, the republic's Police Ministry announced late Thursday.
Those arrested were members of the Chetnik Movement, the paramilitary wing of the militant nationalist Serbian Radical Party. The party, led by Vojislav Seselj, has gained enough popularity over the last two years to challenge the Serbian Socialist Party of President Slobodan Milosevic. 
 Last week Mr. Milosevic dissolved Parliament after the Radicals moved for a vote of no confidence that would have toppled the Socialists, and the arrests this week were seen as a further attempt by the Serbian President to silence the Radicals' criticism.
International human-rights watchdogs and the United States have labeled Mr. Seselj and individual Chetniks war criminals in connection with killings of civilians during "ethnic cleansing" operations in Croatia in 1991 and in Bosnia and Herzegovina in 1992 and 1993. Leaders of Croats and Hungarians in Serbia have also charged for over a year that the Chetniks have terrorized members of those minority groups in an effort to drive them from their homes.
 
Crimes in Serbia Charged
 The arrests were all on charges related to acts committed in Serbia itself, a Police Ministry statement said.
Mr. Seselj, a lanky former Communist who once called on his partisans to "scoop out the eyes of Croats with rusty spoons," was described by Mr. Milosevic last year as his "favorite" opposition politician. But in September Mr. Milosevic turned on Mr. Seselj, calling him a war criminal.
Today, Mr. Seselj condemned the arrests and called them part of a campaign to defame the Radicals, who had 73 seats in the 250-member Parliament to the Socialists' 102. When he dissolved Parliament on Oct. 20, Mr. Milosevic called new elections for Dec. 19.
"The goal is to discredit the Serbian Radical Party using the mass media," Mr. Seselj said. "This is a component part of their election campaign. This campaign will end with the political crushing of Slobodan Milosevic."
But polls over the last week indicate that the Socialists will reclaim a majority in Parliament in the coming vote.
The Radicals accuse the Socialists of plunging Serbia into economic chaos and of betraying the Serbs' national interests by supporting a "compromise" peace plan aimed at ending the war in Bosnia.
Mr. Milosevic attacked Mr. Seselj in an interview televised on Wednesday, in which he ruled out any Serbian participation in international talks aimed at ending the Bosnian war until the United Nations lifts the economic sanctions that have crippled Serbia, which with Montenegro is part of the remaining Yugoslav federation.
"Arrogant, wealthy and armed people will not be a model to be followed in Serbia for much longer," Mr. Milosevic said in a thinly veiled reference to Mr. Seselj. "I do not want to specify which parties I would cooperate with, but it is certainly with all democratic forces, and most certainly not with the forces of darkness, fascism and crime."
The arrested Radicals included Branislav Vakic, a deputy in Yugoslavia's federal Parliament. In June Mr. Vakic assaulted an opposition-party deputy, touching off violent Belgrade street demonstrations that led to the death of a police officer and the arrest and beating by the police of Vuk Draskovic, a political enemy of both Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Seselj.
 
Radical Accused of 4 Murders
 The police charged another Radical, Milenko Petric, with murdering four people in Vojvodina, a region of Serbia with a large Hungarian population.
But Western diplomats called the arrests a purely political move.
"This is not a blow against war criminals," a Western diplomat said. "If the regime were serious about arresting war criminals, they could look elsewhere and find a notorious war criminal who is running a national campaign."
The diplomat was alluding to the leader of the new Serbian Unity Party, Zeljko Raznatovic, a Belgrade underworld figure and reputed secret-police assassin. His paramilitary group, the Tigers, has been named by human-rights organizations and the United States in connection with atrocities in Croatia and Bosnia.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
MUSLIMS LOOT SEIZED TOWN
 VARES, Bosnia, Nov. 5 (Reuters) -- Bosnian Army troops and United Nations forces tried to restore order in Vares today as Muslim soldiers continued looting the town.
A day after the Government troops seized Vares, abandoned by Bosnian Croat forces, pillaging was still going on, Bosnian officers and United Nations peacekeepers said.
"The biggest problem has been Bosnian Army units organized from refugees," said Ekrem Mahmutovic, commander of a Bosnian Army unit in Vares. "Those who have lost everything tried to get back what they lost. What they did was wrong."
Swedish peacekeepers trying to halt the looting were reinforced by French troops sent from Sarajevo, about 30 miles to the south.
 
Muslims Control Highway
 Bosnian Army and United Nations officials said that with Vares in hand, Muslim forces had complete control of the highway running north from Visoko through Vares and Milankovici to Tuzla.
The route links Zenica and Tuzla, the two big Muslim strongholds in central Bosnia, opening the way for civilian and military convoys.
A few Muslim and Croat families displaced by nearly two weeks of turmoil leading to the fall of Vares began returning home. But the Croatian radio said 2,000 Croats who fled Vares had arrived in the Serb-held town of Sokolac, east of Sarajevo. Other Croatian civilians were heading for Capljina, near the southern town of Mostar, Croatian radio said.
About 5,000 more Croats, roughly 1,000 of them soldiers, fled to the Croatian stronghold of Kiseljak to the south, United Nations officials in Sarajevo said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The body of an elderly man who was shot to death lay on the bank of a river yesterday in the central Bosnian town of Vares, north of Sarajevo. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: U.S. Warns Libya of Oil Boycott Unless It Gives Up Bomb Suspects

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 5

 BODY:
The United States warned Libya today that it may face a global boycott of its oil if it does not hand over suspected terrorists. The warning came after Russia, under Western pressure, dropped its objections to a new set of Security Council sanctions against the North African oil-producing country.
American officials said the Administration would press for a total oil boycott if the new limited trade and financial embargo just worked out between the United States, Britain, France and Russia does not prompt Libya to surrender the two suspects indicted in the bombing of Pan American World Airlines Flight 103, which exploded over Scotland five years ago with the loss of 270 lives. 
 Libya would also have to cooperate with a French investigation of the similar destruction of a French airliner over Niger in 1989 and satisfy the Secretary General of the United Nations that it has renounced support for international terrorism.
After trying for several weeks to design a new sanctions package that would force Libya to pay a $4 billion arms debt to Moscow, the Russians gave up the attempt today and settled for a resolution tightening existing sanctions while merely affirming "Libya's duty scrupulously to adhere to all its obligations concerning servicing and repayment of its foreign debt."
 
Debt Settlement Sought
 Russia initially threatened to veto the new sanctions -- which freeze Libya's foreign financial assets, tighten an existing ban on international air links with Libya and cut off exports to Libya of oil refining and pipeline equipment -- unless the Security Council also agreed to give Moscow the frozen financial assets in settlement of the debt.
When the United States and its allies refused, saying this would create a dangerous precedent that could weaken future sanctions against recalcitrant nations, Russia suggested that the other Security Council members advance it a $4 billion interest-free loan instead.
Russia apparently felt that since the proposed new sanctions had been carefully tailored to interfere as little as possible with Western Europe's economic relations with Libya, the Security Council should advance Russian economic interests as well by forcing Libya to pay for the arms it had bought.
The sanctions package would not interfere with the large oil and gas exploration contracts that a number of European companies have recently signed with Libya, including the French oil company Total, E.N.I.-Agip of Italy and Petrofina of Belgium. It also permits Libya to continue exporting the bulk of its oil to Western Europe. Although customers would have to deposit payment in specially designated bank accounts, Tripoli would still have access to these funds.
Moscow finally agreed to the sanctions only after President Clinton and the Prime Ministers of Britain and France wrote personally to President Boris N. Yeltsin this week warning that continued Russian stalling would jeopardize relations with their countries.
 
Council May Vote Next Week
 The new sanctions package, which the Security Council is expected to vote on early next week, will not take effect until a date to be set later this month and until after the Russian parliamentary elections planned for Dec. 12.
The new sanctions close down all foreign offices of Libyan Arab Airlines and require all countries to downgrade Libyan diplomatic missions in addition to freezing overseas financial assets and banning sales of equipment for oil refineries and pipelines.
American officials say the asset freeze would prevent Libya from receiving income and dividends from the extensive investments it has made in refineries, gas stations and other industrial undertakings in Western Europe. But the Tripoli Government has been given plenty of time to try to hide any cash deposits in overseas banks.
American officials argue that the new measures will increase the economic pressure to hand over the suspects for trial in Britain or the United States.
And there is evidence that the debate over whether to surrender them has deepened divisions in Libya and weakened support for its leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, in his armed forces. Earlier this month there were reports that Colonel Qaddafi had been forced to call in the air force to quell an insurrection at an army barracks near Tripoli.

LIBYA DENIES ARMS PROJECT
 CAIRO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Libya denied today that it was either producing chemical weapons or that it had hired Thai workers to help in such an effort.
Washington has accused Libya of building a chemical weapons plant near Tripoli and of contracting with Thai companies to work on it.
The official Libyan news agency, JANA, said Tripoli had repeatedly declared that it had no plans to produce chemical weapons and that it had called for an international agreement to prevent the spread of weapons of mass destruction.
The agency said the allegations were part of a United States campaign to discredit Libya. The Thais, the agency said, are working on a huge pipeline project to cultivate barren land.

HEADLINE: Impasse Over World Trade Pact Poisons Ties to U.S., France Says

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 5

 BODY:
In an unusually somber assessment of relations between France and the United States, Foreign Minister Alain Juppe said today that disagreements in world trade talks were poisoning the alliance between the two countries while sharp differences also persisted over the new role of NATO.
With just over a month remaining until the deadline set by all parties to conclude long-stalled General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks, Mr. Juppe said, "I am not in the least optimistic because the United States is not negotiating at the moment." 
 "It won't be any use for Washington to present us with a cherry-topped cake 24 hours before the deadline and then expect us to agree," he said.
 
Eager to Improve Ties
 Mr. Juppe, a 48-year-old Gaullist who took office in March, told a small group of foreign correspondents that he had been eager to improve the strained ties with Washington that marked the tenure of his predecessor, the Socialist Roland Dumas. But he said his efforts had foundered .
"How can you expect French relations to be good with the United States when we have this conflict over GATT?" he asked. "The trade talks are a formidable cactus and they have made the establishment of a good climate impossible."
Trans-Atlantic differences over agricultural trade, French support and protection of its movie industry, textiles and other issues have long plagued the trade talks to the point that the word GATT has become synonymous in France with marauding American commercial and cultural imperialism.
 
'United States Must Negotiate'
 Mr. Juppe said it was necessary to combat protectionist tendencies at a time of sharply rising unemployment in Europe, but warned: "If we want to have a GATT accord by Dec. 15, the United States must negotiate. If there are no concessions, we will not sign."
France wants revisions in an agreement reached last year between the European Community and the United States calling for a 21 percent cut over six years in the volume of Europe's subsidized grain and other food exports. The United States has said there is no question of renegotiating the accord and has also balked at French demands that its movie industry be afforded continued protection in any new world trade deal.
Mr. Juppe's statement was made as the European Community's chief trade negotiatior, Sir Leon Brittan, issued a report in Brussels also criticizing Washington for blocking progress on the GATT talks and retreating from commitments to reduce customs tariffs made at the meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations in Tokyo in July.
The report said the Community was deeply disappointed that Washington had not respected the Tokyo accord's call for a 50 percent cut in the highest tariffs, many of which apply to textiles.
An American official who follows the GATT talks closely said that there was no question that the top priority in Washington now was securing Congressional support for the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico, and that attention had therefore been diverted from GATT.
But the official, who insisted on anonymity, added that the Clinton Administration remained determined to reach an accord in talks that economists have estimated could add $213 billion to world income by 2002.

HEADLINE: Professionals Sent Back to Class

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
IN EDUCATION circles, what's sauce for the goose is sauce for an increasingly old and wise gander. Like secondary-school teachers who must submit to periodic competency testing, a wide variety of professionals, from dentists to financial planners, are being pressed to recertify their skills.
A nationwide movement is growing among state legislatures, prodded by the public, to compel professionals back to school to keep up with developments in their fields, in order to retain their licenses. Even occupations that are self-regulating, like estate appraisers, are conducting similar programs.
 
Demonstrating Rigor
 The movement, which began with the health-related professions, like doctors and nurses, has spread to lawyers and occupations that provide a wide spectrum of services to the public, such as real estate agents, accountants and social workers. "Professions of every stripe are trying to demonstrate rigor," said Robert S. Lapiner, dean of continuing education at U.C.L.A. Extension, the largest continuing-education school in the country, a division of the University of California at Los Angeles. 
 There are no nationwide statistics on the trend. But Louis Phillips, a consultant who specializes in continuing education for professionals, found in his own nationwide survey that for 13 professions out of 15 between 1982 and 1992, more states were requiring mandatory education. The two exceptions were architects and engineers.
The most successful courses are thought to be those that provide specific, practical information, such as the ones conducted by certified public accountants for each other -- courses along the lines of "How C.P.A.'s Can Profit From the 1992 Cable-Television Law."
Continuing education for professionals is not without its flaws, however: most courses require only attendance for a student to pass. Fewer still require active participation.
Some of those taking recertification courses have not seen the inside of a classroom for years and resent being there. There is a name for their attitude: "The Reluctant Learner Syndrome." "Sometimes they're even worse than reluctant," Mr. Phillips said. "They just don't want to be there. They can be downright disruptive." Most, however, just sit in their chairs to get the credit. But he puts these reluctant learners at a small fraction, and he estimates that 70 percent in any given profession will take courses out of a sense of duty.
Continuing education is also seen by some as a vehicle for tax-deductible vacations, though sunglasses and swimming pools have become more the exception than the rule.
Many states have made continuing education mandatory, requiring courses at a university or some other form of instruction after a professional is established in the workplace. It is an approach designed to guarantee basic competence by denying the renewal of a license unless a minimum number of courses are taken.
The courses also tend to calm the anxiety over the sluggish economic recovery. "When the economy is bad, there is a surge in enrollment," said Pat K. Thaler, chairwoman of the Council for Continuing Education in the Professions and the Liberal Arts, a coordinating group in Washington D.C. "People believe, and rightly so, that the better the skills and the greater the education, the more likely they'll hold onto their job or move up in their job."
Last year, 27 states required continuing education for psychologists, up from 11 in 1982; 28 states had requirements for dentists, up from 10; 31 states recertified social workers, up from 15. Of 15 selected professions in the states studied by Mr. Phillips, Delaware, Nevada and Florida had the most requirements; Connecticut, Hawaii and New York the least.
 
Many Approaches
 Even in New York, where he found that only three of his selected professions (accountants, nursing-home administrators and real estate agents) had to undergo continuing-education requirements, there are a variety of approaches.
New York University, for example, offers 24 accounting-related courses, including fraud investigation (10 100-minute sessions for $380) and cash-flow forecasting ($150 for one eight-hour seminar). It offers more than 40 real estate-related courses.
Appraisers, who assign value to land, watches, paintings and furniture, among other things, for use in insurance valuations and estate sales, carry no New York State obligation to recertify. Yet they can become embroiled in divorce cases if one side disputes the valuation of an asset. And an appraiser can be the object of a malpractice lawsuit if he or she, for example, appraises a painting too low, and the piece fails to recoup its true value at auction.
The Appraisers Association of America, based in New York City, was founded in 1949 by a group of New York State appraisers concerned about such issues and about the growing number of appraisers and the lack of self-policing. Appraisers become members by offering three references and three written appraisals, and by submitting to peer review by an eight-member committee and an eight-hour certification test.
The association requires 100 certification points over five years to become recertified. A university course is 15 points. But an appraiser could earn all 100 points by simply attending five of the association's annual conventions (worth 20 points and costing $395), which many elect to do. And the many seminars on Faberge eggs and picture frames offered by the association can be taken without tests. "We assume that if people are going to spend the money, they'll be in attendance and get something out of it," said Victor Wiener, executive director of the association.
Even the association's minimal certification requirements touch only a small fraction of the nation's appraisers. Mr. Wiener's organization has about 1,000 members, but there may be up to 150,000 uncertified appraisers in the country.
Professionals who object to taking courses for a grade argue that recertifying does nothing to prevent professionals from harming the public. Few lawyers, doctors or other professionals are sanctioned by peer review boards for technical incompetence but rather for civil or even criminal lapses.
Moreover, many who have made a contribution to their field may have specialties so narrow that their general expertise is difficult to test in a meaningful way. There are few real specialists who can devise tests for other specialists. In addition, it is difficult to prove whether continuing education affects job performance.
For these and other reasons, some professions have tried to block recertification. Only Iowa, for example, requires architects to take recertification courses, which represents no change from 1982.
Still, the mandatory continuing education movement is gaining in strength, if cumbersomely. "There is a crying need for greater coordination at the national level," Mr. Phillips said. "Let's say I want to practice real estate in Georgia, Alabama, South Carolina -- I have to conform to three different sets of regulations."
