NAME: Allard K. Lowenstein

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2928 words

HEADLINE: One Person Made a Difference

BYLINE: By David Oshinsky; David Oshinsky, a professor of 20th-century history at Rutgers University, is the author of "A Conspiracy So Immense: The World of Joe McCarthy" and a forthcoming book on race and punishment in the South.

 BODY:

NEVER STOP RUNNING
Allard Lowenstein and the Struggle
to Save American Liberalism.
By William H. Chafe.
Illustrated. 556 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $28. 
 IN the chaotic 1960's, against a backdrop of violent protests, racial strife and televised assassinations, a new kind of politics emerged from a rather novel source. It was a politics of impatience and idealism, propelled by elite college students who had come of age in the prosperous baby-boom years following World War II. And it was molded, in large measure, by a rumpled, frenetic tactician named Allard K. Lowen stein, whose radical strategies sometimes masked his throughly mainstream political beliefs.
The title of William H. Chafe's book "Never Stop Running" perfectly captures the manic crusading, the rootlessness and the fear of personal relationships that made Lowenstein unique. "How we behave in our public lives inevitably reflects values, attitudes and experiences embedded in our private lives, and vice versa," writes Mr. Chafe, a professor of history at Duke University. In pursuing this vital link between the personal and the political, he has interviewed dozens of people and mined every scrap of paper -- including private correspondence and diaries -- from a subject who seemed to throw nothing away. The result is both a superb biography of Lowenstein and a gripping history of liberal protest and reform in an increasingly conservative age.
Politics came naturally to Lowenstein. His immigrant father preached the virtues of socialism while slicing roast beef at the family's bustling cafeteria in Manhattan. Born in 1929, Allard was, at age 7, handing out campaign leaflets for President Franklin D. Roosevelt; at 9, he was raising money for the anti-Franco forces in the Spanish Civil War. His idea of fun in these years was to chart obscure elections and to argue politics with adults. "In almost all these ventures," Mr. Chafe writes, "Lowenstein defended the underdog, the outcast, the less established cause."
This was hardly surprising. As a child of the Great Depression, Lowenstein admired the New Deal's spirit of liberal reform. And he saw that fundamental change could occur within the political process, even in the most perilous of times. That, Lowenstein believed, was what separated the United States from totalitarian regimes. Americans used the strengths of their system to remedy its faults.
As a brilliant graduate of Horace Mann, an elite private school in New York City, Lowenstein had his pick of colleges. Yet he chose to enter the University of North Carolina in 1945 -- a decision that brought his family to tears. Why would a liberal Jewish New Yorker go to Chapel Hill, a sleepy Christian town known to its residents as "the southern side of heaven"? Lowenstein's explanation was simple: he went there, he said, to fight racial segregation at its source.
There was some truth to this. As a 16-year-old freshman, Lowenstein caught the eye of U.N.C.'s president, Frank Porter Graham, a prominent Southern liberal, who quickly became his role model and his friend. With Graham's quiet encouragement, Lowen stein led a crusade to integrate the university a full decade before civil rights became a consuming national cause. His successes were modest; the roots of Jim Crow ran deep. But even then, a classmate observed, he "was able to move people with a power that is all but earthly."
Lowenstein also went South to escape his ethnic roots. Short and stocky, with thick glasses, thinning hair and a large nose, he felt a powerful sense of inferiority about his looks and his Jewish identity. At Chapel Hill, he sang in a Presbyterian church, dated only Christian women and tried without success to pledge a fraternity that openly excluded Jews. Years later, Lowenstein told a friend that he had chosen North Carolina in order to erase "any aspect of Jewishness that would keep
other people from getting close to him." He wanted, more than anything else, to be a "normal American." He eventually married Jennifer Lyman, an upper-class Protestant Bostonian, in 1966.
As Mr. Chafe makes clear, however, Lowenstein was incapable of closeness on any serious level. His ethnic insecurities were compounded by a sexual ambivalence that he never fully resolved. Deeply attracted to young men -- mostly "blond, blue-eyed, 6 foot 3 inch" types, a friend recalled -- Lowenstein spent a lifetime acting on the margin of his desires. He dared not acknowledge his homosexual feelings in an era when same-sex relationships were taboo. "One of the only solutions to this dilemma was to avoid intimacy," Mr. Chafe writes. "It was for that reason that Al had so many acquaintances, and for the most part insisted on being with them in groups."
By the time he left Chapel Hill in 1949, Lowenstein's social patterns were deeply ingrained. As a founder of the National Student Association, a liberal, anti-Communist group that would later be exposed as a re cipient of secret financing from the C.I.A., he aggressively courted older public figures like Eleanor Roosevelt, who added luster to his reputation as a man with impeccable connections. (Lowenstein denied any knowledge of the C.I.A. financing, and no hard evidence has been produced to undermine his claim.) At the same time, he became a mentor to dozens of student leaders he met on his cross-country jaunts for the organization. What was missing -- what always seemed to be missing in Lowenstein's life -- were meaningful relationships with men and women his own age, those most likely to demand an intimacy he could not easily provide.
Lowenstein never had a "real" career. His modest needs and substantial inheritance allowed him to operate, in Mr. Chafe's apt description, as an "itinerant director of various crusades for freedom." After earning a law degree at Yale, and receiving a mock award as "the student who graduated . . . having attended the fewest classes," Lowenstein took a series of teaching and administrative jobs at elite universities like Stanford, where he rallied young disciples to his side.
It was Allard Lowenstein, more than anyone else, who awakened white college students to the evils of South African apartheid and recruited hundreds of them for the civil rights struggle in Mississippi in the early 1960's. And it was Lowenstein who later channeled their seething antiwar sentiments into a political movement that unseated a President. But it was also Lowenstein who grabbed full credit for everything he touched, regardless of the contributions of others. "He was sort of what Alice Roosevelt Longworth said about her father, Teddy," a friend of Lowenstein's recalled. "He wanted to be the bride at every wedding, and the corpse at every funeral."
During the Mississippi campaign, he seemed to be everywhere at once, rushing madly from a voter registration drive in Jackson, Miss., to a liberal fund-raiser on Central Park West. Arrested late one night in the Mississippi Delta -- a civil rights worker's worst nightmare -- Lowenstein identified himself as a lawyer, demanded a telephone and loudly placed a collect call to Franklin D. Roosevelt 3d, spelling out the name letter by letter. "Although Roosevelt was barely awake," Mr. Chafe notes, "Lowenstein acted as though he were intensely engaged, telling him, 'No, don't call President Kennedy tonight, wait until tomorrow.' " The police quickly let him go.
Lowenstein's recruits did not fare nearly as well. Their own lives of privilege and security had not prepared them for the overwhelming violence and poverty of everyday black life in Mississippi. Some were traumatized by the experience; others were radicalized. And many grew tired of Lowenstein's claim to leadership, his love of the spotlight and, above all, his philosophy of working within a political system that seemed hopelessly repressive and corrupt.
Lowenstein felt betrayed by his young recruits. He lashed back, charging that the civil rights movement had been captured by left-wing radicals who preached violence and revolutionary change. There was an element of truth to these allegations, though the larger issue seemed to be Lowenstein's loss of stature and control. His relationship with students had always been a one-way street. He expected them to serve, not to question; to follow, not to doubt. When that relationship eroded, he sadly walked away.
But not for long. If the lessons of Mississippi were lost on Lowenstein, his thirst for mainstream politics remained very much alive. A new protest was stirring in the mid-1960's against American military involvement in Vietnam. As it engulfed one college campus after another, Lowenstein answered the call. His goal, as always, was to make liberal democracy work by directing the enormous energy and idealism of the young within the political system. And his plan was to "dump" President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1968 by mobilizing college students to campaign against his re-election in key primary states. "No one wants him out there," Lowenstein claimed, "and all that we have to do is have someone say it. Like, 'the emperor has no clothes.' "
THE problem, as Mr. Chafe makes clear, is that the someone who said it first, Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota, did not seem up to the job. Lowenstein came to view Mr. McCarthy as lazy, erratic and uninspiring. He supported him only because his personal choice, Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York, a man he truly admired, wavered for months before entering the Presidential race. In the meantime, Lowenstein returned to his old haunts -- the college campuses -- to recruit an army of well-scrubbed volunteers ("be clean for Gene") for Mr. McCarthy's New Hampshire primary campaign. "We were there because Al had brought us there," a student recalled. "He had asked an awful lot of kids to . . . abandon the craziness and fringe stuff and jump into electoral politics."
Mr. McCarthy's strong showing against long odds in New Hampshire led to the President's retirement. Mr. Chafe is largely correct in describing Lowenstein as the "genius" behind "one of the most remarkable political achievements of contemporary American history." But Lowenstein soiled that achievement, in the eyes of many antiwar Democrats, by continuing to support Gene McCarthy in public while working behind the scenes to secure the Presidential nomination for Bobby Kennedy, a more electable candidate. Even worse, perhaps, was the "almost ghoulish" attempt by Lowenstein to draft Senator Edward M. Kennedy for President following Robert Kennedy's assassination in June 1968. ("Uh, uh," fumed the civil rights leader Charles Evers, "you're not going to do it to that family a third time.") Once again, Mr. Chafe maintains, a Lowenstein crusade had combined "principled advocacy" with "manipulation."
Lowenstein eventually endorsed the Democratic nominee, Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey, despite an earlier vow to oppose Humphrey at all costs. As a political pragmatist, Lowenstein clearly viewed the Vice President as the lesser of two evils in a campaign where the Republican candidate was Richard Nixon. And more important, he needed the support of a united Democratic Party in his own bid for a Congressional seat in a largely Republican district on Long Island. When Lowenstein won that race, he became an elected public official for the first and only time in his life.
It proved a difficult fit. The House of Representatives has its own folkways based on courtesy, compromise, deference and team play. These were not the strong suits of a brash, fast-talking individualist like Lowenstein, who thrived on quick action and the glow of center stage. As hard as he tried, the new Congressman had trouble focusing on the immediate needs of his district. What mattered more to humanity, the jet noise at Kennedy International Airport or the famine in Biafra? Why waste time on the garbage problem in Great Neck when the war was still raging in Vietnam?
Lowenstein was defeated for re-election after one term, partly because the Republican-controlled New York State Legislature had gerrymandered his district away from him. He responded, almost reflexively, by promising another crusade to register the millions of young people recently enfranchised under the 26th Amendment, which lowered the voting age to 18. If properly mobilized, said Lowenstein, their ballots could forge a progressive landslide that would end the Vietnam War, bring social justice to minorities and force Richard Nixon from the White House in 1972.
The crusade flopped. As he traveled about the country, Lowenstein discovered a painful truth: most young people did not resemble the well-bred, idealistic students he had sent to do battle in Mississippi and New Hampshire. They had little interest in politics, even less in a decidedly liberal agenda. What concerned them was the deteriorating economy, the explosion of violent crime and the "unfairness" of affirmative action programs designed to aid minorities. As a result, the young people who registered to vote were more likely to cast a ballot for Richard Nixon than for his liberal opponent. Dumping this President would require far more than Allard Lowenstein could ever deliver, as the 1972 Nixon landslide victory over George McGovern made embarrassingly clear.
The 1970's were a nightmare for him. His repeated campaigns for Congress -- five successive defeats in three different districts -- made him look like Harold Stassen in liberal garb. His wife left him in 1976, unable to take the endless political grind. Worst of all, perhaps, was the demise of Lowenstein's once optimistic vision of the United States, a vision now clouded by notions of conspiracy and foul play.
Convinced that the truth behind Robert Kennedy's assassination had been covered up by sinister forces, he linked that killing, in his less lucid moments, to a larger plot involving the murders of John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. And the more he brooded over his own election defeats, the more he began to see himself as a victim of the same conspiracy to rob the country of its liberal dreams. It became an obsession with Lowenstein, a friend recalled, and "people who had known him for a long period of time sort of shook their heads."
By 1980, Lowenstein seemed as marginal as the liberalism he had so passionately espoused. He drifted from one job to another, working at the United Nations, at a law firm in Manhattan and as a consultant to the moribund Presidential campaign of Edward Kennedy. Though Mr. Chafe says that Lowenstein finally had begun to face his personal demons -- "he may have been almost ready to stop running" -- the evidence is very thin. Indeed, Lowenstein's recurring fear at this time was of a violent death at the hands of an assassin. He even began to write out detailed instructions for his funeral.
As fate would have it, Lowenstein's last act on earth was a charitable one, an attempt to help a troubled former disciple named Dennis Sweeney, who in 1963 had left Stanford at Lowenstein's urging to join the civil rights struggle in Mississippi. Like so many northern students, Mr. Sweeney had been badly scarred by the experience. He returned home in a state of depressed exhaustion, completely burned out.
"According to psychiatrists," Mr. Chafe writes, "Sweeney was the victim of adult-onset schizophrenia, a disease that strikes an individual entering his 20's." He attached himself to political fringe groups, plunged deeply into the drug culture and began hearing strange sounds and voices deep inside his head. Convinced that a C.I.A. dentist had planted transmitters in his mouth, Mr. Sweeney filed down his crowns and fillings to nubs. When the voices continued, he blamed Lowenstein and begged him to stop.
On a bleak March afternoon in 1980, Dennis Sweeney came to Lowenstein's law office in New York. Old movement people had already abandoned this frightening man, but Lowenstein refused to turn him away. He felt compassion for Mr. Sweeney -- and perhaps some responsibility for his awful plight. Their meeting lasted less than two minutes. Then Mr. Sweeney pulled out a gun and fired seven shots at the person whose voice kept echoing in his head. Allard Lowenstein died later that day, at the age of 51. "He was killed," wrote his good friend and political opposite William F. Buckley Jr., "by one of his children."
But the Lowenstein brood is very large. In Congress today, the list of his disciples includes Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, Joe Lieberman of Connecticut and Bill Bradley of New Jersey, and Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts, to name a few. All of them are helping to forge a new liberal agenda, and their debt to Allard Lowenstein is truly immense. At his best, he taught them that injustice must be confronted, that one person can make a difference, that meaningful reform demands serious sacrifice and that the political process really does work.
"As you go along," Lowenstein said in 1966, "you build a life . . . in which you do many different kinds of things. But it all has a common denominator that gives it some sense, some direction -- the sense that your total activity is going to make a better situation for people to live in. . . . The question should be, is it worth trying to do, not can it be done? . . . You don't just set goals and when you reach them, find that they equal happiness. . . . Within the quest itself, much of the fullness of life exists."

HEADLINE: Bushwhacked

BYLINE: By Joe Queenan; Joe Queenan is the author of "Imperial Caddy: The Rise of Dan Quayle in America and the Decline and Fall of Practically Everything Else."

 BODY:

HELL OF A RIDE
Backstage at the White House Follies, 1989-1993.
By John Podhoretz.
249 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $21. 
 EVERY year, after a team from the National Football Conference massacres an opponent from the American Football Conference, publishers blitz the nation with a bunch of snap autobiographies written by the winners' head coach, quarterback and outside linebackers. But publishers usually refrain from blitzing the nation with books written by the losers because, frankly, Americans don't think there's a whole lot to be learned from losers.
This is where politics differs from football. Losers, ranging from Richard Nixon to Gary Hart to Jimmy Carter, have been known to churn out reams of material after their careers came to an abrupt end, and occasionally the books are surprisingly informative, even readable. A case in point is John Podhoretz's "Hell of a Ride: Backstage at the White House Follies, 1989-1993." The book has a deceptive title; Mr. Podhoretz -- a conservative journalist who is the son of Norman Podhoretz, the editor of Commentary magazine and a founding father of neoconservatism, and Midge Decter, the writer, editor and founding mother of neoconservatism -- worked at the White House for only the last few months of the Reagan Administration and the first few months of the Bush Administration. So, technically speaking, his behind-the-scenes account of the fall of George Bush is the equivalent of the memoir of a second-string cornerback who retired from the team in 1989 but stayed in touch with the boys after he left. Yet Mr. Podhoretz's furiously sarcastic account of the way he thinks Ronald Reagan's revolution was betrayed by George Bush may well be the most interesting book to come out of Washington recently. Of course, when your main competition is Vice President Al Gore, this is not saying a whole lot.
Cleverly, Mr. Podhoretz has chosen to depict the collapse of the Bush Presidency not from the point of view of such high-and-mighty usual suspects as Richard Darman and James Baker, but from the perspective of the psychologically devastated, middle-level neocon intellectuals who occupied the White House for 12 years. Career opportunities for unemployed, anonymous neocon intellectuals may be hard to come by in Washington for the next few years. "Hell of a Ride" is thus the tale of Young Republicans Facing the Soup Line for the first time in their lives, a group for which many Americans will feel a tad less empathy than the author.
"Hell of a Ride" has one major objective: to put to rest the notion that the Republican Party is a monolithic conservative force and, in the process, to smash the equally foolish notion that the repudiation of George Bush by the American people constituted a repudiation of Ronald Reagan. With its savage attacks on Mr. Darman, whom Mr. Podhoretz calls "a worm," Nicholas Brady ("a dimwit"), Mr. Baker, John Sununu, Samuel Skinner and the outgoing President himself, the book perfectly captures the fury that young conservatives feel toward Mr. Bush, whom they view as a bumbler, a dissembler and a traitor to the cause.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Podhoretz loathes all of the white-shoe Republicans and contends that Mr. Bush could have won the 1992 election had he not reneged on his no-new-taxes promise of 1988, or had he ever given the American people the slightest reassurance that he cared about, or even understood, their problems. As presented by Mr. Podhoretz, one White House staffer explains:
"Somebody -- you heard it was Marlin Fitzwater -- came up with the notion that the President could bolster consumer confidence by going to a J. C. Penney near Camp David and buying some socks. You knew the President didn't even carry money with him and hadn't for years; his personal assistant must have handed it to him in the car. The whole event had a Marie Antoinette, 'Let them buy socks' quality to it."
From Mr. Podhoretz's perspective, 1992 was a fluke, and far from believing that the Republicans should swing to the center to woo back the voting public, he argues that it should swing farther to the right. In his view, the Reagan revolution has merely been interrupted by an "unearned political opportunity" handed to the Democrats by the ineffectual Mr. Bush.
"Hell of a Ride" is not without its faults: Mr. Podhoretz's wisecracks are nowhere near as funny as he thinks they are, and his unmodulated tone of sneering condescension can become wearing. The writing is heavy on neocon malarkey like "hubris" and "Gnomish Gnostic" -- Bill Buckley Lite -- punctuated with cutting-edge inner-city patois like "dissing" that clearly has no place in a book written by a Republican. Moreover, in a book that is largely about networking on the Titanic, the author shows himself to be a major networker himself, actually going out of his way to praise the cerebrally challenged Dan Quayle for his campaigning.
Nevertheless, Mr. Podhoretz's you-are-there diary of an Administration coming apart at the seams works quite well, and has an oddly bipartisan appeal (liberals will be enthralled by details of the self-destructive tendencies of the Bush White House). But the book also issues a warning: that young Reaganites view themselves as cheated rather than defeated, as if the Buffalo Bills had lost the last three Super Bowls because their kinder, gentler quarterback went into the tank. The Bills, it should be noted, keep coming back. So will the Reaganites.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 66; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1224 words

HEADLINE: FORBIDDEN SUN, AND SIN, COMMUNIST STYLE

BYLINE: By Peter Passell; Peter Passell writes about economics for The Times.

 BODY:
The house Champagne is Moet, the lobby Muzak has a vaguely disco beat, and the topless blonde at the pool is reading Danielle Steele in German. The scene might be in Sardinia, the Costa Brava or a Club Med in the Seychelles.
But the Spanish-operated Hotel Melia is either much closer to home or much farther, depending on how you look at it. For this is the glitziest of resorts in Varadero, Cuba's trendiest of beach towns. It's just a stone's throw from Key West -- yet off limits to American pleasure travelers under what Congress solemnly calls the Trading With the Enemy Act. 
 Canadians, Europeans and Latin Americans bearing precious dollars arrive on charters by the tens of thousands each year. American journalists like me, along with academic researchers, artists and Cuban-Americans with relatives in the old country, take Marazul Tours' thrice-weekly shuttle from Miami to Havana. No assigned seats or pineapple drinks with maraschino cherries, but it's just 45 minutes by jet.
Fidel welcomes American tourists, too, even if they have to come through a third country (Toronto, Montreal and Cancun are the most convenient jumping-off spots). Spending money for fun or profit in Cuba is against United States law. But unless you flaunt a "Che Lives" T-shirt while going through customs, the chance of getting caught is roughly equal to the risk of being abducted by aliens.
The primary lure, typically, is the idea of spending a luxurious week by the surf for less than the price of the HoJo in Bakersfield. But once you arrive, there's a far more surreal attraction: seeing this hard-currency chic layered over 1990's Cuba, a socialist workers' paradise that is itself layered over what was once the sin and sun capital of the hemisphere.
Varadero had been a weekend getaway for rich Havanans and the du Pont family (which bought most of the land in the 1930's). This peninsula some two hours east of Havana features blue-blue waters, nice, if a bit rocky, beaches, even a golf course left over from when Cuba had a leisure class. What's more, the taxis are air-conditioned, the tube carries HBO (pirated from the satellite), and the waiters deliver the pepperoni pizza with flair.
Visitors not inclined to take cha-cha lessons alongside an artificial waterfall or to rent a microskirted companion for the night will no doubt prefer Cayo Largo, Cuba's bid for a more adventurous class of snowbird. Getting there from Havana requires a half-hour flight by Cubana Airlines Yak-40, a vehicle with all the amenities of a Murmansk city bus. But it's worth the trip: this sliver of coral in the Caribbean features human-scale accommodations, iguanas that wait patiently for handouts and 15 miles of the prettiest, emptiest, talcum beaches on the planet.
Cayo Largo is catching on: there's a nonstop charter each week from Milan. And the reefs just a mile offshore are drawing rave reviews from scuba divers jaded by the Cayman Islands and Cozumel. But limited development (only 300 rooms now, another 300 in the works) should keep this little jewel of a resort unpolished a while longer.
Beach charms notwithstanding, to me the indisputable numero uno attraction in Cuba is Havana, where, as Irving Berlin wrote, "Dark-eyed Stellas light their feller's panatellas." Havana was a fortress colonial town that burst beyond its walls when Washington was still a swamp. In the 1950's, it looked more like a cross between Buenos Aires and Miami than the capital of a Caribbean backwater. Now, with a population of two million, it still does.
The heavily wooded estates of Little Lake and the suburban sprawl of the Vedado district are intact, though the buildings are now largely in the hands of diplomats, Government agencies and dollar-only shops selling Bausch & Lomb contact lenses, Swatch watches and Cohiba cigars (Cuba's best). And at least from a distance, the high-rise hotels that once lured hedonists from the tamer pleasure domes of Miami Beach seem unchanged.
Casa Marina, the brothel that in the carnal days of Fulgencio Batista specialized in 13-year-olds from the countryside, has long since closed. So have the casinos, hushed temples to high-stakes gambling controlled by businessman Meyer Lansky with a little help from his friend and partner, Batista. But it doesn't require much imagination to recapture the sense of the bad old city.
The Hotel Nacional, which by no coincidence closely resembles the Breakers in Palm Beach, has been restored to its 1955 opulence -- the year Pan American Airlines took over the management and Eartha Kitt headlined the floor show. The Hotel Riviera, the mob's last and most ambitious attempt to eclipse Las Vegas in glorious excess, still features acres of marble, plate glass and Naugahyde -- not to mention an army of ladies of the night camped on the steps. Lansky's 20th-floor suite at the Riviera (stripped, alas, of memorabilia) is available, for $200 a night.
What's more, the Floridita, the handsome bar in Old Havana where Ernest Hemingway got pickled each night on a dozen daiquiris, still beckons. The daiquiris, incidentally, are primo. It is a mystery, though, how anyone, even a Nobel Prize-winning boozer, could down that much sugar in a sitting.
The biggest blast from the past is to be found at the Tropicana, a gigantic open-air nightclub in the suburbs with a floor show that hasn't changed much since the 1940's: Girls! Girls! Girls! in fantastic feathers and frills, the musical extravaganza is good, clean PG-rated sex. Big spenders -- said to be mostly Mexicans and Venezuelans -- can even take home snapshots of themselves leering at the string bikinis.
HOW DOES ALL THIS PLEASURE-seeking-as-usual square with Fidel's self-proclaimed role as the last true prophet of Marx? Better than you might expect.
Judging by the smiles Cubans give strangers on the street, and the ease with which couples neck openly along Havana's seafront boulevard, the dictatorship of the proletariat that transformed Eastern Europe into perpetual Sunday school never made much headway against Cubans' sensuality and grace. And while Castro rules absolutely, he is no Kim Il Sung. Indeed, Fidel must be the world's only Dear Leader whose portrait is nowhere in evidence.
"Socialism or Death" slogans may still be plastered over the entrances to neighborhood bodegas, and the Museum of the Revolution (cleverly housed in Batista's former palace) may still feature the T-34 Russian tank that Castro claims to have personally commanded at the Bay of Pigs. But the rhetoric of the Ministry of Revolutionary Orientation seems as inspired by John Lennon as by V. I. Lenin: across from the "Resist, Fight and Win" billboard is one proclaiming that "Only Love Builds."
Cuba's economic distress is obvious from the collapsing buildings, rolling blackouts and endless lines at bus stops. But here there are no Jeeps loaded with teen-agers prowling for human prey. Nor, in this revolution where literacy, medical care and full bellies got high priority, is there a sense of overwhelming, grinding poverty.
In fact, the harsh realities of street life tugged far less at my conscience than in, say, Rio or Mexico City. And the shortage of everything sold for pesos even offers certain advantages: Havana is surely the only great metropolis without rush hour traffic.

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 22; Column 3; Education Life Supplement

LENGTH: 1451 words

HEADLINE: Hail the Instant Coursepack!

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS

 BODY:
SOMEWHERE on the academic continuum between lugging thick tomes to class and using a notebook computer to tap into electronic library collections, a new era of textbooks has taken hold: the coursepack.
Where many professors once relied on a principal textbook, hefty, hard-covered and selling for more than $50, more and more now rely on "custom-published" compilations of material that are churned out by the campus print shop, nearby copy shops and sometimes even by a traditional textbook publisher. These coursepacks, or course packets, as they are called on many campuses, are simply collections of essays, speeches, newspaper and magazine articles and chapters or excerpts from formal textbooks, clipped together or spiral-bound under a flimsy cover.
 
Average Cost Is $20
 Lighter than a hard-cover text, and generally lighter on a student's wallet as well, these bundles average about $20 in cost. But their greatest virtue is the diversity of voices and the immediate relevance that they add to course readings. 
 Students of modern European history, for example, who rely on a textbook are not likely to find a discussion this fall of the recent stumbling toward the Maastricht treaty on European unity. But a teacher who prepared a coursepack could have included recent press coverage, speeches and analyses from European leaders, as well as recent election results in France and Germany.
"You can have more focused readings," said Prof. Michael Emery of California State University at Northridge, whose textbook "Readings in Mass Communication" (co-edited by Ted Curtis Smythe, published by William C. Brown in 1972) allows a teacher to design a coursepack from among more than 150 articles. "In late July," Professor Emery said, "I was putting together the menu of articles we had available, and I read an article in the July/August issue of Mother Jones. Within a week it was included in our menu and available for the fall semester."
Stan Stoga, executive editor of the publisher Brown & Benchmark, said that in a custom-designed book the readings could be arranged in whatever order the instructor wanted and the book could be in a campus bookstore within six weeks after it was ordered. The company charges 55 an article, so a collection of 15 articles would cost $8.25.
Even more ambitious custom publishing comes from McGraw-Hill's Primis operation, which assembles and delivers custom-designed textbooks drawn from electronic libraries in more than 20 disciplines, from literature to criminal justice to corporate finance. A paper catalogue is available, and all the selections can also be found electronically through the Internet computer network. Robert D. Lynch, the vice president of Primis, said these custom-designed textbooks were being used on more than 800 campuses in the United States, Canada and Australia.
 
Most Sell Coursepacks
 Some university bookstores say custom publishing accounts for 20 percent of course material, which includes textbook sales. The National Association of College Stores, a trade group based in Oberlin, Ohio, said a majority of its 3,000 members sold coursepacks, and at least a third of all college students had used them in at least one class.
For as long as there has been photocopying, students have brought home copies of reading materials, after pumping coins into a machine in the library. As copying became more widespread, with departments installing machines and copy shops opening near campuses, faculty members began assembling their own "books."
Now the coursepack has become institutionalized. At many campuses the bookstore circulates forms, asking faculty members for reading materials they would like to use. They then contact the publishers to obtain permission to copy the materials -- in return for a
royalty -- and assemble the "books."
"The principle of asking for permission is now widely accepted by bookstores and copy shops," said Carol Risher, vice president for copyrights at the Association of American Publishers.
In suits over illegal copying and copyright violations over the years, the association has bludgeoned professors, university administrators and copy shops into compliance with copyright law. In a 1991 case in Federal District Court in Manhattan, for instance, Kinko's copy shops were ordered to pay $1.875 million in damages and costs for violating copyrights; in an earlier case against New York University and eight faculty members there, the university administration agreed to accept responsibility for educating professors about copyright and copying procedures.
If students generally like the more personalized and diverse readings of the coursepack, as well as the lower price, and if teachers welcome the opportunity to shape their materials, publishers surely have mixed feelings. Even when royalties are paid, the packets cut directly into textbook sales.
 
'Their Own Appeal'
 "The build-your-own-textbook phenomenon is here to stay," said Michael V. Needham, president of the college division at McGraw-Hill. "There will always be people who want to use textbooks, but coursepacks have their own appeal."
If coursepacks cut into textbook sales, they are nonetheless a great deal better, from publishers' and authors' point of view, than the sale of used books. New developments and staying competitive with rival books are important factors in publishing, but the driving force behind the regularly scheduled new editions of many textbooks is to make used copies obsolete.
"Used books are a big business," said Mitchell Stephens, whose "Broadcast News," the best-selling textbook in its field since publication in 1980, was recently published in a third edition by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Sales of used texts account for more than $500 million a year, roughly a fifth of the textbook market. And every one of those dollars is lost to the new-textbook market.
No wonder, said Professor Stephens, chairman of the Department of Journalism and Mass Communication at N.Y.U., that "with a reasonably successful book, publishers like a new edition every three or four years."
The long-distance champion of multi-edition books may be "Accounting Principles" (South-Western Publishing), by Philip Fess and Carl Warren, in its 17th edition with more than eight million copies sold domestically. The book began life in 1903 as a pamphlet by James Oscar McKinsey, an accounting professor. In 1935 it became a proper textbook. In its latest incarnation, "Accounting Principles" costs $60 and is 1,000 pages long. The publisher is pleased to sell 96 different supplemental teaching materials, including computer software, a CD-ROM disk for multimedia computers and conventional worksheets.
 
'We're Only Half Done'
 "When I first started there was just a textbook, an instructor's manual and another manual for testing," Professor Fess said in a recent interview. "Now we provide instructors with guides as well as solution manuals, to help with lectures; with an annotated edition, with notes in the margins including real-world examples; with accounting problems on computer software problems, and we have study guides for students. When we're done with revising the textbook, we're only half done."
Second is the redoubtable "Economics," by Paul Samuelson (McGraw-Hill), first published in 1948 and now in its 14th edition; more than six and a half million copies have been sold in the United States.
In recent years, however, it has been surpassed as the economics best seller by "Economics: Principles, Problems and Policies," by Campbell R. McConnell (McGraw-Hill), in its 12th edition with five million copies sold domestically; 500,000 more have been sold in Russia, McGraw-Hill says.
Whether these behemoths will ever be challenged has a lot to do with the evolution of electronic media and their acceptance. Will "students find their way, sodas in hand, to comfortable chairs at electronic ordering stations from which they will select the already electronically bundled materials for each course?" asked James Lichtenberg, a vice president of the Association of American Publishers, last year in Change magazine. "These may be downloaded onto computer disks, printed on paper, or sent directly to their dorm-room computers, with payment automatically deducted from their student debit card."
Or will books -- tactile, satisfying embodiments of knowledge -- always have a place on campus? "The current changes are already breaking the back of the book, cracking its binding," mused Professor Stephens. "Do these rigidly linear arrangements of words represent the best way to transmit information? Or will something better emerge?"

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Stiff Premium To Travel Alone

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
DIANA L. DIAMOND of Palo Alto, Calif., a hospital administrator, signed up with Globus Tours for a trip to India last summer. The price of the 19-day trip, with air fare and land arrangements, was $3,530. This, as is typical of tour operators' offerings, was the price for one person based on the traveler's sharing a room with a companion. For Ms. Diamond to make the trip by herself, she would have to pay $1,026 additional as a "single supplement."
Although a premium of 29 percent seems stiff, it is not unusual. Sometimes, as in this case, it is that percentage of the air and land charges; other times it applies to land arrangements only. 
 Exceptions to the single supplement do occur, particularly where people expect to be housed dormitory-style or in other situations lacking privacy, as on an adventure trip. Underlying the premium is the charge tour operators must pay to hotels for putting one person into a room that two people might use, who would add to the hotel's revenue by ordering drinks for two and other extras and tipping more.
Some tour operators and organizations, Club Med among them, will double up single travelers at random to enable them to avoid the extra charge, and that is what Ms. Diamond decided was a solution. She asked her travel agent to have Globus find another single traveler with whom she might share a room. She said she had done that with other companies, Orient Flexi Pax, for instance. The agent responded that Globus would not find her a roommate, and when she called the company directly, it understandably would not divulge the names of others who would be on the trip so Ms. Diamond could make inquiries.
However, the Globus agent said that if Ms. Diamond were traveling with Globus's sister organization, Cosmos Tourama, which offers less expensive tours, it would find a roommate. But since Cosmos did not offer a parallel trip, she paid the extra charge under protest and took the trip to India, which she said she greatly enjoyed.
John Martinen, president of Globus and Cosmos, with headquarters in Littleton, Colo., said Globus at one time also paired up single travelers of the same sex, but stopped eight or nine years ago "because so often people did not like their roommates and we had to find single accommodations for them during the tour."
"It was not practical at the first-class level," he said. By contrast, he said, at Cosmos's budget level, "they are willing to live with the rooommate." The matching is done by the company, based on gender only, without regard to smoking or other tastes. If Cosmos cannot find a roommate as requested, it will waive the single supplement, Mr. Martinen said.
 
Finding Roommates
 Tours under the two company names differ in hotel quality, by numbers of meals offered and in other respects, he said. For a price comparison, he cited 19-day tours of Europe in the 1994 catalogue. With Globus, the land arrangements would cost $1,858 a person in double occupancy, with a $483 single supplement, about 26 percent; with Cosmos, the cost would be $1,313 in double occupancy, with a $300 single supplement, about 23 percent.
Mr. Martinen said that his companies' single supplement consisted only of the extra amount the company had to pay the hotel to put one person in a room, plus the travel agent's commission on this amount. The trip Ms. Diamond took shows a high single supplement on a percentage basis because the hotels used in India, Bangkok and Hong Kong were luxurious and less competitively priced than those in Europe, Mr. Martinen said.
Eli Milbaur, managing director of Orient Flexi Pax Tours in New York, confirmed that his company would seek roommates of the same sex if asked. He estimated that they succeeded 80 percent of the time but if the search failed by the time the trip drew near, the company would give a full refund of the tour price to the client. Orient Flexi Pax sends 10,000 clients a year to China, the Orient, Australia, New Zealand and Fiji. For a two-week trip to China, he said, the land arrangements in a deluxe hotel would cost $1,599 for a traveler in double occupancy; the single supplement would be $499, or 31 percent.
Another example, Funway Holidays Funjet in Milwaukee, a tour and charter operator that has 800,000 passengers a year, always charges a single supplement, according to Stephanie Hart, a spokeswoman, and does not seek roommates on request. Ms. Hart gave as a price example a London-Paris trip of seven nights. For airfare and a first-class hotel, one person in double occupancy would pay $1,210; one person in a room alone could pay $1,540, or 27 percent more.
Ms. Hart said the price for the single-room ticket included the operator's markup as well as the hotel's extra charge.
 
A Bargain for Two?
 Of course, a simple change in marketing could disguise Ms. Diamond's 29 percent premium. The tour could be sold on the basis of the price for a single person. "The price for this tour is $4,556," this approach would say. "A second person in the room will pay only $2,509." The total for a couple would be the same, as would the price for one person, but the phrase "single supplement," which begets so much hostility, would disappear.
Bill Hanley, executive vice president for sales and marketing for Forte Hotel chain, said he believed the tour industry had always predicated its pricing on double occupancy and theorized that it stemmed from the days when trips to Europe were made by ship and two to a cabin was the usual arrangement.
In contrast, he and other hotel officials said, hotels work in terms of single occupancy: What they need to earn from the room to provide for the mortgage, the heat and electricity, the taxes, the staff, profit and so forth. Then an amount is added on that represents the cost for bedlinens for a second bed, extra towels, more shampoo. This may be $10 on a $90 room.
Rooms in the Forte Travelodge motels cost $5 or so above the base price when two people use them. For 1993 so far, Mr. Hanley said, the average rate paid in his company's Travelodge motels is $44; for a single occupancy it averages $39 and for a couple $46, which includes surcharges for such things as a rollaway bed. Like other hotel officials interviewed for this article, he contended that people traveling together got a bargain, not that people traveling alone paid disproportionately. But if the two people traveling together have separate travel budgets, the cost comes out to $23 each.
However, Mr. Hanley said, despite the tough economic times, the incidence of business travelers from the same company who double up to save has "hardly budged" from the zero point.
The social mores for business travel are thus different than for leisure travel, he said, although both groups are "buying down" to a less expensive category to save money.
One result of this that can perhaps work to the benefit of single travelers is that hotels at the high end of the range are offering more and more special deals, and nothing prevents a solo traveler from bargaining a better rate -- say, perhaps, a singles rate.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2479 words

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Dancing on a High Wire Of Inspired Lunacy

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
Leonardo and his Mona Lisa argue endlessly, bound together in querulous domesticity over the years he takes to paint her portrait. A crooner named Orfeo sings "I'll See You Again" to the housemaid who is his Eurydice. A graffiti artist escapes over the Berlin wall, a man with a stuffed chicken finds that you can go home again, and a Greek-American contralto named Dagmar Onassis, the illegitimate daughter of Maria Callas and Aristotle Onassis, reduces a spellbound audience to simultaneous tears and laughter.
Welcome to some of the many worlds of John Kelly, actor, singer, director, designer -- and performance artist-turned-star. This week, Mr. Kelly will perform on the largest and most formal stage of his New York career in his "Light Shall Lift Them," which will run for four performances starting Wednesday at the Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The new multimedia work, which is subtitled "The Parallel Lives of Jean Cocteau and Barbette" and is part of BAM's Next Wave festival, chronicles the life of Vander Clyde, a young American who, performing as a transvestite aerialist named Barbette, became the toast of Paris in the 1920's and an inspiration to Jean Cocteau. 
 Performance art has become an established part of the New York theater scene in the decade or so since the 39-year-old Mr. Kelly began to perform in the small clubs on the Lower East Side where the unruly heir to the traditions of Dadaist theater and 1960's Happenings was born. He is now poised to claim his place among established performers like Eric Bogosian, Reno and Blue Man Group. But for many he continues to personify the peculiar, scruffy magic of performance, as the genre is sometimes called.
Mr. Kelly does not portray characters like Egon Schiele, around whom he built an award-winning production called "Pass the Blutwurst, Bitte" in 1986. He also does not play himself. At his best, Mr. Kelly exists in the moment of pure imaginative creativity midway between the two realities of the everyday and the life of the theater. Describing Mr. Kelly's "odd, tenuous magic" in The Washington Post, the critic Alan M. Kriegsman wrote, "No sooner does he take the stage than one senses his comfort with it and us, and his feeling that this is his world, which we are invited to share."
In the role of Dagmar, resplendent in an emerald-green gown and overweening beehive, the pale, slightly built Mr. Kelly both captures and comments on the essence of performing, giving himself up to the character with the abandon of those who lose their natural timidity only on the stage. Dagmar, who is modeled on Maria Callas, one of Mr. Kelly's heroes, is a foolish mortal whose singing of Bellini, Mahler and Weill, never wholly beautiful or ridiculous, brings her and her audience a brush with the gods.
"It's the lie that tells the truth," Mr. Kelly said, quoting Cocteau, another hero, during a recent conversation in his Manhattan loft. The space might have been a set for one of his pieces; it is a dimly lighted palace of shabby Baroque splendor filled with artifacts left behind by a previous tenant. "I think there's a lot to that. It's all about looking at the same stuff in a different way.
"If somebody is really in touch with the way that they are going to say something, then it's like it's being said for the first time. I think that should be every artist's goal. To get rid of the extraneous stuff, you must get as much to your essential feeling about something as possible and then find a way of saying it clearly. Sometimes that's by doing it on the oblique."
Mr. Kelly's latest piece addresses, by indirection, reality, illusion and the loneliness of the artist. A small-town boy born in Round Rock, Tex., Vander Clyde became Barbette, for Cocteau the personification of art. Mr. Kelly plays both roles in the piece, which has a score by Bill Obrecht and also stars Robert LaFosse, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, and Mary Elizabeth Poore, a soprano.
The 90-minute work begins with Vander's Texas childhood and takes him through his first circus performances -- as part of a trio of aerialist sisters -- and on to Paris, fame and finally an embittered, arthritic old age. With his usual economy of means and with the help of 16-millimeter films by Anthony Chase, Mr. Kelly provides a multitude of settings, including the backyard where Vander does his first high-wire walking on his mother's galvanized clothesline, an ocean liner and the Paris theater where Barbette performs. Throughout, the piece incorporates images from Cocteau films and Man Ray's photographs of Barbette.
Mr. Kelly's own youthful awakening to the theater occurred when he was a child growing up in Jersey City, N.J., with a chance viewing of Galina Ulanova performing "The Dying Swan" on "The Ed Sullivan Show." Soon after, he saw a film of "Romeo and Juliet" with Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev on television. On the radio, he had discovered classical music. His adolescence was also illuminated by the singing of Joni Mitchell and performances by members of the Cockettes, a San Francisco drag troupe he had seen with a high school friend in New York City.
ONE OF FIVE CHILDREN BORN to an insurance salesman and his wife, Mr. Kelly was a solitary child who was good at drawing and who loved the quiet of treetops and closets. He thinks he always knew he was gay.
"There was pressure to play sports, to be a 'guy,' to be aggressive," he said. "All that stuff didn't seem particularly interesting to me. I was told certain things about myself before I even knew what they were, by -- well, I wouldn't call them friends, in school. I think the way that young men are raised in America is kind of rotten and limiting."
After high school he went to New York to study ballet and performed with the all-male Original Trockadero Gloxinia Ballet Company, whose founder, Larry Ree, he has cited as an early influence. But Mr. Kelly was too old to master ballet technique. A long-building rage overtook him and found its expression in drag performing. "Then, it was a really nasty kind of thing to do," he recalled. "But it was also beautiful.
"And it was just about creating illusion. It wasn't about life style. It was kind of punk. Dagmar now is more elegant, but early on it was torn slips and stockings and teased-out wigs. Dark eye sockets."
Mr. Kelly left dance, with a finality he now regrets, enrolled in the Parsons School of Design and got the first of many waiter jobs in Greenwich Village restaurants. After two years he quit Parsons and worked on his art by himself, painting and drawing in his studio apartment to "wild orchestral music."
It was during a job sketching at a gay bar called the Anvil that he found himself as an artist. "This guy in drag, Tanya Ransom, was lip-synching Nina Hagen. But it was not girly-girl. He was like a banshee or siren. And Nina Hagen is pretty intense music, so it seemed like the music was coming out of his body. It was a total physical thing. I just said, 'My God, that's where I need to go.'
"I started doing that with Callas. Then one night in 1980 -- can I say this? I guess I can -- I was tripping, and I lip-synched a Callas aria in front of the mirror in my apartment and totally mesmerized myself because it was so perfect."
As he worked on it, the routine became almost choreographed. "I would orchestrate the breathing so it would register as if the sound was coming out of my body." So began his "inhabiting" of Callas, as later he would inhabit Schiele and would understand instinctively how completely Barbette took hold of Cocteau's imagination.
Mr. Kelly had long been drawn to the work of the flamboyant French writer and film maker. His introduction to Schiele occurred in art school. Inhabiting the Viennese Expressionist artist was not about being enticed into the mirror and self-portraiture. Instead, using characteristic poses and imagery, he "was grasping definitive or telling moments and giving them two-dimensional life via the accumulated recording of detail, like a puzzle," Mr. Kelly wrote in the Movement Research Performance Journal.
"And this 'visual diary' was highly active. I would find a pose and, to robust orchestral or meandering solo instrumental music, go on a journey of self-confrontation and exploration. Internal combustion with a residue. Egon Schiele, as my hero, pointed the way -- I attempted to go through his open door but to emerge into a place of my own."
Mark Russell, director of Performance Space 122, remembers an early Kelly act at that Lower East Side theater as "blowing everybody away. His choices were so right."
P.S. 122 has been a center for performance art. "Outlaws, renegades and the disenfranchised end up in this indefinable little category called performance," Mr. Russell says. "Performance allows them to define their work on their own terms. If John had come up through theater, he would have been told, 'You have to write things down, honey.' Or that he needed a director. Or that you could be a performer but you couldn't write.
"Performance allows the rules to be defined on the artist's own terms, with a slow process of building up craft to make it work. And as performance developed and people understood more of what was being said, artists got accepted back into the world from which they had been shut out. I consider John as making theater pieces now."
Many of Mr. Kelly's earliest performances were on the tiny back-room stage of Bobby Bradley's Pyramid Club in the East Village, a proving ground for many of today's best-known performance artists. His audiences were not always mesmerized, however, and one night he had to fight off a patron enraged by his lip-synching of "Sempre Libera" by jabbing at him with a plastic lightning bolt he had pulled from the ceiling decorations.
"People were there to dance and drink," Mr. Kelly said. "But when you grabbed the audience, it was incredible. The energy was so high, and it was such a point of communication. They should teach club performance at Sarah Lawrence and N.Y.U."
Nearly all of Mr. Kelly's later pieces grew out of 10-minute versions done at the Pyramid. Anything seemed possible. Anthony Chase, a longtime collaborator who created the film segments for "Light Shall Lift Them," began to work with Mr. Kelly there in 1983. "There was something very seductive about his way with the audience," Mr. Chase said. "He was so charming."
One of their first efforts was "The Onassis Story," an 8-millimeter black-and-white film in which Mr. Kelly played Dagmar, a loyal young fan, an elegant Callas and, by winding socks around his ankles and donning several pairs of gloves, Callas before her thinner and more glamorous days.
Mr. Kelly had been creating his own sets, painting backdrops on rolls of seamless photographer's paper. In 1984 he began a long collaboration with the late Huck Snyder, a gifted scenic designer whose work complemented and drove Mr. Kelly's vision. It was Mr. Snyder whose nerve helped the inarticulate performer move up the performance-art ladder into more mainstream theaters like P.S. 122 and, eventually, Dance Theater Workshop. It was there Mr. Kelly presented his signature piece, "Pass the Blutwurst, Bitte," an impressionistic analysis of Schiele and his work.
"Way back, John, Huck and I sat down and worked on the pieces together," Mr. Chase recalls. He and Mr. Kelly were fascinated with early silent and German Expressionist films, particularly by the lighting. "We'd explore how film would work textually, for example, how to weave that difficult, obtrusive medium into the performance. But as John grew, the work became his own conception."
As Mr. Kelly incorporated language into his increasingly complex pieces, he became even more specific about what he wanted, to the point of laying out scenes and the placement of props, sets and performers like movie storyboards.
He also made conscious decisions to stretch artistically, moving from short pieces to long ones, commissioning scores and challenging his physical skills by crawling along a rope strung high across the stage. For a performance at St. Mark's Church in the East Village, he created the 1983 "Long Live the Knife," a piece about castrati in which he tested his untutored countertenor and vocal technique.
Life experiences often helped to build a piece. "Love of a Poet," an acclaimed 1990 staging in the Romantic-era style of Schumann's "Dichterliebe," grew out of a suicide attempt in 1978, after a failed love affair, when at the last moment Mr. Kelly decided not to stab himself with a pair of scissors but to cut his hair.
"I'd get an idea for a piece and then I'd get ideas for -- well, here would be a great place to have a simultaneous close-up on film with a live action. I'd have these inner stirrings and urges, and I would find the best outlet for them, either in an existing character or a character that I would invent. And I would proceed from there. There would obviously be a certain kind of style. A certain kind of pacing. What dilemma is this character going through? Is there a rite of passage? Do the characters survive? Do they die? Are there other people in the piece that they react against? And each time I would do something new I would try to make a major leap."
THOSE LEAPS HAVE NOT brought Mr. Kelly enough money to live comfortably or to stage and revive his work with the consistency he yearns for. Few theaters bridge the gap between spaces like the clubs or P.S. 122 and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. And financing is always a problem. Mr. Kelly's company will be on an artistic hiatus for at least a year, he said, while it heals from the "hemorrhaging" caused by the expenses of producing "Light Shall Lift Them," which cost $175,000.
The climax of the ambitious piece is an aerial act performed by Mr. Kelly himself. It approximates Barbette's routine as described by a reviewer in the 1927 article in Theater Arts Monthly that provided Mr. Kelly with his title. It is a description that might apply to the frail but seductive art of performance itself.
"Like a coil of caught lightning, a spiral of steel is unwinding its way from one black point to another across the barren stage," the reviewer wrote of Barbette's tightrope, "a statement slung between two mysteries. . . . Narrow and nervous shines the stem that is she, as the leaves of her skirt are blown back by the wind that awakes from the weight of her walk."
Barbette is, in the moments following her act, a Kellyesque creature caught between the worlds that performance art invokes. "With a bow the figure, suddenly seeming very lonely, doffs the golden wig as though saluting something, and uncovers a head the shape of an egg, crowned with a skullcap of short black hair. Barbette is a boy."

HEADLINE: '20 BUCKS';
The First Antecedent

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a film scholar, I am moved to comment on Lauren David Peden's article, " '20 Bucks,' a Film 58 Years Aborning" [Oct. 17]. Ms. Peden mentions that the screenplay, written in 1935 by the Hungarian producer Endre Bohem, is now being made by the screenwriter's son, Les. The premise of the script involves the peregrinations of a $20 bill as it passes from one hand to another. 
 Although Ms. Peden alludes to some cinematic antecedents ("If I Had a Million" in 1932, "Tales of Manhattan" in 1942 and "The Yellow Rolls-Royce" in 1965), she fails to mention the first film in which this plot was used: the 1925 silent "Adventures of a 10-Mark Note." This film, which predates the script for "20 Bucks" by a decade, was produced by Karl Freund, directed by Berthold Viertel and written by another Hungarian screenwriter, Bela Belazs. Belazs called his episodic script a "cross section"; it followed the random travels of a 10-mark note as it changed hands in inflation-ridden Berlin.
The film is often cited as an early instance of the Neue Sachlichkeit (New Objectivity) films.
 
FRANK P. TOMASULO
Atlanta, Ga.

HEADLINE: An Aging Midtown Hotel That Will Not Go Gently

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
NOW clad in a spindly web of scaffolding that heralds its imminent demise, the Hotel Diplomat in mid-Manhattan earns a place in civic annals not so much for its eccentric life as for its protracted death.
It has been nearly four years since the owners, the Durst Organization, filed a demolition application for the decrepit single-room-occupancy hotel at 108 West 43d Street. To create a home for the 31 residents they were displacing, the Dursts renovated Rosoff's Hotel across the street. Then they had to prod state housing officials to action, sometimes through court orders. They had to demonstrate that it made economic sense to replace a 13-story building with a one-story commercial "taxpayer" (so called because it pays the property-tax bills). 
 And they had to deal with two tenacious holdout tenants who, for eight months or so, were the only occupants of the 13-story building. One was a writer who says she was harassed by hotel employees and is suing for $108 million. The other was an elderly man who simply refused to go -- and not, apparently, out of financial desperation. A court-appointed guardian found that he controlled substantial bank accounts.
Douglas Durst, vice president of the family real-estate concern, said it was a "tragedy that taxpayers' money is wasted on this process," when demolition was the "only reasonable and logical outcome."
But was the system abusing the landlord? Or was the landlord abusing the system?
"I don't think the rent stabilization law was intended to empty a building with 160 affordable-housing units," said Leonidas B. Bell, a lawyer at the West Side S.R.O. Law Project, which represented all but one of the tenants who were at the Diplomat in 1990.
"Rather than provide a larger development," Mr. Bell said, "which arguably could be considered an improvement in the general real-estate situation in the City of New York, they're tearing down 160 affordable-housing units, which they had kept off the market as part of this speculative position, and replacing them with a one-story 'taxpayer,' of which there are plenty in the city."
Mr. Durst takes a different view. "Rent stabilization is not a preservation law," he said. "We did create 50 new housing units at Rosoff's without having any requirement to do so. The units at the Diplomat were certainly not habitable and it would have taken a huge investment to make them so. The building we're replacing it with will probably be assessed for around $1 million, and the city will get the benefit of those taxes."
The Diplomat did not begin its life 82 years ago as a hotel but as the Mother Lodge of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks. It was turned into a hotel after a foreclosure in 1934. The Dursts bought it in 1969 but did not take over operations until 1985. The Diplomat was primarily transient but there were residents who had been living there since the 1940's, placing them under rent control.
At the time, the Dursts were actively assembling parcels west of the Avenue of the Americas, between 42d and 47th Streets, envisioning a kind of latter-day Rockefeller Center. In 1971, they also acquired the 49-room Rosoff's Hotel, 147 West 43d Street.
During the 1970's, the Diplomat was the site of Le Jardin discotheque and, in Room 1015, the cocaine arrest that began Abbie Hoffman's six-year underground odyssey.
By 1985, Mr. Durst said, the number of permanent residents had grown to about 100, while there were only 50 to 60 transients.
As long as the rent-controlled tenants remained, it was practically impossible to get a demolition permit, said the Dursts' lawyer, Gary M. Rosenberg, of Rosenberg & Estis.
Moreover, Local Law 9 of 1987 prohibited the demolition, alteration or conversion of single-room-occupancy hotels. Two years later, however, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled that the law amounted to an unconstitutional taking of property.
Also in mid-1989, the Dursts began talking with Chemical Bank about building a new headquarters on the west side of the Avenue of the Americas, between 42d and 43d Streets, the site that includes the Hotel Diplomat. Chemical needed large floor sizes. But the Dursts could not raze the Diplomat. So they moved the remaining occupants to the front of the building with the idea of demolishing the rear 70 feet of the structure, thereby creating space for Chemical. Eventually, negotiations with the bank collapsed.
The last tenant covered by the rent-control laws -- rather than the less-stringent rent-stabilization laws -- moved to a nursing home in January 1990. Within weeks, the Dursts filed for demolition. "We had to overcome the issue of, 'Why are you demolishing a 13-story building to build something smaller?' " Mr. Rosenberg said. "We were losing $500,000 a year, based on occupancy, maintaining staff, heating and everything else. It would take $14 million to $21 million to bring it up to the level of a second-class hotel. With 70 percent occupancy rates, we'd have a building that would make up the cash-flow loss but not make any return on investment. With a one-story 'taxpayer,' we could generate a 12 percent return on investment, but the investment would only be $2 million to $3 million."
Mr. Bell, the tenants' lawyer, said he thought the Dursts brought on their own woes. "The bottom line," he said, "is that they made a business decision to go for this big development project. They withheld units from the market and didn't do any upkeep. And then they came before the state and said, 'Hey, we can't make a go of this.' In my opinion, it was an abuse of the whole process."
The first relocation settlements were reached in June 1991. Tenants were offered their choice of rooms in the newly renovated Rosoff's, at the rents they were paying for their old rooms, about $200 to $400 a month. They were also offered $3,000 stipends, later raised to $5,000. Fourteen tenants accepted, Mr. Durst said, two moved into other Durst properties and two simply left.
IN March 1992, prodded by a court order to decide the matter, the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal approved the demolition application. In April, the Dursts applied to relocate the remaining 13 tenants to Rosoff's. After further prodding, state officials approved that application in October.
By November, only two tenants remained: Clement Gaines, who had lived there since the 1960's and Susan Baba, a writer who had lived there since 1981. They were evicted in June after Ms. Baba, representing herself, put up a strenuous fight at the Appellate Division of state Supreme Court.
"I feel my blood comes from that building -- that much I'm attached to it," she said, adding that it was a landmark on a par with the nearby Town Hall and Algonquin Hotel.
Although city housing officials found there had been no harassment by the Diplomat, Ms. Baba said she suffered "so much harassment." She said she was virtually "choked to death" by a hotel employee during an argument in the lobby in 1987. She said her phone had been tapped and her mail withheld, destroyed or thrown at her. And she is continuing her legal fight.
Mr. Rosenberg described her as a "pro se litigant who is playing the system," using the legal term for self-representation.
Mr. Gaines took the position that he would stay until ordered out. Even after an accidental fire gutted his room on New Year's Eve -- "the only thing to survive were the cockroaches under the books," Mr. Rosenberg said -- Mr. Gaines did not want to leave.
Although Mr. Gaines lived in squalor, Mr. Rosenberg said it was clear he had the means to take care of himself. In the course of a competency proceeding, Mr. Gaines showed a bank statement to his temporary court-appointed guardian with "far more than $100,000 in more than one account," according to the transcript.
Besides Ms. Baba, tenants "did not raise any issues of harassment," Mr. Bell said.
"I will not say that the Durst people harassed anybody," Mr. Bell said. "In fact, some of our tenants felt they were reasonable landlords. The dispute wasn't that they were doing anything illegal and hounding people out of the building. The dispute was the broader policy issue."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk
