HEADLINE: Swords to Plowshares on Brooklyn Piers

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
BENJAMIN HAMALIAN was fed up. Pantrac, his company, was in a storefront space in East New York, a rather downtrodden section of Brooklyn. He had been robbed four times in eight years, and enough was enough.
Mr. Hamalian looked around Brooklyn, but all he found were expensive storefronts in unsafe neighborhoods. Then he moved Pantrac, which exports trucks and tractors, into 1,700 square feet of upstairs space at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. 
 Though the yard is bordered by Fort Greene, Williamsburg and Bedford-Stuyvesant, areas with considerable amounts of crime, security at the yard makes Mr. Hamalian comfortable. And, even including the use of a 5,000-square-foot outdoor lot, he is paying only $1,200 a month. Now he is talking about expanding into some warehouse space and hiring three local mechanics to work on parts.
"It's cheaper here and finally I feel safe," he said.
Edgar Berebi never felt unsafe in his Coney Island costume jewelry factory. But others did, and he had a terrible time getting people to work for him or store buyers to visit.
So four years ago he started looking for space. Rhode Island, Connecticut and New Jersey wooed him and his 200 manufacturing jobs with incentives, but he balked at training a new work force. Then one day, on a whim, he drove to the Brooklyn Army Terminal, now a city-run industrial complex.
"I'd been avoiding them because who wants to deal with a city bureaucracy?" Mr. Berebi said. "But I saw the posh lobby, the elevators, the benches under the trees where my workers could eat lunch, and I was hooked." Four weeks later he moved into 33,900 square feet at the terminal.
"About the only drawback is this place has attracted so many manufacturers that we have to compete for labor a little more," he said.
That is exactly the kind of complaint city officials love to hear. At a time when manufacturing jobs are leaving the city, and loft space continues to beg for tenants, city officials say the Brooklyn Navy Yard is 93 percent occupied and the newer Army Terminal's occupancy is up to 85 percent. Another 400,000 square feet of renovated space will be available at the Army Terminal in January, and management says there's a good chance that much of the space will have been leased by the time it is ready for occupancy.
CITY officials say that employers at the Navy Yard account for nearly 2,900 permanent jobs, about two-thirds from the local area. When ships are in for repair -- and some 17 ships will have been in dry dock this year alone -- 500 to 600 more people can find work there. Similarly, officials say that about half of the 2,600 people who work at the Army Terminal live nearby.
"We're trying very hard to reach out to minorities and local businesses," said Lee J. Benedict, a vice president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, which runs the terminal.
The employment figures are no coincidence. Although the Navy Yard is managed by a quasi-independent corporation, the city takes 10 percent of its rental income. And, since the city manages the Army Terminal itself, it keeps all the rent there. But revenues are not the reason for the projects. Indeed, because both yards are exempt from real estate taxes, and the city is responsible for losses they may incur, revenues are at best a wash with those generated by private commercial properties.
That point does not go unnoticed by real estate brokers.
"They can offer concessions that a regular loft building just can't give, and they are really hurting the private sector," said John Maltz, a director of Greiner-Maltz, an industrial real-estate company in Queens. "You've got the Army Terminal expanding at a time when loft buildings can't get $3 a foot, and from a tax standpoint, that's just not good for the city."
But city officials shrug off such criticisms. Both projects have mandates to be self-sufficient and provide jobs. As far as the city is concerned, the second mandate is paramount.
"We're a lot more flexible on rent with companies that are labor-intensive," said Stephen A. Berrang, an assistant vice president of the economic development corporation who handles the terminal's leasing.
Albert C. Wiltshire, the yard's chief executive, echoed that theme. "We could have this place 100 percent occupied overnight if we would rent good space to warehouses," Mr. Wiltshire said. "But our priority is manufacturers and others that create a lot of jobs."
Tenants document those claims.
J. Abouchar & Sons, which employs about 200 people to sew decorations onto towels, moved from Hoboken, N.J., into 55,900 square feet at the terminal about five years ago.
"The city gave us such a great deal that it's cheaper for us to operate here than it was in New Jersey," said Douglas S. Weigler, the company's general manager.
Until two months ago, when it fell victim to budget cuts, a New York State employment office operated rent-free at the Navy Yard, and tenants were required to notify the office whenever they had jobs available. Many did, and many grew.
MR. WILTSHIRE rattled off the names of tenants -- Agger Trading, a seafood company; All Ways Natural, which makes consumer grooming products; Ares Printing and In-Press Marketing, two printing and packaging companies -- that started small and that together employ a total of 180 people and rent a total of 120,000 square feet of space.
"We are an incubator, a place where infant businesses are nurtured and can grow," Mr. Wiltshire said.
The Army Terminal and the Navy Yard have similarities beyond the emphasis on jobs. Both offer ironclad security systems, access to a large pool of relatively skilled, low-wage labor and ample parking.
But the similarities end there. The terminal is a vertical industrial park, home to businesses that can afford extra amenities like a fancy lobby, a restaurant and, as of last month, a day-care center. Chase Manhattan has a new bank branch on the premises. The terminal has $25 million in state and city money earmarked for remodeling one of its piers for a high-speed ferry service linking Brooklyn and Manhattan.
The terminal, with rents at about $5 to $7 a foot, has wooed Wall Street operations as well as manufacturers. Last spring Salomon Brothers moved 120 back-office jobs into 32,000 square feet at the terminal from Manhattan. In July, Smith Barney Shearson contracted to put its printing and distribution operations into 250,000 square feet at the terminal, where it will employ about 250 people.
If the Army Terminal is the Four Seasons Hotel, then the Navy Yard is Motel 6. It is a serviceable but no-frills place catering heavily to start-up businesses.
"We are perfect for people who go out to see their clients," said Daniel Conlon, the yard's chief financial officer.
Even the yard's amenities are more practical than luxurious. It operates one building as a foreign trade zone in which tenants can import materials or parts and not pay duty until they ship the finished product. It has installed its own steam production system, which enables it to provide low-cost energy to tenants. Its rents rarely top $8 a square foot for the smallest spaces, and go as low as $3 for spaces larger than 10,000 square feet.
The differences between the terminal and yard arise as much from their histories as from physical variations.
The Navy Yard -- formerly and formally the New York Naval Shipyard at Brooklyn -- has an illustrious past. The Adams, America's first homebuilt warship, was built there in 1798; the Fulton, the first steam-powered warship, was launched there in 1837; the Monitor, the country's first metal-skinned ship, got its iron cladding there in 1861. During World War II the yard employed about 71,000 people to build, repair and outfit ships. When it was decommissioned in 1966, it had six working drydocks and about 270 buildings -- a total of 4.3 million square feet of rentable commercial space sprawled over more than 260 acres.
At that point the yard's past became checkered. In the early 1970's, New York City bought the yard from the Federal Government for $24 million. And it gave the Commerce, Labor, and Industry Corporation of Kings, a nonprofit corporation usually known as CLICK, the authority to operate the yard on a 99-year lease. CLICK started leasing space to large tenants.
The problem was that the tenants were not all solvent, and the officials were not all honest. In 1980 Mayor Edward I. Koch replaced the CLICK board after an audit turned up what it called "widespread fraud and mismanagement."
THE Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation, formed in 1981 to replace CLICK, inherited an operation that had fallen into disrepair. Five years later Coastal Dry Dock and Repair, the yard's largest tenant, went bankrupt, returning 1.5 million square feet of space, six drydocks and five piers to the pool of empty space. Real estate brokers, many of whom had not been paid their commissions under CLICK, would not even bring tenants in to look at the space.
"We were so broke we didn't even have the money to clean up the debris that Coastal left," recalled Thomas Montvel-Cohen, the yard's chief administrative officer.
Much like Scarlett O'Hara, the Navy Yard officials vowed that they'd never be hungry again. Although most of the tenants had come to the yard through word of mouth, the yard's leasing people reached out to real-estate brokers. The hope was that the brokers would bring in lots of little tenants, each of which would probably pay more per foot than larger tenants, and none of which could drag the yard down with it should it fail.
"We asked brokers to bring us their tired, their hungry, their poor, and not only would we rent to them, we'd pay full commissions," said William J. Hirschman, a director of the Cushman & Wakefield real-estate concern who is vice chairman of the Navy Yard board.
Clearly, the effort has paid off. In 1985, the year before Coastal's demise, the yard had 40 tenants, occupying an average of 73,000 square feet each, and accounting for $4.7 million in annual rental revenues. Today it has 201 tenants, more than half of which rent less than 5,000 square feet. This year the yard should collect $9.1 million in annual rental revenue.
The rule of thumb in the yard today is that no tenant should account for more than 5 percent of revenues. But it is not a hard-and-fast rule. "They will always be amenable to large tenants if space is available," said Dudley Maddern, an industrial broker with Crosstown Realty who has over the years put several large tenants in the Navy Yard.
Indeed, some of their most loyal tenants are behemoths by the yard's standards. St. Joe Distributing, which distributes books and occupies 200,000 square feet, was one of the yard's first tenants and thus has a miniscule rent of about $1.75 a square foot. It employs about 50 people, almost all from the neighborhood.
"I've had offers from New Jersey for space at $1 a foot, and that's without a 6 percent commercial tax, but I don't want to even think of moving," said Joal Savino, St. Joe's president. "Here, if I need new workers, I just ask my own people to send in their friends. And it's still a lot easier for publishers to get to Brooklyn than to New Jersey."
Still, the yard's focus remains on smaller tenants, and its management is increasingly providing the kind of services that small companies need. It started a newsletter and a series of tenant breakfasts in part to encourage tenants to do business with one another.
The yard also holds seminars and luncheons on topics like business insurance and training. It invites suppliers to give presentations; Citibank did four in the last two years. Since the mid-1980's it has more than doubled the security staff, to 55 guards, and quadrupled the security costs, to $1.6 million.
IT is also paying more attention to infrastructure. In the last few years the yard has refurbished many of its elevators, stepped up cleaning and painting, put in new roads, street lights and windows. This summer it spent more than $200,000 on a new heating system.
"When you're in expansion mode, you spend on vacant space," Mr. Conlon said. "In retention mode, you spruce up what is already occupied."
Still, the Navy Yard's main draws remain safety and economy. About a year ago Susan Griffith and her family started Bimshire Shippers to export American-made consumer products to the Caribbean.
Like most start-ups, Bimshire was a shoestring operation, and the rents Ms. Griffith was quoted -- $1,200 to $1,600 a month for storefront space in the shoddiest parts of town -- were more than she could handle. Then a friend told her about the Brooklyn Navy Yard, where she could get 1,300 square feet -- four times the amount of space she had been looking at -- for $650 a month.
"I can afford the space, and I'm not afraid of a stick-up here," Ms. Griffith said. Bimshire, which has since changed its name to Crystals Shippers & Movers, is nearing $150,000 in annual revenues, and Ms. Griffith is talking about doubling her space and adding an import side to her export business.
There would be no place for a tiny operation like Crystals at the Army Terminal. Everything there is on a grand scale.
Indeed, when the 97-acre terminal opened in September 1919, it was the largest of five supply bases rushed into construction to supply forces during World War I. But even then, the architect Cass Gilbert -- the designer of the Woolworth Building and the Custom House in Manhattan, as well as of the United States Supreme Court Building -- was told to create a complex that would be convertible into manufacturing buildings.
That was not as easy as the Government had hoped. The Army began vacating the terminal in 1966. The Navy and the Post Office occupied about a tenth of the space for a while, but by 1975 they, too, were gone.
The city bought the empty site in 1981. It tried to push the terminal as a center for the printing industry, only to discover that the ceilings and columns could not accommodate modern printing presses.
A PLAN to turn the terminal into a retail mall also failed when the city government decided that a mall would draw too much traffic from local businesses. Talk of turning it into a garment center hub or residential condominiums waxed and waned.
By the mid 1980's, the terminal was back to square one. It had four piers, many of them eaten away by marine borers. It had two huge buildings, each 980 feet long.
The larger building, 2.2 million square feet, has been subdivided into units of 18,000 to 34,000 square feet. The smaller has 1.8 million square feet, part of which is being carved into spaces of 5,400 to 9,200 square feet "to accommodate all the requests we've had for smaller spaces," Mr. Benedict said. It also has some warehouse spaces, many of which Mr. Benedict hopes existing tenants will use as they grow.
In a sense, the terminal has its own version of an incubator mentality. "Our dream is to create a place where a small manufacturer starts in 5,000 feet, moves to larger space, and then even uses a warehouse spot," said Mr. Berrang of the economic development corporation. "Sure, the more tenants, the more problems, but we are committed to helping businesses provide jobs."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Bridgeport Hopes a Dowdy Mall Can Spur Rebirth

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
LINED up along Broad Street in downtown Bridgeport are three sites, two to be developed, one already developed, that the city is betting will form the nucleus of its rebirth.
The centerpiece is the mostly empty, 450,000-square-foot Hi-Ho Mall, on 12 acres between Lafayette Boulevard and Broad Street. It was chosen by the state as the site for a $40 million project that will include a new Housatonic Community-Technical College, a state police barracks and offices for several state agencies that are scattered around Bridgeport in rented space. 
 Two blocks from the mall, at the corner of John Street, is the vacant Read's Department Store, a 68-year-old landmark under contract to Jonathan Bryer of Greenwich. His development company, Certified Historic Properties Inc., plans to convert the 165,000-square-foot building into 152 studio, one- and two-bedroom apartments renting for $600 to $1,300 a month, with a health club, pool, and shops at street level.
Mr. Bryer has until next August to arrange the financing before his contract expires. "Bridgeport has been a real estate disaster and everyone advised against this, but I enjoy a challenge," he said.
Between the two projects is a square block with 250,000 square feet of space, handsomely renovated a few years ago by the failed Citytrust Bank. It is 90 percent rented by the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Consolidated Asset Recovery Corporation, an arm of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and, until recently, the owner in foreclosure. It was sold earlier this year for $1 million to a group of Portuguese investors.
James Fagan, a vice president of CB Commercial Realtors in Stamford who represented the seller, said, "In the early 80's Citytrust probably had the property on its books for around $15 million."
The undistinguished architecture of the mall stands in stark contrast to the elegance of the bank building, but for most of its 25-year history the mall did well. Not until Gimbels moved out in the mid-1980's did the property's troubles begin. A hemorrhaging of departures followed, linked to the economic recession and including the strongest remaining retailers: Lerner's, Wallach's, Walgreen's and, in 1991, Sears.
Early in 1992 the state advertised for sites to relocate the Housatonic Community-Technical College, now in temporary quarters in 110,000 square feet of an industrial building in Bridgeport. One proposal came jointly from D'Addario Industries, the owner of the mall, and the City of Bridgeport, which owns the parking structure next to the mall.
News of the potential sale dealt the mall a death blow, rendering it unmarketable.
Only a dozen shops are still open. "We only get busy on the first and the 16th of the month, when the welfare checks come," said Sandra Hernandez, a saleswoman at J. Silver, one of a chain of 20 low-priced women's clothing stores. Its employees said they worried about the day it, too, would close.
"There is no industry left in Bridgeport so there are no working people to shop," said John Cerreta, the president of J. Silver,which is based in Norwalk. "Pilferage is high and safety is a factor."
Added Michael Freimuth, the director of economic development for Bridgeport: "Urban malls are dying all over the country. Having the school downtown is important for the city's rehabilitation."
Founded in 1966, Housatonic Community-Technical College, part of a state system, has an enrollment of 2,700 students, which is expected to rise to 4,500 in its new 170,000-square-foot building.
"We anticipate bringing in students from outside Bridgeport, via some 25 city and suburban bus routes," said Thomas K. Anderes, the deputy commissioner for finance and facilities at the State Department of Higher Education.
The cost of constructing the school building is estimated at $18 million. The rest of the $40 million will be spent on parking, landscaping and renovations of the Sears store for the state police and other state offices.
Last month the State Department of Public Works issued requests for development proposals, to be submitted by Jan. 21, 1994.
"Our target for completion of the project is July of 1996," said Richard J. Tedder, the director of management services for the Department of Public Works.
Complex three-way negotiations for the acquisition of the mall by the state are under way involving D'Addario Industries, the state and the city. "They should be concluded by the end of this year," Mr. Freimuth said.
Negotiations hinge in part on the mall's $2.5 million delinquent tax bill. In 1992 the city held a tax lien sale to try to collect, but there were no buyers. When he heard of the impending sale, David D'Addario, the president of the mall, sued the city in State Appellate Court, seeking an injunction to prevent it, but his request was denied. He then filed for a permanent injunction, questioning the constitutionality of the state statute governing tax lien sales.
"IT'S too Draconian," said Mr. D'Addario's lawyer, Stanton Lesser of Lesser and Sobel in Bridgeport, "depriving property owners of their equity without a hearing, when a simple foreclosure could be handled by the court in a fairer, participatory and more equitable manner."
Last May the City Council agreed not to take title to the mall, and an arrangement was reached whereby Mr. D'Addario would pay the back taxes and the state would go forward with the negotiations to buy the mall from him. The property was appraised at $6.8 million.
"I regard this as corporate welfare," said Dale Radcliffe, a Republican State Representative from the Bridgeport suburb of Trumbull. "D'Addario will pay the taxes out of proceeds from the sale, when the city could have taken the property in foreclosure for the taxes due and sold it to the state for less than the current price. It's not the obligation of the taxpayers to bail out a developer."
Joining him in dissent during the state legislature's consideration of bonding for the project was Senator George Gunther, a Republican from Stratford. "We were a distinct minority," Mr. Radcliffe said.
"If there was a realistic expectation that the state would have waited a year for a foreclosure proceeding to be concluded, when other sites were available, I would have pursued it," said Joseph Ganim, the Mayor of Bridgeport. "Out of five potential sites, this one does the most for the city and the college, and the state recognized that."
He added: "As for tax lien sales, we will continue to use that device, as we have done in many cases, reducing by several million dollars the $13 million in back taxes that I was faced with when I took office two years ago."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chase Manhattan Bank across from Hi-Ho mall in Bridgeport. Read's Department Store on John Street is to be converted to apartments. (David Carl Labianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: For Condo and Co-op Owners;
Two Conferences, Myriad Topics

 BODY:
People may bemoan the state of the New York co-op and condominium market, but that doesn't mean there's not a lot going on. Indeed, there are enough new developments -- and enough confusion about old ones -- to warrant two conferences on the subject, a couple of weeks apart.
The first, the Council of New York Cooperatives' 13th Annual Cooperative Housing Conference, will be held next Sunday. It will offer 85 workshops on a potpourri of topics, from refinancing a mortgage to current legal issues to dealing with graffiti (the "visual virus," as the brochure colorfully calls it). 
 For $60 for residents of member buildings (ask your board president) and $150 for others, attendees can pick two or three workshops, depending on workshop length. They can also visit a concurrent trade show, where insurance companies, lenders, interior designers, even washing-machine companies, will hawk their wares.
In a not-unexpected sign of the economic times, preregistration has been particularly heavy for the financial workshops, lower for the fun-but-not-essential ones.
"We may even have to cancel one on repairing stained glass, and that's a personal favorite of mine," said Mary Ann Rothman, the council's executive director. "Today, people look to financial ways to improve the quality of life."
The conference, which goes from 8:15 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., will be at Hunter College's West Building, on 68th Street and Lexington Avenue. For more information, call the council at (212) 496-7400.
If this conference whets rather than slakes your thirst for data, try the Federation of New York Housing Cooperative's 37th Annual Seminar & Trade Show for Housing Cooperatives & Condos, at Queens College's College Union Building in Flushing. This one, on Sunday, Dec. 5, is from 8:15 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. and deals almost entirely with legal and financial issues. Fees are $70 for Federation members, $100 for others. For more information, call the Federation at (718) 353-5080.

HEADLINE: O'Rourke Savors His Victory, While Awaiting Recount

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
ANDREW P. O'ROURKE, a narrow winner in his bid for four more years as the county executive, said last week that he was fortunate to have avoided the fate of most other incumbents in the New York City area and claimed that "questionable tactics" by his opponent opened the way for his victory.
"Most of the undecided votes went to the challengers, but Richard's personal attacks," he said, referring to the six-term Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, his Democratic opponent, "never did him a bit of good, largely because he wasn't well known enough." 
 Mr. Brodsky, who lost by 1.6 percentage points, or about 3,400 votes of 211,000 cast, focused on what he saw as Mr. O'Rourke's ethical lapses, including recommending his live-in companion for a job with the county medical insurer and seeking other county-related jobs for family members.
"People looked at him and said, 'What kind of person makes these attacks?' Mr. O'Rourke said. "He wasn't well known enough. If you are going to attack someone, the first thing you do is build up your own positive value so that you are known. Richard never had the name recognition to make an attack and make it stick."
Peter W. Delaney, the former General Services Administrator who quit to run Mr. O'Rourke's campaign, as he did in 1989 when Mr. Brodsky was also the challenger, said, "We asked our pollsters to question people about the corruption issue, and the overwhelming answer was that it was having no impact."
 
'The Issue of Change'
 Mr. Delaney added: "The biggest message that was coming through, and this concerned us far more than the ethics issue, was the issue of change. Andy was in office a long time, 11 years, and maybe voters felt it was time for a change. That feeling pervaded all the incumbent races around the country, and the proof of that is what happened in New Jersey, New York City, Rockland and Orange Counties."
Mr. Delaney was referring to the narrow losses by Gov. Jim Florio to Christine Todd Whitman in New Jersey, by Mayor David N. Dinkins to Rudolph W. Giuliani in New York City, by the Rockland County Executive, John T. Grant, to Scott Vanderhoef and by the Orange County Executive, Mary M. McPhillips, to Joseph G. Rampe. All the winners were Republicans, the losers Democrats.
Mr. O'Rourke piled up a 6,000-vote lead in Yonkers, gaining 22,800 votes to 16,000 for Mr. Brodsky, more than compensating for Mr. Brodsky's best showing, in his hometown of Greenburgh, where he polled 14,000 votes to Mr. O'Rourke's 9,400.
 
Half of Absentee Ballots Counted
 Mr. Brodsky demanded a recount, which will be completed next week, probably by Tuesday. Absentee ballots will also be counted, although roughly half of the estimated 8,000 ballots were counted last week and included in Tuesday's totals.
The re-canvas will also produce results in 31 districts missing from the election night count, but Mr. Delaney said that the outcome of the race will not be changed, "because eight of the missing districts are in Eastchester, where Republicans hold an 855-vote plurality."
Other missing districts, including two in Rye Town, two in Mount Pleasant and one each in Pelham and Cortlandt, contain 1,600 more registered Republicans than Democrats. Democrats outnumber Republicans in four missing Yonkers districts and six White Plains districts, for a Democratic plurality of 350 votes.
 
'The Power of the Incumbency'
 Mr. Brodsky dismissed the notion that the ethics issue did not interest voters. "Our polls showed that it was important to voters," he said. "What you had were messages canceling each other out; he had taxes, and we had ethics and economic growth." The reference to taxes referred to Mr. O'Rourke's campaign to link Mr. Brodsky with "tax-and-spend liberals" in Albany.
"In the end, it was the power of the incumbency that did it; he wrapped himself in it," Mr. Brodsky said. He also observed that his campaign "had to deal with a nationwide Republican surge" as well as a shortage of funds caused by the money spent fighting the primary against Andrew J. Spano.
In other contests:
*Jeanine Ferris Pirro, a former assistant district attorney who resigned as County Court judge to run for district attorney, won easily over Michael G. Cherkasky, a former prosecutor in the office of the Manhattan District Attorney. Mrs. Pirro, a Republican, succeeds Carl A. Vergari, who is retiring after 25 years. Mrs. Pirro won 56 percent of the vote to Mr. Cherkasky's 41 percent.
*Leonard N. Spano, a longtime Republican member of the Board of Legislators, won the post of county clerk, replacing Andrew P. Spano, no relation, a Democrat who gave up the post to run for county executive. He lost in a primary to Mr. Brodsky. Leonard Spano won the clerk post, defeating James P. Doody, the Eastchester Supervisor, with a vote of 51 percent to 46 percent.
*Sy J. Schulman, a first-term Common Council member and a Democrat, won a three-way race for mayor in White Plains. Mr. Schulman, who served for many years as president of the Westchester County Association, which represents major employers in the county, received 42 percent of the vote, and his two opponents split most of the rest of the vote. The incumbent, Alfred Del Vecchio, ran on the Conservative line after losing the Republican primary to Councilman Michael A. Coffey. Mr. Del Vecchio took 29.5 percent of the vote, Mr. Coffey 25 percent.
 
Board Still Republican
 The Board of Legislators remains in Republican hands, although how tightly will not be known until votes in the Fourth District in northern Westchester are recounted. Andrew J. Donovan, a Republican-Conservative, appeared to have narrowly won over the incumbent Democrat, Judith A. Shepard, by 49 votes out of 15,075 cast.
In another apparent upset, a Republican-Conservative, Paul J. Noto, the five-term Mayor of Mamaroneck, unseated a two-term Democratic Legislator, Martin L. Rogowsky, a lawyer. Mr. Noto got 50 percent of the vote to Mr. Rogowsky's 47 percent.
Two former Democratic seats on the Board, filled with Republicans by the Republican-controlled legislature after the incumbents won election to the State Assembly, were returned to the Democratic column.
One was the Eighth District, redesigned by the Board in May as a minority district stretching through parts of White Plains, Scarsdale, Greenburgh and New Rochelle. Pearl C. Quarles, a Republican who was appointed to replace Assemblywoman Audrey Hochberg, lost to Lois T. Bronz, a former member of the Greenburgh Town Board. Mrs. Bronz garnered 55 percent of the vote to Mrs. Quarles's 34 percent.
In the Ninth District, covering New Castle, Ossining and Briarcliff, the seat once held by Assemblywoman Sandra R. Galef now goes to the Democrat Richard G. Wishnie, who beat Barbara C. Fratianni, 55 percent to 43 percent. Both are former Ossining town Supervisors. The Republican incumbent, Mark S. Tulis, appointed to replace Mrs. Galef, did not run.
Another newcomer to the Board, although with a familiar name, is Michael J. Spano, a Yonkers Republican, who won election to the seat that had been held for 22 years by his father, the new County Clerk. Michael Spano beat Bernice Sprechman, a former Yonkers City Council member. Another brother, Nicholas A. Spano, is a State Senator.
The process of filling vacancies on the Board of Legislators by appointment, long fought by the minority Democrats as undemocratic, came to an end on Election Day with overwhelming approval by voters of a proposition requiring special elections to fill vacancies.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

PERSIAN POETRY
Works by the 13th-century Persian poet Jela Luddin Rumi will be read in English translation by the American poet Coleman Barks on Monday at 8 P.M. in the Academic Arts Theater at Westchester Community College in Valhalla. Mr. Barks will be accompanied by Paul Halley, Eugene Friesen and Glen Velez, an improvisational piano-cello-percussion trio from the Paul Winter Consort, which has performed with him at the Manhattan Theater Club and elsewhere. 
 Mr. Barks has spent the last 14 years translating the Rumi works, which are laced with the mysticism of the Sufi branch of Islam. To date 12 volumes of the poems have been translated and published by his own company, Maypop Books in Athens, Ga., Threshold Books in Putney, Vt., and various other publishers. A selection of the poems will be included in the Norton Anthology of World Masterpieces, to be published later this year. Mr. Barks undertook the translations with a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts in 1979. His own book of poems, called "The Juice," was published in 1971 by Harper & Row in New York, and a new volume titled, "Gourd Seed," is due out by the end of this year, under his own banner.
The college is at 75 Grasslands Road; and admission to the reading is free. The number to call for more information is 785-6600.
 
CARAMOOR OPERA BENEFIT
 Four years ago Will Crutchfield forsook his position as a music critic and turned to music itself as a principal vocation. Since then he has conducted at Lincoln Center, Wolf Trap, the Sarasota Opera, the Brooklyn Academy of Music and Mannes College in Manhattan. He is now on the faculties of Mannes College and the Juilliard School, and he continues to write about music for a variety of publications.
On Saturday at 8 P.M. he will conduct a benefit performance of Rossini's "Barber of Seville" at Caramoor in Katonah, providing a narration in English between scenes. The cast, wearing costumes by Cynthia Dumont, will be accompanied by a chamber orchestra in a version of the work that falls between a concert performance and full staging.
Keith Spencer has the role of Figaro. Marguerite Krull is Rosina, and Dan Montez portrays Count Almaviva. Rubin Wilcox is Fiorello. David Shapero plays Doctor Bartolo, and Hyung-Il Moon is Don Basilio.
Tickets at $100 include a champagne reception at intermission. They may be reserved by calling 232-3681. Proceeds will benefit the center's music and art programs.
 
HOMOSEXUALITY SEMINAR
 A colloquium on "Homosexuality: Concerns and Dilemmas," sponsored by the Graduate Department of Pastoral and Family Counseling at Iona College, will be held in Joyce Auditorium at Murphy Center on the New Rochelle campus on Saturday. Registration begins at 9:00 A.M. with Continental breakfast, and the program will continue through mid-afternoon. The fee will be $22 at the door or $20 in advance.
"This colloquium has been organized around the notion that homosexuality is not necessarily fixed in the psyche," said one of the panelists, Dr. E. Mark Stern, professor of graduate pastoral and family counseling at the college.
"Abstinence for the Homosexual" will be discussed by the Rev. John Harvey, professor emeritus at Catholic University of America in Washington, and "Multi-Causations of Homosexuality" is the topic chosen by Dr. Maria Valdes, a New Jersey psychologist. "Homosexuality in the Light of Jewish Tradition" will be examined by Dr. Arnold Zucker, a faculty member at Iona, And the title of a talk by Elizabeth Moberly, a graduate of Cambridge University in England and currently a therapist in Pennsylvania, is "Can Homosexuals Choose to Change?"
Other topics include "Some Moral Observations on the Homosexual Lifestyle" and "Sadomasochism and Idolatry," to be discussed, respectively, by Msgr. William Smith of St. Joseph's Seminary in Dunwoodie, N. Y., and by Dr. Stern.
Iona is at 715 North Avenue, and the phone numbers for more information or advance reservations are 633-2418 or 636-6623.
 
EXHIBITION OF STELES
 Stephen J. Ostrander creates his sculptured and polychromed wood steles from found wood stumps, embellished with paint, shells, bone, seeds and other natural objects. They are inspired by ancient Anasazi, Maya and Assyrian civilizations. "Artists should treat the future as sensitively as the past," he said, believing, as many ancient cultures did, that past, present and future are an uninterrupted circle.
An exhibition of his work, which includes a collection of his photographs, opens at the Sleepy Hollow Gallery, at 231 1/2 South Highland Avenue in Briarcliff Manor on Saturday and remains through Dec. 2.
The photographs, shot in France, the American West, Middle West and New York, depict landscapes, wildlife and abstract subjects. Prices for the steles, which run from six inches to eight feet tall, start around $25 and rise to $600. The photographs are $25 to $200. Hours are Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. For more information, the number to call is 762-2910.
 
MURAL TO BE UNVEILED
 Students from the Museum School of the Arts and Sciences, School 25 in Yonkers, have created a mural that will be installed in the Yonkers Metro-North station on Wednesday. Ceremonies will begin at 10 A.M., open to the public free of charge.
The magnet school, with its special arts and science orientation, maintains an ongoing relationship with the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, where the mural was executed. Twelve boys and girls participated in its design and painting, guided by Sone Tower, an artist from Ossining. The work was begun when the students were fourth graders in April and was completed on Oct. 15 when they had become fifth graders.
Selected for their artistic ability, and working under the supervision of their teachers, the children researched the project by making preliminary drawings of flora and fauna in the Hudson River region and by studying the social and political history of the Yonkers area.
The irregularly shaped mural, which measures 16 feet long by 11 feet high, will be placed on an interior wall of the 1911 Beaux Arts station, designed by the firm of Whitney Warren and Charles Wetmore of Manhattan.
 
KESSLER RETROSPECTIVE
 George Edward Kessler, a pioneering landscape architect and city planner who died at the age of 61 in 1923, will be the subject of a retrospective exhibition at Wave Hill in the Bronx, opening today and running through Jan. 2. Organized by the Cincinnati Historical Society, the collection of drawings, postcards, photographs and other documentation of his life and commissions will be on display in the Glyndor Gallery in the Riverdale estate.
The opening will be marked today with a slide-talk by Kurt Culbertson, an authority on Kessler's work and a member of the Design Workshop, a landscape and city-planning firm in Aspen, Colo.
Kessler, German by birth, came to the United States as a child, returned to Germany for his professional training and came back to America in 1882, when he began work on a Kansas train station and park. His approach was interdisciplinary, combining transportation, housing, economic development and open parkland. His vision, emulating the designed cities of Europe, was well received in the Middle West, where a taste for urban European elegance had developed.
Among his commissions were the Louisiana Purchase Exposition of 1904, the city plan for Dallas, which became a landmark in its field, and numerous parks and boulevard systems in Kansas City, Cincinnati and other Middle Western municipalities.
Wave Hill, at West 249th Street, is open Tuesdays through Sundays from 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. There is no charge for admission on weekdays. Admission today and all weekends and holidays is $4, $2 for people 65 and older and students. For more information, the number to call is (212) 549-3200.
 
McCULLOUGH ON TRUMAN
 The historian David McCullough, narrator of the PBS series "The Civil War" and author of such highly praised works as "Truman" and "The Great Bridge," will give a free lecture on Tuesday at 8 P.M. at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers. The talk, titled "Harry S. Truman and the Ideal of Public Service," celebrates the newly created Joanne Woodward Chair in Public Policy.
The chair, established through the Newman Foundation in honor of Ms. Woodward -- who graduated recently in the class of 1990 and who has been a trustee from 1986 to 1993 -- will help underscore the college's efforts to integrate liberal arts courses with major public-policy issues. The talk in Reisinger Auditorium will be followed by a reception in the Performing Arts Center. The number for more information is 395-2220. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Watch What They Pay, Not What They Say

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
RISING interest rates threw a bucket of cold water on Wall Street last week, but didn't come close to extinguishing the speculative fires.
These days, the fastest way to get a small stock moving is to tell a bullish story on television, especially cable television. Quote an unnamed money manager or two about how a company has excellent prospects, and the stock will leap. An hour later, a report will note that the stock is moving, and refer to the earlier report, bringing in more buyers and provoking more reports. This can go on for days. 
 Consider the wonderful case of Bowmar Instruments. The older folks in the audience will remember when Bowmar briefly dominated the pocket calculator market. Since then, it has become a small military contractor making semiconductors that are supposed to withstand harsh environments. It is marginally profitable.
On Monday, CNBC broadcast a bullish report on Bowmar, making up in optimism what it lacked in specifics. Bowmar has a float of about 4.5 million shares in public hands, and more than half of them traded last week, pushing the price from $2.375 to $5.625. It slipped back to $4.50 when the company said the only news it was aware of was the CNBC report and later reports on the report.
Atari, the one-time video game leader, has also benefited from enthusiastic broadcast reports. There, the optimism is about the company's new Jaguar game system, which will go on sale this month in New York and San Francisco.
Atari may or may not prove to be an example of a company returning from the dead. But it does provide a textbook case of how information can be manipulated to affect how investors perceive a company.
Sam Tramiel, the president of Atari, now recalls the excitement he felt in March, when tests showed the final version of Jaguar worked as expected.
But there was no hint of Mr. Tramiel's excitement in April, when the company reported more losses, or in May, when the board proposed a one-for-ten reverse stock split. Such a split appeared to indicate the stock was unlikely to rally.
A few days later, Mr. Tramiel bought 4 million shares, at 94 cents each, the market price. The seller was his father, the company's chairman, so the transaction looks more like estate planning than insider trading. In June, the company called off the reverse split and announced "the phenomenal Jaguar."
At Atari's current price of $11.375 per share, it has a market capitalization of $650 million, or almost nine times pre-Jaguar annual revenues. That might be justified, if Jaguar is able to knock off Sega and Nintendo and once again dominate the market. But that is uncertain, to say the least. Jaguar has better graphics, but fewer games and a much higher price.
Under securities law, Mr. Tramiel may legally sell Atari stock later this month. Will he do so, or will he wait until Jaguar's success or failure is apparent?
"Anything is possible," he said, adding that diversifying his own portfolio "might be a good idea."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Ties to China Lift Hong Kong Index

BYLINE: By Barbara Basler

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
THE stock market here has soared to a series of record highs recently, largely because of this colony's tantalizing connections to mainland China.
Clive Weedon, head of research at the Nomura Research Institute, said the Hong Kong index -- which has grown more than 70 percent in 1993 -- "will probably end the year as the best performing market in the world." 
 Fund managers from the United States, Europe and Japan have been competing frantically for Hong Kong local blue chip stocks, as a way to "play" mainland China, and that money is the moving force behind the market's phenomenal rise.
"The Hong Kong market is a proxy for the mainland; it's really the only way to play the Chinese economy," said Peter Churchouse, Morgan Stanley's research director for the Asia-Pacific market.
This British colony reverts to mainland control in 1997, but for years its economy has been inextricably bound to China's economy, and both are booming now. Moreover, the Hong Kong stock market not only lists many local companies that do business with China, it even lists a handful of companies wholly owned by the People's Republic of China.
"I think the whole speculation fever here really began about this time last year, when mainland companies started to seek listings on the Hong Kong exchange," said Robert Broadfoot, director of the Political and Economic Risk Consultancy Ltd.
As China has continued to open its economy and encourage more homegrown capitalism, foreign brokerage houses, especially American firms, have been expanding here in order to be close to the mainland action.
Now this tiny colony is awash in foreign investment funds, and many believe the torrent of new cash will carry the Hang Seng index to a permanent new level, where its stocks will be routinely traded at a higher-than-ever price-to-earnings ratio. But the Hang Seng is notoriously volatile, and even brokers who believe the upward trend will continue for the next six months warn that the market will move in fits and starts.
With institutional investors bidding fiercely for shares, prices have risen with dizzying speed. The Hang Seng index, which began the year at 5,512, gained more than 1,500 points in October alone as the rush of foreign money pushed up the index from 7,622 to 9,329 -- its biggest leap ever.
On Oct. 29 it rose 318 points. "It was a case of close your eyes and buy," one dealer said.
Last Monday, foreign investors continued their buying, and the index gained another 300 points to close at a record 9,629.
The atmosphere around the stock exchange has been so heady, the Financial Secretary recently warned excited local investors that this market "is not something for widows and orphans."
After the market rose 13 points on Tuesday, to 9,642.91, profit taking began and the index fell, closing out the week at 8,996.93. One dealer said he thought the index would soon "hit 10,000 or 11,000, but not in an unbroken line." Mr. Weedon said the index is likely to remain high because no other world market currently offers Hong Kong's combination of high growth and minimal currency risks (the Hong Kong dollar is pegged to the U.S. dollar).
"The Japanese institutions began to come into the Hong Kong market over the past two weeks," Mr. Churchouse said. "They could become major players here.
"That's one reason why I don't think Hong Kong will tumble off its high perch yet," he added. "The Japanese have just arrived and they are not yet ready to go home."
Brokers here said fund managers are re-evaluating the acceptable price-to-earnings ratio of Hong Kong shares. After the killing of pro-Democracy students in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in 1989, Hong Kong's stock market plummeted, and foreign investors dumped their shares.
But as China continued to open its economy, Hong Kong's market recovered, and institutional investors took a more favorable view of its shares.
"Today, at 13.5 times earnings, Hong Kong shares are seen as a bargain," Mr. Churchouse said, adding, "I think they could even trade up to 18 times earnings and still be sought after."
Stocks had already been moving up this year when, half a world away in New York, Morgan Stanley's chief investment strategist, Barton Biggs, declared he was "maximum bullish" on China and Hong Kong -- and the Hang Seng soared.
Asked how much of the last two weeks' bull market was attributable to Mr. Biggs, Mr. Churchouse said, "We played a role, but only perhaps by focusing attention on China and Hong Kong."
Brokers said the Hang Seng index, which used to rise and fall whenever Britain and China squabbled over Hong Kong, now tends to ignore politics. Even the latest battle over more democracy in Hong Kong, which reached a heated pitch of name calling and accusations last spring, has been viewed as "a sideshow," one analyst said.
According to Mr. Weedon, "It's what's happening in the Chinese economy that counts."
But Mr. Broadfoot, the consultant, said that while brokers may be discounting politics, "in China, the economy is always second to politics. And right now there are huge political risks hanging over China.
"There is the question of what political price the party will pay to control inflation, and how far will market reforms go before they spark political unrest?"

HEADLINE: Business Diary, October 31 - November 5

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Wall Street's Long Party Gets a Rude Interruption
Long rallies in the stock and bond markets survived an often-nasty October, but the first week of November was something else. Things were going fine as long as the economy was growing steadily and slowly. But suddenly in the middle of last week the growth seemed perkier, and the alarms went off. Interest rates, which had been dozing way down below 6 percent, headed straight up, and investors suddenly remembered that there was life -- and possibly better returns -- beyond stocks. Or, the way these things work, they figured everyone else would think that way. In any case, the Dow industrials, after notching new records early in the week, did an about-face, losing 73 points in two days. The Dow steadied on Friday, but most of the market kept retreating. And it was a busy week, with Big Board volume the second-highest ever. The only busier week? The week of the October 1987 crash. 

Home Sales Rise (but Not Alone)
The economic numbers did spill out last week, one after another pointing upward. One surprisingly big gain was for new-home sales, up 20.8 percent in September. But that strong signal had plenty of company: third-quarter productivity up at a 3.9 percent rate, late-October car sales up 10.3 percent, September factory orders up 0.7 percent . . . and on and on. The rise in home sales was the biggest since 1986, back when it still seemed you could never go wrong in real estate. So if interest rates keep heading up, all those people who bought houses in September may have timed it just right, catching mortgage rates at rock-bottom. But, clearly, people are doing a lot more than buying houses.
 
Back Into the Work Force
One of last week's rising numbers would not seem welcome -- the unemployment rate. But a close look shows that it's a good sign, too. The rate did go to 6.8 percent in October from 6.7 percent. But apparently it rose because some once-discouraged people started pounding the pavement again. In fact, 177,000 jobs were added to payrolls. But the bad news is that 40 percent of those jobs were at temp agencies -- hardly the stuff of new careers.
 
Debating 10 Seconds At a Time
It's the American way. Thoughtful debate degenerates into slogans easily gulped by the couch potato crowd. And so it was with health care, as insurers rolled out ads with phrases to catch the restless ear: The plan will "take away choice." When spending hits a limit, "That's it!" "There has got to be a better way." Last week, Hillary Clinton joined the fray, lashing out at the ads. Insisting that the plan "enhances choice," Mrs. Clinton slammed insurers as "the very industry that has brought us to the brink of bankruptcy." Mr. Clinton pitched in, too, blaming the "overcomplicated, burdensome, bureaucratic" rules of insurers. It must feel good for the Clintons to vent their frustration in plain English after the endless meetings, the reams of reports.
 
Is the Health Plan Bulletproof?
The last thing the Clintons need is another enemy of the health plan, especially one like the gun lobby. But Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan moved to put the plan right in their sights last week. He decided, quite reasonably, that when people get shot, they've got a health problem. So, saying that "guns don't kill people, bullets do," he suggested that if a box of especially nasty bullets cost thousands of dollars, not $24, sales might taper off. To that end, he proposed that a 10,000 percent tax on certain bullets be tacked on to the health bill. And as head of the Finance Committee, he might do it. So don't be surprised if you see a copy of that bill used for target practice.
 
An Instant Philanthropic Giant
How do you exist when you're worth $1 billion? It's de rigueur to have numerous homes -- Doris Duke, who just died, had them all over -- so you've got to keep moving constantly. But where do you keep your toothbrush, your favorite slippers, that novel you just set aside? Miss Duke, the heiress whose family gave Duke University its name, kindly did not impose such a life on anyone, putting most of her fortune to the public good. Her will, filed last week, instantly created one of the nation's biggest philanthropies. Other gifts, from the loose change, included $10 million to the Metropolitan Museum.
 
A Radical Welfare Test
On President Clinton's long list, "Things to Change," is welfare. So when Wisconsin asked for a Federal blessing on a two-year limit on benefits, the Administration granted it, not wanting to shy from such a test. But this test could be harsher than Mr. Clinton envisioned: after two years, you're out unless you get an exemption. There's no community-service option if you haven't found a job. But a Children's Defense Fund official was quick to say, "Children shouldn't be punished when parents can't find jobs."
 
COMPANIES
 
At I.B.M., a Lowly Milestone
Remember when the thought of I.B.M. stock sinking below $100 was like glimpsing the end of civilization? Could anyone have imagined the day when it was newsworthy for it to go above $50? Well, last week it did. Why? For one thing, the chairman, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., insisted that "I.B.M. is on the right track." One number seemed to back him up -- a smaller-than-expected quarterly loss -- and a key analyst gave the thumbs-up. So eager investors bid the stock higher, though by Friday it had slipped back to $49.875. But is it a bargain? Some have doubts, saying that scorched-earth cost-cutting -- Mr. Gerstner's apparent approach -- just doesn't compute here. What's needed, they say, is a top-to-bottom, chip-to-mainframe reinventing of I.B.M.
 
The Latest Fad: TV Networks
These days, you rarely see the word "television" without "cable." One might almost forget that the dinosaurs called networks once ruled the screen. But now, suddenly, everyone wants to start a network. Paramount recently made its plans, and last week Warner Brothers got into the act, saying it intended to create a network called WB, built on six independent stations. Trouble is, there may not be enough stations up for grabs.
 
I Shop, Therefore I Drop
To live is to shop. The mall's always open, and at home you can browse on shopping channels or flip through those 97 catalogues that attack your mailbox daily. But wait. Against all odds, one corner of this busy, busy land has clung to the quaint notion of a day of peace. Even as New Jersey voters were throwing out their Governor last week, Bergen County upheld its ban on Sunday retailing. So all those malls in Paramus, which are just aching to keep their wares flowing, will have to keep watching tearfully as the credit-card-wielding hordes head across the county line to get their shopping fix. . . . Some, by the way, argue that for sanity's sake, all shoppers should skip a day [Page 11]. Maybe then you'd be reading this on Sunday, not Monday.
 
Lost in the Paramount Maze
The business pages should get a lot less confusing if anyone defies the odds and actually buys Paramount. For now, one only hopes all those people are keeping their alliances, and their decimal points, straight. Take a deep breath and sort out the latest: Last week BellSouth, which had weighed its own Paramount bid, seemed poised to chip in $2 billion to help QVC's offer. But follow the maze: Bell Atlantic, a BellSouth rival, is buying Liberty Media, and Liberty Media, yes, owns 22 percent of QVC. So because BellSouth didn't want to be partners with a rival, part of its investment would go to buy out Liberty Media's stake. But to spice things up a bit more, this week Paramount may try to buy Macmillan, the publishing house. Had enough?
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
New Heights for Italy's Scandal
Italy's bribery scandal reached the penthouse last week: Carlo De Benedetti, head of Olivetti and one of the nation's richest people, was arrested and interrogated. But even though a Rome judge said of the arrest that "the law is the same for everybody," Mr. De Benedetti, who is accused of authorizing more than $7 million in bribes, did not exactly languish behind bars. Within hours, he was released. Mr. De Benedetti's defense has been, basically, that everybody did it. Considering the thousands of business executives and politicians implicated, that's probably not an exaggeration.
 
Squeezing Haiti's Drug Trade
In its effort to return Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power in Haiti, the United States has been pinning its hopes on a trade embargo. But the embargo may have a potent side effect. Illegal drugs are said to have provided some military leaders with a tidy sideline, but drug traffickers want none of the hassles of dealing with Haiti right now. So more and more, Haiti's military stands alone.
 
In Germany, Deadly Profits
In the business world, there are misdeeds and there are misdeeds. If apple juice is stretched with sugared water, or if that 10-ounce box holds 9 ounces of cereal, the consumer is cheated slightly. An unthinkable crime, though, would be to sell H.I.V.-infected blood. But that's what a German company is accused of doing, either knowingly or through lax testing. The company, UB Plasma, has been shut down, its manager and others arrested. And last week the anxiety flowed across Europe, as Italy, France, Switzerland, Austria and Sweden halted the sale of the company's blood. An estimated two million Germans received the blood at hospitals. Has the profit motive run amok?
 
Can't Fight 'em? Debate 'em
Ross Perot is back. In the next week or so, he'll lug his graphs and one-liners to prime time to debate Al Gore on the North American Free Trade Agreement. Bill Clinton offered to send his second into the jaws of stand-up politics, and Mr. Perot accepted.

HEADLINE: Does Industrial Policy Work? Lessons From Sematech

BYLINE: By KATIE HAFNER; Katie Hafner, a writer living in Austin, Tex., is a co-author of "Cyberpunk: Outlaws and Hackers on the Computer Frontier."

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
THE world has changed for Sematech, the Government-subsidized consortium of semiconductor manufacturers formed amid much criticism in 1987 to rescue an industry faltering against Japan.
When its president and chief executive, William J. Spencer, goes to Washington these days, it is not so much to ask as to bask. Politicians of many stripes give Sematech a lot of the credit for the recent turnaround in the United States chip industry. President Clinton last February called Sematech "a model for Federal consortiums funded to advance other critical technologies." A Congressional hearing on the consortium last summer was more love feast than inquiry: Everyone from Gov. Ann Richards of Texas to the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, heaped praise on Sematech. 
 Other industries now hold up Sematech as an example for American industry. The aerospace industry, increasingly threatened by Europe's Airbus consortium, would benefit from proposed legislation that would create and help finance a consortium called Aerotech. American textile manufacturers have created a consortium called Amtex that receives Government assistance. And the Big Three auto companies recently announced a Government-backed partnership to design a fuel-efficient "super car."
All that euphoria aside, however, Sematech's value is still a matter of much debate. Seven years and $1.4 billion into the Sematech experiment, industry experts and leaders still disagree over how much the consortium really had to do with the industry's recovery and whether it should continue to receive Federal financing.
There are no clear answers to these questions. But as an experiment in industrial policy without precedent in the United States, Sematech has produced valuable lessons:
* It has shown that the Government should leave the management of such a consortium to the industry. By contrast, two Government-led efforts were disappointments.
* It has offered proof that, particularly in its early stages, a consortium needs a leader with a lot of credibility in the industry.
* It has not produced leaps in semiconductor-manufacturing technology. But it has helped improve existing equipment. And one way it has accomplished this is merely to force the chip manufacturers to sit down with their equipment suppliers.
* It has learned the hard way that a consortium should avoid throwing money at a troubled company, even an important supplier.
Sematech was born of desperation, the brainchild of archrivals in the semiconductor industry who saw a need to work together to recapture a market being lost to Japan.
Saving the semiconductor industry actually meant saving the equipment suppliers, the small companies that make the machines that make semiconductors. They too had once dominated the world market, but by the 1980's they were producing equipment that was far less reliable than Japanese counterparts. A further weakening of the American equipment industry would increase the chip makers' dependence on Japanese equipment, which Japan routinely held from the open market for as long as a year. If the chip industry faltered as a result, it would weaken the nation's entire electronics industry.
Sematech, based in Austin, was to be a manufacturing test bed aimed at improving the quality of American equipment.
Some in the Reagan Administration objected. But the Defense Department, concerned about its growing dependence on foreign-supplied components for advanced weaponry, supported the consortium. In 1987, Congress agreed to pay $100 million a year for Sematech, with the 14 consortium members, all semiconductor manufacturers, to contribute the same. The money would go toward building and running a chip plant, providing research grants to equipment suppliers and buying their equipment for testing.
ONE of the first departures from the traditional mold of the Government-sponsored consortium was the chip industry's insistence on management autonomy. Two Government-led efforts -- President Jimmy Carter's attempt to develop alternatives to petroleum with the Synthetic Fuels Corporation and the Pentagon's billion-dollar quest for superchips -- had both been widely viewed as unsuccessful. "Sematech is a much more sophisticated and useful model," said Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico. "We've kept industry in the management role, and we've made doubly sure they are committed by requiring cost-sharing."
A second early lesson for Sematech was that a consortium benefits from having a champion with a great deal of credibility in the industry. For a year after it was created, Sematech floundered for lack of such a person. Then, in 1988, Robert Noyce, co-inventor of the integrated circuit, agreed to run Sematech. Hundreds of engineers who had dismissed the venture as a fringe experiment jumped at the chance to work for him.
But even with Dr. Noyce as the glue, the consortium's members were hard to hold together. Cultural differences sometimes seemed insurmountable among the 250 people assigned to work at Sematech by their companies (450 others are permanent Sematech employees). I.B.M. employees, the "White Shirts," were put off by the more informal Californians from Advanced Micro Devices. A.T.& T. people were conspicuous for their secretiveness and reluctance to speak up. People from Intel were too blunt.
Finally, Dr. Noyce called in Bill Daniels, a meetings specialist from Mill Valley, Calif. Mr. Daniels employed psychological tactics to chip away at the rancor. For instance, he frequently reminded everyone that they were engaged in the economic equivalent of war against a common enemy: Japan. The point is driven home by Sematech's headquarters building here, which rivals a United States Olympic Team training camp in its decor of red, white and blue and its photos of a chip with an American flag superimposed.
Slowly, attitudes changed. The disparate work force began to talk, to share information.
After Dr. Noyce died of a heart attack in 1990, the Sematech board recruited Dr. Spencer, the chief technical officer at Xerox. Dr. Spencer, now 63, took over at a tough time. The Bush Administration was even more hostile toward industrial policy than the Reagan Administration had been, regularly trying to cut off Sematech's financing. Three of the 14 member companies quit.
But the increased communication that Dr. Noyce and his meetings consultant had encouraged produced something significant. Sematech members gradually realized that the biggest problem with manufacturing was the way the chip companies had treated their equipment suppliers. "The semiconductor industry looked at the equipment industry like used-car salesmen," said G. Dan Hutcheson, president of VLSI Research Inc., in San Jose, Calif. "The way it usually worked was that a chip maker would pit two equipment vendors against each other. So they'd get the prices down, but there was no incentive to produce reliable equipment."
By inviting in the equipment manufacturers, Sematech provided a place for engineers from both sides to discuss their needs. William Elder, chief executive of Genus Inc., a Sunnyvale, Calif., manufacturer of machines that deposit chemicals onto a chip, added that Sematech's testing plant here provides a common ground for measuring a machine's performance and establishing benchmarks.
The reliability of Mr. Elder's equipment has improved, as has that of other equipment suppliers. And the United States has increased its market share in both equipment and semiconductors.
But better communication did not prevent Sematech's most glaring misstep.
In 1989, Sematech began to pour millions of dollars into improving machines made by the GCA Corporation, a small firm in Andover, Mass., which pioneered the part of the chip-making process in which the pattern of circuitry is burned onto chips. In the 1970's and early 1980's, GCA held most of the world's market for this equipment, known as steppers. But GCA's steppers were eclipsed by superior machines from Nikon and Canon.
GCA did improve its steppers, but Sematech's member companies declared the equipment too late to the market and stayed with Japanese machines. Last May, GCA's parent, General Signal, closed the GCA plant. Analysts estimate Sematech's investment in the failed bailout at $75 million.
GCA provided a conspicuous lesson in the wrongheadedness of throwing money at an ailing, poorly managed equipment company, particularly when there is no support from potential customers. Some of Sematech's critics would go further. They say Sematech's insistence on saving American companies in an increasingly global business is the fundamental problem with Sematech.
"IT was a classic mistake in industrial policy," said George Gilder, who has written on the semiconductor industry. Mr. Gilder said that instead of trying to catch up with old technology, Sematech should have invested its money in companies working on the next generation of steppers.
Determining how much Sematech had to do with the recovery of the American chip industry is not easy. Many other factors played a role. Under a 1986 agreement with Japan, the share of chips sold in Japan by foreign companies has risen from 8 percent to about 19 percent.
THE downturn in the Japanese economy is another reason. Japan is selling fewer consumer electronics products, and therefore fewer chips. Also, American chip companies have made some smart moves. "The Democrats are holding Sematech up as an example of something going right," said Representative Robert S. Walker, Republican of Pennsylvania. "But I don't think that reflects what really happened. We made marginal improvements in our ability to manufacture chips. But in reality it was the aggressive entrepreneurial companies that regained market share."
Others are more generous.
"My sense is there's been a net benefit from the Sematech program," said Daniel L. Klesken, an analyst at Robertson Stephens & Company in San Francisco. "It's increasingly important to have a well thought out set of requirements in order to build the next generation of equipment. Sematech has provided a consistent platform."
The most difficult part of Government support for one industry may be knowing when to stop. "If the industry maintains parity with the Japanese and if it continues to be well positioned in the world market, the U.S. should reduce or eliminate support to Sematech," said Michael Borrus, an industry expert at the University of California.
But Robert W. Galvin, chairman of the executive committee of Motorola Inc. and the Sematech board, defends continued Government support for Sematech. "Here's a case where the private sector has very effectively defined a problem and shown leadership," he said. "We can do it collectively but we'll need some help if we want to do it at the same speed as the Japanese."
With some friends in the White House for a change, what started as a five-year experiment could become an industry fixture. That serves as a final lesson to industries contemplating such a solution: like taxes, industry consortiums may be more difficult to end than begin.
