HEADLINE: Profile: Laura S. Scher;
She Took One Look At the Age of Greed And Made a Quick Left

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
LAURA S. SCHER graduated from Harvard Business School near the top of her class in 1985, smack in the middle of the Decade of Greed.
Most of her classmates were seduced by the gaudy salaries and vainglorious life style of Wall Street. But not Ms. Scher, who was "put off by the idea of making so much money, by the insane hours, the New York life and the cultishness of it" and whose career goals included "wanting to do something I could believe in." 
 So she took an unpopular path in those "Bonfire of the Vanities" days and signed on as chief executive of what was then a brand new San Francisco-based company, Working Assets Funding Service, whose mission was to do well by doing good.
The company began by offering a donation-linked credit card, thought to be the first of many that followed, and then added a similar long-distance telephone service, which has recently vaulted Working Assets Funding Service and its 34-year-old chief to success.
A spin-off of Working Assets Money Market Fund, although now a separate and thriving entity, Ms. Scher's company is based on the premise that generosity can be painless if it is linked to purchases people are already making and bills they regularly pay.
Thus holders of Working Assets credit cards "donate" a nickel on each purchase to a group of charities, all eco-leftist in outlook, and customers of Working Assets long distance give away 1 percent of each monthly bill, and more than that if they elect to round up their payment to the nearest $5 or $10.
The last two years have marked a breakthrough for Working Assets, which was recently named one of the 500 fastest-growing privately held companies in America by Inc. magazine. Revenue jumped from $2 million in 1991 to $15 million in 1992 and is expected to hit $35 million this year, the bulk of it from long distance, which has seen its subscriber list grow from 5,000 to 130,000.
While these figures hardly put Working Assets in the ranks of telecommunications and banking mega-companies, they are impressive, and a credit to Ms. Scher's ability to translate a simple idea into a complex operation.
"They have a clear mission, an effective game plan and have made more and more money," said Michael A. Levett, president of Businesses for Social Responsibility, a 15-month-old association of companies with similar interests. "They tapped in early to a growing movement to judge corporations by their reputation as well as their product. And there are a growing number of people -- enough to make real profits -- who are saying, 'This is the way we want to spend our money.' "
The reason for Working Assets' recent growth spurt is three-fold, said Ms. Scher, who lives in suburban Tiburon with her husband, Ian Altman, an employee-benefits consultant, and their 3-year-old daughter, Alison. The first is sociological: the changed climate of this decade, when many baby boomers have turned from hectic have-it-all consumers to more sober let's-give-some-of-it-back members of the community.
"We're doing well because of what the 90's are about," said Ms. Scher, seated in her office beneath a wall of posters from the charities that Working Assets supports -- including Planned Parenthood, the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, the Rainforest Action League and the Coalition of the Homeless.
THE other two reasons for Working Assets' newfound success are technical and prompted by sea changes in telecommunications, which allowed Working Assets long distance to switch from being a sales agent for Sprint to being a reseller.
In the first incarnation, from 1988 to late 1990, Working Assets got a tiny marketing fee, about equal to its 1 percent charitable donation. As a reseller, the company buys telephone time in bulk at a deep discount, sells it to its customers at competitive rates and pockets the difference. It also has a discount program similar to MCI's "family and friends" promotion that cuts 25 percent off the cost when one subscriber calls another.
Also, as a reseller, Working Assets controls its own billing and has created a customized document that Ms. Scher said is her company's greatest innovation. "No one else thinks of the bill as a product," said Ms. Scher. "They think of the bill as a transaction. This is the crux of our whole operation, and this is where we have fun."
The bill, produced and processed by EUR Data Center in Mechanicsburg, Pa., allows Working Assets long-distance customers to round up their bills, paying, say, $35 instead of the $32.56 owed. "It's like the penny jar next to the cash register," Ms. Scher said.
Padding the payment this way is not possible with the Working Assets Visa or Mastercards, because they are issued and billed through the Fleet Bank of New York. The only customization with these bills, which carry a 15.4 percent interest rate, are the inserts, among them instructions on how to avoid abusing credit cards. "We'd rather they had the card for 10 years than go bankrupt in two," Ms. Scher said.
The proceeds from the round-ups -- which are tax-deductible for customers -- of the telephone bills, an average of $50,000 a month, are usually added to the charitable pot, which is distributed at year's end to several dozen groups selected by a vote of Working Assets customers and winnowed down by the directors. Since its inception, Working Assets has donated $2.5 million, with $1 million of that raised last year.
Some bill round-ups have focused on specific issues, like one last summer to buy and retire pollution credits. Under the 1990 Clean Air Act, utilities that cut emissions of sulfur dioxide, a component of acid rain, below the federally mandated level can sell the remainder of their allowance. The Working Assets program bought $60,000 worth of credits and took them off the market. That worked out to 600,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide, which Ms. Scher said was "a drop in the bucket" but perhaps "a catalyst for other people to do the same."
The customized phone bill also allows Working Assets to promote timely causes and tell subscribers which corporate and political decision-makers to call or write to have their opinions heard. Those calls are free on the first Monday of each month and discounted the rest of the time.
Leaders contacted this year, at the rate of 25,000 calls and letters a month, include the chief executive of McDonald's (supporting veggie burgers), the chairman of the Federal Reserve (opposing red-lining), the head of the Environmental Protection Agency (opposing toxic-waste incinerators near schools) and the Governor of California (opposing proposals to penalize immigrants).
"Now we have a lobbying tool as opposed to just a fund-raising tool," Ms. Scher said.
Working Assets Funding Service was the brainchild of Peter Barnes, one founder of the Working Assets money market fund. Mr. Barnes was marketing vice president for the fund, which was founded in 1983, when he decided that a product or service linked to charitable donations might be a more popular way for consumers to back what they believe in because people spend more than they save and because many people lack the $1,000 needed to open a money market fund.
He hired Ms. Scher as chief executive of a fledgling company that would launch a donation-linked credit card and then figure out what other avenues to pursue. Then, in 1988, Working Assets Funding Service split from the parent company, eager to use its revenues to market its own products rather than the money market fund, which has about $250 million in assets. In 1991, the money fund was sold to Sophia Collier, founder of Soho Soda, who still uses the name under a licensing agreement with Ms. Scher's company.
"It makes sense for them to be separate," said Mr. Levett. "Their socially responsible component is all that blends them. They're really no more alike than Bear, Stearns and the Baby Bells."
BUT customers drawn to the company are not as a rule comparing prices. "People that would be joining aren't likely to be penny-pinchers," said Daniel Briere, president of TeleChoice, a New Jersey consulting firm.
Working Assets understands exactly who its target customers are. According to a recent survey, more than a quarter are from California and 10 percent from New York, 98 percent vote (most of them for Democrats), 7 of 10 are college-educated (more than a third have graduate degrees), and more of them listen to National Public Radio than watch television.
And the marketing strategy preaches to that choir. Working Assets long distance, for instance, bills itself as the only telephone company that is endorsed by Ralph Nader and Gloria Steinem, the only one to offer a free pint of Ben & Jerry's ice cream to new subscribers, the only one to print its bills on 100 percent post-consumer recycled paper with soy-based ink, the only one to plant 17 trees for each ton of paper used. And the only one with a woman as chief executive.
MS. SCHER, a native of Clifton, N.J., comes to the task naturally, in terms of both business and politics.
Her father owned a small chemical company that is now, after his death, run by her older brother, who says he would rather be rock climbing or cross-country skiing. Her mother is a professor of economics at Montclair State College in New Jersey and a former head of the economics department.
Ms. Scher describes her family, including a younger sister who is a family doctor in the rural reaches of Northern California, as "liberal and concerned" and recalls a childhood of licking stamps for local candidates and celebrating Earth Day on the banks of the Passaic River.
To the extent that she had an epiphany about her own career, Ms. Scher said, it came during recruiting season at Harvard Business School, when the best and brightest at the Wall Street firms came courting the star students.
"I would go to all these dinners with people who told me how much money they made," she said. "It didn't excite me at all."
Ms. Scher will not disclose her pay at Working Assets, a privately held 45-member company. In general, she said, lower-ranked employees make competitive wages while those at the upper echelons pay dearly for their career choice.
"What I earn is lower -- much, much lower -- than anyone at a comparable-sized company," she said. "But there's a lot of job satisfaction other than salary."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST NEW YORK;
After a Small Respite, Murders Soar in the 75th

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
On a recent chilly morning, Allan Bouser was keeping warm in his red Toyota Corolla parked at a curb near Alabama and Cozine Avenues when six gunshots rang out. Two bullets shattered the car's rear window and tore through Mr. Bouser's back and left arm. He died a couple of hours later. The motive is unknown, according to the police.
An hour and 15 minutes later, as the same chill hung in the air and not far away, Freddie Furpie was talking to his girlfriend at a pay phone on the corner of Sutter and Crescent Avenues when more gunfire rang out. 
 His voice disappeared as a single bullet ripped through his left shoulder and he fell to the ground mortally wounded. The receiver dangled from its cord above him as his girlfriend screamed his name. The motive is unknown, but he is thought to have been an unintended victim.
These were the 105th and 106th killings in East New York in the first 10 months of this year. The 75th Precinct, which encompasses East New York, leads the city in homicides, and investigators are bracing for a record year.
So far, the killings have surpassed last year's 92 homicides in the precinct.
In 1991, a record 115 people were killed in East New York; that record should fall in about a week, said Lieut. Kevin J. Perham. He said the precinct may even surpass the city record for a precinct, set in the 28th Precinct, in Harlem, in 1976, when 123 people were killed.
The shootings of Mr. Bouser and Mr. Furpie are apparently unrelated, said Lieutenant Perham, who heads the 75th Precinct's detective squad. The killings occurred on Tuesday. Mr. Bouser, 37, of 721 Monroe Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, was shot at 6:15 A.M., and Mr. Furpie, 26, of 1140 Manor Avenue in Hunts Point, the Bronx, was shot at 7:30 A.M. They both died at 9:30 A.M. at Brookdale Hospital.
Asked why the number of killings in the precinct had risen again after falling considerably last year, the police said they had few answers beyond the thriving drug trade in this community pockmarked by urban decay, unemployment and crowded, ramshackle homes, apartments and classrooms.
"There are a lot of legitimate people here," Lieutenant Perham said. "There are a lot of people who live in nice homes, get up and go to work and school. And there are a lot who stand on corners and sell drugs. The competition for these corners and customers just dictates that people will be shooting each other."
Lieutenant Perham, whose voice dripped with frustration, said it's almost impossible to prevent murders. But, he added, the police try to combat the conditions that lead to homicides, like prostitution and drug dealing.
Six months ago, when the crime rate began to soar in the 75th Precinct, Community Board 5 formed a team to work with the precinct to fight the problem, said Earl Williams, chairman of the board. They meet to talk about problem areas and what can be done. The police assign more officers or squads like Special Narcotics Units to hot spots of prostitution or drug dealing.
Does it help? "It's like proving a negative," Lieutenant Perham said. "How do you know that that prevents homicides?"
Mr. Williams said: "Lord knows we have enough youth programs and everything going on. We're searching hard to find answers." L.H.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PORT MORRIS/HUNTS POINT;
Resurrecting A Rail Yard: A New Hitch

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
For decades, the Harlem River Rail Yard has been abandoned, a forlorn stretch of rickety tracks in Port Morris that once teemed with freight cars transporting coal, lumber and other cargo. A proposal to resurrect the yard would create jobs and revitalize the sagging neighborhood, supporters say. Critics of the plan say it doesn't go far enough to reduce dependence on trucks.
The State Department of Transportation expects to release its final environmental study next month on a plan to convert 28 acres of the sprawling rail yard into a revitalized hub for transporting freight. 
 If the project is deemed environmentally sound, it will take a major step toward construction. But critics, including merchants, residents and others, say the $250 million project is not the best use of one of the last remaining rail yards in a city that largely relies on trucks for shipping goods. The nearest active rail yards for freight are in New Jersey.
The debate is the latest hitch in the state's effort to reactivate the 98 acres on the waterfront near Yankee Stadium. In the early 1980's, the state considered reactivating 70 acres of the rail yard, but the plan was stalled by budget constraints.
Whatever happens, the dilapidated landscape of Port Morris will probably be changed forever.
Under the latest proposal, at least 40 acres have been set aside for developers who would rely on rail service. Supporters, including planners with the Bronx Borough President's office, say that this aspect would insure the creation of new jobs. The state has signed a 99-year lease with a private developer, the Harlem River Yard Venture Corporation, to carry out the project.
"We want to get the most of that yard as we possibly could get out of it," said Paul Pastecki, the supervisor for the project coordinating section of the State Commercial Transportation Division.
Opponents say that the plan for the yard is not extensive enough to reduce the city's dependency on trucks. They dismiss as unproved the state's contention that the new yard could handle 150,000 trucks a year.
"If we start giving away parts of the rail yard now, there won't be any left when it becomes clear how important it will be for the city in the future," said Alisa Eilenberg, president of the Riverdale Committee for Clean Air, which opposes the plan. "We need to take polluting vehicles off our roads as much as possible."
Nick Unger, the political director for New York's Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, said that the plan is shortsighted because it surrenders property that could be used to expand the transportation network.
"It's penny-foolish and pound-foolish," he said. "Cutting out the potential for this kind of transportation kills the potential for economic development in New York."
But Mr. Pastecki said many questions have been raised by a preliminary study that was released this summer, including a question about the capacity of the proposed freight transfer point, where trucks would deliver cargoes for transfer to trains.
Mr. Pastecki said the study to be released next month would address concerns about capacity. RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

HEADLINE: Price Rises Explain Low Yankee Attendance

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I wonder if all the commentators who talk about the area around Yankee Stadium as unsafe actually buy tickets to see the games. If they did, they would know that the immediate neighborhood is fine. The real reason for declining attendance in the last few years is the price of tickets. That includes general admission, up from $8 in 1989 to $10.50 (which is to say from a price competitive with a movie to one that isn't), and backless bleacher seats, up from $4.50 to $6.50. 
 Most of us would say that anyone raising prices in an economic slump is either a fool or a schemer. The scheme here is using self-induced lower attendance as a rationale for deserving public funds.
 
RICHARD KOSTELANETZ
Manhattan

HEADLINE: Poverty Is No Excuse, But It Doesn't Help

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his Oct. 10 essay, "Alibis for Educational Failure," Michael Meyers criticized the new school performance scale that "allows for social and economic differences among students' families." According to Mr. Meyers, looking at differences among students' families provides a way of "letting teachers off the hook."
Indeed, there is ample evidence to support Mr. Meyers's view that higher teacher expectations and changed learning environments produce improved student outcomes. But there is also ample evidence that other variables have considerable impact. The amount spent per student is just one of these variables; it is reflected in leaky roofs and peeling paint versus well-maintained and cheery buildings, in class size or teacher-student ratio, in availability of guidance counselors and social workers, and in access to computers and books. 
 Both by making direct contributions to their children's schools and by wielding the political power to divert resources inequitably toward these schools, families of higher social and economic status increase the likelihood that their children's schools will be successful in educating whichever children attend them.
Of course, poor children can be educated, and their poverty should not be used as an excuse. But as a psychologist who has worked in the schools, I recognize the need for greater resources than our society has been willing to supply for children who are poorly motivated, angry about lack of nurturing and security, neurologically damaged from malnutrition, ingestion of lead or prenatal drug exposure. Teacher-bashing is an easy but incorrect and fundamentally lazy explanation that will not solve the problem.
 
NORMA J. HART
Manhattan

HEADLINE: THE NATION: Switching Brands;
Cranky Voters Fire Everyone In Sight

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
DAVID STEWART, a professor of marketing at the University of Southern California and an expert on consumer behavior, compares voting to shopping for something you don't particularly want to buy, like toilet paper. "Where customer satisfaction is not high, you see a lot of switching," he said. "I'll buy one I haven't tried recently."
He is not alone in thinking that way. In a world without strong party or ideological identifications, voters do look increasingly like shoppers in the American marketplace. They become isolated decision-makers whose choices depend essentially on the information and attitudes they pick up from the mass media, especially television. 
 Consumers are known to be readily manipulated -- something that advertisers and professional political consultants bank on. And certainly campaigns these days look a lot like product roll-outs.
But, as they will tell you at Macy's the day after Christmas, there is a dark side to every shopper. In a world where advertising mobilizes desire, commitments are almost inevitably short-lived.
And that might explain what happened this last Tuesday just as well as the theory, enthusiastically promoted by Republicans, that President Clinton had been placed on the scale and found wanting. Americans were disappointed with his meager achievements, his liberal agenda, his sweeping vision for health care security. And so, the theory went, they booted their local Democratic mayors and governors out of office.
But above all, Americans seemed to be just plain impatient. Two records were set on Tuesday, both for brevity. David N. Dinkins became the first black mayor of a major city who failed to win his first re-election bid. Jim Florio became the first New Jersey Governor to be defeated for a second term in a general election.
Moreover, in New York City and in the state of Maine, voters opted to institutionalize impermanence by imposing term limits on a variety of officeholders. In New Jersey, they went one step further, voting themselves the right to recall any elected official in the state after a year.
 
A Time to Pay Up
 This time around, it may be President Clinton and his party who are paying the price of voter restlessness. But, arguably, it is only 12 months since they benefited from exactly the same trend.
Last November, when restive voters sent George Bush back to Texas, they created the largest contingent of living former Presidents since 1861, enough to field an eminent, if somewhat out-of-breath, basketball team.
"If you want to know what happened on Tuesday," said Pat Caddell, a political consultant, "just go back to 1992."
To be sure, there were also local factors at work that had a determining impact in all the major races. In New York, where Mayor Dinkins won practically all of the black votes and Rudolph W. Giuliani took three-quarters of the white vote, race was clearly more at issue than national politics. So, for that matter, were crime and homelessness and dangerous schools, problems that could make Mr. Giuliani wonder if the people will get tired of him even before he takes office.
In New Jersey, Mr. Florio paid for pushing through a $2.8 billion tax increase and doing so, in the eyes of many New Jerseyans, with infuriating arrogance. (Even so, he came within two percentage points of winning re-election against the Republican Christine Todd Whitman, who had given Senator Bill Bradley a big scare in his last re-election campaign.)
And in Virginia, George F. Allen, a conservative Republican, defeated former state Attorney General Mary Sue Terry. She suffered from the contagious unpopularity of the state's two leading Democratic officials, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder and Senator Charles S. Robb, who have spent most of the last few years feuding with each other. It didn't help that, after 12 years of Democratic rule, the state's once-robust economy is in a funk.
 
Someone to Count On
 The results clearly fit within a larger pattern that political scientists have been plotting for the last few years. Americans, who had been historically indulgent toward incumbents, have become uncreasingly unwilling to give them the benefit of the doubt -- or second terms. This is especially true for executives in high-visibility jobs like mayor, governor or President.
"There are fewer people now who you can count on," said Cliff Zukin, a professor at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. "More people are susceptible to the impulse, 'I don't like what I have, let's change.' "
There used to be some powerful institutions working against this impulse. The party machine, for example, fostered long-term commitments and could be counted on to deliver large blocks of votes. The same was true of unions.
Even the Soviet Union helped in its own way. The existence of a Red Menace lent debates in national politics, and even to a certain extent those in local politics, an underpinning of ideology. (Consider the fight over the Staten Island home port, which aroused intense local opposition, in part because of fears that Navy ships berthed there would carry nuclear weapons.)
"Now, no one pays attention to parties, and the cold war has ended," said Darrell West, a professor of political science at Brown University. "There are no paradigms to replace that, and so our decisions are more short-term in nature."
Americans say that one of the main reasons they are so dissatisfied with their government is that politicians have become increasingly self-centered. In polls and interviews, they complain that their elected officials are more occupied with their own plans for re-election than with the public interest.
Proponents of term limits cite this as one of their principal motivations; maybe if politicians knew they were going to have to leave, they say, they would be willing to take some risks. It's hard to believe, though, that last week's electoral turnover will make politicians any less risk-averse.
Many politicians, particularly many White House officials, were watching the New Jersey election as a sign of whether it was possible in these recessionary times to raise taxes and live to see another inauguration. The lesson they may have taken from Mr. Florio's fate is that it is not.
At the same time, the results in New York City suggest that caution has its dangers, too.
Mr. Dinkins was perceived as a kindly, but basically ineffectual, mayor. Mr. Giuliani promised an administration that would put more drug dealers in jail and deal more aggressively with the problem of the homeless. In a city that seems on the edge of unraveling, where "quality of life" means such basics as being able to walk on clean streets and being free of strangers who insist on washing your windshield, that helped him win the election.
Some analysts say that incumbents will have a hard time for as long as there are hard times. With government resources so scarce, candidates are bound to make promises that, once in office, they find they can't keep.
And so they, in turn, will be replaced by different politicians, who also don't keep their promises. Sam Popkin, a professor of political science at the University of California at San Diego, predicts "musical chairs."
"We'll play musical chairs at this level," he said, "until someone comes up with an economic upturn."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Debris of Past Failures Impedes Poverty Policy

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON may be presiding over the first activist government with doubts about activist government.
The Old Executive Office Building is filled with policy planners working overtime. They are plotting revolutions in health care and welfare, overhauling job-training and child care programs and mapping the "empowerment zones" meant to revive cities. 
 But this is not an unschooled crowd. Some of the Clinton planners are scholars who have spent decades studying the unintended effects of social reform. They embrace government, but they realize that social programs often cost more and do less than intended -- and that government itself can be the enemy.
And nowhere does the need for government action and the distrust of it collide more sharply than in anti-poverty policy. The abiding national assumption is that everything has been tried and nothing has worked.
Today one in four American children live in the cramped, mean place called "beneath the poverty line." For a mother with two children, that's $11,300.
But what politician would dare call for another war on poverty? In the millions of words uttered on the topic, none linger more convincingly in the public mind that Ronald Reagan's perfect-pitch quip: we fought a war on poverty, "and poverty won."
Is it true? Is poverty policy a god that failed?
The answers begin in the reams of studies documenting disappointments in housing, welfare, job training, education and other programs. Although the failures have been real, they have also been judged in a harsh light. (After all, the Pentagon produced the $435 hammer without discrediting the very notion of defense policy.)
 
A Grudge About Race
 The Government's defenders argue that the country has forgotten its successes, exaggerated its failures and blamed poverty programs for problems beyond their control -- most notably the wage stagnation and family breakdown that have plagued other countries, too.
And as Professor Hugh Heclo of George Mason University has argued, the grudge against poverty programs is sometimes a grudge about the racial minorities who use them disproportionately, one that is exploited by politicians. "Today, as always, it remains politically easier to engender resentment against the weak than against the powerful," he has written.
In retrospect, the confidence espoused by the early antipoverty theorists seems impossibly innocent. As late as 1971, Robert Lampman, one of the theorists who worked for Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, was still predicting poverty's demise by 1980.
The percentage of Americans living in poverty did steadily decline, to 11 percent in 1973 from 23 percent in 1959. Then oil shocks and stagflation arrived, and the poverty rate has never again been so low. It is now 14.5 percent.
Other indices of well-being also plummeted. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, then a Labor Department official, found it shocking in 1965 that a quarter of the nation's black children were born to single women. Now a quarter of all American children are born to single women. And the figure for blacks has risen to two-thirds. Almost three-quarters of black children spend at least a year on welfare before age 18.
And government programs sometimes seem only to make things worse. New York City officials discovered as much when they began moving homeless people to the head of the long lines awaiting public housing. The result, researchers found, was that more and more people began declaring themselves homeless.
The Federal Job Training Partnership Act tried to boost the earnings of young men who had dropped out of school. Last year, a major study announced the results: those enrolled in the program earned 8 percent less than those who were given no training.
Nathan Glazer, the Harvard professor who is one the nation's leading social policy skeptics, said the disappointing results have become the norm. "When we try to get into such complex issues as family behavior or crime or school achievement, government just hasn't been very good," he said.
Partly, he argues, that is because decisions like whether to work or study, have children or marry are complex ones beyond the reach of social workers. And government programs, he says, are difficult to change, since interest groups inevitably grow up around them.
Defenses of poverty policy generally fall into three categories. One argument is that the country fails to appreciate its successes. The Social Security system is the favorite example. After a series of benefit increases, the poverty rate among the elderly dropped from 29 percent in 1965 to just 13 percent last year. That is a success, but no politician has stood up and crowed, "We fought a war on poverty -- and we won!"
 
Beyond Policy's Reach
 A second argument is that the financing of the war on poverty never kept pace with its rhetoric -- the battle was never really fought. At its height in 1969, the Office of Economic Opportunity, the era's main anti-poverty agency, never spent more than $2 billion a year.
Today total housing, welfare and health care expenditures for poor people total in the hundreds of billions. But, as Gary Burtless of the Brookings Institution has written, "many of the most costly programs do not even aim to reduce poverty." They aim to cushion its effects by giving people housing, health care and nutritional assistance. Judged on those terms, he argues, they more or less succeed.
And a third defense of poverty policy is that it has been thwarted by events largely beyond its control. The rise in single-parent families -- a phenomenon that is occurring across the industrialized world -- accounts for a large part of the nation's poverty problem.
So does the state of the general economy, clearly the most important factor in the fight against poverty. Anti-poverty initiatives have had to contend with two decades of economic shifts that have depressed wages of workers with few or no skills.
"Part of the reason that people perceive that anti-poverty policy doesn't work is that the policy has been swimming upstream," said Robert Haveman, an economist at the University of Wisconsin. "The private sector has been throwing low-skilled people out of jobs they've held for a long time."
The White House understands both the raw needs on the street and the legacy of past social policy failures. Some of its proposals stem from the confidence of success, while others come from the fear of doing nothing at all.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: Urger to Splurge;
Mexico's Hunger for U.S. Goods Is Helping to Sell the Trade Pact

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
PITCHMEN for the North American Free Trade Agreement always focus on the consumer paradise presented by Mexico's young and growing population: 85 million people, more than half of them under 25 years old, with slowly rising wages but a seemingly insatiable appetite for things made in the U.S.A.
In fact, trade with Mexico already is big business. Mexico imports more than $42 billion in goods and services from the United States, more than three times what it was in 1986, when the Government began lowering tariffs on imports so that some American goods could compete with their less desirable Mexican imitations. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, an old Mexico hand, says that with Nafta, trade with Mexico will grow by another $10 billion in three years. 
 No doubt the argument that Mexico offers vast trade opportunities will be made Tuesday night as Vice President Al Gore presents the Clinton Administration's case for the accord in a televised debate with Ross Perot, Nafta's chief critic. President Clinton, who last week escalated his campaign for approval of the agreement in the face of its discouraging prospects in a scheduled vote in the House a week from Wednesday, is working hard to convince Congress that rising trade with Mexico will more than make up for the American jobs that could be lost because of lower wages south of the border.
For those already involved in the Mexican market, the demand for American products is obvious. Mexicans spent $450 per capita on American goods in 1992, more than consumers in Japan or European countries. The Marlboro man still gallops headlong across television screens here. Wal-Mart recently opened a megacenter in a working-class neighborhood in Mexico City, and J.C. Penney and Kmart will be here soon too. Compact disks can now be bought at Tower Records, mufflers can be replaced at Midas and, at select supermarkets, shoppers can take advantage of promotions offering a stack of fresh corn tortillas free with the purchase of Hostess hamburger rolls.
But although more than 70 percent of everything Mexico imports comes from the United States, not everything American sells. And there is evidence that Mexican consumers could turn fickle once the novelty of widely available American goods wears off. More problematic for American exporters, traditional market research has rarely been able to crack the intricacies of Mexico, where much income is unreported and households routinely cover several generations.
"Even the best statistician would have the hardest time here," said Juan Suberville, general director of two Kmart stores set to open on Mexico City's outskirts next spring. "Mostly, you work on gut feelings."
Taco Bell found out the hard way. Intent on grabbing a niche in Mexico, the Pepsico subsidiary conducted market research that suggested that its fast-food expertise and consistent product could overcome the coals-to-Newcastle disadvantages of trying to sell American tacos here. It opened a stand in a Mexico City parking lot last year and planned 25 more in a year.
 
Opening the Doors
 But only three others ever opened, and none is a runaway success. Company officials say their mistake was to focus too much on Mexican manners, changing their menu and style to be more authentically Mexican. It turned out that what Mexicans wanted was authentically American tacos served in a clean restaurant away from traffic fumes.
The Taco Bell experience is one of many indicators that what Mexicans want most is what they couldn't buy before. When the country's economy was closed to most American goods, Mexicans couldn't buy the Raisinettes or Frosted Flakes they saw on imported television programs and in movies -- only weak imitations.
Under President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, Mexico has been intent on dismantling its import-substitution economy and opening its markets. The doors were cracked ajar in the mid-1980's by lowered tariffs on imported goods. Nafta, which would end tariffs and other trade barriers among the United States, Canada and Mexico over 15 years, would complete the opening of Mexico's economy to the north.
Tariffs act as taxes, artificially pushing up prices. Reduce them, as happened in the 1980's, and suddenly imports start showing up on store shelves. At first, Mexicans couldn't get their fill of imported products like Coca-Cola in cans, which until then had been unavailable. But when the novelty died down, people realized they were paying two and three times what it cost for a Mexican-made Coke, and the American-made version didn't even taste as good. North of the border Coca-Cola is made with corn syrup, while Mexican Coke uses sugar, and Mexicans say they can taste the difference.
"Mexicans are willing to try something new," said Francisco Sanchez-Loaeza, president of Panamerican Beverages, the largest Coca-Cola bottler outside the United States. "But they are becoming more and more demanding."
Coca-Cola was one of a limited number of American products available even when the Mexican economy was closed. Mexicans drink more soda than any other people except those in the United States, in part because drinking water here is so risky. Coca-Cola controls 55 percent of the market and, with Government restrictions lifted, is flooding the market with previously unavailable flavors and bottle sizes, including non-returnable two-liter monsters.
 
Changing Habits
 A big question is how much and how quickly Mexicans will change their shopping habits. Most Mexicans still shop at small stores and street stands -- not surprising in a country where street vending has been well established since Aztec times. They go to the store on average eight times a week, while shoppers in the United States go twice. Tortillas, the Mexican staple, are a big factor, because fresh tortillas, made without preservatives, are considered inedible after a day.
But habits are changing. Enrique Legoretta, commercial director in Mexico City for the A.C. Nielsen market-research concern, said that once Mexican consumers glimpse the new consumer world, small stores just don't hold their attention any more. In some ways, Mexicans have shown themselves willing to change their whole concept of shopping. The Price Club has opened two successful stores in Mexico City that are about as different from the street-corner mom-and-pop as can be. The stores are warehouses, selling institutional-size cans of peaches and rolls of toilet paper by the dozen. A typical trip requires at least $100 and a car to haul the booty home. With an average income of anywhere from $3,000 to $43,000 a year, and many families without cars, Mexico seems an unlikely fit for the Price Club.
But Robert Price, the chairman of the company, said he has done well by targeting the top 10 to 15 percent of Mexicans, those with cars and salaries above $43,000 a year. "We've found that Mexicans at that level are more committed to consumerism than Americans," he said. He said if the trade accord passes, fully a quarter of all Mexicans will wind up in the high-income bracket.
Retailers and free trade supporters are also betting on a similar increase in buying power. They know by experience that the sheen of American products could wear off, but say a trade accord ending tariffs, and therefore lowering consumer prices, would mean that they could successfully compete with domestic products.
For now, imports are still getting a boost from the curiosity built up over so many years of living right alongside the biggest marketplace in the world without being able to fully participate in it.
That was what brought Alicia and Esperanza Rendon Huerta to the new Wal-Mart in Mexico City a recent afternoon. The sisters, both in their 60's, spent more than 500 pesos, almost $200, on many things they admitted they didn't really need, including cookies, napkins and several two-liter bottles of Coke.
"We wanted to see what it was like," they said.
No one really knows whether Nafta would make Mexican wages rise or change what Mexicans buy. But it seems certain that markets on both sides of the Rio Grande are coming together. The new Wal-Mart sells tequilla glasses made in the United States and Superman pajamas made in Mexico. At last count, salsa was outselling catsup in the United States. And Wonder Bread is baking "authentic" soft tortillas.

HEADLINE: THE NATION: Gauging a 'Cold Wind' in the Work Force;
How the Job Count Is Off

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
THE Labor Department issued its monthly report on the health of the nation's labor force on Friday, but for millions of Americans, the unemployment rate has lost its meaning as a gauge of their well-being. For them, it will take some measure not yet invented to accurately capture their experiences.
By the Labor Department's standard, a Harvard graduate who once owned a business and now sells diet formula door-to-door is employed, not unemployed. So is a technician forced out of I.B.M. and now stacking shopping carts. The unemployment rate has declined to 6.8 percent in October from 7.8 percent in June 1992, but the sheer fact of holding a job does not mean, as it once did, that a jobholder feels safely ensconced in the economy. 
 "We fasten on the unemployment rate as a guide to the economy," said James Hechtman, a University of Chicago labor economist. "But the fact is that it was never all that satisfactory, and now it is much less so."
Measuring the labor force today has become similar to measuring the windchill factor in weather reporting. The unemployment rate -- up one tenth of a point since September -- is the "temperature" on a windless day. And the buffeting that people are taking in lost job status, in lost income and damage to self-confidence represents a stiff, cold wind. Various efforts are now being made to clock this rising wind. Even the Labor Department notes its existence.
"We are telling people who ask that the unemployment rate should not be viewed as a hardship measure," said John E. Bregger, an economist in the Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. "The unemployment rate is only what it pretends to be: the proportion of the labor force out of work and hunting for jobs."
While times have changed, the Labor Department's statistical tools haven't. The monthly survey of 60,000 households that the department uses to determine the unemployment rate dates back to the 1940's, when jobholders generally enjoyed more security than they do today, and wages for most people went up each year by more than inflation, instead of failing to do so -- the case today. In such a world, the questions asked by the interviewer were easy to answer, and much more representative of actual conditions.
If people said that, during the week before the survey, they had worked for a company or for the Government or for themselves, as doctors, plumbers and the like, then the interviewer put them down as jobholders. Or they told the interviewer that they had not held a job the previous week, but had looked for one. That qualified them as unemployed. And in those days, a person without a job looked for work and usually found it.
There was not, as there is today, a huge contingent of men in their 40's and 50's who have given up. Rather than hunt futilely for work or accept a pay cut, they declare themselves retired. That makes them, in the household survey, neither employed nor unemployed. What's more, in earlier days, the unemployed were often blue-collar workers on temporary layoff. This year, for the first time, the white-collar unemployed -- mostly permanent job losers -- outnumber the blue-collar jobless.
Finally, the survey was not designed for the likes of John Strong and Thomas A. Stalker, jobholders whose declining incomes dampen the economy.
Mr. Strong, 52, had worked at I.B.M. for 16 years, his last post bringing him $32,000 a year as a senior technician. Rather than wait to be laid off, Mr. Strong said, he took a buyout in 1992 -- four years short of qualifying for a pension. He'll still get the early-retirement pension at age 55, but until then he needs income. So in August, he rejoined the ranks of the employed. He earns less than $13,000 a year at the new Wal-Mart store in Fishkill, N.Y., greeting customers and stacking shopping carts.
Mr. Stalker, Harvard class of 1958, took over the family lumber and flooring business near Boston. It folded in 1989. Since then, he has been variously unemployed, a jobholder and out of the labor force.
"If the Labor Department had asked me a week ago about my status, I would have said that I was out of work and job-hunting," Mr. Stalker said, listing the two criteria for unemployment. "But a fellow has just brought me some of his inventory of diet formula, which I am selling, and now I consider myself self-employed."
Attempting to measure what the Labor Department misses, James Medoff, a Harvard labor economist, has created an index that covers incomes as well as jobs -- not unlike the late Arthur Okun's "misery index," a measure of the economy based on inflation and unemployment. The Labor Research Association, supported by unions, has devised an index that includes things like duration of unemployment (lengthening lately) and help-wanted ads (fewer per unemployed worker than in the 1980's). And the University of Michigan's Consumer Research Center is trying to better measure attitudes about jobs.
Even the Labor Department compiles a quarterly index that takes into account part-time workers as well as people too discouraged to look for jobs. The result is an unemployment rate of 10.2 percent -- well above the publicized monthly rate.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: The U.N. and Problem Nations

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN

DATELINE: Reasoned Discourse Is In, Corporal Punishment Is Out

 BODY:
FROM ancient days to the more modern era of colonialism, big and powerful governments had a variety of tactics to choose from when trying to quiet smaller, uppity and rebellious peoples and maintain order. They could resort to tribal subventions, which meant bribing people to behave themselves. They could mount punitive expeditions to cow obstreperous outlanders. They could even banish local leaders, sending them into exile in some far area of empire.
These days, as tasks of establishing order in imploding countries and suppressing the ambitions of remote satraps and tin-pot tyrants fall more and more to multinational organizations, it is obvious that so far neither the United Nations, nor the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, nor the European Community, nor other regional associations have found ways of doing any such thing. 
 Instead, in a world where all sovereignties are at least technically regarded as equal, the weapons with which the powerful address crises in Haiti, Somalia, Bosnia and other places have been limited to embargoes, seemingly endless discussion, moral suasion and low-caliber peacekeeping. Where a British viceroy in New Delhi might have ordered a column to march with flags flying in a show of force through a restive Baluchistan, today great powers are more likely to gather together and jawbone the situation -- watering down their individual responsibility, resolve and initiative in the process.
Such diminished assertiveness had the United States, which once saw fit to militarily occupy Haiti for 19 years, last week struggling to fine tune rather than broaden an embargo that draws its rationale not from the Monroe Doctrine but from a United Nations decision. And last month it ordered a naval vessel carrying military personnel in support of a peace plan to retreat over the horizon as thugs in Port-au-Prince harbor chanted rude slogans.
Deploring the timid responses to what has been happening in Bosnia, Vaclav Havel, the Czech President, in a speech last month recalled earlier tragedies of appeasement in Europe. "We talk and talk, we drown in compromises, we redraw the maps, we read the lips of the ethnic cleansers," he said, "and, with increasingly serious consequences, we forget the fundamental values upon which we would like to shape the future of our continent."
Actually, the contemporary approaches have not always proved ineffective. International embargoes similar to the ones the ones currently being applied to Haiti and Serbia have worked to alter what was held to be unacceptable behavior in places like Rhodesia and South Africa. But as the experience of those countries shows, sanctions tend to work very slowly, sometimes taking more than a decade for their bite to prove decisive.
And it is worth recalling that the old ways were often abused to maintain not so much peace as the exploitative relationship of colonial master and subject. Punitive expeditions and the bribery or subversion of local figures were probably carried out more often in pursuit of such imperial aims as conquering land, acquiring monopolies, protecting slave routes and opening up the opium trade than they were in quelling factional slaughter.
Still, there was an efficacy and directness in older gunboat diplomacy that must seem enviable to diplomats who have been trying to curb or prevent killing in places like Serbia, Somalia, Liberia, Angola and Cambodia -- all places where, in contrast with the zones of colonial conflict, the major industrial powers have debatable interests, if any at all. In places where the interests of more powerful states have been clear -- like those of the Americans, British and French in Kuwait; the Americans in Grenada and Panama; the British in the Falkland Islands; the Israelis in Lebanon -- punitive operations have been successfully mounted.
The motives for those interventions were more like those of an earlier era when armies set out unabashedly to punish, to frighten and sometimes to occupy. They differ from those current hot spots where the rationales for interference make use of a more positive vocabulary: to insure humanitarian assistance, build confidence, provide peacekeeping, pave the way for elections and entrench or advance democracy.
 
Bribes for Peace
 All of this is obviously more compassionate and sensitive, more tolerant of the sovereignty of weak states even when it seems their elites may have run amok or when in fact no sovereign state exists, as in Somalia. But what happens when what is needed is something that might work more quickly than sanctions? When what is needed is precisely to punish, to frighten, or to bribe?
Somalia is the most obvious case. Never really members of a nation state, the Somalis range over a large and desolate area of East Africa, organized in clans. During the colonial division of Africa, when these lands were partitioned into British Somaliland, Italian Somaliland and French Somaliland, peace was often maintained by the payment of tribute to clan chiefs by foreign patrons, though with forces like the French Foreign Legion standing by should sterner measures be required. Then, in the period of superpower rivalry, it was first the Russians who provided the subventions and then, in the mid-1970's, the Americans.
For a long time, such arrangements formed the basis of Somali dealings with the outside world. It is not unreasonable, given the history of the region, that local chieftains may regard payments of such tribute as honorable mechanisms of peacekeeping. But these days who is to pay? The United Nations has no such capability.
Nor does the United Nations or any other international organization seem to have much stomach for administering punishment or even identifying culprits (the United Nations tribunal set up for war crimes committed in the former Yugoslavia has not yet proven its effectiveness). If everybody is a member of the United Nations, if everybody is sovereign, it is difficult for anyone to label anyone else a bad guy. And yet there still really are bad guys.
For the last 16 months there has been no doubt that the Government of Serbia spawned and fanned and continues to back a war against the Muslim population of Bosnia, bringing about a level of terror and destruction unseen in Europe since World War II. Slapped with sanctions, but with not a single allied bomb dropped on its forces or bridges, Serbia and its President, Slobodan Milosevic, have prevailed. The Muslim nation has been dispossessed and the control of most of its land has been lost. Mr. Milosevic tested the resolve of those he had appalled and when all he heard was talk of economic sanctions, humanitarian aid and the positioning of vulnerable peacekeepers, he held to his plan.
Now, facing the faits accomplis of so many refugees, so much land ethnically cleansed, the prospect of punitive intervention seems to have evaporated. One can only wonder how different the situation might be today if a year and a half ago military commanders in Serbia were made through heat of fire to feel that they and their allies in Bosnia were truly subject to attack.

HEADLINE: Clinton Calls Trade Debate World Issue

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
As President Clinton has thrown himself into the campaign to win approval for the free-trade agreement with Mexico and Canada, he has shifted away from emphasizing its impact on jobs and begun to stress a different argument -- that failure to pass the accord will undermine American foreign policy.
The shift in emphasis is in part a campaign tactic. White House polling experts are convinced that the public and Congress tend to defer more to the President on foreign policy issues than they do on domestic or economic ones. So Mr. Clinton has made a conscious effort, they say, to cast the debate on the North American Free Trade Agreement as a virtual foreign policy crisis. 
 But it is a strategy that carries risks. If approval of Nafta is vital to foreign policy and Mr. Clinton fails to secure its passage, the message to the allies would be that he could not deliver on one of the most crucial issues in American foreign policy today. Rejection of Nafta, coming after policy retreats in Bosnia, Haiti and Somalia and on the eve of a meeting with Asian leaders in Seattle, would further tarnish Mr. Clinton's image as a world leader.
The President seems to have warmed to the challenge. Unlike most of his foreign policy addresses, which sound as if he is just going through the motions, his speeches and town hall meetings on Nafta are as animated, enthusiastic and full of arm-waving as any on health care. Perhaps that is because Nafta is the only foreign policy issue that really seems to go to the heart of his abiding political passion: renewing America so it can face the future.
Most foreign policy experts argue that Mr. Clinton is justified in getting excited. Failure to pass Nafta would be devastating for American foreign policy, they say, because the debate over the agreement is in many ways a debate about how the United States should engage generally in the post-cold-war world.
"About once in a generation," former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger said in speaking in favor of Nafta at White House ceremony last week, "this country has an opportunity in foreign policy to do something defining, something that establishes the structure for decades to come."
"After it is established, people wonder how it could ever have been otherwise, but when one goes through the debate, one is conscious of all the technical objections that are raised," he said. "Now we live in a world in which the ideological challenge has disintegrated and a new architecture needs to be created, and Nafta is the first and crucial step in that direction."
 
Central Issues of Past
 Indeed, after World War I the central foreign policy question, as framed by President Wilson, was whether America should retreat to its former policy of isolationism, or accept a new relationship with the world and take part in a collective security system that would call on the United States to protect the territorial integrity of some 40 other countries. That choice was framed in the debate over the League of Nations, and when the Senate rejected membership, America essentially opted for isolationism.
After World War II, the central foreign policy issue was what role the United States would play in maintaining the front lines in Western Europe against Soviet Communism. That was framed in the debate over whether the United States should finance the Marshall Plan for European reconstruction and join NATO, a battle that President Truman narrowly won.
 
Global Trade Pact in Balance
 Since the end of the cold war, probably the central question of foreign policy facing the United States is how it will remain engaged in a world increasingly defined by what the military strategist Edward N. Luttwak has called "geo-economics." In this world the military and diplomatic struggles of the past are increasingly replaced by economically driven competition and alliances in a single global market; arrangements like Nafta are the currency for this new era.
That is why experts, when asked what the biggest impact of a failure to pass Nafta would be, cite the undermining of efforts to reach an even broader global trade accord in negotiations that are supposed to be completed in Geneva by Dec. 15.
This is their reasoning: To complete negotiations on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which would eliminate or reduce tariffs on goods, services and agricultural products worldwide, the United States, Japan, France and developing countries must all make some politically unpopular decisions at home, forcing their farmers and certain industrialists to accept freer trade.
If Mr. Clinton cannot secure passage of Nafta, the argument goes, his ability to get GATT approved will also be in doubt, because the Europeans and the Japanese are not likely to risk alienating voters at home if they think the United States Congress is going to squelch the deal anyway.
"Our moral authority to persuade other countries to support freer trade would most certainly be eroded if Nafta fails," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, "and therefore our ability to secure expanded markets for our exports would decline."
 
Credibility Issue Cited
 "If we turn our back on free trade with our closest neighbor," Mr. Hormats said, "how credible will we be in the eyes of the Europeans or Japanese in asking them to accept lower trade barriers as part of GATT? Foreign governments will conclude that Perot and opponents of free trade in America are calling the shots."
That is why, said Dr. Lorenz Schomerus, director of foreign policy of the Economics Ministry in Bonn, "we in Europe are watching with great interest to see what happens with Nafta. If it is passed. It would be very healthy for regional integration and that would, in turn, promote better global economic integration. If it fails, that would not be good."
On Nov. 18, the day after the Nafta vote, Mr. Clinton flies off to Seattle for a summit meeting with Asian and Pacific leaders. Virtually all of the heads of state from Indonesia to China have been planning to attend -- in large part because they were certain that once Nafta passed, they would have to scramble to get access to this huge North American free-trade zone, which they viewed as even more threatening than the European Community.
If Mr. Clinton greets them without Nafta, he will not only suffer extreme embarrassment, but will also be left with a much weaker hand in gaining access to their markets for American products.
 
Pushing the Free Market
 Equally important, the Nafta vote comes at a moment in history when the United States has been urging leaders in Eastern Europe, Latin America, India, Russia and even China -- whose governments have traditionally been protectionist and socialist -- to adopt an American free-market model. The long-term stability of these countries, many of which have now chosen avowedly pro-American, pro-democratic paths, depends on their having access to the world market for their exports.
"For years we told these countries, 'You got it wrong -- you should organize like us," said Michael Mandelbaum, an expert on East-West relations at Johns Hopkins University. "And now we say, 'We are not going to let you into the game.' "
Argentina, Chile and Venezuela have all been moving toward more market-oriented economies, in part out of necessity but also enticed by the prospect of joining "AFTA" -- an American Free Trade Agreement that would enlarge Nafta territory into South America all the way down to the southern tip of Chile, encompassing 800 million people.
James Cheek, the American Ambassador to Argentina, quoted its President, Carlos Saul Menem, as telling him in one of their first conversations that leaders of Latin America would feel "abandoned," if not betrayed, by the United States if it disavowed Nafta. Mr. Menem said the Argentines, the Mexicans and other emerging Latin American "democrats" have staked at least some of their hopes for future economic well-being and social stability on being brought into Nafta.
 
Trade as the Core
 More broadly, if there is going to be a new organizing principle for the post-cold-war world, and some new cement to replace the Eastern and Western blocs of the cold war, it is probably not going to be United Nations membership or an assertive multi-lateralism. It will most likely be based to some degree on trading associations.
If both Nafta and GATT collapse, it will mean that the economic trading system built up alongside and reinforcing the strategic NATO and Japanese-American alliances of the cold war will be crumbling.
"The feeling one gets watching all of this from Europe," said Dominique Moisi, deputy director of the French Institute for International Affairs, "is that you Americans just don't give a damn about the outside world anymore.
"Of course, that is an exaggeration. But there is a feeling that you just don't want to be the organizers of global affairs anymore. Well, if Congress says no to Nafta, that is certainly the message you will send."

HEADLINE: GIULIANI PROMISES NEW TACK ON DRUGS AND CITY SPENDING

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Sending a signal about some early priorities of his administration, Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani said he would issue two executive orders soon after taking office to enforce budget discipline among his department heads and to make clear to police officers that they can make street arrests of drug dealers.
The budget order, he said, would place agency spending under the Mayor's review every three months, to insure that "the budget we agree on is the budget we will stick to." 
 He also said that he or his police commissioner would issue a written order emphasizing the police authority to make drug arrests. "I want to make sure police officers understand they have discretion to go ahead and do that," he said.
Officers have that authority under the Dinkins administration, but the emphasis has been on stopping higher-level drug dealers, rather than street dealers, and Mr. Giuliani pledged during his campaign to reverse that policy.
Mr. Giuliani spoke in a series of interviews Friday night and into yesterday morning as he traveled by van -- as he often did during the campaign -- to a dance of the Emerald Society of firefighters in Queens Village and then veered into Nassau County for a late dinner of pasta and red wine.
The dance and dinner were among the final events in a week that included the last frantic days of campaigning, his tense and narrow victory over Mayor David N. Dinkins and several days of efforts to reach out to black and Hispanic New Yorkers.
He finally slipped away for some private time with his wife, Donna, after a news conference yesterday morning announcing that Richard D. Parsons, chairman of the Dime Savings Bank and a prominent black supporter who had served in the administrations of Nelson A. Rockefeller and Gerald R. Ford, would head his transition council. The group will recommend candidates for appointment to City Hall. [Page 41.]
 
Mayor-Elect in Limbo
 Less than 12 hours earlier he had been driving along the city line looking for a favorite restaurant that he thought would still be open. "I think it's right over the line in Nassau," he said, directing his driver after 11 P.M. to Stella Ristorante in Floral Park. "Are we allowed to go to Nassau?"
At dinner, Mr. Giuliani drank two glasses of wine and ate in stolen bites as he used a portable phone to field questions on a radio call-in show, bouncing his leg up and down with nervous energy.
Three nights after he declared victory in the mayoral race, Mr. Giuliani showed no sign of the exhaustion that had staff members dozing in the van. Yet he seemed in limbo, suspended between campaigning and governing, uncertain what to communicate and what to keep secret, after a race that often saw him at odds with the press. "Can I tell her?" he asked his press aide, Richard Bryers, several times before answering a reporter's questions.
At the dance in Queens under balloons in the orange, white and green of the Irish flag, Mr. Giuliani was surrounded by admiring firefighters and their wives, who grabbed him, kissed him and begged for souvenir pictures. But on the radio show, he also received his first taste of how his efforts to heal the racial polarization of the campaign could alienate some of his most ardent supporters.
One caller condemned Mr. Giuliani's meeting in Harlem Friday morning with United States Representative Charles B. Rangel, the dean of the city's Congressional delegation and a prominent supporter of Mayor David N. Dinkins. "She was angry about our meeting with Rangel," he told Mr. Bryers."You should tell people you worked with him before in Washington," Mr. Bryers advised.
Mr. Giuliani insisted in his interview that no one should have been caught off-guard by his effort to reach out to black voters who opposed him, and contended that the intense focus of the campaign had turned him into a caricature of himself. "I think maybe people get to know you better, if you're lucky enough to become mayor or governor," he said. "They get to see other parts of your personality.
He added, "In a campaign, they come at you from the stereotype. It's hard to see the other part. It's also because a campaign is combat."
Throughout the campaign he ridiculed Mr. Dinkins's emphasis on putting minority groups into government, accusing him of valuing symbolism over competence and merit. But explaining his post-election trips to Harlem, he said, "I didn't say that symbolism wasn't important, I said that the emphasis has to be on substance."
"Charlie Rangel is in fact the dean of the New York City delegation," he said. "Now it also is true that he's a significant leader in the African-American community. But he's somebody that I have to work with, that has to work with me. It makes sense for us to have good personal relationship, or heal whatever scars there are from the campaign. I didn't meet with Charlie today purely for symbolic reasons. I met with him because I want him to know from me that I want to work with him."
Mr. Giuliani had pledged during his campaign to crack down on street-level drug dealers and to be an engaged manager, and in some ways his planned executive orders are symbolic to signal that change.
The Office of Management and Budget already conducts quarterly audits of agency compliance with the budget, although not with the Mayor himself involved. And although Mr. Giuliani said during the campaign that Mr. Dinkins had directed the Police Department to arrest fewer street-level drug dealers to save money on overtime, Mr. Dinkins denied the charge. Instead, administration officials said that there had been a management decision to use scarce resources to go after higher-level dealers.
Calling the fiscal situation one of his top priorities, Mr. Giuliani hinted at quick action "to take advantage of the first three or four months of the administration to put into motion the things you sort of have the momentum to do."
But he declined to say what he had in mind to trim the budget. "A lot of it depends on the decisions that Mayor Dinkins makes," he said. He maintained he could move ahead with a reduction of the hotel occupancy tax that would go into effect "10 months, maybe a year" after it is put into law. And he said as he had during the campaign that significant savings could be achieved through changing procurement procedures.
As he raced through the night in his van, Mr. Giuliani seemed still uncertain how to take command of his new persona as mayor. At one point, he acknowledged that he was never completely certain when he had said something that would make headlines.
He said he was irritated at the perception that he had changed his position on the city's affirmative-action program for minority and women contractors -- caused by his remark early Friday that "I would be very interested in looking at how it's working."
He said he had been widely misunderstood during the campaign and had never planned to abolish the whole program, which sets aside as much as a fifth of the city's $3 billion in contracts for companies owned by women or minorities. But he then outlined a series of steps that would, in essence, gradually rewrite the program to eliminate the preference for women and minorities and instead reward companies operating in economically distressed areas or seeking to hire the unemployed.
 
Reviewing the Past
 As he reviewed the campaign just past, he acknowledged for the first time that his campaign counsel, Dennison Young Jr. had been put in charge of transition planning in August. But he said he had not spoken of this in public for fear of seeming "presumptuous."
On election eve, he said, he had both a victory and a concession speech written. And it was former Mayor Edward I. Koch who told him to reach out to Mr. Dinkins to stand beside him the day after election, even suggesting that he ask Mr. Dinkins to go to Harlem with him. He decided instead simply to request the City Hall meeting.
Mr. Giuliani said he did not anticipate problems in dealing with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, noting that the two men had mutual friends and that Mr. Cuomo had even given him advice during his last mayoral race on how to make the transition from being a lawyer to being a candidate.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
G.O.P. Embraces String of Victories, But It Is Still Seeking Vision for '96

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Edward J. Rollins, whose place as a Republican wise man was restored on Tuesday by his role in the upset victory of Christine Todd Whitman in the New Jersey governor's race, had stern advice for fellow party members: "Republicans shouldn't start buying inaugural tickets."
The Republican sweep this week will no doubt boost morale, fund raising and, perhaps most important for next year, the party's drive to recruit prime candidates. But amid their jubilation about winning all the big contests since President Clinton was elected, including last week's races for governor in New Jersey and Virginia and the mayoralty in New York, many Republicans said the victories did little to crystallize the vision of a party still trying to find its ideological way since losing the White House. 
 Advisers to the candidates who won on Tuesday agreed that the single element they shared was that they ran as outsiders who carried a message of change. Frank Luntz, a pollster who worked for Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani, was downright critical of the Republican Party, saying it had a long way to go to shed a stuffy image. He singled out two Republican Senators running for fourth terms next year, Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and Orrin G. Hatch of Utah.
 
Incumbents as Targets
 "We don't know as Republicans how to communicate as well as we could because we're still so stuck up," Mr. Luntz said on a panel of Republicans on Friday that assessed the elections. "We are still so damn formal. I mean look, I'm going to take two candidates that I am running in '94, Orrin Hatch and Dick Lugar, who I like very much and I would vote for if I was sitting in their states. Do they look like the kind of people you can kind of have a beer with and talk to? They look like morticians. I mean, they are the people that my mother wishes I dressed like."
Greg Stevens, the media adviser for George F. Allen, who was elected Governor of Virginia, said his optimism for Republicans stemmed from the party's having more challengers than incumbents running for Congress and for Governors next year. That situation in 1994 and beyond "bodes well for Republicans because there are more of us," he said. But the anti-incumbent feelings could also be to the advantage of Ross Perot, who briefly tapped the talents of Mr. Rollins and the votes of many Republicans last year.
Beyond that, there is plenty of historical evidence that it takes more than seizing on anti-incumbent sentiment to turn a party around. In 1986, the Democrats won back control of the Senate and picked up a large share of House seats, saying it was a verdict on President Ronald Reagan and the sour shape of the economy. But two years later, the Democrats still lacked a unifying agenda, and the party stayed fractured.
Asked what the winning Republican candidates had in common, Fred Meyer, chairman of the Texas Republican Party, said, "Bill Clinton." Pressed further, he retreated to a cliche: "They believe in less taxes, less Government."
To some Republicans, such a vision falls short.
 
'Results Are Too Good'
 "My fear is these results are too good for the party," said David Tell, an organizer of the Project for the Republican Future, a new group that is proposing conservative alternatives to Mr. Clinton's proposals. "It's not enough for us to be satisfied simply with having cuffed this guy up six times. The most dangerous inclination will be to suspect that you can get the White House back simply by dumping on the guy who's in there now. You need a coherent, intelligent governing agenda."
If Republicans were looking at the races on Tuesday as a prescription for victory in the future, they did not find it. In Virginia, some Republicans were pointing to Mr. Allen's victory as a sign that a traditional conservative can win election. Others contended that the unexpectedly strong showing of Michael P. Farris, an outspoken member of the religious right, in the race for lieutenant governor of Virginia showed that views like his were on the ascendancy. Even though Mr. Farris lost, he received more votes than Mary Sue Terry, the Democratic candidate for Governor.
 
'Need to Do More'
 But such theories did not hold up in New Jersey and New York, where more moderate campaigns were waged, particularly on social issues. Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Giuliani made no secret of their support for for abortion rights. Some prominent national conservatives like William J. Bennett, who was the drug policy director under former President George Bush, and former Gov. Pete duPont of Delaware went so far as to support George J. Marlin, Mr. Giuliani's Conservative Party opponent.
Nor were there obvious parallels in the earlier victories starting last year with Senator Paul Coverdell's election in a Georgia runoff and continuing earlier this year with the triumphs of Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison in Texas and Mayor Richard J. Riordan of Los Angeles.
Haley Barbour, the chairman of the Republican Party, agreed that it would be a mistake for the party to rest on its victories. "Winning elections in 1993 is no guarantee of anything," Mr. Barbour said. "I don't think there's any greater advocate than I in that we need to do more than oppose Clinton."
Arguing that the party's victories this week were driven by more than anti-incumbent sentiment, Mr. Barbour said crime and taxes were important issues that the party's candidates would again seize on next year.
Michael Murphy, the Whitman campaign's media adviser, said Mrs. Whitman's election should not give new hope to Republicans like Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, who are moderate on social issues. "They want to go find a moderate and say: 'Aha! Christie Whitman proves that the ideal Republican candidate is a moderate.' Christie Whitman was never in this race to be examined under the calculus of 'are you moderate' or not," Mr. Murphy said.
"She was examined on 'Whether you are scatter-brained or not? Will your nutty tax plan work? And do you have any kind of experience in the Government?' "
Because Mrs. Whitman won on a pledge to cut New Jersey income taxes by 30 percent, she faces the most pressure to deliver on her promises. Whether she succeeds will determine whether supply-side economics comes back into vogue.
"We have to deliver on our promises," said Tom Slade, chairman of the Florida Republican Party. "If we indulge in any complacency, we're engaging in the ultimate of political stupidity."
