HEADLINE: In Twist, Protectionism Is Used to Sell Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Increasingly desperate to win support in Congress for the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Clinton Administration has resorted to the odd tactic of selling a free-trade pact by highlighting its protectionist provisions.
These provisions, highly technical and buried in annexes, are designed to insure that the agreement eliminates taxes and other trade barriers for Canadian, American and Mexican factories, but not for goods produced by their foreign rivals. The provisions not only require that goods be assembled in North America but also that many manufactured products, ranging from cars and television sets to clothing and shoes, be made from North American materials. 
 For example, a clause that has won the American fabric industry's strong support says a garment sewn in North America qualifies for duty-free treatment only if the fabric for it, as well as the yarn to make the fabric, is made in North America.
 
Protecting an Advantage
 Such clauses, known to trade experts as rules of national origin, are sprinkled through the agreement, though few are as restrictive as the apparel rules.
"The one thing you don't want to do is let other countries take advantage of what we've negotiated," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative.
Actually, these provisions were negotiated by the Bush Administration, out of political necessity, to drum up corporate support. They went largely unnoticed until recently, when they began to attract criticism from abroad, notably from Japan. Now, as the Clinton Administration seeks to appease trade hawks in its uphill pursuit of votes, it has not only welcomed the criticism but advertised it.
When an obscure Japanese trade official attacked the agreement's rules of origin as "sneaky protectionism" during a speech recently at a business convention in Cancun, Mexico, the White House trade office tried to make sure everybody in Washington knew about it.
"They're complaining because the United States is finally, finally trying to protect the jobs of our workers and the competitiveness of our businesses," Mr. Kantor said at the time.
 
'Rules of the Road'
 In a subsequent interview, Mr. Kantor was even more emphatic. "There is no such thing as free trade -- it doesn't exist," he said. "You have to have rules of the road."
A senior Administration official took a similar tack at a briefing for reporters on Thursday. He said the legislation putting the free-trade pact into American law would make it impossible for President Clinton or his successors to alter the rules of origin on apparel -- an act of Congress would be required for any changes.
"That was to provide assurances to the textile and apparel industry that the Administration wasn't going to, by regulation or by practice, somehow change or alter those rules of origin," the official said. "Those are, as you know, very strict origin rules."
The new argument from the Administration coincides with a recent bid by President Clinton to present the free-trade agreement as the only way to prevent Japan and Europe from taking over the Mexican market. Both arguments represent an effort to placate opponents and persuade undecided members of Congress and the public that the agreement is in the economic interest of the United States.
 
Weighing U.S. Benefits
 The problem for the Administration is that while the rules of origin might help American factories compete against European and Japanese adversaries, the rules apply equally to the three countries in the pact and do not give the United States an advantage in competing with Mexico or Canada. Congressional opponents are not impressed by the argument, and predict that few members will be swayed.
"The real question is not whether it's good for the hemisphere but whether it's good for the United States," said Representative Sander Levin, Democrat of Michigan, who specializes in trade policy issues and opposes the agreement.
The Administration's effort has also not appeased the ardent critics of the agreement in organized labor. "They are beginning to have to try new arguments because what they have tried so far is not working," said Edith B. Bond, the research director for international affairs for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
 
No Violation of GATT
 To be sure, all trade agreements, even the 116-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, have some rules of origin. Trade agreements are based on mutual reductions in taxes on imports, and the idea behind the rules of origin is to prevent other countries from taking advantage of the lower import taxes without reducing their own import taxes. Mr. Kantor said the North American pact, taken as a whole, did not violate GATT rules for regional trade agreements.
But the North American Free Trade Agreement is unusual in the way the rules of origin are stated. The international standard is that the nationality of a product is determined by the last country in which it underwent a "substantial transformation." For example, east Asian countries have been able to avoid steep American duties on their television sets by shipping the expensive picture tubes to Mexico, where they are screwed into housings and become Mexican television sets under traditional international trade rules.
 
New Rules Created
 The North American Free Trade Agreement uses the substantial transformation rule for many manufactured goods but creates new rules for some. For example, the new rule for television sets is that a set only counts as North American -- and is exempt from various taxes totaling up to 21 percent of the wholesale price -- if it is not only assembled in North America but also has a North American-made picture tube, which consists of the screen and electron gun.
Already hostile to the restrictive rules of origin of the agreement, free-trade economists said they were appalled that the Administration was presenting the rules as economic virtues rather than the result of political need.
"We would not like these rules of origin in Europe; we would oppose them," said Gary Hufbauer, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics, a nonpartisan research group in Washington. "These are warts, these are clearly warts" on the agreement, he said.
 
Wart or Beauty Mark?
 But American businesses, many of which advocate unrestricted free trade in all but their own industries, said they were pleased. "One man's wart is another man's beauty mark," said Timothy Regan, a trade official at Corning Inc., a glass manufacturer based in Corning, N.Y.
The company said it hoped to sell more glass for use in television sets when manufacturers have an incentive to use North American television screens, and has been lobbying strenuously for passage of the pact. "We are contributing money and we are contributing time and energy -- we are probably contributing as much as anybody," Mr. Regan said.
The strict rules of origin have helped the Bush and Clinton Administrations win broad corporate backing for the agreement. After heavy lobbying last year by Detroit, for example, the North American agreement also contains a rule that cars will qualify for duty-free treatment only if at least 50 percent of their value in parts and labor is produced in North America. The requirement rises to 62.5 percent by 2002.
 
Assessing Foreign Content
 The rules also require that foreign ball bearings and electronic motor controls be counted as part of a fully-assembled car's foreign content, even if assembled in the United States into larger components with mostly American parts. The free-trade agreement between the United States and Canada stated that the nationality of the larger components applied even to the ball bearings and electronic controls used to make them.
The ball bearing industry, an aggressive user of American trade laws that has persuaded the Commerce Department to impose steep anti-dumping duties on imports from nine countries, has mostly supported the agreement.
"I don't think the rules are inappropriate," said David D. Gridley, the director of sales for the Torrington Company, a ball bearing manufacturer based in Torrington, Conn.
But while the rules of origin may help factories in North America and their employees, the rules do not necessarily help American shareholders. The reason is that the North American Free Trade Agreement says nothing about the nationality of a company's ownership. So, cars from the Nissan factory in Smyrna, Tenn., can receive duty-free treatment when entering Canada and Mexico if they are built with enough North American parts.
Several of the biggest Japanese electronics companies have television picture tube factories in the United States. Japanese companies have also been accumulating stakes in television glass companies here. Asahi Glass of Japan owns 49 percent of the Corning subsidiary that makes glass for television screens. Nippon Electric Glass of Japan last month completed its purchase of a subsidiary of Owens-Illinois that is the other large producer of television screen glass in the United States.

HEADLINE: Jeffrey Schmalz, 39, Times Writer On Politics and Then AIDS, Dies

BYLINE: By RICHARD J. MEISLIN

 BODY:
Jeffrey Schmalz, a journalist who wrote with passion and insight about the determination and despair of AIDS sufferers, died of complications of the disease yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 39.
When his illness was discovered three years ago, Mr. Schmalz, who spent his entire two-decade career as a reporter and editor at The New York Times, saw his situation not only as a patient but as a journalist. 
 Returning to work after a year of battling AIDS-related illnesses, he persuaded his editors to allow him to cover AIDS and gay issues. His writing gained him national attention as he brought readers into the world of gay politics and of people with AIDS in a blunt and sometimes startling way.
 
Finding Kinship
 "To have AIDS is to be alone, no matter the number of friends and family members around," Mr. Schmalz wrote in a searingly personal article last December in The Week in Review section of The Times. "Then, to be with someone who has H.I.V., be it interviewer or interviewee, is to find kinship. 'I'm so glad they picked you to do this,' Mary Fisher said in an interview just before she spoke at the Republican National Convention as a woman with H.I.V. With her, as with Magic Johnson and Bob Hattoy and Larry Kramer and Elizabeth Glaser, who spoke at the Democratic convention, the talk was the same: of anger and courage and politics. We talked of that deep nausea in the pit of your stomach when even cancer patients pity you and when a doctor, who should know better, puts on latex gloves just to shake your hand."
Colleagues credited Mr. Schmalz with a finely honed news sense, a devotion to accuracy, a sharp-edged writing style and an innate sense of politics, both of the Government and of The Times, that helped him to rise quickly at the newspaper.
 
Began as a Copy Boy
 Born in Abington, Pa., he began his career as a night copy boy in January 1973, while a student at Columbia University, where he studied economics.
Mr. Schmalz was regional editor and a metropolitan news reporter before being named chief of The Times's bureau in Albany in 1986, where he covered the early years of the Cuomo administration.
He joined the national staff in 1988, working as bureau chief in Miami before returning to New York two years later as deputy national editor.
"The healthy Jeff was an outstanding correspondent and editor with a great future in American journalism," Max Frankel, executive editor of The Times, said yesterday. "Jeff in illness plumbed the depth of his experience and applied it brilliantly to his coverage of the plague, producing a remarkable bequest to American journalism."
 
A Seizure at His Desk
 Mr. Schmalz was deputy national editor in December 1990 when he suffered a brain seizure at his desk that led to the discovery he had AIDS.
Part of the price of his ascent at The Times, Mr. Schmalz long believed, was that he hide his homosexuality from at least some of his superiors. But after his illness became known, and with his sexual orientation no longer a secret, he became an eloquent spokesman for the frustrations of people with AIDS and an outspoken supporter of equal rights for gay people. In public speeches, he frequently apologized for coming late to the cause.
At the same time, he was careful to limit how much his own feelings got into print. The potential conflict in having this "by the book Timesman, no personal involvement allowed," as he put it, covering the disease that was killing him, was one of which he was acutely aware, and he addressed it head on in the article last December.
 
'The Prism of AIDS'
 "Now I see the world through the prism of AIDS," he wrote. "I feel an obligation to those with AIDS to write about it and an obligation to the newspaper to write what just about no other reporter in America can cover in quite the same way." He spoke of his situation as a reporter in the context of women who cover women's issues, or blacks who cover issues of importance to blacks, calling it "the cutting edge of journalism."
"Some people think that it is the journalism that suffers, that objectivity is abandoned," he wrote. "But they are wrong. If the reporters have any integrity at all, it is they who suffer, caught between two allegiances."
Mr. Schmalz's life centered on his association with The Times. But with his career ambitions blunted by his illness, he became more contemplative and more philosophical. In a talk to students at the Dalton School earlier this year, he marveled at the idea that, after a year of fighting a usually fast-killing brain infection, blood clots and pneumonia, he had been given "time to get my life in order; my life is more together now than it ever was."
 
A Fatalistic Edge
 His sense of humor, always acid, took on a fatalistic edge. Told by a doctor in April 1992 that he would have to give himself blood-thinning injections each day for the rest of his life, he cracked, "Well, at least it won't have to be for too long." When the count of his T-cells, an indicator of the strength of his immune system, dropped into single digits, he joked about giving them names.
He was acutely aware of the "looking-glass world" in which he lived, seeing his disease as "a good story" as well as a reporter's tool as he sought to give a human face to the AIDS epidemic.
"I make sure everyone with AIDS whom I interview knows that I have it, too," he wrote. "To be sure, that is an interview ploy; I'm hoping the camaraderie will open them up. But there is more to it than that: I want them to take a good look at me, to see that someone with full blown AIDS can carry on for a while, can even function as a reporter. Much of the time, it works. Their faces light up. There is hope."
"But sometimes it fails," he continued, "and I am the one changed by our chat, overcome by guilt that I have lived these two years when so many of my friends and hospital roommates and people I've interviewed have died. At times, I think my fellow AIDS sufferers are laughing at me, looking up from their beds with eyes that say, 'You'll be here soon enough.' "
Mr. Schmalz is survived by a sister, Wendy Wilde of Manhattan, a literary agent.

HEADLINE: Seoul's Big Fear: Pushing North Koreans Too Far

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 5

 BODY:
When Secretary of Defense Les Aspin arrived here this week to devise a strategy for dealing with North Korea's nuclear weapons project, his party of aides and top American officials was immediately whisked off to the Foreign Ministry, where three photographs dominate the conference room wall.
The first shows Seoul in 1945, a peaceful town of traditional-style Korean homes. The second was taken from the same site in the early 1950's, after the forces of Kim Il Sung had swept over the border, leaving nothing standing except smoldering ruins and a few chimneys. Next to it is a color photograph of the same site today, with its sweeping boulevards and office towers. 
 Such images crop up with increasing frequency here in these days, as South Koreans try to impress on the United States how high a price they might pay if they forced Mr. Kim's desperate, often irrational-sounding Government into a corner. The message seemed to sink in. By the time Mr. Aspin left, he and his aides were talking openly about their growing worries that the wrong kind of pressure on the isolated North Korean Government could provoke it to lash out.
 
'Kind of a Danger Zone'
 "There is a very fine line between coercing North Korea to do what you want them to do, and provoking a tremendous disaster," one of the most senior American military officials said here this week. Another official, aboard Mr. Aspin's plane returning to the United States, said, "We may be entering kind of a danger zone here."
Their fear is that events in the next few weeks may force the United States and its Asian allies into the one step they have been clearly trying to avoid: imposing economic sanctions to force North Korea to permit regular inspections of its nuclear sites, under its obligations as a signer of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. Failing to make good on that threat, officials say, would totally undercut the Clinton Administration's repeated policy that "counter proliferation" is a new mainstay of Washington's post-cold-war foreign policy.
But as the moment to impose sanctions through the United Nations has drawn closer, American, South Korean and Japanese officials are wondering aloud whether the nearly bankrupt Government of North Korea would respond violently in a last-ditch effort to preserve its power base.
 
Not 'Just a Chess Game'
 "It is easy in Washington to regard this as just a chess game," said Gen. Gary Luck, the new commander of the 35,000-member American military forces in South Korea, as he accompanied Mr. Aspin to Osan Air Force Base, where F-16's take off every few minutes toward the fiercely armed demilitarized zone. "I keep reminding people that this is for real, and it's real scary."
Indeed, while North Korea may be so desperately poor that it is unable to feed its own people, it holds an ability to rain tremendous damage on the American military forces and their allies in a mission of "re-unification."
Few believe that such an attack, if it came, would last long. China and Russia, North Korea's allies in the conflict of the 1950's, would almost certainly sit on the sidelines this time around. American intelligence reports estimate that Mr. Kim's forces would soon run out of gas supplies. President Clinton, visiting the demilitarized zone in July, warned that such an attack "would be the end of their country." An outcome drawn up by the Pentagon envisioned a 90-day conflict.
Nonetheless, South Korean officials repeatedly stress that even a brief conflict could wreak tremendous damage and threaten neighboring countries. South Korea's extensive system of nuclear power plants are an obvious target. American officials this week talked at length about North Korea's military buildup along the demilitarized zone, saying it had placed about 70 percent of its forces within striking range of South Korea.
Those forces include about 800 jet fighters and 3,500 tanks. Seoul, which is about 25 miles from the border, is within easy artillery range. With North Korea building up those forces, Mr. Aspin and the South Koreans agreed on Thursday to an immediate review of their own deployments and plants. Mr. Aspin said the review was prudent "just in case we've missed anything."
 
Where the Resources Go
 "The reason North Korea is so poor that it does not have enough food for its people is because it devotes almost all its resources to preparing for war," said Charles W. Freeman Jr., the Assistant Secretary of Defense for regional security affairs. But the North Korean Army, other experts say, is poorly trained and poorly fed, with much of its 1.1 million-man force working on construction projects around the country.
The endless debate about what would happen if the North is pushed into a corner explains the tone that South Korea and Japan have taken in recent weeks: keep talking tough, they have told American officials, but avoid hard deadlines and sanctions at all costs.
"There is an opinion around that if the pressure for the North Koreans becomes intolerable, there will be a type of Waco, Tex., situation -- an effort at joint suicide with South Korea," said Kim Jung Woo, an adviser to the National Unification Board, which heads South Korea's talks with North Korea. "This is why we have no choice but to try to appease the North Koreans. Since we know what North Korea is apparently capable of doing, it is not a situation where we can take risks."
North Korea, of course, knows that its reputation for unpredictability is its best card. So far, it has used this to protract the discussions and win some small concessions. But American and South Korean officials insist that as long as there is no evidence that North Korea is making rapid progress on its nuclear weapons development, they have little to lose from playing along for a while.
 
Safeguards and Sanctions
 "We start with the assumption that there is a chance for the peaceful process to work," South Korea's Foreign Minister, Han Sung Joo, said in an interview in his office on Friday.
But this week Mr. Aspin, Mr. Han and others discussed several possible situations that could force sanctions to the fore. One would be a declaration by Hans Blix, Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, that the "continuity of safeguards has been broken" -- in other words, that the agency could no longer establish that nuclear material had not been diverted to weapons projects. Mr. Blix, however, seems reluctant to make such a declaration, even though most experts say the safeguards are now so minimal as to be nearly worthless.
A second possibility is that Washington and its allies may decide that North Korea's actions have gone on too long and move toward sanctions in at the United Nations Security Council. "Our patience is not unlimited," Mr. Aspin said at a news conference here. "It is not our intention to either be weak or look weak."
Mr. Aspin's comments notwithstanding, there is already speculation that Washington may soon back down from its insistence that North Korea allow the nuclear inspections before agreeing to talks about improving relations. Instead, it could offer a "package deal" of inspections in return for economic or political enticements.
 
Some Economic Fears
 Still, many South Koreans say that as much as they fear an attack by North Korea, they are also deeply worried about another possibility: that Mr. Kim's Government will just collapse, leaving Seoul with the responsibility for assisting the North.
Beneath all the oratory about the re-unification of the Korean Peninsula, it has become an article of faith here that the failure of Mr. Kim's Government, either by his death or a power struggle, could lead to a merging of the two nations so fast that South Korea's economic miracle would screech to a halt.
Study team after study team has been deployed to Germany to explore the costs of re-unification, and each one has returned with visions of economic disaster as South Korea pays for rebuilding a country whose basic public services have not been improved much since the Japanese left in 1945.
Some South Korean businessmen talk openly about the need to keep Korea partitioned for a decade or more, with essentially two classes of workers: well-paid ones in the South, and low-wage workers in the North. In short, they would feel best with Mr. Kim's remaining in charge, but without his nuclear weapons project.

HEADLINE: China Lacks Water to Meet Its Mighty Thirst

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZHOU CHANG, China

 BODY:
Heaven River dried up 20 years ago. Canals no longer bring water from Beijing's reservoirs. And it has been more than a decade since anyone could afford to fill a rice paddy.
But 53-year-old Xing Shuqin gestured over her donkey to the wheat field beyond and said: "We don't have a water problem, because we have a well. See, the wheat is growing just fine." 
 But in the same breath she conceded that her confidence in the future water supplies in this county was beginning to waver, as it is for millions of peasants in northern China where even the wells are drying up.
The country's Water Resources Minister, Niu Maosheng, said recently in Beijing that "in rural areas, over 82 million people find it difficult to procure water." And more and more water supplies are suffering from industrial pollution or contamination by pesticides.
In urban areas, shortages are worse. More than 300 Chinese cities are short of water and 100 of those are very short, Mr. Niu said.
At a time when China's population of 1.1 billion is enjoying a harvest of plenty relative to any other time in its history, a growing number of environmental scientists are concerned that the country's water resources and farmlands will not be able to keep up with the demands being placed on them to feed ever more robust expansion.
"What is at stake here is the ecological underpinning of Chinese society," warned a physicist who is spending a year in China studying scientific issues for the United States State Department.
China's water predicament is not unique. Dozens of countries, particularly in the Middle East and Africa, face diminishing water resources and fast-growing populations. Even in the United States, a large aquifer that irrigates the wheat and corn belt in the Midwest has suffered serious depletion.
But as in everything, China's size magnifies any shortage. With 22 percent of the population of the world, China has just 8 percent of its resources and 7 percent of its arable land.
A study by World Bank scientists last year warned that "the increasing pressure on this limited resource base to feed, house and meet the energy needs" of the Chinese was rapidly destroying "whole ecosystems" and threatening to put the brakes on China's current economic boom.
 
Two Major Issues
 Soil quality and water scarcity are major issues in these new analyses.
In Daxing County, about 30 miles south of Beijing, the peasants have been growing rice and wheat for millenniums. In the villages around Heaven River no one can remember a time when water was so scarce.
Leaning on his shovel in the big empty pond in front of his new house, Tian Jie, 69, said water used to be so plentiful that villagers raised fish in ponds like the one he was standing in. But Mr. Tian is converting his old pond into a vegetable garden and he hopes there will be enough water from the nine wells that serve his village to irrigate it next spring.
The villagers here, most of them peasants, offer a range of opinions about why the water supplies have been drying up.
Mr. Tian seemed to think a combination of declining rainfall and increasing demands for water from Beijing's urban sprawl were the culprits. Down the dirt rut that passes for a main street in Zhao Chang, where Mr. Tian lives, the village Communist Party secretary, Tian Wan Ling, said that the region was only suffering from a "historic drought."
 
Rainfall Below Average
 It is true that since the 1980's rainfall on the northern China plain has been 10 to 20 percent below average, but this is no worse than the ups and downs of recorded cycles in this century.
The difference today, a number of analysts say, is that northern China, with its dense population, its industrial boom and its urban growth, is making extraordinary demands on the region's thin water supplies.
In the 1950's, Beijing wells drew water from 16 feet below the surface. Today, the city's 40,000 wells reach down 160 feet on average and the prospect of shortages has prompted official debate over the viability of Beijing as China's capital.
Huo Changfu, a 57-year-old well driller in Daxing County, said he remembered when all he had to do was scrape out a yard of dirt to find the beginning of ground water flow. In those days, in the late 1950's and early 1960's, he said, he would sink a well about 40 feet to insure that the water would always flow, even in the dry years. Today those wells are useless. Mr. Huo said he now puts wells down more than 250 feet to insure the water flows.
A Canadian environmental scientist, Vaclav Smil, says that China's land and water resources are approaching the limits of their ability to keep up with population growth. By the end of this decade, China's population will increase by about 120 million, roughly the population of Japan.
"The environmental foundations of China's national existence are alarmingly weak and they continue to deteriorate at high rates," Mr. Smil writes in a study of China's environmental problems.
 
'Environmental Refugees'
 Of the estimated 80 million Chinese in the so-called "floating" population that is migrating to cities or coastal provinces in search of work, Mr. Smil said, many are "environmental refugees pushed out of their villages because there was simply no land left for them to till."
"In the northwestern provinces, there are whole villages that have had to get up and leave," he said in a telephone interview.
The sheer size of China's population makes the task of planning to avoid catastrophe here all the more urgent. If China cannot sustain the food output that has managed to keep pace with a doubling of the population since 1949, there may not be a great enough surplus in the rest of the world to come to the rescue.
"Because of China's size," Perry Link of Princeton University wrote in discussing Mr. Smil's book, "we are all partly in China's boat."

HEADLINE: Taxi Panel Sets Hearing On Possible Fare Increase

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
The Taxi and Limousine Commission is planning to hold a hearing this month on whether to impose a fare increase by early next year, a commission official said yesterday.
The hearing, scheduled for Nov. 30, will consider the possibility of raising fares for the first time since January 1990, said Bruce Schaller, director of policy development for the commission. 
 The owners of some taxi fleets have been asking for an increase since early this year, arguing that their expenses have jumped since the last increase, Mr. Schaller said. They have submitted data to the commission to support their request.
The hearing will include testimony from fleet owners, drivers and members of the public about whether the fare should be increased and, if so, by how much. After the commission's staff makes a recommendation, the commission will hold another hearing to debate the specific proposal, and vote on it about a month later.
 
Move Is Broadly Backed
 "I think the industry is broadly in favor of an increase in fares," Mr. Schaller said. "Now we have to listen to what exactly they are asking for."
The last time fleet owners requested a fare increase, about two years ago, the commission did not support it, in part because many small fleet owners and independent drivers said business was down already because of the recession and raising the fare would reduce business. But this time expenses on items like new cars, gasoline, health insurance and worker's compensation have gone up, Mr. Schaller said.
But Edward Rogoff, a management professor at Baruch College who has studied the taxi industry for more than a decade, said the increase is not warranted. He said the cost of operating taxis has been artificially inflated by the price of medallions (city licenses for taxicabs), which are at an all-time high.
A private medallion costs about $130,000 and small-fleet medallions are selling for more than $140,000, he said. Since drivers often have trouble finding long-term loans, they have to pay off the medallion cost quickly, as well as make enough to live on.
 
'Riders Get Nothing'
 "It's clearly in the industry's interest to support fare increases," Mr. Rogoff said. "But riders get nothing. They get higher fares with no improvement in services."
Historically, when fares increase, ridership drops off and then increases after a few months. The one exception in recent memory was after a 27 percent increase in April 1980, when riders stayed away much longer than usual.
"The same thing happens to the Transit Authority when they raise subway and bus fares," Mr. Schaller said. "Whether they increase again to the former rate is another question."
Mr. Rogoff said ridership would likely not decline much with a fare increase, since most passengers are not deterred by the higher price. The majority of riders are business travelers, people riding to and from the airport, sick or elderly people and people who do not live near public transportation, he said.
"It's been a while since the last increase, and business is generally up, so even the people who were nervous last time think they can sustain a fare increase this time," Mr. Rogoff said.

HEADLINE: Years of Neglect Raise Cost Of Restoring a High School

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
Six years after it was hailed as the start of a symbolic regeneration of the New York City school system, the reconstruction of the city's oldest high school has become the latest symbol of the Board of Education's troubled maintenance operations with costs ballooning from $22 million to $78 million.
Work crews at Erasmus Hall High School in Flatbush, Brooklyn, have discovered that the school's exterior masonry is so eroded after years of neglect that its terra cotta facade is peeling away from the sprawling four-story structure. Contractors were recently forced to take emergency measures to keep its Gothic towers from crashing down onto Flatbush Avenue, and workers have begun dismantling the towers brick by brick. 
 Officials at the Board of Education and the School Construction Authority, the state agency carrying out the restoration, attribute the huge growth in costs to years of neglected maintenance dating from the city's financial crisis in the mid-1970's.
 
'We've Neglected the Schools'
 "Erasmus is the ultimate, extreme example of what we're facing in this city because we've neglected the schools," said Barry Light, the president of the School Construction Authority.
But officials acknowledged that costs have also exploded and deadlines slipped because Board of Education architects failed to detect Erasmus Hall's extensive structural defects when they surveyed it eight years ago, forcing extensive design revisions over the years since and putting the project three years behind schedule. Also complicating the effort have been repeated discoveries of asbestos in areas that board inspectors had declared asbestos-free.
With much of the school closed off for cleanup or construction, its 2,800 students are packed into jury-rigged classrooms in gymnasiums, basements and cafeterias. Parents are angry, and teachers, complaining of pervasive filth, construction noise and asbestos hazards, are in near-revolt. Many refused to teach during the first week of the fall term, forcing Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines to step in personally to mediate.
Construction began in mid-1992, and teachers, parents and students complained about conditions during the 1992-1993 school year. But the asbestos crisis worsened the overcrowding this fall as portions of the school had to be closed off for asbestos removal. The renovation will not be done until 1997.
 
'It's Not Safe'
 "This is an untenable situation," said Bernice G. Fleischer, a chorus teacher appointed as a liaison with the construction crews. "It's not safe, it's not conducive to good educational techniques, and I think conditions are getting worse."
The reasons for the cost overruns at Erasmus Hall are at the heart of the debate that has emerged since the Board of Education issued a five-year $7.5 billion construction and maintenance request last week. Mr. Cortines argued that leaking roofs and other defects are ruining schools at an alarming rate and that unless the city spends more money on maintenance, repair bills will rise exponentially later.
But other leaders, including Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council, have argued that the main cause of deteriorating school conditions has not been underspending but bureaucratic paralysis at the board.
Several studies indicate that the city has cut corners on spending. One, conducted in 1990 by the Hay Group, a consulting concern, found that New York City spent considerably less per square foot on school maintenance than most other big city systems. While Dade County, Fla., spent $7.27 and Los Angeles spent $3.02 per square foot, for instance, New York City spent only $2.62.
And the State Education Deparment found in 1992 that New York City spent $564 per pupil on plant operations and maintenance, while the rest of the state averaged $656 per pupil.
Also lurking behind the problems at Erasmus Hall are failures that critics say have become characteristic of the school's maintenance bureaucracy. One is janitorial neglect. Because Erasmus Hall is one of the largest schools, it has been a lucrative prize for custodians, whose salaries rise with school size. Erasmus Hall has had 12 custodians in 10 years, most of them senior men who have gone to Erasmus Hall to wait for retirement, school officials said. One achieved notoriety in 1991 by hauling his yacht onto the school's athletic field and ordering his staff to caulk its hull.
 
Damage From Tree Roots
 School officials pointed to one sign of the custodial neglect: a stout tree, perhaps a dozen years old, growing out of Erasmus Hall's roof. Its roots have caused considerable damage.
Squabbles between agencies have also plagued the modernization. Officials from the School Construction Authority and the Fire Department are haggling about whose error resulted in last-minute design changes over the placement of fire evacuation areas for the disabled that have increased the cost by $1.5 million.
The board grossly underestimated the Erasmus Hall project's cost; city officials said this is hardly the first time. Borough President Howard Golden argued in an interview that in the board's 1989-1994 five-year plan, which contained the Erasmus Hall modernization as a $22 million line item, the board underestimated the costs of much school construction to promise more projects to political allies.
"Everybody knew it would take more money, and Erasmus wasn't the only school over budget," Mr. Golden said.
 
Estimates Are Defended
 Amy Linden, the board's chief executive for school facilities, rejected Mr. Golden's claims.
"That is ridiculous," Ms. Linden said. "The fact is, we thought we could do these projects for this amount of money, but we were off," she said. "The lesson here is, the more you defer school repairs, the higher the price."
Because the city's 1,100 schools are badly overcrowded, there was no alternative space into which to transfer the Erasmus Hall students before the saws began shrieking, Ms. Linden said. Not surprisingly, many Erasmus Hall students are upset about conditions.
"Half the school has been closed down," said Terrance Dudley, a sophomore who, with the school on a split schedule, attends classes only in the afternoon. "We only get two full periods," he said. "I get history and I get math. The rest aren't even normal classes."
"Its almost impossible to learn," he said.
 
Illustrious Alumni
 Erasmus Hall's current troubles are a blemish on an illustrious history. Founded in 1787 as a private academy, the school occupied for its first 118 years a colonial mansion near its present address, 911 Flatbush Avenue. After the school joined the public system at the turn of the century, the city between 1905 and 1939 built four adjoining buildings in a rectangle around a central courtyard.
The school has always been one of the city's proudest; illustrious alumni include Barbra Streisand, the chess champion Bobby Fischer, and hundreds of physicians and jurists. But like many schools, Erasmus Hall decayed rapidly after the fiscal crisis in the 1970's, which decimated the Board of Education's maintenance work force. By the 1980's, the school was badly dilapidated.
Its 200th anniversary, however, ignited a restoration campaign. "The 200th birthday of Erasmus Hall is a celebration of all that is best in American public education, and of what it can yet become," former board president Robert F. Wagner Jr. wrote in a 1987 letter to The New York Times. Inspired by the brilliant hues beaming through the stained glass windows of the Erasmus Hall chapel at the 1987 celebration, former Mayor Edward I. Koch pledged to reverse the decline: "Whatever is required to be done, let us commit ourselves to do it."
 
'Didn't Do Their Homework'
 Commitments followed. In the School Construction Authority's first five-year capital plan, written for the construction authority by the board in 1989, the Erasmus Hall modernization was budgeted for $22 million. Ms. Linden said the estimate was based on a 1985 board survey of the school. But officials at the authority said they were puzzled from the start about how the board could have estimated so little for the work.
"Somebody didn't do their homework," said Daniel Millman, a senior project officer at the authority. To conduct an adequate survey of the Gothic towers, board officials needed to erect scaffolding and ladders, he said. Instead, "Somebody stood on the roof with a pair of binoculars and tried to estimate the work that way," Mr. Millman said.
Mr. Light said that after new surveys and an open bidding process between 1990 and 1992, the construction agency produced its own early estimate of the project's cost -- $62 million -- which the board approved.
But the construction that began last year brought a series of unsettling surprises. Last fall, masons discovered that the school's tile facade was not tied to the building with steel rods, as is normal, but only with flaking cement. Months later, workmen on scaffolding to repair the Gothic towers removed a series of tiles and, to their horror, felt the entire tower shift. Later investigation showed that the 88-year-old towers, too, lacked any metal skeleton that could provide stability.
 
Errors on Blueprints
 Last spring, the construction authority discovered that holding rooms built to keep handicapped people safe until evacuation during a fire had been incorrectly located on blueprints, requiring extensive design changes. Authority officials attributed the error to the Fire Department; a deputy fire commissioner, Harry G. Ryttenberg, said the authority was at fault.
Despite repeated inspections of the school by both the board and the construction agency, discoveries of asbestos have twice caused costly disruptions. Earlier this year, workmen tearing up a basement floor churned up clouds of cement dust, and tests later proved that the cement contained asbestos. The dust, billowing upward, contaminated everything in four stories of Erasmus Hall's east wing. Contractors said they were forced to discard vast quantities of tools and building materials, and the cleanup was costly.
The nearly two years of setbacks have raised its estimated cost from $62 million to $78 million.
And in September, shortly before school was to open, the disclosure that the board's asbestos inspections in the system's 1,069 schools were completely unreliable forced a reinspection of Erasmus Hall. Asbestos was found in the plaster walls of the school's north and west wings, forcing a six-week cleanup that has greatly reduced classroom space this year.

HEADLINE: Watch Those COLA Interpretations

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "No Inflation, but Hold the Cheers" (Business Diary, Oct. 17), it is noted that this year's modest increase in consumer prices will lead to Social Security recipients getting the "second-smallest ever" cost of living adjustment (COLA). Surprisingly, the 2.6 percent COLA is referred to as a "cost" of low inflation. The purpose of the COLA is to keep the value of Social Security benefits constant in real, not nominal, terms. When inflation is high, the COLA is high; low inflation means a low COLA. To argue that a low COLA is a "cost" is to commit an act of what economists call "money illusion." Presumably no one believes that senior citizens were better off in real terms with COLAs of roughly 10 to 12 percent in the inflationary late 1970's.
 
PHILIP ROTHMAN
Greenville, N.C., Oct. 18
 
The writer is an assistant professor of economics at East Carolina University.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Twins, Triplets and Other Siblings

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
IT'S funny how things come together. A couple of months ago, my friend Joe bought a Geo Prizm and was delighted with it. Then, a week later, another friend, Jim, bought a Toyota Corolla.
Both talked to me about the shiny new wheels, both bubbling over, each telling me the same sorts of things. Finally, I told the two of them that they ought to get together because they'd bought cars that were basically identical. 
 I've been with them since, listening to them compare notes -- Joe about his $12,000 aqua Prizm and Jim about his $13,000 tan Corolla -- but the kernel of truth in all this still hadn't occurred to me. Sometimes I'm not so smart.
What it took was (gasp!) a press release from the American Automobile Association, which pointed out that the organization's auto pricing service could save consumers money by letting them know that less expensive cars are often clones of pricier models.
Dave Van Sickle, the A.A.A.'s engineering director, noted that the twins, triplets and quadruplets being manufactured in Detroit and elsewhere were virtually identical cars and that buyers could often use the information to their advantage.
The chart (at right) shows the vehicles that are built on the same platforms, often on the same assembly lines, but that have different nameplates, like Joe's Prizm and Jim's Corolla.
Both are products of New United Motors Manufacturing, the General Motors-Toyota partnership in Fremont, Calif., although some of the Corollas also come from a Toyota plant in Canada. And while there is some difference in styling, the half-sisters are the same under the skin.
According to Van Sickle, however, some insurance companies charge 5 percent more to insure the Toyota. And there was that $1,000 difference in the stickers that Joe and Jim found on their cars.
The A.A.A.'s pricing service (dial 1-800-932-0065) reports a similar figure in at least one area of the large-car category. Shoppers, it says, can save $1,124 by purchasing an Olds 98 Regency that retails for $26,500, rather than its twin, the Buick Park Avenue, at $27,624.
Among competitively priced siblings, the association says, there is also enough variation in standard equipment, colors, styling, option packages and accessories to give shoppers a real choice.
Further, clones expand an owner's service options; knowing that a Mitsubishi Mirage is the same as Plymouth and Dodge Colts and the Eagle Summit means you have a larger selection of repair shops.
Negotiating for a car with a twin can have other advantages, too. A clone that has lower sales may offer more "haggle room," for example, although it is important to note that the more popular model generally will hold its value better.
"Even the well-heeled can find a relative bargain," the A.A.A. said. "If you don't mind a different grille and headlights, opting for the long-wheelbase Bentley Brooklands at $152,400 rather than its twin, the $178,200 Rolls-Royce Silver Spur III, can save $25,800."
That's a nice bit of pocket change, but you can figure to donate it to the corner gas station. Another thing that the Bentley and Rolls have in common is an "economy" rating of 10 miles per gallon, city, and 13, highway. Easy come, easy go.

HEADLINE: In America;
The Voting Equation

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
On Thursday, while Mayor-elect Rudolph Giuliani met with a small group of supporters in the creaking, musty basement of Salem United Methodist Church in Harlem, a young man named Arnold Wattley stood on the sidewalk across the street and lamented Mr. Giuliani's election.
"It wasn't fair," said Mr. Wattley. He jammed his hands into his pockets and shifted from one foot to the other, his body tense against the damp, cool afternoon air. "They didn't give Dinkins a chance. Now it's going to be hell on us because Giuliani ain't down with no brothers." 
 Mr. Wattley, 26, described himself as an unemployed electrician. I interrupted his complaints about Mr. Giuliani to ask if he had voted Tuesday.
He looked startled. For a moment he couldn't speak. He had the good sense, at least, to be embarrassed. He hadn't voted.
I asked the question again and again, in Harlem, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, in Brownsville. Dinkins territory.
"Did you vote?"
"No."
"Did you vote?"
"You know, I had planned to vote."
"Did you vote?"
"Man, I couldn't make it."
We have heard that David Dinkins was defeated because so many white voters who usually vote Democratic voted against him. We have heard that he was swept out by a surge of Staten Island voters, many of them drawn to the polls to vote for secession. We have heard about anti-incumbent sentiment, the desire for change, and disenchantment with old-fashioned liberalism.
But we have not heard much about the tens of thousands of Dinkins supporters, most of whom are loudly complaining about the election of Mr. Giuliani, who could not get themselves to the polls on Election Day.
It's an easy equation. They vote, he wins.
Only a fool would deny that race played a major role in the election. But you don't fight racism by whining about it. You counter it with some form of action. In this instance, voting would have been a good start.
For Mr. Dinkins, the election results were probably a godsend. He escapes City Hall with a huge pension and his reputation intact. Instead of absorbing his daily barrage of criticism, the Mayor is now the toast of those who marvel at his grace and applaud his contribution to the healing of the city. People who trashed him a week ago now speak of him as a saint.
Mr. Giuliani, on the other hand, is entering the maelstrom. His first and most serious problem is not the budget deficit he will face as soon as he takes office but the resentment that has surged through black neighborhoods since Tuesday night.
Arnold Wattley's view, correct or incorrect, is the prevailing one: that David Dinkins was treated unfairly because of his color, and that Rudolph Giuliani is no friend of black people.
It is not that African-Americans across the city thought that David Dinkins was such a terrific mayor; it is their feeling that a comparable white mayor who was a Democrat would have been re-elected.
Mr. Giuliani has gone out of his way since the election to stress that he will not run an "exclusionary" administration. He has visited black neighborhoods, and he has promised to reconsider some of his campaign positions that have caused unease among African-Americans.
He deserves a chance. And he could use some help getting his message out.
Mr. Giuliani does not have an extensive network of contacts and organizations linking him to black and brown neighborhoods. That is especially dangerous when some of those neighborhoods are rife with frustration, anger and fear.
Black and Latino leaders would provide a tremendous service to the city by cooperating with Mr. Giuliani in forging the necessary links.
Mr. Giuliani can help himself by seeking the advice of Bill Lynch, Mayor Dinkins's closest aide, on establishing stronger contacts in the neighborhoods. Mr. Lynch is an expert in that area.
And it would be wise to keep Raymond Kelly on as Police Commissioner, a move Mr. Giuliani is considering. Mr. Kelly is respected by law enforcement people and by the people in the neighborhoods, a combination that is especially needed in New York right now.

HEADLINE: Health Plan Is Toughest On Doctors Making Most

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
After a quarter century of surging incomes that made many of them millionaires, the nation's doctors now face the prospect of stable or shrinking pay.
Vulnerable to the biggest declines are specialists whose incomes have soared with the advent of expensive medical procedures -- cardiac surgeons, for example, who make an average of $575,000 in private practice, and radiologists, who make an average of $310,000. At the same time, family practitioners, who now average about $119,000 a year, may hold their ground or see modest increases in income. 
 "The half-million-dollar-a-year doctor, I think, is in trouble now," said Dr. John M. Eisenberg, chairman of medicine at Georgetown University and chairman of an advisory group to Congress on Federal payments to doctors. He predicted a leveling of medical pay, saying, "I suspect physicians will continue to be in the upper 1 percent of the American public in income, but we'll see less disparity among them."
 
What Is Fair?
 The question of what income would be fair and reasonable is an often unspoken subtext of the health care debate. As it promotes its health plan, the White House speaks of improving medical "efficiency," not of slashing salaries; doctors warn of the possible impact of cost controls on patient welfare rather than about what new limits portend for their own livelihoods.
New pressure on doctors' fees is already coming from insurers, who are more aggressively negotiating discounts and challenging high bills, and the Federal Government, which is reallocating Medicare payments among specialties as well as limiting total payments. That pressure will intensify if Congress adopts anything resembling President Clinton's health proposals, which would encourage more prepaid care and set limits on medical spending.
Payments for "physician services" account for only about one-fifth of all the money spent on health care, Federal data show. Clearly, restricting the pay of individual doctors offers no panacea for runaway health costs, but lower fees for many medical services will almost certainly be part of any plan for curbing health spending.
The prospect of stagnant or reduced pay has caused soul-searching and anger among many doctors and growing conflict among specialists, now fighting for shares of a pie that no one expects will keep expanding as in the past.
What many experts consider excess payments for surgical and diagnostic procedures may also be harming patients, medical experts say, by encouraging doctors to subject them to unneeded procedures.
The most frequently cited income statistics are compiled by the American Medical Association. The association's most recent data, for 1991, found an average net income among all doctors of $171,000. Among 17 specialties listed by the A.M.A., average incomes ranged from a low of $112,000 for family practitioners to a high of $274,000 among orthopedic surgeons.
But these averages mask enormous differences between and within specialties.
A more detailed and recent breakdown of incomes in 46 specialties and subspecialties provides a far more revealing picture of earnings at the upper end. These data, compiled by a medical trade association, show that a minority of doctors in certain specialties are making vastly more money than others.
Those doctors at the high end include cardiac surgeons, who have exceptionally long training, high stress and long working hours. They also include radiologists, whose training is not as arduous and who often work normal office hours but use technicians to serve large numbers of patients at high fees.
These more detailed numbers were collected by the Medical Group Management Association in Englewood, Colo., a trade group that includes 113,000 doctors in group practices with three or more members. These doctors make up "a fairly representative cross-section of American medicine," said David M. Gans, a senior project director at the association, although their incomes tend to be somewhat higher than those of doctors in solo or academic practice.
 
Vast Range of Income
 At the high end, the group association data show that cardiac surgeons made an average of $575,000 in 1992, and neurosurgeons an average of $449,000. Orthopedic and hand surgeons averaged more than $300,000, while diagnostic radiologists had average incomes of $310,000.
At the low end, doctors in family practice averaged $119,000, those in pediatrics $124,000 and those in general internal medicine $130,000.
The association also provides a breakdown of incomes within the specialties, showing that 10 percent of cardiac surgeons, for example, made more than $887,000; 10 percent of radiologists made more than $469,000, and 10 percent of ophthalmologists more than $434,000.
There is no objective way to determine how much doctors should make compared with other professions. Many doctors argue that the rise in their income over recent decades was not excessive compared with the increases in lawyers' or bankers' incomes. But those professionals make no bones that making money is one of their chief goals. Doctors defending their incomes are more apt to cite their extensive training and the miraculous benefits they offer.
"People pay orthopedic surgeons more because they feel that what we do is so skilled and specialized," said Dr. Bernard Rineberg, an orthopedist in New Brunswick, N.J., and president of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. He noted that a hip replacement could take someone from a wheelchair to a nearly normal life.
Dr. Dean Kross, a cardiologist in Pittsburgh, said that he had trained for six years beyond his four years of medical school and worked long, often stressful days. "I treat patients in the throes of a heart attack who survive and can go back to work without the terror of facing death on an ongoing basis," Dr. Kross said. "I don't know what that is worth."
What is clear is that doctors have largely evaded normal economic forces. Studies have found a growing surplus of doctors in some medical specialties compared with the need, yet incomes have continued to rise.
"Supply and demand economics never applied to doctors," said Dr. Ira M. Rutkow, a hernia surgeon in Freehold, N.J., who also holds a doctorate in health economics. With insurers paying almost whatever was asked, specialists could make up for declining volume with higher prices.
As recently as the 1950's, disparities among the incomes of different specialists were not that huge, although surgeons usually made the most, said Dr. Albert D. Roberts, an internist and a nephrologist at the University of Texas at Houston. He noted the crucial role that Medicare, the Federal program for the elderly, initially played in raising fees of some specialists.
When it was founded in the mid-1960's, Medicare agreed to pay "usual and customary rates" for doctors' services. In the 1970's, as the Government became concerned about soaring costs, those traditional fees were locked into the Medicare payment scale. But as new surgical and diagnostic techniques developed, Dr. Roberts said, " 'usual and customary' tended to be whatever the first surgeon charged."
 
'Fortunes Began to Be Made'
 As Dr. Eisenberg describes it, "the trick was to start up as high as you could when you adopted a new service." Private payers followed the Federal lead.
So, while surgeons may have been receiving $1,200 for removal of a lung, those who did the first cardiac bypass operations could say it was worth $5,000, and get it. The story was similar for other advances -- usually, to be sure, of major benefit to patients -- like hip and knee replacements, cataract and retinal surgery and diagnostic tools like fiberoptic scopes and new imaging techniques.
For instance, gastroenterologists had been receiving $50 or $60 for peering into the colon with the rigid proctoscope, but then the technology changed. "Those who mastered the new scopes started charging $1,000 for it," Dr. Roberts said. "Fortunes began to be made.
"So the gastroenterologists and cardiologists have princely incomes," Dr. Roberts added, "while the non-procedural doctors, those using the trained brain, are typically paid at the same old rates."
Furthermore, the financial reward for doing tests and surgery are such that many experts suspect it leads to overuse of procedures, perhaps to the detriment of patients.
"The current system pays you multiple times over to do the procedure instead of watching and waiting," Dr. Eisenberg said. "Any normal human being has to fight off the financial incentive to go ahead and do the procedure."
In 1992, Medicare began phasing in its new fee schedule, which seeks to link payments more closely to the actual training, cost and time involved in performing a given service. In an extreme case, cataract surgery, which has become a relatively simple and quick operation, Medicare fees are declining to below $900 from $1,500, said Paul B. Ginsburg, executive director of the Physician Payment Review Commission, a Congressional advisory body.
Medicare payments account for about one-fourth of the average doctor's income. Today, private insurers pay doctors more than Medicare does for a given service. But many Blue Cross plans and private insurers, while keeping a higher overall level of fees, are adopting Medicare's method of re-ranking the relative value of different services. This will only intensify the pressure on upper-end specialists.
 
H.M.O. Salaries
 If an era of spectacular incomes for a minority of doctors appears to be closing, the financial future for the majority may not be as bleak as many fear. With or without the Clinton plan, more doctors may end up in health maintenance organizations, many of which have doctors on salary. If current H.M.O. salaries are any guide, doctors who join will have handsome incomes, usually with shorter days and few of the administrative headaches of private practice.
A national survey in early 1993 by Warren Surveys of Rockford, Ill., shows that H.M.O.'s pay somewhat less than private practice, but are still fairly generous. The average H.M.O. salary for orthopedic surgeons was $207,000, while the senior surgeon in each group received an average of $429,000. Bonuses averaged $12,000.
Near the lower end, the average H.M.O. salary for pediatricians was $98,000, with senior doctors averaging $135,000 and bonuses averaging $7,000.
Even the worst nightmare of many doctors -- national adoption of Medicare fees for all patients -- would not mean calamity. A study in the Fall 1993 Health Affairs by Christopher Hogan of the Physician Payment Review Commission found that universal adoption of Medicare fees would yield net incomes for doctors of $100,000 to $200,000. Incomes of general doctors would typically rise, while those of specialists would fall, in some cases drastically.
"It's very clear that society gives physicians a signal about what it values by how it pays them," said Dr. Eisenberg, the commission chairman. "Now, it's giving a changing signal."

HEADLINE: Strategist Stayed Calm In the Storm

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
On Election Night, with the outcome of New Jersey's gubernatorial race far from being settled and the political future of his candidate, Christine Todd Whitman, and perhaps his own on the line, Ed Rollins retired to his hotel room to watch his favorite television show -- the police series, "NYPD Blue."
"When I went back downstairs to see where we were, we had dropped by about 40,000 votes," Mr. Rollins recalled. "It didn't upset me too much, because I tend to get calmer in a fight." 
 Mr. Rollins had had a real fight on his hands. Like an aging gunslinger, he had gone up against the new top gun, James Carville, the man who in many politicians' minds had displaced him as the nation's top political strategist and who had been imported to salvage Gov. Jim Florio's political career.
Hours later, after it became clear that the New Jersey electorate would not provide Mr. Florio a second term or Mr. Carville another political miracle, a bewildered Mr. Carville told a crush of reporters who gathered about him: "I don't like to lose, I'm a competitive guy."
 
Another Opportunity
 And he may have lost more than the Governor's office. The race has been widely interpreted as evidence the President is largely powerless to help his most loyal supporters in time of need, and further, that voters do not forgive tax increases or look benignly on incumbents. For their part, the Democrats reply that for Mr. Florio to have come as close as he did amounted to a moral victory -- though you can't take moral victories to the bank.
For Ed Rollins, the Whitman campaign was seen as an opportunity to repair a slightly bruised reputation.
He had orchestrated Ronald Reagan's 1984 landslide, a 49-state triumph, but last year he made himself a pariah to at least some highly influential Republicans when he signed on as campaign co-chairman for Ross Perot. His tenure in that post was even briefer (and unhappier) than Mr. Perot's initial fling at the Presidency. (Mr. Perot dropped out in July, then rejoined the game in the fall.)
"All the stories of me being an outcast of the Republican Party were never true," Mr. Rollins said. "This was not quite the make or break that some people wanted to make of it."
"I've been in politics for 32 years and this was the best campaign I've ever run against," said Mr. Rollins, tipping his hat to Mr. Carville. "But in the end, we had a better ground operation and that made the difference."
 
Respect for Her Grit
 Mr. Rollins also emerged with considerable respect for his candidate's grit. "The beating Mrs. Whitman took, the vast majority of candidates would be under the bed saying, 'Please stop it, please stop it,' " said Mr. Rollins. "We've all had candidates like that. I had a billionaire who was like that."
Mr. Carville and Mr. Rollins provided as much a clash in style and public persona as the candidates they represented.
Gray-haired and paternal, at 50 Mr. Rollins is just two years older than Mr. Carville, but they project images that are worlds apart.
"I'm not used to having the high profile," Mr. Rollins said. "I've never lived quite the life that Carville has."
Mr. Carville's Louisiana heritage, his folksy but barbed humor and his scorched-earth style of politicking long ago earned him the nickname the "Ragin' Cajun." In last year's Presidential race, he coined one of the catch phrases of American politics: "It's the economy, stupid!"
"People don't hire people like James and me for our personality, for our charm," said Paul Begala, his partner. "They hire us to win. We take this very personally, so we're hurting."
Mr. Rollins took day-to-day command in mid-October, the day after a New York Times-CBS News poll had shown Mrs. Whitman trailing by 21 points. To all appearances, her campaign, under the command of her brother, was foundering. "I was able to get the strategy focused," Mr. Rollins told television interviewer John McLaughlin this week. "We focused it back on his record. We basically asked people to give her another chance, that she really was the candidate of hope."
With two weeks to go, Mr. Rollins said, he took Mrs. Whitman aside and said, "Christie, you have got to make this thing happen. You have got to connect with the voters, and if that means telling the truth about Jim Florio, that is what you have to do." After that, he said, his candidate found a new aggressiveness and a new assurance.
"I always said that Jim Florio was the issue in this race and if you put Christie Whitman beside him, you couldn't lose."
 
Not All Were Surprised
 Though the Whitman campaign had seemed to be bumping bottom, not all her gladiators were surprised, they say. "The conventional wisdom is always very rough on challenger races," Mike Murphy, a Whitman consultant, told an interviewer after the election, "because you tend to get beat up during the summer, you tend to get high negatives, and then you tend to win October and win the election and surprise everyone."
That happened, he said, because challengers -- including Mrs. Whitman -- "tend to hold their dollars and win the one month that counts, and that month is October."
Mr. Carville's bruising and hard-edged campaigning had made him a strategist feared by his opponents and lionized by those he served, including President Clinton, whose cause he shepherded a year ago.
In Mr. Florio, he found his kind of fighter but also his toughest challenge.
Three years ago, in his first year as Governor, Mr. Florio had set off a storm of public anger and was written off as politically dead after he raised taxes by a record $2.8 billion. But with a campaign strategy scripted by Mr. Carville that included unrelenting attacks on his Republican rival, Mr. Florio came within two percentage points of winning re-election.
 
Carville's Lament
 On election night, a dumbfounded Mr. Carville was left to lament the outcome and offer television cameras an uncharacteristic display of self-doubt.
"I'm disappointed in myself," he said. "I let the Governor down. We just didn't do it; in the end, we didn't make it."
The next day, he flew off to Paris, his favorite decompression spot, and left it to Mr. Begala to give the Florio defeat a final spin.
"I think the lesson from both of these candidates is that tenacity matters," Mr. Begala said. "But my greatest fear is that politicians will take the wrong lesson out of this race -- that they have to play it safe to have any chance of being re-elected -- and it will weaken the little backbone that they have left."
Mr. Rollins drew a more pointed conclusion. "If there is a lesson to be learned," he said, "it's that an incumbent in a re-election effort is really judged on his record. You can get a lot of other issues involved in the campaign, but in the final analysis, voters make an up-or-down decision on the incumbent.
"The national consequences are that the Republicans won the big races on Tuesday and will now have the crowing rights for a while. But in the final analysis," he predicted, "if Bill Clinton is successful as President it doesn't matter who the alternative is. If he fails as President, if the economy fails, then obviously it's very difficult to be re-elected."
 
Next Time?
 The candidates' polling as well as independent exit polls show that the election was won in its final days when thousands of undecided voters shifted to Mrs. Whitman, many on the strength of her promise to cut taxes if elected.
Mr. Carville's role as a political strategist for Mr. Clinton has extended beyond last year's race. The President has brought him in to help on such matters as the North American Free Trade Agreement and on his health care package.
Mr. Begala said he and Mr. Carville also are committed to two high-profile political races next year: the re-election campaigns of Senator Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania and Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia, both former clients.
If President Clinton seeks a second term, Mr. Carville is expected to work with that campaign, a prospect that could again place him on the opposite side of Mr. Rollins.
"Having this victory, there certainly will be ample opportunities to do other things," said Mr. Rollins, who except for his dalliance with Mr. Perot and Mrs. Whitman's campaign had stayed out of elected politics since the Reagan years. "Right now, I just intend to go back and put my corporate business back together."

HEADLINE: Enlightenment On the Harbor

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
IT'S A LITTLE unreal, this place called Battery Park City. Laid out in 1979, the 92-acre office and residential development on lower Manhattan was designed to re-create the look of an earlier day. The neatly aligned facades of the masonry apartment buildings, the tidy streets and the old-fashioned lampposts lining them recall New York in palmier times, before the postwar suburban e3xodus had transformed the work "urban" inito a prefix for "decline."
 Stuyvesant High School, the most recent addition to the neighborhood, also looks too good to be true. Designed by Cooper, Robertson & Partners inassociation with Gruzen Samton Steinglass, the new school stands in benignly defiant contrast ot the dark images of poverty, illiteracy, violence and drugs often associated with big-city public schools. Instead, the building's sturdy masonry walls, devoid of graffiti, refresh the idea that the public school is among the finest flowers of America's Englightenment roots. 
 And in Stuyvesant's case, at least, the distinctive architecture accurately reflects the condition of the institution it was designed to house. Founded in 1904, and renowned for its outstanding science curriculum and its roster of distinguished alumni, Stuyvesant has long been a bright beacon in the New York City school system. But by the 1980's the school, with an enrollment of nearly 3,000 students, and a need for new science facilities, had outgrown its old building on West 15th Street, and in 1986 the decision was made to look for a new site. The handsome result, completed last fall, is the architectural equivalent of those leather book bags students used to tote before the advent of nylon backpacks. It's stutfy, spiffy and, for now, somewhat stiff.
 
 
An Unusual Collaboration on Design
 The design is the result of an unusual collaboration between the architects and the Stuyvesant Coalition, a volunteer group that became, in effect, the architects' collective client. Formed when discussions about the move were getting under way, the Coalition inlcuded current and former students, teachers, parents and administrators.
 In a sense, the coalition became a school for the architects. Renee Levine, a mother of two Stuyvesant alumnae who now works at the school as "building coordinator," says that "Stuyvesant is not a building but a state of mind." And a major function of the coalition was to educate the architects to grasp that idea. When two members of the design team showed up for their first meeting with coalition members, they were given pencils, pads and T-shirts and assigned a student "buddy." Soon they found themselves sitting in on calculus classes, joining students for lunch, attending gym and chatting informally about life in an urban school.
 Though the students were generally pleased to be leaving the old building, they were strongly attached to its atmosphere and hoped the architects could somehow transplant it. The old building, for example, boasted a fine old jgrand staircase. Couldn't the new building have one, too? The old school's auditorium had a balcony, a design feature that has largely disappeared from comtemporary architects' vocabularies. Wouldn't it be nice to revive it? The students wanted a serious place of learning, but also a haven of warmth. They asked the architects to avoid primary colors and use traditional building materials like granite, brick and wood.
 Happily, these desires coincided with the aims of Alexander Cooper, the school's chief design architect and the co-author of Bettery Park City's 1979 master plan. And moving the school to Battery Park City enabled Mr. Cooper to fulfill the plan's original spirit. Originally, the magnificent waterfront site was to be occupied by luxury housing, an economically attractive option but one that would have reinforced the community's exclusivity. With a major civic institution, the neighborhood would at last gain the public identity that the master plan was designed to evoke.
 The wedge-shaped site had a major drawback: it was tiny, barely 60,000 square feet. If the school's plant was to be expanded, the only place to go was up. This has resulted in a distinctly untraditional 10-story building, twice the height of the usual New York City school. While the students got their staircase, and a stately granite lobby at its foot, the stairs have become a largely ceremonial adjunct to a fast-moving "skip-stop" escalator system that rises through the building's core.
 The architects compensated for the height by breaking up the building's bulk: separating Stuyvesant's academic from its non-academic functions and giving each a distinct architectural treatment. The school's 70-plus classrooms and labs are housed within the 10-story structure, an academic tower clad in buff and brown brick, with finely proportioned windows that give the block a sense of scale. Rising from a base of white limistone, and capped by a curved penthouse of gleaming stainless steel, the tower resembles an updated version of the large industrial buildings that proliferated in nearby TriBeCa in the prewar decades.
 Stuyvesant's non-academic areas are clustered in a trio of lower buildings attached to the northern edge of the classroom block. Housing, respectively, the school's athletic facilities (two full-size gyms, stacked atop a competition pool), the auditorium (with, yes, a terrific balcony) and the shop wing (topped by a penthouse cafeteria with peerless river views), these structures help to create the impression of a campus - a quadrangle without its central courtyard.
 In effect, the courtyard has moved indoors. The escalator core, and the corridors bordering it, have become not only the school's chief circulation spine but also its chief areas for students to gather. This was a deliberate feature of the design. Instead of providing student lounges, the architects created informal spaces "where things could happen": shallow alcoves or stretches of hallway where a Ping-Pong table might materialize, a band could rehearse or a group of seniors might unoffically assert their territorial claims.
 
 
A Serious, Working-Place Atmosphere
 Stuyvesant originated as a manual trade school, and its industrial origins persist inthe serious, working-place atmosphere that pervades tha academic block, with its tiered classrooms, chemistry and physics labs, banks of computer terminals, and the shop wing's somewhat spooky laboratory for sophisticated robotics. The industrial look, too, is evident in what Alexander Cooper calls the "subway esthtic" of the interior finishes of ceremic and vinyl tile. but pride of place is given to a dignified two-story library, in the exact heart of the building; furnished in warm woods, the library is expressed on the building's southern facade with a columned loggia of classical proporations.
 The move has had its share of bumps. The beautiful pool has beenj out of commission because of leaks. The drinking fountains had to be turned off when pipes carrying toxic wastes endangered the water supply. And the school has yet to work out an agreement with the Battery Park City Authority over the community use of the auditorium and the athletic wing.
 Like Battery Park City itself, in other words, Stuyvesant High School needs some breaking in. You can duplicate the trappings of tradition, but you can't fake the familiarityj that comes from years of use.

Instead of lounges, architects created informal spaces "where things could happen" - alcoves for Ping-Pong, impromptu band rehearsals ro for seniors, say, to stake out territory.
