HEADLINE: Treating Drugs at School

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif.

 BODY:
KARL GONZALES tried alcohol and marijuana at his older brother's urging at age 7. He got his first tattoo at 11, joined a Latin gang at 12 and was arrested for stealing car parts at 13. By 14 he was smoking pot regularly, and at 15 he dropped out of school.
 Then things got ugly. 
At 16 he was fighting with knives, carrying guns and using cocaine, and was shot in the stomach by a rival gang member. The following year he was dealing drugs, smuggling Uzis and M-16's and was arrested for trying to steal a car.
 A probation officer sent Karl, who is from Los Angeles, to Phoenix Academy, a residential high school here for teen-agers with drug problems. The school is one of five that were established in California, New Jersey and New York in the 1980's and early 90's by Phoenix House, the nation's largest residential drug-treatment organization and the first to make the schools available to teen-agers of any economic status.
 
Skipping Class, Using LSD at 16
 Holly Oehlman, the 16-year-old middle child in a Long Beach, Calif., family of five, was using LSD the summer before her freshman year of high school. Drawn to the wrong crowd, she became a Deadhead -- a devotee of the rock group the Grateful Dead. At first she skipped classes, then whole days of school. When she did attend, she was usually high on drugs. Her parents, Bill and Pam Oehlman, placed her in short-term hospital treatment programs but they didn't work. "We were on a mental roller coaster," said her father, a 47-year-old building contractor. "Her actions were on the edge and beyond."
 Holly was enrolled at Phoenix Academy by her parents, along with Karl and 50 other teen-agers.
 Karl is now free of drugs, working on the student newspaper as a graphic artist, jogging several miles a week and, as head of the grounds crew, making sure the hedges are trimmed. Academically, he is thriving. Holly is earning high honors, and is immersed in theater and other activities.
 Phoenix House says Karl and Holly are taking one of the few approaches that can work for such teen-agers. Its philosophy is that educating anyone seriously addicted to drugs is next to impossible, but that for many adolescents, drug treatment is far more effective and longer-lasting if it is combined with sound education.
 Staff members at the labyrinthine academy with its red-tiled roof, tucked into a busy commercial landscape here, say their first task is often piecing back together personalities ripped apart both by drugs and the pain of the urban life from which drugs may have been an escape -- the effects of childhood abuse or neglect, the disappearance of a parent or parental divorce, peer pressure or violence. The task is to set these young people off on a kind of inner search for elements of themselves never developed, like patience, discipline, compassion, a sense of achievement, even their own emotions. Especially their own emotions.
 "Feelings will get you -- like a soda bottle," says Karl, making a vigorous shaking motion with his hands. "Before I was always on drugs, so I didn't know what feelings were. Sometimes I want to run out of here because it hurts too much."
 William H. Smith, director of clinical services for Phoenix House programs in California, explained the importance of getting students to look inside. "The drug addiction itself, in our way of looking at it, is a symptom of an underlying cause," he said. "If we can teach people how to feel better about themselves, how to manage their feelings, how to work on some self-discipline and how to be positive, the addiction part of their life will take care of itself."
 Most of the students at the Santa Ana academy say they don't want to be here; they need to be here. But observing them singing before 8 A.M., spurring one another on, hugging counselors, saying what's on their minds, one gets the feeling the first half of their contention is not always accurate.
Some students work at their own pace and some need intensive remedial help in a program that is a collaboration between Phoenix House, which provides buildings, drug counselors and students, and the local school district, which supplies teachers and textbooks.
 The air at one recent morning class was sharp with concentration as students drew time lines of world history. A boy, researching the date of Jesus' birth, was amused to find that it is now estimated to be 4 B.C. One girl mischievously added the year she lost her virginity. But the atmosphere is not always this kind of teachers' dream. Eyes glazed over during a lesson on common versus proper nouns and transitive verbs.
 But on the whole, the teachers are pleased with the environment. Indeed, the students, given responsibility for each other, may privately -- or publicly --help out in this regard, confronting each other if one talks in class or blows off homework, as they put it.
 
Teachers Must Walk a Fine Line
 The students are neither robots nor adults. They squirm and fidget. They indulge in horseplay, though it's officially forbidden. They give each other high-fives. They get moody. The teachers and counselors must walk a fine line, remembering to let them act their age.
 It is also true that the students often rely excessively on staff members, wanting to make them Mommy and Daddy. In some cases, drugs have effectively blocked their maturity. "When you get into heavy drug use with people who are not fully developed psychologically, you can have certain kinds of damage occurring," said Rodney Skager, a professor of educational psychology at the University of California at Los Angeles. "They stay children, particularly in terms of things like impulsiveness and their ability to plan and deal with frustration."
 For that reason, these schools sometimes resemble the Marine boot camp Parris Island, and initial dropout rates are high; 40 to 50 percent of all new residents leave in the first month or two.
 Every minute is structured. Even going to the bathroom is scheduled. There are rules upon rules: initially girls can't wear any makeup, but eventually they can put on mascara. Boys can't grow mustaches or wear pants with the crotch around the knees.
 The academies begin promptly to teach discipline and responsibility. Students are given in-house jobs and are encouraged to climb up a hierarchy of positions, earning power and respect. Group therapy in self-understanding and honesty is given three times a week (when students are allowed to use profane language --an opportunity they seize with gusto) and all are encouraged to vent their feelings in confronting each other. At first it can be rough. "When a kid comes in, their whole code is from the streets: there's no telling on anybody, they lie all the time," said Howard Friend, senior director of the Phoenix House here. "It takes awhile for the peer pressure of the group to break that down."
 More intense group sessions last five hours and center on one subject, such as abandonment or grieving. Six months into the program, residents go through marathon sessions of 24 to 36 hours, in which various psychodramas are enacted. "They recognize that they are safe and can say what they want and no one will punish them for it," said Dr. Mitchell S. Rosenthal, president of Phoenix House. "They can tell their worst fears, their worst secrets and humiliations. They find the loneliness and alienation start to disappear and that they have 'family,' brothers and sisters, people who really know them and can help them."
 Parents are urged to attend weekly family therapy and a social afternoon tea to help open lines of communication.
 Holly's impish smile cuts through her ethereal aura: "We've grown so much. I had never expressed any feelings to my parents except that 'I hate you' or 'everything's fine.' " Her father says he has grown, too: "I've become more aware of the negative things I would carelessly say before" -- barking "knock it off" at his children -- whereas now, he says, "I sit down with them and talk about how to disagree in a constructive way."
 Phoenix House has a saying: "When you're looking good, you're looking bad." This means that a student whose room and appearance are consistently tidy and whose grades and behavior are always good may be on automatic pilot, headed for a crash. Counselors would rather students undergo a more turbulent metamorphosis, acting out in controlled situations. "You don't want them going through the motions, putting up a front, " says Mr. Smith, "and then when you get them back out there and take away the restraints, they fall on their faces."
 In fact, 90 percent of those who stay past the first two months graduate from the program, which lasts from 12 to 18 months in the facility itself and another year in which the student returns for group therapy and other activities.
 Is Phoenix House waging a relatively small battle in a hopelessly large war?
 In addition to the academy here, where there are 35 names on the waiting list, California has another in the mountains outside San Diego with 40 students; a third on the boardwalk in Venice with 50 students, and a fourth academy under construction in Los Angeles. In the East, it has an academy in Yorktown, N.Y., for 300 students and one in Rockleigh, N.J., for 35.
 But in Santa Ana, the county seat of Orange County, 6,500 juveniles are watched by the county Probation Department, and a recent study showed that 43 percent of all youths had drugs in their system when they were arrested, most for burglarizing homes. "Phoenix House serves a very great long-term need," says Michael Schumacher, chief probation officer. "They're making a meaningful dent. But it's still just a dent."
 As with many excellent social service programs run by nonprofit organizations, the obstacles to expanding them usually come down to a lack of money and commitment. Phoenix academies have faced other hurdles, from a not-in-my-backyard attitude on school location to bureaucratic fighting among substance-abuse agencies and education departments. No funds from the Federal Department of Education, for example, may go toward drug treatment, only prevention.
 Though much less expensive than youth detention centers, the Phoenix academies still cost between $20,000 and $35,000 a student a year. That sum is paid in part by social service agencies and probation departments. The few parents who can afford it pay their entire bill, while most pay according to a sliding scale. Phoenix House aggressively courts corporations, foundations and private individuals for money. Despite these efforts, however, the programs remain "just a dent." And local, state and Federal governments -- in other words, the taxpayers -- have been inclined in the last decade to cut back, not enlarge, social programs.
 "There are so many thousands of kids who need these services, and what's tragic is that this model hasn't been expanded," says Mitchell Rosenthal. "We need a President and First Lady who will say, 'By God, we're going to lose an entire generation of these kids if we don't provide more of these services.' We have the means to fix the problem -- but we don't have the will."
 All students leave the program for the yearlong "live-out" phase. For some, this coincides with a return to their original high school to complete their studies. Others get their high school diplomas directly from the academy, and the live-out period entails finding a job and living on their own.
 All along the way toward graduation, the kids work on self-esteem, and often the first glimmers of success with this are seen in the classroom. As they do better and better on assignments, a constructive peer pressure tends to compound the positive results. The meaning of "cool" is redefined.
 "In our school the peer pressure is reversed," Mr. Smith said. "The pressure is to do well, not to drop out. It's not 'If you study, you're a chump.' One of the biggest things the kids tell us when they move back home and go to school is how now they are viewed as the nerd."
 In addition, staff members try to move the students toward depending less on the teachers and counselors and more on each other. "Spread it around" is a refrain of theirs. The residents are not allowed to associate with their former drug-using friends, so they need new friendships.
 "That's my goal right now -- to make best friends and build a support system," says Holly. Karl has no choice. His five buddies from his former life have vanished: Three are dead; one is missing, the fifth is serving life for murder. Karl prefers his new friends anyway. "They're not after you for your money or your drugs, or because you have a car," he said. "They're there because they're your friends."

HEADLINE: How the Unemployed Are Facing Changes in the Workplace

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
ECONOMISTS would say Eugene J. Cribbin and Catherine Devito are "meeting the challenge of change." Mr. Cribbin and Mrs. Devito, unemployed as a result of company staff reductions, say, however, that they are enrolled in the occupational-training center run by the Board of Cooperative Educational Services in Yorktown Heights because they need jobs.
Mr. Cribbin, 48, married and the father of four, spent 30 years in the banking industry. For the last seven years, he was data-center manager for Chase Manhattan Bank. Now he is studying to become a licensed practical nurse. 
 "I guess I saw it coming," Mr. Cribbin said, referring to the loss of his job. "The banking industry is not doing well, and data processing, in particular, has been downsized."
Mr. Cribbin added that he first thought of entering the health-care field as a viable alternative to banking when he was a patient in a hospital. "This time around, I wanted a skill that would make me independent, and one that was transferable and flexible. As a health-care-giver in private practice you can set your own time, and when you pass the New York State Boards, you are licensed to practice in every other state. I know I will be earning less, but I will be gaining more in personal satisfaction, and, eventually, I hope to go on for further training and become a registered nurse."
 
An Increase in Enrollment
 He recalled the reaction when he told his wife and children about his decision to become a nurse. "At first my wife was shocked," he said. "The children were understanding, and now they all think health care is a good second-career choice for me."
Mr. Cribbin, who started classes on Sept. 8, is enrolled in a full-time day program. "The women in the class outnumber us -- 35 to 5."
Kevin Hart, director of occupational education for the Board of Cooperative Educational Services, said that an increasing number of students taking courses at the occupational-training center are dislocated workers, adults who have lost their jobs. "We have 23 different programs, and this fall we have noted higher enrollments in all of them," Mr. Hart said.
 
A Victim of 'Downsizing'
 The occupational program, he added, provides daytime classes for adults in training programs, which range from 120 to 1,200 hours in health care, word processing, food service and cosmetology. "The programs serve unemployed and dislocated workers and are open to the public," Mr. Hart said. "All students receive support services during their training: career counseling, job development and job placement."
Ruth F. Richards, the coordinator of the adult education program at the board, said: "Today there are so many mature adults who are unemployed. Everyone is interested in finding a new career. Many students are preparing for a second, even a third, career."
Mrs. Devito, who said she is older than 50, is one of them. She was first a business manager, then a customer sales and service representative, who worked for the last three years in Ossining at Hudson International Conductors, a wire manufacturer. On Aug. 1, she lost her job.
"I am a victim of company downsizing," she said. When Hudson, an old-line family firm in business for 90 years, was taken over by the Phelps Dodge Corporation, the Phoenix-based copper-mining giant, Phelps "melded it into their plant in Inman, S.C., consequently terminating almost all of the Hudson employees. But I have to work, and when Phelps Dodge gave us a job-training option, in September I enrolled in the word-processing program at Boces to improve and update my skills."
Mrs. Devito described the course as wonderful. "It is really fun and so exciting to be learning something new," she said. "I only hope when I finish I will become more marketable, since I feel my age is against me in the job market."
Vickie Moretti, who is 36, has a job as an administrative assistant at Reader's Digest in Chappaqua, yet Ms. Moretti is taking a course in cosmetology at the continuing-education program at the occupational-training center.
"In today's world, when you can't count on any job lasting forever, I feel it is important to diversify," she said. "I am the oldest one in the class. Although I have always been interested in cosmetology as a career, I took a lot of secretarial courses when I was young on the advice of my parents and my guidance counselors. I'm not sorry about that, but I have a feel for cosmetology. I'm glad I finally did something about it. There are always jobs for skilled cosmeticians."
Ms. Moretti, who is being reimbursed for her tuition by Reader's Digest, said she expects to take a two-year certification program to apply for her license from the State Board.
Ms. Richards said: "Our continuing-education program offers short-term career-related courses four times a year. We have an enrollment of 1,400 students currently, who take courses four nights a week and on Saturdays in career-focused categories such as business management, computers, construction trades and culinary arts."
 
A Need for Collaboration
 Mr. Hart said there was a paradox in the fact that while many companies were laying off workers there is a shortage of skilled labor and that that is already damaging America's competitive position in world markets.
"What's happening is that the nature of work has changed so quickly that academic and vocational institutions will have to collaborate if we are going to get people with the skills we need to do the jobs of the future," he said. "For example, take auto mechanics. Today an auto mechanic has to know an awful lot. He has to understand computers, and you can teach a whole course in physics through auto mechanics. Vocational teachers will have to pour more academics into their courses, and by the same token academic teachers must learn to teach more practical applications to support concepts in order to raise the capabilities of high school students who are career bound."
Observing that by the year 2000 70 percent of jobs in the nation will require skilled workers with specific training rather than a college degree, Mr. Hart said: "Thanks to a new educational concept known as 'tech prep,' which is part of the New York State Career Pathways plan, Boces has four tech prep courses under way with more in the developmental stage. Students are required to take academically demanding courses in mathematics, science and communications while continuing their vocational education."
The Career Pathways plan, he said, will require students to have academic technology and work experience during their school year, but the proportion of each will vary according to individual goals. A Career Pathway certificate, somewhere between a high school diploma and a college degree, will be granted to the students on graduation.

HEADLINE: After a Suit, Moving to a New Life

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
ONCE she navigates past the smoke-scarred lobby downstairs, the litter in the hallways and the three dead-bolt locks at her front door, Carol Giddins finally enters a private oasis -- her tidy two-bedroom, plant-filled apartment that belies the squalor below.
But the sixth-floor apartment on this city's west side has also become a fortress that Ms. Giddins and her two children -- Lacrecia, 9, and Michael, 20 -- leave warily these days. The streets below are scattered with the detritus of drug users, and the threat of crime and violence pervades, she said. Ms. Giddins can recall only two times in nine years when she allowed Lacrecia to play outside. 
 Now a plan, tentatively approved by a Federal judge, may change all that for Ms. Giddins and up to 1,000 poor minority families who live in crime-ridden ghetto areas and receive Federal rent subsidies under a program known as Section 8, which is intended to help low-income families.
Seventeen black and Hispanic families who filed suit in 1991 against the United States Department of Urban Development and other agencies say they want to move out of southwest Yonkers into mostly white areas of Westchester. The minority plaintiffs, with Ms. Giddins as the main plaintiff, say that they, like whites, want their children to grow up in a safe and nurturing environment.
It is a court case that some observers say could have a greater impact on racial integration than the separate Yonkers desegregation case. The Yonkers suit was filed in 1980 and calls for construction of low-cost housing in middle-class areas. Implementation of that plan, which has been slow and the cause of continued court action, relies on moving groups of minority residents into blocks of housing in predominantly white neighborhoods of the city. It has met vehement opposition from east side property owners who claim that racial integration threatens the hard-earned equity on their homes.
In contrast, the case of Carol Giddins "on behalf of herself and all other persons who are similarly situated" would move individual families into existing apartments scattered throughout Westchester's cities, towns and villages, where they will possibly meet less resistance from neighbors.
 
Could Become a H.U.D. Model
 Judge Robert P. Patterson, who presided over the Section 8 case in Federal District Court in Manhattan, approved a preliminary consent agreement between the parties in September.
The decree calls for a five-year program that would entice landlords in nonminority areas to accept tenants who use Federal Housing and Urban Development subsidies to pay their rent. The judge is expected to hear final objections to the plan on Wednesday and to sign a class-action consent agreement shortly after.
The proposal, "if successful in Westchester, could become a model for H.U.D. throughout the country," said Jerrold M. Levy of Westchester-Putnam Legal Services in White Plains, who along with John E. Kirklin of Sullivan & Cromwell in Manhattan, represented the plaintiffs.
"We're optimistic, but there are still uncharted waters out there," Mr. Levy said.
The plaintiffs charged that the defendants, among them two local agencies overseeing the Federal program -- the County Planning Department and the Yonkers Municipal Housing Authority -- steered applicants into apartments in rundown neighborhoods in southwest Yonkers. The suit contends that the agencies made no effort to find apartments in racially and economically mixed neighborhoods in other areas of Westchester.
"Our claim was that Section 8 had been used to perpetuate segregation in minority-concentrated areas," Mr. Levy said.
Robert W. Sadowski, an assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York who represented the Housing and Urban Development Department in the lawsuit, called the department a "willing defendant" and said the Federal agency was pleased with the consent decree.
 
'Taking Other Communities' Poor'
 "The suit was filed to bring H.U.D. to their side and compel Yonkers and Westchester, who have become lax, to fulfill their obligations," Mr. Sadowski said.
But the lawyer for the Yonkers Municipal Housing Authority, Joan Magoolaghan of Koob & Magoolaghan in Manhattan, said that the agency she represented was less to blame than the county, which was sending to Yonkers Section 8 recipients "who could have gone anywhere."
"Not only were we taking care of our own poor people, but we were ending up taking other communities' poor as well," Ms. Magoolaghan said.
P. Lynn Oliva, Commissioner for the County Planning Department and a defendant in the suit, denied that Westchester's Section 8 program, which is operated locally for the state, had been steering families to ghetto areas in southwest Yonkers and, by doing that, perpetuating segregation.
 
Anywhere in the County
 Of the homeless people who come under the county program, "many are from larger cities and may want to go back there," the Commissioner said. Also, most available apartments were in urban areas, she said, "and not in places like Pound Ridge." The county operates 1 of 17 voluntary Section 8 programs in Westchester. The others are operated by municipalities.
Louis J. Ganim, a spokesman for the State Housing Finance Agency and the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, also named as defendants, said the consent agreement "moves desegregation in the right direction."
Section 8 participants now can spend up to $976 a month, and in some cases $1,171, for a two-bedroom apartment anywhere in Westchester. Under the program, tenants spend 30 percent of their income for rent, although in some cases it can exceed that, with the rest covered by Federal subsidies. To qualify under Housing and Urban Development guidelines, individuals can earn up to $22,900 a year, and a family of three can earn up to $29,450.
The impetus for the lawsuit began several years ago when Mr. Levy was a staff lawyer in a Legal Services branch office in southwest Yonkers and noticed that housing agencies handling Section 8 applicants made no effort to help families move into other areas.
Mr. Kirklin, whose law firm provided pro bono services in the lawsuit, said there was the implication in the way that the Section 8 programs were being run that "new neighborhoods might be intimidating to minority applicants who wanted to stay where they were."
 
'Away From Drugs and Crime'
 The two lawyers for the defendants said that premise was contrary to the original purpose of the Federal program, which was started in 1974 to help minority residents improve their lives.
"All people are basically alike," Mr. Levy said. "They want to live in nice neighborhoods away from drugs and crime. Environment takes its toll on kids. The program operates on the assumption that if you give the poor extra purchasing power, if you give them a little boost, they will be able to have a better way of life. And their kids can mix with others who go off to college."
The consent decree is patterned on a 1981 Section 8 settlement in Chicago known as Gautreaux v. Landrieu. A study done in connection with that suit found that families who moved to white middle-class areas found jobs more often than those living in predominantly low-income black areas.
Mr. Levy said that in Yonkers the Section 8 program was used to exacerbate the existing segregation, which was "tragic, just the opposite of the purpose of the program."
Under the consent decree, the plaintiffs will set up an Enhanced Section 8 Outreach Program for clients, which would perform many of the same duties a real estate office does for its customers.
 
A Good Deal vs. a Do-Good Program
 The office, to be in Yonkers, would be financed by the defendants and administered by the Westchester People's Action Coalition, a nonprofit social services agency.
The office's function would be to bring landlords with apartments in nonpoor, nonminority areas into the Section 8 program. Under the consent decree, if the office does not find at least 550 apartments in five years the defendants will no longer have to support the program.
"Landlords are business people, and they will see that the rents can be paid at top rates," Mr. Kirklin said. "These are good people without criminal records. There are a lot of Carol Giddinses out there."
The landlords will be informed that they are not participating in a "do-good" social-action program, but in what Mr. Kirklin called "a good deal," especially at a time when some landlords are having difficulty filling apartments.
Albert A. Annunziata, a spokesman for the Apartment Owners Advisory Council in White Plains, a 400-member organization, called the goals of the outreach office realistic.
"We are talking about market-rate rents, a landlord's dream, especially when some two-bedroom rent-stabilized apartments go for less than $500," he said.
 
'Just a Nice Place to Live'
 The plan -- in contrast to the housing part of the Yonkers desegregation case -- provides incentives for all parties, and therefore "stands a chance of working," said Andrew Beveridge, a Queens College sociologist who was a consultant for the plaintiffs.
Also, Mr. Levy observed that the plan is being implemented by the plaintiffs and not the defendants, thereby increasing its chances of success.
In addition to helping minority residents, the program will try to find apartments for elderly and disabled Section 8 participants.
Ms. Giddins, a 42-year-old secretary who earns $19,000 a year, has become something of a celebrity in her neighborhood. She said: "People keep asking me, 'How did you do this? You mean we can really get out of here?' "
"I tell them we can," said Ms. Giddins, who will begin looking for a new apartment early next year. "We're not looking for Hollywood glamour, just a nice place to live, a safe place."

HEADLINE: The Killing Never Ends

BYLINE: By Linda Robinson; Linda Robinson is the Latin America correspondent for U.S. News & World Report and the author of "Intervention or Neglect: The United States and Central America Beyond the 1980's."

 BODY:

UNFINISHED CONQUEST
The Guatemalan Tragedy.
By Victor Perera.
Illustrated. 382 pp. Berkeley:
University of California Press. $27. 
 ARITHMETIC is the simplest way to tell the story of Guatemala. In one five-year counterinsurgency campaign (1978-83) conducted by the army, almost one-third of Guatemala's 85,000 Ixil Maya Indians were wiped out. Since the mid-1960's an estimated 120,000 Guatemalans have been killed and another 46,000 disappeared, according to Guatemalan human rights groups. The indigenous Mayas, most of whom live in the northern and western highlands, have borne the brunt of the violence.
Victor Perera, a writer and journalist whose books include "Rites: A Guatemalan Boyhood," set out in "Unfinished Conquest" to document the calamity that has befallen his native land. By his own admission Mr. Perera, who now lives in California, fails in this task, his quest for facts stymied by fear. Illustrative is his encounter with the mayor of Cotzal, who tells him that 7,500 residents have been killed by the army for their alleged revolutionary activity. Then, in a second meeting with Mr. Perera, the mayor insists that the deaths are entirely the fault of Marxist guerrillas, the changed tale apparently due to a visit from the regional army commander.
That killing on this scale has occurred in Guatemala is accepted as fact by many international human rights organizations. But an exact accounting must await a peace accord between the Government and the guerrillas that would include a public airing of atrocities like the ones already conducted in El Salvador, Chile, Argentina and Brazil. Even now, however, it seems that Guatemala's record is closer to that of Pol Pot's Cambodia and the campaigns to exterminate the Armenians and the Kurds than to the dozens of wars of Guatemala's Latin neighbors. The highland Mayan communities may regenerate quickly, given high birth rates. But the psychological, cultural and political toll is crushing. Mr. Perera's description of it, with a wealth of firsthand and scholarly material, is more than enough to compensate for his self-declared failure to compile the definitive ledger of Guatemala's dead.
As "Unfinished Conquest" makes clear, the atrocities are merely the latest in a long line of horrors visited on Guatemala's indigenous people. The repression began in 1524, when Pedro de Alvarado arrived from Mexico to conquer the highlands for the Spanish crown. In the 1880's his successors took the Mayas' lands to create vast coffee plantations, putting the Indians to work as indentured labor. After a four-century battle the Mayas are still a majority, but they also remain essentially landless and powerless. They have not vanished but they are not much closer to gaining their freedom. Their attempt to fight back with revolution, beginning in the 1960's, was the proximate cause of the most recent depredations unleashed on them.
Without regret or glee Mr. Perera portrays the revolutionaries as failures, seeing in the resurgent Maya-pride movement greater strength for political organization. By telling the stories of real people, Mayas who cling to their traditional gods, their communal ways and their brilliant woven clothing, Mr. Perera has selected the most effective means of conveying the astonishing resilience of Mayan culture. He befriends Mayan women who sustain their offspring by living and scavenging in Guatemala City's dump, after their tiny corn patches in the highlands have been exhausted and their menfolk have died off.
In an effort to convey the impact of the killing on Guatemala, Mr. Perera calculates that it is analogous to a half-million dead and a quarter-million disappeared in the United States. In his analogy, comparable victims of assassination or kidnapping would include Jesse Jackson, William Rehnquist, Donald Trump, Mario Cuomo, Jane Fonda and the editors of The Washington Post and The New York Times -- some 4,000 prominent American citizens and 10,000 students from top universities. Although the violence has claimed proportionately far more Mayas than people of Spanish or mixed descent, no class or ethnic group has remained untouched. Nor is the the killing over: a few months ago the founder of Guatemala's large centrist party, and the runner-up in the last presidential election, Jorge Carpio Nicolle, was stopped on a country road and shot dead by unknown assailants.
Mr. Perera's account is powerful and, equally important, suffused with sympathy -- the kind that only comes from knowing what it is like to live in constant fear surrounded by death. This helps readers to understand the pathology of death that drives such waves of killing, and drives survivors into retribution or helplessness. But on another level the reasons for Guatemala's brutality remain opaque. Because the author does not delve deep for explanations, one is left with the impression that he views conquest and ethnic cleansing as immutable forces of history, like earthquakes. He writes: "The bulk of accountability must once again fall on Guatemala's ladino officer class. The same army officers who see a potential subversive in every Mayan child and adult, regard trees as enemies in league with ambush-minded guerrillas." Similarly, the upper classes of Guatemala respond to their economic imperatives as obediently as bees build their hives. Guatemala is certainly a Manichaean place if ever one existed. But because Mr. Perera does not get inside this half of the country as he does the Mayan half, the dark forces are not illuminated.
This is a pity, in part because as an educated, well-off Guatemalan Mr. Perera might have had valuable insights to share about the elite of his country. Moreover, these insights could have helped to explain what appear to be a few signs of nascent change. Most of the intelligentsia and enlightened businessmen (that is, the modern bourgeoisie rather than the traditional landowners) mustered enough force, in coalition with prominent Mayan leaders, to derail President Jorge Serrano's extraconstitutional power grab this May. Previously, they would have been silent or silenced, killed, driven out of the country.
Nonetheless, this new elite is unlikely to be the engine of redemption in the rural areas. There the army continues to rule over the Mayas.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: ENDPAPER;
The Peace Deficit

BYLINE: By Bruce Handy; Bruce Handy has written for Spy magazine, "Saturday Night Live" and the Learning Annex catalogue.

 BODY:
The prospect of peace in the Middle East has everyone giddy. So many promises, so many dreams, so many inevitable editorial references to walls "tumblin' down" in Jericho. There are those who have sworn to undermine the agreement between Israel and the P.L.O., but even these extremists seem to cling to a utopian vision of their own -- namely, that the other side will just sort of cheerfully go away, much as future Serbian textbooks will no doubt portray Bosnia's Muslims as having done.
But who speaks for the Middle East status quo? This is no idle question, for 20th-century history proves one thing: that peace can be a mixed blessing. After all, what did we gain from the end of World War I? In the short run we got the Jazz Age, which was much like the 80's, although there were no Armani spats. In the long run we got the Great Depression, which was much like the 90's, except that the unemployed didn't have automatic weapons. Ultimately, we got World War II -- the conclusion of which brought on the cold war and such embarrassments as the Bay of Pigs, My Lai and Jason Robards's performance in "The Day After." 
 Was it only four years ago that we cheered the dismantling of the Berlin wall, naively unalarmed by the sight of frenzied young Germans wielding sledgehammers? Today, of course, we are faced with resurgent neo-Nazism and hate-inspired bloodshed throughout the former, now seemingly not-quite-so-Evil-by-comparison Empire. True, we are no longer as frightened by the threat of nuclear war -- or the threat of having to see Yakov Smirnoff on TV commercials. But as Boris Yeltsin's way with democracy proves every bit the equal of Janet Reno's with fringe religious groups, millions of former Soviet citizens are beginning to believe they were better off under Communism, and tens of thousands of unemployed aerospace workers in Southern California would heartily agree.
A lasting settlement in the Middle East will present its own peculiar problems, including some that even Benjamin Netanyahu and Hamas have probably not foreseen. For instance: Could the United States survive the humiliation of losing to a country named Gaza Strip in some future Olympiad? If peace spreads and Beirut is rebuilt, will editorialists be able to conjure as handy a metaphor for the South Bronx?
There are more immediate dangers, too. Yasir Arafat has already turned up on "Larry King Live"; we can only expect more talk-show appearances as the P.L.O. leader is drawn further into the American orbit. Mary Duffy, a producer who oversees guest bookings for "The Montel Williams Show," offers a professional assessment: "Arafat would scream 'Donahue' to me."
Does that mean he won't get a shot on "Montel"?
"It's just that we would want to approach him from more than a five-minute news package angle," she says. "Our viewers would want to know more about the human side -- how Mr. Arafat would feel about neighborhoods and people and things like that." The spectacle of Arafat baring his human side for Montel can hardly seem far-fetched when even the President of the United States governs by the maxim "Speak quaveringly and carry a big hand-held mike." Perhaps Arafat will be offered his own show ("Yasir!"). He's got an undeniable star quality and appears, for a reformed terrorist, surprisingly cuddly . . . in a gamy, Burgess Meredith sort of way. At the least, it's not hard to imagine his cameos in future "Naked Gun" movies. Is this a future we want?
PALESTINIANS WILL REQUIRE BILLIONS OF dollars in Western investment if they are to make a go of it as a nation. Are they prepared for Lady Footlockers and TCBY's? A spokesman for the Gap will neither confirm nor deny that the clothier has plans to open an outlet in Jericho, admitting only that "we're always considering new markets." If that doesn't give you pause, consider this: Isro-Disney. Just because it didn't work in France doesn't mean it couldn't succeed in Haifa. Think of all the new, free-spending Saudi tourists.
And yet, as ominous as these scenarios are, a dearth of Western investment could be just as destabilizing -- especially if the Palestinian Government is forced to seek alternative forms of revenue. No one wants to see river-boat gambling on the Jordan, let alone a Holy Land Pick 4.
The economic ramifications for the United States are equally perilous. If peace takes hold, large numbers of Israeli emigres might decide to return to their homeland. The resulting exodus would cripple the dial car industry in New York City -- yes, the drivers would be able to raise their children in a happier, safer Israel, but, on Madison Avenue, Conde Nast editors would be left waiting at the curb. And who would move our furniture? Peace will be hardest of all on those whose careers have largely been predicated on Arab-Israeli enmity, like neo-conservative writers and editors (first Communism, now this). What, for instance, will Martin Peretz do? Some fear he might try his hand at a boyhood memoir, or perhaps even a novel -- a sobering thought indeed.
But by far, the most upsetting thing about the Israeli-P.L.O. peace pact is the way it has forced us to rethink long-held assumptions about human behavior. While never exactly welcome, this sort of activity is tolerable in controlled circumstances, like psychotherapy sessions or TV movies about the Jackson family. But when we open the morning paper, all we really want is to enjoy a little Schadenfreude at the expense of Sol Wachtler (or whomever). Israelis making nice with Palestinians, Jordanians and Syrians. . . . What's next, we must now sigh in exasperation, peace in Red Hook? The South Bronx? The cheese department at Zabar's?

HEADLINE: As U.S. Vote on Trade Pact Nears, Mexicans Are Expressing Doubts

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEON, Mexico

 BODY:
In the dizzying course of a five-minute conversation on the North American Free Trade Agreement, Jesus Hernandez begins with a great burst of national pride, focused on his shoes.
"See this," the 28-year-old owner of a tiny shoemaking company says, lifting a shiny black exhibit from a friend's workshop table. "The gringos can't do leatherwork like this!" 
 But when prodded a bit about a possible inrush of cheaper mass-produced shoes from Canada and the United States, the glow of satisfaction fades from Mr. Hernandez's face.
 
'We Are Blind Here'
 "The truth is, we do not know what is coming," he says. "Some people say it is going to hurt us, and the leaders here, they do not ask us what we think. We are blind here."
As Mexicans watch the United States anguish over a trade accord that would affect their country far more than either of its wealthier northern neighbors, many express a similar mix of uncertainty and fear.
Such worries would seem to rebut critics in the United States who have described Mexico as the clear beneficiary of the accord. After denying the concerns for months, Mexican officials now say that if Congress rejects the agreement in the vote scheduled for Nov. 17, the opportunity might be lost for a generation.
But the way in which Mexico's concerns are being expressed also underscores the vast differences in political development between this society and the two that would be its partners. By contrast to the tumultuous debate in Canada and the din in the United States, the qualms of Mexicans like Mr. Hernandez are not echoed in infomercials or on the evening news.
For the most part, criticism of the possible effects on Mexico has been reported only in a handful of independent newspapers and on radio news programs and talk shows.
Under pressure from the Government, industries likely to lose jobs under the accord -- big labor-union coalitions and business chambers -- have reiterated confidence in the long-term wisdom of the deal and have said little of their worries for the shorter term.
The Mexican Senate, where the long-ruling party holds 61 of the 64 seats, will merely vote on the agreement after the vote in Washington and will not deliberate in any meaningful way.
According to several public opinion polls, including surveys taken for President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, a big plurality and perhaps a clear majority supports the accord.
Mexico is virtually certain to gain considerable foreign investment under the pact, which would gradually dismantle most barriers to trade and investment between the three countries. Most trade studies also predict that Mexico would gain more jobs than Canada or the United States.
At the same time, however, Mexico is expected to face the greatest short-term job losses, and most surveys indicate that support for the accord has been falling steadily. As the economy struggles through a near-recession and challenges to the agreement grow in the United States, there has also been evidence of a new questioning in Mexico of the terms of the agreement.
 
'Protectionist Attitudes'
 "There is an ambivalence that is starting to emerge," the Trade Secretary, Jaime Serra Puche, said in a recent interview. "In industry and agriculture, people support trade liberalization in general, but not in their own sector. The more protectionist attitudes are gaining weight."
Such comments mark a significant shift after three years of a steady insistence that Mr. Salinas's embrace of the agreement reflected a broad consensus. Although the Government consulted with important business and labor groups during negotiations, such "advisers" never openly challenged the Government's positions or articulated their own. Pro-Government labor unions and business associations generally served to contain dissent.
But as a final decision on the agreement draws nearer, voices are rising in industries likely to be hurt, like textile manufacturers or toy makers or grain farmers.
The central state of Tlaxcala, for instance, has watched textile factories and other businesses vanish since Mexico joined the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in 1986 and began opening its borders to imports.
In Apizaco, for example, a 32-year-old brick maker, Carmelario Vega, suggested that free trade had struck like a mysterious disease.
"Lots of people have lost jobs and they really don't know why," Mr. Vega said. "People are afraid, more than anything because they really don't know what is coming next."
In Leon, the capital of Guanajuato State, the probable effects are mixed. Shoemakers like Mr. Hernandez are likely to face more imports from the United States, in addition to the inexpensive Asian-made shoes that already trouble their lives. Boot makers and vegetable growers will have an easier time exporting their products north.
 
A Steady Drop in Support
 In surveys by Mr. Salinas's polling unit, support for the trade accord in major cities has fallen from 64.3 percent in October 1992 but remains strong: in September, 53.7 percent of those polled said they favored the pact.
Polls taken by a leading independent firm, Market and Opinion Research International, show a sharper drop, from 77 percent support in 1990 to 47 percent earlier this year. The surveys also show that fully half of those polled think that the agreement will benefit the United States more than Mexico, and will make Mexico more dependent on the United States.
To some extent, politicians and political analysts say, Mexicans are challenging the centerpiece of Mr. Salinas's economic strategy since the benefits of his policies have grown more uncertain. Inflation has dropped sharply, to under 9 percent. But growth has slowed, per-capita income is falling again, unemployment is rising and the Government must keep interest rates high to prop up what many economists believe is an overvalued peso.
A contrast remains between more or less scientific measures of the mood and the extent to which worries about the agreement are reflected in public debate. At a news briefing in Mexico City, Deputy Secretary of Agriculture Luis Tellez Kuenzler said, "If you look at the press from August of last year to today, people are not complaining about the free trade agreement."
But a pro-Government briefer at the meeting, Abelardo Sanchez, a leader of the National Agricultural Council, questioned whether the press was reflective of the country's views.
"We don't have good railroads, highways, ports -- how are we going to be able to compete?" Mr. Sanchez asked.
Faced with what they call the impossibility of stopping the agreement in Mexico, some critics have concentrated their efforts in the United States, arguing that democracy and economic justice would be better served if the agreement were rejected or postponed.
While two critics, Adolfo Aguilar Zinser and Jorge G. Castaneda, are important advisers to Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, the leader of the main leftist opposition party, Mr. Cardenas himself has grown steadily more ambiguous.
Mr. Cardenas has in the past sharply criticized the accord, and other leaders of his Democratic Revolutionary Party have been unequivocal in saying the party's two senators will vote against it. Now, mindful of the Government's assertion that he would usher in a wave of anti-Americanism if he won the 1994 presidential election, Mr. Cardenas will not even go that far.
That has left only one organization in all of Mexico devoted to challenging the agreement. In the place of Ross Perot and the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Mexico has the Mexican Action Network, a small union-supported group with an infrastructure consisting of a small office on loan from a leftist labor alliance, three telephone lines and a fax machine.
The group's leader, Berta Lujan, a 40-ish former high school teacher, describes its crusade as "clawing along with our fingernails."
"Whenever they are talking about the free trade agreement, we are there," she says. "They simply have not allowed people to hear us."

HEADLINE: BALANCED BUDGET GAINING SUPPORT AMONG SENATORS

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Conservatives who hate raising taxes and liberals who cannot stand to cut spending have joined to bring the Senate to within a handful of votes of passing a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget.
Senator Paul Simon, the liberal Democrat from Illinois who is the measure's chief sponsor, is not yet predicting victory in the vote later this month, but he said in an interview that he had detected a gradual increase in support. He has been pushing the measure for several years, and won a promise from the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, a firm opponent of the amendment, for a vote sometime in this Senate session, which may end by Thanksgiving. 
 The deficit issue has forced itself over the years into the consciousness of both the right and the left, and it is good politics to promise to do something about it.
 
Clinton Denounces Amendment
 While most people think that the only way to cope with the deficit is to both raise taxes and cut spending, each wing of this tenuous alliance argues that only the approach the other side dislikes need be used.
But the opponents, led by Senator Robert C. Byrd, the powerful Democrat from West Virginia, got a boost today when President Clinton weighed in on their side. Mr. Clinton denounced the amendment as a "budget gimmick," and said it was so vague that appointed judges would end up making decisions elected lawmakers should take on.
Mr. Clinton's letter to Congressional leaders said the amendment would hurt average American families and require some combination of "huge increases in taxes," "massive reductions in Social Security benefits" and "major cuts in Medicare and Medicaid that would make it impossible to pass meaningful health reform legislation."
 
60 Senators Back Plan
 He said the last effect would be particularly counterproductive because health legislation was "the nation's best hope of bringing down the long-term deficit."
While Presidents have no veto on constitutional amendments, Mr. Clinton's intervention still matters, especially because 16 of the 20 senators who have not announced their position on the measure are Democrats. With 60 supporters identified through public statements and interviews and 20 declared opponents, the backers need only 7 of the undeclared senators to get the two-thirds majority an amendment must have under the Constitution. Opponents need 14 of them to defeat it.
The Senate is expected to vote in about two weeks on the measure, which would require a balanced budget in 1999. The result is likely to be as close as it was in 1986, when the proposal fell short by a single vote; or in 1982 when it passed the Senate with 69 votes, or two to spare, but died in the House.
If the Senate adopts the amendment, an equally close vote is expected in the House. In July 1992 supporters got 280 votes in the House, nine less than they needed. Should both houses adopt the amendment, it would require the approval of the legislatures of 38 states within seven years to become part of the Constitution.
Mr. Simon told the Senate last Monday that the amendment was necessary to force lawmakers "to make some tough decisions."
 
Expecting Close Vote
 Unlike Senator Simon, who favors giving tax increases a major role in balancing the budget, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a conservative Republican of Utah, asserted in an interview that the amendment would lead to deep and desirable cuts in Federal spending.
Mr. Hatch, the chief Republican sponsor of the measure, argued that in the current political climate -- including election results this week in New Jersey and Virginia where anti-tax voting played a major role -- it will be very hard to find majorities for Mr. Simon's tax increases. He said the constitutional amendment's fate would "come down to one or two votes in the Senate."
Senator Byrd said he was worried that his side would lose. He scoffed at the measure as "political catnip" and despairs of senators who beg him, in his role as chairman of the Appropriations Committee, for money for their states while supporting an amendment that would dry up that spending.
He called the amendment "an economic, fiscal and political calamity in the making." He then added "constitutional" to the list, saying if the measure was adopted it would probably fail to balance the budget, and in so doing would greatly diminish the nation's faith in the Constitution.
 
Likely Targets of Amendment
 Most of these points are familiar. But the health care argument used by Mr. Clinton is a fresh one, introduced earlier this week by Senator Jay Rockefeller, Democrat of West Virginia. He argued that not only the new spending in the Clinton bill but Medicare and Medicaid would be obvious targets for very serious cuts if the amendment were part of the Constitution.
Mr. Rockefeller said, "Congress cannot lie to the American people" and say they can have both a balanced budget and health care legislation. Senator Simon contends that argument is exaggerated and the country could have both.
The Simon amendment states that outlays of Federal money cannot exceed receipts in any fiscal year and that the statutory limit on the national debt cannot be increased. Three-fifths majorities of both houses could override those provisions.
Under the amendment, the President would be required to send a balanced budget to Congress. The measure's provisions could be waived when a declaration of war was in effect or when a joint Congressional resolution was enacted declaring that the country was involved in a military conflict "which causes an imminent and serious military threat to national security."
The three-fifths majorities the amendment speaks of consist of the complete membership of each house, or 60 in the Senate and 261 in the House of Representatives when no seats are vacant. Tax increases and the resolution on military conflict would require majorities of the complete memberships, or 51 in the Senate and 218 in the House.
The amendment would take effect in the 1999 fiscal year that begins on Oct. 1, 1998, or in the first fiscal year beginning two years after ratification of the amendment, whichever comes later. After last summer's deficit reduction legislation, the Congressional Budget Office now projects the deficit for fiscal 1999 to be $223 billion.
The strongest force against the amendment is Senator Byrd himself. The Appropriations Committee chairman can fix fellow senators with an icy stare they take to mean: "If you vote for this terrible amendment, Federal spending in your state will be cut first as we try to balance the budget."
Senator Hatch sees Mr. Byrd as a special problem for his side to overcome. "He does cause some quivering around here," he said.
Lobbying and pressure are expected to intensify in the next couple of weeks. Representative Charles W. Stenholm of Texas, the leader of the effort in the House, said this week: "It's looking pretty good. But I learned after last year not to depend on looks."
To Senator Byrd, of course, last year's defeat of the measure in the House was a cause for hope, not for fear. He said he hoped Congress would be "like one who unwittingly falls into a scheme that would lead to murder, in this case, the murder of the Constitution, but as he gets up to the brink, up to the point of plunging the knife for the fatal thrust, he draws back."

MRS. CLINTON ATTACKS MEASURE
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (Special to The New York Times) -- Hillary Rodham Clinton warned the Association of American Medical Colleges today that the balanced budget amendment, along with efforts to limit Medicare and Medicaid spending, were serious threats to their institutions.
Making the case for President Clinton's health plan, Mrs. Clinton said not overhauling the health care system could fuel other, more dangerous efforts to control medical spending, like putting caps on "Medicare expenditures in order to lower the deficit."
"A second and equally threatening development is the balanced budget amendment," she added. Such efforts, she said, would imperil the association's institutions by "financing cuts that will be unpredictable, arbitrary and not replaced with any other funding stream."

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: North Korea and the Bomb;
Sanctions Won't Work

BYLINE: By Dave McCurdy; Dave McCurdy, Democrat of Oklahoma, is a member of the House Armed Services Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Still reeling from crises in Somalia and Haiti, the Administration is about to face another foreign policy test, in North Korea. President Clinton said yesterday, "North Korea cannot be allowed to develop a nuclear bomb. We have to be very firm about it." The U.S. must move quickly to avoid a confrontation, but also must temper an impulse to punish North Korea with economic sanctions.
International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors discovered last year that North Korea may have reprocessed plutonium at least three times, not just once, as it has claimed. We have no idea how much plutonium it may have or how close it is to a bomb. The I.A.E.A. has demanded that it be allowed to inspect two possible plutonium waste sites. Pyongyang has refused permission, arguing that the sites are conventional military facilities -- a blatant lie. Calls are mounting for decisive action. 
 U.N.-mandated economic sanctions offer little hope of success. If we go to the Security Council for sanctions and China rejects them, as it may, North Korea will believe that it is off the hook. If sanctions are imposed, North Korea would likely rule out any dialogue until they were removed (and China could allow goods to flow across the border anyway). If sanctions pushed the North to the brink of economic collapse, it would only further the country's instability, which is precisely what South Korea and Japan want to avoid.
Sanctions would probably incite North Korea to hasten its nuclear work. Thus, pressure for the U.S. to bomb the North's nuclear plants would grow -- even though a raid might not disable the plants, would shower radiation across Japan and South Korea and could provoke North Korean retaliation on Seoul. Surgical airstrikes could spark a second Korean war.
Under these conditions, Americans would rightly ask, are we ready to go to war over a threat to Japan and South Korea? If we failed in a confrontation with an African warlord, how can we go toe-to-toe with President Kim Il Sung, who has thrived on brinkmanship for four decades?
A hardline approach would also lead to new arguments with China, South Korea and Japan, all of which prefer diplomacy to threats. Our dedication to nonproliferation cannot succeed if our approach is at odds with the very countries it is designed to protect.
The challenge is to avoid a showdown while holding firmly to our demand for thorough inspections. Our goal should not be to eliminate all risk -- that is impossible -- but to keep the North from obtaining more plutonium and from turning the nuclear material it has into weapons.
What should we do? First, we should not reinvent sanctions that already exist. The U.S., Japan and South Korea already deny North Korea economic and political contacts, and Russia has placed trade on a hard-currency-only basis. We should insist that our allies not invest in the North until the nuclear issue is resolved.
We should consider a policy of "no blame" for past transgressions. North Korean leaders resist inspections for fear of being caught in their lies. We should tell them that, like South Africa, if they came clean, they would face no new sanctions.
We should give them face-saving incentives to allow inspections. We could allow them to inspect U.S. military bases in South Korea, to verify that no tactical nuclear weapons are present. And we should support South Korea's offer to end its joint military exercises with U.S. troops.
Given our pressing domestic issues and foreign policy missteps, the U.S. is in no shape to play nuclear brinkmanship with North Korea. We need to push this looming crisis to an amicable conclusion and move on. In Somalia, the price of failure is 29 American lives; in Korea, that price could be war.

HEADLINE: Clinton Warns North Korea Against Building Atom Bomb

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
President Clinton issued a stern warning today to North Korea not to develop a nuclear weapon as it continues to block international inspections of its nuclear sites.
"North Korea cannot be allowed to develop a nuclear bomb," Mr. Clinton said in an interview on the NBC News program "Meet the Press." "We have to be very firm about it." 
 The President also continued to express support for President Boris N. Yeltsin, despite the Russian leader's plans to cancel an early presidential election.
Mr. Clinton declined to say whether he would consider an American air strike against North Korean sites where such a device might be under construction, but he added: "We are consulting with our allies in South Korea and Japan. They are most directly affected by what we do and how we do it."
Asked about the massing of North Korean troops near the border with South Korea, Mr. Clinton warned that any military thrust southward would be met with force by the United States. "We have our soldiers there," he said. "They know that. They know that any attack on South Korea is an attack on the United States."
 
Seeking to Project Firmness
 Tensions in the area have been rising since North Korea announced its intention this spring to pull out of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. A deadline expired on Monday for North Korea to allow inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency to return to sites. Responding to the standoff, American officials have sought to project firmness without forcing North Korea into a corner. And Mr. Clinton's comments this morning seemed in keeping with this strategy.
On Russia, Mr. Clinton reiterated his support for President Yeltsin, though Administration officials said they were unsure of the Russian leader's motive in announcing his intention to cancel an early presidential election in June. President Clinton said that of Mr. Yeltsin: "As long as he is promoting democracy, as long as he's promoting human rights, as long as he's promoting reform, I think the United States should support him. He has been brave and consistent."
Mr. Yeltsin surprised Administration officials on Saturday when he told Russian newspaper editors that he preferred to serve out his current five-year term, which ends in 1996, and not run for re-election.
 
Seeking an Explanation
 Administration officials, including Thomas R. Pickering, the United States Ambassador to Russia, have not yet spoken to Mr. Yeltsin or any of his top advisers to obtain an explanation of his remarks.
Mr. Yeltsin's comments suggest he is reneging on the pledge he grudgingly made in September, when he dissolved Parliament, to hold presidential elections six months after Russian voters elect a new Parliament and vote on a new constitution on Dec. 12.
Sergei B. Stankevich, a senior adviser to Mr. Yeltsin, was quoted by the Interfax news agency as saying the Russian leader believed his authority would be weakened if presidential elections were held so soon after a new constitution took effect. A draft of the constitution has a provision stating the presidential elections cannot be held before 1996.
Administration officials said Mr. Yeltsin may have been signaling his preference to voters on the issue before the constitutional referendum. They also said he may have been indicating his preference to potential lawmakers who may have to deal with the issue once they have been elected.
"While we don't know exactly what lies behind President Yeltsin's latest statements, some Russians are speculating that he is keeping his options open on how best to be sure that he will be able to deal from strength with the new Parliament once it comes in," said a senior Administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
In his interview, Mr. Yeltsin said he would not run again and suggested that he was tiring of the pressures, saying: "Everybody knows how many blows of fate I have already suffered. It is too much for one man."
As he has in recent weeks, Mr. Clinton refused to rule out the use of force to restore Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Administration officials have been frustrated by their inability to persuade Haiti's military leaders to abide by an agreement they signed in July that would restore Father Aristide, Haiti's first freely elected President.
Mr. Clinton said today that he preferred to increase economic pressure on Haiti's military leaders and their supporters by having other nations follow the United States' lead and freeze their financial assets.

HEADLINE: Spoiling to Debate Gore, Perot Puts Up His Dukes

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 7

 BODY:
Tuning up for Tuesday's debate with Vice President Al Gore, Ross Perot taunted President Clinton today for sending "somebody else to do the dirty work" and asserted that the proposed North American Free Trade Agreement not only would destroy American sovereignty but also worsen Mexican poverty.
"I want to know how a President of the United States can be for that," Mr. Perot demanded during a two-hour rally here that was attended by 3,500 cheering, whooping Perot partisans. 
 Then, obviously delighted that his dogged nine-month campaign against the trade pact and the Washington establishment had put him once again in the national political limelight, he predicted defeat for the pact and shouted confidently, "How'd you like to have Al Gore's job on Tuesday night?"
Again the crowd, mostly drawn from Tampa's manufacturing center and outlying citrus and vegetable regions, rose, whistling and hooting derisively.
 
A Telling T-Shirt
 "God, I love the man!" Mariam Lancaster, a retired restaurant owner, shouted above the uproar.
Clad in a bright "Perot for President" T-shirt, she had driven to Tampa from Orlando to attend the event, the 92d political rally held by Mr. Perot since January. Like many Perot supporters around the country, she has spent much of her time since the 1992 Presidential election, in which Mr. Perot ran a strong third, trying to build up the Perot political organization, United We Stand America.
But for all the applause and enthusiasm here this afternoon, there was little substantively new in Mr. Perot's 90-minute attack on the proposed trade agreement. And while the crowd was enthusiastic, it did not fill the 5,000-seat fairgrounds fieldhouse, a measure, perhaps, of the fact that many Tampa-area residents believe the pact would be a boon to port business here.
Mr. Perot restated his contention that the pact would cause American industry and agriculture to flee south with "a great sucking sound" toward cheaper labor, and he again asserted that American companies that have already moved to Mexico have done little but exploit Mexican labor and violate Mexican environmental laws.
 
Jagged Edge to Remarks
 But his attack on the President was notably sharp-edged and personal, as though he sensed a political crack in the White House armor. He went beyond his patented one-liners, those verbal zingers that White House aides contend are increasingly seen by voters as entertaining but little more.
He predicted that the trade pact would be defeated so long as the Perot forces kept up the pressure until the crucial Nov. 17 vote on the pact's ratification in the House of Representatives. That defeat, he said, would teach Mr. Clinton "to stop chasing cars."
Next he accused the President of cowardice by refusing to engage in debate himself. "How many people have you known who, when push came to shove, got somebody else to do the dirty work for them?" he asked.
 
'Hear That, White House?'
 Looking directly into the bank of television cameras recording his speech, he warned Mr. Clinton that there were 85 million people who potentially stood to lose their jobs should the trade proposal pass, an estimate disputed by leading economists.
"Eighty-five million people can elect anybody -- anybody!" he added, his Texas twang rising. "Do you hear that, White House?"
Mr. Perot closed with a bit of stage drama reminiscent of the furor he caused in the Presidential campaign when he said the Vietnamese had in 1969 sent a team of Black Panther members to kill him.
Shortly before coming to Tampa, Mr. Perot told the crowd, he had been warned by the police that there were rumors that he might be the target of an assassination attempt by "a Mafia-like group in favor of the free trade agreement." Many friends, he added, had urged him to cancel the rally.
 
Martyr to His Cause
 "But I never considered it," he said. "I thought about the people who make our country go. We will never waver until Nafta is stopped. So here we are. And if something should happen, don't spend a minute mourning. As Step 1, make sure you stop Nafta, with or without me."
Then he headed off the stage as the band broke into "When the Saints Go Marching In." But suddenly he wheeled, snatched the microphone again and shouted, "We're going to go marching down Pennsylvania Avenue one day."
The crowd roared.
A spokesman for the Department of Justice, Carl Stern, said tonight that a third-hand report of a death threat against Mr. Perot was passed on to the Tampa police and to the Secret Service by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Mr. Stern said the F.B.I. office in Los Angeles was contacted by a telephone tip line in Alberquerque, N.M., which had been called by a man who said he had heard of the plot from another man who had recently been released from a Mexican prison. The ex-prisoner had heard that a hit squad of six Cubans had been recruited to assassinate Mr. PerotMr. Stern said. The threat's legitimacy has not been confirmed, he said.

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Debates Statehood or Status Quo as a Vote Nears

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R.

 BODY:
Should Puerto Rico petition to become the 51st state, remain an American commonwealth or proclaim its independence? After decades of debate and months of intense campaigning in every corner of the island, voters here are about to declare their preference in a historic plebiscite whose result the White House has pledged to support.
For the 3.7 million residents of this lush Caribbean island, the vote on status, scheduled for Nov. 14, hinges on questions both of cultural identity and material well-being. Gov. Pedro Rossello and his New Progressive Party say statehood will bring a financial bonanza. But the opposition Popular Democratic Party argues that statehood will force a mixed-race, Spanish-speaking society to renounce everything that defines its character. 
 Recent polls show statehood and commonwealth running about even, with about one-fifth of all voters saying they are still undecided. Independence, the third option on the ballot, is supported by about 5 percent of the voters and is not considered a realistic course for an island that has lived under American rule since the end of the Spanish-American War in 1898.
 
Happy With the Status Quo
 "I'm voting for statehood in order to tell the American people that the people of this island want to be first-class American citizens," said Esteban Ramos, a teacher. "It is time for Puerto Rico to be decolonized."
But supporters of commonwealth say they are happy with the status quo, which has given Puerto Rico a standard of living that, while only half that of the United States, is higher than that of any country in Latin America. "If things ain't broke, why fix them?" asked Angel Colon, a 41-year-old social services worker.
Under the commonwealth arrangement that has been in place here for more than 40 years, residents of Puerto Rico cannot vote in Federal elections, but also do not pay Federal taxes. In addition, Federal health and welfare payments to poor and elderly residents of the island are capped at levels significantly below what Puerto Rico would receive as a state.
The 2.6 million Puerto Ricans living on the United States mainland, on the other hand, have the same rights, benefits and obligations as other American citizens.
 
Congress Must Approve
 "I know the difference between statehood and what we have now because I was born in Connecticut and lived there until I was 15 years old," said Carmen Torres Colon, a 33-year-old housewife. "I know that schools and health care are better there, that there are more opportunities, and that's what I want here for my kids."
The vote is the first on Puerto Rico's status since 1967, when commonwealth status won handily, taking 60 percent of the vote.
The plebiscite is nonbinding, meaning that even if statehood wins a narrow majority, Congress would still have to approve the formal petition to join the union that Mr. Rossello has promised to submit. That process promises to be long and complicated, with the issues of language and increased Federal assistance leading the list of thorny questions to be resolved by reluctant members of both houses.
Though former Presidents George Bush, Ronald Reagan and Gerald R. Ford are featured in television advertisements here that urge voters to choose statehood, President Clinton has taken a neutral position, promising only to support whatever decision Puerto Ricans reach.
All autumn long, pro-statehood caravans have been roaming Puerto Rico, blaring the message over loudspeakers that "statehood signifies equality." Commonwealth backers have responded by plastering this island with posters proclaiming that only the status quo offers "the best of two worlds."
Addressing coffee growers outside the mountain town of Aibonito, Senator Miguel Hernandez Agosto, president of the Popular Democratic Party, argued that commonwealth status allowed "us to conserve our traditions and character as a people" while enjoying the benefits of American citizenship. Under statehood, he said as his listeners nodded in agreement, Puerto Ricans would "gradually lose our language and our identity" through assimilation into a larger English-speaking society.
But statehood supporters, especially those who were born on the American mainland or have lived there, scoff at predictions that their language and culture will disappear if Puerto Rico enters the union.
"Why should anything be any different?" Aurea Rivera de Miro, a 35-year-old school supervisor, asked while attending a rally for statehood in the town of Aguas Buenas. "I'll keep on talking both languages, just like I did when I lived in New Jersey."
Seeking to draw on other cultural symbols close to the hearts of the populace, Mr. Hernandez Agosto has also been warning audiences that Puerto Rico would no longer be allowed to have its own Olympic team if it enters the union.
Anti-statehood forces have emphasized that if Puerto Rico became a state, it would have to relinquish a system of special tax incentives that are the backbone of the local economy. To encourage American corporations to create jobs in Puerto Rico, Section 936 of the Internal Revenue Code permits subsidiaries of American companies to shelter from Federal taxes all profits made here.
As a result, commonwealth and independence backers say, Puerto Rico would inevitably be reduced to "welfare statehood" if it entered the union. In advertisements that argue "statehood will cost you," the Popular Democrats say that property, gas, liquor and sales taxes will have to be raised to pay for the loss of revenues contributed by Section 936 companies.
Governor Rossello has accused his opponents of telling "tall tales." He says that Section 936 has outlived its usefulness and that only statehood can promote further economic growth. His party's radio spots even talk of a "statehood bonus" that would be paid to poor Puerto Ricans under the earned-income credit provision of the Federal tax code.
"We feel we can guarantee that Puerto Rico will not pay more than it pays now," Mr. Rossello said in a recent interview.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Pedro Rossello encouraging Puerto Ricans to support statehood for the island in a plebiscite. (Cindy Karp for The New York Times)
