HEADLINE: Deep, Painful Descent of Tokyo Stocks

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 7

 BODY:
With the Japanese stock market having taken another steep dive in the last two weeks and share prices in the fourth year of a deep overall decline, dissatisfaction over the Tokyo Stock Exchange's policies is growing.
At the heart of the market's drop, analysts say, are the nation's persistent recession, plummeting corporate profits, a mounting toll of bad loans by banks and the near-abandonment of stocks by small investors. 
 The stock market has been perceived as so unattractive that although Americans have been pouring tens of billions of dollars into mutual funds that invest overseas, only a trickle of that money has come to Japan. That is surprising, given that Tokyo has the second-largest market in the world, after the New York Stock Exchange.
 
The Power of Fear
 But some experts say that outmoded attitudes at the Tokyo Stock Exchange, a meddlesome Government and inadequate order systems have contributed to the lack of confidence. In particular, experts say, the exchange's policies have kept frightened individual investors away, and that absence has inhibited recovery.
The exchange says it is trying to help, but admits it has had little success. "Increasing individual participation is the main concern of the Tokyo Stock Exchange at the moment," said Yoshiaki Kaneko, who left the Finance Ministry to become the exchange's managing director later this month. "That will contribute to stability in the market. What we're trying to do is increase the attraction of the stocks themselves."
Mr. Kaneko said, for instance, that the exchange is urging companies to increase their stingy dividends, reduce the minimum number of shares an investor must purchase and provide better information about their finances. Companies, though, have been in no mood to comply.
The problems have been highlighted in recent weeks by one of the largest new listings of a company in a decade. On Oct. 26, the Government-controlled East Japan Railway, known as JR East, made its debut. The listing had been postponed for more than a year and had been eagerly awaited, as officials hoped to use the offering both to raise cash and give the market a psychological lift.
By most accounts, though, it became a fiasco that helped send the market on its latest plunge. In the less than two weeks since, the Nikkei index of 225 issues has lost more than 8 percent of its value.
The Government sold half of the four million shares in the giant railroad at an auction that put the price at 380,000 yen a share, the equivalent of $3,518. Some criticized the auction process, because it left more than 10,000 individual investors each owning just one share.
When the shares were formally listed, individual investors who had been frustrated with their meager allotments bid lustily for more. The exchange could not deal with the orders, and so could not set a price until nearly 40 minutes after it closed for the day. The price was then put at 600,000 yen each.
Some thought that looked too good. The next morning, the small investors whom the Government and the exchange had been hoping to attract as stable, long-term stockholders placed waves of sell orders. The exchange suspended trading that day and the next, making it difficult for most of those who wanted to take profits to do so.
 
A Four Years
 The price of JR East shares has steadily fallen since, to 485,000 yen on Friday, the equivalent of $4,491. The Nikkei index closed Friday at 18,590.46 points.
[The Nikkei index gained 21.60 points in trading Monday morning, to 18,612.06 at midday, up 0.12 percent.]
Since the end of 1989, despite occasional upswings, the Nikkei has lost more than half its value from its peak -- more than $3 trillion.
The Tokyo Stock Exchange blamed its computer systems for the halts in trading, and this angered some experts. The major brokerage houses never criticize the Tokyo exchange in public, since it is regarded as virtually an arm of the powerful Finance Ministry -- which provides the exchange's top executives. But they came as close as they could when they issued a statement saying they had asked the exchange to insure that such foul-ups do not recur.
"In my view, the exchange has not been innovative enough in developing its technology," said Shoichi Royama, dean of the economics department at Osaka University and an expert on financial markets. "The problems with JR East are just symptoms. I'm not astonished."
The problems and the subsequent decline in the value of both JR East and the general market have embarrassed the Government and the exchange. Not least, this has complicated efforts by public companies and brokerage houses to reopen the exchange to more new issues.
Three years ago, the Finance Ministry decreed a near-halt to new listings on the Tokyo exchange, in one of many failed attempts to lift stock prices. It was hoped that a successful JR East listing would once again permit the market to receive a steady flow of new issues.
In 1989, for instance, before the decline began, Japanese companies raised 5.8 trillion yen from new offerings on the Tokyo exchange, the equivalent of $53.7 billion. Last year, the figure fell to four billion yen, or $37 million, and will be higher this year largely because of the JR East offering.
"I'm sure there is some concern about the computer problems -- no doubt about it," Mr. Kaneko said. "But we are still analyzing the situation."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Health care commercials bring a scolding from the White House, as well as a lot of attention.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
THEODORE ROOSEVELT assaulted the "malefactors of great wealth." Franklin D. Roosevelt inveighed against three Republican isolationists with the mellifluous names of "Martin, Barton and Fish." Spiro T. Agnew condemned the "nattering nabobs of negativism."
And what has the Clinton Administration chosen to attack? Bill and Hillary are lashing out at television commercials starring a couple named Harry and Louise. The couple's creator is, it turns out, bemused -- but unapologetic. 
 Those hoping the White House was condemning the Taster's Choice coffee couple will be disappointed. Instead, Harry and Louise appear in spots sponsored by the Health Insurance Association of America. The trade group, representing more than 300 health insurance companies, is spending $6.5 million on a campaign questioning the Clintons' health care plan.
The commercials are produced by Goddard-Clausen/First Tuesday, an agency with offices in Malibu and Sacramento, Calif., that specializes in policy issue advertising. They feature an actor and actress at a softly lit kitchen table, going over a stack of medical bills and earnestly raising objections to the changes sought by the plan.
"Having choices we don't like is like no choice at all," Louise says in one spot. Her glum mate replies, "They choose," to which she responds, "We lose."
Hillary Rodham Clinton, in a speech Nov. 1, decried the commercials, mocking their "homey kitchen" approach and accusing the association of "great lies."
"They have the gall to run TV ads that there is a better way," she said, "the very industry that has brought us to the brink of bankruptcy because of the way they have financed health care."
Two days later, President Clinton echoed his wife's ad bashing. "You need to know what is fueling these television commercials," he said, adding, "There's a lot of money in the health care system that doesn't have a rip to do with health care."
The First Couple's castigations were unorthodox, but in character. After all, this Administration came to power largely through a shrewd use of the so-called new media like MTV and talk shows. Since people talk about whatever they watch on television -- programming or advertising -- commercials are as much a component of the new media milieu as Tabitha Soren or Larry King.
"It's not often that one is scolded by the First Lady," Ben Goddard, president and partner of Goddard-Clausen/First Tuesday, said in a telephone interview last week after the Clintons landed their one-two punches.
He recalled dryly that he was "made aware fairly quickly of her interest in Harry and Louise" while he was "on a conference call with the client."
"Someone came into the room," he continued, "and announced she was attacking us even as we spoke."
"It's understandable political strategy on their part; it's classic Carville strategy to launch frontal attacks on opponents and try to back them off," he said, referring to James Carville, the consultant who helped lead the Clinton election effort.
Mr. Goddard writes and directs all the commercials for Goddard-Clausen/First Tuesday, which was formed in 1989 by the merger of his agency, First Tuesday, with one in Sacramento owned by Richard Clausen. Mr. Goddard described himself as a Democrat who has always worked for Democratic candidates, but added, "That doesn't mean I only agree with Democrats."
David Beiler, senior editor at Campaigns & Elections, a political advertising trade publication in Washington, praised a commercial Mr. Goddard produced in 1982 for John Melcher, a Democratic Senator from Montana who was besieged by an expensive campaign waged by the National Conservative Political Action Committee, declaring him "too liberal for Montana."
Mr. Goddard counterattacked with what is famous in political advertising circles as the "talking cows" commercial. One cow spoke sympathetically of "Doc Melcher" -- the Senator was a veterinarian -- while the other suggested that outsiders had been "stepping in what they have been trying to sell."
"A branding iron branded a logo into a piece of leather," Mr. Beiler said admiringly. "It was really cute."
And Senator Melcher won re-election.
Mr. Goddard described a commercial he created "at the height of the Reagan era" for the Democratic National Committee, in which "an elephant destroyed a china shop" -- an allusion to a controversy over Nancy Reagan's purchase of expensive White House china during a recession.
"Nancy Reagan didn't attack us," he said slyly.
Though Mr. Goddard said he had no plans to have animals, talking or otherwise, join Harry and Louise in the kitchen, he produced another commercial last week for the health insurance association and is working on one more that will start running before Thanksgiving.
Last week was a hectic one for Mr. Goddard and Mr. Clausen for reasons apart from the Clintons' criticisms. The Malibu office was evacuated because of the fires there. And the agency is opening an office in Washington.
It will be, Mr. Goddard promised, "more than a stone's throw from the White House."

HEADLINE: Oil Companies Shifting Exploration Overseas

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
As United States oil companies continue to cut their spending for oil exploration and the development of existing oilfields, an increasing percentage of the money that remains is being shifted to projects overseas.
A report to be released today by the American Petroleum Institute at its annual convention in Chicago shows that $5.3 billion was spent for exploration in 1992, a 29 percent decline from the $7.4 billion spent in 1991. 
 There was a huge drop in the amount for domestic exploration, which fell 44 percent to $1.8 billion -- one of the lowest levels in recent times -- from $3.2 billion in 1991. Annual spending for American exploration ranged from $3 billion to $4 billion in the 1987-91 period.
 
 
Foreign Exploration
 But spending for foreign exploration fell just 21 percent in 1992 from the year before, totaling $3.4 billion compared with $4.3 billion. As a percentage of all spending for exploration, the amount spent in foreign countries rose to 64 percent last year, up from 59 percent in 1991 and 51 percent in 1990.
The figures reflect a trend that began in the late 1980's, when oil companies began to rein in their exploration divisions. Many of these units had drilled a number of expensive wells that often came up dry.
The focus now is on areas where oil has already been found, in fields in Russia, Kazakhstan, parts of the Middle East, the Pacific Rim and Africa. And the percentage of money spent overseas is expected to rise rapidly when companies like Chevron, Amoco and Texaco gear up for huge drilling efforts in Russia that are expected to consume billions of dollars a year.
 
 
Properties and Leases
 The petroleum institute, a trade, lobbying and research group for the oil industry, also found that the share of money spent on acquiring properties and leases had shifted greatly toward foreign countries.
The report found that 14 oil companies with operations mostly in the United States -- in contrast to huge international companies like Mobil, Exxon, Texaco and Chevron -- have also shifted exploration efforts overseas.
Until 1991, for example, the 14 mostly domestic companies spent more than half of their money drilling for oil in the United States. As domestic oilfields have become less productive, these companies have spent more than half of their exploration capital in foreign countries.
The 14 domestic companies were Amerada Hess, Amoco, ARCO, Ashland Oil, Kerr-McGee, Maxus Energy, Murphy Oil, Oxy USA, Oryx Energy, Pennzoil, Phillips Petroleum, Shell Oil, Sun, and Unocal.
In the United States, large areas off the coast of California and the East Coast have been put off limits for exploration because of environmental concerns.
 
 
Occidental's Strategy
 Dave Martin, the president of the Occidental Oil and Gas Corporation, a unit of Occidental Petroleum, said in a meeting with analysts on Friday that even though it was still economical to keep drilling for oil and gas in the company's fields in the United States, more money was being sent overseas in places like Yemen, Russia and Ecuador.
Occidental expects its oil production in the United States to remain at about 61,000 barrels a day, while its output in foreign countries grows from 165,000 barrels a day to 202,000 barrels by 1995.
